Here With You Now

by kayniiine

Summary

Rio Vidal lives a quiet, quaint life on her houseboat in northern New Zealand, tending to her plants and the occasional text from her daughter, away at college.

On a day like any other day, the winding course of her path is interrupted by a woman, seemingly falling out of the sky -- and right into her lap.

What does it take to fall in love with somone? Familiarity? Time? Recognition? Rio has none of that and yet, her descent begins the moment their palms touch, and an unbelievable journey across the world unfurls in front of her.

Empty Space

I'd rather be no other place than here with you now.

*****

The warmth of the Auckland sun had begun to heat the bed chambers of the houseboat that sat on the coast of Bayswater Marina, a sure sign that it's occupant had overslept.

A soft sigh passed through slightly chapped lips as the woman in the bed sat up, arms reaching upward, pulling, tugging at the muscles that had been idle from sleep. A soft squeak of satisfaction filled the air as she settled back into the mattress, palms flush against the gentle fluff of the duvet. Bare feet touched the cool and dark hardwood floors and her eyes slid closed, the last air of sleep passing through her lungs in a light sigh.

The sound of the waves lapping against the side of the home had always brought her peace, and it was the best thing she felt she could ever wake to. Or, one of them at least.

Soft footsteps carried her to the small bathroom with the camp shower and drain sink as she peered into the mirror.

Dark but warm eyes met her, still a little cloudy with sleep, thin lines pressed into her right cheek from the folds of the pillowcase she had been laying on. Her dark hair spilled in soft but disheveled waves over the tops of her shoulders and she could tell that if she didn't tend to her drying lips, they were going to end up splitting.

Rio Vidal was a simple woman. She lived in the water, she worked from the office on her house boat, consistently working on the coding to complete the pollinating drones she had spent the last six years working on, and her daughter was coming close to closing out her senior year of university in Queenstown.

Estrella Vidal was Rio's pride and joy. She had her mother's smile, the same cheekbones and jaw. There were even days when Rio saw a reflection of her own gaze when she looked into her daughter's eyes. It had been the two of them against the world, and they had made it this far.

That wasn't to say that perhaps there weren't certain facets of Rio's life that could have been considered... a little lacking.

Although she tried to avoid the conversation every time Estee brought it up, her daughter knew she was lonely. She played it off with ease; work kept her busy, tending to the boat occupied her time, and of course she attempted to spend every waking moment with Estee when she flew home from school. She was honestly surprised that she hadn't asked outright: "When are you going to let yourself be loved?"

Although she told anyone who wasn't her daughter that asked that she didn't, she remembered the name of Estee's father, but she had buried it deep, only ever unearthing it for the only person who had a right to know.

When Estee had turned eighteen, Rio had finally decided that it was time to tell her the heartbreaking truth of how she had come to be her mother's pride and joy. Rio had been a little older than Estee was at the time, in college. There had been a party, she had left her drink unattended. She had stirred in an unfamiliar dorm, an only semi-familiar man in the bed next to her. Her body had ached, torn from the inside out, but she had forced it into motion. She had dressed herself, collected what she could find of her things, and left before he had ever even stirred.

Four months later, she found out she was pregnant.

Estee had teared up, but because she understood so many things that had been unspoken through her entire childhood. What she voiced to Rio that had bothered her the most about the entire thing was that Rio had always made it out that it had been his choice to leave, but not that it had never really been her choice to have her life flipped on its head.

As tough as it had been to have that conversation, Rio knew that it had strengthened their already iron-clad bond. Estee fully understood the extent of the lengths Rio would always go to in order to see that she had a good life. She saw her mother's sacrifice and realized that without it, she would have never existed. Rio had gotten lucky with that one, and she knew it. Estee was an incredible kid, and Rio had been told multiple times that it was all in how she had raised her; she treated her like she had always been a human being before anything else, even a child. Life was a fickle thing, and Rio hadn't taken to the idea of sugar coating pain and heartache. She wanted Estrella to understand life before it upended her own.

It really had been her biggest pride, watching her little girl grow and flourish into a young woman, watching as she made her way through uni, fighting every step of the way for her psychology degree. Sure, Rio had achieved her own triumphs, but something about watching her daughter take life head-on and win? It was even sweeter, even more to savor.

She finished brushing her teeth before she ran a hand loosely through her hair to try and tame some of the stray strands that whipped and twisted into a halo -- or crown -- atop her head.

As her feet carried her to the kitchenette, her fingertips traced gingerly over a photo of the two of them together that was pinned to the refrigerator with a magnet. She pulled the door open, a deep frown forming at what she saw on the inside: half a bottle of orange juice and half of a cucumber. Well, she had apparently forgotten that a market run had been a severe necessity. An annoyed huff of a sigh passed through her lips as she withdrew the orange juice and shut the door, making haste in pouring herself a small glass, stowing the remaining juice for another time.

She stood, poised at the edge of the dining room table as she sipped at the juice, her eyes tracing gentle lines over the view outside of the window, the other homes, the bridge that crossed over the marina, close and wondrous in structure, sometimes casting a cool afternoon shadow over her deck when the sun hit just right. Maybe that was what she would do today; she would spend the day outside. Well, after her market run, of course.

And so, she had set about her day. She watered the throngs of plants that clung to or hung from every surface available in the home. They were one of the many things she was proud of, the ones both inside and out. She changed her clothes and grabbed her keys, departing for the market.

As the sun climbed higher in the sky, it was quickly becoming another hot Auckland day, and Rio was secretly hoping that she would catch the shadow of the bridge pillar enough to enjoy some respite from the heat later.

Upon her exit from the market, her phone buzzed in her pocket as she closed the back hatch of her car and she fished it out, her smile instant at seeing a text from Estee.

"Hi, mama. This is your daily reminder that I love you. And you are a badass."

A soft chuckle passed through her lips as she made her way around to the front, sliding into the driver's seat.

"I love you too, roo," she texted back stowing her phone as she started the car.

The most arduous part of grocery shopping? Getting everything inside, hands down. By the time Rio stowed the last two items, bottles of white wine, her face was flushed and she was ready to grab a book, pour herself a glass of that wine, and spend the afternoon bathed in the hot fall day.

As it so happened, pretty much all of that had gone to plan. She had changed into shorts that were perhaps a little too short for public purview and a soft pastel green tank top, a lighter color for more reflective purposes. She hid her eyes behind a pair of aviators and pulled her hair into a messy bun atop her head.

It was what happened in the middle of her solitude that threw the outlook of her day into a blender at full speed.

She had heard her before she had seen her.

A woman's voice echoed off of the water, rising and dipping in volume as she was traversing the bridge, on the phone with someone. The alarm in Rio's eyes was masked behind the sunglasses she wore as she watched cyclists heading toward the woman. The closer they got, the more they shouted in their thick Kiwi accents, not that dissimilar to her own (though her own was only considerably a trace, tinged with her Puerto Rican upbringing). The woman looked confused, but tucked her head and kept walking.

Oh no, Rio thought, this was not going to end well.

She was on her feet, pacing over to the edge of the deck as she tucked both pinky fingers beneath her tongue. She exuded a loud whistle, which caught the woman's attention. Rio took her in for a split second; her long dark hair whipped gently in the wind behind her, her tall frame well dressed in a cream button down and waist high plum trousers. She lowered the phone, having noticed that Rio was trying to get her attention.

"Can I--?" the woman had started, but she was cut off when another cyclist came whizzing by, bumping into her. What happened next almost didn't seem real. The force of the hit, and where it was placed, sent the woman lunging forward from where she stood, with just enough momentum that she flipped over the railing and dropped about seven or eight feet into the water, her phone launching out of her hand, landing in the water a good ten feet away. Immediately, Rio rushed to the side of the deck that was closer to the bridge, pushing the gate open so that she could drop the ladder, her head lifting as she saw the woman surface.

"Is there something you wanted?!" the woman nearly shrieked as she began to tread over to where Rio was, if for no other reason than realizing it was the quickest route of escape.

Rio's lips tugged upward, stuck in something that was halfway between a smirk and a truly amused smile.

"You were walking in the bike path," she stated, holding out a hand for the other woman to take so that she could hoist her onto the deck.

As their hands clasped, the woman's expression was sheepish, realizing that she had indeed brought this upon herself.

Rio hoisted her out, taking half a step back as she gave her a once over, pressing her lips into a thin line.

"Give me a second." She disappeared inside and returned with a towel, handing it over. The woman began to dry herself to the best of her abilities, but Rio could literally see the realization hit her quickly.

"Shit," she hissed, and Rio's gaze cut to her. "I dropped my phone."

"Its okay, you can use--" she tapped her chest, where she had stowed her own phone, but it was gone. It was, she realized, at the bottom of the water, right next to the leg of the ladder from where she had leaned over to help her out.

"Well. Fuck."

The other woman's eyes widened slightly, but she did not appear to have lost much composure, despite the fact that she was soaking wet.

"Tell ya what," Rio offered, tilting her head innocently. "I can give you a change of clothes and dry those off for you. And then I can take you wherever you need to get to, if you'd like."

The stranger considered a moment, tapping a finger to her pointed chin. "You know, most people at least offer to buy me dinner before they ask me to strip down," she replied, a clear light dancing in her eyes.

The urge to fumble was strong within Rio, but what came out was far smoother than she had thought herself capable.

"Right, right. How rude of me. Would you like to join me for dinner?"

Rio almost had to ask herself who she thought she was, talking to this woman like that. Was she flirting? She couldn't even recall the last time she had done such a thing.

The woman's eyes glimmered, bright in the light of the afternoon sun.

And then, she gave her this smile, this knowing and pointed smile that said more than what rolled off of her lips. "Do you care if I rinse off? Marina water is... ugh." And then it hit Rio. The accent. This woman was American.

"No problem. The washroom is directly back and to the left. Towels are in the cabinet and help yourself to the closet, whatever is most comfortable. I'm going to head back outside, feel free to join me when you're done."

The woman offered a soft thanks, and Rio did as she stated she would, and returned outside. When the woman resurfaced a little while later (admittedly a little later than Rio had expected), there was a second wine glass and the chilled bottle sitting next to it on the table set beside Rio, another chair on the opposing side.

"Help yourself," she indicated with a flourish of her hand as she rose and took the wet clothing from the woman, hurrying inside to throw them in the dryer, turning it on. The thing was ancient, and needed replaced, but it would get the job done, albeit slowly. When she returned to the deck, the brunette was perched on the once empty chair, the now-full glass of wine in her hand.

"I... erm--" she breathed a nervous chuckle, drowning it with a gulp of the wine. "Sorry, I guess, for crashing your afternoon."

Rio shook her head. "You crashed nothing. I was just reading when I saw you in the path of an onslaught, so I thought I might be able to play hero, but I've really got to work on my timing," she teased, her eyes sparkling behind those sunglasses.

"I suppose I could have been more mindful. I guess I'm used the the world moving around me, most of the time." She snorted a soft chuckle, taking another pull from the wine glass.

Rio would admit, there was this air of confidence that seemed to encompass this woman. Even with wet hair, having just climbed out of a marina, there was just this aura about her, bright and burning hot. It was enchanting, to say the least.

"At least you got free wine out of it?" Rio posed, hiding her smile behind her own sip of the crisp liquid. Her eyes lifted, drifting over to the profile of the woman.

She was striking, truly so. Her features were sharp and pointed, yet somehow still soft in the right places. There were the lightest of lines that stemmed from the corners of her eyes, wrinkles that came for years of smiling, of laughter. Her eyes were a glimmering blue when the sun hit them just right, sparkling like the water often did at sunset. Her lips--

Woah. Woah.

Rio blinked, thankful for the protection the sunglasses on her face had to offer when it came to the look that had flashed across her dark green eyes.

What was she thinking? It was true, Rio had been alone for over twenty years. It had always just been her and Estee, and she had never once considered bringing someone else into their fold. Hell, she still wasn't, but this was the first time in an incredibly long while that she felt this unfamiliar pang in her chest. Was it--? No, it couldn't be. She had just met this woman twenty-five minutes ago. She couldn't be attracted to her.

She took another large gulp of the wine, her eyes casting out in front of her.

"Free wine never hurts. Especially when you're nursing the sting of being a complete idiot."

At this, Rio laughed, a truly delighted but gentle sound that was light and filled with a genuine joy, her head turning as she took in the sight of the woman, who she realized was looking at her, a little wry smile twisting up her lips.

"It's okay, I promise. Mistakes happen. But, to be noted, you learned your lesson, hm?" A brow hiked over the thin frame of the aviators, and the smallest smirk tugged at the corner of her mouth.

"Well, thank you," she said softly and Rio's expression loosened.

"You don't have to thank me. It was sort of my fault anyway. You were just sort of... magnetizing."

If she didn't know any better, she could have sworn that for the briefest moment, the other woman blushed. Before the moment could hold any gravitas, her voice sounded, drawing Rio's attention.

"Do you live here alone?" she asked coolly, casually.

"I do. My daughter often stays when she's not at university, but otherwise, it's just me."

She could almost hear it, the way those eyebrows shot up from across the table.

"You're old enough to have a kid in university?" she asked, the sound of her voice bordering on the edge of disbelieving. This drew a smirk from Rio, her eyes watching the water patiently, carefully. "I call shenanigans."

Another laugh slipped through Rio's lips, her head turning again. She raised a hand, palm out, and placed her other to her chest. "Honest truth!" she responded, though the grin on her face was wide. She was flattered, honestly.

"Well. I wouldn't believe it," she countered, glancing over to take Rio in, that light dancing in those gorgeous blue eyes again. "But I'll give you the benefit of the doubt."

Rio grinned again, another sip of wine landing in her stomach as she tried to quell the dull heat that had started to burn somewhere in her chest. What was she doing? Why did she feel like she had known this woman for years instead of minutes? Why did she feel like this woman could see right through her?

"What about you? Do you have kids?"

The woman gave a soft nod, a gentle expression blanketing her features. It was clear that there was an affection there.

"I have a son. He just turned twenty a few weeks ago. He's currently living in Dubai pursuing his social media empire," she informed her, though Rio could almost hear the unmuttered scoff that wanted to follow the last part of that sentence.

"And your husband?" Rio asked it before she could think it through; she was an unwed mother, it stood to reason that this woman could be too.

But the sound. That sound. It was loud, boisterous and thoroughly entertained. The laugh that escaped the brunette almost startled her, but then it warmed her. It was a beautiful sound, almost heart-stoppingly pristine in its magnificence. And then, she realized what she was laughing at. Shit.

"I divorced him ten years ago when I realized that what we wanted out of life was never going to be mutual. I'd rather be alone than sacrifice large parts of myself to make someone else happy." Her voice had started strong, but the longer she talked, the softer the tones became. Rio knew that feeling, she knew it deep in the fabric of her bones. She knew what it was like to want to hoard the good pieces of yourself for fear that giving them to someone else could break you.

The silence fell between them, a gentle understanding, but before Rio could thrum on to the next topic, the other woman's voice hit her ears.

"I've never been on one before," she commented, her gaze sweeping. "A houseboat, I mean."

Rio's smile tugged again, this time a little warmer, a little softer. "It's pretty much the same as a house. But this one's old. Needs a lot of work. And a laundry set up that isn't a half day project," she added, chuckling softly.

"So we have time, then, is what you're saying?" the other woman questioned with a brow quirked.

"It is," Rio responded.

The other woman lifted her glass. "I'll drink to that."

The rims of their glasses touched with a soft clink and both women threw back the remnants of the wine. Rio reached for the bottle, refilling her own before she held it up in question to the other woman, who held her glass out in response. Rio filled it, then set the empty bottle on the ground at the base of the table, leaning back in her own chair.

"Did you really want to stay for dinner?" Rio asked, and though she had pushed it out confidently, there was the smallest twinge of something -- hope, perhaps -- that tempered it's certainty.

Those blue eyes cast over to her and with the sun beginning its descent in the sky, the orange tones seemed to accentuate those sharp and beautiful features, elevating them to a stunning degree. There was a smile across those lips, one that was prodding, daring. Rio could almost see it in her eyes: She had suggested, but not expected the invitation.

"That depends. Can you cook?" she posed, her brow arching in curiosity.

Rio's response was immediate. "Would I be offering if I knew I'd embarrass myself?" she posed back, that smile still stuck to her face.

"Fair enough. What would be on the menu tonight, then, chef?"

She could feel it, feel the bow of this woman's confidence gliding over her, playing each string with exact precision like the fiddle that she was. Her dark eyes darted behind tinted lenses, searching her face for -- what even was she looking for? Approval? Interest? Engagement?

"It's nice enough I had planned to grill. How does steak and potatoes sound?"

She could see the delight immediately write itself across her face. "That sounds great, actually," the woman responded and Rio gave a decisive nod.

"Steak it is then."

She had excused herself to prep things and had returned ten minutes later with everything she would need, and another bottle of wine, uncorked, in one hand.

"For you, my lady," she offered with a soft laugh, one that was echoed by the woman's laughter as well. She handed over the bottle and set to work, taking only a few more moments before she closed the lid of the grill and resumed her spot on the left side of the table.

"So, you're American?" Rio posed casually, trying actively to hide the interest in her voice.

The woman nodded, that icy gaze sweeping over to her. Gods, Rio thought, she really was so beautiful.

No. Absolutely not. Stop it.

"I was born in Salem, Massachusetts, but I've lived in Los Angeles for the last thirty years." She paused, watching Rio's face, and then spoke again. "Two very different ends of the spectrum, when it comes to America. Also, two different ends of the country, too."

Rio nodded in mild understanding; she had heard of LA. It was a hub for the entertainment industry. Everyone knew that, though. Her knowledge beyond that much? Well, it was pretty limited.

"And you?" she posed, her gaze seeming to pry, to peel a little bit as it bore into her, though her own eyes were still shielded. "That accent isn't strictly here."

"I was born in Puerto Rico," she admitted, glancing down into her wine. "We moved when I was six, and I've just... never left, which was my father's intent. We left after my mother was taken from us and upon arriving, he denounced our citizenship." Rio paused, sensing that she was providing a little more detail than was necessary. "So... My whole life is here. Well, in the country. She spends the majority of her time in Queenstown."

The woman's lips curled a bit more, into something more of a smirk. "I thought I heard something else, there. It's... different. It's..." This time, her lips twisted in thought before she spoke her last word. "Beautiful."

The heat on Rio's neck was instant and she willed it away before it could manage to seep onto her cheeks. It was stupid, wasn't it? The woman wasn't calling her beautiful, just a tone or cadence she had not heard before. It wasn't about her, it was just the way she spoke.

Rio leaned back in her chair, but as she did so, she reached up, boldly removing the aviators before she set them down on the table, her dark gaze falling forward.

"So... are you here on business or pleasure?"

"Business," the woman responded, continuing, "But it's a Saturday and it was filled with meetings. I was actually on the phone with my best friend, coordinating a gin date for when I got back to the hotel when--" She flourished a hand to indicate their current situation. "Y'know," she added, as if to accentuate her point, though the way her lips slid back to reveal that beautiful smile, Rio thought it to be infectious, eliciting the same reaction from her.

"I travel a lot. Part of the job, I guess. Maybe it wouldn't kill me to be still for an evening."

The way she said it, something about it struck Rio. This woman was a shark. To stop moving would be her undoing.

"Is all of the travelling for work?" Rio posed for the sake of conversation. She knew she had no business asking these questions, thinking she would get answers, but she couldn't seem to stop herself.

"Most of it," she responded with a light shrug, an air of ease about her. "But I'm no stranger to the occasional vacation, too."

Rio's dark gaze was caught on this woman, watching the astonishment in her expression as she took in the sights, the sounds of where they were. There was mystery, there was intrigue, but there was also... just pure curiosity. Suddenly, her head turned and Rio found herself eye to eye with her since the first time she had taken off her sunglasses, and honestly? It felt like she was crystal clear, like this woman was peering right into her, right through her.

Yet, what she said when she spoke was not even a fraction of how intense that stare was.

"So, what is there to do? I'm here til Tuesday, and I did manage to only have one meeting scheduled for tomorrow. What's something I absolutely have to do before I go?"

Rio took a moment to rectify where this conversation was in her head and where it actually was, though her cool exterior never wavered.

She pondered her response for a moment. "Do you like rugby?" she asked curiously, and the smile she got was almost breathtaking.

"I do, but the All Blacks don't play until Thursday. I already checked."

"Damn. The hakas alone are worth it. That energy? Insane." Rio tapped a finger to her chin in thought, her eyes casting out toward the open sky. "If you can take the time," she started, looking back over at her. "I highly recommend the blue pools at Haast Pass. It's a little hike, nothing too crazy, but it's home to the most beautiful glacier-fed pools. It's... astonishing." There was something on her face, as she peered at Rio, that same cutting gaze that was still somehow warm and soft. It was reading her, assessing her, devouring her. She didn't speak, so Rio continued. "There's also Waikawawu Beach Tunnel. It's not as remote, but the beach is only accessible by a tunnel that was hand-carved in the 1900's. Man-made, but beautiful."

"You love it here," she commented, and Rio softened, giving a gentle nod.

"The majority of my memories are here, on that water, on the sand, in the city. It's been my night and day for most of my life. It's... my peace."

The other woman smiled, revering her with a sense of understanding that Rio could see in her eyes. There was something else there, too, something she could not quite name. Perhaps it was a sense of jealousy, but Rio saw no reason for such. Her hum drum existence, her very tiny place in the world, was worth no amount of jealousy.

A push of wind sent the scent of the grill in their direction and Rio's eyes widened a bit, having completely forgotten about the food.

"Shit!" she muttered, launching to her feet to tend to the grill. After a moment, the heat in front wasn't the only heat she was feeling. The other woman's eyes were on her, hot and searing, just watching her. She confirmed this by glancing, just briefly, over her shoulder to discover that she had been right. The heat crept up again, but this time she decided to use the guise of the grill to cover the flush on her skin.

She closed the lid and returned to her spot, plopping down a bit unceremoniously. "Another couple minutes and it should be ready," she informed her, reaching over to pick up her wine glass again.

"You're... quite nice," the woman said, causing Rio to turn her eyes toward her again, a disarming curl of her lips happening.

"I mean... there really was no other choice here. I was really bad at the hero thing, so the least I could do is dry your clothes." Her shoulders lifted, then sank, in a light shrug. It made sense to her. She considered herself kind, sure, but this was something she felt the owed this stranger.

The brunette looked like she wanted to argue, but she tempered it with a knowing smile. Perhaps too knowing. It made Rio shift slightly in her seat, and while she wouldn't admit it, the way the other woman was slowly slipping beneath her skin, it made her nervous -- but excited at the same time.

The sun was sinking further now, the oranges fading into purples and navies. She wanted to keep the conversation going, to ask questions she didn't know she had, but her mind wandered back to that grill.

That damn grill.

She excused herself once more and removed the meat from the grill, shutting it off before she made her way inside to ready their plates. It took her only a couple of moments, but before she returned, she stuck her head out the door.

"Would you like to eat out here or inside?" she posed, her tone sweet, showing that she did not care either way.

The woman's eyes swept the exterior again, as if looking for something specific. Her eyes met Rio's again across the deck.

"Do you have any lighting out here?"

Rio offered a small smile, leaning down at the base of the wall to plug in the string lights that ran around the trellis that lined the deck.

"I have a couple of candles, too, if you'd like."

"Ooh, like a date?" the woman posed, her grin wide and wicked. Rio would have never fessed up to it, but immediately, a burst of heat flared somewhere in her middle and she actively battled herself to not let it show on her face. It was an uphill battle; she hadn't been on a date since college. She hadn't felt any swell of affection in decades, for anyone that was not her child.

The other woman's stare was steely, but there was this underlying warmth that Rio could not push aside. Her lips cracked, though, parking way into a charming smile.

"Candles would be nice."

Rio was still fighting the flicker of a flame that was burning inside of her as she turned to head back inside, grabbing a couple of pillar candles and a lighter, returning to set them on the table between them. With a deft quickness, she lit them and stowed the lighter in the pocket of her shorts. She dipped back in one more time, this time returning with the plates in hand, setting them down and handing over the silverware.

The woman looked utterly enthralled, almost like she was ready to salivate at the drop of a hat.

"This looks amazing," she informed her, looking up at Rio with a gentle light in her eyes. "Thank you."

"You can say that when it doesn't turn out to have the consistency of shoe leather," she responded back with a gentle chuckle.

As it turned out, Rio knew her way around a grill. The two women ate, keeping light chatter, though it appeared as though they were wise enough to reserve the actual meat of their conversation for when it wouldn't be interrupted by chewing. The woman thanked her again as Rio rose to take the plates back inside, but she also got to her feet.

Shit. The clothes.

"We can check on the-- um, the dryer."

The sudden prospect that their time was quickly drawing to a close grabbed Rio up by the throat, giving a firm squeeze.

She wasn't ready.

The two shuffled back into the living quarters and Rio dropped the plates into the sink. "Do you need anything else?" she asked softly, as if prolonging the inevitable.

"Could I have a glass of water?" the woman asked, and Rio obliged with a nod. She pulled down a glass, filling it, and handed it over. She couldn't seem to keep her eyes off of her, watching as she took a few passive sips, but then realized she was staring and diverted her gaze.

"Let me just -- uh -- check on your clothes."

Rio glided across the floor to the laundry area, not even hearing the gentle footsteps behind her. She turned to open the door to the dryer and suddenly, the other woman was far closer than she had realized, the glass still in her hand.

It would have been so easy. She was closed enough that all Rio had to do was take half a step into her, and they'd be close enough to--

Damn it!

Rio was again fighting the flush that was trying to overtake her. She fought it, shoved it down as far as she could. Instead, she offered a nervous smile, maneuvering enough to pull the door open so that she could feel inside. Much to her heightened disappointment, they were dry.

She stood to full height and indicated the open dryer to allow the woman to pull her clothes out.

Those blue eyes studied her long and hard, and she felt so impossibly transparent, like she could see every scribbled thought in Rio's brain about how good of a time she'd had, about how badly she didn't want it to be over, about how she wanted another hour, or two, or five. Then, those eyes shifted down and hesitated a long few moments on the dryer. In one fluid motion, the woman bent over, the glass of water still in her hand, and tossed the contents of it inside of the dryer. She stood, adjusted the almost-too-tight t-shirt of Rio's she had on, and pressed the 'start' button again.

"I guess they needed a little more time."

Rio blinked up at her in astonishment. Her words seared themselves into Rio's chest, sinking into the bones of her ribcage. That hadn't been prompted, hadn't been something she would have ever asked for. More time with this stranger certainly was not something she would have objected to, but for the call to be out of her hands, and in this woman's? It made her feel good. It made her feel valuable. It made her feel wanted.

Someone had chosen her.

Something close to a smirk had graced Rio's lips. None of this made absolutely any sense, but if this woman was going to give her what she was craving in the form of more time? She wasn't going to argue with her.

"Since your water is gone..." Rio offered, her eyes flickering down to the empty glass and then back up again. "Does that mean you might like more wine?"

There was a flash, something bright and undeniable, behind those gorgeous eyes, and the grin that accompanied them. It caused Rio's heart to beat just hard enough to catch in her throat.

"I would love more wine."

The pair returned to the deck, placing themselves in the chairs they had been occupying, but a soft silence fell over them like a warm blanket. Rio turned to the right, taking in the view of the woman next to her. She was a sight, surely, in that t-shirt and those shorts that had actually belonged to Estee. Her eyes searched out over the coast, the incredulity there prevalent, even from a profile view.

"I imagine it's nothing compared to LA," Rio offered gently, pulling the woman's attention, but she didn't turn her eyes away from the sight she was beholding.

"It's different, but in a good way. LA is towering buildings with lit up windows and peeks into other worlds. And sometimes, the sunsets are amazing too. But this?" There was a sense of awe in her tone, twisting around her words as her eyes lifted to the clear sky. "The lights, they're beautiful, but it's the fact that you can have them at the same time as getting to have the stars. That will never, ever happen in LA."

Rio's gaze followed, her head tilting back as her eyes fell on the dark navy canvas, speckled with hundreds of lights.

She was quiet for a long moment, thinking, pondering, calculating. She wanted to ask something, but knew what kind of question it was.

"Can I ask you something a bit personal?" she asked, her eyes trained on the other woman, who turned to meet her eye-to eye. "With the caveat that your answer doesn't really matter one way or another, I'm just curious."

The curiosity was there, in that gaze that was boring into her, looking into the very depths of who she was. But then, a ghost of a smile graced the woman's lips.

"You absolutely can."

Rio's eyes turned out again, toward the water. "Do you... believe in God?"

She had almost expected a laugh, a bark of irritation, but was instead met with silence. She snuck a glance over and could see the answer forming behind her eyes. The way her lips twisted and the cheek closest to Rio pulled in, like she was chewing on it, piqued her interest. Being in the throes of thought looked good on her.

Thinking looked good on her?

Jesus Christ. What was wrong with her?

Fortunately, Rio seemed to tune back in at the most opportune time.

"I was raised Catholic," the woman stated, her fingertips tracing lightly over her own chin as she spoke. "It... justified a lot of shitty things that happened in our rural town. By the time I left and went to college, though? I realized something incredibly important. You cannot believe something and know it at the same time. You can absolutely believe that there is a higher power, but only because there is no way to know there is one." The woman's lips pressed together as she searched for her next words. "I know that we have one life on this one planet, and at the end of the day, we really do little more than walk each other home." Her gaze dropped into her wine glass, a soft and sad chuckle passing through her lips. "I don't know how we got here, or why we are here. One thing I do know? Life goes on, so long as we choose to keep letting it. I know that inevitably, we are our own makers. Does that make us gods?"

In that moment, Rio had sat, completely rapt by every word that was coming out of her mouth. She wasn't sure what she had been expecting when she had asked such a question, but the answer? She was a bit gobsmacked, slightly lost for words. This woman had such an undeniable eloquence to her, to everything about her. From the cadence of her tone to the way she used her hands to accentuate the words she said, it was so... divine.

Their eyes met again, and she spoke, turning the question on Rio.

"Do you?"

I could believe in you.

The thought was brief and fleeting, but it caused a prickle of electricity at the base of Rio's neck. She instead fought the urge to look away from this woman's scrutinizing gaze, holding it as she formed her answer.

"I don't know," she finally admitted. She began to ease her gaze off of her, moving it to the scene splayed out before them. "I've looked for reason in my life, spent time trying to decide if things happen for a reason, or whether it is all just harsh coincidence. I've wondered if things like pain have purpose, of if it's all just some random lottery of meaningless tragedy." She paused, glancing down into her glass, before she looked back up, still not braving to meet that icy blue gaze. "I don't know that I've ever reached a conclusion, but most days, I lean toward the latter." Her voice, while it had been soft already, dropped a little lower, a gentle hum in the night. "But I sit here, and I soak this all in..." her hand flourished to the sights before them, the home beneath them, and her sitting there right next to her, "and moments like this sure make me wonder."

Her gaze lifted and swept across that table, finding that white hot stare studying her, dissecting her, picking her apart. And then, those features smoothed, almost as smooth as the words that floated from her lips.

"Nothing wrong in having hope that the good can balance the meaningless tragedy. Be it by the natural order, or by divine intervention."

That's what this was, wasn't it? It was the universe, sticking its fingers in their lives, pushing them together, forcing them to cross paths. Destiny wasn't real, but this? It was... something.

"Maybe it does. Maybe... I just need to look for it a little more often." Rio's eyes were stuck, studying this being in front of her. This confident, bold, beautiful being that she did not want to see leave.

A heavy and thick silence fell between them; they were just learning, just looking, just studying. But then, Rio's voice came in a rushed murmur.

"You know, if you wanted to stay longer... you could have asked."

Those blue hues crackled with lightning for the briefest moment, but Rio didn't miss it.

"But we have no agenda," she returned, as if the choice had not already been made.

Rio sat back in her chair, her eyes flickering down to the remaining bit of white wine in her glass. She pursed her lips for a quick moment as she thought.

"Well," she started, tracing over her chin with the tip of her finger in thought. "We can stay out here and enjoy the evening, or I have a pretty hefty DVD collection. Disclaimer, though, a good eighty percent are nature documentaries."

At this, there was something amused that crossed the woman's features. It was playful, happy. Rio felt almost bashful at the look she was being given, but she fought herself to not let it show.

"We can go inside," the woman suggested, lifting up her own glass to drain the last bit of wine. She stood and held her hand out expectantly. Rio's eyes fell down to it, then back up to her face.

"Shouldn't I be the one to lead? It is my house," she questioned, quirking a brow.

"I've seen enough to have a good idea of where to go," she responded, and there was a fluttering in Rio's stomach, a ripple of butterfly wings tickling every inch of her ribcage from the inside. Aha, that was why it had taken her a little longer to resurfaced after her shower. She had been scoping her out.

In the world they lived in? That was fair, and honestly? It didn't bother Rio in the slightest.

She slid her palm into the other woman's this time, instead of the other way around. She let her pull her inside and toward the den, exactly where they needed to go. Inside was a small sofa, a bit outdated but comfortable enough, and a little stand that had a twenty inch television on it that was hooked up to a DVD player that came straight out of the early 2000's.

She could see the amused light flickering in the other woman's eyes, but she tried not to let it phase her. This wasn't a place she spent much time, but it was still somewhere she could relax. She indicated the stacks of DVDs and sat down on the couch.

"Guest's choice," she voiced, watching the woman as she took to the task of selecting something.

Her eyes dared to linger on the tall, muscular but slim frame of the woman. Her legs were toned and slightly tan, though smooth all the way down as they came down from the openings of the shorts. There was a gentle curve of her ass in those shorts, shorts that didn't come up high enough to meet the bottom of that damn t-shirt. There was the smallest sliver of skin, probably so warm.

Fuck. Snap out of it, Vidal.

After a moment, the brunette sat back on her heels, looking at the case in her palm. She looked up, glancing over her shoulder at Rio.

"This was filmed near here?" she asked, holding the case up to show Rio what she was referring to. It was a documentary about the wildlands that were located roughly twenty minutes up the road. She gave a slight nod accompanied by a gentle smile. She watched with interest as the woman popped it out and slid it into the tray of the DVD player. She got to her feet, placing herself on the couch next to Rio, though notably, there were a couple of inches of space between them. That was fine with Rio, honestly, because this woman had her so fucking nervous already.

And for what?

It did seem, for the time being, that she truly had been interested in the documentary. As the time wore on, though, Rio noticed that she became increasingly restless, trying to shift and stir to get comfortable. It was getting late, but she knew the dryer had at least another hour on it from the stunt she had pulled earlier.

"You can.. you know, get comfortable. It's okay," Rio assured her. They locked eyes for a moment, and it appeared as though the woman read this as a soft challenge. She shifted, pulling her legs up to curl them as she moved to her side and laid her head right in Rio's lap.

Her head was right there, laying on top of Rio's thigh.

And Rio was about to combust.

"Mmm, better," the woman mused, though her tone was rich and dark, unlike any use of it Rio had heard before. The way she spoke, the tone she used, the words she chose, it made it so infinitely difficult for Rio to not reach down, run her fingers through those soft brown locks.

It was a battle she won for all of five minutes. Almost mindlessly, her hand dropped and her fingers made a gentle sweeping motion, back and forth, as the tips of them carefully combed through her hair, soothing and sweet. Even though it was something she had not done... well, almost ever, it was almost terrifying how easy it felt to carry out.

She wasn't sure how long she had been at it, but something caught her attention: It was the softest of snores. Her eyes dropped to see the form of the woman in her lap, her chest rising and falling evenly, slowed by her slumber.

A gentle smile curled Rio's lips, but something else happened, too. There was a pang in her chest. Maybe it was of loneliness, or maybe it was of fear. She knew that in three days, this woman would be back on a plane to America and Rio would become just a memory. But damn it if she didn't want her to go.

Slowly and carefully, Rio slid herself out from beneath the woman's head, supplementing her absence with a throw pillow. She reached up and pulled the blanket off of the back of the couch and draped it over the woman's thin frame, making sure she was completely covered. With that, she turned on her heel and made her way to her own room, changing out of her day clothes and into a pair of pajamas, which didn't look much different. As she climbed into bed and laid her head down on the pillow, she knew that sleep was going to be an elusive entity that night, and she had been right.

She woke with the sun as it clawed it's way over the horizon; glancing over at the clock, she realized she'd only been asleep for an hour. Well, today was surely going to call for a nap. She sat up and rubbed at her eyes, the weight of the previous day settling in over her.

Shit.

There was still someone in her house. Or, at least, she hoped there was. She was quiet as she threw back the duvet and scrambled to her feet, tiptoeing out into the rest of the house. As she reached the den, the warmth returned to see the woman still asleep on the couch.

She had stayed.

Rio busied herself with pulling the now truly dry clothes out and folding them before she left them on the small coffee table in the den, there for her whenever she woke up. She knew that she needed to keep busy, in order not to fixate, but she had no clue what to do. So, she took to the kitchen, cleaning up the dishes from the night before, and then decided on brewing a pot of coffee. Halfway through that, she decided on pulling out eggs and bacon, setting to work on making a quick breakfast for the two of them.

She was halfway through her task when she heard a soft shuffling behind her. Her head lifted and her warm and sweet smile was instantaneous. There she was, dressed so smartly in that blouse and those trousers. Her hair cascaded down her shoulders in loose waves.

Gods. What a vision.

"Good morning," the woman greeted.

"Good morning. Coffee's on if you want some. And I'm making eggs and bacon," she informed her, though there was an underhanded offer in there, an unspoken request for just a little more time.

Rio could sense the rejection coming, though, from about a mile out.

"I really should get going. I am sure there at least a few concerned people waiting to hear from me," she explained, and Rio could feel herself deflate inwardly, though she didn't let it touch her exterior. "But thank you, this has all been so kind of you, -- uh..." she trailed, a flash of panic in her eyes.

In an instant, the same flash mirrored in Rio's eyes. She froze, though, and the words came spilling out, breaking the dam of her nerves before she could think to stop them.

"It was my pleasure, really, -- er..."

And then, there it was. A silent agrement between the two of them: This had been a night, one that had been nearly tangible in its excitement, but that was all it was ever destined to be.

Just a night, where two strangers who did not even know one another's names, simply enjoyed one another's company.

The woman hesitated, just for a moment, and took a step that Rio thought was going to carry her toward the door, not toward her instead. She was suddenly right there, their fronts brushing ever so slightly. Both of her warm palms raised and slid to the curves of Rio's jaw, holding her face as if it were fragile glass. They eyes met, those blue irises staring into the deepest parts of her for the split second she stood still. And then, she felt the tug, the pull that was asking her to come halfway.

She caved, leaning in toward the other woman as their lips brushed, first, almost barely, and then met full on in a warm kiss that seemed to tangle its way through every inch of Rio's body. It was warm in its inception, but the seconds ticked on and the heat started to rise --

And then, suddenly, cold. No warmth, no skin. Just cold air.

But, it was only because the woman had been holding her breath. She exhaled, her warm breath on Rio's face, their foreheads barely brushing.

"Thank you," she breathed. Her eyes flickered open, beholding Rio at close range.

She could almost feel it, the fight within the other woman, but she let Rio go, and Rio's heart sank at the same time, in sync with the other woman's hands.

Rio offered her a tight, if not sad, smile, and gave a nod of understanding. She watched as the woman turned, making her way to the front door. She stopped, though, and for one fleeting moment, Rio thought she might stay.

But then she spoke.

"I won't forget you."

Rio's gaze was unwavering as the door closed behind the woman, and closed on any hopes that she might have found an actual connection with another human being.

The sting felt more like a burn and it was instant, flaring in every last nerve she had. Her chin dropped and she exhaled a quiet sigh, her teeth digging softly into her bottom lip.

"You might. But I won't."

Heart Down Low

Spent the night alone in your company.
Your body is a TV screen.

*****

That nap Rio had been so intent on taking when her guest from the night before had left? It had never happened. Instead, she had picked at the bacon and eggs she had cooked, spending the majority of her time pushing it around the plate. For as hungry, genuinely hungry, as she had been before that woman had walked into her kitchen and out of her life, she now could hardly stomach the idea of putting another bite in her mouth.

She had tried to tidy up; she put the throw pillow back where it belonged and folded the blanket back up so that she could drape it across the back of the couch as it had been before she had stormed in and flipped everything Rio had thought she'd known on its head.

Every time she thought about it, part of her was a little indignant. She was upset with herself. She had made no move, at the woman's prompting, to introduce herself. By a general rule of thumb, then, she could not rightfully be upset over the fact that the woman had not offered her name, either. It had been a mutual mastery of the situation, a grasp that they lived two different lives. In fact, she had no idea what the woman did for work that had brought her to the reaches of New Zealand. Then again, it wasn't like she had offered her own profession up for discussion.

There had seemingly been more important things to talk about.

That stupid conversation about religion kept replaying in her brain. She could see it, projecting on the front of her skull, a vivid memory as she had watched the other woman as she had provided her answer.

She had locked every hand wave, every gesture, every tone shift into her head like it was a treasure, coveted by all who sailed the seven seas. It was her treasure. Her stash, one that no one else got to see or touch. It was a memory, something for her to cling to when she needed to recall something that would make her feel the edge of life again.

She turned, looking down at the folded t-shirt and sleep shorts she had lent to her the night before sitting on the coffee table.

Why couldn't she have taken them? It would have given her an excuse to come back.

Rio cursed herself for such a line of thought. That would have had to mean that the other woman would have seen last night with the same value Rio did. Judging by the fact that she had left, and not given her even an inkling of how she might find her? Well, Rio was of the very clear opinion that some people did not want to be found. Some people walked away because they never looked back.

It was discouraging, but she was quickly climbing to the realization that this was something she would have to let go.

She tried. She really did.

But she was... everywhere.

When she had finished picking up and cleaning up her failed attempt at breakfast, she realized that there was a very important task she had needed to handle. She grabbed her keys, climbed into the car and made her way into the city to the mobile shop in order to replace the phone she had dropped when helping that woman out of the water. It had taken a little over an hour, and she went straight back home, both feeling like she wasn't out long enough and also like she couldn't get there fast enough.

There, she could live in the remnants.

There, she could hold onto that magic.

After a brief period of setting up her phone, she had headed to the deck, picking up her book. She opened it, her fingertips gliding over the edges of the pages that remained for her to read. And again, she tried. She started to read, and then, five minutes later, she was re-reading the same paragraph for the twelfth time, still having absolutely no clue what it said.

Her palms on either side of the cover pressed inward and the book closed with a tight snap that wasn't quite as loud as her frustrated grunt. She had started to set the book down on the table, but hesitated only a moment as her phone began to ring. She made the exchange, setting the book down to pick up her phone, her lips curling up warmly at the sight of the name on the screen.

"Hey, roo," she cooed gently, leaning back into the chair, tilting her head back in the sunlight.

"Hi, mama!" Estee's tone was bright and it made Rio's heart squeeze in her chest. "I was just calling to make sure that you were still going to be able to pick me up Saturday! My flight should be in about eight that morning."

"Of course, baby. I've been counting down the days. Did you get the money I sent you?" Rio's voice was smooth and gentle, strongly affectionate. It would have been clear to anyone that would have looked in on her life from the outside that the most important thing in her entire life was that young woman.

She could hear Estee roll her eyes, even over the phone.

"Yes, mama, but I told you that you didn't have to do that."

Rio could hear the admonishment in her daughter's tone, but it just caused her to smile, bright and wide.

"Let me take care of you, yeah? One day the roles will be reversed," she reminded her with a laugh.

"And that's the one reason you won't be going into a care home," Estee responded, to which Rio delivered a dramatic gasp. "Hey! I said you won't!"

Rio laughed again, truly tickled and amused. That girl was her lifeblood.

"So... anything exciting happening lately?" Rio could hear it in Estee's tone; she was fishing. And this one time? Maybe Rio would offer a bite.

"I need to go back to the market," she stated offhandedly, as though Estrella was not entirely aware that she had been the day before.

"What did you forget?" Estee shot back, a thin line of anticipation winding its way around her words.

"Nothing. I just... had a dinner guest."

At this, Estrella was unable to hold in her gasp.

"Mama! What?!"

Rio was red instantly, her thoughts back on that mysterious, alluring, beautiful, sexy woman.

"Spill!"

Rio's lips twisted as her free hand picked at the hem of her shorts nervously. This was a first. In twenty one years, it was the very first time she had anyone, or anything, to talk about in this manner with her daughter.

"I was outside reading yesterday after I got back, and I heard someone up on the bridge. A lot of the bikers were shouting, but the woman kept walking."

There was a quiet interest on the other end of the line; Estee was already hanging on every word.

"I whistled at her and as I got her attention, a cyclist bumped into her... and ay dios mio! She fell right into the marina!"

"Mama! You're lying!" She could hear it, that hike that she had never heard before. She could hear the excitement, hear the thrill that this was bringing to her little girl.

"She swam over and I let her on the deck. She lost her phone, and I dropped mine when I went to help her out. Just got it replaced a little bit ago."

Estee was giggling, a pure and raw sound that often made Rio's heart thud a little harder in her chest. It was everything.

"So, I got her a towel and offered to dry her clothes. In that five hundred year old dryer."

"Mama, no," Estee gushed, the giggles overtaking her again.

"We had some wine, I grilled us some steaks. We, uh... ended up watching a movie."

"Okay, okay. Now that's bordering on too much information," her daughter countered, but she couldn't help but roll her eyes.

"No, silly. We watched that documentary that was filmed in the wildlands. Well, we were watching it, until she fell asleep."

There was measured silence, surely as Estee was trying to decide if her mother was telling her the whole truth, which she almost immediately had decided she wasn't.

"So are you going to see her again?" she asked, and Rio could already feel the wave of her disappointment rushing in to shore.

"No, roo. She left this morning before breakfast was done. She... didn't tell me her name."

"Oh no."

Rio's lips pressed into a thin line and her fingers picked even harder at the fraying edges of the short. She had really fucked things up for herself, hadn't she?

"It's okay, baby. It was a good night. I forgot what it was like to sit down with another adult and have a conversation about anything other than the coding algorithms it takes to make a pinto bean sized drone fly."

"Mama?" Estee spoke, her voice soft.

"Yes, baby?"

"You're a fuckin' nerd."

Their laughter was an echo on either side of the line and they spoke for a few more moments about random odds and ends until Estee had announced that she needed to head to class. Rio had told her she loved her, that she would see her on the weekend, and that they would buy extra champagne for their annual Oscar viewing party, which elicited a squeal of delight from the younger girl.

"Te amo, mama."

Every time she heard those words, she could feel the warmth, like the same warmth she would get every single time Estee wrapped her little arms around her from the time she was a toddler until most recently as of two months ago.

The words were enough sometimes.

They mattered.

"Te veo, mija."

There were times, especially on days like that one, where Rio just wished that her daughter was closer. She was feeling the acute sting of loneliness in a way that she had never before dared to let herself feel. She was closed off and guarded for this very reason. She was lonely by choice, she told herself. Or, at least, she had been. It had been her decision to not pursue relationships, to not seek out companionship. She had all she needed in the two of them.

Now?

Now, she had this deep rooted, rotting ache in her middle, one that told her this was the first time she had ever wanted something like this. Now, she knew what it was like to want something and have absolutely no way of attaining it.

The passing two days, they had been filled with an agonizing sense of restlessness. No matter what Rio did, her mind often wandered. She thought about the woman, about her smile, her eyes, her laugh.

She thought about that kiss. Gods, what it was like to feel that way for the first time in so long. The pulse pounding, the warm heat that pooled so briefly in the pit of her stomach, the weakness in her knees, it was all etched into her grey matter, scarred deep within her brain tissue.

She thought about the sound of her voice, smooth like velvet and intentional in her usage of tone. She spoke with forethought, with a plan on her delivery.

That woman knew her words mattered.

The two empty bottles of wine had sat at the foot of the table for the first day before she finally had the courage to dispose of that memory, too.

Tuesday had rolled around and as she tried to move about her day, something kept whispering in the back of Rio's mind.

She was leaving, going back to America.

Her fingers hovered over the keys of her computer, her eyes staring blankly into the screen ahead of her, the coding completely jumbled as she tried to process it.

She couldn't do it anymore. She'd waited two days, hoping she might come back. She never did, though. Sitting around acting like she would? It wasn't doing Rio any good. So, to combat the sting, she shut off her computer and changed into a swim suit, two pieces, and threw a few things into a beach bag. If she couldn't escape her by sitting around, she would go out in an attempt to drown the memory from the depths of her mind.

It had been enjoyable enough; the sun had been warm and the water had been cool and refreshing in a way she had not allowed herself to enjoy in some time.

The weight of life sometimes felt a little too heavy, and in the passing days, the weight of Rio's loneliness had started to crush her. The worst part about all of it was that there really wasn't a remedy here. There was no possible way that she would ever see her again, and she had absolutely zero interest in throwing herself into any kind of dating pool; that had never changed. What had changed was that she now knew she was capable of attraction, it just happened that she found herself attracted to completely the wrong person. She had let one person in close enough to develop even the smallest bond, and then she had blown it all to pieces because she couldn't help but to speak before she thought about what she was going to say.

"Damnit," she hissed under her breath, reaching up to adjust the sunglasses on her face. Her skin was warm and tan from the hours she had spent in the sun, but it hadn't helped in her main goal of distancing herself from that night. Instead, she was coming to the realization that she could do her best to outrun every thought of the woman, but there was absolutely nowhere that she was going to find to hide.

There was an air of indignance about her as she got up and gathered her things, heading back to the car, not wanting to go home quite yet but knowing it was the only destination. She heaved a sigh and started the drive back, though the closer she got, something in her tugged. It pulled, it nagged, it begged her to go a different way. She had ended up on the other side of the marina, and just as she asked herself what she was doing there, her eyes lifted and she saw it.

The bridge.

She hesitated only a moment before she cut the engine and pulled the keys. She climbed out and with even, measured steps, she paced toward the opening of the bridge, starting to cross it, though she was on the correct side. She reached that point, the one she could still see so clearly in her head. She looked both ways and stepped forward, her eyes casting down onto the marina, then drifting to her own home. This was the last vantage point the woman had seen before she had toppled into Rio's life and made her question far more than she was comfortable with. This was the sight, the last glimpse of what Rio had looked like before her white hot existence had set Rio's world alight.

Her lips pressed firm and she breathed a light sigh out of her nose. She needed to go home. She needed to sleep, something she hadn't done in a while.

She climbed back into her car and made the short trip around the marina, pulling into the lot that was a small walk away from her home. As she approached the walkway, something caught her eye. There, hanging on a rogue nail that stuck out of the docking post and glimmering in the setting sun was an earring.

It wasn't just any earring.

It was her earring.

Rio's breath hitched in her chest and she reached out, though she pulled her hand back before her fingertips made contact with the black and silver dangle. It wasn't going to bite her, but the fact that it was there in the first place was enough to sting. How? She had been back and forth a few times in the passing days, and she knew it hadn't been there. She slid it off the nail and held it in her palm, almost afraid that if she held it too tight, it might shatter like an illusion. It was there, though, really there. It was right there.

Why was it there, though? The safest explanation, and the one Rio knew she had to cling to was that she had lost it. Someone had spotted it near the post and put it up to make sure it was seen. It was just a trinket that had been forgotten about.

Like me.

She had let herself fixate for a few hours, but ultimately had placed the lone earring in her jewelry box and shut the drawer. If she put it out of sight, it might lend to letting her stop thinking about her a little sooner.

The rest of the week had carried on, and by the time Rio found herself driving to the airport to pick up Estee, she had almost managed to push the woman from the weekend before completely out of her head.

Almost.

She had been surprised at the lack of push she'd gotten from Estee once she had gotten in the car; she'd expected her to give her the third degree, to rake her over the coals about the weekend before, about the nameless woman that seemed to have deeply unsettled her. Instead, she had been almost too affectionate. She talked about wanting to do things on her break that they hadn't done since she was little; she wanted the zoo, wanted to bake, wanted to go to the beach. By the time she suggested getting sushi -- which Rio knew she hated -- the jig was up.

"Alright," Rio voiced, flipping down the indicator for her turn signal. "What is going on with you?" She looked to her left, taking Estee in measuredly as they sat at the red light. She looked... sheepish?

"Nothing, mama. I just... want to keep you busy."

Rio balked slightly, blinking at her daughter. What was that supposed to mean?

"Whatever happened that night... you've been different." Estee's eyes widened as Rio's head jerked back slightly, her brow furrowed in distaste. "Not bad different, just... Sad."

Rio's lips twitched downward in the pull of a frown.

"She really did something to you, didn't she?"

While Rio had always been rather open and honest with Estrella, there were just certain things that she had never learned to talk about. Any kind of romantic feelings? Well, those were right at the top of the list.

"That's just it..." Rio started, pressing the gas hard enough to make their turn. She pressed her lips together, her grip tightening a little on the steering wheel. "She didn't... really do anything. She was..." she blew out a soft puff of air, knowing there weren't words. "I just... I wish that if she knew she wasn't going to come back, she wouldn't have kissed me."

In the blink of an eye, Estee's arm flew out and grabbed Rio's, her eyes wide and wild as she took in her mother.

"MOM!" she exclaimed, the use of the word causing uncomfortable goosebumps to sheet Rio's skin. She hated it when she called her mom. "You guys kissed?!"

At this, Rio could no longer fight the small satisfied grin that wanted to overtake her lips. She let it. "I mean... she kissed me, but yeah."

"Way to really bury the lead there, mama," Estee chastised, and Rio offered a soft laugh in response. Surely, there was more to unpack there, but for the time being, Estrella knew to let it be.

The weekend seemed to fly by; they went shopping, had a meal out, got ice cream. The two of them walked down the beach as the sun was setting in the sky, and by the time they retired, Rio had realized that she had hardly thought about her since her earlier conversation with Estee, and she felt a little proud. Of course, this devolved into diving right back into those memories, but the few hour long run had been a triumph in its own right.

Sunday was slow and lazy for them; she made them pancakes and they lounged around most of the afternoon, reading on the deck for the most part. The evening started to roll around and Rio couldn't ignore the excitement that had been bubbling in her daughter for the last few hours. She had pulled down the popcorn, threw it into the pan and put a lid over it, a waiting game until it was finished.

Estee pulled out a bottle of the champagne Rio had bought and artfully popped the cork before she filled the two flutes Rio had set out for them. Maybe the tradition was silly, but it was something they had done since Estee was just a kid.

"Any personal favorites you're rooting for this year?" Rio posed, pulling her own flute in front of her.

"There's one that came out a few months ago... God, I can't for the life of me remember what it's called. It's about the same crime happening in exactly the same place four times over a century. I've heard it's really good, and is leading the pack."

Rio plucked a piece of popcorn off the top of the finished pile and popped it into her mouth. "Hm," she hummed, chewing as she dumped the popcorn into a large bowl for the two of them to share. "Sounds interesting."

They had missed most of the red carpet, but she didn't mind. Instead, they settled into the couch, watching the Oscar awards on that twenty inch TV. Best Director was up and for a brief moment as they announced the nominees, Rio's attention pulled to her phone.

"That's the one I was talking about," Estee divulged, but Rio glanced up only for a moment, her eyes falling back down.

She scrolled for another moment and dismissed the email, locking her phone as they announced the winner.

"And the Oscar goes to... Agatha Harkness for 'The Travelers.'"

As if something reached beneath her chin and pulled her gaze up, Rio's eyes fell on the television.

She froze.

No breath, no beat of her heart.

No fucking way.

There she stood, even far more elegant than Rio would have ever given her credit for from memory. She was clad in a breathtaking purple dress -- what an amazing color on her -- that shimmered in the right light. Her hair was curled in loose ringlets and her makeup made her look even more beautiful, which Rio had been convinced had not been possible. That woman had been flawless, covered head to toe in ocean water, and yet, in that moment, on that television screen?

She was a deity to be worshipped.

"Mama?"

There was no fucking way. Not in any universe could this be happening.

"Estrella," Rio managed, her tone tight and strangled.

"Mama, are you okay?"

"That's her," she breathed, but Estee didn't make the correlation.

"Yeah, mama, that's the director of the film I was telling you about."

Rio's head shook, her skin flushed and sweltering under the new found heat of realization.

"No, no. I mean... that's her. That's the woman that fell into the marina."

Estee blinked at her, clearly trying to read her, trying to decide if her mother was completely and utterly fucking with her.

"You're serious?" she asked for clarification, her green eyes searching her mother's face as if she might find any indication that she was not being honest.

But she was.

Rio nodded, swallowing down the rock in her throat.

No wonder she hadn't wanted her to know her name.

She was Agatha Fucking Harkness.

Rio didn't need much more knowledge than she already had to know that what had happened? It was cemented into memory, solidified into being something she would never have again.

Rio was just... Rio.

And Agatha Harkness? She was a renowned film director, her life thriving in the hustle and bustle of LA.

While Agatha was a memory for her, she knew that she would have been considered lucky to have been given a second thought by the other woman.

It all made so much more sense, now.

They weren't just on different pages, they lived on entirely different planets.

Eventually, Rio would move on. For now? This felt like a wound that she needed to take the time to lick.

Gut Rot

Oh, it hurts too much.
So call me out for not having the guts.

*****

For one single, solitary moment in her life, Rio had wished that Estee was back at school. What had followed her revelation had been an absolute grilling. Most of it, she had managed to dodge, but she gave up enough to assure Estee that she had been telling the truth.

Just enough.

There was still a secret she had been keeping close to the vest, one she failed to mention even over the course of the next two weeks.

She still had that earring.

She knew it was foolish; she was still primarily convinced that it had been a lost item, that someone had seen it, realized it was close to her home, and put it where they knew someone would inevitably find it. There could be no other explanation, no clear line of reasoning, and Rio refused to let her mind get carried away with extremely unlikely scenarios.

So, she simply didn't mention it.

She instead chose to enjoy the break with her daughter, doing the things she had asked, like making a trip to the zoo, going out to surf on a couple of mornings. It was good, quality time. There were sometimes moments when she would catch Estee's stare, the way she watched her with deft cunning, a silent but wise observance. Rio had ignored it, for the most part, and continued to prattle on about whatever it was they had been discussing. She saw it, though. She knew it was there.

She was thankful enough that she wasn't as inquisitive for the rest of her time as she had been that first night, but there was a strange crackling in the air as she drove them back to the airport so that Estee could finish her final semester. They usually held conversation in the majority of the time they spent together, but this ride was turning out to be uncomfortably quiet.

At last, Rio couldn't take it anymore.

"What's going on?" she posed, and while the question was direct, the delivery was soft and tame, tempered to be understanding.

Estee's lips worried together, her gaze shifting over to her mother.

"I think you should go to America."

Rio's reaction, it was completely automatic, an utter knee-jerk reaction.

She laughed. It was a bellowing, hearty, surprised almost-cackle that she had never heard from herself before. She glanced over at Estee, as if she would be laughing just as hard, like it was the funniest thing in the world.

She wasn't, though. In fact, she looked a little off-put by the reaction.

"Oh. You're not kidding."

Estee's stare was straight ahead out the window, her fingers beginning to fidget in her lap, her lips turned down at the corners. As Rio looked over again, though, she saw something else. Something... mischievous.

"Estrella Liliana Vidal," Rio dared, stealing another glance while still trying to focus on driving. "What did you do?"

Estee glanced over at her from the corner of her eye and looked back down at something she was pulling up on her phone.

"She has an office in LA."

"Estee," Rio scoffed, rolling her eyes. "Stop it."

"There's something you're not telling me."

At this, Rio's brow pulled tight. She had tried very hard not to lie to her child, and so there were times that she felt withholding the truth was the best option. Her personal life, the first one she'd had in two decades, was on that list.

"I found her earring. Hanging on the post by the dock." There was a tinge of defeat in Rio's tone. Clearly, it was something she hadn't stopped thinking about, something that was consuming her whole.

"Mama..." Estee breathed, a light flickering in her eyes, although her mother was not looking at her.

"She just lost it. Someone found it, hung it on the post. It's really that simple." Even as she was speaking, she could literally hear the lack of conviction in her own voice. She wanted it to be for any other reason, wanted it to be a calling card, a lifeline. She knew that she had to remain realistic.

She was a tech developer who lived her life on a boat.

Agatha Harkness was Hollywood royalty.

For a day, they had been quite the pair, but it had never been destined to see another sunset.

"Can I ask you something? And I think that whatever the answer to this question is will answer whether or not you should go."

There was an entire mask of uncertainty that seemed to cross Rio's face as she understood the permission her daughter was seeking. She glanced over, that beautiful little face, and had a feeling that she was about to completely throttle her life view. She nodded, offering the acceptance she had been looking for.

"Did the earring have the back on it?"

It was stunning, the rate of speed at which realization slammed into her. Rio almost lost her breath, but instead, she forced herself to blink, to recall what that earring looked like in her palm, the small rubber backing around the curve.

She swallowed down the rock that had formed in her throat and gave a gentle nod.

"It did."

She didn't have to look over to know that Estee was wearing a very satisfied smirk. She knew that maybe her mother wasn't going to give in right away, but this realization? Well, it might give her a nudge in the right direction.

Damn it. Why did they have to have this conversation right before they spent another five weeks apart?

Rio parked and got out with her daughter, following her inside of the airport. She stood by as she watched her check in, not failing to somehow get the attendant to smile and even laugh.

That girl was a ray of light.

As she pulled away, Rio met her and nodded her head toward TSA. They walked and she could practically hear the gears turning in the girl's head. They reached the end of the line and Rio turned to her daughter, not hesitating to pull her into a warm and firm hug. She held her close, taking in the feel of her in her arms, the way her shampoo smelled. They were the little things she would hold onto in her absence, the things that would make her feel a little less lonely.

She relinquished her hold and stood back up to full height, looking down on her beautiful girl. She had almost started to raise her hand to touch her cheek, but Estee beat her to the punch, both of her palms coming up to cup Rio's cheeks.

"Think about it. I can send you the address. But... I think she might want her earring back."

Rio could feel the heat on her neck; she knew she really only had one choice, here.

"I'll think about it, mija." She leaned forward and pressed her lips softly to Estrella's forehead.

The younger woman threw her arms around her mother's neck, squeezing her tight, so similar to how she had once done as a little girl.

"Te amo, mama."

"Te veo, mija."

They separated and Rio gave her hand a soft squeeze, letting her hand go so that she could depart. Rio did not move, though, just watched as she went through security until she had walked out of sight, right before she glanced over her shoulder and offered her mother one last wave.

And there it went, the part of Rio that often kept her sane and rational.

The drive home was hard, and it was even harder returning back to her empty house after having her daughter's company for two weeks. She missed her sorely already, but her words were still ringing in Rio's head.

I think you should go to America.

America was a big place. A really fucking big place. Yes, she knew that Agatha was somewhere in LA, and she was even more acutely aware of the fact that Estrella had gone out of her way to track down where this woman's office was, but it was wild. It was unrealistic. It was stupid. There was absolutely zero sense in the idea of getting on a plane to California to, what? Show up at this office building and, as a literal no one, beg for a moment of this woman's attention? Telling anyone who she was would mean nothing -- Agatha did not even know her name.
