She had been turning over the conversation, and over the message that had apparently been left for her. It was a screaming, waving attempt at saying I was here! I didn't forget!

Something about reflecting on it made Rio's middle molten hot, melting at the mere idea of seeing her again.

No, it was literally insane.

It was the stuff of movies.

It wasn't real life.

She set her keys down on the counter, sighing softly as a hand ran idly through her hair. Her eyes scanned over her apartment, tracing along the throngs of plants, vibrant and green in their nature.

And then it caught her eye. There, tucked among the leaves of a devil's ivy plant was a post-it note -- purple, per the ones Estee had picked out -- folded into a flower.

She was still for a long moment, staring hard as if it might disappear. She had watered those plants multiple times and somehow, she had missed it. In fact, it didn't even look like a drop of water had ever even touched it. She moved forward, reaching out with a feather light touch as she plucked it from between the leaves and pulled it close. Gently and carefully, she worked to unfold it, her heart thudding loudly between her ears.

What were the chances there was even anything inside?

It was flat beneath her palm, vibrating with all of the energy of potential, of what could have been, or maybe even what could be. She lifted her hand and glanced down at the piece of paper.

What a soft place to land.

The scrawl was neat and tidy; it did not belong to her, and she knew for a fact it did not belong to Estee. Something in her chest caught, and for a moment, Rio forgot how to breathe. She had already been convinced that Agatha's presence would haunt her home for the foreseeable future, but she had not expected such a blatant show.

For as good as she had been doing about not devolving into the complete spiral that was that stupid night she had spent with Agatha Harkness, it was all suddenly out the door.

Maybe Estee was right.

But it was still completely idiotic, bordering on kamikaze... right?

She was no one, and she was going to come across as some insane stalker, begging for the attention of one of Hollywood's biggest names. She had just won a fucking Oscar for chrissakes. And what? She thought she would actually get anywhere by showing up?

She pushed a defeated sigh through her nose, turning to head toward her bedroom. She paced inside and toward the closet, thumbing through the clothes to decide what to pull on after her shower. She settled on an olive green t-shirt and a pair of comfortable beige sweatpants and headed into the bathroom.

While she had always preferred hot showers, the one she stepped into might have been too much for every day Rio. That day, though? She needed the heat, needed to feel that burn on her skin to force her into the mentality of making tough calls. She knew she was being a complete fool, but she couldn't stop thinking about it, especially after finding the note.

She knew it didn't technically mean anything, that it was probably just the musings of a grateful woman, but in the same turn of thought, she knew that thinking that way? Well, perhaps she was being more foolish than she had given herself credit for.

What reason on earth could she have had for doing it? And how had it turned up today, of all days?

She shut the shower off and stepped out, toweling down before she pulled on her clothes. She tried to float about her evening, tending to a meal, and trying to watch a movie, but her mind kept drifting. By the time she made her way to bed, her eyes fell on the side table, the purple square of paper still laying, message side up. She picked it up, looking down at it in the light. She glanced up at the ceiling, blinking back the emotion welling in her chest.

She set the note down and turned off the light, lifting up her phone to unlock the screen as she climbed into bed. She stared at it for a long moment, something bubbling up in her chest. After minutes of hesitation, and several taps to keep the screen on her phone from falling asleep, she pulled up her travel app and began to search.

She spent a good thirty minutes finding the right flight, and a hotel that seemed like it would be nice enough if she ended up a) not finding her, or b) getting turned away. She booked without a return ticket; if this worked out, she had no clue how long she would want to stay and if it didn't? Well, she also had no clue how long she could stand to stay after that.

Her last step was booking the Uber to take her to the airport. She submitted and sat back, her eyes darting over the phone in front of her.

Was she really doing this?

She was really doing this.

She pressed her lips together and pulled up the contact list, dialing out to Estee. It rang only twice before Estee's tired voice came over the line.

"Mama? Estas bien?" she murmured in that sleepy tone, like Rio had pulled her straight from a hard slumber.

"Si, si, mija. I... You were right. I'm going to go."

"What?" Estrella breathed, the disbelief nearly tangible in her tone of voice. Rio knew it would throw her, but she also figured she had a right to know.

"My uber picks me up at one and my flight leaves at three thirty tomorrow," she divulged softly. She knew she was being an idiot, but... something was pulling her. Something she could no longer ignore.

"What changed?" Estee asked in a soft murmur.

"She left me a flower."

"You found it, then?"

Rio balked, stammering for a moment as she tried to catch up.

"You knew?"

"I found it on the floor this morning. I put it in the devil's ivy because I know it's your favorite." Estee paused for a moment, breathing a gentle sigh. "I'm glad you did."

"Me too, kid." Rio responded in a soft voice. She hesitated a moment, humming softly in thought. "I'll text you before takeoff, yeah? Get some sleep, mija."

"Mmmk mama. Te amo," she murmured, clearly giving in again to the pull of sleep.

"I love you too, roo," she breathed before the line clicked and she was left alone again.

Alone with the gravity of her decisions.

By the time the next afternoon rolled around, she stared at her phone, her eyes fixed on the cancel button on the Uber. Sure, she would lose out on the cost of the cancelled flight, but wouldn't it be better that way? Wouldn't it be better than completely embarrassing herself? This was a fool's errand, and she was flying thousands of miles to see it out. She was... completely out of her mind.

It was almost as if for the next fifteen hours, she completely blacked out. There were fleeting, flashing memories of the flight, of the layover. There were little blips, weaving in and out, but before she fully understood the depth of her journey, she was exiting the plane in the throes of LAX, her duffel bag slung over her shoulder.

It didn't seem real. Was she really there, in America? In California? In LA?

Was she really in the same city as Agatha Harkness?

As she pulled up her phone and ordered another Uber, she tried to map out a plan in her head. It was probably best to head to the hotel first, check in and gain her bearings. It couldn't be the worst idea to try and work through her nerves before she made the plunge into searching out someone who probably didn't even remember her.

So, she slid into the back of the car as it arrived and drove her to her destination. The hotel was beautiful; it was called The Freehand and the architecture, coupled with the art? It was a breathtaking sight, and she gave herself a mental pat on the back for having the sense to at least pick somewhere that was worth spending her time. The bar was a nice touch, too, and she was almost certain she would be spending some of her time there.

Rio Vidal in the big city. Wasn't this a fucking joke?

She had spent a few minutes in a text exchange with Estee, letting her know she had arrived safe and also informing her that she had no direct plan on how to tackle this.

"Just show up. Wing it from there."

Sage advice from her twenty-one year old daughter, she supposed.

She had put her phone down and moved over to the window, taking in the sights of a brand new city, a brand new country. It truly was beautiful, in an incredibly different way than she was used to at home. She checked the time; it was edging on 1pm -- oof, that time change was already kicking her ass. Well, no better time than the present, right?

She pulled up the address on the screenshot Estee had sent her, punching it into the Uber app, requesting a car. She had paced, anxiously, as she waited for it to show up. She was so nervous, nearly crawling out of her skin. The same thoughts kept repeating: What are you doing? Are you insane? This is awful. What are you thinking?

The car pulled up in front of the towering office building, the glass sheeting up the sides in a shimmering display of power, of money, of status.

The hammering of Rio's heart? It was a complete thunderstorm in her ears, a rapid repetition of crashing and thumping. This was never going to work.

This was a suicide mission.

She climbed out of the car and bravely found her feet carrying herself up the concrete steps that led to the walkway of the building. She had thought this through up until the point she crossed the threshold into that building.

The next forty minutes, she had been tasked with trying to barter with security, though every single attempt was futile. They asked her name, and she had given it willingly, but she knew it wouldn't matter. Agatha didn't know her like that. She knew that if she pushed any harder, security's next call was likely going to be to the police. He had let slip, at one point, that she wasn't in, but Rio had taken it as something said to deflect from her persistence.

Honestly, as she finally realized she would not be getting on that elevator, she heaved a soft and deflated sigh, asking instead for a piece of paper. She scribbled down her name, her phone number, and drew a small boat on jagged waves. Maybe, just maybe, that might be enough.

The doubt in her was strong, though, as she handed the paper over to the security guard who was still looking at her like she was entirely out of her mind. She knew what this looked like, and she knew that he had been of half a mind to start the process for a restraining order, but she'd had her hopes. She had wanted so badly for this idea that her life could be a real life fucking fairy tale to be real, to be tangible, to be hers. What she was realizing, as she turned around and tucked her chin to walk through those glass doors, was that any kind of a happy ending? When it came to her, it was reserved for the tales she had told her daughter as a child, and nothing more.

There was a sense of shame; no one really knew her, or why she was there, or why she had spent so long trying to strike some kind of deal with security that might afford her even a moment of Agatha's time, but it felt like they did. In the end, none of it really mattered, and yet? Rio's pride felt like it had been put through a gravel crusher.

Her mind was turning circles over what she was going to do. She supposed that it wouldn't be a terrible idea of spend some time in the city, to see the sights and experience things that she might not otherwise get to see or experience. She was in one of the biggest, busiest cities in the world. Surely, she could find something to do, some way to fill her time. She still couldn't help but feel the sting of disappointment; none of those things would ever measure up to what could have happened if she had managed to find Agatha again.

Her feet shuffled gently, scuffing softly over the concrete as she made her way back toward the stairs, the loneliness entwining itself around her, from head to toe. She reached the top of the stairs and lifted her head, an exhaled sigh catching mid breath.

There, at the bottom of the stairs, stood two women. There was a thin woman with long scarlet hair that cascaded over her shoulders, and then there was a woman next to her.

Not just a woman.

The woman.

She was gripping onto her friend's arm, their eyes still locked across the expanse of the stairs. They were there, frozen in time, just scrambling to integrate what they were seeing into being reality.

And then, in sync, there was movement.

Rio's feet began to move, carrying her down the stairs on the tips of her toes, the rubber of her combat boots scraping the concrete with how quickly she was moving. At the same time, Agatha was rushing forward, headed straight for the bottom of the stairs. The distance had been of almost equal measure, and as both of Rio's feet flattened on solid ground, she hardly had time to ground herself before they met.

Agatha's body bumped into hers as Rio felt her hands on her face, that touch, that caress, that captivating hold that commanded her attention. She could hardly even begin to process what was going on, and did not have a moment to think of anything to say before Agatha's lips were on her own, a hot and sultry kiss, passionate in its fair measure.

The way Agatha kissed her like that? She didn't need to breathe. Oxygen was irrelevant. All she needed in that moment was to keep kissing Agatha.

Then -- like a flash -- the bright realization of their setting and location sparked her to open her eyes, pulling back, though she didn't go far.

The smile on Rio's face was warm and instant, but before her brain could even adjust enough to form words, Agatha was speaking.

"Hi. I'm Agatha. What might your name be?" The words were a soft brush, a sweet song to Rio's ears. They made her stomach twist in sheer delight, that familiar pink heat rising to her cheeks.

Rio's smile only seemed to grow, her dark eyes just searching over the woman's face, taking in every freckle, every crease, every divot and dimple. She wanted to commit this memory to an eternity, something she would always and forever have to hold on to.

"My name's Rio."

"Rio," Agatha breathed, and the sound of her name on the other woman's lips had her heart leaping straight up into her throat. It was so beautiful, so elegant when it rolled off of her tongue. "It's nice to meet you."

The heat Rio was feeling in the pit of her being had to be showing, had to be obvious to anyone looking at her. There was no possible way in any existence that this was actually happening, that she was standing there with her hands on the hips of Agatha Harkness at the foot of her building. There was no way that Agatha had run up to her like that, held onto her like precious materials, and had kissed her in front of every single passerby that was on that block.

Agatha placed a gentle hand to Rio's chest, their eyes meeting. Gods, those blues were even more enchanting from such a close view.

"I have so many questions," she murmured across the space at Rio, though there was a consistent and bright light that was shimmering in her gaze. "But first..." she managed, sliding to the side to face the woman she had abandoned closer to the street. As she turned, though, she seemed to slide right into Rio's side, like she had always belonged there. One arm slid around the small of Rio's back, and the other resumed its home on her chest, dead center.

"Rio, this is my best friend, Wanda. Wanda this is... Rio, apparently. Otherwise known as 'boat woman.'"

At this, Rio's eyebrows shot up in surprise, and honestly, a touch of amusement, too.

"'Boat woman?'" She echoed, her gaze flickering up to Agatha, an undeniable smirk tugging on the corners of her lips.

"I mean. So maybe I've talked about you. A little bit." That almost would have been believable if her friend had not laughed the way she had, causing Rio's smirk to grow even more.

Agatha's gaze flickered down to the woman at her side, her stare light and full of amazement. She leaned a little closer, her voice dropping to that velvet smooth croon that she had used only once in their time together.

"I take it you found my message?"

Rio's skin sheeted in goosebumps, the thudding of her heart increasing at the proximity. She gulped down a breath, trying to keep her head steady. She nodded, her fingers dipping into her pocket to produce the earring. She held it up for show, letting it dangle from her fingers.

The other woman's eyes were so bright in that moment that it made Rio swoon there against her side.

Agatha tapped Rio's chest softly with the tips of her fingers, her attention sweeping back to Wanda, an apologetic look crossing over those gorgeous features.

"I know we just made plans for the evening, but would you be super upset if I call for a rain check?" Agatha posed, a bit of honey laced through her words.

The other woman rolled her eyes. "I would be disappointed if you didn't."

Agatha thanked her and they exchanged a brief hug before Wanda departed, and the full weight of Agatha's attention suddenly settled on Rio, those beautiful blue eyes taking her in, mystified. Perhaps Agatha was of the same mind, here, that this felt far more surreal than either of them knew how to wrap their minds around.

"I need to grab my bag and coat from my office. If you'd like to join me, we can figure out what to do with the rest of our night."

Rio's smile had hardly left her face from the moment their lips had pulled apart. She had wanted it to last longer, but she suddenly had a promise hanging in front of her that there would be plenty more time for that, that it might become something she would get to do at her leisure, and the thought alone was enough to excite her.

"Lead the way, my lady," Rio teased softly, flourishing a hand for Agatha to lead the way. What she had not been expecting was that, as she walked by, Agatha took hold of her hand and pulled her along, not letting go. In fact, she gave it a soft squeeze as they entered the building.

If Rio would have had a camera? She absolutely would have snapped a photo of the expression that crossed the face of the security guard at the front desk as the two women crossed the floor, hand in hand. Rio couldn't help the satisfied smirk that filled her face, an air of confidence beginning to exude from her form.

The elevators were absolutely pristine, and as the door shut behind them, she felt it again -- that gentle squeeze. Her head turned and her chin tilted up slightly, her eyes meeting Agatha's across the couple of inches between them.

There was this strong, silent exchange between them. There was this urge inside of Rio to grab her up by the face, to crush their lips together until neither of them could breathe anymore and had to separate only to gasp for air. She, somehow, found restraint. Where it came from, she had no idea, but she never once let go of her hand, even as the elevator slowed to a stop, the doors sliding open.

Agatha pulled her into the large and spacious office. She tugged her along to a back corner, pulling her through the doorway to an open space decorated in minimalist furniture and floor to ceiling windows that seemed to illuminate the entire space. It was beautiful, really, and Rio was struck with an overwhelming sense of awe.

"Give me one second," Agatha requested, but Rio was enchanted by the view, which she stepped closer to so that she could get a better vantage point.

There was a disbelief in her eyes, a wonder that was beyond linguistic expression.

"You've never seen anything like this?" came Agatha's soft, rich tones, quiet but close.

As Rio started to shake her head, she felt an arm encircle her waist, pulling her back, holding her firmly. Being held by Agatha? That was actually happening? The other woman's chin rested on Rio's shoulder, their gazes casting out on the city evenly.

"Well, I suppose we might have quite a bit of exploring to do in your time here," Agatha suggested in a warm but smooth murmur, and Rio glanced down, lifting an arm to lay it atop Agatha's. She could tell, by the brief squeeze around her waist, that the delivery there was more than intended as a double entendre, and by no means did that perturb her in any way.

Her reply was smooth and rich, not missing a beat.

"I suppose we do."

Slow Dancing in the Dark

When I'm around slow dancing in the dark
Don't follow me, you'll end up in my arms.

*****

The view outside of that high rise window had been one thing, but turning around in Agatha's grip to take her in, really take her in?

Gods. Be. Damned.

Everything about her was... perfect for what Rio knew of her as a person, thus far. Granted, there was a plethora left to learn about her, a great deal of knowledge to catalog and store away for future use. What she did know, though? Agatha wore every bit of who she was through what she looked like. It wasn't even that it was just how beautiful was; Rio saw that air again, the one that swirled around her, confident and proud. Her posture carried her authority, no matter what space she was walking in to command.

Agatha knew who she was to the world and she wore it like a cape, like it gave her the power to take on the universe.

She was her own god.

That conversation flashed, quick as a blink, and a gentle fondness filled Rio for a brief moment, and then, she was back to the task at hand: Her first lesson in Agatha Harkness.

They were close, Agatha's arms snugly wrapped around the small of her back, holding her close enough that the fronts of their bodies were touching, just barely, but enough to really constitute contact. Just that little touch, it was enough to have every inch of Rio's skin searing with a burning heat that she was convinced could not be cooled. Those dark eyes took her in at that close proximity, her mind racing a million miles a minute.

How in the Hell was she right there, in that huge fucking building, standing damn near forehead-to-forehead with an acclaimed director? How in the hell had this become her life in the matter of a month? How had life gotten that far away from her?

Was it that it had gotten away, or was it more that she had watched it go, only to decide that the risk of chasing it and getting lost was worth the reward of finding it?

It would have been like pulling teeth to get her to admit it, but Rio knew it leaned toward the latter.

There was such a sense of reverence as her eyes traced every inch of the other woman's features, from the gentle slope of her nose to the light curve of her thin lips. Those blue eyes? Gods, those blue eyes were absolutely to die for, especially when soaked in the look they were wearing in that moment, that utter adoration practically bleeding out of them.

"I'm free for the rest of the evening, so what we do is totally up to you," Agatha spoke, finally shattering the charged silence that had settled around them.

Rio's eyes danced with light as they darted again, her lips curving up slightly as she thought. While she did have an actual agenda, she couldn't pass up the blatant opportunity to give Agatha a bit of a hard time. After all, she'd flown six and a half thousand miles. Hadn't she earned the right to razz her up a bit?

"I don't even have to ask?" Rio posed, and a flash of confusion crossed Agatha's expression. "I mean, not to toot my own horn, but you agreeing to a date without me having to ask? I must have some serious game."

Her grin was automatic, canvassing her entire face, even reaching up as far as to crinkle her eyes at the corners, the pure joy painting itself over every crevice of her features. Seeing that Agatha's expression rivaled her own? It sent a pulse of warmth through every extremity she had, surely touching her neck with that pink dusting, though she didn't much care anymore if Agatha bore witness to it.

"Well, didn't we sort of already have one of those?" Agatha asked, a brightness flickering there that nearly made Rio melt.

"I mean..." Rio began, her lips dropping just barely into something that was a version of a softer, gentler smile. "There were candles?"

The laughter was immediate between the two of them, and for a second, Rio was pretty sure that her feet left the ground, that she had started to float toward the ceiling before the sound of Agatha's voice grounded her again.

"So... what do you think?"

Rio pondered a moment, the thoughts buzzing around behind dark irises. "We could go back to where I'm staying. There's a really nice bar on the ground floor."

Agatha tutted her tongue, a sly smirk finding her face. "Tsk, tsk, tsk. Always so insistent on plying me with alcohol. My mistake, though. I should have offered to buy you dinner first."

The wink that she tacked on at the end of her sentence? I could have just about ended her, full stop. It had been literally decades since she had been paid this kind of attention by literally anyone. She was even pretty damn amazed with the fact that she seemed to be keeping up with this woman. She would have laughed if someone had looked her in the eyes and told her she would be flirting with someone when she was nearly forty years old. The thought would have been downright hysterical.

But, there she was, holding her own.

"You can make it up to me with the best take out that you try to keep a secret from anyone else. And if you really feel that bad, you can pick up the tab, too."

At this, Agatha's brow quirked, and if Rio didn't know any better, she could have sworn that she heard her breath catch, for just the briefest second. She was not usually one to be so bold, at all, but there was something about the comfort in Agatha's aura that seemed to lend a hand to nearly yanking her out of the shell she had confined herself to for so long.

"Hm," Agatha murmured, her gaze intense as she seemed to regard Rio. Rio was focused on those eyes, on what was brewing in them.

"Yes?" she posed, as if to prod her into answering.

"Oh, nothing," Agatha dismissed, though her scrutinizing gaze had not let up in the least.

"Agatha," Rio pushed, tilting her head forward with an encouraging smile.

"I mean, I guess it's just that I misjudged you."

"Oh?" This intrigued Rio; she had thought that she had been pretty transparent in their first meeting, at least in regards to everything that came up between them. Sure, there were pages of history yet left for them to learn, but she could not deduce what Agatha could possibly be talking about.

Agatha gave a curt nod, that intense stare boring right through Rio.

"I just assumed you didn't have a bossy bone in your body." Her voice had dropped, it was textured and smooth, but there was a husky edge to it that Rio could not willingly ignore. Instead, another pulse of heat reverberated inside of her, but this time it was contained to her middle, white hot.

"I may just surprise you yet," Rio murmured back, her own voice slightly haughty, though for a moment she almost laughed at herself at the attempt to be sexy, alluring. Was it even succeeding? Well, only time would tell.

Agatha's focus shifted, having held her stare for so long, down to Rio's lips. They lingered for a solid moment before they raised again.

Rio couldn't control it, the look of amusement that had crept over her features.

"Yes?"

Agatha's gaze was unrelenting, looking straight into the depths of her very essence, but Rio didn't waver, didn't hesitate to feed it right back.

"You make it really hard to not want to kiss you," Agatha told her, her voice hardly more than a coarse whisper.

Instantly, Rio was set alight. She might as well have literally been on fire, because the heat that consumed her was instant, causing beads of sweat to spawn on the back of her neck, her temples. A spike of boldness flared through her, her voice coming out far stronger than she had thought it might, though her tones were still hushed.

"So what's stopping you?"

Rio could see clear as day, the way the giddiness nearly smothered Agatha for a split second at the permission she had offered to her.

What threw Rio off was that with that permission? It wasn't an immediate response. Agatha was still looking at her, watching her with this hot intensity that felt scorching, a daring tug pulling at her lips to reveal those perfect teeth in a full smile.

Slowly, Agatha's hand raised, landing on Rio's shoulder, and the simple touch seemed to send a current straight to her chest, stopping her heart for a beat before kicking it back on again. And then, it moved. It was a firm pressure, an announcement that she was there, that she was right there, that Rio could really feel it. It was there for her to take in, to absorb, to devour. It slid up the crook of her neck, over the side of it as Agatha's thin fingers curled around the back. It slipped up higher, Agatha's hand easily finding a gentle grip in Rio's hair.

Their eyes had not left one another's stare, despite the fact that Rio knew for a fact she had crossed every bit of the color spectrum from pink to red to scarlet, finally landing at a bright crimson.

If Agatha was trying to make her want this so bad it fucking hurt, it was working.

Her heart was a steady drumline in her chest, ricocheting off the prison of her ribcage, just seeking the freedom it needed to beat, to thrum, to pound however hard it needed to without being controlled.

If she had been convinced that it wasn't going to get any better than that moment, what followed had been sure to blow her away. She had in no way been expecting Agatha's words, and it showed the moment they graced her ears.

"I have thought about you every single day, and every single night since I walked out your door. I've thought about doing this twice as much."

Rio had been quite certain that as the words processed, every bit of oxygen had been pulled out of her. It was damn near a known fact in that moment, but then? When Agatha finally dared to eliminate the space that had been like a solid wall between them, every bit of that heat ruminating in Rio's middle?

Their lips crushed together, mild at first, as if Agatha was gauging what level of heat Rio might find acceptable. It took only a moment for Rio to push back, to escalate it up another step.

She was convinced that breathing? It was unnecessary, something that had been a trick, a brainwashing of the masses.

Who needed to breathe when they could be kissed like that?

For as many times as Rio had told herself that she wouldn't know how to kiss someone even if she had to? Something primal, instinctual seemed to possess her. She fed right back into the exchange, her own hands gripping lightly at Agatha's sides, pulling her closer, their fronts flushed together.

There was only a mild sense of shock that struck Rio as she felt the tip of Agatha's tongue tracing lightly along the bottom of her top lip.

What pulled her attention instead was the bolt of lightning that shot straight up her spine, searing itself with scorching tendrils across every inch of her brain.

Gods, that was fucking hot.

She understood it for what it was, though. It was a tap on the barrier, a request for entrance. Agatha wanted in, and Rio was all but ready to kick the door down.

Her lips parted and there was not even a split second of hesitance from the other woman as Rio felt their tongues meet, brushing, pushing, caressing. If she was a terrible kisser? Well, there had been no objections thus far, and she was inwardly begging the universe to just give her this, for as long as she could have it.

Agatha's grip tightened at the base of her skull and she could feel her pulling her closer, needing more, wanting more, taking more. And Rio was happy to give.

She couldn't have said how long they stood like that, gripping, grasping, sighing, gasping, but what she could have said was that by the time they parted, their pants and heavy breaths echoing off of the walls around them?

She knew she was never going to be able to get her fill of Agatha Harkness. Ever.

"What do you say we go back to the hotel?" Rio posed, the gentle caress of her stare sweeping over Agatha in question.

"I'll call the car," she murmured. Before she loosened her hold, though, she dipped her head, stealing the briefest of pecks right off of an unsuspecting Rio's lips, leaving her gaping slightly in wonder. How the fuck did she do that? Where did this power come from? Where had she found this presence that she wore so proudly like battle armor?

Rio was sold. Whatever it was Agatha was selling? Rio was investing everything she had in it.

She knew there was risk. She knew that they could spend two days together and realize that they hated each other. Right then, standing in that office as she turned to watch Agatha's form as she paced behind her desk on the phone, gathering her things? She didn't care. Every chip was on the table, a go-big-or-go-broke mentality finally having settled over her.

There was not much in life that Rio had ever really chased after. She'd found that she'd had everything she needed, in her career, and in her role as a mother. She'd been totally and utterly convinced that she lived a life that was full enough, and that she did not need to seek out anything else -- like a relationship -- to 'fix' any part of her.

Her loneliness had been so severe, though, that it had needed repairing.

Maybe, she thought, Agatha could be good with her hands.

There was the tiniest twitch of her lips, a barely-there smirk that she was glad Agatha could not see. She was getting ahead of herself, of course, and she was well aware, but that didn't mean she wanted to stop. Of course, she was not going to take her back to her hotel room and throw her down only to rip her clothes off, but she was not going to offer any sort of objection to any natural progression the night might have chosen to take.

Agatha folded her coat over her arm, holding her purse in the same hand as she turned back to face Rio; out of the corner of Rio's eye, she could see the woman pause, for just a moment. She could feel that heat again, the scrutiny of her gaze, the way she was eating up everything she could glean from that vantage point.

She lifted her head, turning to meet Agatha's gaze across the room, an instant smile blossoming across her lips.

"Shall we?" Agatha offered as she stepped forward, holding out a hand as if it were the most natural thing in the world.

Rio glanced at it for only a moment before accepting the invitation, their palms clasping together as Agatha led her back toward the elevator and out the building.

Rio had not held hands with another being that was not her own offspring in... well, almost ever. Her early college days had been mostly flings, not ever reaching any form of establishment when it came to a relationship. She had still been trying to figure herself out, but that ability for exploration had been seized from her before she'd had a chance to do anything with it.

But the way that Agatha seemed to refuse to let her go? The way she seemed to cling to the contact like it was some kind of lifeline? Rio had been completely bombarded with every emotion that could possibly be named since she had landed on American soil, but there was something special about what was flickering to life inside of her.

Rio felt wanted.

The touch only dissipated twice in the journey from Agatha's office to the hotel, and it was the two times they had to break apart to get in and out of the car. The contact was never initiated by Rio, always Agatha. She was making a very clear, very bold statement, one that left Rio feeling eternally flushed: This moment is ours, but I need the world to see that you are mine.

They probably looked like a pair of teenage girls as the poured into the lobby of the hotel, the way they were so close and faces filled with amusement, light, happiness. It was a new outfit to wear for Rio, but she was quite liking the work out the muscles in her face were getting; they had been idle and unused in this manner for far too long.

The wind seemed to carry them, even in an enclosed lobby, as they made their way over to the bar that was located in the heart of the hotel.

They slid onto stools at the smooth cherry bar top and Agatha pulled her black credit card out, pinning it at the corners between her thumb and the pad of her middle finger, spinning it mindlessly as the bartender, a younger man with dark skin and bright eyes, approached them.

Everything about Agatha was so... effortless.

"A martini, dry with two extra olives and..." Those blue hues sliced over to Rio, regarding her, studying her, trying to deduce something. Rio had almost thought that Agatha had paused to allow her to answer, but it only took a moment for her to understand that she was playing a game. She wanted to know if she could guess.

She could see the question there, watching with earned interest as Agatha tried to land on the right answer. She faltered for a moment, and when she turned back to the bartender, she had thought that she might at least pose her deduction as a question.

There was no question in Agatha's addition to the order.

"A sidecar."

Rio balked; how the fuck had she known that? She blinked, though Agatha's profile remained completely cool and collected. She hadn't even glanced over to see if she was right. She had taken Rio's silence as a quiet victory, and Rio could tell by the way the corner of her mouth hitched up despite her eyes not leaving the bartender as he went about making their drinks.

"How do you do that?"

Agatha's hand brushed beneath her chin and she glanced over at Rio with a feigned sense of shock. "Do what?"

Rio's lips pursed in amused dissatisfaction and she cocked a brow at her, tilting her head as if to say You know what.

"Guess you'll have to stick around long enough to find out."

Rio had begun to dispute, but she was interrupted by the man behind the bar as he turned around and slid their drinks in front of them. Agatha pressed the black plastic to the bar top and slid it over to him.

"Leave it open."

Rio studied her, an amused dance of expression flickering across her face

"Oh, okay, Mommy Warbucks."

At this, Agatha's searing gaze sliced over to Rio, that sense of being transparent washing over all over again. It was solid and steady, assessing everything it saw, piecing together how she best wanted to respond. It could have been an illusion, but Rio could have sworn that she saw a lick of rose curl its way up Agatha's neck, but it seemed to fade just as fast.

Okay. So that had pressed a button.

Agatha's eyes were smoldering for a passing moment, and then, just like that, she extinguished the fire, though Rio could still see the remaining coals there, fighting for enough oxygen to keep burning. It wasn't an angry look, it was something else. It was attraction.

That stare, it was unrelenting, heavy in its weight, but only because Rio was learning that Agatha's silence often meant she had time to think, and when Agatha gave herself time to think? She could be damaging.

Rio didn't want to forfeit the upper hand quite yet, though.

"Can I ask you something?" she posed, neglecting the drink that Agatha had just ordered for her to instead quench the thirst of her curiosity.

Agatha's expression softened as she considered, giving her a gentle nod of her head.

"When did you come back?"

The look in her eyes? Rio hardly knew how to make sense of it's tenderness, but she hardly had time to ponder it before she was pulled into the answer Agatha had to offer.

"The day I came back here. It was just after noon. You weren't home and I... I panicked. I didn't have anything on me, like a card, or even paper to write you a note. So I left the one thing I did have on me. It seems as though it got the job done."

Rio's cheeks were suddenly hot and her eyes dropped to her lap, though there was a small smile still on her face. She lifted her head again, looking across at Agatha a bit earnestly.

"Honestly? I put it in my jewelry box with every intent of ignoring it. I... I thought you just lost it. However, after I realized who you are when we watched the Oscars, I told my daughter, and she was pretty insistent that I get on a plane and fly six thousand miles and find you after pointing out that you had left the back on it intentionally."

A soft hum of approval escaped Agatha's lips, which were twisted up in a grin, the softest huff of humor accompanying it a moment later.

"Smart girl."

She swiped her martini off of the bar top and swiveled in her seat, her knees nearly pressing into the side of Rio's thigh. She held the glass up, tilting her head to the side as she took in the sight of the other woman.

"What's her name?" Agatha asked, her tone tender, sweet.

"Estrella."

"Well then," Agatha announced, pushing the glass forward. "To Estrella."

Rio could feel it, this nestling of affection in her chest. How sweet was it that, as they shared their first toast on American soil, Agatha thought it deserved to belong to the one person who had pushed this to happen?

"To Estrella," she echoed, lifting her own glass to touch the rim of it to Agatha's.

It had been the first toast, but it hadn't been the last. Or the second, third, or forth.

Rio did not get drunk. It just wasn't something she did. However, right then? Well, she was pretty damn close to toeing the line.

They had been at that bar, just sipping their drinks, sharing soft conversation back and forth, finding some way to make small talk not seem so awkward. Rio had learned a lot in that couple of hours; Agatha had been in Auckland on business, that much had been true. In fact, she had even been at the wildlands the day before, doing a scouting for a filming location. She was still in the beginning stages of finding the legs for the project she was working on, but she had been growing more confident that she was coming close to settling on a location. She learned that Agatha's favorite flowers were azaleas, she hated dark chocolate, and she had a pretty intense allergy to cinnamon. Her favorite time of day was dusk, the most breathtaking place she had been for work had been Iceland, and her favorite holiday season was Christmas, solely for the spiked eggnog.

This woman wasn't just a book to be cracked open and read. She was an entire series, a multitude of standalone stories that, when put together, were an intricate and detailed showing of a completely and entirely complex woman.

She was full of content, filled with endless tales of sage wisdom and surely, tales of light and humor and life. Rio couldn't wait to absorb every single chapter.

Agatha had flagged down the bartender with an assured flick of her wrist, and he answered her call, appearing before them.

"Close me out," she instructed, "but before you do... could you add a bottle of the Remy Martin for room..." she trailed, glancing over at Rio, who seemed to catch on quick.

"2315."

"To room 2315."

"Yes, ma'am," he agreed with a nod. He turned to his work, finalizing the tab and placing the order for the bottle to be delivered up to Rio's room. He slid the check across the bar and Agatha signed it easily after adding a tip that Rio couldn't help but notice -- $150 -- and slid it back over to him. He thanked her with a grateful nod and took his leave.

Her face turned back to Agatha, drinking her in like a tall glass of water after a week in the desert.

"We should probably beat them up there, hm?" Agatha posed, the traces of a giggle lingering on her lips, though they never formed fully.

The light danced in Rio's face as she gave a nod, sliding off the stool to get back on her feet. When they said that it was impossible to gauge how drunk one was until they stood up? She knew exactly what that meant in that moment. She swayed, just barely, but kept herself steady, though she did not miss the way Agatha's hand flew up, hovering just outside of the side of her arm, though it never made contact.

Rio had not even had time to consider where the elevator was before she felt Agatha's fingers slide between her own and she gave a light tug, seeming to know where she was going. Rio should have taken charge, should have acted like she had some semblance of control here, but there was something so... enticing about watching this woman brandish her confidence like a weapon, daring anyone to stand in her way.

They slipped into the elevator, devolving into a flurry of giggles as the door clipped Rio's heel on the way in as it started to close.

The way they laughed, the pure delight that shook them left them leaning into one another, holding onto each other. The calm started to come and the laughter began to die down, but they were so close that Rio could smell the gin on Agatha's breath mixing with the brandy on her own. Their eyes caught and after another beat, the laughter subsided.

They were there, locked in that battle of wills, each of them silently daring the other to be the one to jump, to careen over the edge of sanity and pull the other with them.

After only another moment, Rio broke. Her hand was up, firm against the side of Agatha's neck as she pulled her in, her mouth finding Agatha's with an astonishing ease. Their lips met in a crush of heat and desperation. This was something Rio could have done over and over again until she either suffocated, or the rest of the world melted away around them. Either was an option she was fine with.

For their setting and the fact that their inevitable destination was not that far away, that kiss seemed to spark a fire that spread in the blink of an eye. By the time the door dinged and slid open, Rio was far too engrossed with the way her tongue probed Agatha's mouth, wild and exploratory in nature to pay any attention. The door closed again, but with no destination, the elevator just sat.

Rio? Oblivious. She needed that, the taste of gin and vermouth on those lips, on that tongue. She needed the scent of palo santo and lilac that filled her senses from Agatha's perfume. She needed the feel of that silk blouse beneath her fingertips, smooth and rich at her touch.

And then, Agatha pulled away, her chest heaving a bit with the effort.

"Erm. I think we've arrived," she indicated, a pointed finger gesturing to the stilled number above the door.

Instantly, they devolved into a fit of giggles, Rio leaning over to press the 'door open' button. The laughter was still bubbling out of her as they stumbled out of the elevator, never even an inch apart. As they neared her room, there was a sharply dressed man in uniform standing by her door, the bottle Agatha had requested in the palm of his hand, resting against his forearm.

As they approached, Agatha pulled something out of her wallet and tucked it back in her bag. She approached the man and made the exchange, sliding the hundred into his palm the moment she removed the bottle from it.

"Ma'am," he acknowledged gratefully before he turned and made his exit.

Agatha turned on her heel forty-five degrees to face Rio, a pleased smile on her lips. Her free hand gave a wave toward the door and Rio nodded, stepping forward to slide the key into the lock. The light flashed green and she pushed the door open, holding it while Agatha entered.

She let it close with a soft click and turned back to face the room, watching with interest as Agatha set the bottle down, slipped her shoes off and draped her coat over the back of the desk chair.

Rio stepped further into the room, but her eyes never left Agatha. She moved with such a fluidity as she reached up, removing the clip from her hair. She shook it loose as it cascaded down her back in those flowing soft waves. She moved again, and even though her back was to Rio, Rio knew exactly what she was doing, only being proven right as Agatha turned around, the top two buttons of her blouse undone.

This woman was going to be the end of her, if she let her.

It was looking like a pretty feasible option from where she stood.

Transcendental Weather

What if we get to the sky and this was all a lie
This was all a dream?

*****

In the hours that had passed as the two women had perched at that bar, the alcohol sliding down with ease and the banter free flowing, the world outside had grown dark. Not only had the sun started its descent in the sky, but thick shelves of dark clouds had rolled in.

The thunder was not loud enough to shake the center of the hotel, but in that room, its soft rumble could be heard outside of the window. The pelting of raindrops was soundless, but they collected on the glass, pooling in tiny spots that distorted the view ahead at the right angle. There could have been tornadoes, there could have been a tsunami, and Rio wouldn't have known.

Moreover, she wasn't sure she would have cared.

The tangible interest was still hanging thick in the air as Rio and Agatha both settled on the soft, plush bed that was stationed in the middle of the room, a little square of privacy that might offer them the space to explore, to learn, to understand.

Agatha's hand swept over, gently laying the bottle of brandy in the small amount of space between them. Did Rio need it? Probably not, but it was a fun little temptation, a little reminder that she could lose herself a bit further in the warmth the liquor had to offer. She knew she didn't really need it -- the heat that had been smoldering within her since the moment she had arrived had not died down for even a second. But it was there if she wanted it.

Once again, as if she could not stand the thought of a bare palm, Agatha lifted a hand and reached over, securing Rio's snugly in her own.

Rio's lips were parting and she was speaking before she had formed even a thought.

"Why do you do that?" she asked, though there was a tender curiosity laced in her voice. Her hand gave a light squeeze as if to indicate what she was referring to.

Agatha turned her head toward her, leaving Rio to be met with an assessment, an evaluation of everything she was in that particular moment under steeled but warm eyes.

"Because it's a constant reminder that the day we spent together wasn't a complete dream."

If Rio had been standing? She probably would have crumbled, her knees turned to absolute jelly. She had been feeling much the same way; every time they kissed, she was jolted into reality, into her reality, where chasing the things she wanted had, for once, turned out in her favor. She had intended on letting the weight sink over her, but Agatha spoke again.

"And because I can't kiss you constantly to hold firm in that assessment instead."

Rio flushed, an undeniable blushing that seemed to coat her from head to toe. This woman... This woman was absolutely something else.

"And while I would love to indulge in that within the privacy of these walls... My interest in getting to know you is a little heavier."

Still warm, Rio's eyes cast down to their hands, clasped together in a strong grip. She considered for a short moment before she looked back up at the other woman.

"What would you like to know?"

Agatha's eyes darted, ever so slightly, as they surveyed Rio's face, as if she were going to find the questions she wanted to ask there. Something about the way the moment drew on, about the intensity of that prying gaze, it started to unsettle Rio the slightest bit. She could sense it cooking, brewing; it was a desire for knowledge that wasn't quite so common.

Rio gave the smallest nod, a silent encouragement, a light push to get her to keep going.

"Is..." Agatha's lips twisted slightly in discomfort; she looked like she knew she had no right to be asking the question she was about to ask. "Is Estrella's father in the picture?"

At this, there was a sudden squeeze, a tightening in Rio's throat that nearly choked her.

This was a conversation that had taken her eighteen years to have with the only person she had thought deserved to know. It was something she was still wounded from, even if the pain it caused was nothing more than a minor sting after so long.

She could have lied. She could have made up some story about a college tryst gone wrong, or that she had made bad choices in her youth. She could have said anything other than the actual truth, but then... What would be the point? This woman was clearly interested in her, clearly wanted to get to know her. Neither of them had any clue if this would amount to anything after this trip, but to lie?

It wouldn't be productive, wouldn't lend to establishing any form of trust between them. Her eyes fell again on their hands, her thumb brushing over the back of Agatha's knuckles nervously. While she knew that the silence while she tried to decide on her delivery of a rather fucked fact of life was extensive, Agatha was patient, her hold firm on Rio's hand.

"I was in my second year of uni. I went with a couple of friends to a house party one night." Her voice had the lightest hint of a waver in it. It was the first time she had ever actually recounted what happened that night without censoring herself to protect Estee. "One of them wanted to show me something, a record collection, I think, and so I followed her, leaving my drink on the kitchen counter." There was the most subtle drop in Agatha's expression, as if she could already see where this was going. "I came back, as if nothing could have changed in those two minutes. The rest of the night... it was a blur."

Rio exhaled the smallest sigh, as if she were ashamed.

"I woke up the next morning in a dorm room I didn't know, next to an older guy who I only knew in passing. I was naked and my body hurt in ways I had no clue it was capable of hurting." Her lips twisted dryly as she finally gathered the courage to look up at Agatha. "About four months later, I found out I was pregnant. It... it could have destroyed me, but I have always been so damn stubborn."

A flicker of agreement, and understanding, flashed over Agatha, dashingly quick. It touched Rio, a gentle grace of her soul.

"Every day for the last almost twenty two years, I have never regretted my decision to keep her. She is... my light, my reason, my sanity. She is my entire world, and watching as she grows, shaping into this amazing young woman with a ferocity and determination that just blows me away? It feels like my biggest accomplishment that I raised her. Me, alone, her whole life. I did that. I am the main reason that she is able to find joy and spread it like a cure to all that ails the world. I am why she strives to be the best person she can possibly be. I know it sounds like a brag, like I think so highly of myself, but... I know her. I know that for as much as she is everything to me, I am all she has ever known."

The longer she spoke, the more she could see the tides of different emotions swelling and ebbing inside of Agatha. She had a child, she knew what it was like to love another being so impossibly wholly that it made little to no sense. She knew what it was like to hope, day after day, that you had somehow been able to help create a productive member of society, or, even more, someone who could make a difference.

This tender quiet settled over them and there was only the feel of their hands, the soft even sounds of their breathing.

Rio felt bare. She felt naked, like the armor of secrets she had been carrying with her had been peeled away by the woman next to her, a piece at a time. It had been a sudden but careful process, but Rio knew it was inevitable. She had known it the first time her fingers wrapped around Agatha's wet hand and pulled her out of the water.

She had known, immediately, that Agatha could so easily be her undoing.

"I have the same affection for Nicky," Agatha responded softly, her own eyes on their hands.

"Your son?" Rio asked quietly, her gaze lifting curiously.

Agatha nodded. "He's... a good kid. But, he also seemed to inherit his mother's complete and utter impulsivity and inability to weigh pros and cons of any given situation."

"You mentioned he was living in Dubai," Rio recalled, still studying the other woman, watching the warmth of her love for her son take hold of her.

"He created a dating app with a girl he went to high school with. It's basically all anonymous, but it's geared more toward finding connections through similar music tastes. It's been... really amazing to watch, but in the process he just..." Agatha hesitated, her eyes lifting straight ahead. "It just feels like he kind of forgot that Mom's still here, and she still likes hearing from him, and knowing he's okay." She exhaled a gentle sigh, a sad sigh. "I think... with what I do, he just assumes I no longer have time for him, but I have always made it when I needed to."

"He'll come around," Rio assured gently, though she had absolute zero grounds to even consider stating such a thing. She didn't know her son, and she arguably barely knew Agatha, but something in her could see it, that this woman lived and breathed for her child.

Agatha breathed a soft laugh, that soft caress of her gaze holding onto Rio's face, as if for dear life.

"Your optimism is..." she started, but Rio was quick to cut in.

"Mildly annoying?" she offered, a brow lifting as the smallest smirk found her face.

Agatha almost snorted, regarding her with a newfound softness.

"I was going to say... refreshing. After all, without such optimism, do you really think you would have spent fifteen hours on a plane and in airports to be sitting here with me?"

Okay, so, that was an incredibly fair point.

Rio's lips parted, and the words sat on the very tip of her tongue, just waiting for the permission to fly free, but she was stuck, knowing that what they were? The weight they would hold? She hardly knew this woman, and yet? She said it anyway.

"I would have traveled to the ends of the earth to find you again," she admitted, the mixture of shame and honesty flashing in her eyes.

All at once, Agatha's hand lifted and affectionately cupped Rio's cheek, her thumb brushing light lines along the curve of her cheekbone. Rio had been anticipating the kiss that was sure to follow, but... the moment hung startlingly still between them.

There it was again, those eyes digging, burrowing deep within her.

What the hell was she looking at? What the hell did she see?

"Do you..." Agatha started in a quiet murmur, her eyes flickering down to Rio's lips, then back up to her gaze, "believe in soulmates?"

The cross between amusement and curiosity settled over Rio as she considered, though her eyes never left Agatha's face.

In her smitten haze, she had somehow missed the actual gravity of the question, but responded honestly, nonetheless.

"I have never believed much when it comes to love. My loneliness for years is indicative of that. But... I believe that there are people out there, people who have lived and experienced a life entirely different from my own, but because of that, those people have developed parts and pieces for themselves that i would never have had the experiences to know they needed to be planted." Rio hesitated, letting go of a soft, tension-filled breath. "I believe that sometimes, the edges of those pieces, the give and pull of how a puzzle works... two people can fit together just right, just enough to offer a fuller view, while still limited, to the bigger picture."

Agatha was looking at her the way she had looked at her when she had asked Agatha about religion, and she had provided her answer.

Another moment passed and the tension broke, snapping like a rubber band that had been stretched beyond its capabilities.

She had still been acutely aware of the touch on her face, still present, but it was impossible to ignore as it moved, Agatha's fingers sliding into her hair as she pulled her closer, though with nowhere near the urgency she had exuded earlier in the day. Instead, her movements were slow and deliberate, making sure that Rio was entirely aware of what she was requesting of her in that moment.

It was a show of thanks for the things Rio had been so willing to share with her. It was the whisper of gratitude that, when given the choice, Rio had chosen to let her in.

It was sweet, and Rio understood it for what it was, but she wanted more. She wanted to bask in the feeling of this woman's adoration, to let the feeling of being wanted just cover her, head to toe. It could smother her, for all she cared. Being wanted, for her, was a high she couldn't stop chasing. She wanted it, and when she got it? She wanted more.

Agatha was peppering affection over every inch of her soul. It wasn't frenzied or hurried. It was a slow, sweet moment of nothing but lips on lips, hands on warm skin. Rio's own fingers had wrapped around the wrist of the hand that was gently tangled into her hair, holding Agatha there, as if she was not going to get even an inch away.

For a long few moments, that was all it was. It was a lip lock that was designed to root them in the moment, to tether them together. The warmth of it had snugly fit around the both of them, kissing each other like life itself was dependent on it, that three hundred dollar bottle of liquor still cradled by the covers beneath them.

They separated after a little bit longer, though their breathing was a bit louder and the serene sound of it felt good, felt pristine in Rio's ears.

"You've got to stop letting me do that," Agatha hummed warmly, her breath still hot on Rio's lips. "Because I swear, I won't ever stop if you don't tell me to."

The softest, most pure sound of complete delight fluttered from Rio's lips in the shape of a giggle. The reaction it had was instant, a softness sweeping over Agatha's entire being.

Rio's eyes were bright as she considered.

"As fun as that sounds," Rio murmured back, a spark of mischief flashing in her gaze for the briefest moment, "I've been quite enjoying playing '896 questions on the second date.'"

Agatha smiled, sweet and soft.

"So it was a date," she mused, the cutest light finding her face.

Rio blushed, glancing away for a brief moment. She knew that she needed to work on her composure, but damn if Agatha did not get under her skin with little to no effort.

"You literally fell into my life because I whistled at you. At the time, I assumed dinner was obligatory," she teased back softly, though there was some truth peppered in with the statement.

She had felt some guilt, some of the blame for what had happened that afternoon, but it was apparent that every single thing she had done since? Well, Agatha apparently appreciated it enough to be sitting there telling her that she had the willful intentions of drowning her in attention.

And then a thought struck Rio, the dawning realization of her forgetfulness washing over her.

"What a soft place to land," she breathed in a bit of a mystified whisper.

Agatha's face softened, beholding this woman before her.

"So you found that too," she deduced, wearing an expression that screamed that she couldn't have been more thrilled.

"You left that day, and then still somehow lived in my house for weeks."

Agatha's brows lifted, her delight clear between them.

"I have been told I can be a bit... haunting." She laughed, a soft sound that brought a sense of joy bubbling in Rio's chest.

"Could be worse," Rio murmured, brushing the tips of their noses together. "You could have stalked a complete stranger halfway across the world in the hope that they might give you five minutes of their time."

"Why would I do that when you're so good at it?"

It was Rio, this time, who chose to do away with any inkling of space between them. She pressed forward, stealing another kiss, one that started innocently enough.

That feeling of closeness, of warm contact, it was enough to send her rocketing off into space. It was no longer just a sense of feeling light or weightless. No, she was being propelled to reach the stars, to burn, scorching in the heat of the sun. She wanted to revel in it, to wrap it around herself tightly, to compress herself in that feeling that filled her from the top of her head to the tips of her toes.

They stayed tangled like that for a few minutes, hot breaths, soft pants, hands gently exploring over fabric. Nothing was being pushed, no agenda, just a general understanding that they had time before them, and they could use it appropriately. Finally, Rio gently removed her lips from Agatha's, though her compulsion to stay close did not wane, their foreheads pressing softly together.

"Who the fuck are you, and where have you been my entire life?"

Rio's question elicited a sound so delectable and sweet, a tantalizing mixture of an amused laugh and something more. Something... deep.

"Waiting to take the plunge, I suppose."

The tension in the space around them was thick, but not heavy. Rio understood it as a line they were standing on opposing sides of, both inching closer, gauging the other's reaction to the removal of space between them, in the metaphorical sense. Physically? Physically, they couldn't get close enough.

Rio watched her with an intense desire to just... know her. To just know everything she could possibly know about her.

"Tell me something," Rio beguiled, her eyes focused on Agatha's, on the way she gave a little nod to signify that it was okay to continue. "Why did you come back that day?"

Warmth radiated in Agatha's expression as she regarded Rio with that unbridled affection that was rooted deep within her.

"Because I needed to know your name."

The answer was so simple, so honest, and yet there was such a weight to it, a poundage that held it solid and firm where it sat, that answer nestling in the pit of Rio's stomach. Everything about this was so unfamiliar and new, and yet, in her bones, Rio could have sworn that it was the one place she had always meant to be. The comfort was overwhelming, and the ease with which she felt she could just exist was something she had not known she could feel.

Though they had been stuck like that, forehead to forehead for several long moments, Rio could feel the rise of something inside of her. It was an insatiable need to be closer filling her, brimming over the edges of her entire being.

She reached between them and pulled the bottle of brandy into her lap so that she could wiggle her hips enough to scoot over, sealing that remaining space, too. Agatha sensed what she was doing and adjusted accordingly, lifting an arm so that she could wrap it around Rio's shoulders, pulling her firmly into her side. Without hesitation, Rio's head fell to Agatha's shoulder, her eyes shutting in complete surrender.

Experiencing all of this, all of these emotions? These were literally all things that were entirely new to Rio. She had not been loved, or even cared for, by someone who was not her child. She had not been treasured, or coveted throughout her entire forty years on the earth, and she had never been bothered by it.

It had never really mattered one way or the other, until it had.

What Rio was thinking, in those moments as she felt a sense of peace rest over her like a weighted blanket, was that she had been missing out. And then, she wondered if anyone else she could have possibly ever met in her life could have ever made her feel like she did right then, snugly fit against Agatha's side, the weight of the other woman's grasp heavy and comforting in its sense of safety over her shoulders.

She knew she could spend all night picking it apart, trying to dissect this insane and instant attraction that had developed between the two of them. She could understand her own insanity, but then she realized that if she was insane? Well, she was staring at a spitting image of someone else who was, too, when she looked at Agatha.

"Do you want to know something?" Agatha whispered into the quiet, her fingertips beginning to trace light lines up Rio's arms.

Rio's eyes lifted, but her head did not move. Agatha still seemed to sense her interest, and decided to keep going.

"I have this director friend. I've known him a while; he's younger, but he's a good guy. I texted him after I came home and asked him to pick between two locations, one in Australia, and the one near you. He asked why I was struggling when I was usually so decisive. I told him it was because I knew I could not make a decision without bias."

This intrigued Rio. Their meeting had really effected her to that point, that she was questioning solid business decisions because she thought she was only making them based on personal feelings?

"He ended up prying it out of me, what happened. I think that honestly, he didn't believe me for a solid ten minutes. He asked how much money I wanted for the publishing rights to a script." She laughed, the hand that was on Rio's shoulder raising to gently comb through her hair. This caused Rio, too, to breathe a soft chuckle. She had to admit -- it was literally insane. There were films made over decades that were not nearly as good as the reality they were living out. "If anyone's making that blockbuster, I think I could do it justice before anybody else."

There was a strong satisfaction that warmed Rio, causing her skin to sheet in a thin layer of goosebumps. The way Agatha sat there talking, it made her feel like she was not as crazy as she had convinced herself they were. Sure, they were still in those beginning stages, but it was clear that the other woman saw the same thing she had: The gold string of fate, running from one chest to another, binding them together.

"What time is it?" Rio posed, her tone thick with exhaustion. She was a bit too worn to do the math, but she was pretty confident that she had been awake over twenty four hours.

"It's about ten 'til midnight," Agatha responded after glancing over at her phone on the bed beside her.

In her comfort, Rio had forgotten something very important. To extend an invitation.

"You'll stay tonight, won't you?" she asked, trying to fight to keep the desperation out of her voice. She had just gotten there, it seemed, and she wasn't ready to part ways so soon.

The corners of Agatha's eyes wrinkled with her smile, her head bobbing in a gentle nod.

"But only if you let me buy you midnight sushi from a flower shop basement."

Rio's eyes shimmered with a fondness as she recalled her own prior comment about wanting something that Agatha kept a secret.

"You really know all the spots, don't you?"

Agatha laughed, a light and flittering sound that seemed to expand, hugging every wall in the room.

"Give me a sec," she mused, turning her head slightly to brush her lips against Rio's forehead as she reached for her phone. She pulled it into her lap and set to work, triumphantly placing it back on the bed a moment later. "Food's ordered. The delivery guy will be here in twenty five minutes."

Rio found herself asking the internal question again that still seemed to have no apparent answer: How the Hell had this happened?

She was so comfortable, so rested, so relaxed as she sat there nestled into the side of the other woman. She knew that the road that lay ahead of them was filled with plenty of opportunities for them to learn and explore, and so she took that night for what it was: a moment to rest in a place where not only did she felt safe, but she felt cared for. She felt, for those passing minutes, like this woman just completely cared about her, about her well-being and her state of mind. She cared about pouring attention into her, about making her see that to Agatha? Rio was haunting in her own right.

They were both quiet, reserved in their silence as the soft hum of the tv played from across the room. Rio was exhausted, but she was fighting it long enough so that they could share their meal and she could inevitably pass out to catch up on some of the sleep she had been depriving herself of over the last day.

A soft tap at the door signified the arrival of their dinner and Agatha whispered a soft request for a moment as she removed herself from Rio's side, leaving it cold with the sudden lack of body heat. Rio's eyes slid shut as she listened to the soft exchange, and then the door shut again. She could hear those barely-there footsteps as they carried Agatha back toward the bed, the soft crinkle of the bag rustling as she set it down, her own weight causing the mattress to sink as she fit herself onto it. There was not even a single second of hesitation as she slid right back up into her position against Rio's side.

They ate, mostly in the quiet noise of the television; it had become pretty apparent that the day had taken its toll on them and rest was in their immediate future, but there was still something hovering around them that Rio could not ignore.

It was the dull drum of potential.

She put the last bite of her sushi into her mouth and chewed thoughtfully for a moment before she swallowed, her gaze sweeping over to the other woman, even as the chopsticks were still poised in her hand.

"I'm really glad I'm here," Rio admitted, a shy divulgence that was truly underselling how she really felt.

Agatha regarded her with a gentle reverence, but otherwise remained still.

"I'm really glad you're here too."

She punctuated that sentiment by leaning toward Rio, their shoulders pressed firmly together as their lips brushed in another heaven-sent kiss. It was brief, but it sent Rio's pulse pounding in her neck. And then, there was space between them, but it was filled with Agatha's immediate question.

"Are you ready to lay down?" There was a tender curiosity there, one that made Rio blush. She nodded her head gently in response, and Agatha set to cleaning things off the bed to prepare for sleep.

Rio lifted herself to her feet, making her way over to her duffel bag. She pulled out a t-shirt and then glanced up, over her shoulder, at Agatha.

"Do you want something more comfortable to sleep in?" Rio questioned, her tones hushed. Agatha's head lifted and she offered a smile that seemed to answer the question.

Rio reached in, pulling out another shirt, but then hesitated. She stared down into the bag, her mind turning circles. She grabbed only one pair of shorts and turned back to meet Agatha at the corner of the bed.

"Here's a shirt and a pair of shorts. I... don't normally sleep in anything but a shirt and underwear, but if that's any kind of an issue, I can wear shorts," she tried to explain in a soft rush, but the amusement was already painting itself in Agatha's expression.

"I think I can practice some self-restraint for a night," Agatha offered, though her tone was low and textured, like it was meant to be enticing.

And it might have been, had Rio not been so thoroughly depleted.

Agatha reached up and plucked one of the shirts from her grasp, her eyes sweeping down to the shorts before they cast up, flicking in instruction toward the bag. Rio was stunned for a moment, a low thud of something happening in her middle. She obliged, though, turning back to toss the shorts back into the bag. With her back to Agatha, and a mind too tired to consider any ability to be embarrassed, she stripped down.

Her jeans, her hunter green tank top, her bra all laid in a small heap at her feet as she finished tugging the sleep shirt over her head. The hem of it hung down low enough to not be considered too revealing.

Rio turned, and as she did, she froze, her gaze stuck on the profile of the woman, bare chested, as she reached up, sliding her own shirt over her head. It had been brief, nothing more than a stolen glance, but Rio had paid the price of forgetting how to breathe.

It was a snapshot, a photo that she wasn't sure she should have gotten the chance to take, but it was there, locked away, those hues of dim orange light clinging to that bare torso in every right way, the long waves of her hair cascading down her back as her head tilted up to put the shirt on with ease. Her mind quickly scanned over the image in her mind, tracing over the curve of her breast from the side, the little pouch of skin that often signified childbirth, the tiniest bit over rollover at the waist of her underwear.

It had been a private moment, one Rio was certain she was not meant to see, but she coveted it beyond reason, nonetheless.

Agatha Harkness was a goddess, of that Rio was convinced.

Despite the swelling of heat and deep pulse in her center, Rio willed herself toward the bed, sliding in between the covers with ease, her eyes shimmering as Agatha did the same. The other woman reached over and turned off the light, leaving them cast in the shadows left by the projection of the television that was still quietly droning on in the background.

The two seemed to gravitate toward one another, meeting in a compromise at the middle of the bed, legs tangling with no effort. Agatha's arm felt strong and secure as it slid into place over Rio's side, holding her close. It was like the best version of any dream Rio could have ever had, to be held by Agatha, to be coveted by this absolute masterpiece of a human being. She had wanted it to keep going, didn't want the night to end, but she could feel the sleep winning out. Her eyes were growing heavy and her breathing was beginning to even out.

She could feel herself slipping; she could hear the faintest rumble of thunder outside and the sounds of the tv were still soft. However, as she would have a thought, it would glide from her grasp, falling away from her, leaving her wondering what she had just been thinking about. And then, like a shot in the night, a soft plea slipped from her half-asleep lips.

"Please don't leave in the morning," she requested in the smallest of whispers, as though she were a child begging for something they were scared they could not have.

The response was a pressing of lips to the skin of her forehead.

"I'm not going anywhere, darling."

Landing Feet First

Ayo, Ayo. I hope you weren't waiting long.
I hope this night makes up for time lost.
Feels like I met you years ago and
We're picking up right where we left off.

*****

There had never been a thought, the night before, to pull the curtains shut. It would explain, then, why Rio winced slightly at the light that poured into the room as she stirred to consciousness. It was so bright, nearly blinding, and it disoriented her, leaving her trying to place where she was and what was going on.

She rolled onto her back, her arms flat out on either side of her and a groggy sigh passed through her lips. She pulled her eyes open against the heavy weight of wanting more sleep, and if she had thought she was disoriented before?

It took all of three seconds for life to catch up with her. She was in America. In Los Angeles. She had come to find Agatha.

Agatha.

Rio's hand swatted at the side of the bed the other woman had been on, confirming there was nothing there. She felt her heart sink, her last words still ringing through her mind. She had asked her not to leave.

And she had left anyway.

Groggily, Rio sat up, wiping the sleep out of her eyes as she surveyed the room, first sweeping over to the bedside table on the far side of the bed. No phone.

Her gaze landed across the room, though, at that desk. There, still hung on the back of the chair, was Agatha's coat, and not half a foot away sat her purse on the desk. Something brimmed in Rio's chest, a blossoming warmth that she could feel creeping out of her chest and into every other part of her.

The question still remained: Where was Agatha?

She exhaled a long breath as she leaned back against the headboard and grabbed her own phone, pulling up her messaging app.

Shit.

She still didn't have her number. Her lips worried together for a moment as she stared down at the phone in her hands, realizing after a moment that she had somehow opened a text without realizing it, one from Estee.

"You okay, mama? How's it going?"

Suddenly, Rio felt a surge of guilt that she had not been communicating with her daughter since she had landed.

"Yes, mija. I found her. We drank at the bar here and had sushi. She stayed the night."
