Her grin was instant at her daughter's reply.

"You will definitely be giving me way more than that the next time we facetime."

She was still staring down, smiling stupidly at the sheer amount of joy she felt to be having that conversation with her daughter, even with the ocean between them. There was a sound, though, of the lock on the door clicking, which caused a wrinkle in Rio's brow.

The door swung open and in strode Agatha, that air of confidence and certainty about her as she held the door open. Another man in a uniform pushed a silver cart through the door with his head down, one that was laden with plates covered in cloches and chilled bottles of champagne and orange juice on the bottom level.

Rio's eyes danced with light, feeling completely and utterly flattered that someone had gone to such lengths just to make her feel good. Well, she wasn't certain if that was Agatha's motive, but it was exactly what was happening. Rio felt like a diety, like this woman was a patron of her shrine and would send whatever offering she could to please her, to make her feel coveted. It was working. All of it was working.

Agatha thanked the man and slid a bill into his palm -- a quirk Rio had noticed, tipping the help well -- and he turned, pulling the door shut behind him.

In an instant, Agatha's attention turned to her, full and focused. She felt like the sun, like Agatha just wanted nothing more to bask in the light of her presence. She clapped her hands together, glancing down at the cart. For the first time, she realized what Agatha was wearing.

She had put the shirt Rio had given her the night before on again and something in Rio's middle stirred at the fact that Agatha had dug just enough to pull out a pair of sweatpants that were a hair too short -- Rio's legs were not as quite as long as hers -- but they hugged every other part of her perfectly.

She eyed her, a dull ember flickering across her eyes.

"You went through my things?" she posed coyly, as if in challenge, though the struggle to keep the smile off of her lips was intense.

Agatha's face fell, her hands dropping as she realized the breach of privacy.

"I, um... I didn't think... I'm so--"

Rio's lips split into a full grin and she dissolved into laughter.

"It's okay. I'm not upset. I just wanted to give you a hard time."

The realization that she was not, in fact, in trouble settled over Agatha, the quick tension seeping out of her muscles with ease. Then, a flicker of mischief.

"I suppose in that case, all of this breakfast is for me?" she posed, raising a brow in a silent dare. She broke, though, only a moment later, pulling the cart a little closer.

"I didn't know if you were a sweet or savory breakfast person yet, so there's a benedict and an order of French toast, so I can take whichever you don't want. The bowl of fruit I figured we could share, and of course mimosas. "

Agatha was talking, and Rio knew what she was saying, but she wasn't listening -- not really. Instead, she was just staring, watching, understanding. She was realizing something very fast: Agatha cared. They had spent a total of two days together, with a month of time between them, and yet, in that moment? There was this mix of feeling like they were both in the beginning stages of attraction and also like they had been at this for a while. The ease between them was startling, and Rio was certain that the catch was coming, eventually.

For now? She would enjoy what she could get. And what she was getting? A woman who had ordered food and alcohol for breakfast and brought it up to the room? What on earth had she ever done to be so deserving?

She was struck with a thought.

"How did you get back in?" Rio posed, though Agatha was mid-move toward the desk with something pressed against her palm. She stopped and pushed it toward her fingertips, holding up the keycard. Rio grinned, a soft breath of a chuckle passing her lips as Agatha set it back down on the desk.

Agatha handed over the French toast, per Rio's request, and she could see the silent annotation; it had been something else to learn about her, something Agatha marked down with piqued interest.

They ate and discussed things like the weather, what there was to do on a Sunday, what the beach conditions looked like. They formed a basic outline of the things they might do throughout the day, but Agatha notated that she needed to run home for a few things first. Rio had, missing the beat, volunteered that it would give her time to shower and get ready. Agatha's face had fallen slightly, but it picked right back up after the passing of a second.

As they finished breakfast, Rio found herself staring down at the empty plate in front of her, a thought briefly springing to life in her mind.

Her voice was curious, not accusatory or harsh.

"Did you charge this to the room?" she asked softly, her gaze lifting to Agatha. The look she wore, the expression on her face had such a casual nonchalance.

"I did." She could tell that Agatha could hear her reaction, and picked it up immediately. "After I changed the payment information to my card."

"Agatha!" Rio's voice was sharp, but it was still warm. "You should not be paying for me to stay here."

Agatha shrugged, tipping her head back to down some of her drink.

"I don't have to, but I want to. And I will until you make the decision that you'd be comfortable enough to come stay with me, instead."

Rio blinked, stunned to silence. Agatha wanted to take her home? It had to seem stupid; Agatha had immediately been welcomed into her home, but Rio was well aware that it was only because of the circumstances. The fact that Agatha was looking her in the face, her sincerity practically bleeding through her, telling her that she wanted Rio's presence in her safe haven? It made her mouth dry, and made a pitch of nerves hike up her throat.

Her eyes softened as she beheld the other woman, a soft sense of regard washing over her.

"We will see," she offered back, though there was a hint of promise to her tone. She knew that if things continued the way they had been going since she arrived, it was inevitable but she did not want to put any undue pressure on the situation, or set any kind of an expectation. She did not want Agatha to feel like anything was owed, here, or like there was some set standard of what this was supposed to look like.

This was a mess, at first glance.

It seemed, though, that Agatha was willing to sit dutifully by her side as they sorted it out and untangled the threads of what had drawn them together. The attraction was undeniable, but what about what came after? What about when it came down to the nitty gritty? Sure, they had already started breaking those walls down, but when would it come? When would the moment hit when they realized that their vastly different lives would stand in the way of anything they might have hoped to build together?

Agatha was pensive, observant for a moment as she watched Rio, a fondness settling in her features.

"Do you want to go see it, at least? You can come with me while I change and re-do my face."

Rio's smile was soft and she gave a gentle nod. "Let me shower really fast," she offered, pulling the cover back so that she could prepare to get out of the bed, but Agatha's hand was instant on her wrist. Her eyes lifted, those beautiful blue pools of warmth and desire peering right into her soul. Agatha raised her other hand, cupping Rio's chin in a firm hold of affection.

She pulled her gently and Rio obliged, leaning into her, their lips brushing, softly at first, and then a little more firmly.

"Go on, hurry up!" she chided, giving Rio's cheek a soft pat as she quickly swiped another kiss before she leaned back against the headboard.

Rio was still grinning as she pulled herself from the bed and moved over to her bag, pulling out a change of clothes for the day. She doubled back to the bathroom, stealing a glance at Agatha over her shoulder, who was still watching her. She blushed under the heat of her gaze, tucking into the bathroom for a brief recovery.

Her shower was quick, and as she dressed and towel dried her hair, she found herself finding that dark reflection in the mirror, breaking if only just for a moment. What the hell was she doing? Who did she think she was to have Agatha Harkness sitting out there, waiting for her in the bed they had both slept in the night before?

She didn't know, but she wasn't going to stop the careening descent until someone made her.

She hung the towel and made her exit from the bathroom, those eyes landing on her almost instantly.

Agatha looked so... what was the word? Struck? Stunned? Taken aback? She just blinked at Rio, her lips slowly easing into a smile, an adoration overtaking her.

"You are so beautiful."

The blush was back instantly, heat pooling onto her cheeks and neck.

"You are the first to tell me, but with your sincerity, I am inclined to believe you," Rio shot back, her expression soft, reverent.

Agatha climbed out of the bed, having changed back into her clothes from the day before, and stepped up to Rio, her hands finding Rio's sides with a starling ease. They were close, and Agatha's eyes on her felt heavy, weighted, like she was doing that thing again where she was seeing far beyond her skin. Unnerving her. Leaving her restless.

Before she could dwell on it much longer, Agatha leaned toward her. There was no hold, no grip that was voicing what she wanted, but Rio understood it anyway. She met her, her own hands on Agatha's biceps as their lips met again, a kiss that was brief, but it said exactly what it needed to.

With another warm smile, Agatha grabbed her hand and they set about their day.

The car Agatha had called for had arrived and Rio watched with rapt interest as the world moved beyond them on the other side of those windows. The city was massive, and there was so much to see, even at a street level. It was incredible, really, but she was still aware, in the back of her mind, that Agatha was still clinging to her hand.

The car pulled out of the immediate city, the landscape beginning to fill out more with flat green areas, vineyards dotting them every so often. The longer they drove, the more the view continued to shift. Soon, they were rolling up the highway and Agatha gave a soft squeeze, pulling Rio's attention. As she looked over, Agatha was indicating the window and she followed, taking in what was across the highway.

It was blue and vast, and while Rio had spent the majority of her life on the water, seeing it like that, on the Pacific coast? It was breathtaking.

It was only a few more moments by the time the car slowed, pulling along a street that was incredibly long, each house having exponential space between it and the one next to it. They were massive homes, beautiful in their architecture and their presentation. Some of them were fronted with glass, some of them had keeps reminiscent of grand castles.

The car slowed and Rio's gaze swept to the view of the home outside of the window, an active battle taking over her as she tried to keep her mouth from falling open. The home was... massive. It was two stories, visibly, because she could not see the lower level from the front view of the house. There were two large garages, the doors a dark mahogany with ornate gold handles, trimmed with a dark brown molding.

It, as well as the rest of the house, was covered in a cream stone layout, giving it a legitimate castle feel. The house itself hung around in an angled shape similar to the letter 'j.' The shutters matched the color of the trim on the garage, and the windows were framed perfectly, set in just the right places. There were pillars that stretched from the overhang from the roof down to the balcony on the second floor, then down to the ground.

Rio was... verklempt. She didn't know what to say, or what to think. She had seen those glaringly obvious signs that Agatha was well off, including the three times she had tipped the wait staff at least a hundred dollars. Still, somehow it had not really set in until that moment that this woman was wealthy.

Agatha seemed to read the apprehension on Rio's startled expression and squeezed her hand a little tighter.

"We can have a conversation about it later," she offered in a gentle tone, her other hand reaching up to brush at Rio's cheek affectionately.

This seemed to satisfy Rio, who only let go of Agatha in order to climb out of the car and follow her up the walk to the home, still completely overwhelmed by the sheer size of it. If she had thought it was beautiful from the outisde?

She nearly lost her breath as they stepped over the threshold into the home. It was striking, the painfully white walls that were decorated in different pieces of framed art, the foyer opening up into a wide and open living room with a two story ceiling. There was a winding staircase to the left that led up the stairs, a balcony portion of the hallway bridging over the official entrance to the living space.

Rio could not hide the awe that had completely overtaken her. The further they went into the house, the deeper it ran. This was... amazing. As the room opened up, there was a fireplace on the far wall, carefully designed shelving on either side, and an incredibly large television bolted to the wall above the stone mantle.

In the middle of it all, a thought struck her.

That twenty inch television they had watched that night.

A soft breath of a laugh escaped her lips, but Agatha didn't seem to notice.

"This... it's really, really beautiful." Her compliment was genuine, and she could tell that she landed the way had hoped it would.

"Thank you. Make yourself at home, I'll be as quick as I can," she informed her, leaning in to press her full lips to the apple of Rio's cheek sweetly before she departed to shower and change.

I wonder if this is what she felt like Rio thought to herself when she was alone in my home.

The nosy part of her had surfaced and while she kept it mainly tempered and did not venture anywhere outside of the room she was in, she couldn't help but to want to inspect what she could see. The walls had varying styles of art, from Japanese Contemporary to Moorish Revival, and something in Rio told her that each piece had been specifically selected for reasons she could only hope to learn over time.

She turned her attention to the shelves on either side of the fireplace. There were decorative candles, small knick nacks, but most noticeably, there were several photos of Agatha and her son. Nicky.

Before she could think to stop herself, she reached forward, picking one in a black frame up off of the shelf, looking down at it.

Nicky looked younger than Agatha said he currently was, probably about fifteen, and Agatha was stood next to him, each of them securing the other in a one-armed hold. Agatha was wearing a fitted lilac gown, her hair twisted up into a bun, pinned tightly at the back of her head. Nicky stood beside her in a dark grey tuxedo, a bright and beaming smile on his face, his own hair pinned neatly atop his head in a tight bun, too, a few stray curls sticking out by his ears.

Most notably, there was a golden statue clutched in Agatha's hand. Judging by Nicky's age, Rio found herself safe in the assumption that it was probably a photo of the night Agatha had won her first Oscar. They both looked so happy, ecstatic in her victory. It was... touching.

She replaced it back in its spot on the shelf, shifting to look at other photos, most of them together, but a few stray ones of Nicky through the years, from a toddler to a teen. The most recent one, Rio figured, by the sight of the Burj Khalifa standing resolute in the background. He looked happy, looked like the world was in the palm of his hand, and the joy of it was resounding in his smile.

"Ahem," she heard over her shoulder, causing her chin to pull over it, a sheepish expression landing snugly over her. She was dressed smartly, though not entirely business. She had on a short sleeved lavender blouse that had one small flower embroidered into the corner of the chest pocket. A pair of slightly torn denim jeans hugged those slender, toned legs, and nude flats covered her feet. She looked so... effortless.

"I was just looking," she insisted, turning back to face Agatha, pacing over to her.

"I know. Because I'm guilty of the same thing, you just didn't happen to bust me."

Rio breathed a laugh, giving a shrug in agreement. She couldn't really argue that point.

"Shall we? I booked us a reservation at Redbird for lunch and then we can see where the day takes us."

"Do you always just... completely manhandle any situation you encounter?" Rio asked in astonishment, though there was the hint of amusement in her tone.

"I love it here," she said in a tone that was almost a correction, a reminder. "I want you to see all of my favorite parts." The words hung between them for a moment, and she watched as a silent battle waged within Agatha, and one side won as she spoke again, a daring sparkle in her eyes. "Maybe I can make you love it enough that you can't stand to be away."

Funny, Rio thought. If she was going to fall in love with anything enough to want to stay, it was certainly not going to be the city itself.

She caught herself at the tail end of that thought, startled at the ease with which it had come. While this was obviously an unconventional whirlwind, she still had to find a way to keep herself in check, to remind herself that everything about this was still fragile, and needed to be handled with care.

They departed the expansive home and made their lunch reservations, Rio seeming to eat up any moment of Agatha's time that she had to offer. They ate, shared a drink, and then spend the day venturing through the city. They would stop in the occasional store, browse, and move along to the next. Agatha would occasionally drop a little anecdote about a bar they passed, or a restaurant they had to try at some point, and Rio absorbed it all, every single droplet of knowledge careening right into her awaiting bucket.

By later afternoon, they found themselves on the patio of a restaurant on Venice Beach, two glasses of chilled white wine sitting between them. The conversation had hardly hit a snag all day; it was free flowing and easy, just a constant give and take of information, of personal facts, stories of life, and random knowledge.

Talking to Agatha was the easiest thing in the world.

The sun had set by the time they finished their meals and just as Rio was about to suggest that they could go back to the hotel, Agatha's eyes lifted, alight with an idea.

"Do you want to see if anyone left a fire burning?" Rio's brow wrinkled slightly in confusion, but Agatha's gaze swept to the sand. "On the beach."

The realization dawned on her and she followed the direction Agatha had been looking, seeing the faint orange glow of an unattended fire. She smiled warmly and gave a gentle nod. In a familiar move, now, she hardly had to look for it as Agatha's hand held out expectantly and Rio slid her own into it with utter ease.

They removed their shoes at the edge of the sidewalk and ventured out onto the sand, making their way over to the fire they had spotted from the patio. They placed themselves in front of it, the ocean casting out in a wide and open expanse just behind it, the moonlight dancing across it in fractured patterns, broken up by the waves.

She seemed to be locked into that moment, the vastness of it really touching something deep within her. There she sat, thousands of miles from home, missing her daughter like hell, but coping with it because the only thing she had wanted more was to find the woman that had turned her life upside down.

She had found her, and there they sat, thighs pressed together with Rio's hand cradled in both of Agatha's as she held them in her lap. It was a stunning snapshot of the pure chaos her life had become and yet, streaked across it, in every shift of the light, in every flicker of the stars, there was an undeniable beauty.

The universe had tipped Agatha over that bridge and into her life, and while she had momentarily been convinced that it was the only times their paths should ever cross, she was resolute in her understanding that her not coming to LA? It had never really been an option.

She leaned her weight into Agatha's side, her head tipping to lay on her shoulder, the quiet reverence settling around them as the sounds of the waves lapping at the shore echoed around them.

"Is this one of those moments?" Agatha asked in hushed tones.

"Hm?" Rio hummed in soft response, though she didn't move to look at her.

"The ones where you wonder if maybe there's a higher power out there?"

Rio released a soft sigh in thoughtful response.

"How did you know?"

"Because it is for me. Only because I know that even if I am my own god, most times, this? This is beyond me. I... couldn't have even written this."

Rio's head finally lifted, but it was a slow and tender motion, and she did not go far. She looked at Agatha's profile at close range, the dancing orange hues licking up her face. She leaned in a little closer, pressing her lips gingerly to Agatha's cheek.

"Fate, I suppose, is sometimes a kind mistress, too."

At this, Agatha's lips flickered up into a smile.

They sat like that for a little while longer, Rio's weight comfortably settled against Agatha, their hands together, the gentle and salty breeze of the ocean blowing over them. As the temperature began to sink, though, the cold began to set in. Agatha suggested they head back and Rio agreed easily, soaking in the last few moments on the beach as they waited for the car to arrive to pick them up.

They spoke in hushed tones as they recounted their day, the things they had seen and experienced, the way the city was full of wonder and astonishment. They recapped Rio's favorite parts, and as the car rolled to a stop in front of the hotel and they climbed out? She wanted to start it over, to live through it again. It had been truly perfect in the most simple way. How could what lay ahead of them be any better?

They entered the elevator and Agatha made the move without hesitation, pulling Rio into her side in a warm embrace, her lips pressing to the top of Rio's head. They stood like that, silently holding one another until the door opened and the finished the venture to Rio's room.

In an instant, Rio realized something. Agatha had a bag with her. The revelation made her stomach flip in delight. She didn't have to ask again; Agatha had made it clear that until Rio was ready to check out? She was going to be pretty present.

They parted and changed, and Rio was ready for the closeness climbing into that bed would have to offer. Her phone dinged on the nightstand, though, and the tiniest wrinkle formed in her brow. She lifted it up, turning the screen to face her as she looked down at her, a message from Estee sitting unopened.

She slid onto the bed, one leg hanging over the edge as the other folded in front of her. She unlocked the phone and opened the message, her breath catching in her chest at what she saw. It was a three word message, and it nearly ended Rio right then and there.

"Elias messaged me."

The tears were almost instant, stinging at the backs of her eyes. She fought them as hard as she could, but they still spilled silently down cheeks that were now flamed red. Her hands trembled and she felt a knot of emotion sitting dead center in the middle of her throat.

Agatha seemed to notice the stillness and the silence, almost immediately.

"Rio?"

But Rio didn't respond, she just stared at the message. Estee was undoubtedly waiting on a response, but Rio had absolutely no clue what to say.

"Rio..." Agatha said again, this time her voice a little more firm, trying to pull her attention. Slowly, the tears still rolling down her cheeks in steady streams, Rio lifted her head.

She could almost see it, the breaking of Agatha's heart in her chest. She just wanted to know what was wrong.

She was quick on her feet, gliding straight over to where Rio sat on the bed, placing herself on it directly in front of her.

"What's wrong?" Agatha tried to pull, so gently, as she reached forward and placed a comforting touch on Rio's arm.

"I... I..." she stammered, unable to look up and unable to form words. She was stuck, unable to speak more than a soft stutter of a beginning she couldn't finish.

Slowly and carefully, Agatha reached down and pulled the phone from Rio's hands, otherwise not doing anything with it aside from setting it down on the mattress next to them. She scooted forward, closer, and gathered Rio on her arms, tucking her head beneath her chin to compress her as much as possible.

Something had clearly upset her, and Agatha was under no misconceptions that it had anything to do with her, but she wanted to fix it, regardless. She understood pretty quickly that Rio was not immediately ready to talk and so instead, Agatha would do the only thing she could, which was to offer physical comfort.

Rio let her hold her, those tears having a hard time finding a way to dry. She knew she owed Agatha an explanation, but something in her was crushed.

"The man... that raped me, he reached out to Estee for the first time in her life."

She could almost hear it, beneath her ear: The distinct sound of Agatha's heart breaking. She could feel her lips on the crown of her head, which seemed to shatter her even further.

"I've got you, darling," Agatha soothed in a low murmur, her hand coming up to run comfortingly over her hair. "It's going to be alright."

In a moment when she shouldn't have, she put every bit of stock she had into believing the words Agatha said. Because if it wasn't?

She had no idea that she would do.

Someone Else's Arms

I just want to wake up in someone else's arms.

*****

For about fifteen minutes, that had been all Rio had been able to say. It was the only thing she had been able to manage, and only because she knew that it was a silent debt that she owed to the other occupant in the room. The reality of it was raining down on her like shattered glass, completely cutting her open one slice at a time, and there had been no shield.

At least, not the immediate instant the wound had been inflicted, the second in time when Rio had read that message.

In the minutes following? Agatha metaphorically had thrown herself into the line of fire, shielding Rio from the damage as much as she could. In the physical sense, she sat there, so patient and kind as she just kept her arms firmly around Rio's slightly smaller frame. Her fingers had not once stopped the gentle combing through her hair, and every so often, Agatha would breathe a phrase meant to offer comfort.

It's okay.

You're safe.

I'm right here.

Get it out.

Just keep breathing.

Despite the fact that Rio felt utterly lost in the flurry of every sour emotion that curdled in the pit of her stomach, she felt... grounded. There was a ribbon around her ankle as she began to drift, but Agatha was there, holding on for dear life. There was something in her grip that nearly shouted that she couldn't stand to let Rio get even an inch away when something was wounding her so badly.

They were strangers.

Agatha's question hung heavy in her mind in that moment:

"Do you believe in soulmates?"

The thought caused her to curl into Agatha further, tucking her face in the skin of her neck. She was still sniffling softly, and she knew that her reaction could be masked with the fact that she was already struggling. That one time, that one second, it was okay to keep it to herself.

"Hey," Agatha coaxed gently, her hand sliding out of Rio's hair and down to her back, rubbing a gentle path up and down it. She pulled back the slightest bit so she could look down, and Rio met her gaze with a broken resolve, though it was still actively cracking in the irises of her eyes. Agatha's other hand reached up, a finger curling affectionately under Rio's chin.

"Why don't you take a moment, sit outside, and call her?" she suggested, and Rio simply blinked at her in response. She didn't think the suggestion was stupid -- no, she thought herself to be a complete idiot for not having considered it sooner. What was more? Agatha had known. There hadn't been any prodding, any poking to try to understand.

She just... got it.

Rio sniffled again, reaching up to wipe at one cheek, though in the same instance, Agatha's thumb caught her other cheek, brushing the trail of tears away. She straightened up a little more, lifting her gaze to meet Agatha's beautiful blue one, that warm and too-kind smile gingerly gracing her lips.

She reached up, her palm soft as it cupped Agatha's cheek in an honest adoration. Her thumb brushed tenderly over the arch of her cheekbone for just a moment before she leaned forward, pressing their lips together warmly, fully. She just held it there for a long moment before their lips parted, but their foreheads were still pressed close. Her thumb hadn't stopped making its way across the mindless path on her cheek as the thoughts brewed behind her eyes. There was so much she wanted to say, so much she wanted Agatha to know, and yet? Nothing seemed to form.

Instead, something else blossomed inside of her: A gratitude that she could hardly contain.

"Thank you."

Agatha stole another soft brush of their lips, her own hand raising to brush her knuckles over Rio's cheek. She sat back, her eyes filled with this gentle appreciation, a full understanding that she might not totally understand, but she didn't need to in order to show compassion. Her chin tipped in indication toward the sliding doors of the balcony.

"Go," she instructed in something bordering on a whisper.

Rio was going to listen, but first, she simply sat. Her dark gaze wasn't intense, but it was critical, trying to pick this woman apart. She was trying to see where she was going to break. She was trying to envision however far in the future, just in what way this woman was going to completely crush her. Her palm was still idle on her cheek, though her thumb had since stilled.

Right then? After three entire days spent together, Rio had no clue how she'd survive any kind of fall out with Agatha.

Not when she was proving exactly the kind of person she was. Agatha was a rock. She was steadfast and resolute. She was unmovable.

After another beat, Rio seemed to snap back into the moment, her eyes meeting Agatha's across the small space between them.

"I'll be right back," she offered softly, unable to resist the urge to lean in and steal another quick peck, somehow knowing she was going to need the comfort it was able to offer, something to wrap around her as she headed into the night to have an impossible conversation.

Rio picked her phone up off of the bed and departed to the balcony, a defeated sigh passing through her lips as she folded into the lounger that was placed there. She glanced at her phone; it was just after midnight, which meant it was around eight back home, albeit the next day.

She stared at the contact page for her daughter, her mouth suddenly bone dry with the miserable anticipation that had overwhelmed her. There were questions they both needed answers to, though.

Before she could hesitate any longer, she pressed the camera icon as the FaceTime rang in. It only rang twice before the image of Estee's face was full across her screen.

Immediately, Rio noticed a few things. One: Estee's gorgeous green eyes were red and swollen, indicative that she had been crying. Two: There were faint lines of mascara streaking her cheeks, indicative of just how long she had been crying. Three: She had clearly just gone through the same ritual Rio had, of preparing herself to come face to face with someone she loved enough to try to hide her pain from.

"Oh, mija," Rio breathed, her lip quivering involuntarily at the sight. She could suddenly feel this immense ache as it pulsed and radiated through every inch of her being.

She hated seeing her baby upset.

Estee wiped at her face again, sniffling in spite of herself.

"What... what happened, mija?" Rio asked, her voice soft and low, her best attempt at being comforting from thousands of miles away.

Estee swallowed hard, clearly trying to compose herself.

"I... was on a date --" she cut herself off at Rio's expression, shaking her head. "Not now. Later, yes. But... it was a Facebook message request. I haven't even actually opened it, but... I can see what it says."

Rio could feel the flexing of her throat as it happened, a slow suffocation before she remembered that she could force herself to breathe. She was quiet, waiting for Estee to continue, but she could tell by the way her lips twisted that she was truly unsettled by it all.

"It said, 'Hey, I'm an old college friend of your mom's. I've been trying to get in touch with her. If you could have her reach out, I'd appreciate it.'" she read, though Rio could see the disgust bleeding onto her features. Estee knew who he was. She was the only one who had known who he was.

Rio forced down the peach-pit sized ball of anxiety and took a slow, steadying breath.

"Obviously, I think you should block him. On anything you can find him on. But..." Rio's eyes softened, taking in the disheveled state of her sweet girl. "Mija... tell me what you're thinking."

Estee's eyes lifted, looking somewhere off camera and Rio could see the tears glass them over. At the same time, the bobbing of her throat in her neck signified that she was angry, that she was upset.

"Sweetheart..." she prodded, but she could do what it was doing, so she fell quiet. She let Estee build her resolve, find the right words she was looking for. Her gaze dropped back to her phone and Rio could still acutely feel the shattering happening in her chest.

"I... Do you think it has to do with the pictures?"

At this, Rio's brow knitted together in confusion.

"Pictures? What pictures?"

Estee suddenly looked uncomfortable. She was chewing on the inside of her lip nervously, as if physically finding a way to not keep talking.

"Estee..."

"I... they turned up this morning, probably around your lunch time."

Rio's brows hiked, a silent prodding.

"There's... this website. It's called TMZ. It's pretty much a gossip rag."

Rio was still clearly not following, not even from the beginning. She was entirely lost, but she was using her judgment to try and understand that this was something Estee was truly struggling with.

"There's pictures of you and Agatha together. A few of you both on a patio, a couple of you walking down the street holding hands."

Rio had always heard people use the expression 'my stomach fell through the floor' many times in her life, but she had never really understood the depth or gravity of it, not until right then.

"Mija... I... I'm so sorry," she fumbled, her eyes wide in terror.

"Mama, stop."

"But I--"

"Mama."

Rio snapped her mouth shut, looking back at her daughter on her phone screen. Estee straightened up a bit, a sudden shift in the air around her.

"If it does, and he saw them and that made him reach out? Well, fuck him. I mean, fuck him regardless because he's human scum, but he doesn't get that, mama. He doesn't get to take this from you. Which, that brings me to my second point." Estee's brow's hiked, as if to signify that she was about to get serious. "In my twenty-one years on this earth, I have never, and I mean NEVER, seen you smile like that. In my LIFE!"

At this, a small smile automatically pulled at her lips.

"Really, though. You look... so happy. You look like you've gotten a peek at what heaven looks like."

Rio's expression softly as she considered.

"I just might have."

They talked for a few moments, the general heaviness of the moment having dissipated the more they spoke. It was hard, sure, but they would get through it. She had even asked, at one point, if Estee wanted her to come home. The response had been a chastising that she was still in school, so it wouldn't really much matter.

Rio leaned forward, announcing that she was going to turn in for the night. Before she could get to telling her that she loved her, though, Estee spoke.

"Mama, can I ask you something?"

"Of course, roo," she breathed, tilting her head slightly in curiosity.

Instantly, Estee's grin spread wide, ear to ear.

"Can I say hi?"

A blooming tenderness warmed Rio's cheeks as she gave a gentle nod and stood, carrying the phone inside.

"I have someone who would like to say hello," she announced softly as she took in the sight of the other woman for a tender beat. She slid onto the bed next to Agatha, who was sitting on her side of the bed -- her side of the bed -- and fit right up next to her. She held the phone up, that shit eating grin still plastered to Estee's face.

"Hi! I hear that you're taking good care of my mama," she teased softly, causing Rio to curl into Agatha a little more in mock embarrassment.

"I'm sure trying. It's very nice to unofficially meet you, Estrella," Agatha offered, and Rio felt it. In was instant, a washing of warmth, like running into a heated building on a subzero day. It started in her core, right in her very middle, and it shot out. It touched the end of every nerve she had, not only catching her breath, but stopping her heart for a split second in the process.

It wasn't just the fact that Agatha had used her proper name -- absolutely nailing the pronunciation -- it was the the sheer raw tenderness in her tone as she spoke to the most important being in Rio's life. It wasn't forced or fabricated. It was soft, natural. It was the tone of a mother.

"I did really just want to say hi, but..." Her gaze shifted from Rio to Agatha, a sweet smile forming on her face. "I'm really glad my mama met you."

Rio could physically feel it as Agatha melted, just the slightest bit, at the compliment.

"I'm pretty glad I met her, too," Agatha offered back tenderly, tilting her head to lay atop Rio's as it rested on her shoulder.

Estee's eyes shifted back to her mother, that same warm smile still on her lips.

"Te amo, mama," she offered softly.

"Te veo, mija. I'll check on you when I get up, yeah?"

"Sleep in. You deserve it."

Before Rio could protest, the video image cut and Rio breathed a soft laugh. All at once, Agatha shifted, pulling her arm out from between them so that she could secure it snugly around Rio's shoulders, her hand rubbing gently at her bicep.

"Are you okay?" Agatha asked her gently.

Rio looked down at the dark phone in her hands, considering for a moment. She inhaled a slow breath before she picked up her head, looking up at the woman beside her.

This beautiful, compassionate, extraordinary, sensational woman. This kind-hearted, bright, intelligent woman.

What on earth had she ever done to be worthy?

There was a soft flicker in Rio's eyes while she took a moment to gather her courage, the words sitting heavy in her throat.

"I wasn't. But... I am now. It... wasn't awful. Just... him trying to get in touch with me."

Rio had started to fidget with her fingers in her lap, picking nervously at her cuticles.

"But... she asked me if I thought it was because of the pictures. I had absolutely no clue what in the world she was talking about, obviously. But then..." Rio pressed her lips together, studying Agatha carefully as she continued. "Does TMZ mean anything to you?"

The question landed immediately, and Rio could see it was like a sucker punch. Agatha's eyes slid shut and she tipped her head back, knocking it against the headboard of the bed.

"Gods be damned," she groaned. She lifted her head again, her gaze sweeping down to Rio's face, a clear apology written there. "I... I am usually so good at sussing out the paparazzi. And, as of late, they hadn't really been bothering me. I guess I really failed to take the Oscars buzz into consideration."

Something formed, though, tugging on just the right muscles, pushing at all the right places on Agatha's face. It was this clear mixture of realization and utter wonder.

"What?" Rio prodded, her eyes never moving.

"It was my fault."

"Agatha--"

She shook her head, holding up a finger as if the thought were still forming in her head. Her eyes landed back on Rio's face, though, and there was the tiniest flicker of mischief that faded into something more... soft.

"I didn't notice because I wasn't looking. I wasn't looking because I have a really hard time looking at much else that isn't you when you're in my immediate vicinity."

Flattered? Understatement. Smitten? It was a step in the right direction. Infatuation didn't feel like it fit right.

Rio landed on it, going off like a lightbulb over her head.

She was so wholly enamored with Agatha Harkness.

"Did you know..." Rio began, reaching up to brush a few light fingertips across the side of Agatha's neck, "that almost every time you have something to say, my heart stops beating so I can hear you clearly?"

An amused and thoroughly delighted grin split Agatha's lips, her eyes wrinkling at the corners with it's width.

"That kinda sounds like me when you smile," Agatha countered, raising her eyebrows in playful contest. "The whole breathing thing starts feeling like a sham for a few seconds there."

There was a gentle, sweet giggle that flittered off of Rio's lips, but she was stuck, so pulled into the way she felt when she basked in those beautiful blue hues. The air around them condensed for the briefest second, almost like there was something unspoken between them, something neither of them were ready to say.

Rio had considered herself to be a sane person through most of her life.

Sitting there, meeting Agatha's reverent gaze?

She had to be insane, sitting there thinking about how she could have just said it, and actually meant it. She could have just pushed it out and hoped for the best.

No, she told herself, there would be more time for that. More time that, perhaps, might not make her look so damn insane.

Instead, her hand planted more firmly to the side of Agatha's neck, her fingers curling around into her hairline. With a gentle tug, she pulled her the slightest bit closer so that their lips could meet. It was soft, patient, thankful. It was a show of appreciation for literally every single thing she had done that day.

How many times was she going to get to kiss her, eyes closed, before she opened them to realize that Agatha had been nothing more than a figment of her imagination?

The reality of it was that in this life and on this plane, they had known each other a few days.

In the very far reaches of the essence of who Rio was as a human being? She felt like she'd known Agatha as long as the universe had been in existence. It was this deeply seated familiarity, this rooted feeling that something about their souls, something about their very existences were meant to collide in this world, in this time, but perhaps not for the first time.

In her grand debate over religion, rebirth was not a theory Rio had ever entertained. However, the longer she sat there, kissing Agatha and feeling her swallow every bit of her sadness and despair, she considered it. This was not their first time knowing one another. It simply couldn't be.

Maybe, she thought as Agatha pulled back for a soft breath, I just might believe in soulmates.

Agatha's fingertips still lingered on her own cheek, the wonder simply sitting over them, pinning them in the moment.

"Do you want to lay down?" The question was a genuine question, not an invitation. Rio was sure that Agatha was reading every bit of the emotional hangover mixed with her exhaustion as it was so plainly decorating her features.

Rio nodded her head gently and they moved around just enough to get under the duvet after Agatha shut off the light.

Like a magnet, Rio gravitated into her side, her head finding a home on Agatha's chest, that soft thump of her heartbeat a steady lifeline beneath Rio's ear.

The room fell quiet, the TV off this time, and Rio let her eyes fall closed. She could feel the exhaustion in her bones, but she couldn't shut her mind off, couldn't make it stop. She just kept thinking about it, about the way Agatha had reacted to seeing her in distress.

Rio had been taking care of herself for an incredibly long time. She couldn't even really lay claim over to having an actual relationship. She had been a lonely woman, but it had always been by choice. She had done what she thought was best, not only to protect Estee, but perhaps to protect herself, too. After all, the brightest light in her life was born out of darkness. People were wicked and cruel. She knew that all too well.

But then... there was Agatha. Rio had been able to glimpse a few different sides of Agatha over the course of the last couple of days, and what Rio saw? It was a complex piecing together of so many various things. There was that tenacity that Rio adored, then the absolute intelligence that radiated off of her. She was authoritative, undoubtedly from being a woman in a very male-dominated industry, but she also showed gratitude.

Agatha, Rio realized, had a very stern understanding of the world, and while she could use it to be stern herself when needed, she also had the knowledge to know when life called for more tender moments.

She was a complex masterpiece, and Rio was completely of the understanding that she had barely scratched the surface.

The time had ticked on as her thoughts ran laps around the inside of her skull, and as she became aware of the room around her, she realized that Agatha's heartbeat had softened and her breathing was far more slow and even than it had been.

Rio squeezed her eyes shut, confident that the other woman was asleep, her soft whisper so quiet that it barely touched her own ears.

"I'm not ready to love you yet, but I think I do already."

***

As Rio's consciousness slipped back into her physical form, she became hyper-aware of something in the entire two seconds it took her to take a breath:

For the first time in her entire life, Rio had woken up in someone else's arms.

There was a strong sense of comfort in the snug hold of Agatha's arm wrapped around her middle. She could feel, with almost intense awareness, every single place that Agatha's front was pressed her back, including the way her face was nuzzled into Rio's shoulder.

Breaking that moment was absolutely not an option, and so, Rio laid there, just reveling in what it felt to be held by someone, to be cuddled by another person. Rio felt safe in the assertion that she had literally never shared a bed with another adult, in her entire adult life, until she had found herself laying next to Agatha.

She didn't want to find out what it would feel like to lay next to anyone else.

After a short while, she heard Agatha draw in a breath -- likely the first of consciousness -- and the hold around her middle tightened.

"Mmmm," Agatha hummed into the back of Rio's neck, a truly warm and happy sound, one that touched Rio dead center in her chest.

"Good morning, beautiful," Rio cooed, her own arm draping over Agatha's, her thumb brushing softly over the warm skin there.

"Do we have to get up?" she questioned in a tired grunt, snuggling in even closer.

"I mean, we don't have to, unless you have anywhere to be," Rio answered, her voice light. After a moment, she shifted, turning to roll over in Agatha's arms. Their legs wove together in an act that almost felt too intimate for where they were in the relationship, but the feeling it caused inside of Rio? It felt too good, and she wasn't going to give any credit to those voices in the back of her head that kept insisting she needed to keep herself grounded in reality.

Maybe Agatha was her reality now.

There was a soft air of calm over them, but it was shattered as Agatha sat up, her eyes wild, as if she had just realized something.

Rio pushed herself up, too, looking at Agatha with mild worry and more intense confusion.

"It's Monday," she hissed, reaching over for her phone to see what time it was. "And I am forty minutes late to a meeting with my casting director." She sighed, moving to type a couple of messages before she tossed the phone on the bed, sighing softly.

"Well, crisis averted. She figured when I hadn't texted her by nine thirty that I was likely not going to make it. But..." her eyes swept up to Rio, as if considering. "I do have some paperwork to do when it comes to filing for filming permits. You don't have to, but you can come to the office with me, if you'd like."

Rio could tell just by the look on her face that Agatha knew it wasn't an exciting invitation, but it was still one that she could extend to show that she really was only leaving because she needed to, and not because she wanted any amount of space between them.

"I can bring a book," Rio suggested, as if that were enough of an answer to the question.

"Do you wear reading glasses?" Agatha asked, though Rio did not miss the way she quirked one brow.

"Regular ones. But I keep contacts in about ninety eight percent of the time," she admitted with a soft laugh. "But I have them, if you'd prefer I wear them," she teased, a small wrinkle forming in her nose as she scrunched her face.

"Let me see them," Agatha beguiled, her eyes dancing with an excited light.

Rio heaved a sigh and removed herself from the bed, making her way over to her bag so that she could rummage through it, pulling out her glasses case. She snapped it open and removed them, sliding them onto her face before she lifted her head. She couldn't see anything through the double prescription, but it accomplished the task she had set out to do. The frames were thick, but not too thick, and a marbled blue all the way around. They weren't completely square, but they fit Rio's face perfectly.

She could hear it from across the space between them, that sharp intake of air as Agatha's bottom lip was pulled between her teeth.

"Verdict?" Rio posed innocently, reaching up to slide them off, her gaze casting back up to Agatha.

"Contacts out. All of the time. Don't ever wear a single contact again," Agatha nearly gushed, the adoration clear in the look she was wearing. Her laughter was such a sweet sound, but Rio knew she was, in fact, being very serious.

"Glasses it is, then," she mused.

They busied themselves with getting ready for the day -- which had come to include Rio taking her contacts out -- and had regrouped a few minutes later as Agatha called for the car.

That softly flickering affection seemed to follow them everywhere they went, as long as they were together. Even as they spent a small chunk of the afternoon in Agatha's office, Rio lounging on the sofa with a book propped on her knees, she had the stunning realization that there was literally nowhere else in the world she would have rather been.

She had caught it -- a couple of times -- the way Agatha kept staring. Rio would glance up for the briefest moment to see Agatha scribbling at the papers in front of her and then turn her eyes back to her book, only to feel a gentle heat creep over her skin. Her gaze would flicker, ever so slightly, as it met Agatha's for a brief second and the other woman shyly diverted her gaze, though the smiles that curled both of their mouths at the same time matched in perfect harmony.

The sun was still shining, but Rio could tell that it had started sink the slightest bit in the sky, an indicator that sunset was approaching.

"I'm almost finished, here. You ready to blow out of here?" Agatha asked from behind her desk and Rio perked up a bit, looking across the room at her.

"Of course."

"I have to admit, I'm not quite so ready to give up the view of you on that couch, with that book, in those damn glasses."

Rio's cheeks flushed with the flattery, her eyes diverting only for a moment before they flickered back up, taking Agatha in.

"I can read in the hotel, too," she mused back, sitting up a little more.

Agatha leaned forward, resting her chin on her the backs of her hands, her elbows on the desk. There was that soft reverence again, that measured intake of all that she saw before her.

She's looking through me again.

"There's somewhere I'd like to take you, first." Her words were so sure, so decisive. She knew that she could write the entire playbook and Rio would follow it to a t. She had to know.

"Do I get to know where?" Rio posed curiously, closing her book. She rested it atop her thighs, leaning forward in interest.

"Somewhere on the beach," Agatha offered back vaguely, though a sly smile played at her lips. There was very obviously something she was failing to include, but this mysterious side of her seemed to suit her well.

"Well, then. I suppose we have somewhere to be."

Agatha's entire demeanor had shifted upon Rio's agreement; she was even lighter, bubbling with something that, if Rio had to name it, seemed pretty close to complete excitement.

Most of the car ride up the coast was filled with Rio asking probing questions, trying to deduce what it was that Agatha had up her sleeve, but Agatha remained tight-lipped, though her laughter at Rio's often outlandish guesses was unrivaled in the sound of its pure joy.

After about forty minutes, the car turned into a large lot, the beach opening out in its expanse on the other side. Rio eyed Agatha with a sizzling curiosity, something that was nearly crackling just above her skin.

With ease, Agatha slid out and offered her hand to Rio, who took it happily and filed out behind her. Her questions had subsided, now that she realized that she was on the verge of getting the answers she had been asking for. She let Agatha guide them, pulling her down to the sand and around a bend of trees that jutted out, obscuring the view Rio now took in.

There were about eight horses being tended to or drinking water out of a trough, their lead lines slung around a long wooden hitching post. There were saddles slung over a smaller stand in varying sizes, some laying on the ground in front of it.

Rio's eyes widened in surprise as she fully digested the sight before her.

"Agatha... I can't ride a horse."

Agatha waved a hand, a sweetly dismissive gesture. "I wasn't banking on you being able to. I can. So you'll saddle with me."

Rio blinked at her, clearly stunned. She took just a moment before she finally found her words.

"Are you literally asking me to go on a horseback ride with you at sunset?"

The pride settled on Agatha like a warm coat, hugging all the right places. That grin she was wearing? In the light of the now-setting sun, it stole Rio's breath right off of her lips.

"And if I am?" Agatha posed. "Are you really going to tell me no?"

Rio softened in her entirety, a raw moment of honesty slipping through the cracks.

"Honestly, Agatha? I'm not sure there's much you could ever ask of me that I would say no to."

Capsize

Three words never come easy
But you're more than they ever could be.

*****

Rio liked to read. That was about as much of a natural fact of order as stating the sky was blue. She read a lot. She read everything. She could immerse herself in every type of fiction with ease, but a lot of non-fiction seemed to pique her interest as well. She had books upon books about different plants and how to care for them back home, something she had indicated to her neighbor when she had left, and the other woman had agreed to tend to the ones she had.

Rio had read many romance novels in her time and yet, as her head turned, those burning green eyes casting out on the dancing lights of that setting orange sun, the jolting feel of the horse beneath her? Her arms tightened a bit subconsciously around Agatha's middle, holding herself the slightest bit closer. She had no qualms about falling off, but this was something she wanted to be close to Agatha for.

She had been able to tell instantly, the moment she had started laughing as the horse began to move, that Agatha was enraptured, that she was hanging on literally every single moment of the exchange like it was her whole reason for being. There hadn't been a time yet, since they had left that alcove, where Rio had not caught sight of Agatha's profile as she glanced over at any time when it was lacking a positively elated smile.

She was stuck in that feeling of being in-between worlds, a feeling that she'd not had in quite some time. A feeling that had felt nothing like this did. This sense of dissociation was brought on by the fact that in less than 72 hours, her entire life had become something she had not recognized. In less than three short days, almost everything she had held solid convictions about in life was suddenly out the window.

A week ago, Rio Vidal would have insisted with absolute authority that she would never be the kind of woman to fall in love. Life had been too fickle to her, had taken too much, and she was resolved in needing no one else. Romance was always a fond thought, but she was a realist in a world filled with dreamers.

At least, she used to be.

She was there, right there, ultra-aware of every movement of the beast beneath her, every breath that the woman in front of her took. She was acutely aware that if she moved her hand just a few inches, she would have the firm and steady beating of Agatha's heart right beneath her palm.

There, she could feel it. She could feel the confirmation that if she was spinning into insanity? That thumping proved to her that she wasn't alone. That rhythm was becoming a familiar drumline, a steady echo of the beating in her own chest.

That thin line of connection seemed to glow hotter as Rio held on, immeasurably moved by the sight of the sun as it sank with finality into the ocean.

Agatha clicked her tongue, her heels giving a gentle squeeze into the side of the horse, causing its gait to slow to a gentle stroll. For the first time, Rio managed to tear her eyes away from the horizon to see where it was they had arrived.

She blinked; it was a dead end, a jetty of dark slate stone that erupted and shot every which direction.

The horse moseyed toward the brush, a very obvious hitching post sticking out of the ground. It was like muscle memory for him, it seemed. Agatha adjusted slightly in the saddle, reaching down with one hand to give Rio's arm a light pat to signify that it was okay to release her hold. Rio obliged, her arms loosening before they dropped. With ease, Agatha slid out of the saddle, her feet hitting the sand beneath her soundlessly.

Rio's gaze cast down, taking in the sight of that woman there beneath here, looking up at her like she might as well have been that sun, been that one setting in the sky. In a gesture that was becoming commonplace Agatha behavior, her hand raised, waiting for Rio's so that she could help her off of the horse and they could trek a little further.

Without a moment's hesitation, that familiar meeting of their palms happened and she succumbed to the warmth it had to offer. She shifted, swinging her leg over so that she could drop down, landing on both feet as she swooned slightly into Agatha, who wrapped her up in an embrace as if it were completely natural.

Rio realized something, her gaze casting around before it landed back on Agatha, illuminated in the most stunning orange lights from the reflection of the sun on the water. They were alone.

"What are we doing here?" Rio probed curiously, her arms wrapped around Agatha's neck as she looked up at her, beholding her with that smoldering adoration.

"We're not 'here' yet," Agatha divulged, the smallest sparkle of excitement flickering in those gorgeous blue pools. She gave Rio's hand a light squeeze at the precise moment she leaned in to steal the briefest kiss. Her hold on Rio concurrently released and she stepped back so that she could begin to lead the way on the rest of their short trek.

Rio's eyes swept, filled with a quiet curiosity as she let Agatha pull her along, toward those rocks. The closer they got, the better she could see it. There was a path, a little winding of flattened stone that lifted up the scape of rocks on one side.

"I'm glad you're wearing sensible shoes," Agatha offered with a soft laugh as they began the small hike. It only took a moment to reach the precipice, a peak that mounted in the middle of a large break in the stone, and it was followed immediately by a six step descent.

They hit the sand, and for a moment, Rio was still so struck by the wonder she felt when she looked at Agatha that she did not think to survey their surroundings.

Her eyes slowly tore from Agatha's smile to take in where they actually were.

That wall of rock that they had passed through tangled out toward the ocean, curving in before them in some sort of haphazard cave. The angle of the light from the mouth of the cave poured in at just the right angle, in just the right way that caused the reflections to dance on the overhead slate like an endless sparkling of thousands of diamonds.

Rio was completely taken. This was a secret. This was something Agatha kept close to the vest. It was something she was choosing to share with Rio, not only because Rio had indirectly asked, but, she sensed, because Agatha had been waiting for this moment for some time.

She didn't have to say it, but Rio saw it. It was that unmentioned shield that Rio could always see, hanging braced on Agatha's arm, invisible by her side. She had gathered that although she had received nothing but the most gentle demeanor from Agatha since the moment they had met, she had faired through her own hells and was ready, at any given moment, to throw that shield up and keep the world out.

Rio was thankful, really, that she hadn't tried to keep her out.

She would have had every reason. That afternoon in front of her office could have gone a very different way if Agatha had chosen, in that moment, to protect herself instead of embracing the endless wild of fate, instead of choosing to trust Rio to not hurt her.

Rio was an understanding person, and if she had not been in the position they were in, she could not say with any predetermined amount of certainty that she would have trusted someone who was in the position she now stood resolute in.

Nothing in Rio wanted to see anything out of Agatha other than joy and light, happiness and exhilaration. She was not foolish enough to think that, if somehow this managed to pan out, they would never know struggle in their lives, but there was some thread of comfort to be found in the idea that maybe it was something neither of them would have to shoulder alone.

She was getting ahead of herself again.

Tuning back into the moment, her gaze landed into that burning hot stare, a shimmering of pure... unadulterated... merriment. Her arms were snug around Agatha's neck, and their chests brushed just noticeably.

Rio's own chest tightened in a way she couldn't ignore, and she realized that it was because she had stopped breathing the moment their eyes had met. She exhaled the breath she had been holding, her fingers rolling a few strands of Agatha's hair, placed at the base of her neck, between them.

They were so close that Rio could have kissed her, but there was something more in the moment. It was weighted, but it was comfortable, form fitting to the moment. Her lips worried together for a moment as she debated what it was she wanted so badly to say, so badly that she could feel it boiling in her chest.

Finally, as she picked up the thread of where she wanted to go, she began to pull, not realizing that as she did so, the long thread wound around and out of sight, swinging behind her, weaving into who she was as a woman.

A tug, the loosening of her own threads, just beyond her own comprehension, done by herself.

"I want to tell you something that's going to make me sound like a really sad and pathetic person, and if you become of the immediate opinion that you should need to head for the hills, it would be completely understood."

The curiosity in Agatha's gaze was gentle, her eyes soft as she understood the weight of what she was being offered. She gave a slight tip of her head, a silent encouragement for Rio to continue.

Those few strands of hair felt so smooth as she focused on rolling them between her thumb and forefinger, grounding her in the moment. It tethered her solidly to Agatha.

"I have never been in a relationship. I've... I mean, I had my fun in college, but... when life happens at nineteen, you just kind of become disinterested." Rio's throat bobbed with nerves, her gaze having fallen to just over Agatha's shoulder, and attempt to keep some form of control, and to shy away from the feeling like Agatha was looking directly into her again.

"Hell, the last time I even slept with a woman, I was in my first year of uni. Christ." A nervous laugh escaped her lips, and she had turned her gaze even more, an additional shifting of her head. She felt it all at once, though, that light hold on her chin that dragged her right back into the abyss of warmth and comfort that was Agatha.

"You can keep going. It's okay. It's just you and me," she encouraged, her hand moving just enough so that she could cradle Rio's jaw in her palm.

Rio's eyes took her in, so close, so warm, so gentle.

"I have been alone the entirety of my adult life. And I have always been okay with that. The thought of being inexperienced in bed, or not knowing how to properly operate in any kind of romantic entanglement? Well, they were enough to remind me why I was so steadfast in my want -- no, my need -- to be alone."

Rio's lips twisted uncertainly, her eyes flickering over the entire landscape of Agatha's face, trying to read what her response was going to be.

"For over twenty years, I have been at peace with the fact that Estrella is my entire world. I have faired just fine, every night for the entirety of that time, falling asleep and waking up alone. But... for the first time in my life, I woke up this morning to being held... held by you."

There was this wave that washed over Rio's face; it was a flash of warmth, but it was tinged by something else, by a sense of fear.

"And I... I'm already dreading the moment when we decide it's best for me to go back home."

The shift in Agatha was visible, almost tangible. For as squared and strong as Agatha's posture always was, it was clear that something had softened her immensely. Her hands lifted from the homes they had settled into on Rio's sides, so gentle and careful in their movements as she cupped either side of Rio's jaws.

She leaned in, their faces close, but she stilled, her eyes fluttering shut. Her thumb swiped a soft line along Rio's cheek and she pressed their foreheads together, a soft sound escaping her, something that tried hard in its efforts to be a laugh, but did not quite make it.

"I just got you," Agatha breathed at her in a heavy whisper, the way her head moved as she spoke causing their lips to brush, just barely, with her words. "Don't make me think about having to let you go, yet."

It was a soft plea, and yet, it boomed like cannons in the night.

For as deep into this as Rio knew she had become, she still had these moments of wonder where she was hit with the weight of the realization that the feelings between them? It wasn't some fabrication, some willing of her own desires. It was mutual. It was a give and take, a solid foundation if they truly did have hopes of finding a way to build something a little more sustainable.

Their faces hung like that, so close that she could almost taste Agatha's breath, sweet with the remnants of the tea she had been drinking in her office.

"I could kiss you until my lungs explode, you know?" Rio offered softly, keeping hold so that as she spoke, that brushing happened again, her eyes boring daringly close into Agatha's.

Agatha's grin was instant, her thumbs brushing over Rio's cheeks tenderly again.

"Give the arm a good ol' double tap when you're getting to that point and I'll give you a breather, hm?" Agatha coaxed in a low, sultry murmur.

Before Rio could even think about forming any kind of response, the swell of Agatha's tide washed in, their lips meeting in a tender display of affection. It felt like her legs had been swept out from beneath her. It always felt like that, every single time Agatha kissed her.

Her grip tightened a bit around Agatha's neck, pulling her closer, kissing her a little harder.

Her life was a literal fucking fairytale. They stood there, in the middle of that little cavern as the diamonds of the setting sun sparkled on every surface around them, the water clear and cool at their feet. There they stood, kissing each other like it was the only single fact in the universe that made absolutely any sense. They just... were, in that moment.

The rest of the world? Gone.

The thoughts about what had happened the night before? Carried away by the gusts of wind that whipped wildly whenever Hurricane Agatha blew in.

Agatha was the most beautiful storm Rio had ever stared in the eye.

There was a silent pang in Rio's chest, a pang of wanting.

What I would give to feel her thunder in my teeth, to be lit up by every bolt of lightning she could strike me with.

Breathless, they parted, instant and warm smiles reflecting as they peered across that small space at one another.

"We should probably head back before it's completely dark," Agatha suggested, reaching up with a tender hand to tuck a strand of hair behind Rio's ear.

Rio gave a nod, though she was quick in stealing one more soft, fast kiss. They turned and made their way out of the cove to the awaiting horse, who's gentle trot carried them back to the section of the beach where they had been dropped off. As she unseated from the horse and Agatha turned to take care of everything else, Rio found herself wandering just slightly, soft footfalls carrying her a little further toward the water.

How was any of this real? How had it happened that not only had she somehow lunged into this whirlwind romance, but that she had seemingly found the most ideal partner to do so with in the entire world? This dance was a carefully executed one; while it was a flurry of mostly positive emotions, Rio knew that this was going to take thought, and problem solving if they hoped to lay any kind of foundation for a future.

Was that what Agatha would want? Before she could cynically provide her own answer to that question, though, she felt a pair of arms snake around her waist, securing around her firmly. The scent of Agatha's shampoo was strong and immediate as she felt the other woman rest her chin on her shoulder.

"Admiring the view?" Agatha murmured softly, tilting her head forward so that she could place a soft kiss to the seam of Rio's shirt on her shoulder.

Rio breathed a soft chuckle, her head turning just enough so that she could nuzzle into Agatha's hair.

"Holding an existential debate, actually," Rio corrected playfully. She could feel Agatha shift slightly behind her.

"Yeah? About what?" she asked curiously.

An amused smile curved Rio's lips and she closed her eyes, breathing in that scent of vanilla and lavender, that scent that had become so familiar to her in the last few days.

"About how to identify deities."

"Mmmm," Agatha hummed in thought, a warm delight buzzing in her tone. "Thinking about subscribing to a new religion?"

"That depends. Where's your temple of worship?"

The question landed exactly how Rio had intended it, though there were layers to such an response, ones she could really break down and dissect if Agatha asked her to, but not right then.

Right then? Rio was acutely aware of the sharp draw of breath by her ear and the subtle tightening of Agatha's arms around her middle. Her face turned and Rio instantly felt the warmth of her face as Agatha tucked it into the crook of her neck, holding her there firmly, steadily.

"Stop that," Agatha chastised in a low murmur, almost a growl, something that reached into the depths of who Rio was and struck a match.

She hummed an inquisitorial response, and after a moment, Agatha lifted her head to respond.

"You're trying to mess up my plans," she purred into Rio's ear, gracing it with a barely there brush of her lips that sent goosebumps cascading onto every single inch of her skin.

"I was unaware of such plans. How could I be trying to mess them up?"

Agatha's hold on her relinquished, and for a moment she found herself disappointed, but the turnaround was relatively fast as Agatha's hands found her hips and physically turned her around. One arm looped around her waist, pulling her in close, their faces a mere breath away.

"You, Rio Vidal, have messed up my plans since the moment you whistled at me from across the water. You don't have to actually try." A flicker of light danced in Agatha's eyes and she tilted her head affectionately at the woman before her.
