It was just that soft reverence, a way to bask in the moment that was bonding them together even further.

"Who the hell are you?" Rio finally managed, her whisper husky despite her genuine quest to attain that answer.

Agatha seemed to let this land a little deeper, the answer forming in the depts of those cerulean irises.

"Someone who is completely enamored by everything that you are," she admitted in the quietest of whispers.

She didn't say it, but Rio still heard it.

Someone who, for some insane reason, has completely fallen in love with you over the course of three days.

Her lips twitched in a smile, though it was in response to both of Agatha's answers, spoken and unspoken.

Same, Agatha.

In that moment, their eyes met again and there was this sobering moment where Rio actually considered the possibility that Agatha could truly read her mind.

The moment was thick, heavy with the weight of their unspoken feelings nestling between them. It felt almost tangible, the way Rio simply couldn't put any of what was going on inside of her into words. She had to find a way. She needed to make Agatha understand what she was doing to her, how she was opening her up and nurturing every piece of her without even actually trying.

Rio's words were soft, but they lost their timid edge by the time she finished speaking.

"I want to touch you."

Agatha's eyes widened slightly in her surprise, though a softness still shone in them, mixed so completely with the desire that was washing over her.

"Touch me."

Skin & Bones

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Baby I just think that you need someone to be true to you
I know how to heal your heart.

*****

Permission.

As it turned out, all Rio had simply needed was to be given the permission to find a way to funnel what it was she was feeling into some form of expression. All she had needed was for Agatha to look into her eyes, to stare right into her exposed soul, and tell her that it was okay.

She took it for everything it was worth in that moment, but it was perhaps not in the way that Agatha had anticipated with just how much weight there had been hanging over them.

Rio was precise in her movements, raising a single finger to place it in the space between Agatha's eyebrows, tracing it lightly down the length of her nose. Her eyes stayed locked on Rio's though, and she felt a ripple of nerves was through her. She didn't let it touch her face, but it was the reason for her next request, even if she could have passed it off by insisting she thought Agatha should get the same experience she'd had.

"Close your eyes," Rio breathed, her tone silky and smooth, but also sultry in its own gentle way.

Agatha stilled, her eyes locking into Rio's, a flash there that Rio could not immediately name, but then it settled into her very being.

Agatha was always in control. She had a firm hold on life and directed it more firmly than she directed her own films. She did what she could to make life bend to her will, and she was good at it. It was why she had the power, the station that she did.

What completely struck Rio in that moment was that from the literal second their eyes met, Agatha perched on that bridge and Rio hanging over the rail of her deck to try and get her attention, Agatha had been losing control.

Rio was an uncontainable entity, and Agatha really had said it best: Rio, in her purest form, was controlled chaos, and that was why Agatha was so drawn to her.

This time, it was Rio who took the chance to assure Agatha.

"It's okay. I promise."

That unfamiliar vulnerability was still soft in Agatha's gaze, but after another breath, she let them flutter shut, leaving Rio celebrating the gravity of the concession. In the way that Rio had trusted Agatha, Agatha was returning the favor.

Gingerly, a few of her fingertips raised, gracing light lines along Agatha's hairline, still damp from their shower. She started on one side and ventured to the other, caressing light lines along the frame of her face. She trekked over her temple, over the little hump of the outside of her cheekbone, down to her jaw. She traversed the angle of it, tracing the tips of those fingers along the length of it, to her chin, and doubled back on the other side. It curved up, back up the other side of her face, a couple of fingers deliberately brushing over her ear as her hand made its way back up.

Both hands then raised, landing on the sides of her face, leaving space for her thumbs to hover over her cheeks in their movement, a not-quite-there touch that, by the look on Agatha's face, she still felt. She drew her hands back, dragging the tips of her fingers along both sides of Agatha's neck until they met at the center of her throat. One hand dropped, but the other touched the very tip of her chin, a light press that silently commanded action.

Wordlessly, Agatha heeded Rio's request and tipped her head back the slightest bit, the edge of her lip pulling between her teeth in heated anticipation.

Rio couldn't help the small smirk that curved her lips; it felt good to be in that woman's lap, and yet, Agatha was the one who was putty in her hands. For as much as she had insisted that there was little she would say no to when it came to Agatha, she was starting to realize that it was more of a mutual understanding than something that only went one way.

That touch, that feather of contact drifted down, right down the center of Agatha's throat, causing it to quiver the slightest bit as it tightened within her. As she reached the base of her neck, though, she lifted her finger and instead moved to touch the spot just beneath Agatha's ear, causing her to draw in a sharp breath; she'd obviously hit a spot. She let her touch glide down, over the crook of her neck and over the top of her shoulder. It ventured down, sliding over the length of her bicep to her elbow, then down to her hand, which she pulled into both of her own.

She looked down at it, but glanced back up at Agatha to make sure her eyes were still closed. Her fingertips graced along the bones of her hand, careful to pay attention to each one equally, following those lines to the tips of Agatha's fingers, one by one. When she had finished that, she turned it over in her grasp and rubbed it gently, softly, working any tension there out. After a moment, she lowered Agatha's hand and intentionally placed it on her thigh, giving her a gentle squeeze.

With focused intent, she repeated the process on the other side, the touches over her shoulder, her arm, her hand. She massaged that palm, too, those palms she loved so much to hold. She gently set it down again, putting it where she wanted on her opposite thigh. As her gaze swept up, though, she found herself a little shocked to be looking Agatha in the eye.

A deep blush crept up her neck, but she didn't waver, didn't back down. She met her smoldering gaze evenly, as if to push, to encourage her to explain why she had chosen to open them.

What fell from her lips struck something in Rio, causing her eyes to glass over.

"What are you doing to me?" Agatha whimpered in a sound that was almost helpless, and the confusion on her face was almost palpable.

Rio considered for just a moment, but spoke before she could stop herself.

"I'm taking one of my many lessons in learning how to love you."

Agatha stilled completely, not even a shift of her chest with any breath. She was looking at Rio like she was fucking terrified, like she was so impossibly scared that Rio had just put a name to something they had been trying so hard to keep taboo.

Visibly, Rio shrank.

In an instant, Agatha was sitting up, both of her hands raising to take a firm hold on Rio's face, pulling her close, those deep pools of blue looking straight into her. A breath passed between them, and the space was gone.

The way Agatha kissed Rio right in that moment? It was crushing, it was consuming. It was almost aggressive, but in a way that was fueled by a deep emotional welling that knew no other cure. Their lips smacked, their teeth clicked, and they were locked in a trade off of who could devour the most number of moans. Tongues were wild, brushing, pushing, damn near wrestling. Her hands wandered, first over Agatha's chest, over both of her breasts at the same time that drew out an incredibly loud moan, one that rattled Rio's teeth.

There it was!

A thrill twisted through her, a skipping of her heartbeat that had to be noticeable through their kiss.

Agatha's thunder.

Her fingers flexed as an automatic response, gripping as she was stuck, trying to keep herself tethered to the moment, instead of completely floating away from the utter bliss that swarmed her. She loosened her grip, somehow able to command her movement despite the fact that they kiss they were sharing was shooting fire at every single neuron in her brain. "I love you, Rio. I know it's insane, it's--"

In an instant, Rio's hand raised and she pressed a solitary finger to Agatha's lips, a silent request for her to stop talking, and a silent assurance that she didn't need to explain herself. It lowered the next moment, Rio's gaze soft, holding Agatha in its warmth.

She leaned forward, pressing a kiss that was almost too soft for their current position to Agatha's lips, pulling back to press their foreheads together. Her own voice was a low, honest whisper.

"I love you too, Agatha. And I have since the moment I pulled you out of that marina."

She kissed her again, though it was brief, more of a punctuation than anything else.

"It doesn't have to make sense, because it doesn't make sense at all. All I know..." she breathed at her, pulling back just enough so that she could look at her, really look at her. "All I know is that I am ready to do what I need to if it means I get to keep you, like this, in my life."

Agatha blinked, and two lone tears dropped, one on each cheek. She wasn't upset anymore, and the fear was gone from her eyes. Those tears, they were pure emotion. They were a raw showing that for as much as Agatha had been grasping Rio's heart from the inside, Rio had been doing the same thing back the entire time, without even realizing it.

Rio lifted a hand, palming one of her cheeks.

"I've got you. And I promise, I will never intentionally hurt you. You've given me every single reason to trust you, to believe that you have my best interests at heart." Rio's lip quivered for a moment, the tears threatening to spill from her own eyes as she pressed forward. "Trust me, Agatha. Trust me to do for you what it is you strive to do for me every moment we're together. Trust me to love you."

That emotion was clearly overflowing in Agatha's entire expression, as if it were the first time in her entire life that she had heard someone say something even remotely similar to her. They were frozen in time for that moment, basking in the new weightlessness that had come the moment they had let go of all they had been holding back.

"You... you're..." Agatha managed, her tone still soft, her eyes darting from side to side across Rio's face as she searched as if she could somehow find the words there.

Rio leaned toward her again, folding their lips together in a toned down, emotional kiss that lingered for just a moment.

"What I am, Agatha, is yours."

Agatha was pulling on her again, this time a frenzied flurry of moving grip, anything to try and get Rio as close as she could possibly manage, like she wanted to melt right into her. Their lips met again, but there was more urgency there, this time, like Agatha was desperate for the taste, like she couldn't get enough.

Rio's hands were at it in an instant, but this time there was more of a strength in her grip, in the way she would grip and squeeze, feeling the give of Agatha's muscles beneath her fingertips. They kissed like that, loud and heavy, for what could have been an eternity, but Rio had taken every bit of that time to gather her own courage.

She pulled away, eliciting a soft whine of disappointment from the other woman, but she was fluid in her movements as she pulled herself from Agatha's lap and shifted off to her side. Her hesitation had evaporated and she pressed her face into Agatha's neck, her lips grazing the skin there. She was gentle in her ravishing, only the softest nips, the gentlest sucking at her skin, but she could tell that it was accomplishing what she set out to do.

It was an idle palm, nothing immediately pressing, but she could feel the swell as Agatha pulled in a slow breath right at the same moment Rio's lips touched that spot on her neck.

"Touch me," she said again, but this time, it was a soft whimper, a gentle beg for release.

Her lips somehow maintained their work on Agatha's neck and jaw, but if only by some autopilot response. Rio's entire mind was on her hand and its location. Her fingers were gentle in their exploration, feeling out every dip and fold of the most intimate part of Agatha. The reaction it was pulling from her was tantalizing, but something about Rio's mind was hung up on memorizing it, of learning this lesson the right way.

Two fingers started toward the bottom, dragging slowly up the slickness they found there until they brushed up, a gentle grazing of that small bundle of nerves, which caused Agatha to immediately stiffen, an uncontrollable moan filling their air around them.

Gods, Rio thought, I will never, ever get enough of that.

The way Agatha's hand had found it's way to her occupied arm was not lost on her, especially with the increasing strength of the grip located there. She didn't mind it, mostly because she was too focused on what she was doing to pay it any attention.

She tilted her head up and swept Agatha's lips into a warm kiss, some deep part of her needing the thunder she knew was on the verge of rolling in.

And then, with the slightest flick of her tongue against Agatha's, it arrived in every bit of its glory, both the thunder and Agatha's rippling orgasm. The way she could feel that sound in every inch of her soul as it filled her mouth, filled her throat, filled her lungs, it was entirely disorienting. What was even more disorienting was the way Agatha's body seemed to completely seize, her knees slamming together, effectively trapping Rio's hand where it was. Her nails were embedded in Rio's arm and it was almost like, for a solid ten seconds, she forgot how to breathe.

In a sudden gasp, Agatha came back into herself, though she was still panting wildly, her eyes shut in a mix of bliss and surrender. Without hesitation, Rio shifted, moving to place herself against the headboard. In the same second, she reached over and pulled Agatha into her arms, holding her firmly to her chest.

"I've got you," she breathed at her, tucking her chin to place her lips to the top of Agatha's head, but she left them there.

"I... Fuck, Rio. I love you so much."

Rio breathed the lightest, softest chuckle, kissing her head again.

"I love you just as much. You can believe in that."

Agatha's own breath was warm across the skin of her chest as she, too, exhaled the gentlest giggle.

"Yeah? And what is it that you believe in?"

Rio reached for Agatha's chin, tilting it up toward her so that she could meet that gaze again.

"I believe in you, Agatha."

*****

There was no recollection as to which one of them had been the one to do it, but the curtains had thankfully been pulled the night before, so that when Rio awoke in a tangle of warm flesh and soft hair, she was not immediately disgruntled by the onslaught of light pouring in from it. Instead, she just laid there, eyes closed, and let the weight of the night before settle over her.

She could feel it, what had been accomplished, in every single place that their skin touched. Their legs were tangled and Rio could feel every single place the front of Agatha's body pressed to her back, the body heat something to revel in.

She laid like that for a decent while, just taking it in, just realizing that this was her life. This could be the rest of her life, if there was a feasible path toward it. She could wake up every single morning in the arms of the woman she loved, if she wanted it badly enough. It was a topic that would take a lot more thought and planning than she was willing to give it in those moments, so she pushed it to the back of her mind for the time being.

Carefully, she reached for her phone to check the time, unable to stifle the softest laugh that spilled from her lips. It was 3:30 on a Tuesday afternoon. What time had they even fallen asleep? The sun hadn't been coming up, she didn't think, but she could have been wrong.

Another few moments passed and Rio could feel the tugging in her chest, the need to call Estee. Of course she wasn't going to completely kiss and tell, but she owed it to Estee to at least provide some information about what had been unfolding there.

She was careful and slow as she managed to slide out from Agatha's arm, though she stilled as Agatha stirred the slightest bit, but then sunk back into her pillow, the sleep still keeping its grip on her.

She had started over to her bag, but then something caught her eye a few feet from it -- Agatha's bag. With a warm smile to herself, she paced over to it and gently thumbed through it, pulling out a soft violet t-shirt. She pulled it over her head and pulled on a pair of her own underwear before she scooped up her phone and quietly made her way out onto the balcony.

She pressed the call button, but at the sight of herself in the camera, her eyes widened slightly and she raised her free hand to smooth out the wild tangle of her hair. It had lowered just as Estee answered, that bright and beautiful smile filling Rio with a new but familiar warmth, one that only Estee could provide.

"Mama! I miss you!" she chimed brightly, and the grin Rio had already been wearing only seemed to spread wider.

"I miss you too, roo. How are things over there?" she posed, tilting her head curiously.

"They're good. No second date, so no need for elaboration on that tidbit from the other night. I've mostly just been cramming for finals. It's so crazy that I get to come home for good in almost a month."

Rio nodded in agreement, but before she could respond, Estee cut her off.

"But school is boring and not at all what should be the substance of this conversation. How are things going?"

Although she had tried to temper her immediate reaction, Rio's smile grew a bit sheepish, and Estee picked up on it immediately.

"Mama!" she practically squealed.

"Shh!" Rio hushed, leaning forward in her chair, as if to pull the source of the sound further from the door. "She's still sleeping."

"I... am amazed. I thought you were going to be a celibate spinster until you died."

"Ouch, mija."

Estee's eyes sparkled with her laughter before it sounded.

"But really... good for you, mama. You have waited a very long time to be with someone, and I'm just... so fucking happy that you finally got your person."

Rio's eyes softened, that recollection of their exchange the night before playing through her mind as an involuntary memory.

"Mama?" Estee posed, and Rio re-focused, eyes snapping back to the phone.

Rio's lips twisted as she watched her daughter for a moment. She was trying to find the right words, the right phrasing for what she wanted to ask. And then, it hit her. Agatha had asked it exactly the right way.

"Mija, do you... do you believe that people can be soulmates?"

The fascination was immediately clear on her daughter's face, as if she were trying to gauge whether or not Rio, of all people, had actually just asked her that question. She wanted to be admonishing, Rio could tell, but she took a moment to actually think about the question.

"Mama, I think what you need to hear is that if it feels right to you, then it is right. It doesn't matter what anybody else thinks."

Rio was quiet for a moment, her throat bobbing slightly with her nerves as she tried to find her voice.

"She told me she loved me," Rio divulged, and Estee's reaction? She completely lit up, as if someone had flipped a switch inside of her.

"Mama! Oh my god!" she gushed, clearly losing her mind. "And?!"

"And I told her that I loved her, too."

Estee's squeals filled Rio with absolute joy, so much that it was about to spill over. She had never known in her life what it could feel like to be so impossibly fucking happy.

"I mean... after she took me on a beachside horseback ride to a secluded cove, how could I not, right?" she posed, and this drew an even more exaggerated reaction out of Estee.

"Mama, what the actual fuck?! How the hell did your life become a literal romance novel?"

"Absolutely no clue, mija. But... I'm going to live in it a little while longer."

"Do you know when you're going to come home?"

Rio's lips pressed together and she exhaled a soft sigh. She had been trying not to spend a lick of her energy dwelling on that minute detail.

"Probably in a week or two. I definitely want to be home to get you from the airport."

"Mama, that's in a month."

"I know, sweet girl, but I have work. I only took a week off, and even though I brought my laptop, I might only be able to land another week tops. Plus, I really hate being so far away from you."

Something washed over Estee's face, and in the moment Rio picked it up, it disappeared. She wanted to ask, but some part of her could already see it. How was she going to make this work with Agatha if she was already homesick? That was yet another question she would answer at a later date, if only for herself.

"Well, see if you can bring her back with you," Estee teased softly, her smile warm.

"Maybe if she were not a woman of power in the industry who probably has a lot more important things to do than take an impromptu vacation across the world because I'm needy."

At this, Estee gave every bit of effort she had into rolling her eyes as far back into her head as they would go, causing Rio to dissolve into laughter.

"Consider it, mama. I'd love to actually meet her."

Rio's smile softened. "I think she'd love to meet you, too, mija."

Estee straightened up a little, tilting her head at her mother.

"Alright, I'm all caught up to speed. Get back in there with your girlfriend," she offered, her tone thick on that last word. This time, it was Rio's eyes that rolled.

"I love you, mija. Have a good rest of your day, okay?"

That warm smile and those beautiful eyes staring back at her, they made Rio so impossibly thankful to have that child as hers.

"Te amo, mama."

"Te veo, mija."

She lowered the phone and leaned back into her chair, the warm afternoon sun touching every bit of her face, bathing it in its glow. For the first time in her entire life, a brand new Rio was looking out on the world.

She was a Rio that was in love, and a Rio that was so very loved.

After another moment, she lifted herself up from the chair and turned to head back in the sliding door, pulling it shut softly behind her. The room was still quiet, and so when she lifted her head to look over at the bed, she had not been expecting Agatha to be awake.

There, wrapped up in the olive colored sheets, draped over her hip as a bare leg curled out and forward, laid Agatha looking like she had been pulled from a late 18th century painting. Her own eyes swept to take in Rio, and an instant grin seemed to blossom on her lips.

"You went through my bag?" she posed, though her tone was still laden with sleep.

Rio shrugged innocently, making her way over to the bed. "Tit for tat, I figured," she offered, her eyes bright as she slid onto the bed, laying on her side in front of Agatha.

"You are something else," she breathed in a soft laugh.

"Maybe," she offered back, a gentle smile gracing her lips. "Or maybe, I'm just everything you want."

"Oh Rio," Agatha gushed, leaning forward to steal a quick kiss. "There's not a single question in my mind about that."

Chapter End Notes

i just wanted to add that in the end notes for the final chapter, i will be posting the tracklist each chapter title is named after/inspired by just because music is such a big part of my writing process. that's all thank you for your patronage xx

A Space to Grow

I swear I heard a song inside the earth.
I put my ear to the gound and I sang with every word.

*****

The two of them laid in soft reverence for a few moments before the audible grumbling of Agatha's stomach echoed and caused the both of them to dissolve into giggles. They had decided on ordering room service, which had mostly consisted of fruit and cheese and crackers, and they had lounged around for a little longer, idling between flipping through their phones or watching television.

For as non-stop go as they had been those first three days, it felt nice to just sleep in, lounge around, and spend the majority of her day curled against Agatha's side, her arm draped over her in a warm but protective hold, as if she couldn't stand the thought of her getting even an inch away.

It was bordering on seven in the evening, and as the gentle sounds of the television landed around them, Rio was suddenly struck with a thought -- or more of a feeling -- and sat up at the weight of it. She was quiet as she processed, her teeth digging gently into the inside of her lower lip. She had been that quiet just a beat too long, and Agatha spoke, raising a hand to rest on her back.

"Rio?" she posed, her tone so soft and innocent, so curious.

There was another beat of silence, of processing, and then Rio's voice, thick with its sudden sense of urgency.

"I should check out."

She could feel it, the way Agatha stilled behind her; the thumb that had been brushing at her back stopped its motion immediately. She could hear that sharp breath, and the uncertainty in what that implied. She didn't want it to root anywhere within her, so she turned her head enough that she could take Agatha in, her eyes soft with affection.

"I think I'm tired of running up your tab."

At this, Agatha's smile was wide and instant, something she could hardly think to temper. She understood, the dawning of realization washing over her, bathing her in that rich warmth. She tilted her head at Rio, an utter look of amazement dancing across her expression.

"I get to take you home?"

In an instant, Rio's chest squeezed, but she was quick to mask it with a gentle, warm smile as she gave a light nod of her head. What she was hiding? The way Agatha had decided to phrase that, it pointedly shot right through her. This wasn't her home, and likely never would be, but there was something so purely innocent about it that left Rio feeling as though she could have floated away.

"It is a little later... do you want to wait until tomorrow?" Agatha posed sweetly, her gaze sweeping over Rio's face, as if to gauge her response, which was almost instant.

"I think if the last month of my life has taught me anything, it's that I'm really tired of waiting for things I want," she returned. Her head had turned forward again, but she was surprised by the slipping of Agatha's palm around her throat, gently pulling her back, pinning her to the pillows. In a single blink, Agatha was hovering above her, her hair cascading over her shoulder, tickling Rio's neck.

Rio watched with vested interest as she came closer, their lips a breath apart, but she stopped, a devilish light dancing in her eyes. She didn't miss it, that briefest contact, the slightest swipe of the tip of her tongue along the under side of Rio's top lip.

A low, gravelly whine sounded from her throat, Agatha's fingers tightening in automatic reaction.

Then, so slowly, a wicked smirk twisted up Agatha's lips and she released her hold, pressing herself to sit back up.

From behind her, Rio was blinking at her wildly, a soft whimper falling from her lips in disappointment. What the fuck was that? Where was the follow-up?! That was it?

Then, as if Agatha was listening in once more, her chin tucked over her shoulder, a perfect display of her profile.

"Some things are worth waiting for, don't ya think?" she posed, and even from that view of her from the side, Rio could see that same smirk finding a home on its her face.

"You little devil," Rio shot back, though she was instantly sitting up, using every muscle in her core to lift her as quickly as possible, her hands landing immediately on Agatha's sides, squeezing gently. She pulled her back closer and buried her face in the crook of her neck from behind, breathing a sigh of laughter and contentment against her skin.

The hum she got in response was satisfactory enough.

"Come on, let's pack," Rio suggested, giving her sides a light squeeze again.

They had set about their work, packing their things and tidying up the room in accordance with being a decent human being. As they each pulled their respective bags over their shoulders, Rio couldn't help but turn as they stopped to open the door and take one last survey of the last four days of her life, and her first four days not only in a new country, but in a brand new emotion.

That hotel room would forever be the place Rio let herself fall all the way in love with Agatha Harkness.

There was a fondness in the smile that curled up the corners of her lips, but she turned, picking up Agatha's awaiting hand as they made their exit from the Freehand and turned the page to their next chapter, a chapter where this time, they were on Agatha's turf.

Though it should have terrified her? There was something strangely thrilling about it that had Rio aching in anticipation.

*****

Something enticing was coursing through Rio's entire being as the two of them stood on that welcome mat, Agatha fidgeting with her keys as she found the right one and unlocked the door, swinging it open into the darkness of the home.

Immediately, Rio noted that it smelled differently than when they had been there those couple of days before. There was something in the air, something like the scent of... cologne?

Her brow had knit slightly at the same time Agatha flipped on the light, her eyes falling behind Rio to something in the living room. The expression on her face was a forced mask, the true emotions of concern and mild panic flashing through her eyes instead.

Rio turned, her eyes finding the dark navy garment on the white couch with ease. Her own confusion was immediate on her face as she turned back, the unasked question in her eyes. After only a beat, Agatha's expression softened as she marched with exaggerated steps over to the base of the stairs, leaning casually on the banister.

"Nicholas Scratch! If you're up there in that bedroom instead of waiting to surprise your mother whenever she decided to turn up, you've missed your shot!"

There was nothing for just a moment, then a faint "Shit!" from overhead as scrambled footsteps ripped down the hallway.

Rio's eyes lifted from where she stood to the bright-eyed young man that stood at the top of the steps, an utter look of adoration on his face as he bound down the steps and swept his mother into a massive hug, holding her tight.

The sound that came from Agatha? That pure, raw, unfiltered laughter of sheer joy and happiness? It melted Rio right in her middle, that familiar warmth she felt when she was with Agatha beginning to spread through her again.

His chin had been over Agatha's shoulder, his eyes squeezed shut as he reveled in the moment. As they opened, though? A pair of impossibly bright green eyes were staring straight into her own, confusion clearly washing over him. He placed his hands on the upper part of Agatha's biceps, pulling back so he could look down at her. He looked... guilty?

"I didn't know you were going to have company. I should have texted," he told her softly and Rio diverted her gaze, suddenly feeling like she was toeing the edge of being intrusive.

"Nicky," Agatha admonished softly, reaching up to lovingly cradle his cheek. "It's okay. I'm glad you're home. And before you get annoyingly persistent about going somewhere else, I will lovingly remind you that you know where the keys to the pool house are, and also remind that the refrigerator in there still has that twelve pack of beer from your birthday."

"Mom, are you sure?" he questioned back, the clear weight of what they knew that Rio did not sitting in his gaze.

She gave a gentle nod, letting go of his cheek to swivel, placing her hand in the center of his back as she ushered him forward, causing Rio to lift her head. "In fact, there's someone I'd like you to meet." She held her hand out to Rio who hesitated a moment, glancing up into her eyes as if to double check that it was okay. She was only met with warm reassurance in those beautiful blue eyes.

She reached down, sliding her hand into Agatha's as she stepped forward, a genuinely warm smile coming to her lips.

"Nicky, this is Rio. She's..." Agatha's gaze swept back down to her, regarding her with a gentle affection for a moment while she found the right words. Her eyes lifted to her son again, the smile of sheer joy finding her lips easily. "She is my partner."

He did an amazing job -- almost -- at hiding the way he wanted to balk. It was the slightest widening of his eyes and the smallest loosening of his jaw that completely gave him away. This was clearly something he was not accustomed to from his mother, and Rio's interest was suddenly piqued.

Something a little... uncomfortable? It shifted in her middle, but she did her best to temper it, to not let it grace even a muscle of her features. It was just the context of the entire welcoming that had gnawed at her interest. His words, his ask for assurance, the way he seemed to be not that surprised that she had company, but definitely shocked that she had announced that this woman in her home was her partner?

That word, it held gravity. In some strange way, Rio understood it. They weren't just girlfriends, that felt too cheap. Agatha always seemed to have quite the penchant for finding just the right words at just the right times.

Still, those facts stacking on one another in rapid succession left Rio with questions that she knew needed to be saved for another time, and she was also aware that they were questions she might not want answers to.

He recovered quickly, a warm smile finding his lips -- so much like Agatha's -- as he reached out, holding a hand out for her to shake. She obliged, though it felt a little awkward, maybe even forced.

"And Rio, this is Nicky, my son."

She offered a sweet smile in response, feeling that she was doing a great job at masking the sudden inner turmoil within herself.

Those few awkward moments were enough for Rio to become acutely aware that if Agatha had considered this, having the two of them meet, she had perhaps wanted to have a bit of a conversation with her son about it. Rio had sensed that they were not as close, perhaps, as herself and Estee were, but she had found nothing wrong with that. Agatha had explained it pretty well, she had thought.

Maybe, she thought, that was where this was all coming from. He had been in the dark, and he felt like the one that was intruding, even in his own home.

Something reminiscent of an ache tugged at Rio's heart; she couldn't imagine having gone through the last month of her life without her daughter knowing. She knew that every relationship was different, that everything in a parent v child relationship was heavily dependent on the experiences of both parties during the child's entire life.

Estee had been her one and only, always. It was becoming clear to Rio in that moment, and based on past things Agatha had said, that Agatha and Nicky had used their careers to put space between them intentionally.

It made Rio a little sad. She wasn't sure why, but she had been expecting something... different when she had eventually been presented with this moment.

It was a very vivid waving of a flag that reminded Rio that there were still years of Agatha that she had yet to learn. She knew the reverse was true, but it felt more pressing now that she was learning another lesson in Agatha, one that she did not really want to be present for. It felt like she did not belong, like it was something she should not be there watching.

Agatha was suddenly doing something Rio had never seen her do before -- she was fidgeting, a restless motion of rubbing the fabric of her leggings between her fingers, as if she were nervous. Rio ached so badly to reach out, to grab her hand and soothe those nerves, but she recognized that they were nowhere near in a scenario where that would be acceptable.

"Would you like to have dinner with us? I can throw something together, if you'd like," Agatha offered sweetly, and Rio could hear that tinge, that squeeze of a plea. She could see it on Agatha's face, the moment she realized what he was going to do. Her lips tucked just slightly at the corners and the wrinkles of hope from lifted eyebrows smoothed out in realization.

"It was a long flight. I think I'll grab those keys and tuck in for the night. Maybe we can do something tomorrow?" he posed softly, a hopeful smile appearing on his face. The sincerity in his tone seemed to soothe Agatha the slightest bit and her posture gave in, slack for the time being.

"Of course, baby boy. As always, help yourself to anything in here. The back door will be unlocked if you need anything."

He gave her a long, firm hug and let her go to kiss her on the cheek.

"I'll see you in the morning, mom," he voiced gently, giving her arm a light squeeze as he turned to depart for the evening, Agatha watching after him.

Rio stood behind her, her teeth digging lightly into the full flesh of her lower lip as she held herself, her arms wrapped loosely across her own middle, as if she were trying to protect herself, even though something in her shouted that they were past that... weren't they? Slowly, Agatha turned to face her, and the guilt she saw there metled the bit of frost she had started to develop in her bristling.

Agatha stepped forward, her hands sliding smoothly onto Rio's side as she stepped a little closer, wrapping one arm around her waist. With such a fluid movement, it compelled Rio to release the hold on herself, her hands landing flat on Agatha's chest. Her eyes lifted, meeting those soft blues in silent curiosity.

"I... I had no idea he was going to be here," she told her softly, but of that, Rio had already been aware. She had been able to tell the moment Agatha had laid eyes on that sweater, watch as the confusion had crossed her face. It had been genuine, not fabricated. "If I would have, you know I would have said something..."

"Agatha, shh, it's okay. I believe you." Rio's tone was a gentle comfort, a soft reassurance that it really was okay. Sure, she had a genuine desire to understand a little more about that dynamic, and the interaction itself, but that could be a conversation for later.

That look in Agatha's eyes was unfamiliar to Rio and it was only lending to the fact that she could tell something about this had really shaken something up in Agatha. Rio, herself, was feeling a little lost in the dark; had the dynamic changed? What was she allowed to do? What should she not do? She was suddenly back into the mind frame of classic Rio, the anxiety bubbling up in her chest.

Her lips twisted in a mild apprehension as her eyes darted over Agatha's face in thought, trying to find the courage she needed to get the words out.

"I can... go back to the hotel, if you think it would be better?" she offered, though it was obvious in her tone that it was really the last thing she wanted. She was trying to offer a remedy to a quick tension, and the last thing she wanted to do was cause any kind of friction between Agatha and her son.

Agatha shook her head dismissively.

"Of course not. This is, after all, my house, and whether or not my son decides to show up on a whim does not dictate the company I get to keep in said home."

The content of what she said, and exactly how she said it, it was new. It was something Rio struggled for a moment to identify: It was Agatha fighting to keep a firm grasp on something she felt like she still had control over. It didn't make her point any less valid, but it was a subtle show of defiance, a way of asserting that in her domain, she was the one with the control.

"Agatha..." Rio breathed at her, beguiling her to look back down at her. When she obliged, Rio leaned toward her, brushing their lips softly together.

"It's okay. You don't have to do that when it's just us."

In a series of firsts, Rio saw Agatha's nostrils flare the slightest bit and a small crease formed in her brow. As she realized what she had done, even automatically, her face softened as she beheld the woman in front of her.

"I'm sorry... I just..." Agatha exhaled a soft sigh, her lips moving to worry together in a thin line. Her expression softened the slightest bit, though, and she tilted her head slightly to the side. "Why don't I throw something together for us to eat, and then we can go get comfortable?"

There was something on the tip of Rio's tongue, an unasked question that she couldn't quite force out. She shoved it down, pushed it away for the time being. Time and place. Time and place.

She agreed with a gentle nod, leaning in to take the most gentle kiss before letting Agatha go so that she could do as she had said she would. Rio had perched on one of the stools at the kitchen island, watching her with a gentle interest as she started perparing what Rio had gathered was a bruschetta.

The tension in the air was new, and it was uncomfortable. Agatha was quiet as she worked, no conversation and no trace of a hum, just straight focus. It was unnerving Rio the longer it drew on, her eyes hardly wavering from Agatha's back as she busied herself with the task at hand.

"Agatha... are you okay?" Rio finally decided to ask.

Agatha lifted her head, glancing over her shoulder just briefly, hardly long enough to be constituted as an actual look.

"I'm fine," she dismissed, offering no further elaboration.

Rio could feel it, the stone in her chest as it began to sink, lower and lower into her stomach. She felt like she was suffering from whiplash, like the Agatha that she had walked into that house was suddenly gone and had been replaced with an Agatha that was willing to shut her out when things got uncomfortable. It made her sad, although she was trying not to let it.

The anxiety that stemmed in her chest came from the fact that, really? She didn't even know what was wrong, so she didn't know what she could possibly do to try and fix it.

After a few more minutes of Agatha moving between the counter and the stove, she had plated their food and turned to face Rio.

"Would you like to go upstairs? I'd just really like to climb into bed with you, eat this, and snuggle up." Her voice was so resigned, so suddenly tired. The defeat in her was something Rio was bearing witness to for the first time and while she had been gripped with the anxiety that it had been because of her presence, she realized that it had been stupid to make such an assumption.

If they had walked into that house, and it would have been empty? This night surely would have taken a different direction, but Rio was suddenly understanding that the shift in Agatha's demeanor had everything to do with that short little interaction.

"I'll grab the bags," Rio told her softly, leaning toward her to press a gentle kiss to the apple of her cheek, a pure show of affection and understanding more than it was of intimacy.

She paced over and picked up both bags, nodding toward Agatha, who had tucked a bottle of wine under her arm, to lead the way. She followed her through the home, and while her intent had been to observe and take in the details the further exploration of the house had to offer, she found herself too stuck on Agatha to really care about anything else.

She wanted to fix what seemed to have broken in her, wanted to mend the tears in her that were opening her up in a way Rio had not quite been so ready to see. Even her posture was different as she carried herself up those stairs, so laden with the weight of what Nicky's presence had brought with it.

Agatha led her down the long hall, turning toward the left to gently nudge the door open with her foot. As she entered, she used her elbow to flip on the light. Rio stepped into the doorway behind her, eyes sweeping to take in the contents of the room. It was huge and it was immaculately decorated. Against the far wall, directly centered, was a king side bed with a post at every corner, a rich dark marbling of wood. There were two beautifully polished wooden nightstands and a dresser on the left wall that seemed to match. The vanity was extravagant in all of the best ways.

Rio's eyes shifted, though, to the right wall in the corner. Cut into the wall, there were shelves that ran from the floor to the ceiling, lined side to side with too many books to count. Something in Rio warmed; Agatha was a bookworm. There was something endearingly cute about the fact.

"So, this is it, hm?" Rio posed, her voice low and rich as her gaze cast to Agatha.

Agatha set both plates down, tabling the bottle of wine right next to them. She turned to face Rio, the question on her face.

"This is the temple of Agatha Harkness," Rio stated, as if it were completely obvious.

That nervous, upset tension that had been pulling Agatha's muscles taught seemed to ease, if only the slightest bit. Her expression melted a little, and her posture slackened before she crossed the space between them, reaching up with one hand to cradle Rio's jaw in her palm.

"How do you do that?" Agatha asked Rio, this time, her gaze a little frantic in its search for answers.

She almost played coy, almost asked what she meant, but she sensed that the moment called for a little more seriousness, a little more acknowledgement. She took a moment to find her voice, to say what she felt the impulse to say.

"Because I see you. Sometimes, I even think I hear you in my head. But you... you are a book I've read a million times, and yet, somehow, new chapters keep appearing."

Agatha, in that moment, looked like she wanted to cry. Rio understood that the words had power, her words had that power, but this was something she was struggling to figure out. She was being honest, and she was following through on every single promise that she had made thus far, so why did Agatha look so afraid?

Agatha tilted her head forward, their foreheads pressing together as she exhaled a soft sigh.

Rio had this sense, this feeling like something was weighing on her, breaking the illusion that had been following them for four days straight. She picked up on it, and she wasn't sure she could let it go. She raised a hand and gingerly tucked a strand of hair behind Agatha's ear, tilting her head as she did so to give her a gentle kiss.

"Do you want to talk about it?" Rio breathed softly against her lips.

She could almost hear it, the battle of wills raging inside of Agatha. She was fighting herself, and with the conversation they'd had the night before, it left her wondering if Agatha had not quite believed her, or if this was somehow worse than she had thought it might be.

"Let's sit," Agatha suggested in a gentle murmur, though a spark of rememberance flashed on her face. She paced over to her bag, rummaging through it for a moment before she let out a soft aha! and produced the bottle of brandy, still unopened, from the first night they'd spent at the hotel. She paced back over to the bed, sliding to meet Rio in the center of it, the food suddenly irrelevant as it sat on the nightstand.

For what felt like the first time -- or at least the first meaningful time -- in their relationship, Rio was the one who lifted her hand and turned it over, palm side up, and held it out to Agatha. She could sense that Agatha had not even shifted to look at it, but met it with her response immediately. Rio threaded their fingers together, giving a soft squeeze as she leaned a bit of her weight into the woman next to her.

The silence was steady around them and Rio sensed that whatever this was, it was something Agatha was doing her best to summon her courage to bring up.

"I... When Colton and I divorced, ten years ago... I made a lot of really questionable choices. And I did that for years, bad choice after bad choice. By day, I was living my dream, making the films I wanted to share with the world. By night?" Rio could hear it, that wrapping of shame that twisted over her words. "There was just... this endless frustration that I had wasted so long of my life on someone who had never really cared about me, not actually. And so, instead of turning to copious amounts of booze, or drugs like my counterparts in the business, I let the door of my home become a revolving one of countless strangers that could... make me feel like I mattered for an hour at a time."

She gave Agatha's hand a gentle squeeze, as if to say I'm right here. It's okay.

"I was selfish, in that time. I didn't take Nicky into consideration, and I... I know that even though he has probably tried to cope with it with countless hours of therapy, it was hard for him, and he probably still holds it against me."

The pieces were starting to fall into place in Rio's mind, but Agatha was not finished.

"He's been gone for three years. I had really fought myself on letting him leave before he was eighteen, but he couldn't seem to get away fast enough. In that three years... I've become a different person. And even more than that, I am certain that the me he just met? That woman is probably a stranger, in his eyes."

It all made sense in that moment. Nicky had struggled with the way she had coped with losing her marriage, and he had been too distant to witness any change in the time since he had made the choice to leave. What he saw, when he looked at Rio, was that revolving door swinging open again. But then, Agatha had put a name to it, and the shock had clearly displayed that he had been caught off guard.

Even with the revelation that Agatha was doing things differently, though, Rio could also see that because of such a reality, he did not know in what way to treat Rio. He had never been put in a situation where Agatha had placed herself into another relationship. As a result, he had no manual on how he was supposed to act.

Rio was quiet for a moment, just watching as her thumb brushed over the back of Agatha's hand tenderly. The thoughts were rolling, swirling, and she was trying her hardest to find the right ones, to find a way to say the right things.

"I... I guess what you have to ask yourself is... Is the you he just met the one you want him to know going forward?" Rio posed in a soft murmur, though her tone was so smooth and gentle.

Agatha seemed to absorb the question, soaking it right through to her bones.

"I don't know that I can be anyone else, anymore."

Rio turned her head, her eyes sweeping over Agatha's profile before she reached across them. Her hand lifted, her fingertips catching the other woman's chin ever so softly, beguiling her to look up.

Those blue eyes met hers and Rio's palm slid to cradle Agatha's jaw, her thumb brushing tenderly over her cheek.

"Maybe... maybe you should talk to him. Just... be honest with him. He's probably just feeling a little confused, and I think that if you explain things to him, it might help bridge that gap a little bit."

Agatha breathed an almost sardonic huff of a chuckle, though the tenderness on her face didn't really match it.

"So... do you just carry around a book called 'all of the right things to say,' or is it just natural for you?" she posed in a rich whisper, tilting her head in adoration at Rio.

"No, I just thought about the other night when Estee texted me and you encouraged me to go outside and talk to her. I realized that even though it's hard, communication with our kids can make or break how they feel about us." Her lips pressed together for a moment before she found it in her to continue, though the humor danced in her eyes. "I didn't realize at the time that I'd be able to spin it back on you so soon though," she added in a quiet, smooth purr.

"I don't know if I like it when you use my own logic against me," Agatha grumbled, though Rio could hear in her tone that she was not actually upset, just perhaps a mixture of smitten and annoyed.

Without a word, Rio closed the space between them with a tentative kiss, though she didn't hold it for long. It was more of a morale boost than anything else.

"Go," she whispered, stealing one more soft peck. "Go talk to him."

Agatha had every intention of listening, but she didn't immediately move. She simply found that deep pit of reverence that seemed to reside within her, pouring out of her as she watched Rio with curious intent.

"I love you, you know?"

Rio smiled, warmth washing over her.

"I know. And as you are well aware, I love you too. Now, stop stalling," she teased with a breathy giggle, deciding on one more gentle show of affection as she took one more kiss, letting it linger for just a moment before she pulled away.

Agatha looked across at her, helpless, but she knew she had been tasked with an important mission, and she needed to prove to Rio that she was brave enough to carry it out.

Rio watched as Agatha slid off the bed and paced over to the door, though she hesitated at the threshold, turning to look back at Rio for one more moment, doing what she could to find the solace she needed for the conversation ahead. Rio gave her a comforting smile and a light nod of her head in silent encouragement.

Another beat of a moment passed between them, and just before she turned to disappear, Rio could swear she heard it across the room, but she was painfully aware that Agatha had not, in fact, spoken a word.

Still, it bounced around her head like it had been whispered into her ear.

You are all I need.

The Next Twenty Minutes

The next twenty minutes, love, surely won't be my best.

*****

Rio's eyes had lingered on that door frame, replaying over and over again in her head the sight of Agatha walking out of it.

The sight of the woman she had fallen head over heels for, commanding and present as she had tipped her chin up, given her hair a shake, and marched on to face something that Rio entirely understood made her very uncomfortable.

It struck Rio as her eyes swept over the decor of the bedroom, noting every little minute detail in the catalogs of her mind, that when they had talked, that first night on her houseboat, Agatha had spoken about Nicky with such a tender care and affection. There had never been any reason to have some kind of inkling that perhaps the relationship was not all that it seemed at the very surface level of a casual conversation.

In a way, it made her sad. She loved her daughter more than she knew how to love herself most days, and the idea that there could be three years and thousands of miles of space between them? It hollowed out something in her middle, even just thinking about it.

She had sensed, although Agatha had not explicitly stated, that the tension there had a few more layers than what Agatha had just divulged to her. She knew that with the more time she invested into spending with Agatha, the more she would be able to peel, to get closer to the center. She knew she would earn the ability to see Agatha more clearly, if she just gave it time.

Rio's eyes, in their journey across the room, had fallen across the bed to that nightstand, and the two plates of food sitting atop it. She was pretty hungry, even if they had gotten distracted by discussing the weight of what had unfolded upon their arrival.

She shifted, moving so that she could reach across and grab one of the plates, pulling it to her lap. It wasn't a Michelin star meal, but Rio could very clearly see the craft that went into it, and something began to stir in her middle -- Agatha knew how to cook.

It was the silliest realization, and it was even more ridiculous how it made her fill with warmth, but it was just another small piece to the grand puzzle that Agatha was.

Seeing the little piece of art had been nothing compared to tasting it. Rio knew that it wasn't a lot of ingredients, but the way they had been combined, the way the toasting on the bread was literally perfect? Even more warmth sparked through her at the next realization; Agatha really knew how to cook, and this was just a very little glimpse of that.

As she finished, she stared down at the plate, holding a debate in her mind. She needed water, but she wasn't quite sure of the limits here, of where she should go or what she should do. She stopped herself, though; it was stupid to even consider that Agatha might even be remotely upset with her if she chose to go to the kitchen and get herself a glass of water.

After a moment of debate that ended in her telling herself not to be an idiot, she slid off the edge of the bed, her feet hitting the cool hardwood. The plate was still in her hand as she began the trek down the hallway and stairs, nearly floating her way into the kitchen. The lights were still on, illuminating those pristine countertops and stainless steel appliances.

Everything about it was just so... composed. It was so very... Agatha.

She turned, surveying the cabinets for a moment, trying to see if she could guess where she might find a glass. She paced and, after only two other attempts, she found the location of the glasses and pulled one down for herself. She turned, moving toward the front of the sink as she put the glass beneath the tap.

At the same moment that she lifted the handle, something caught her attention.

Rio both saw it through her peripherals through the window in front of her and heard it -- the door to the pool house flew open violently and Agatha came thundering out of it, a clear look of anger and frustration screwing up every single one of those beautiful features and also, at the same time, causing a pang of pain to ripple through Rio's chest. She didn't like seeing Agatha look like that, like she was hurting and covering it up with seething rage.

"You don't get to do that, Nicholas. You don't just get to fuck off to Dubai for three years with the ever so occasional visit or phone call, and then turn up here and think that you get to make snap judgements and lecture me on how I am living my life." Agatha's voice was loud -- as evidenced by the fact that Rio could hear her crystal clear from inside the house.

"Well, you raised me to call a spade a spade, and you are being LITERALLY insane!" he shouted back, causing Agatha to whip on him, her finger raised in a pointed warning as she took a step toward him, but then seemed to stop herself.

"I get it, I do. I thoroughly wrecked a good chunk of your childhood. But gods be damned, Nicholas," Agatha managed, her tone bordering on exasperated, as if this were a conversation that had been turning circles, "if I haven't fought to make myself better. I know I wasn't always the best mother, but I loved you, and I have always respected the fact that you're able to make your own decisions. Why is it that hard for you to give it back?"

Rio's gaze shifted across the space to Nicky, who's eyes were wide and wild, as if he couldn't believe this were actually a conversation they were having.

"Maybe if you'd ever been anyone worth being respected in any given memory, it wouldn't be such a struggle," he bit back sharply, his voice bordering on hostile.

Rio felt it, at the same exact moment Agatha did, judging by the reaction. She looked like he had physically struck her, the pain immediate and visible on her face. Rio's own heart dropped somewhere far beneath the floor below her.

That hurt. That was vicious.

"I... I don't know what you want from me, Nick. You told me you wanted me to be happy, and now that I'm happy, you take issue with how I got there." Agatha's tone was no longer a shout, but had lowered into something Rio could still hear. She did not miss the sting in her words, in the way she felt every inch of what he had said to her.

"You're literally talking about spending the rest of your life with someone who is a complete fucking stranger. Mom, come on. You're smarter than that."

Rio's stomach clenched, and she found herself gasping for a breath, feeling like he had struck her, too. Another jab, this time landing on both of them. Rio wanted to be thrilled with that small little bit of information -- that Agatha had literally told him she wanted to spend her life with her -- but she was too hung up on the burn his flames had left on each of them.

Agatha put her hands up, palms out, shaking her head.

"I do not owe you an explanation about what goes on in my personal life, but fuck me for thinking it was a decent thing to do to try to just have a conversation with you about it. It means something to me, and I had hoped that might make it mean something to you, too."

Nick scoffed, rolling his eyes, flicking a hand at his mother dismissively.

The sheer amount of disrespect, it flared something in Rio. It wasn't just a pain, an ache for Agatha, who was clearly distraught by what was happening, but it hurt Rio, too. She was watching as this... this child completely eviscerated the one human being in the world who loved him without condition or stipulation. He was hurting her because he could, and Rio didn't understand it.

She also, decidedly, did not like it one bit.

Rio understood, from the point of view of someone who was overly compassionate, that what Agatha had chosen to do in her past had severely impacted Nicky in a negative way, a way that he was still actively holding against his mother.

"Do what you want. But keep me out of it. Don't ever expect me to look at her, or anyone else you bring around like they'd ever be any kind of parent to me. You hardly are yourself."

And then, Rio felt her heart somehow slide even closer to the core of the earth. His words were so cold, so hollow. Rio could feel them reverberate in the very core of her bones, through each and every one.

He turned around and stomped back into the pool house, slamming the door shut behind him, leaving Agatha standing there, metaphorically bleeding out from every wound he had just dished. She was still, frozen in that moment of her pain. Rio could read it on her face, the way she was working to build her composure again, to piece it back together so she could head back inside that house, and back to Rio.

Rio had just had the thought that she should probably go back up stairs, but before she could will any muscle in her body to move, Agatha's head lifted and their eyes met through the window.

Everything in Rio completely left her. There was no sense, there was no air, there was not even a single beat of her heart. She should not have witnessed that, should not have intruded on such a personal moment. She knew, in her own heart, that it would only help her in tending to Agatha's wounds, but she knew without a doubt that the way it would make Agatha feel? She could already see it, the glassing over of her eyes as she fought herself on whether or not to move.

Slowly, Rio set down the glass on the counter top, her eyes not leaving Agatha's until she turned, commanding her feet to move. She paced over to the back door and gently pushed it open, her hand remaining on the handle as she held it open, her eyes lifting to take in the other woman. She tilted her head toward the inside of the house.

"Come on," Rio coaxed softly, her tone almost pleading. She didn't want Agatha to fight her, or put up a protest. She didn't want to watch her continue to struggle just for the sake of it, anymore.

Agatha's head hung a bit -- most likely from a sense of shame mixed with embarrassment -- but she heeded Rio's request, pacing across the concrete toward the door. She passed by her without a word, and Rio's chest tightened, her lips turning further down at the corners.

She shut the door and turned, watching as Agatha moved toward the stairs, but Rio reached out, gently taking hold of her hand and using it to turn Agatha toward her. She looked up at her, her own green eyes impossibly soft and earnest as she searched every divot in her face, trying to pinpoint a place to begin, somewhere she could start to begin to mend what Nicholas had completely torn down. She searched for a long minute, but what she found, it was the most honest thing she knew.

"I... I'm sorry."

There were so many things that she could have been apologizing for in that moment, from the way she was sure she had not been meant to see that, or the fact that she seemed to be the main source of that discord. She could have been apologizing for the fact that none of this would have happened if they had never met, but she wasn't.

Rio was offering a strong tie of empathy, of understanding that she had been hurt by the one person in the world that she had loved unconditionally for twenty years.

She could see the emotion in Agatha's eyes, brewing like a storm, despite the fact that she was fighting herself to keep her expression placid. She could see the struggle there, the strong urge to not be emotional, to not lose control.

Rio pushed forward, leaning up so that she could place her lips gently to Agatha's cheek. She left them there, a firm and solid reminder that she was right there, right in front of her. It was a reminder that Agatha did not have to do this alone.

"Let's go upstairs," Agatha suggested, and Rio immediately found herself in an active battle to try and stop the way her stomach lurched at the smallness of Agatha's voice. She leaned back so that she was entirely upright again, reaching to pull Agatha's hand into her own. She let the other woman lead them back up to the bedroom, but as they crossed the threshold, Rio pulled her to her again.

This time, though, she was quick in her movements to completely envelop Agatha into a firm hold, pulling her as close as she could possibly manage. As Agatha laid her head on her shoulder, a hand raised to cradle the back of her had, holding her gently there, though Rio's presence was softly commanding.

They stood just beyond the doorway like that for a long few moments, Rio's hand smoothing so tenderly over Agatha's hair.

Rio felt scared, but only because she didn't have a plan. She didn't know what to do, how to fix this, or at the very least, how to make Agatha feel better. She could see the pain his words had caused, could see that he had wounded her pretty badly. His words had been meant to cut, and that was exactly what they had done. They had absolutely shredded his mother.

Soundlessly, she released her hold and picked up that soft, gentle hand before pulling them over to the bed.

They each slid atop it and Rio did not waste any time in pulling Agatha into her, reestablishing that firm embrace, though one hand moved to rub soothingly at her back. Rio just wanted to help, just wanted a find a way to see that look disappear.

If she thought she could have kissed it out of her, she would have. If she thought that she could sit there the rest of the night, just talking or singing or whatever Agatha needed from her, she would have done it without any sense of hesitation. She would have gone to the ends of the work to make the tidal wave of hurt pull back into the ocean it had spilled from.

The soft sound of the television across the room filled the air, but for a long time, it was the only sound. The minutes ticked by and Agatha didn't so much as twitch as she was there so steadfast against Rio's side, tucked into her, her cheek pressed just above the steady thump of Rio's heart. In fact, after enough time that nothing else seemed feasible, Rio's eyes swept down and as she saw the small sense of serenity on Agatha's face? She realized she was asleep.

Rio tilted her head back a little more, her eyes sweeping up to the steep cathedral ceiling of the room, wet despite herself.

This was painful. This was almost as painful as watching Estee go through really hard shit in life, and Rio felt something stir at the idea that someone else who had been able to make her feel that way. She knew she loved Agatha, but in that moment, she felt like she could feel every single bit of her pain.

For a few hours, they stayed completely still like that, Agatha fast asleep against Rio's side, but Rio simply had not been able to quiet her tired mind. It had lapped, paced and circled over and over again, waffling between the sheer thrill and joy those first few days had brought and what this felt like, which was not the most favorable feeling in the world.

Rio reached over and lifted her phone off of the nightstand on her side, seeing that it was a little after two in the morning. She sighed; she was still thirsty, and thinking about that glass of water still sitting on the counter top in the kitchen. A soft sigh passed through her lips and very slowly -- and with impossible care -- she removed herself from beneath Agatha, making sure she landed softly on the pillow that had been under them.

With deathly quiet footfalls, she wound her way down the hallway, down the stairs and crossed the space to the kitchen. She had glanced up to see that there was an odd refraction of light on the ceiling, but she did not realize where it had come from until she stepped further into the room. Her gaze swept over, realizing that the refrigerator door was open, and that there were a pair of legs protruding from the bottom of it.

She had tried to be soundless as she moved for the sink, noting already that her glass had been emptied and flipped, sitting on the plate she had placed in there earlier in the night.

Well, fuck.

She moved with a stillness that was inspired by fear, just wanting to get her water and scamper back up the stairs to hide away from anywhere he might be able to injure her, too.

It wasn't good enough, though. He shut the door and caught sight of her, his posture straightening, as if he were looking for a fight. She ignored him and filled her glass. As she turned away from him to walk the long way around, she heard him scoff and it really lit something up right in the core of her chest.

She turned, which she could tell surprised him, and met him evenly with her gaze across the expanse of the kitchen.

"Look, you don't know me. And that is perfectly fine. And I don't expect you, or literally anyone in this entire world, to understand, but..." Her lips twisted, her brow knit tight as she debated on her next words. "Your mother loves you. She talks about you like you are literally every star in her sky. I obviously don't know you, or what your life has been like... But she's really trying. She loves you, more than you will ever be able to understand."

"Yeah?" Nicky snipped, his tone sarcastic. "And what gives you any authority to say that?"

Rio offered him a smile; it was warm in its appearance, but there was a sense of certainty there, just beneath the surface.

"Because I have a daughter. And I know what it's like to be willing to do anything to know that she gets to live a good life. Maybe... Maybe letting you leave was her way of doing that for you."

Rio watched as her words landed, causing a bit of a dumbstruck look to flash across his face before it set again. Before he could open his mouth to say anything else, though, Rio turned on her heel and made her way around the island, heading right back up those stairs as she felt his gaze following her.

When she returned to the room, Agatha was still out cold, a soft snore sounding about three seconds after Rio had passed over the threshold. It caused a tender smile to bloom on her lips; even though she knew that the storm would roll back in the moment Agatha opened her eyes, she looked so... at peace, like the weight of the evening was no longer trying to drag her under.

While Rio knew that she could have panicked, that she could have worried in their hours of silence that Agatha was shutting her out, there was something underlying that left her of a different opinion.

Agatha had never once asked her to leave. Even with that expression, that look in her eyes, she had never wanted Rio any further away.

She placed her water on the nightstand and turned to her bag, changing out of the clothes she had been wearing for the day and into something a little more comfortable. When she was finished, she laid back down, gently draping an arm over Agatha's back, her thumb absent-mindedly brushing at the fabric of her shirt as she tucked her face into the hair on the top of her head.

She knew that she didn't have pretty much any of the answers that Agatha needed, but she was steadfast in her desire to do whatever she could to help on the search for them. She needed to find a way to soothe the injury, to nurse the burns that had seemed to cover her as a result of Nicky's white hot anger.

It hadn't taken much longer for her to fall asleep, pacified by the smell of Agatha's shampoo filling her nose, and the lingering reminder that it was there because she loved the woman she was holding onto, and that woman loved her, enough to stare in the face of her son and offer an unwavering defiance.

When she opened her eyes, the sun was gentle in the windows, but there was something noticeably different from when she had fallen asleep.

Agatha wasn't in bed.

Sleepily, she sat up, gently grinding her knuckles into a closed eye in an attempt to wipe the sleep away. With another soft breath, she realized that there were definitely a symphony of smells circling through the air, from coffee to bacon to something that almost smelled like fresh bread. Her brow wrinkled in curiosity for just a moment before she flipped back the duvet and slid out of the bed. She paced to the bathroom where she brushed her teeth and made herself look at least half-way presentable in the event she had to face Nicky again.

Rio's caution was evident in her posture, in the weight of her step as she descended down to the lower level. Her eyes turned toward the kitchen; Agatha's back to her, but there was steam rolling above the stove and a fresh loaf of what looked to be sourdough sitting on a cooling rack on the counter next to her.

Rio slid onto one of the stools, just watching for a moment as she moved about, clearly doing everything she could to keep herself busy and not dwelling on the entirety of the night before. A little pool of guilt formed low in Rio's belly, a slight twisting of nerves that curled around her spine. She shouldn't have engaged with Nicky the night before. And if he had in any way informed Agatha, it probably had not settled well.

"Good morning, darling," Rio braved, her voice low but still holding a gentle sense of warmth.

Agatha jumped in response, a startled motion that caused her head to whip over her shoulder, though the tension eased when she realized who it was.

"Good morning," she returned softly, finishing whatever it was she was tending to before she reached up to turn off the stove. She wiped her hands on a towel that hung on the handle of the oven and turned, greeting with a smile that, while still warm, was tinged with the heaviness of what they had experienced before they had fallen asleep.

She paced back toward the island, pushing a coffee mug to Rio before she pulled the coffee pot off the warmer, moving to pour some of it into the mug.

"Do you need any sugar or cream?" Agatha asked, that tender tone pulling at Rio's heart.

"I like my coffee black, but thank you." Rio offered a small smile as she pulled the mug into her hands, letting it warm her palms. Her eyes lifted to Agatha's face, holding with them the full empathy she felt for it. "I... I just want you to know... that if anything has changed, and you need your space back, it's okay. I just--"

She was cut off as Agatha raised her hand, a gentle request for her to stop.

"I don't want you going anywhere," she assured her, pressing her lips together. "I just... Can you maybe bear with me while I just... get it back together again?"

Rio's whole demeanor softened exponentially, her hand reaching across the countertop to pick up Agatha's.

"You'll find that patience is... kinda my thing." The smile that filled Rio's expression was warm and bright, a way to reassure Agatha that she was still right there, still steady and resolute.

"I..." Agatha started, but she stopped herself, pressing her lips together. "I'm really sorry that's how that went. I... had hoped it could be better, under different circumstances. I... guess I didn't realize just how angry he still was."

Rio gave her hand a light squeeze, her eyes never wavering.

"It's alright, Agatha. You don't have to explain it to me."

"I know, but if it made you feel even half the way it made me feel, we're a right miserable pair."

Rio let go of Agatha's hand and pushed herself to her feet, making her way easily around the length of the island. Her arms raised and slid perfectly snug right around Agatha's middle as Rio hugged herself to her, squeezing her tightly.

"At least we're together?" Rio posed, to which she felt Agatha's lips against her head.

"At least we're together."

Relief Next to Me

Reaching out for you in the dark.
I guess I'm just no good at finding relief.

*****

By the time they had untangled from their warm embrace, in which Rio was silently willing every bit of healing she could muster as if it could transfer like osmosis from her form into Agatha's, Rio's attention had been drawn to Agatha's previous task.

As she looked to the side, she saw the fruits of her labor; there was a pan with for perfectly cooked over easy eggs, one filled with a mixture of potatoes and peppers, and laid out on a baking rack was cooked bacon. Oh, and there was that damn loaf of bread. Rio's gaze swept from the spread, landing on Agatha's sheepish grin.

"When the hell did you have time to bake a loaf of bread?" Rio asked, the light of incredulity dancing in her eyes. The amusement curved her lips upward, ever so slightly, as if trying not to give herself away.

"When I woke up and, even though your thumb was still moving on my back, you were snoring," Agatha responded, entirely non-plussed. Her grin spread like wildfire, though, torching something in Rio's chest in the same moment. "I figured that you had probably just fallen asleep, so I didn't want to wake you. But... busy hands make idle minds?"

The expression on Agatha's face scrunched as she said it, as though it was something she had just made up to sound like she was being poetic, but it sounded like utter bullshit. They locked gazes and immediately burst into laughter, hands on arms across the space between them to keep steady.

"Come on, let's eat. Bread should still be warm," she offered, tilting her head toward the stove.

They had made their plates and placed themselves at one end of that unreasonably long dining table, their knees bumping occasionally with the way they were sat, closer toward a corner. Rio sensed, though, that the spot Agatha sat in at the end of the table? That was her throne. That was where she found her power. Rio was sure that table was used for more than meals; she could see it in her mind like a vision: Agatha with a small cluster of others, papers strewn across the table as she pointed, gave orders, watching as the pieces all fell into place to bring life to the vision that lived in her mind.

From the end of the table, Agatha could see whatever the world put in front of her.

Right then? Well, it just so happened to be Rio.
