Halfway through their meal, Agatha leaned back in her chair a bit, chewing thoughtfully on a piece of bacon. Rio watched her, for just a moment too long. She could see it as the light began to dim, ever so slightly, and the clouds begin to roll in. She was quiet for a beat before she spoke.

"Penny for your thoughts?" she offered, quirking a brow in mild curiosity.

Agatha's attention seemed to snap back into the moment, her gaze casting across the small space of the corner of that table. Her lips twisted, but then the clouds rolled out and her eyes lightened to that familiar warm blue. It was funny, Rio thought. Blue had been taught as a cool color, on the spectrum, but she couldn't have disagreed more. That blue? The ones when she caught glimpses into Agatha's very soul? That blue couldn't have been warmer.

"I have a couple of conference calls that I need to take from the office in a couple of hours... And in full interest of recognizing that you are your own entity with your own autonomy and not a puppy that has to follow me around all of the time, I would like to ask you what you would like to do." Agatha sat back up, her gaze zeroing in on Rio, looking through her again. "You are more than welcome to come with me, but you don't have to." She paused, her expression softening the slightest bit. "You are also welcome to stay here, though I think I know you well enough at this point to gauge that you would probably be uncomfortable with that. So, as a third option, you are more than welcome to take the car and explore, if you would like."

There was this strange feeling that wound through every inch of Rio's being, as she sat there and listened to what Agatha had to say. There were a few things to dissect there; Agatha had really hit the nail on the head -- several times. She was offering her a choice, options. She was under no pre-conceived notion that although yes, Rio was there for her, but she also did not have to dedicate every single moment to being together. Second, she had been spot on, knowing that the idea of being alone in the remote vicinity of Nicky was not exactly something she would clamor at the chance for. But the third offer? That was the one that churned Rio's the stomach the most.

In that moment, looking into those eyes she wanted so badly to drown in, she realized something incredibly striking, and perhaps bordering on embarrassing.

She didn't really have any desire to see anything the city had to offer if she wasn't also afforded the opportunity to see it through Agatha's lens, at the same time.

Rio's hand lifted, landing on Agatha's where it was resting on the table, that light brush of her thumb trekking over her skin. Her green eyes studied her own movements for a moment and then lifted, looking at a face that -- as much as she never would have admitted it -- looked like it could be her home?

"I want to go with you."

The reaction was instant, Agatha's smile spreading, moved and bright. But then, something flickered in her eyes; it was that ornery spark.

"Does that mean you're bringing your book?" she posed, her tone a little lower, a little thicker as she raised a lone brow.

The heat on Rio's neck was instant, and she could feel as it blossomed on her chest, too. There was an instant smirk across her face, her eyes dancing with their own light.

"I suppose I'll need my glasses, too?"

Agatha blinked, as if the sudden realization had hit her. She clucked her tongue, pursing her lips as she looked away dramatically.

Rio was watching, hanging on the playfulness of the moment as she chose to play the game Agatha was laying in front of her.

"Is something wrong?" Rio cooed sweetly, leaning a little over the corner of the table.

Agatha's expression scrunched, as if she were focusing hard on recalling something just beyond her reach. Her hand raised, reaching up to tap a finger to her lip in thought.

"Yes, actually," she finally answered, her head turning back to match Rio's stare that had never once moved. "I distinctly remember telling you that you should never take those off."

Both of Rio's brows shot up in amusement, her laugher instant. "Aye, so am I just supposed to sleep in them, too?" she asked back, tilting her head in an adorably interrogative fashion.

Agatha gave a shrug of her shoulders as she popped the last bit of her bacon into her mouth, somehow managing to hold a deliciously predatory smirk that sent a thrill coursing through Rio's veins. She flipped her hand over beneath Rio's and gave it a light squeeze before she stood, scooting the chair back as she did so.

Before she let go, though, she leaned down and pressed an affectionate kiss atop Rio's head.

"I'm going to go shower."

She let go and grabbed the now-empty plates with a soft thanks from Rio, who had turned her attention to the remaining bit of coffee in her mug. As she was mid-sip, though, she glanced toward the stairs as Agatha crossed into her line of sight. By the time her foot hit the second step, her arms were crossing her front. In one deft, quick movement, she pulled up and stripped the shirt off of her torso, her bare back a valley of muscle and skin that Rio often ached to get lost in, in the quieter moments.

The moment it actually processed in Rio's mind? She exhaled a sharp sigh into her coffee that bubbled and splashed it both inside the cup and also flecking out to leave a few drops on her upper lip an chin.

She lowered it with haste, immediately reaching up to wipe at her face, her eyes still practically bulging out of her head.

She had disappeared up the stairs, which left Rio thankful for a moment to recover, but then it sounded, a bolt of lightning launched from Agatha's position, piercing straight through Rio's middle:

"Well, are you coming or not?"

*****

Those showers? They had become a safe haven for Rio in a way she had never thought was possible. When they crossed from cool air to the warm flow of water? It was like the moment that door closed, nothing else existed. It was just the two of them, no one and nothing else.

Despite the earlier conversation, they had managed to keep the shower short and oddly focused -- for the most part. At one point, Rio's hand had begun to wander, but Agatha had stopped her, that admonishingly gentle clicking of her tongue. Rio had let out a whine, but as Agatha had taken her up by the face and kissed her like she was intent on pulling every last breath from her lungs? It was what she had said that had seared into her the most.

"You don't get to ruin my plans this time."

It had sent a shiver of pure thrill up Rio's spine, and it had probably given off the opposite of the intended effect. In fact, it took almost every drop of self-restraint Rio had to keep her mind from wandering about what, exactly, that meant.

In fact, even as they rolled through the city in the back of Agatha's town car, she still couldn't get it out of her head. She had seen that look in her eyes, like she could have swallowed her whole, devoured her, but she had practiced far more restraint than Rio had wanted to. Agatha was the one running this game, and Rio was just rolling dice, like the numbers that turned up could determine the course of action they would take.

Rio had never spent so much time in elevators as she had since she had set foot in LA, but they were often filled with the physical closeness of Agatha's arms wrapped around her shoulder, sometimes peppered with the occasional kiss to the side of her head. They were quickly becoming one of her favorite softer moments of isolation. In that elevator, it was just them. In the elevator, anything could happen and no one would know.

The had filed into Agatha's office, but she had done something that she hadn't done before, which was close the door. Right then, it seemed nothing more than just a little difference, and she attributed it simply to the fact that Agatha had said she would be on calls and probably wanted to eliminate any extra noise.

Rio had cozied up in her spot -- her spot -- on that plush white couch in Agatha's office, her knees pulled toward her chest and her book resting on the tops of her thighs.

She would hit a good run, get through about ten to twelve pages, and then her mind would start to wander back to their shower that morning. She wasn't upset -- by any measure -- but Agatha was clearly up to something, and even thinking about it? She could feel the dull thrum kick up between her legs at the same time the pink clawed its way up her neck. She would tuck her chin a bit further and spend the next five minutes trying to coax herself back into an attempt to immerse herself in the story instead of losing herself in the mental video she'd taken of Agatha bare, in the shower, in that hotel bed, walking up those stairs.

FOCUS!

And it would last all of another ten to fifteen pages. Each time she glanced up, Agatha was deeply immersed into the meeting that was on her laptop, but she had an AirPod in, which meant Rio was only able to hear half of what was being discussed, though she wasn't paying too much attention. Well, except for every time the word 'Auckland' came out of Agatha's mouth, drawing a pointed stare accompanied by a smirk from Rio every single time. And every single time, Agatha met her eyes across the room, that same pink creeping up the sides of her neck ever so slightly.

And then, like a flash, she would remember that she was in the middle of a meeting and would snap back to attention, though the pink sometimes reached her cheeks, too.

The meeting drew to a close and Agatha reached forward, closing the laptop. She leaned back in her chair, her gaze sweeping over to take in Rio, still propped on the couch, focused on the page in front of her, for once.

"One down, two to go, but I have about an hour and a half until the next one. We can order something to eat, if you want," she offered sweetly.

Rio sat up a bit, letting her legs extend the length of the couch as she raised her arms in a bit of a stretch. She reached up, sliding her glasses on top of her head.

"Do you know what I've always heard about but know nothing about?" Rio posed, a little smile spreading.

Agatha tilted her head in question, as if encouraging her to continue.

"If I fuck this up, do not laugh at me," Rio warned, tipping her head forward to accentuate her point, though she was still smiling. "American Bar-Bee-Que," she pronounced deliberately, and she could see it in Agatha's eyes before it touched her lips; the laughter dancing there like lights in the sky.

She covered her mouth in an attempt to stifle it, but it bubbled out of her, a bright and beautiful sound that echoed off of the walls of Rio's soul.

Her face puckered in mock distaste as she exhaled in a huff, her arms crossing her middle like a scolded child.

"I said you weren't supposed to laugh," she whined, her bottom lip jutting out in a pout.

"Okay, but to be fair, that was probably the most adorable thing I have ever seen in my entire life," Agatha returned, leaning forward on her arms across the desk, her eyes seeming to drink Rio in. She raised an arm, giving a gentle flick of her hand. "No tall order. I'll get us Bludso's. Do you have a preference, chicken or beef? Their brisket..." Agatha tipped her head back, an oh! sounding that sucker punched Rio right in the middle escaping her lips. "It's to die for," she added, lowering her head again.

"You know," Rio mused, though she had slid her glasses back on and looked down at her book, idly flipping a page she hadn't read yet, more for effect than anything else. "The fact that you have not one, but two more meetings is... pretty annoying," she mused, though it was clear by her tone that she understood.

She reached up and gave a gentle tug on the tie that had been holding her hair into a secured bun atop her head, shaking her hands through it as it dropped down over her back and shoulders. Her eyes, over the top rim of her glasses, caught sight of Agatha, and it caused a smirk to fill her face.

There, phone in hand with a finger poised over it, Agatha sat with her jaw slack, her mouth in a 'o' shape. The hunger hadn't quite arrived -- yet -- but there was this utter look of awe and complete reverence written clearly across her face. It lit that match in Rio's stomach and she didn't even try to temper the blush that found her cheeks, bright crimson.

"Aren't you supposed to be ordering food or something?" Rio teased, her nose scrunching to accentuate her point.

Something was stirring in Agatha, that much was very apparent, but at Rio's question, she seemed to realize that she had been staring -- no, literally ogling -- and had not completed the task she had started. Her free hand raised, a much gentler finger than the one Rio had seen the night before raising to point at her as Agatha chewed on her bottom lip.

"You... You woke up feeling ornery this morning, didn't you?" she questioned, though that little smile playing at her lips gave her away -- she was eating up every minute of it.

Rio offered a shrug, to which Agatha had rolled her eyes, doing her best to turn her attention back to completing their lunch order.

"There! Should be here in twenty." Agatha leaned back in her chair again, exhaling a content sigh. "Any ideas on how to kill twenty minutes?"

At this, Rio perked, sitting up a little straighter. "Well, that depends..." she mused, closing the book in her lap. Agatha's posture stiffened the slightest bit, but she did not sit up in the chair. Rio placed the book on the couch by her legs and turned, placing her bare feet on the soft carpet.

"We could... listen to music..." she offered, another deliberate step. "Or scroll our phones," another step. "Or maybe we could see if anyone has a newspaper to read." By the time she finished speaking, she was directly beside Agatha's chair, raising a finger to push at the uppermost part of the chair so that she would swivel in place.

As she reached an adequate position, Rio made her move. Fluidly and with honed-in precision, she lifted a leg and swung it over both of Agatha's, setting herself directly in her lap. As she met her gaze, she could see a delicious swirling of both hunger and wonder.

"Or maybe," she offered in consideration as a hand raised to twist a strand of Agatha's hair around her finger. "We could see how far into that twenty minutes we can get by ways of making out before one of us passes out from lack of oxygen?"

The look on her face was an adorable twisting of her features, as if she were genuinely curious which option Agatha would choose, though she'd known before she even started listing them off. She got her answer, though, not a moment later.

Agatha's hands fell to her hips, a firm grip that actually caught Rio off guard, eliciting a delighted squeal. She was sitting up, their chests colliding with just enough force that Rio wavered slightly, bending back half of an inch before she righted herself again. One hand was off Rio's hip in an instant, raising to cup her jaw as she pulled her in for a kiss that was yes, warm, but then quickly elevated in heat.

When Rio had bared enough teeth to catch Agatha's lower lip between them, the whimpered moan that rumbled out of Agatha left Rio feeling more desperate for her than she had in the shower that morning.

As the minutes ticked on, they had worked as hard at fulfilling their goal as they could, though every time Agatha pulled back to gulp in a solitary breath, Rio always took the time to goad her.

"You must be a terrible swimmer."

"That's all?"

"Take a deeper breath."

She could tell that each one landed exactly as she intended by the way Agatha would grab at her, smashing their lips back together again and again.

Rio had been completely occupied by the way Agatha's tongue was exploring every crevice of her mouth when there was a sharp rapping at the door. She pulled away in an instant and the whine from the other woman? Rio briefly considered running to grab the food, tossing it aside and bolting back to bend her right over that desk.

Show some self-control, for fuck's sake.

She reached up and ran an almost taunting finger up Agatha's throat to just under her chin, not missing the way she tilted her head back the slightest bit.

After another brief moment, she removed herself from her perch on Agatha's lap and flitted over to the door, pulling it open to thank the assistant who handed it over. She shut it again and sauntered back over to her, placing the bag on her desk.

"Still hungry?" she posed, her tone thick with her smart-aleck demeanor.

"Oh, ravenous," Agatha answered, her eyes never leaving Rio's face.

The corners of Rio's eyes wrinkled instantly with her grin, but she gave a shrug that feigned innocence. "Suppose we should eat, then, before your meeting in... half an hour?"

Agatha tucked the edge of her lip between her teeth, as if she were having a debate inside of that beautiful brain of hers. With a dissatisfied resignation, she heaved a sigh and reached over to untie the bag.

"Hm," Rio exhaled, watching her as she worked, pulling boxes and containers out.

Agatha's eyes snapped up. "Yes?"

"Oh nothing," Rio offered, very reminiscent of when Agatha had underhandedly called her bossy. "I guess I'm just rather impressed."

"Oh?" Agatha raised a brow. "With what, exactly?"

Rio reached down, picking up one of the plastic wrapped sets of cutlery, toying with it idly in her fingers.

"That steel trap you've got locked on your self-restraint. Truly, incredibly impressive."

Agatha's lips twisted, her eyes a little darker, but it was not the same storm Rio had been seeing since the night before. This one crackled and burst with lightning.

"Yeah, well," Agatha said, forcing herself to sort through their meals. "I'm kind of regretting not keeping a spare pair of panties in my desk."

A delighted spike of a thrilling rush shot throughout Rio and her own eyes flashed with her mischief and glee.

As Agatha finished opening everything, there was this one split second, but Rio had caught it. Agatha had stared straight ahead at the spread in front of her, and her jaw clenched. That was new. Suddenly, Rio was piecing together a whole new puzzle; it was an inner battle. Agatha had a duty to her career, and it was the entire reason they were there, but it became so glaringly obvious in that one little gesture, that there were plenty of things she would have rather been doing -- the majority of them to Rio.

Rio leaned down, placing the softest of kisses, something reminiscent of the flutter of a butterfly's wings, to Agatha's cheek.

As she stood, though, she realized that she was going to have to go back to the couch. Even though she wasn't looking at Agatha, it was almost like she could sense the frown that pulled at Rio's lips. She rolled back slightly and gave a light tug on the hem of Rio's shirt. Now That You're Home

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Sweet Jesus, I swear that I love you
No matter what the chariot says.

*****

As lids slid open, a soft gasp passed through Rio's lips as she was throttled into consciousness by a restlessness that only seemed to come from nightmares. She could feel it in the tips of her fingers and toes, like it had been one of those illusions of falling and waking up mid-air.

Slowly, the world around her began to bleed in; the room was mostly dark, but there was one dim lamp still on in the corner, casting the faintest glow on the ceiling. She inhaled; lavender and vanilla and the slightest tickling of her nose by the few strands of hair her breath had picked up. Agatha was warm against her, Rio's own arm draped over her middle. Her head turned slightly, nuzzling into the comfort she felt in those first few moments of consciousness.

And then it hit her.

She lifted her head, processing more of where they actually were, her eyes immediately finding the back of that white couch. Shit. They had fallen asleep.

It wasn't like anyone could have blamed them. What had unfolded in that office that night? Rio had read books and that was something she didn't think anyone could pen into existence.

Then again, was any of the last five days?

Five days. Had it really only been five days? The revelation seemed to pounce on her in the dark, stilling her breath for just a moment. Everything they had done; the hotel bar, dinner and a beach fire, a literal fucking horseback ride, going home with Agatha, making Nicky's unfortunate acquaintance, and then what had happened in that office?

How had it only been five days?

After a brief moment of reflection, she realized that it was probably a good idea to wake Agatha so they could sneak their way out before the sun came up and people started showing up to work.

Rio lifted her head off of Agatha's shoulder and leaned toward her sweet, serene, sleeping face. Her lips pressed ever-so-softly to the apple of her cheek.

"Agatha," she breathed against the warmth of her skin. Her fingers pressed tenderly into Agatha's side, a gentle prodding that she hoped might rouse her.

A soft snore, and a gentle stirring as Agatha's arm moved, her hand landing just below Rio's elbow. She could have imagined it, because Agatha was still clearly asleep, but she felt her gentle grip flex into the flesh of her arm.

Rio tugged on her side a little harder this time.

"Baby, wake up." As it tumbled out? The way it hit her own ears caused her chest to squeeze. It was a term of endearment that Rio was using for the very first time in this context, in the context of a relationship, and it struck her how easy it had been to will it into the universe.

That seemed to work. Agatha's body shifted a little and her head turned, forehead landing flush against Rio's lips inadvertently. She exhaled a low hum that Rio could feel in the depths of her being. She would have loved nothing more than to just curl back up into the warmth of Agatha's bare skin and sleep for a day, but they were in a very compromising position... literally.

"We fell asleep in the office," Rio murmured at her. The next words came with a sleepy ease that startled even her the moment she said them. "We should go home."

She could feel it, that mix of panic and thrill that sat heavy in the middle of her throat. She knew that Agatha was likely still groggy enough that she hadn't actually caught the weight of it, or how it was suddenly making Rio batten down the hatches against her own internal monologue. It wasn't her home. It was Agatha's. Where her son was likely still ruminating in that pool house, angry at Rio's sudden presence in his life.

Rio had checked into Hotel Harkness, but she was merely a guest. She had a home, a daughter, a life that would undoubtedly still be waiting for her by the time she found the courage to peel herself from the depths of the fantasy she was now living in. She would go back to waking up to waves instead of skin, to watering her plants instead of the blossoming bud that was beginning to flower between them.

Agatha was quiet for a few long moments and Rio could almost hear the search for the perfect words going on inside of that head. Subtly, her grip around Rio's middle tightened.

"I don't know. I know it seems stupid, but... Even with you right next to me, I often can't get that sight out of my head, that view from up on that bridge, looking down on you. Your little shorts that I'm almost willing to bet you would not wear out, that soft green tank top, your sunglasses." Agatha paused and Rio turned her face toward her a little bit. "You whistled at me, I looked up, and for a moment, it felt like... Gods, I don't know how to say it without sounding idiotic or entirely insane."

Rio's hand landed on Agatha's elbow on the opposite side, brushing softly at her skin in her show of support, as if to tell her that she wasn't going anywhere, no matter what she said.

"I saw you and it felt like seeing someone I'd known my whole life and yet had not spent a minute of time with. I saw you, and I felt a familiarity I have never known. And then... next thing I knew, you were holding your hand out, lifting me out of that water."

The lightest sound -- a chuckle -- passed through Agatha's lips in just a breath.

"That entire night, I had so much fun. It was so impossibly nice to just... be no one to the rest of the world for a night. You... you have this way about you. Honestly? I'm still trying to figure it out. Despite the things you've gone through in life, you move with certainty and ease. Your trauma never made you second guess your place in the world, you knew that your duty and purpose was to be an amazing mother to Estee. That much was clear that first night."

Although physically she was finding a way to somehow not let it show, Rio was completely crumbling at listening to the way Agatha was talking about her. It caused a stinging at the backs of her eyes, but she took in a slow breath to try and steady the pooling of emotion that was gathering in her chest.

"When I went inside to shower, I definitely scoped you out, but not for the reasons you think. I... saw all of the plants, wanted to look at them. I just... followed them. When I looked up, I could see into what I now realize is Estee's room. I mean, I realized it when you told me you had a kid, but at the time, I was interested. I accidentally passed your room when I went to get clothes to wear and ended up in the den."

"Hm," Rio mused. "That was why you held your hand out to me... for the first time," Rio tacked on, the smile audible in the thickness of her words.

"After I got out of the shower, I saw the post-its and the pen. I don't know why I did it, or why that was why I wrote, as if it would mean anything, but --"

She was cut off at the way Rio's grip tightened on her arm, a willing for her to stop.

"It meant everything."

Agatha's face tucked into the crook of Rio's neck as she squeezed her a little tighter, held her just a little closer, though they were already practically bleeding into one another, the lines blurring between where Rio ended and Agatha began.

"Estee helped me out with that, too, turns out. She found it on the floor and stuck it in one of my more prized plants, knowing I would see it."

Another flitter of a laugh rolled in over the skin of Rio's neck, a shiver coursing through her.

"I owe her a drink, or something. 'Cause Jesus, what a wing-woman," Agatha responded, the curve of her smile still pressed to Rio's skin. She pulled back, though, hooking her chin back where it had been.

Agatha was quiet for a moment, but Rio could feel it, the slight tension creeping into Agatha as she sat there behind her. Rio raised a hand, the backs of her knuckles caressing Agatha's far cheek.

Her jaw set as Rio perceived she had been biting her lip, but Rio made no move, did not prod or push. It was clear there was something building up inside of Agatha, something she was working on articulating, so Rio let her have her time.

"Last night, when I went to go talk to Nicky... It was reasonable at first. I explained to him, in the most bare bones way, how I felt about you, and that you were not to be lumped into the experiences of my past. And honestly? It had seemed to pacify him, until he had asked how we met." Agatha sighed softly, her lips worrying together for a moment. "The more I tried to explain it, the less he wanted to hear it. He is under the impression that you could very well be an international serial killer and/or gold digger, to which I reminded him I am not that old. "

Even though the humored smile wanted to find Rio's features, it didn't quite make it there; the moment was too heavy for that.

"I understand as much as I can, as the person who put that trauma on him. I know that what I put him through wasn't fair, but it's also why I've let him strike his own path. Sure, he comes back every so often, like for birthdays and some holidays, but I was just so... so fucking happy to realize he had come home, only for him to act like that."

Rio's thumb had picked up a pace of brushing at Agatha's arm, just leaving her to focus entirely on what she was being told.

Another sigh, longer this time, pushed from Agatha's nostrils.

"When I told him that you were someone I could really see spending the rest of my life with, it set him all the way off."

There was the slightest uptick of Rio's heartbeat, there steady in her chest. She knew Agatha had said it, because of the way Nicky had hurled it at her like it were a Molotov cocktail, but hearing Agatha say it in that moment?

The tears were falling before Rio could even feel them behind her eyes. She was quiet and still, though, not wanting Agatha to stop if there was still more she had to say.

"He looked me dead in the face and asked if I had finally caved to doing hard drugs, and he meant it. He... he called it lust, infatuation. He told me that I couldn't be so reckless because I wanted my life to be a movie instead of one I'm orchestrating, that I was putting everything I had, my career, my relationship with him, at risk to see this out. It... hurt. Which was the point I believe you might have been privy to."

Rio was still crying, but now it had shifted to an empathy for this woman she cared for so desperately, this woman she had fallen in love with in a matter of days.

"I'm not worried about my career, and as far as he goes, he hasn't left, so I think it's safe to say it's probably still salvageable. And if he does, the security system will let me know and I'll call him and we'll probably spend twenty minutes yelling at each other until he gets mad enough to shut up and listen."

Despite her silent tears, Rio did release a soft breath of a laugh at this. In the next, though, she remembered something. The thought caused her to stiffen slightly in Agatha's arms, which drew her curiosity.

"I... I couldn't sleep last night. So I went to the kitchen for a glass of water and he was in there getting something to eat. I ignored him and got my water, but as I was leaving, he saw me and he just... I don't care if he hates me. He doesn't know me. His opinion of me, at this point, does not really matter to me because I am just a no one." At this statement, Agatha's arms noticeably tightened around her waist, as if to assert her defiance to the acknowledgment of that fact. "But... it really wounded me to hear him speak to you like that. So, I just told him that yes, he and I don't know each other, but that you love him. And that you're actually trying to be someone he can be proud of, which in my own opinion, you already are. He just doesn't see it."

Agatha lifted her chin from Rio's shoulder, but immediately, her lips were pressed to the side of her head, that grip tightening even more. She could feel it, even before Agatha breathed it into her hair.

"I love you."

Rio moved, slowly as to give Agatha enough time to retract just slightly as she turned, their gazes meeting over her shoulder. She tipped her chin, catching Agatha's lips in a kiss that only seemed to megaphone her response.

"I love you, too."

With another kiss, Agatha gave her one final squeeze, declaring that it was probably getting close enough to when people would show up that they should make a quick exit.

"Do you happen to have a secret way out?" Rio asked, pulling her shirt over her head as her own eyes cast down, indicating the sex-stained blouse of Agatha's -- that was also buttonless -- where it laid on the ground. She lifted her eyes, taking in the sight of the other woman.

Her slacks were back on, and her chest was back to being hugged by that lavender lace. The tone in her muscles was visible with the way her hands were raised and she was pulling her hair into a ponytail toward the back of her head.

"Alas, I do not. However..." she offered, pacing over to the cabinets that lined the wall behind her desk, reaching up to press on a longer panel. It clicked open to reveal a couple of shirts hanging and a few pairs of shoes on the bottom. She reached in and plucked one of the hangers out, sliding the shirt off of it before she placed it back in its home. "Shirts, I always keep. Though, I've thoroughly learned my lesson and will be bringing underwear with me to keep in there too," she added, a flirty raise of a brow cast in Rio's direction, only made better by that smirk she wore as she pulled the shirt over her head.

They gathered the rest of their things and departed into the dark of the building, quiet as they waited for the elevator to reach the bottom floor, Rio nearly falling asleep in Agatha's hold on the way down.

She had, actually, ended up dozing for a moment or two once or twice on the way back to Agatha's. She was only aware because the second time, she stirred to Agatha's lips on her forehead, beguiling her to wake up long enough that they could get inside and get into bed. She agreed, somehow forcing cognition into herself enough to climb out of the car and make it in the house. Their fingers were laced as Agatha pulled her into the house.

The lights were off, but there was the bright glow on the kitchen counter that was obstructed by a silhouette, and Rio's stomach began to seep into her toes, sinking at the sight of Nicky.

Agatha's hold on her hand tightened and she pulled her toward the stairs.

"Goodnight, Nicholas. I love you."

Agatha's words were firm, assertive, but they also left no opening for a conversation as the pair ascended the steps, quietly tucking into the sanctuary that was Agatha's bedroom.

They had been impossibly fast in the shower they took to remove the dried sheen of sex on their skin, and as Rio made her way into the bedroom, wrapped loosely in one of Agatha's robes, she couldn't help the warm blossoming of pink that licked at her cheeks when she took in the sight of Agatha looking at her like that.

"What?" she asked softly, almost shyly, as she shook her fingers through her hair one last time. She came around the edge of the bed and shifted down onto it, sliding over to press against Agatha's side. Her presence was immediately met with that protective and firm hold around her shoulders, pulling her in, into everything Agatha was and had ever been. And maybe, into everything she ever could be, too.

"I just keep wondering at what point I'm going to wake up, tangled in sheets, alone, and realize that this has been nothing more than one really fucking long fever dream," she murmured, turning to nuzzle into the side of Rio's head.

Rio's hand shifted over to land tentatively on Agatha's thigh, giving a gentle squeeze.

"Even when you wake up in the sheets, alone, I'll only be a call away," Rio offered back, though the anguish in her tone was hard to hide as she said it. It was still at least over a week away until she had to think about going home, but she felt like they needed to be reminded of the inevitability, to keep them in check.

Keep them in check? Yeah right. Like that was ever going to happen.

Rio had spent more than twenty years alone, twenty years with the company of her own existence. Twenty years that she could say with certainty that she was happy.

In a grand total of six days, she was having to examine what the scope of her life was going to take in, and how she was going to move about a world that was suddenly so much bigger than the little island she had spent almost her whole life on.

In six days, she had fallen so deeply in love that she had absolutely no idea what she would do if she lost it.

"I guess that means I'll have to hold onto waking up in your skin for as long as I can," Agatha murmured, placing another soft kiss to the side of Rio's head. Her hold slackened the slightest bit on Rio's shoulders, and she sank back into the pillows, leading Rio to follow suit.

She slid down and curled into Agatha's side -- her spot -- an arm fastening itself across Agatha's middle, the steady drumming of her heart beneath Rio's ear.

And within minutes, they were both asleep.

When Rio stirred the next morning, she was not wrapped up in Agatha's arms, but her presence was still felt by the way their legs were tangled together. Gauging by the way it felt, and without turning around, it was likely Agatha had rolled to her other side at some point during the morning.

She lifted her phone to check the time and saw that she had a text from Estee asking if she would be able to FaceTime in a bit. Rio had shot her a text back to let her know she had just woken up, but that she would call her as soon as she got up and moving.

So, she had set about the routine she had started to build, brushing her teeth, combing through her hair. She changed out of the robe and into an old camp shirt and a pair of joggers, giving herself a once over in the full length mirror by Agatha's dresser.

She was timid in her journey downstairs, but was relieved both to see that Nicky wasn't inside and that he had also left behind half a pot of coffee that was still on the warmer. She poured herself a cup and decided to sit out back in the warmth of the afternoon California sun to call Estee.

"Mama!" that sweet voice rang the moment her sweet face filled the screen. "I miss you!"

Rio's grin was instant, as it was any time this happened. Well, almost.

"Hi, roo. I miss you too. You doing alright?" she posed, glancing away to take a sip of her coffee before she re-focused.

"I am, mama. Tay just got back from Melbourne, so we have been just watching movies and ordering take out after class."

Taylah was Estee's best friend, and had been since they were in primary school. They graduated top of their class together, went to the same college, and even got an apartment together. That child might as well have been Rio's second, honestly.

"And I suppose you have filled Tay in on why I'm out of the country?" Rio posed, quirking a brow in amused curiosity.

Before Estee could speak, Taylah's head of blonde hair poked into frame.

"I think she's lying to me, Mama Vidal. Is she lying to me?" Tay asked, her own brows arched high in interrogation.

Rio laughed, shaking her head. "She is not lying to you. I plan on staying for another week or so. But... I think it's safe to say that I will be planning future trips. I... already hate thinking about leaving."

Rio's gaze was so locked on her phone that she did not notice that the window to the pool house was opened more than half-way and the curtains were moving slightly, but not from a breeze.

"That's because you're in love, mama," Estee practically sang at her, to which she rolled her eyes, but still offered a laugh in mock consolation.

"Yeah? And is that a problem for you?" she asked back, her tone light and teasing.<

"I'm actually thrilled for a chance to get you off my back," the joke came back over the phone, Rio's grin growing so wide that it wrinkled the corners of her eyes.

"And I think this is literally the cutest fucking thing I have ever heard, so good for you, Mama Vidal!" Taylah chimed in, the laugher only bubbling more from between Rio's lips.

"Thank you, Tay. I do have to say, I miss the fuck out of the both of you. We need to have a girls' day after graduation. Entirely my treat! Just my way to show the both of you how proud I am of everything you have each accomplished. You both just... Gods, I'm so lucky to have you in my life."

A soft echo of "Awwwww"s came from both of the girls, the smiles on their faces bright and genuine.

"So, any plans for the day?" Estee asked, the curiosity flickering in her eyes.

"Not yet, but that's typically how the days begin. Plus, it's two in the afternoon, here. I'm guessing if Agatha had to go into work, I would already be aware."

Work.

Agatha.

Her office.

"Mama?"

Rio's eyes cut back toward the phone, the sudden realization that she had been drifting causing an embarrassed heat to slip onto her cheeks.

"Sorry, mija. Got distracted, but I'm here!"

Both girls rolled their eyes.

"Mama Vidal, I think you've got it bad."

Rio grinned again, this time rolling her eyes at the two of them.

"Maybe I do. Only time will tell. You girls go watch your movies. Catch a wave for me if the tide's right, yeah?"

They both gave assertive nods, saluting to her, though they both broke out into giggles.

"I love you girls."

"Te amo, mama."

"Te veo, mija."

As she hung up the phone, Rio reached for her coffee and took a long pull, feeling the warmth as it filled her from the inside, though the sun had its own heat. After another moment, she got to her feet and made her way back inside the house.

As the door shut behind her, she was oblivious that, across the patio the door to the pool house opened. Nicky placed himself in the frame of it, watching through the window as Rio's form disappeared up the stairs.

He'd heard every single word of that conversation.

Chapter End Notes

i have posted my playlist for this on yt music to my twitter if anyone is interested! my handle is @kayyniiine love you all and thanks for being on this journey with me <3

Dreamer to a Dream

I've been called a dreamer, desperate for sleep.
You have been that dream, the one I shut my eyes to keep.

*****

It hadn't been long, perhaps a little over an hour, after Rio had returned to the bedroom after her chat with Estee. The warmth in her chest at the sight of Agatha sound asleep in bed caused the softest smile to form on her lips. How was this her life? How was it that every morning for the last five days, she'd gotten to wake up in the presence of this woman?

What the hell was she going to do when she had to go home? What was she going to do when she wasn't surrounded by the scents of palo santo and lilac, or lavender and vanilla? What was she going to do when she didn't wake up to already smell breakfast cooking in the kitchen? How was she going to handle it that she was going to spend night after night climbing into an empty bed?

More importantly, how was she going to be able to live with herself when she wouldn't be able to look Agatha in those gorgeous blue eyes, feel her cheek under her palm, and tell her with bleeding earnesty that she loved her?

Rio seemed to catch herself spiraling, propped up against the headboard with that mug of coffee idling in between her palms. Her lips twisted a bit in frustration; she still had over a week. She could not spend the next eight or more days sitting around, thinking herself into a pit over every reason this might not work. She'd already known that it was impractical, that it was beyond any logical explanation, and yet, she'd jumped out of that plane, not really giving a single fuck to check if she had a parachute on her before she did.

The only way forward? Let herself experience it. She couldn't get hung up on the what-ifs, even if they were outright terrifying. She wanted to soak up each moment she got with this damn enigma of a woman. Every day she woke up thankful for the pieces of Agatha she had given over the day before, that thirst for more knowledge, for more understanding would leave her parched before too long into the day.

She had raised the mug to take a sip of the coffee at almost the same time Agatha rolled over in bed, and for a moment, she was still. And then, her hand began to move around, frantically patting at the bed, her fingers landing shy of Rio's thigh by about an inch.

Rio turned, setting the mug down on the nightstand and reached over, picking Agatha's hand up as it continued its exploration.

"I'm right here, love," she breathed, raising Agatha's hand to lean forward so that she could place a soft kiss across the back of it. "I didn't go anywhere. Well, aside from outside to call Estee."

A sleepy hum reverberated off of Agatha's own teeth. She gave a tug on Rio's hand, as if she wanted her closer.

Immediately, Rio obliged, sliding down to lay on her side in front of Agatha, her hand falling in its place on Agatha's side.

"How is she?" Agatha mumbled softly, as if she were in an active battle to keep the sleep from pulling her under again.

"She's good. Her best friend was visiting her family in Melbourne and she got back I think yesterday. Or -- today? Er... The time change really fucks with my head," she disclosed, breathing a light laugh.

"Tay is like my adopted child, one of those that your own picks up along the way, you know," Rio told her; she knew she didn't have to say it outright to imply that if ever there were to come a day that she got to meet Estee? Well, she would probably meet Tay, too.

"Mmmm," Agatha hummed, a gentle smile tugging on her lips. She looked so peaceful, so... carefree.

"I take it you don't have to work today?" Rio cooed at her, craning her neck far enough forward that she could press a soft kiss to the tip of Agatha's nose.

"I can work from home today," Agatha prattled back, though her tone was still a little gravelly with her drowsiness.

Rio reached up, running a fingertip down the length of Agatha's nose, her eyes dancing with light as she watched her own movements.

"Are you still tired?" Rio posed, trying as hard as she could to make it sound as though her tone was curious, but there was an edge of taunting just around the outside of them.

"You fucking wore me out, what do you mean? Of couse I'm still tired," Agatha responded, her brow pinching in mock offense. She wasn't actually upset, but she also wanted to provide a little push back for the fun of it.

"Oh, so is this the part where we talk about that?" Rio asked, a smirk springing to her features as a brow cocked in question.

Agatha's eyes finally opened, looking right into Rio's with the piercing accuracy of a well thrown javellin. Her expression held a form of neutrality for a moment, and then there was an air of self-satisfied pride that washed over her.

"Which part? The one where you're a real good listener, or the one where we learned new things about our bodies?" she drawled slowly, her gaze steady in its carress of each and every one of Rio's features as she took her in, really beheld her.

"Listen," Rio breathed, that flush of embarrassment dropping on her like an anvil. "I had literally no idea that that was even a thing. But..." her lips pressed together, her own eyes darting back and forth between each of Agatha's. "You looked like you'd just won the biggest lottery in the world, so I couldn't even get upset or embarrassed."

"I did win the lottery," Agatha countered, her voice verging on daring. "But it was long before that happened."

In an instant? Rio absolutely could have just disappeared, just melted into the warmth of Agatha's stare. She knew what she was saying, without saying it. It was a common sentiment between them at this point.

Rio's palm raised and nestled lovingly against Agatha's cheek as she leaned forward enough to press their lips together in a smooth and full kiss, a welcome to the day she was hoping they would have.

Things with Agatha weren't ever set in stone, which Rio thought to be rather ironic. Agatha seemed the type who would need to keep a tight schedule, but she was just so... There it was, that word again. She was so damn carefree.

Hadn't Agatha told her, that very first day?

"I guess I'm just used to the world moving around me."

Agatha went where she wanted, did what she wanted, anyone's opinions be damned. She didn't care about making other people feel validated, or like what they said had any weight in her life. Hell, she hadn't even taken it from her own son. Rio was not sure if that was a testament more to who Agatha was as a person, or if... Could it be that she had already grown that protective of Rio?

That was silly. Even Rio was well aware that in Agatha's world? Number one had been and would always be Nicky, and as a mother? Rio respected that, and would never dare consider the idea of trying to tread on that relationship. The issue Rio took was with the rebellion that was constantly seeming to spike at every given moment.

That conversation out back had replayed through her head more times than she cared to admit; the way she had picked it apart, tried to analyze it and understand it, even without twenty years of history or context, it just left Rio feeling sad. She knew that while she had done everything she could to do right by Estee, she had made her own fair share of shit decisions, but the difference was that Estee actually had a forgiving bone in her body.

Still, there had been that strangely charged air around them when she had gripped at Rio's hand so tightly as she bid goodnight to her son. She couldn't have put a name to it at that moment in time, but looking back on it now?

Agatha had been protecting her.

The realization in the moment made Rio kiss her a little harder, just a push but nothing meant to entice. It was just a showing of true, pure affection. It was a way for her to understand that Rio simply felt like she could not get close enough. The reason Rio would kiss Agatha until her lungs no longer worked behind closed doors?

It was the same reason Agatha was insistent on holding her hand once they stepped out of them.

It was a constant reminder of the now, of the physical grounding of what it felt like to be in direct proximity to a human that burned brighter than the sun.

As Rio pulled away, her eyes fluttered open to behold Agatha's adorable face, still half smashed into the pillow, though there was more awareness in her gaze, like that had certainly been a way to wake up.

In her first actual substantial movement for the day, Agatha raised a hand and used two fingers to tuck a few strands of Rio's hair behind her ear, just... watching her. Worshipping her with that gentle gaze.

"So, I was thinking..." Agatha's voice came, soft and sweet as she chewed on the inside of her cheek in thought. "I do have some things I need to look over and approve at some point today. But... I remembered you telling me about the blue pools, which... I did visit, and also secured a permit for. So... thanks for that little bit of inspiration," she gushed in a praise that washed over Rio like a warm rain. "If you're up for a little hike, probably about the same duration, I'd like to take you to Escondido Falls. We can pack a lunch --"

"Dinner," Rio corrected, her grin instant.

"Shit... What time is it?" Agatha asked, lifting her head to glance toward the window. Rio noticced those deep red lines on her cheek, causing her stomach to give a little flip in adoration.

"A little after four."

She let out a low groan as she dropped her face directly into the pillow, letting if muffle the sound of her frustration. She lifted her head again, breathing a sigh.

"Maybe hike tomorrow. How about..."

"Agatha," Rio cut her off. "You do realize that we do not have to non-stop go and do things all the time, right?" she offered with a knowing tip of her head.

"I'm okay if you just want to stay in tonight, get your work done, and then maybe we can watch something, or sit outside."

There was this slight dimming in Agatha's eyes, and Rio almost backtracked, but then Agatha spoke.

"Are you sure?"

Rio scooped a gentle hold under Agatha's chin as she rolled up onto her elbow to get a better look at her. "Haven't you realized it yet?"

The question in Agatha's eyes was clear; she didn't know which part Rio was talking about.

"We could literally get stuck in your elevator, for hours, and I could practice self restraint and not put my hands on you. And you know what? I'd still have the time of my life."

That smile? That full, sweeping smile that literally touched every single piece of Agatha's expression? Rio might as well have been on the moon, because being on any plane of earthly existence? It was not going to happen when Agatha was looking at her like that, smiling at her like that.

"Really, though. Pull that laptop out and I'll be stuck to your side, book in hand and glasses on. Maybe you'll cook me something fancy if I'm lucky." The warmth of her tone was reminiscent of the end of a hot summer day as the sun just slipped over the horizon. It had its heat, but it was like a cloaking of softness and harmony.

Agatha pushed herself up onto her elbows so that their faces were a little more even in front of one another, those eyes doing that ever-so-familiar thing they did where they looked straight into her, picking apart the pieces until she found what she was looking for. Those thoughts bustled and blew behind those blue pools and Rio had almost reached a point of anticipation, waiting for Agatha to speak.

"I know it's a common topic... But... I just..."

Rio's grin was tamed only slightly, but the sheer joy at watching Agatha fumble for words was completely lighting her up. Someone who was so well-spoken, so outspoken, so sure in everything she put forth into the world?

"It's okay. I know. You're thankful, because I am too. I think that the true test in a relationship is when you figure out if you still work when you sit in silence for hours tending to your own things," she offered, her features softening. "So, I suppose it's good we're hitting that hump now, hm?"

Agatha's hand raised in a quick motion that Rio had not been expecting, and she had not been expecting the way Agatha's palm covered her entire face, her fingertips sliding over her scalp as she playfully pushed her away.

"Ack! That optimism again! You should really go get that checked out," Agatha released in a mix of a declaration and a laugh.

Rio had started to open her mouth to say something back, but something caught her attention. It was... a smell? A good smell. It smelled like food, but she couldn't immediately identify what it was. Her brow wrinkled the slightest bit and she glanced back at Agatha, her curiosity also seeming piqued.

With pinched brows, the two of them climbed out of bed and offered gentle adjustments to hair and wardrobe to make sure that if they did venture downstairs and Nicky happened to be there, it might not encourage him to show his ass in its entirety. She was behind Agatha, fingers linked together as Agatha's arm reached out behind her for the contact.

As they reached the base of the stairs, they both stopped, a bit stunned by what they saw.

There were three plates stacked on the corner of the island with three sets of silverware laying next to them. A few inches away, there sat a bottle of red wine and three glasses.

On the other side of that island, Nicky's back was to them as he tended to something on the stove.

Rio, breaking out of her nervous tension, realized that the smells had become more intense, and they smelled really good.

"Hi, son," Agatha greeted, though there was a tense edge of nerves that wrapped snugly over both words.

Nicky's head lifted, looking over his shoulder at the both of them for a brief moment before he turned his attention back to his work. Rio could feel as that protective flame flared up in her stomach, but then he spoke.

"Hey, mom," he offered back, his tone far less tense than the last time Rio had heard it.

"Are you having company?" she asked curiously, clearly having taken notice to the dinner wear he had set out.

"No," he responded, and for a moment, Rio felt stupid. Obviously, he could not possibly mean what he was implying with such a vague answer.

"So you're cooking for...?" Agatha pressed on, clearly missing the cue that Rio had quickly picked up on, but would not dare to speak on.

"You guys," he answered, his tone so cool and calm like it was just something that made the most sense in the world.

Rio could feel it, that obvious shift in Agatha's posture as it went through phases. First, her hand gripped at Rio's a little tighter. Then, she inhaled a sharp breath, tensing. Last, she exhaled it, her posture softening completely.

"Nicky..." she managed, obviously in an attempt to try and understand.

He still didn't turn, though, keeping himself busied by whatever it was that he was working on.

"Nicholas."

Slowly, he stilled his motions over the stove and turned around, his lowered gaze slowly raising to meet Agatha's over the space of the island.

"I'm sorry, mom. And... I'm sorry to you, too Rio," he offered softly, his eyes sweeping over to her for a moment in acknowledgement.

Rio almost immediately realized that this was a rare moment; the way that Agatha was holding her breath, as if she thought that it was going to shatter right in front of them and he would instead reveal that it was some grand scheme to make her miserable.

"I... I wasn't fair to you. And... I got angry because I really had thought things were different and I just..." He stopped, pressing his lips together in a very Agatha-like way as he tried to pull the right words out. "I reacted because I thought we were at a good place, that you were doing really well. And I just... When you told me, about Rio," he said, his eyes shifting over another moment, then cutting back to Agatha. "You're both right. I don't understand it. But... maybe that's because it's not my place to understand."

Rio stole a glance at the woman beside her and she realized she was seeing another new facet of Agatha; the agonized mother who was actively trying to correct past mistakes, staring in the face of the injured son who was still healing.

His gaze drifted to Rio, watching her for a moment. In the light? His eyes looked so much like Estee's. She felt a pang of understanding in her chest, but when he spoke? It was Rio's turn to be shocked to her core.

"I heard you, earlier," he voiced, but he was quick to clarify. "On the phone with your daughter and her friend. And... I heard you guys talking about my mom. And I guess it made me realize that I judged you pretty harshly for not knowing anything about you. You had no idea I could hear you, and you just..."

Rio could feel acutely every place where her knuckles collided inside of her hand as Agatha squeezed it so hard she actually had a brief moment of worry where thought something might break.

"You clearly love her. And... As much as I still don't get it... I've always wanted my mom to find someone who could love her for all that she is, mistakes and imperfections included. Because god knows, it's a really fucking hard job sometimes."

She could hear it, the huff that accompanied a tight smile on Agatha's lips. She understood it.

"But... if you meant what you told your daughter, then... that's good enough for me to give you the benefit of the doubt."

There was still this small, indignant part of Rio that wanted to be mad, that wanted to read deeper into what he was saying to try and dissect it and shred it down until its validity was no longer credible. With the way Agatha still had that death grip on her hand? She did what she could to squeeze back as she spoke.

"I did mean it. So... thank you."

She got it; he was being protective while also trying to deal with learned behaviors that his childhood had taught him. Agatha recognized that, in her eyes, she had not been a good mother when he was younger and while she knew she could not go back and do it over with a fresh understanding, she was actively trying to make her life better. Agatha only ever wanted to make Nicky proud; that much was painfully obvious.

Slowly, Agatha's hold began to slacken on Rio's hand until they were at a normal level of pressure when it came to the contact.

"What did you make?" Agatha asked softly, tipping her chin toward the stove.

"Spinach and artichoke stuffed chicken with scalloped potatoes and brown sugar glazed carrots. I just did what I could with what was already in there," he offered by means of explanation, as if every item he had not listed did not sound positively delicious. The thought also struck her -- Agatha had taught Nicky how to cook. It warmed something in her, something that was fighting to stay iced in regards to him.

Agatha's eyes swept down to the bottle of wine, raising back up to his in silent question.

In the wordless exchange, Nicky's eyes followed her gaze, then lifted back up to her. The grin on his face was sheepish and he raised a hand to the back of his neck, giving a gentle shrug.

What Rio did not know was that the bottle he had pulled from the wine cellar and placed on that island countertop was worth over a thousand dollars.

"The Rothschild? What's the occasion?"

The look that fell across Nick's expression? Even though she was undoubtedly still wary, for fair enough reasons, Rio softened at the sight. It was... tender. Sweet, even.

"Well... it's our first dinner together," he stated, as though it should have been the most obvious thing in the world.

Agatha's grip on Rio's hand relinquished entirely as she paced over to her son, her hand raising to ruffle his hair as she kissed him on the side of the head.

"You did good, kid."

*****

The three of them had sat at that massive dining table, Agatha perched in her throne with each of her loyal subjects at either hand, Rio and Nicky directly across from each other.

Admittedly, Rio had carried some tension with her into the interaction, but it quickly seemed to dissolve. Nicky was, honestly, a pretty charming young man. He had clearly inherited his sense of charisma and charm from his mother, and he knew how to hold conversation without making it feel awkward or forced.

She sat, rapt and often with her fingers entwined with Agatha's beneath the table, as he told stories about his time in Dubai, about the things he and his best friend did in the spirit of getting all they could out of the experience. Then, he started to talk about his app, which Rio was sure was meant to be an update for Agatha, but Rio had recognized the opportunity as her in.

For the next forty-five minutes, there was a fluid back and forth about differently scaled algorithms, processing systems, and coded syntaxes between them, and Agatha simply sat back in her throne and watched. She didn't try to interrupt or ask questions, she just let them talk, let them make points the other had not thought about it.

Nicky, intrigued, had caved and asked how Rio knew so much about coding, because that knowledge was definitely not common. When she had provided her answer? Agatha's gaze was in a constant battle of who to focus on more in that moment. Nicky was floored; he had clearly not expected something of such magnitude, and Rio looked so goddamn smug that Agatha could hardly contain the swelling of feeling that took her over.

Between the three of them over the course of the two hours they had sat there, they had drained the entire bottle of wine.

"I did not have the foresight to make dessert, too," Nicky announced with a downturn of his lips.

"Well," Agatha posed, leaning forward to prop her chin on her palm, elbow planted on the table. "How about you take the car, I'll send you some money, and you can go to Atomic and get us some ice cream?"

Nicky's grin was easy and fast, his eyes lighting up. "Of course. Salted caramel and marshmallow for you, of course. And...?" he posed, his gaze shifting. It all happened in a split second; Rio knew what was coming and her gaze cut to Agatha, and Agatha's grip on her fingers tightened.

"The cherry jubilee. The one with the cherries and chocolate chips," Agatha told him, and the way she said it with such authority? Nicky seemed to believe it as if it were a fact they had shared in a previous conversation, but Rio's stomach was doing absolute somersaults in her middle. She was fighting for her life not to leap across that corner and pounce on that woman and pepper her with every kiss she could stand.

He stood and tapped his back pocket to verify his wallet was there before he headed out to meet the driver. "I'll be back soon, I love you!" he called, disappearing down the foyer to the front door.

The moment Rio heard it click shut? Her head whipped back, wild and wondrous eyes taking Agatha in.

"How the fuck did you know that cherries and chocolate are my favorite?"

Agatha's smirk was almost wicked, but she simply squeezed her hand in response.

"Like I said. When I look at you, it's like I've known you my whole life. I'm just enjoying the minutes we now get to spend together learning the things I can't already feel in my bones."

Rio stared, completely dumbstruck by how positively enamored she was with the woman who looked across the space at her.

"You're a goddamned wonder, Agatha, you know that?"

"I've been told. But the way it sounds in your accent is my favorite."

Speak Easy to Me

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Speak easy to me.
I've got a lot on my mind this time tonight.

*****

The rest of the night seemed to have gone by in a flash.

Rio had taken the opportunity Nicky's absence had afforded her to utilize the time to shower Agatha with affection, leaned over the corner of that table. She had kissed across her face, lips gracing cheek bones, forehead, nose. She had told her how beautiful she was, how intelligent, how vivacious and cunning. For each kiss, an acknowledgment of each part of Agatha that made her more and more attractive.

When he had come back, they had migrated to the couch and spent the evening watching The Challenge, which Rio found to be absolutely fascinating. The mastery of both physical challenges and the social politicking intrigued her. Nicky and Agatha would indicate their favorites and explain why, or, on the other end, explain why they couldn't stand certain players. When they had reached the episode that's elimination challenge was two men, harnessed with their backs together? Rio was practically on the edge of her seat.

The larger of the two men had somehow, in a feat of absolute incredulity, managed to get himself to his feet, the other man flailing and kicking in an attempt to find solid ground. He stood to full height, the man on his back like a little backpack, and marched his way across the proving ground to launch them into a metal barrel.

Rio's eyes had been wide as her head turned to take in Agatha, who was next to her, and Nicky, who was on the other side of Agatha.

As her eyes found them, her heart nearly stopped. They were both looking at her, that exact same shit-eating grin plastered to their faces. They had known this was coming; hell, it was probably the whole reason they started at some random season out of the forty that were available.

The chorus of laughter that bounced off of every surface in that home was almost heavenly. For as reserved and nervous as Rio had been when they had first taken him in when he was cooking, she was rather quickly finding a softness for the young man, now that he had decided to shed his spikes.

Just looking at the two of them... It was insane how similar they really were when side by side. Nicky's eyes were green, but almost in an aquatic shade that had so many of Agatha's flecks of blue in them. His hair was so curly and wild, so bleached by the sun in different places. He had the faintest kiss of freckles on the apples of his cheeks, surely a product of his childhood.

They had finished their ice cream and watched another few episodes before Agatha announced that she was getting tired and that the two of them were going to head up for bed. Nicky had nodded his understanding and said he was going to stay inside for a little bit longer before he tucked in too. Agatha had leaned over and placed another kiss to his temple before she told him that she loved him, and bid him a goodnight.

Rio and Agatha had scaled the stairs, hand in hand, both nearly melting the moment their feet crossed the threshold. Before they could reach the bed, Agatha gave a firm tug on Rio's hand, pulling her in for a strong and satiating hug that reached every part of Rio's soul. She could hear it, beneath her ear as Agatha tucked her head to her chest: The thundering pound of unyielding love.

When they had crawled into bed that night, Rio never could have imagined what the passing days would hold for her.

That weekend, Nicky had turned up with three tickets to Knotts Berry Farm. Rio, obviously, had no clue what that was, but when Agatha explained that it was an amusement park that used to be a berry farm year ago? Well, that sounded interesting.

They'd spent the day bouncing from ride to ride, just enjoying the little bit of thrill-seeking it had brought them. The laughter that had been shared had been plentiful and each second of it only seemed to pump Rio's chest full of something that had to be helium, with the way it made the heels of her feet lift, only her toes dragging as she floated her way around.

That day, with the three of them just doing the most trivial thing like riding roller coasters?

All Rio could think about was how she knew if Estee and Tay could have been there? It would have been an entire squad, and it probably would have fit perfectly. The more time she spent with Nicky, the more she could see that he and Estee would get on like a house on fire. They were both bright and driven, motivated in their own ways, and some deep pang of longing twitched in her at the hope that she might get to see such an interaction someday.

As their weekend had drawn to a close, Nicky had announced that he was headed back to his home base for a little while to try and push an update to the app as quickly as he could so that he could come home for another visit. He had been of the intent to simply take an Uber, but in a move that surprised Rio, Agatha had pulled a set of keys out of a bowl and held them up in question.

Nicky had nodded and allowed Agatha to drive the three of them to the airport -- in her goddamn Range Rover -- so that he could catch his flight. Rio, for the sake of being polite, had gotten out as well when they unloaded so that he could grab his things and depart. He had hugged Agatha long in hard, a soft conversation happening over shoulders that was not quite loud enough for Rio to hear.

As they parted and Agatha begrudgingly let him go, Rio had not been expecting his eyes to fall on her as she stood a foot or so behind Agatha.

He stepped forward and tentatively held his arms out in question. A warm smile filled her face and she stepped forward to heed his request. It was a gentle hug, but it meant a lot, coming from him.

"Take care of her while you're still here. When you have to go, we'll work together to figure it out."

As that embrace ended, Rio, whose lips were pressed so tightly together that she was biting the insides, gave a curt not and turned back, climbing into the car.

The sound of the door slamming shut gave her the permission she needed; she began to cry. She knew how he had felt the moment he had looked at her in that living room. She knew that he had been angry, upset, and scared, all for very valid reasons. But there he had stood, pulling her into an embrace and forming a plan of attack of how they were going to hold Agatha together when neither of them could be around to physically do it.

It moved her, in the way that she knew if the roles were reversed and it were Estee instead of Nicky, she would have been saying the same thing to Agatha.

By the time she heard Agatha open the driver's side door, she reached up, furiously wiping at her face in an attempt to save some face.

When she looked up?

Agatha cheeks were wet, too.

Wordlessly, Rio reached across the console and picked Agatha's hand up, fastening her own around it snugly, so many unspoken things settling between them.

The ride home had been silent, and it was the heaviest silence that had fallen between them since Rio's arrival, and it remained that way throughout the following week.

The week had seemed to go by in a flash; they'd both had to invest quite a bit more time into the obligations of their careers, but it was done either side by side on that couch in Agatha's living room, or in Agatha's office posted in their designated positions.

The difference between the book and her laptop perched on her lap?

The laptop seemed to draw more focus from the far side of that desk. In a conversation that happened after the second day she had noticed it, Agatha had divulged that the expressions Rio often wore while in the throes of work were incredibly difficult to keep her eyes off of.

Their days, while filled with work, often led to nights of majesty and wonder. There were nights spent on the beach that was literally in Agatha's backyard. There were nights they sat atop that office building, watching the world move around them. There were nights when the brightest stars of the evening were the ones in Agatha's eyes every time she looked at Rio. There were nights when they would fall asleep and wake up to the warmth and dampness of skin and sweat. Every physical exchange seemed to only dial them in even deeper, beginning to entwine them in a way that was going to make separation impossible.

There was even a morning, three days before Rio was determined to go home, no matter how badly she did not want to, where she had woken up in an empty bed, much to her own chagrin. As she had lifted her head, though, she saw that there was a post-it note on Agatha's pillow. Her neat scrawl was across it with a simple instruction:

Get something nice. The car will take you where you need to go. See you at 6.

Her eyes dropped, seeing that matte black credit card laying where the note had been.

And so, she had done as she was told. She got herself up, showered and dressed and made her way downstairs to rush a cup of coffee and head out. As she walked outside, though, her phone dinged in an announcement that she had received a message. She pulled her phone out to see it was from Agatha, an eyebrow arching in piqued curiosity.

Gio has the address for the store. I mean it, get whatever you like the most. And for the love of gods, do not look at price tags.

Rio had gulped down the sudden push of affection that had nearly erupted from within her. Rio was not poor by any measure; her work over the last six years along had landed her with a salary that totaled in the high six digits, but she also was a tech developer, and not a critically acclaimed film director. Being told to treat herself on someone else's tab with no give or take was not something she was used to, ever, but she was learning very quickly that it felt... really good.

She had spent the afternoon pouring over different dresses, trying them on and sending Estee and Tay photos so that they could help her decide.

After about two hours, the three of them had come to a collective decision and she made the purchase, only after swiping the matching clutch on an whim. She checked the time; it was almost five. She grabbed the bag and made her way outside to see Gio standing at the back door, awaiting her return. She smiled at him kindly and he informed her he would return her to the house so that she could get ready, but that he was under strict instruction to have her in Santa Monica at 6pm sharp.

She had thanked him as she got out at the house and made her way inside to do as she had been charged. She took the time to do her makeup, the smoky eye and winged eyeliner suiting her appropriately. When she was done, she pulled the dress on and rummaged through Agatha's closet to find a pair of shoes, thankful that they wore the same size as she pulled the black velvet over her feet, securing the ties around her ankles.

She was ready and in the car by a little before 5:30, the anticipation slowly beginning to vibrate in her chest. What did Agatha have up her sleeve?

She watched the outside world in quiet reverence as the landscape would shift and change every so often. It had been a short while -- right at 6pm -- as they slowed at the curb and Rio's eyes lifted to see that they were in front of a building with the letters Capo printed neatly above the door. Even from the outside, Rio could tell... This wasn't just dinner. This was an experience.

Her eyes dropped, though, beneath the awning, her breath immediately escaping her.

There, in the most beautiful violet dress that hugged every single curve in just the right way, was Agatha, one lone rose secured snugly between her fingers.

Rio's eyes threatened to glass over, but she choked the emotion back. Taking a deep breath, she pulled the handle and pushed the door open. She slid to her feet, looking across the sidewalk to take in the sight of Agatha.

Her eyes had started at Rio's feet, a small smirk forming at the sight of her own shoes, but then it traveled up.

It inspected every single way that black dress hung on Rio's frame perfectly, that high slit that almost reached her hip leaving just enough to keep Agatha wanting more. The cut was a deep v that ran from her shoulders to just below her navel, the empty space filled with an opaque black mesh. The way her hair was curled, and those earrings -- wait a minute.

Although she had been completely stuck on finding words, seeing those earrings made something in her balloon wide with heat, like she was going to be carried right off the ground.

"Are those... the earrings?" Agatha asked, and though she was still nearly slack-jawed and in shock, Rio could hear the softness in the question.

An alluring smile curled her own lips as she nodded. Agatha crossed the space between them, her hand sliding into position on the small of Rio's back as she leaned in for a tender but full kiss that nearly yanked Rio under in its soft and unassuming demeanor. As she pulled away, Rio's smoldering green gaze found her at close range.

"I took your shoes, too," she added, leaning up to steal another soft kiss that lasted but a couple of seconds.

Agatha had handed over the rose and they made their way, hand-in-hand, into the restaurant.

Rio had been right. It had absolutely been an experience.

The atmosphere had been dimmer, warmer, candles lighting up might of the space that wasn't quite touched by the overheads. It really was incredible, and the food had somehow been even better. The conversation, as it always had, flowed easily and they had genuinely seemed to understand that there may never come a time when they couldn't just talk to one another.

They had departed after their meal and while Agatha had asked Rio if there was anything else she wanted to do, Rio's insistence that they get home had obviously landed exactly right with Agatha.

The care and yet necessity with which they had completely stripped one another out of those dresses had been truly beautiful in the most soft ways. It was nearly a daily occurrence, to fall into the warmth of everything that was Agatha's nude body, but there was something about the impending weekend looming that pushed it to something else, to something that not only left them both trembling in the rippling waves of constant orgasms, but that had welded them together, permanently.

Physically, she would have to leave. Emotionally? She was branded into Agatha for the rest of time.

They had assumed their typical position in the sheets, tangled in every inch of one another, and it had not taken them long to fall asleep.

The ringing of her phone caused Rio to sit bolt upright in the dark, her chest tight as her eyes flew over to the phone; she could see both that it was 3am and that the person calling her was not her daughter.

In a confused panic, she swept up the phone and answered in a rush.

"Tay?" she questioned softly, as to not wake Agatha, but at the sound of crying on the other side? Rio's soul completely left her body.

"Taylah, baby. What's wrong? What's going on?"

"Mama, I... we -- it wasn't our fault -- she did everything right."

She wasn't making any sense, and it was only driving the stake of panic deeper into Rio's chest.

"Baby, calm down. Where is Estee?"

"They're t-taking her in for surgery now."

Rio literally could not breathe. Surgery? They were taking her in to be operated on? What the fuck had happened?

"Tay. I need you to tell me right now what happened."
