She could hear the deep breath the girl pulled in, trying to steady herself and stop the tears from choking her up.

"We were coming back from the beach after crabbing. She was driving. We went through a light, she had the green, but a truck veered in front of us and hit us head on."

Jesus fucking Christ.

"Okay... Okay, so... first off," Rio managed, somehow building the strength she would need to finish this conversation. "Are you okay?"

"I'm fine, Mama Vidal. Just some cuts, and I might have broken my wrist, but I'm... I'm just worried about her. Her leg... Mama, it was bad..."

Rio literally had no idea how she was still conscious when every single beat of her heart pumped the blood directly to her ears, nowhere else.

"How bad?"

Tay began to cry harder.

"Honey, are your parents coming?"

"Yeah, they're heading to the airport now."

"Me too. If she gets out and is awake before I get there, please make sure she knows I'm on my way. I love you, sweet girl. And tell her I love her, too. I will see you as soon as I can. I love you."

"I love you too, Mama."

In the same instant that Rio hung up the phone, she reached up and turned on the light, nearly flying out of bed to locate whatever clothing she could to throw on. She had her phone in one hand, frantically trying to book the soonest flight she could.

The light had caused Agatha to stir, but she had not moved or raised any question. In fact, she had not even opened her eyes until, in her panicked shuffling, Rio kicked the leg of the bed and let out a pained cry. She steadied herself, not looking at Agatha, and continued her frenzy of throwing what she could grab into her bag. She submitted the purchase for the ticket that would let her on a flight that left in three and a half hours and threw her phone on the bed.

Agatha was completely stunned to silence, having no idea what the fuck she had just woken up to.

"Rio?" her voice sounded, so soft.

Rio didn't acknowledge her, just ripped through the room like a tornado in her terror. As Agatha blinked, getting a better look at Rio's face, she could see that she was absolutely distraught and there were rivers carving down her cheeks. In an instant, Agatha was up and moving across the bed, gently taking hold of Rio's hands as she looked up at her.

Something happened in that moment that had never happened before.

Rio yanked her hands away.

Immediately, Agatha's brow pinched together sharply and the look on her face was deeply wounded. What the fuck had happened?

"Rio," Agatha said again, though her tone was more hard, more demanding.

Yet again, Rio kept moving, her body trembling with her sobs. Agatha was on her feet, marching over to her before she reached out, forcefully pulling the other woman into her arms, hugging her to her bare chest.

The excruciating sob that filled the air around them? Agatha's heart completely busted in her chest. It was probably the most painful thing she had ever heard in her entire life. Her hand held tight to the back of Rio's head, trying to soothe her but being all too aware at the same time that it was not working.

The longer she cried, the more it helped Agatha understand.

"This is about Estee, isn't it?" Agatha questioned in a pained whisper, her own eyes filled with tears.

Rio was silent as she shook with her sobs for just another moment before she pulled back, her eyes finding Agatha's. They were filled with nothing but fear. Pure, unbridled terror that she might never get to see her little girl again.

"She and Tay were in an accident. Tay's probably got a broken wrist but..." she began to sob again, burying her face in Agatha's chest. "Her leg is broken badly. They've taken her into surgery. I... I booked a flight. It leaves in three hours."

In that very second, it all came crashing down around them. This wasn't how things were supposed to be. Rio wasn't supposed to leave like this. She wasn't supposed to get on a plane worried sick about the one person she cared most about in the world. She wasn't supposed to leave until she was ready. She wasn't supposed to have to walk away from this until was absolutely necessary.

This was absolutely necessary.

In the blink of an eye, Agatha was thinking, building, trying to piece together a new plan, one that would benefit Rio more than commercial travel.

"Finish packing. I'm going to make a call." She placed a kiss to the top of Rio's head. "I love you."

Rio sniffled and nodded, stepping away to do as she had been told. Agatha retrieved her phone and paced to the window, pulling it to her ear, though Rio could still hear her clearly as she spoke.

"Hey, Jack," she had breathed, knowing full well that it was past three in the morning. "I know it's early, but I need a solid. Can you have the Hoatzin on the runway for me in less than two hours? I'll give you whatever you want, but I... It's really important." She was quiet for a moment as the man formed his answer, which caused Agatha's posture to slacken. "I seriously owe you."

She disconnected the call and silently moved toward the closet to both change and also throw what she could into a duffel bag. She emerged only a moment later, the bag slung over her shoulder.

"Cancel your flight, love. We're taking a quicker route."

Rio blinked at her, clearly not understanding.

"There's going to be a jet on the tarmac for us in Ontario in less than two hours, courtesy of a friend."

Rio's eyes dropped to the bag on Agatha's shoulder, then raised back up to her in silent request for clarification.

"You're not going alone."

More tears. This was not the way she wanted to bring Agatha back to the place she called her home.

Agatha dropped, kneeling before where she sat on the bed.

"It's going to be alright. We're going to get you back to see her," she soothed. "But I need you to realize that you don't have to do this by yourself."

"Agatha," Rio managed in a soft cry. "I cannot expect you to just drop everything to do this."

"Then don't. You don't have to expect it for me to do it. You love her, and I love you, so by extension, I kind of already love her, too. You need to be there with her, and you also need support. It's possible for you to have both at once, if you just let me."

Rio's wet eyes shook with terror the longer she looked at Agatha, but she finally managed to bring herself to deliver a nod. Agatha rose to her feet, though she leaned over so that her face was directly in front of Rio's, giving her a supportive kiss.

"Let's get going. Ontario's about an hour and fifteen from here."

Rio stood, but before she took a step, she made a desperate grab for Agatha's arm, turning her back around so that Rio could surge forward, folding into her like she were a small child that needed to be comforted.

"I don't know what I ever did to deserve this, to deserve you. But... thank you."

Agatha, blinking back tears, kissed at her head again.

"You loved me before you knew me. And now, I will love you until my brain and heart lose their fight to keep you there. I promise."

Chapter End Notes

i need yall to know that hurt me as much as it hurt you. fuck man.

eta: it literally hurt so much I forgot the chapter title

Comfort Far Away

When I sleep, when I dream
Does somebody take control of my body?

*****

Although the audible crying had stopped by the time Agatha shut the door to the car behind her and Rio immediately tucked herself into her side as a result, the tears had never really stopped.

This was her fault. This happened because she had left, because she had put distance between herself and her daughter. She wasn't there to help, she wasn't there to protect. Rio's absence had allowed this to happen. She had been living in an absolute dreamscape for almost two weeks and she had forgotten that the universe? Well, it didn't really give one single, solitary fuck about her plans.

Rio's hands were trembling in her lap, fidgeting as she picked at her cuticles, not even wincing as she pulled a piece of skin large enough that it immediately caused her to start bleeding.

She didn't notice. But Agatha did.

The hand that wasn't secured in a hold on Rio's shoulder lifted, covering both of Rio's hands lovingly, giving them a gentle squeeze. She could almost feel it, though, in Agatha's touch: the tentative worry that Rio might pull away again.

It hadn't been intentional, but it had since began to overwhelm her with guilt. Agatha had been... was there even a word for it? She could have said that she was amazing, but that downplayed her ability to dominate any problem someone put in front of her. She could have said that she was smart, but that would have undermined her sheer ability to simply think her way out of any given situation. She could have called her compassionate, utterly underselling just how much love she was truly capable of, but none of that seemed to fit, to feel right.

She sat there, her arm around Rio's shoulder being the literal bracing that was keeping her from completely falling apart. She was distraught, yes, and the truth was? In the dead silence of that car ride, she was taking every moment to completely kick her own ass, over and over and over again.

At about the forty minute mark, this had become painfully obvious to Agatha. She had been watching out of the window to try and keep any undue pressure off of Rio in the moment, but it was almost so loud she could hear it. It was a constant berating, a self-flagellation that she had somehow caused this, that she was somehow the reason this had happened. Agatha wanted to offer consolation, wanted to tell her that it likely would have still happened even if she had still been home, but she knew there was no sense in it. It wouldn't help.

Agatha's head turned, looking at the top of Rio's head where it rested on her shoulder, those thoughts only seem to get louder as Rio seemed to shrink into her.

"Rio," Agatha's soft voice crooned in gentle request, but Rio didn't move. Agatha knew she wasn't asleep, not with the rate of her breathing and the occasional sniffle.

"Baby."

There was another tremble of the smaller frame against her own and the tears were back to stinging at Agatha's eyes again. Still, though, Rio stayed tucked, her tears having completely soaked a couple inch patch of Agatha's sweatshirt. Agatha tightened her hold a little bit, dipping her head to place a soft kiss to the crown of Rio's head, though she did not lift the contact.

"I know it sounds like chliche bullshit... but it's going to be alright."

At this, Rio suddenly sat up, her red and swollen eyes finding Agatha's in the dark of the car.

"Is it?" she shot back; a flicker of recognition flashed in Agatha's eyes as she watched, her teeth sinking into the inside of her bottom lip in anticipation for what she was about to get. That tone? That tone was one of sheer fright, of panic and worry. "I make the stupid and selfish choice to fuck off six thousand miles away, and I'm not there for my own child when she's literally in a room full of strangers who are cutting into her -- hurting her! And here I am, sat in this fucking car, not able to do a damn thing about it!"

Agatha was still, just watching her, an understanding expression melted gingerly onto those smooth features.

"And?"

Rio balked for a moment, blinking, but then tore right back into her tirade. "And... And you just... You just make a phone call and summon a fucking jet, like that solves anything!" At this, Agatha battled valiantly to keep a twitch out of her lips. Rio was just yelling, now. She wasn't actually angry with Agatha, or the fact that she had used her connections to help her. In reality, it solved everything. They'd shave almost four hours off of the travel time, getting there in less than twelve. "You just have all the answers! You just take one look, and it's like you give no fuck about anything other than fixing it!"

Agatha's head tilted to the side, her eyes so full of love that it confused Rio.

"Why are you looking at me like that?!" she nearly shrieked, but Agatha's response was instant.

It was a smile.

"Because I bet that's the first time since we got in the car that you stopped beating yourself up. And you did it by just shouting about things that don't actually make you mad or upset you."

Agatha carefully lifted a hand, hesitating as her eyes softened in question. Rio didn't move, but she did swallow down the boulder in her throat.

The moments Agatha's fingertips slid onto her cheek, Rio's eyes slid shut, pushing more tears down her cheeks.

"I know it's still new, my love," she told her softly, though there was a sense of resolution that was tight over her words. "But soon, you're going to see it. You're going to realize that you're not alone."

"Until you leave, and I am again."

Agatha's face fell a little and she was thankful that Rio couldn't see it.

"We'll tackle the semantics of that at a better time."

There was the softest whisper, the tiniest subtext in that line, one that Rio could never have understood the full volume of.

What Agatha was really saying?

I'm going to find a way to be with you, come hell or high water.

Rio's face crumpled again, though she had not opened her eyes. Agatha was rapid in her response, releasing the contact on Rio's cheek to instead pull her into her arms, wrapping her up in both as she nuzzled into her hair. For as strong as she had been holding, despite the stinging eyes and the few rogue tears, Agatha's resolve was beginning to crumble, one pebble at a time.

Seeing Rio like this? Agatha had known pain in her life. She had lost loved ones, she had grown up in a home without love her entire childhood. But that acutely hollow ache that opened in her chest, that was a new feeling.

Rio could feel it, the way Agatha was clinging to her, the way she was begging her to just fall into her, to just let her help her through this. None of this felt easy, because none of it was. It was never going to be a simple thing to see a loved one in pain, and even though she knew that Rio could throw it in her face that she didn't understand, she really did.

"I know it's easy to pin blame somewhere, to say that you leaving caused this. And I know that because for three years, I have worried every single day that if something happened to Nicky, it would be my fault for letting him go." Agatha hesitated, turning her head so that her cheek laid flush against the crown of Rio's head. "But... sometimes..." Her fingertips ran lovingly through the ends of Rio's hair. "It's sort of the way someone incredibly wise once put it to me. Sometimes, life is a lottery of meaningless tragedy. In the grand scheme, this doesnt actually mean anything, but because of where you are in your life, you're giving it meaning. Don't give it that power over you, my love."

That was the second time Agatha had used the sentiment, and Rio could feel it land and nestle in the deepest caverns of her heart. It was a flicker of warmth in the freezing cold.

"The important thing here is your reaction. You didn't even wake me up, you just hit the gas. You would have left me asleep in that bed without a second thought. And you're probably thinking that I would have been so pissed." Her expression was so... gentle, so filled with every emotion she couldn't name. Agatha was talking to her like no one had ever cared enough to talk to her before. "But... I know that the moment you had a chance to breathe, you would have called me before you got on the plane to tell me. And then I would have rushed out of bed, grabbed whatever I could, and prayed that if the gate was closed, I could somehow bribe someone to let me on to catch the flight with you."

Rio shuddered again, a soundless choked sob. Hearing Agatha talk like that? Hearing her literally pour her heart out in the back of that towncar?

Slowly, Rio lifted her tear-stained face, biting roughly into her bottom lip.

"You would have followed?" Rio asked, the sound of her voice so impossibly small that it made Agatha's lips pull tight and down despite knowing that it was a valid question in regard to the duration of their relationship.

"Don't you get it?"

Rio's brow wrinkled slightly, as if she truly did not understand what Agatha was trying to imply.

"I would do anything in the world if it meant it could make your life easier. That's what love is, Rio. And the way I love you? It terrifies me every single day. It makes me feel insane. It makes me wonder if I'm really making the right choices."

Agatha's voice wavered with her emotion, the way she was truly put to the test when it came to letting go of enough to control to really reach in, crack her ribs open, and pluck that heart right out of her chest.

Right there, she was handing it over to Rio, both with a sense of certainty and also void of fear.

And there they were, two astral forms, hovering above them; Agatha's hand was out and Rio saw it.

That astral hand hovered as Rio's eyes searced Agatha's in the dark, a silent willing for her to keep going.

"In twelve days, I haven't just fallen in love with you. I have fallen into you, and I have felt every single day, the deeper I sink, as if I could live in your skin. I'm not ready to climb back out yet. I'm not ready to go back to a version of myself that doesn't have you around."

Above them, in that plane that vibrated just out of sync with their own, those astral fingertips brushed over the beating offering in Agatha's palm. And then, with all the care in the world, it took hold and lifted.

"I am so terrified... by how much I know I need you," Rio admitted, her bottom lip quivering at the admission. "But I'm even more terrified of facing life without being able to hold your hand through it."

Agatha's hand raised, so carefully cupping Rio's jaw, her thumb brushing tenderly beneath her eye.

And there it was.

That silent exchange, happening just a moment out of time, but happening none the less.

Rio understood it, the weight of what she now held.

"We're going to be okay," Agatha whispered to her softly, and the sincerity that was practically bleeding out of her? It was impossible for Rio not to believe. It had been harder before, in her hysterics, but in the quiet veneration of the back of the car? Something in Rio felt deep in her essence that Agatha wouldn't ever lie to her, not without good reason.

There weren't any words left, wasn't anything else left for her to try and articulate. They had pretty much all but bled themselves out on those leather seats and yet, somehow?

They had been good at being a couple, but now?

Now that they were embracing the magic?

It was the two of them, their own coven that housed power and potential, a true bonding through the power of emotion.

It had only been a couple of moments before the car turned off of the mainway and bumped down a long, desolate road that emptied out into a private airfield.

Despite the fact that Rio wanted to see it for what it was, in every bit of its grandeur, she felt like the only reason she was able to keep walking was because Agatha was pulling her along. Hell, if she'd insisted she couldn't keep going, there was little doubt in her mind that Agatha would not have lifted her onto her back and carried her the rest of the way.

Agatha led her onto the plane and told Rio to make herself comfortable while she spoke with the pilot. She had returned a moment later with the update that they had gotten clearance to land outside of Queenstown at another private airfield -- another favor Agatha was going to have to pay back to Jack tenfold.

The flight had been just over eleven hours, and Agatha was thankful for every hour of it that Rio slept, having thoroughly exhausted herself from the gauntlet of emotion she had been putting herself through. Agatha had decided to wake her about ten minutes before they landed so that she could get some kind of gauge as to where they needed to be going.

Rio had checked her phone once they landed, seeing that she had a couple of messages from Tay, updating her.

"She's out, but they have her sedated."

"They did another x-ray and there's a bone shard that hadn't been visible before they set her leg. They scheduled her for another surgery at 11am."

Rio's eyes swept to the top of her screen; it was almost 1:30pm.

Before she could even process what it was she was doing, she was calling Taylah, finding it in her to stifle a sob when she answered, her voice so soft and sweet despite the trauma she was right in the middle of enduring.

"She's out," Tay told her, sniffling. "Nothing else major, but they did have to put a plate in. They literally just brought her back to her room. They told me that she'll probably be out for a couple more hours."

"We're here. We just landed about twenty minutes from Lakes District. The car is on it's way, so we should be there by about two. Have your parents gotten in?"

"Yeah, they were here but when I promised them I was okay, I sent them back to the apartment. If I manage to kill the devil's ivy Estee bought while she's stuck in the hospital, she'll never forgive me."

Rio leaned forward, her torso folding completely over her thighs as she fought to keep the wail in her lungs contained. It wasn't that significant to anyone but Rio, and it had shot her right through the heart. She was still crumpled, but she felt Agatha's hand on her back.

Before she could think to say anything, Tay spoke again.

"I'm gonna go back in and sit with her, but I'll see you when you get here. I love you, Mama Vidal," Tay told Rio softly and the tears were pouring hot again.

"Tay?" Rio choked before the other girl could hang up.

"Yeah?"

"I don't know the right words to tell you how thankful I am for you, or how much I love you. But when I find them... you'll be the first to know."

"Get here soon, Mama."

"On my way, baby."

Rio lowered the phone, her arm hanging defeated at her side. Agatha's hand was still smoothing out the worry, the pain, the anxiety on her back. Slowly, she unfolded herself, sitting back in the chair as she looked over at Agatha, completely helpless.

"Car just got here," Agatha offered in consolation, though she knew that had been a hard conversation to have. But now? Now, they were only twenty minutes from Rio getting to hold her daughter's hand, to tell her she was there and really mean it.

Agatha got to her feet and even though Rio had been staring straight ahead, she saw it, that lifeline being offered to her when she needed it most; Agatha's hand was waiting for her.

Rio's gaze swept up to her face and what she saw both somehow shattered and mended her heart at the same time. The softest light shone in her eyes, beautiful blues that were glassed with emotion. The corners of her lips were lifted, ever-so-slightly, in a hopeful manner. When she looked into that face?

Rio saw it all. Time stood absolutely still as her fingertips slid across Agatha's palm and all at once, every single memory they had made, and what felt like every single memory they would ever make together slammed into her at full force. It was a flashing of colors, of lights, of smiles and tears. It was shouting and hand holding and sex and joy and satisfaction all at the same time.

In the middle of the biggest emotional storm Rio had ever endured, there was Agatha, willing to risk her own well being to pull her out.

And, with the most certainty she'd had since she had woken up to the sound of her phone, she got to her feet and let Agatha lead the way to the car.

She had been restless and quiet the entire ride to the hospital, Agatha's fingers laced between her own in a firm hold. Agatha's free hand was tracing the faintest lines up Rio's forearm, just a steady back and forth that helped Rio center herself a little more. She was trying not to get caught up in the remaining minutes, but things started looking familiar again and she knew where they were.

Another few minutes and they were rolling up to the main entrance of the hospital.

Agatha never once let go of her as she went through the motions of letting the woman at the front desk know who she was there to see. The woman directed them where to go and this time, it was Rio that was the one who was practically dragging Agatha along in her wake.

She was so close to her baby, but there was still space. Space that she had to close immediately. She had pushed the button for the elevator, but it was taking too long. She gave another strong pull on Agatha's hand as she threw open the door to the stairs, nearly taking them two at a time. Somehow, Agatha was keeping an even pace.

They reached the fourth floor, both of them red from their effort, but Rio was off again, her eyes scanning the room numbers until she saw the right one, swinging a hard right inside to see Taylah sat by the bed, holding the hand of her little girl.

Rio's eyes lifted to take the sight of Estrella in, and she could feel it all over again as her heart shattered in her chest. She was torn between wanting to rush to her child and wanting to also give overdue attention to the pseudo-child that had been the one to bring her home.

Although she didn't exactly want to, something inside Rio compelled her to let go of Agatha's hand as she paced over to behind where Tay sat. Rio laid an arm across her shoulder gently, leaning down to kiss the top of her head.

"I don't know how to tell you how much you mean to me, Taylah. I know the last day has been hard and terrifying but... you've never left her side."

"Of course, Mama Vidal. I love her."

Rio's heart pattered softly in her chest; she knew she could have taken it at face value, but she'd been waiting for the penny to drop in that regard for years. Maybe this was what finally did it.

Rio loosened her hold, pacing over to the side of the bed closest to where Estee's head was resting, those rich dark locks unruly as she laid there. Her crazy little girl, always getting herself into scrapes. Her features were smooth, and Rio knew that it wouldn't last. When she came to, she was going to hurt. She was going to be in pain for a good while, and it was going to be hard to deal with, but they would get her through it.

She had her tribe, her coven of women that were there for her, to love and support her through whatever the next months had to bring.

Her fingertips brushed along her daughter's hairline, over her cheeks, her nose. It was something she needed, to see and feel her little girl right there in front of her.

The other two women were completely locked in on the exhange, just watching a terrified mother gaze lovingly at the daughter she could have lost. It was a moving display in every bit of its gravity, even causing tears to line Agatha's lids.

After a long few moments of Rio's quiet appreciation of the woman in that hospital bed, she leaned over to place a soft kiss across Estee's forehead. She straightened up and turned back to Tay, taking in her appearance for the first time.

She had a black eye, her wrist was in a cast and there were a few cuts on her arms. She got to her feet and without a single second of hesitation, Rio pulled her into her arms, hugging her as firmly as she could while still paying heed to the fact that she had just endured a severe trauma. She stood there for a long few moments, the silent tears spilling as she clung to her second daughter.

Finally, she loosened her hold and pulled back to look down at the blonde, her eyes soft.

"You've been a hero, baby. But maybe you should call your parents and get them to take you home so you can get some sleep."

Tay offered a slight twich of her lips, something that landed in the vicinity of being a ghost of a smile.

"I texted them after you called me. They're waiting in the garage."

Rio placed a soft kiss to the side of her head and gave her shoulders a thankful squeeze.

"Get some rest, mija."

"I love you, Mama."

Tay placed a sweet and emotional peck to Rio's cheek and turned to make her way out, but she caught sight of Agatha and stopped, obviously a little stunned both that she had come with Rio, and that a Hollywood Director was standing right in front of her.

"I hope you stay long enough that I get to actually meet you, but I'm going to go home and sleep. So... thank you, for not letting her do it alone."

Her voice had been soft, knowing that Agatha was close enough to hear it, and Rio likely was not, and was also probably very fixated on her daughter, too fixated to notice.

"It was the least I could do. And for what it's worth, I hope we get to spend time together, too. I've heard a lot of good things." Agatha's lips pulled into a warm smile despite the circumstance. She tilted her head toward the door. "Sleep, kid. Doctor Rio's orders."

It was the mother in her that seemed to take the wheel in that moment. She gave a gentle nod in Tay's direction as she turned and passed through the door.

Agatha had sat on the couch by the window, hardly able to take her eyes off of Rio's back as she sat, folded over with her arms beneath her head on the edge of the bed, her hand wrapped snugly around Estee's.

It was such a tender moment, one that was both heartbreaking in its reality and warming in its reaction. Maybe Rio really could have done this by herself, but... she was eternally in Agatha's debt that she didn't have to.

After about an hour, she sat up a little, though she didn't release Estee's hand. She looked back over her shoulder, though she couldn't see Agatha all the way without turning around.

"Hey," Rio called softly, to which Agatha was on her feet, pacing to behind her, her hands falling immediately to Rio's shoulders in comfort.

"I really need to pee," she admitted, though her tone was soft in just how soaked in exhaustion it was. Those hours of sleep on the jet had not been able to cut it. "Can you... Can you just hold her hand? In case... in case she wakes up while I'm gone." Rio's voice caught on the last word as the emotion choked her. "I don't want her to be alone."

"Of course, my love," Agatha breathed, leaning slightly to kiss the top of her head.

Rio stood and before Agatha took her place, she pulled Rio into her arms firmly, just holding her steady for a few brief moments. As she loosened her grip, though, she was a little surprised as she felt Rio's soft lips brush against her own. It was something that could hardly have been constituted as a kiss, but Agatha had received the sentiment loud and clear.

Rio gave her hand a soft squeeze and departed, leaving Agatha to slide into the chair at Estee's bedside, picking up her hand and holding it in both of her own.

She leaned forward in the chair, her eyes casting up to that beautiful woman in that bed, Rio's little girl forever and always. It hadn't been as noticeable over a phone screen, but she looked so much like her mother.

Agatha leaned forward, much like Rio had, laying her head on her arm as she held onto Estee's hand, letting her eyes slide closed.

She wasn't sure how long she'd had them closed, but she must have imagined it -- the slightest brush on the inside of her palm

Wait! There it was again. Agatha gently gripped back out of sheer reaction, but as she realized what was happening, she practically flew up, her eyes cutting right to Estee's face, which was now trying its hardest to scrunch in frustration as she fought her way back to consciousness.

Stuck, and not knowing what to say, Agatha simply gripped her hand back.

"Mama?" came the lone, broken and rough word. Something in Agatha's chest squeezed.

"She'll be right back, she had to pee," Agatha tried to explain in a gentle whisper.

The struggle continued as Estee fought to open her eyes, finally winning that war as she found herself staring at the ceiling and then, so slowly, her gaze dropped and landed right in Agatha's.

"A-Agatha?"

"Yeah, Estee, it's me."

Feels Like Home

I don't know where I am
But it feels like home.

*****

The weight of the last twenty-four hours had settled on Rio like a wet jean jacket, awkward and heavy, weighing her down. At the same time, it felt like taking it off would leave her bare; sleep was not yet an option.

As Rio had exited the room, intent for the washroom, a woman stood from a chair within the nurses' station and waved her over. She was tall, a bit lanky, but she had a kind smile. "You're Estrella's mother?" she posed, to which Rio gave a nod of acknowledgement.

"Both surgeries went well, and the second one was only necessary because of the location of the shard and how the dislocated bone had been covering it from x-ray. But she... You've got a tough kid on your hands."

"Thank you. I guess I always knew it, I just never wanted to find out she could be this tough," she returned.

They quickly wrapped up the conversation with only essential questions from Rio, who departed back down her intended path.

As she emerged from the washroom down the hall from Estee's room, she glanced back toward it and her lips pressed together. The cafe wasn't far; she could grab them each a coffee and hopefully be back before Estee woke up.

She needed something to pick her up; Agatha was fairing pretty well on such a task, but physically, Rio was absolutely drained.

It was almost earth-shattering, to have a night like the one she and Agatha had gotten to experience the night before, to go out in those dresses while people looked at them, to have an incredible meal and expensive wine and then wake up to that phone call. It felt so far away, now, the way they'd nearly stumbled into the house, a flurry of lips and hands and sighs only to tangle in that bed for hours. It had become overshadowed by what had followed, and a deep part of Rio ached at that realization.

So, she had carried herself down and fetched them coffee.

Coffees that were still grasped in each hand as she got closer to Estee's room and heard -- was that laughter? Agatha's laughter?

Rio's brow knit tight and she stepped into the doorway to see the source of the sound.

It was like a snapshot of a moment, something so stilled in time. There, in that chair by the bed, was Agatha, leaned forward, holding onto Estee's hand with both of her own. That wasn't the most striking thing about her, though. No, that was the absolute light that was touching every single crevice of Agatha's face, and every fleck in her irises, those blues burning like the hottest part of a fire.

Rio's gaze shifted, taking in the sight of her daughter -- awake and alert -- and talking softly with Agatha, who was clearly hanging on every word she had to say.

Neither of them seemed to notice her, and while her first inclination was to throw the coffees to the ground and run to smother her daughter in love?

There was something so... still about what she was seeing.

Her own first meeting with Nicky had, arguably, gone pretty fucking poorly.

But there she stood, watching as she absorbed the reality that Agatha was the first person Estee had seen when she had been able to open her eyes. Agatha had been the one there holding her hand. Agatha was the one there sitting with her, talking to her, laughing at whatever it was she was being told -- that beautiful fucking laugh -- with literal stars in her eyes.

It made her breath catch in her chest, but she was careful to keep it quiet as to not completely disrupt the moment. It was too tender, too precious. She just watched, silent reverence filling her entire being.

"Okay," Estee managed, her lips pulling up. "So you're not pulling my leg with the jet thing? You really just called your friend and said 'Hey, let me borrow your jet?'" Rio could hear it, the tone of Estee's voice that all but indicated that she thought it was some tall tale.

"I mean... that's pretty much how it went. I didn't tell him what I needed it for, but I promised him anything he wanted. He had joked before that if your mama and I decided to sell publishing rights to the story of how we met, he got first dibs."

It had been near impossible for Rio to keep her jaw clamped shut to keep the soft sound that wanted to escape her at the way Agatha had said that one word, the one word Estee and Tay both used so affectionately with her. It wasn't just that she had said it, it was the inflection she had put on it, like she understood that it was a different form of respect for Rio's heritage, and by extension, Estee's.

"Well, when we landed, I had a message from him that said 'Those rights up for grabs yet?' Which, with the weight of not knowing if you were okay hanging over our heads at the time, wasn't the funniest. But --"

"It's pretty funny," Estee said, breathing a sweet but soft giggle, one that still made her wince.

Rio's eyes dropped, taking in the way Estee's thumb would flex or occasionally brush over Agatha's knuckle.

She was doing it too! Rio thought. She had to make sure Agatha was really there!

Like mother, like daughter.

"I still can't believe you guys literally got on a plane at five in the morning. I think it's because mama knew if she waited until I woke up, I would have told her I was fine and not to come home and then she would have had an entire existential crisis," Estee managed through measured breaths, very visibly fighting off the ache that was gripping her entire body to instead focus on this bonding moment with this woman she knew her mother loved so dearly.

Rio saw this shift happen in her, though. This new look crossed her face, and bled into the way her eyes softened as she looked at Agatha.

She wasn't sizing her up, wasn't trying to scrutinize or pick her apart.

No, Estee was simply... regarding her. She was looking for, and quickly finding all of these reasons that Agatha was the one that was sitting right there. She could see, in those blue eyes, where her mother could get lost. She could see in that smile, where her mother might find a daily source of warmth. She could hear it, in those soft spoken and warmly rich tones, where her mother could find sounds that soothed her.

Very quickly, Estee could see almost every single reason her mother had fallen for this woman.

"Oh, also," Agatha voiced, as if something had just dawned on her. "Tay was here until we got here and your mom strong-armed her into going home. Her parents flew in, too, and they're staying at your apartment, so they came to pick her up. But... She's a great friend."

At this, there was another shift in Estee, her eyes getting a little glassy in the fluorescent lights of the hospital room.

Rio was holding her breath, clinging to the tension like it were as thin and fraught as a tight rope.

"You know those big moments in life where... you just kind of realize that you might have prioritized the wrong things?" Estee asked Agatha softly, and Agatha gave a knowing nod in response. "I was conscious for a little bit, after we were hit. It was hard to talk, or breathe, but..." The emotion seemed to surge inside of her, but she took a very slow breath in and then let it go just as slowly. "I felt her holding my hand. I heard her telling me we were going to be okay." Her voice shook, though, and Rio could see the slight movement as she gripped harder at Agatha's hands.

Severely, in every depth of every well that resided in Rio, she both felt her own swell of overwhelming emotion, and saw as it washed over Agatha's face, too. Rio was still fighting herself to remain still and quiet, but she absolutely could not break this, or even dream of interrupting it.

"I have spent the last thirteen years of my life with her. We had sleepovers every single weekend, mama taught us to surf together. We have explored every available inch of this island that we can get to. I have experienced so many of the best moments of my life with her right beside me. And as it turns out, I experienced a pretty bad one with her, too."

The pause she took instilled a heavy and thick silence, one that was filled with such unspoken affection from all three women in the room.

"And I... I'm scared that if I tell her how I feel... she won't feel the same way."

"I don't think you have to worry about that, mija," came Rio's voice from the doorway.

Both of their eyes were wide, a little shocked that they had not otherwise noticed that she had been there, or how long she had been there.

Rio paced over to the small stool that the doctor would often use when in the room and pulled it over next to Agatha, handing over one of the coffees before she shuffled around her to resume the stationing she had momentarily taken earlier when they had first arrived, up by Estee's head.

Her hand hung out with her own coffee out of sheer positioning, but she felt as Agatha gently plucked it from her fingers so that she could choose to embrace her daughter how she wanted to.

She leaned over her, kissing her forehead again, the now-free hand cupping under her chin and up her cheek, a lightly affectionate hold.

"I am so happy you're okay, mija. You scared me, dios mio!" Though her words were gently chastising, her tone was anything but. It was soft, it was full of love, full of concern, full of adoration.

"I'm happy you're here, mama," she murmured back softly, her eyes sliding shut in the warm comfort of her mother's hold. Her eyes opened again, this time landing back on Agatha. "And I'm happy you didn't make Agatha stay in America."

"Ay, mija. Not now; let me love on you a little longer before you start being ornery."

"Oh, so she get's it honestly, then?" Agatha offered up with a breathy chuckle. This drew a response from both Vidal women who managed the softest, sweetest giggles.

As Rio gently released her hold on her daughter and turned to go back to the chair, she caught sight of Agatha, who honestly looked like she was fighting for air.

"Are you alright, my love?" Rio posed, her genuine curiosity heavy over her words.

Agatha blinked, her gaze snapping up to Rio.

She was blushing.

And judging the additional giggle behind her, Estee could see it.

"That sound..." she managed, looking like she had put forth some serious effort into getting those words out. As it processed, though, there was a familiar shimmering in her eyes, an impossible softness that often made Rio weak in the knees. "It was beautiful."

Rio's tender smile was immediate on her lips. She placed a gentle hand on Agatha's shoulder and bent enough to kiss the side of her head before relinquishing all contact to take her seat on the other side of Agatha. As she sat and lifted her head, it was now Estee's turn to be staring at her in complete awe.

"Mama," Estee gushed, her eyes widening slightly. "This is literally the cutest thing I have ever seen. Are you sure that you guys haven't been secretly dating for like at least three to five years? Because... that's the vibes," she offered, accentuating with a weak flicker of her hand between the two of them.

Rio's knee lightly nestled directly against the side of Agatha's as she handed over the coffee back to its rightful owner, glancing at her with a shy smile that she didn't want Estee to catch the entire gravity of.

"So, how long am I stuck here?" Estee decided to state as the segue into how much different life was going to work for the next three weeks while she finished her classes and took exams.

"The doctor said that if you react well to all medications, she's comfortable letting you go home tomorrow. She wants to check both incisions to make sure that there's no indication of infection. Doc said that she's willing to write up any paperwork she needs to so that you can do your schoolwork and exams from home, because it's three weeks of bed rest for you, mija."

Estee's soured expression truly indicated just how dissatisfied she was by this answer, but Rio was not quite finished.

"After bed rest, you start physical therapy. Three times a week, ninety minutes. Between myself and Tay, we'll get you there, so don't fight when the time comes, yeah?" Rio posed, tilting her head as if it might somehow be convincing enough to work.

Tay.

Estee's face softened again, as if realizing that they had not quite finished their conversation from earlier.

"What did you mean, mama? About Tay?"

Rio's expression seemed to dissolve into this enlightened sense of affection.

"She's been here the whole time. When she called me, she was here and you were going into your first surgery. She was texting me updates, and she immediately gave me one when she picked up the phone the moment we got here." Rio paused, gently biting her top lip as the emotion because to snake a grip around her throat. "When we came into the room? She was poured over you, clutching onto your hand with her one good one. She looked like she'd been crying since the second it happened, but she wasn't letting you go for anything until I got here."

Rio took in a slow, deep breath as she tried to re-steel her bubbling of emotion.

"She protected you. She took care of you. And even though she's told me a million times before that she loves you... This time, it was different. This time, I think she meant it more."

Estee's eyes began to leak and she swallowed down the realization that maybe she wasn't as insane as she had thought she might be.

"She texted me while I was grabbing coffee. She said that you get to pick who you'd rather crash with you tonight, us or her. She said she didn't care either way, but just to let her know."

In that moment, when presented with such a choice? Estee looked truly torn. Of course she wanted her mother around, she wanted to feel that safety that came so easily in her presence, and she was quite enjoying not only the effect that Agatha was having on Rio, but also that she was an incredibly easy person to talk to.

On the other side of that coin, though? Rio could see so clearly as she laid there in the bed, suddenly realizing the weight of her own feelings in regards to someone she had suppressed feelings for... for a very, very long time. She might have been beat all to hell, but that girl had a look of determination in her eyes.

Her gaze cast up to Rio's, her lips twisting in thought for just a beat longer.

Before she could speak, Agatha had something to offer.

"I can put us in a nearby hotel, that way... Tay can come back, and we're close enough that if you need her," Agatha indicated with a tip of her head toward Rio, "then she can come right back."

There it was again, that melting right in her middle. Rio shifted her coffee to her far hand and set the newly-freed one on Agatha's knee, giving a gentle caress with her thumb.

Estee's eyes fell to Rio's, as if in silent question.

Rio smiled, soft and genuine.

"I'll text her and tell her to come on back."

"Mama?" Estee suddenly asked.

"I am really hungry. And a pizza sounds... exquisite."

Rio breathed a soft laugh, her eyes casting up to the morphine drip they'd inserted into her intravenous line; clearly, it was working.

"I can order us a couple of pizzas and ask if Tay's parents wouldn't mind stopping to pick them up when they bring her back."

Estee's soft hunter green gaze swept back and forth between them as she tried to temper her reaction to ask the questions that still ended up falling off of her lips.

"You'll both stay and eat with us?" she asked, her tone edging on hopeful.

Estee had never been starved for attention, ever in her life. That was something that Rio had worked her hardest to make sure of. But what Rio was realizing as she took in that look on her face, and listened to what she said and how she said it? What Estee now wanted more of was this experience of Rio basking in the light of another human, someone who saw her for every incredible part and piece she had.

What Estee had ached for, her entire life, was to see her mother find that comforting warmth that could come with the genuine emotion of love, and it was more than obvious to see that she'd not only found it, but Rio had made sure to wrap it around the pair of them. It was beautiful in the most touching way, and Estee hardly knew how to start processing that it was real, that she could literally sit there and look and them, right there in front of her. She could see the inherent happiness that came from being close to one another, that gentle buzz of raw affection that surrounded them.

Estee was seeing what soulmates looked like.

"Of course we will, mija."

*****

And so, stay they had.

Rio had done as promised after getting the approval from Tay's father that he could stop to pick them up food. She ordered Estee's favorite for her and Tay -- double cheese with extra mushroom -- and she and Agatha had settled on a classic pepperoni. Roughly twenty minutes later, Tay had come through the door, her dad behind her with the boxes, and a third that he informed Rio was a box of brownies he had purchased in addition.

She set the boxes down on the table and moved to give him a gentle hug, thanking him softly.

He told her to let them know if they needed anything at all and departed to leave the women to the rest of their evening.

They had shared pizza and just talked for hours. The girls asked their fair share of questions, and it had almost felt like a bit of an interrogation, but Agatha had not buckled ones under the weight of their grilling. It wasn't malicious, or even slightly genuine. They had clearly been playful in their fascination and simply wanted to understand it more, wanted to admire it for all it was.

As the night wore on, though, it had become pretty clear that everyone was growing tired. Honestly? Rio had been pretty surprised that Estee had lasted so long; she had watched over the course of the evening as the exhaustion had begun to creep into those soft and beautiful expressions, the light in her eyes dimming ever so slightly.

"We should probably head out soon so you two can get the rest you need," Rio acknowledged in a smooth but comforting tone.

"Do you know where you'll be?" Estee asked, her tone tinged with the slight edge of nerves.

"I just booked us a room at the Millennium. It's about a twelve minute walk from here, so an even faster Uber," Agatha volunteered; as annoying as that might have seemed to anyone else, to have someone answer for her, there was something so... endearing about it. Agatha knew her, and Agatha always seemed to know what to do, even in the most high-pressure situations.

This seemed to be good enough for Estee, who relaxed back into the pillows.

They had ended up giving their hugs, Rio stealing her head and forehead kisses at each chance she could get during the goodbye exchange. She had looked each of the girls in the eye and told them how much she loved them. When she had tucked her chin over Estee's shoulder, though, she murmured a soft encouragement.

"You'll probably sleep better if you tell her before you turn in."

She could hear as her daughter breathed out a knowing huff, giving her shoulder the lightest squeeze as she pulled back.

"Los amos, mijas. Call if you need anything."

The harmonizing response?

"Te amo, mama," the girls said in unison, causing a wave of warmth to wash over her.

"Te veo, sweet girls."

Hand in hand, she and Agatha made their way out of the hospital and decided to make the trek, with their duffel bags, by foot.

The night had grown balmy, but not too hot. It was a gentle dusting of heat in the evening air. It would undoubtedly taper off once the sun sank a little lower, but for now, it was pleasant enough for the sake of comfort on their walk.

"So..." Agatha began, shooting a sideways glance at the woman next to her. "How long, exactly, were you in the doorway?"

Rio's magnanimous grin was wide an instant.

"Long enough to admire the view."

"Yeah? And what did you like about it?" Agatha asked back, though her voice had dropped in volume, and it had lost its questioning edge. This was just a genuine attempt at looking in on some of the thoughts she didn't swear she could already hear.

Rio was quiet in her consideration for a few moments as they continued to walk. She wanted to say it right, to make her understand it in acutely the right way.

"I liked the look on your face, like you were looking at every star in the sky at one time. You get that look when you look at Nicky, too."

Agatha's chin tucked and Rio could almost sense the heat of the blush that crept to her cheeks.

"She is..." Agatha began, but it was clear that she quickly could not locate the right words. "She is so very much your daughter, first of all," she informed her, a gentle laugh blossoming from her lips. "But she's also... I don't know how to say it. We talked alone for all of maybe ten minutes and she's just... What a ray of light."

She was, wasn't she? It was the same thought that had passed through Rio's mind that day she had dropped Estee off to come back down this way.

"She's always been my entire world. And she's still a very large part of it. But... I think she is undoubtedly thrilled that there's something else there that she gets to share space with." Rio's grip on Agatha's hand tightened and she very smoothly, in rhythm with their walking, leaned over to steal the briefest peck off of Agatha's cheek.

"She can take up all the room she wants, I will gladly occupy what is left."

The rest of the walk was only a couple of moments and check in was rather seamless. They were closing the door to the room behind them as their bags almost hit the floor in perfect unison, a soft thud sounding as they did so. Rio stretched, but then cast her glance over to Agatha, who was at the foot of the bed, preparing the bed so that they could simply climb into it and let themselves release some of the tension they'd been holding for the last day.

She was quiet in her method, but Rio couldn't keep away long enough to let her finish. She padded over behind her, securing her arms firmly around Agatha's middle, who stopped her work and straightened back up, a content hum passing through slightly parted lips.

As she reached full height, Rio turned her head and pressed her cheek to Agatha's shoulder, just holding her close, trying to somehow convey to her the weightiness of every ounce of love she felt for her. She knew that at this point? Trying to put a word to it was a fruitless. Rio could spend days, weeks even, pouring over a thesaurus and she still somehow would never have been able to find the right word, or even combination, that could somehow put that feeling into words.

She had always believed that there was a right way to say anything, but as she nearly clung to Agatha at the foot of the bed?

Maybe what they said was true; maybe love was speechless, in its most tender happenings.

They simply stood in the totality of the moment, just letting it lay and fill the space around them with their closeness, both physical and emotional. For a brief ticking of a second, Rio considered that they could have very well just fallen asleep like that, but she finally released her embrace, her hands landing without initiative on Agatha's sides as she placed a soft kiss to the fabric of her shirt above her right shoulder.

Begrudgingly, she released that contact and helped her finish readying the bed. When they finished, she slid out of her leggings and crawled onto the large, plush bed, finding an immediate home in the middle. As Agatha did the same, meeting her in a tangle of legs and embraces?

Rio really paused, for just an additional beat, to both ask and acknowledge:

Is this really the life I've gotten the chance to live?

It is. So keep choosing it.

Get Comfortable

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

I feel right at home in my town, happy day
And step out into the freezing morning air.

*****

As Rio opened her eyes into the morning of a new day, it actually took her a moment to reintegrate herself into the reality she was living, but it was in a far different way than the last time she had woken up in an unfamiliar hotel room.

When Rio had woken up for the first time in The Freehand, she'd opened her eyes into that empty room, the panic of Agatha's absence filling her and overflowing her in a fear that she had somehow made the wrong choice. And then those eyes had swept over the room, landing on the lingering traces of Agatha, ones that held a promise of her return.

What she had right then, as she opened her eyes in their suite -- which she had chastised as being entirely unnecessary at one point before they had fallen asleep -- was tangible, was right there under her arm. What she had was Agatha.

Agatha.

Even as Rio laid there, the sleep still chewing at the edges of her consciousness, she watched Agatha, an unwitnessed and unbridled devotion reflecting in her gaze. She could still see it so easily, the way she had held effortless conversation with Estee, like they'd spent hours of time together before. If anyone else would have been blessed enough to bear witness to what Rio had witnessed from that doorway? They would have assumed that Agatha was likely some form of parental figure to Estee, someone that had an amazing relationship with her, not that they were meeting for the very first time.

It had really been the look on Agatha's face -- it was like a beacon of light that sat on a coast just far enough away in the middle of a thundering storm.

Before Rio had become the observer in that situation, she had been feeling pretty hopeless. She had taken to heeding Agatha's request to give herself a break, but there had still been this emptiness, this feeling as though she had done something wrong, that had been gnawing at the pit of Rio's stomach.

She wasn't a bad mother, she knew that. But... She was getting closer, step by step, to having a massive and impossible choice close enough to stare her directly in the eyes. She was going to have to find a way to sit down, to map out her entire life and figure out what pieces might be able to move and where. She was going to have to find a way that this could work. It had to work.

If there were no more moments in her future where she got to look in from the outside on any tender exchange between the two women she loved most in the world, Rio wasn't sure that was any kind of life she wanted to be living.

Even without having had a one-on-one conversation with Estee yet, Rio saw it. She saw the way she looked at Agatha, like the gratitude was just consistently pouring out of her, like she was so thankful that someone finally understood what an absolute gem her mother was. Of course Rio never felt as grand as the pedestal her daughter had placed her on, but Rio supposed that she had always looked at her papa like that, even if he had always insisted that he was a deeply flawed man.

What Rio realized, laying there as she looked at the serenity blanketing Agatha's beautiful face, was that seeing them? Hearing them? Hell, hearing Estee be so quick to talk about her feelings for Tay with Agatha before she brought it up to her? It had been a lighting quick flash of realization:

It wasn't just Rio. Estee felt it too.

The magnetic pull that would forever be Agatha Harkness.

Estee had been helpless when it came to not being pulled in by that gravitational force that seemed to extend out and encircle Agatha, much in the same way Rio had.

Rio was pulled from thought at the sound of a soft snore across the few inches between them, an instantly delighted smile curling up her lips.

Judging by the way the sun was coming through the window, it was still pretty early.

A soft grumble sounded low in Rio's stomach and she breathed a light sigh out of her nose, shifting slightly to her back, though that simply left Agatha's arm draped over her middle instead of her side.

She could probably make it to the bakery she knew was a few blocks over and back by the time Agatha woke up, but the idea of leaving the safe haven of that bed?

Another grumble.

Okay, so maybe it wasn't really much of an option. She laid like that for a few more moments before carefully, she removed herself from beneath Agatha's hold and placed a soft kiss to her temple. She turned and busied herself with the task of getting ready for the day. Once she was dressed and looked presentable -- although the dark circles under her eyes could have been better -- she grabbed the room key and slid out, setting out into the balmy Queenstown morning.

She had maybe only been gone thirty or forty minutes, but as Rio came down the hallway -- pastries and coffees in hand -- she'd heard it from a few doors down.

It was the sound of Agatha's voice, and it was loud.

A deep line formed in Rio's brow as she approached the door, hovering outside of it as she tried to get a gentle grasp on what she was about to be walking into.

"I don't care about the fucking permits, Dave. Let them expire. So what if we wait a year?"

Then another voice, a man's voice, sounded, though it was softer, like it was on speakerphone.

"Agatha, you've already put four MILLION dollars into this project, and now you want to push it off a YEAR?"

"Yes, Dave, that is very clearly what I said. I do not believe anywhere in that statement did I stutter."

"You realize that this is insane, right? This was going to be the next year and a half of your life, and now suddenly it just doesn't matter? You were so invested in making this happen, even before you started location scouting. What the fuck changed that you're staring career suicide in the face?"

The loud, sardonic bark of a laugh was absolutely scorching in its heat as it boomed out of Agatha's throat.

"Dave, do you know how many Oscars I have sitting on a shelf in the den of my home?"

"Yes, Agatha, I do."

"So, then, are you really going to sit there and try to make me feel like if I push this film back eight to ten months for deeply personal reasons, I'm going to lose my career?" Her voice was so sharp, so calculated, so measured with the intention behind every single word that left Agatha's lips.

Rio realized that she was holding her breath, waiting on Dave's response.

"This has to do with the woman on TMZ, doesn't it?"

Somehow, even though she had been holding her breath, it still caught in Rio's chest at what he asked.

Agatha did not hesitate in her response. "The answer to that question, either way, is inconsequential to this conversation. I've made my decision, and now I task you with the duty of relaying the message to the team."

"But! You're the one --"

"Thank you, David. Have a great rest of your day!"

The faint beep that signified the end of the call was so very faint through the door, but Rio still heard it.

She was stuck, frozen, not knowing how to completely process the conversation she surely had not been meant to hear. It was become a recurring pattern, wasn't it? Rio accidentally getting glimpses of the pieces of Agatha that she should not have been privy to?

She was playing it over in her head, trying to piece it together so that it made sense. The only conclusion she had reached?

Agatha was putting a pin in her current project and nothing in Rio needed to ask the question to know why.

While Rio could sometimes swear she could hear Agatha in the depths of her own mind, in that moment it was almost deafening.

I am prioritizing. I am putting what's most important first. I am doing the right thing.

Slowly, and with slightly shaky movements, Rio raised her free hand and slid the key into the door, pushing it open with a trace of uncertainty.

Agatha, who had clearly been in the throes of an intense pace, stopped suddenly in the middle of the room. The look she had been wearing before her halting had been tight and focused, pulled together in sheer concentration. The moment she stilled, though, and looked up to see Rio?

It thawed in the matter of a second, so much relief weaving into every tense muscle.

"I brought breakfast," Rio offered softly, holding up the holder with the coffees and the bag that held the pastries in one hand.

With a breath, the tension seemed to completely evaporate, Agatha's shoulders slumping slightly in surrender. She crossed the few remaining feet of space between them as one hand found Rio's side and the other wrapped around the small of her back, bringing her in close enough so that their fronts were pressed together and she could tip her head down slightly to grace Rio's lips with the gentlest kiss.

How did Agatha do that?

Rio wondered at what point she was ever going to stop asking that question. The reality of it was that Agatha found new ways to amaze her every single day and she had this feeling in her bones that the wonder might not actually ever go away.

She didn't have to say a word, and yet Rio could feel all at once how much Agatha needed her presence when she was actively working to turn her own world on its head.

Rio took the soft kiss, even feeding back enough to make sure Agatha was aware of how she was feeling. As she pulled away, emerald pools finding those azure ones, she could see it; it was the brief crackle of a storm, darkening those blue shades the slightest bit. In fact, perhaps no one else might have noticed it, but it was glaring Rio directly in the soul. She didn't want to force Agatha into telling her about that conversation, but she also felt nervous about admitting to eavesdropping.

"I..." Rio managed, her eyes darting back and forth as she tried to find the best way to blow that storm back, to keep it from rolling in deeper.

"I heard you..."

At this, Agatha's face fell, but not in a frown. Instead, she looked like she had been caught red-handed. It was almost... adorable?

"You... could have told me you were thinking about doing that," Rio murmured at her softly, raising a hand to rest on Agatha's sternum, her fingers mindlessly brushing from the innermost curve of one collarbone, over the divot at the base of her throat, to the other innermost curve of the opposing collarbone. It was a gently affectionate movement a back and forth of calculated presence on Rio's end.

That look on Agatha's face as Rio lifted her eyes to look away from her own hand?

She looked utterly helpless.

"I wasn't..." she managed back, though by the way her tongue clung to the roof of her mouth and the way her throat bobbed that Agatha's mouth was bone dry. She was... nervous? This was fascinating to Rio, simply for the fact that this was a facet of Agatha that she had not really had an opportunity to see yet. "I just..."

Agatha cut herself off, clamping her lips together in a tight line as she emotion fought to bubble its way out of her chest.

"I opened my eyes a little bit ago and when I could not see or feel you in bed next to me, I..." Another sudden pause, Agatha's jaw clenching as she tried to build her resolve, though Rio had hardly found herself able to tear her eyes out of the depths of Agatha's. She could see it there, building, the utter piety that consumed her when she looked at Rio.

"I panicked, in those first few seconds, before everything came back. And I realized... Sinking my time into eighteen months of a project that yes, I am passionate about, but that would keep me on a seemingly endless schedule of not really knowing my own availability?" Agatha's hand raised, cradling Rio's jaw in the crook of her hold. "I'm just not ready. I wanted to make the film. I need to be here, for both as long as you need me, and as long as you'll have me."

The tears that were indicative of just how moved Rio was sprung to life, pouring down her cheeks rather unceremoniously.

The hand that had been idling on Agatha's sternum slid up, over the side of the neck, fingers curling toward the back of Agatha's head into her hair as she pulled her toward her, placing the most loving kiss across her lips. She knew she could have told Agatha a million times over that she loved her, but she knew that it would never cut it. It would never be loud enough.

So, she let her actions speak for her instead. She let the way her lips skimmed Agatha's just barely there be the loudest shout in the room. She let the way she was cradling her, that giant, beautiful brain nearly in the palm of her hand, be the underline of emphasis on what, exactly, she was trying to convey.

There was a loud ding! from her back pocket and she could feel, there against her lips, as Agatha's own slid into a blithe smile.

"I bet that's our beckoning," Agatha breathed against her lips, though Rio was just a little too hung on the moment to let it go that easily.

She pressed forward, stealing another kiss, this one a little more present, a little more aware. She did not let it linger long, though, and pulled away to retrieve her phone, her hold releasing as she felt Agatha take hold of the coffee and bag in her hand.

Hey, mama. We're awake, so whenever you guys get up, feel free to come when you're ready.

"They're up," Rio offered warmly, as she typed back her response.

We're getting ready now. I went to Ma Boulangerie and picked you both up some lamingtons and mock cream donuts. We'll be there shortly. I love you.

Agatha padded back over to her, holding out the coffee to her. She took it with a soft thanks and took a sip, feeling the warmth slide all of the way into her chest.

"Mmmm, they seriously have the best coffee I've ever had," Rio hummed, clearly having a moment of peace over the mundane pleasure.

"It is pretty good, but those pastries smell delicious. Are we going to eat breakfast with the girls?" Agatha posed, tilting her head adorably in question.

Rio gave a nod. "Yeah, I had picked them up a few things, too. I figured either you and I could eat if they were still sleeping, or we could all eat together. Glad to see it worked out."

Agatha reached up between them, her thumb landing on Rio's chin while her index finger curled securely, the smallest hold, but it was firm. Their gazes met and there it was again, Agatha staring right into her.

"What do you see when you do that?"

The question clearly caught Agatha off guard by the way her expression tightened in one moment, but then smoothed in the next.

Her lips parted, but then pressed. Her throat quivered slightly as the emotion bobbed somewhere in the middle of it, rising and sinking with every push of a wave. Her jaw set a bit forward and Rio could really see that she was holding an inner war on how she wanted to answer that question, so she offered a gentle reassurance.

"You can tell me."

The lone tear caught Rio off guard this time, but she was quick to reach up, brushing it off the velvety smooth skin of Agatha's cheek.

"I see the rest of my life."

For every time she had thought she had felt it before? Rio knew that anything she had considered before that moment paled in comparison to what it felt like right then.

What it felt like as she was struck by Agatha's lightning.

The emotion in Rio's own expression was immediate and heavy, nearly causing her features to crumple, but it was not because it was she was upset. It was because she was completely and entirely heart-struck.

Her hand raised, fingertips ever-so-gentle as her graced the angle of Agatha's jaw, the sheer astonishment practically bleeding out of her. She tipped her head forward, the skin of their foreheads meeting in shared warmth.

"I am so in love with you, Agatha Harkness, that I can hardly think straight."

"Well," Agatha breathed at her, her tone reverent. "If you thought straight, this probably wouldn't work out too well."

The giggles that erupted between them were boisterous and bright, lifting every bit of tension out of the room, carrying it high to the floors above them.

"Come on," Agatha beguiled, giving a playful tap to the cheek of Rio's ass, a grin filling her face. "We've got an episode or two of 'Kiwi Love' to catch up on."

Rio's grin was so wide that she was almost certain her face was going to crack. The fact that Agatha had just given a name to the saga of what could turn into Estee and Tay's relationship left Rio feeling so completely filled with love and adoration that she could have just floated away and had zero qualms about the view.

*****

Hand in hand, Rio and Agatha had gotten out of the car and made their way back up to where they knew Estee's room to be, though they were cautious as they reached the doorway. Like a couple of absolute snoops, the two older women carefully slid the top most parts of their heads into the doorway, peering inside.

There, on the hospital bed, laid both women. Estee was on her back and Tay was curled against her good side, resting her head on Estee's shoulder. They were having a soft back-and-forth of a conversation and Tay was absentmindedly toying with Estee's fingers in her own. Her eyes would occasionally sweep up, a smile crossing her face at something Estee had told her.

It had been a good three or four minutes before Estee had glanced over at the door, just barely catching sight of her mother's eyes poking from the outside of the door frame, with Agatha's head a couple of inches above hers.

Estee's grin was wide and instant, sweeping cleanly across her beautiful features.

"Good morning!" she chirped, and while Tay turned to see what she was looking at, also dissolving into soft giggles, she did not otherwise move from her spot against Estee's side.

Agatha and Rio both straightened and came through the door, both of them lit up like Christmas trees in the dead of a winter night.

"Gloating does not suit either of you," Estee advised, raising a brow in taunting challenge, though the smile broke out a moment later.

"So..." Rio began as she pulled up the stool, offering the chair again to Agatha. "I get to consider the possibility where some day I might actually be your mama, even if it's mama-in-law?" Her eyes found Tay's hazel ones, causing Tay's grin to sprout immediately.

"Let's not put the cart before the horse, now," Tay teased back, but Rio didn't miss the way her arm tightened so gently across Estee's middle.

"The cart rolled down the hill a long time ago, loves," Rio offered back with a soft laugh. "You're just horseback riding at this point."

This earned her a gentle poke in the ribs from Agatha, causing the sweetest giggle to flitter from her lips as she swatted Agatha's hand away, though in the next second, she leaned into her, their arms forming a solid brace.

Rio reached down to where Agatha had set the bag between them and pulled out the box, doling out pastries.

"I have not had a lamington in so long," Estee gushed as she picked one out of the box, behold it for the true treat it was.

"A lamington?" Agatha questioned, seeking clarification.

"It's two pieces of cake," Tay offered, picking up one of her own. "And they put cream and jam in the middle, cover it with simple syrup and coat it with coconut. It's so good."

"So good," Estee echoed before she took a bite, humming her immediate satisfaction.

Rio had picked up one of the donuts and held it up to Agatha in question. "Wanna split it? They're pretty rich, so it's hard for me to have a whole one to myself."

That tender shimmer rippled over those blue pools, causing Rio's stomach to squeeze in delight. Agatha nodded and Rio set to her work of pulling it apart before she handed half of it over. Agatha thanked her, leaning in to steal the briefest -- but sweetest -- peck.

Rio let her adoring gaze linger just a moment, but when she moved it?

Both Estee and Tay were staring at the two of them, the biggest fucking grins across their faces.

"Oh, knock it off, you two," she chastised, though the smile was still audible in her voice, even if it had not been apparently written all over her face.

And so, the four of them had taken up post in that hospital room for the majority of the day, and the doctor had come in to let them know that they had planned to discharge her on the evening after one more course of antibiotics.

At this, they had discussed between the four of them what this was going to look like.

Rio felt comfortable enough with the idea of letting Estee go home, knowing that both Tay and her parents were there for the time being. Surely, they would know the moment the other couple decided to return to Melbourne, and would be expected to give up the hotel to instead occupy the spare room in their spacious apartment.

The plan they were currently making was for the three weeks moving forward, but Rio was all too aware that they were going to have to work something out beyond that. Surely, both girls would want to go back to Auckland to at least enjoy what they could of their summer before they set to the daunting task of beginning their careers. And Agatha?

Oh, Agatha.

Rio was all too aware of that fact that Agatha had pretty much cleared her schedule for the next eight months, at least, but what did that mean? How did it correlate to the relationship between the two of them? How long would she stay?

That, Rio decided, was an inner turmoil she could ruminate on some other day.

"Mama, I didn't have to say a word. She crawled in next to me, asking me if it hurt me and if I was okay, and she laid her head on my chest." Estee's eyes flickered upward, clearly trying to keep the gripping hold of that emotion at bay. "She was just... drawing shapes on my chest. She breathed a disbelieving chuckle. "If two months ago you would have told me that us Vidals would ever both be in healthy relationships, I probably would have laughed my entire ass off."

Rio's lips worried together for a moment, but she found her voice again. "She has indefinitely postponed the project she came here for in the first place. For, as she put it 'deeply personal reasons.'"

"Goodnight, ladies. Sleep well," Agatha added, waggling her fingers at them in a playful wave of parting.

It really had been a rollercoaster, seemingly endless ups and down, but now they were sitting at the top, taking in the landscape of their lives from the view.

Rio looked back, following where Agatha was staring, her gaze on the back of the man at the desk. There were slides on his feet and khaki cargo shorts on his legs. A short-sleeved button up with small planets on it was around his torso, and that wild messy tangle of a bun atop his head?

Rio blinked, saturated in complete shock and disbelief.

"Nicky?" Agatha's uncertain voice came, strangled with its question.

The young man turned around, an immediate grin on his lips.

"Hi, mom."

Miles Don't Mean Anything
