*****

What the hell was Nicholas Scratch doing in New Zealand?

Rio kept blinking, kept trying to verify somehow that she was not hallucinating, even despite the fact that Agatha was standing right next to her, clutching her hand. Nicky was really standing there, that big and stupid grin on his face, looking like he was not an inch out of place standing in that hotel lobby.

By the way his face softened, but the smirk remained, Rio could tell that he was quite enjoying having stunned the two women to complete silence.

After another beat, Agatha's death grip on her hand released and she pushed forward, pulling her son tightly into her arms, pressing her face into his shoulder. Rio saw it, even though the motion didn't duplicate itself again, not once; it was the gentle tremble of Agatha's body as she exhaled a silent sob.

What Rio had been blissfully unaware of was that almost every single time (which, honestly, wasn't quite that frequent) Agatha had picked up her phone, it had been to update Nicky, to let him know that she was out of the country, that she was tending to an emergency with Rio.

What Agatha had not expected when she casually made mention to him of the hotel they were staying at, was that he would show up in support.

Agatha recognized it for what it was, but Rio still felt a bit baffled, like she was trying to put a puzzle together when half of the pieces had been knocked off of the table. She was missing things, here. Sure, they were things that she would have likely been told by Agatha when they had retired to their room for the night, but for Rio? She didn't understand it, if support was what was happening.

They had not gotten off on the best foot, and even though he had tried valiantly to prove that he was trying to engage more, Rio had still been wary of him, for her own reasons.

None of those reasons seemed to matter in that moment. Her heart was swelling at the sight, just watching Agatha cling to her son in a display of emotion so public, and yet, Agatha did not care.

She pulled away from him, her hands sliding to cup his cheeks in her palms, just staring at him in wonder.

"Thank you."

She leaned forward, placing a soft kiss to his cheek and then let him go all the way so that she could turn back to Rio, who had edged a little closer, but not close enough to intrude on what felt to her like a very meaningful moment. What Rio did not understand was that it was meaningful for her, too, she just didn't realize it yet.

"Hi, Nicky," she offered with a small wave, though it had to be obvious that she was exhausted. "What... what are you doing here?"

Nicky's face softened and he glanced down at his luggage for a minute, then back up to Rio.

"Mom texted me when you landed and told me what was going on. She's... been keeping me updated. But... I couldn't go to bed after we talked. So, I booked a flight and got on a plane, and here I am, twenty hours later."

Rio could see it, the exhaustion in those bright green eyes. He had really done this for them. He had come all this way so that he could be there to help, to support. He had come to make things easier not only for his mother, but for the woman she loved, too.

Rio felt it, a slow crawl. It started in her stomach, clawing its way with no rush up to her chest. The quickening of her pulse began to thud a little harder in her neck as her chest tightened. She could feel the tears welling, could feel as her hands began to tremble. Before she could reach the point of feeling like she couldn't breathe, she blinked back the glassiness and cleared her throat.

"Excuse me," she pardoned herself, not giving room for protest as she turned on her heel and disappeared toward the elevators.

"Rio, wait --!" Nicky called, starting to move forward, but Agatha placed a gentle hand on his arm, holding him in place. She shook her head.

He looked up at her, feeling like he was in the wrong, that helpless pit in his gaze.

"It's not you," Agatha told him softly. "She... has been alone for a very long time. I think that... she's just not used to people showing up for her."

"I... Mom, I didn't know," he offered in a gentle murmur, almost ashamed in its tone.

Agatha leaned toward him, pressing her lips to his forehead.

"I know, baby. Why don't you head up to your room and get settled. You definitely need some sleep after that, you insane child of mine."

The smile he wore as he tilted his head up at Agatha?

She was so lucky to have him as a son, no matter what they had been through.

The sounds of Rio's labored breathing bounced off the walls of the elevator like a deep chamber, endless in their anguish. Her heart was pounding so hard that she could hear nothing else, her palms were sweating and she could hardly think about each step she took as she shot down the hallway.

Her hands were shaking so badly that it took her far too long to get the key into the door, and that she dropped it the moment she pushed the door open, leaving it half hanging out into the hall once the door closed.

She pushed off the door and staggered to the bathroom, throwing the cold faucets on and turning on the overhead in the shower. She managed to kick off her shoes, but otherwise threw herself into the shower, fully clothed. Her knees were pulled, hugged to her chest and her face pressed into them as the chillingly cold water fell over her.

She was still heaving, still unable to still a single thought that was racing around her mind at break-neck speeds.

Nicky had shown up for her. Nicky had decided to get on a plane for almost an entire day so that he could be there for her. She knew that it was because of Agatha's feelings for her, but he had still made that very adult choice. He had booked his own flight, packed his own luggage, and put himself on that plane.

He had chosen to stay in the same hotel they were, to be close to them.

The thought made her sob harder, squeezing her legs closer to her chest.

People did not choose Rio. Estee and Tay? They were her family, they would always choose her. Anyone else? Anyone else would never choose Rio, because Rio had never been a noticeable choice. She had always kept to herself, tucked herself away in her own little corner of the world because she had convinced herself that people just weren't worth the risk. They weren't worth pain.

"Sweetheart," Agatha called softly, but there was no response. There was no sound of movement.

Concerned, Agatha's brow pinched and she knocked a little harder.

"Rio," she voiced, raising the volume a bit.

"Baby, let me in," she requested, even a little louder.

What was she scared of?

That eventually, they would leave.

Although she wasn't quite trembling, the moment she felt his arms move to wrap around her securely, the tears poured faster.

She had been so panicked by the idea of them leaving that she had not stopped to let herself enjoy them being there in the present.

Rio's eyes were pinched shut out of sheer will to stop crying, but they opened at the beginning of a stale smell, and indication that if their meal was not attended to, it was close to reaching a burning state. Nicky seemed to notice at the same time and straightened, letting her go.

Without another word, he turned back to the stove and tended to what had almost turned into a disaster.

It had only been another couple of minutes by the time Rio was pulling down plates and he was loading helpings onto each one. She made a trip with the first two, handing them over to the girls in the bed, whose eyes went wide with the sudden flaring of appetite.

"It smelled good," Estee commented, "But it looks even better."

Rio offered a small smile and retreated to the kitchen, returning the next time with Nicky in tow, two plates in her own hand for herself and Agatha, and one in Nicky's for himself. She handed the spare over to Agatha before taking her spot, nestled against her side.

They had spent the evening like that, all snug in their own positions in that bedroom. The girls on the bed were pretty much stuck together, only shifting when Estee needed to find a position that was more comfortable. They had all been absorbed in some television show Estee had put on, a visual feast with a plot about eight people across the world who became of one mind, inheriting one another's languages, abilities and emotions.

It was an interesting choice and Rio was even a little thrilled at the fact that they had all reached the point of maturity and adulthood where things like sex scenes on television weren't so awkward to watch if your parent was sitting right next to you.

The storytelling had been immaculate, and Rio could almost hear the intense interest and processing that were running through Agatha's mind as they watched. She was seeing things through that lens that only she possessed, picking apart camera angles and position choices. She was studying different techniques, learning what she could to better improve her own ability.

There had been a timely shift in position, Rio having crawled onto that massive bed with the girls, and Nicky having migrated to take her spot next to his mother.

At some point, as the hours had worn into the night, they slowly began to drop, one by one as the exhaustion of what they had all been going through pulled them under.

By about eleven, the last two standing were Estee and Agatha. They had been sitting in silence, Nicky's head on Agatha's shoulders with his slumber and Estee on the closest side to her, the end of the little train that began with Rio nestled up asleep against Tay's side.

Estee's voice was nothing more than a soft whispered as it broke the silence, but Agatha still heard her loud and clear.

"Can I... ask you something?" she posed softly, her eyes sweeping over to Agatha's in the light of the television.

Silently, Agatha gave her a light nod of encouragement.

"If... if the time comes, and you know that the only option for your life is to bring her to you, don't take no for an answer."

Agatha's expression had fallen from genuine curiosity to the pain that was caused by what Estee was telling her. "Estee, you and I both know that she's never going to leave you. Especially not after this."

Estee's brow wrinkled in her immediate distaste for this fact, even if she knew that Agatha was right.

Agatha could see it, so clearly, the emotion in Estee's eyes; it was panicked, but trying to be self-soothing. She was clearly trying to piece it together, trying to find a solution that hadn't been considered, but Agatha had been doing this for weeks and was still coming up empty handed.

"She'll never ask you to leave your life behind, you know that, right?" Estee told her, though her whispered tones were dripping with her certainty on the fact.

"I know," Agatha responded, her head hanging a little bit.

That was where they were, wasn't it? They were at this impasse of knowing that neither answer was the right answer, and they were the only two they had. It was frustrating, it was painful, and it was a struggle that Agatha had never thought she would ever have in her life.

"But... for now, I'm here as long as she wants and/or needs me," she offered in consolation. "And if, sometime in the next six to eight months, I can figure out a feasible way to make this work that benefits everyone involved, then we'll go from there."

Estee blinked at her a bit in the dark, a little more than shocked to silence at the information Agatha had just casually mentioned like it were a simple fact of the universe.

"You're going to stay for at least six months?" she whispered, incredulous.

"I might have to pop home to renew my visa, but... I've cleared my schedule for longer, so... there's just no where else I'm needed more."

Estee's eyes brimmed with dampness, but she refused to let the tears fall.

"I am so in love with the way you love her, Agatha."

Agatha's features pinched slightly in a pang of feeling completely understood. She had spent so much of her life pushing people away because everyone took the two seconds needed to see that she was hard-headed, that she was powerful, that she had a commanding sense of authority that bled through her at any given chance.

But when Agatha finally learned what love was?

It was a reconciliation of what she had always been and something she had never thought that she could ever be, slamming together with so much force that the impact left a radius of dust. The collateral of those two pieces colliding as it floated to the ground was nearly visible, no longer needed for the structural make up of those core beliefs.

Agatha reached forward, her fingers hooking affectionately over Estee's hand.

"That's one thing you can always count on me to do, kid."

A few more moments stretched on in silence, but Rio shifted and Estee turned her head back toward Agatha.

"If you want, you guys can sleep in Tay's room, and Nicky can take the spare that her parents were staying in."

Agatha's eyes sparkled in the dark with the quick but full feeling that had been building since the moment Estee had opened her eyes, the sheer affection she had for the young woman. She gave a gentle nod of understanding; she was getting tired and wanted some of her space back.

After another beat, Agatha gave her hand a soft squeeze and got to her feet, pacing around the other side of the bed to gently wake Rio, who grumbled her disapproval.

"I can carry you," Agatha mused, the flicker of a thought flashing through her mind that she already knew herself capable of supporting Rio's weight.

Another soft grumble sounded from Rio's lips as she forced herself into a sitting position, Tay only stirring slightly beside her. As she opened her eyes, they immediately fell to Agatha's waiting palm.

Sleepily, Rio slid her hand into Agatha's grasp and pushed off gently from the bed as Agatha had already turned to rouse her son, who also looked a little groggy and perturbed at being disturbed.

As the three of them shuffled down the hall with Rio indicating to Nicky where he could go to sleep, there was something chewing at the back of her mind.

Family.

Maybe they weren't one, yet, but the idea that there was the potential there? The thought that maybe Rio might actually be able to, some day, have what she had always hoped for in life?

It was a peaceful enough thought that by the time she and Agatha climbed into Tay's bed, it had taken her all of two minutes to fall back asleep, nestled into the safe haven of Agatha's embrace.

*****

The days had drawn on in a constant shuffle between the hotel and Estee's apartment, doing everything they could to make her life as easy as it could be. Tay had been quintessential in getting the majority of Estee's school work to her, and she was set to take her exams the following week from the comfort of her own home.

After almost a week of sitting around and doing nothing, though, Estee had grown restless, the cabin fever nearly swallowing her whole. Nicky and Agatha had run back to the hotel to grab showers and change, though Rio had only bit back the urge to tell them to just bring everything over, only because it was not her home and she had not really had that discussion with Estee yet.

Rio was cleaning up their breakfast dishes when Tay called that she was going to be jumping in the shower. She had given her acknowledgement and had tended to finishing up her task before she padded her way back to Estee's room. She could tell the moment she laid eyes on her daughter that something was bothering her.

"What's on your mind, mija?" Rio posed, her tone soft but smooth, as if it were meant to be offered as a comfort.

"I'm tired of looking at these walls, mama."

Rio breathed a gentle but understanding side as she placed herself on the edge of the bed, careful with how she did so. Estee was not quite as fragile she had been in those first few days, but Rio couldn't help but be cautious, trying to keep from hurting her little girl as much as she could, even inadvertently.

Estee had always been the kind of person who knew no way to drop her life into a lower gear. She was constantly on the go, constantly trying to find ways to fill her time, to see all that she could see of their home islands.

"Can we please just try and see if we can go to Bespoke for lunch? I promise I will keep the whining to a minimum, but I would really just like the five of us to get the hell out of this apartment and enjoy sitting on the patio and drinking wine and fighting over who gets the last piece of brie off of the charcuterie board."

Rio's heart squeezed in her chest the longer Estee talked. She could tell that while she had been keeping a smile on her face, it had only been for everyone else's benefit. She had watched as this tribe built itself around her and what she was experiencing and she had started to feel like it was unfair to hold everyone hostage just because she was in a less than desirable physical state.

"Do you..." Rio posed, her lips twisting as she studied those beautiful green eyes. "Do you really think you'll be okay if we go? I just... I don't want you to be in pain for the sake of making everyone else happy."

"I will be fine, mama, I promise. Plus, I'm willing to be in pain if it means I get to soak up from fresh air for a couple of hours."

Rio leaned forward, pressing her lips to Estee's temple in a sweet kiss.

"When Tay gets done, we'll get you dressed and I'll just text Agatha the address so that she and Nicky can just meet us there. It's a little closer to the hotel than here anyway."

Estee looked so happy that she could almost burst into tears.

"Thank you, mama. I just... really need this."

Rio offered her a warm upturn of her lips.

"Of course, mija."

With another gentle kiss to her head, Rio had departed to ready herself, running a brush through her hair and applying a light layer of foundation and a couple of swipes of eyeliner.

She had picked up the phone, shooting a message over to Agatha that they were going to go out for lunch, and sent her the address, including that while they did not have to come, Estee and very pointedly made it about the five of them going out together. Agatha had responded with haste, assuring her that they would meet them there.

It was only a few minutes before she headed back down the hallway at the same time Tay emerged from the bathroom, dressed but her hair still wet.

She had quickly filled her in on the plan she had made with Estee, and she could see the light flicker in Tay's eyes in excitement. She was likely feeling about the same way Estee was and while she was free to move with her own volition, Rio was all too aware that Tay leaving Estee's side? Willingly? Yeah, that was never going to happen.

It had taken the two of them a good chunk of time to work around Estee's cast, but they had managed to get her dressed.

Rio had sat behind her, taking the time to meticulously French braid her hair, amazed at how much it had grown in such a short time. When she had finished, though, she moved to wrap her arms snugly around Estee's middle, leaning forward to press her cheek to her daughter's back.

"Mama..." Estee managed, the sound of her voice immediately tight with the emotion it brought forth in her.

"Si, mija?" Rio whispered, her eyes still forced shut to keep the sudden welling of feeling at bay.

"I really like this. It..." Estee stopped herself and Rio could feel immediately every place where she stiffened. She could almost feel those tears as they welled in Estee's eyes as she found a way to force the next words out of her mouth. "It's the closest thing we've ever had to family, and... I'm just not ready for it to go away."

Rio's hold around Estee's middle tightened and she hugged herself closer, feeling every single word that she was saying in the very hollows of her bones. It coursed through her, passing from join to joint, swirling in place of the marrow that should have been there.

"I know, mija. But... Agatha is her own woman, and she will make her own choices. I love her, but I would never try to control her."

Estee was quiet for a moment, and Rio could almost hear through her back how her heart had started to pick up.

"Six months," Estee whispered softly, giving her mother's forearm a gentle squeeze.

"Six months until what, mija?" Rio asked, lifting her head to look down at the back of Estee's head in question.

"We have six months to figure it out. She told me last night. She said she might have to go back for a little bit for visa purposes... but..."

In that very second, Rio forgot what it meant to breathe.

"She really told you that?"

Estee gave a small nod, though her mother could not see the look on her face, which screamed that she wanted Rio to just accept it instead of finding any reason to worry it could be too good to be true.

"Mama, I don't want to be the reason you stay," she managed back softly, though the soaking of emotion was evident in her tone.

Rio hugged her tighter.

"Then I guess that means you'll just have to follow."

*****

Although Rio knew that they shouldn't have had Estee out in the world so soon, she had hooked those crutches under her arm and insisted with a pained smile that she was going to be more than fine to enjoy a lunch out with people she cared about.

That damn stubbornness, that whole air about her that screamed I can do it myself! just hanging around her, that self-satisfied look on her face. All of it was everything Rio had ever raised her to be, but it made her nervous to see it in full display.

Putting her own feelings aside, though, she could tell the immediate difference in her little girl. She looked like she hadn't seen the sun in years instead of a week or so, and it was practically glowing on her skin as the three of them unloaded out of Tay's SUV, Rio tossing the keys over to her as she moved around to help Estee out of the back.

It may have been a little slow going, but as they made their way through the restaurant to exit onto the patio, Rio lifted her gaze to see Nicky and Agatha already sat at a corner table, awaiting their arrival.

They crossed the space and all slid into their respective seats, the jovial mood seeming to surround them, containing them within its invisible walls. They were a snow globe, a captured moment in time that would live on for the rest of time. It was a feeling that Rio felt everywhere in every single inch of her chest, one that she knew she could never willingly let go of.

The mood at that table? They were certainly the loudest ones on the patio, their raucous laughter and squeals of delight at different tales seemed to echo into the scape of the city, for anyone within a five mile radius to hear. It was the sound of unity, the sound of joy, the sound of family.

They had ordered their food with Rio and Agatha deciding that they would both get something different that the other was also interested in and split each meal between them, for -- as Agatha had put it -- the variety of life, which had caused every other person at that table to dissolve into a fit of laughter.

Even as they ate, the conversation never seemed to stop, and Rio and Agatha both would watch with vested interest as Nicky and the girls would get off on a tangent that held little interest in the minds of the two older women. It was like magic, watching the bricks get laid, stacked higher, a true foundation for what the future might come to hold.

They had drained their second bottle of wine between the five of them and Agatha and Rio had both volunteered to run inside to retrieve another one. They'd meandered back inside, hand in hand, and made a beeline for the bar.

They had been standing side by side as they waited to be acknowledge, but Rio shifted on her feet slightly, turning so that her hip rested on the edge of the bar. A hand raised to tuck some stray hair behind her ear, her eyes lifting to the far wall of the bar.

The moment her eyes settled and she realized what -- or who -- she was looking at?

Rio stopped breathing. It wasn't even that she had sucked in a sharp breath, or had made any kind of sound that would have indicated to Agatha that something was very, very wrong.

As her trembling hand raised to reach out to Agatha, her terrified gaze still stuck straight ahead, his head turned and he was staring directly at her, the wave of recognition washing over his expression.

"Agatha," Rio sputtered, but it was hardly audible over the noise of the restaurant.

"Agatha." It wasn't much louder, but it was more firm.

Agatha's head turned and immediately, her face shifted into a look of worry. Rio looked like she had literally just seen a ghost; her skin was pale and it looked like she was going to throw up at any given moment.

"C-cash out. We... We need to leave," she stammered, though her gaze still had not moved, something Agatha was suddenly realizing.

As casually as she could manage, Agatha shifted, turning her gaze to sweep over the back wall, and while she spotted him instantly? She didn't let her eyes linger and continued to look around.

Rio had not needed to say the words out loud for Agatha to see the similarities, however minute, when she looked at the image of Estee in her mind's eye.

"Text Estee, tell her to have them exit the front gate I saw. We'll meet them in the parking lot," Agatha instructed as she indicated to the bartender to close their tab. She had bent over to sign the receipt at the same time Elias slid off of his chair, his eyes still locked on Rio, a sickeningly sinister smile on his lips.

Rio's hand shot up, gripping Agatha's arm -- hard -- in a panic.

All at once, Agatha threw the pen down on the bar top and snapped back to full height, turning to her left so that she had placed herself directly in front of Rio, her hand whipping up to plant on his chest as he entered her vicinity.

"Back off," she warned in a low growl.

The man scoffed at her. "And you are?" he asked in a sneer, sizing Agatha up. Her fist was clenched at her side, her nails digging into her own palm.

"Someone I promise you, you don't want to mess with," she returned sharply, her voice oozing venom.

He shuffled to the side, at the same time, reaching out for Rio.

It wasn't even a thought.

It was an action.

One that happened with a lightning quick precision.

Agatha had cocked her arm and released one hell of a punch, landing it just below his right eye. He hadn't staggered back far enough, though, and the reaction was instant; another blow, this one more centered, the crack of his nose echoing through the restaurant.

As he dropped to one knee, holding his now bleeding and busted face, Agatha leaned down, close to his ear so that he could hear her crystal clear, but no one else could.

"If I ever see your face again, and you ever try to speak to my girlfriend for as long as you so fucking live, I will see to it that whatever parts you might end up in are never found."

With that, she turned and ignored the look of every patron in that restaurant, her hand sliding into Rio's as they made their way out, Agatha shaking her free hand out in a quest for relief from the pain it had incurred in the contact.

Despite the fact that Rio felt like a shell of a human in that moment?

What Agatha had just done?

She had literally just beat the shit out of the man that was the very reason Rio had become the way she was. Agatha had seen what he had done, what his impact had been on the woman she loved, and she had taken charge.

Agatha?

Agatha was Rio's savior.

Tigers in a Cage

You are an aimless ghost.
You haunt your bag of bones.

*****

Although Rio had been the one to pull Agatha out of those front doors, it was Agatha that surged past her. Her pace was quick and she was nearly dragging Rio, who was still in a complete state of shock at everything that had unfolded in the course of an entire two minutes. She simply let Agatha guide her where she needed to go, following her blindly, at that point.

They crossed the length of the building and made it to the parking lot, where all three of their children were waiting.

Estee had been just about to ask why they wanted to call it quits so soon, but the moment she took in the deep crimson on Agatha's cheeks and the way her mother looked sickly and pale? Her eyes darted back from her mother to Agatha, a quick back and forth as she tried to assess who was going to be more likely to answer her questions.

Despite how angry she looked, Estee was putting her money on Agatha.

"What happened?" she asked, her voice strong but not demanding. Her eyes shifted down to Rio, though, who's expression was utterly helpless.

"We should talk about this somewhere else," Agatha answered as diplomatically as possible, though her tone gave her away.

She wasn't just angry. She was seething.

"Mom..." came Nicky's voice, a calm in the storm.

Agatha's gaze cut to him, that raging fire burning so impossibly hot in her eyes.

"I said we will talk about this somewhere else."

All three of them straightened up, their eyes matching in the way they widened.

There was this new tension; Nicky was seeing a side of Agatha that, while familiar, was one she had never used in his direction. Estee? She was hyper-focused on the fact that Rio looked like she needed medical attention. What the fuck had happened in there?

"Don't just stand there!" Agatha barked, causing Nicky and Tay to snap into the action of helping get Estee into the vehicle.

That terrified, panicking, hard edge that had lined her in those moments?

It melted the moment that she looked back at Rio, who still didn't even seem present.

Because she wasn't.

There was nothing but a thundering roar happening inside of her head. To her, it had felt like the panic attack that had taken her over that night Nicky had showed up, but it was far more intense. Instead, it had robbed her of her cognition, of her ability to feel like a person. For twenty years, she had outrun her past. She had found a way to keep going, to never stop, to never look back.

She had raised Estee with no help from anyone other than her own father until even he was no longer around. She had been the sole reason that Estee was the woman she was. He had no part, and he'd had no reason to seek her out.

It had shaken her, knowing that he had reached out to her daughter, but actually seeing him? Actually looking into those eyes? It had completely tanked her, completely submerged her in the waters of the Arctic. She was freezing cold, trembling in the sheer numbness of it all.

And then suddenly -- warmth.

Rio was still hollow, still devoid of any coherent thought that could command her into presence, but she was enveloped in an instant embrace as Agatha pulled her into her chest.

She wasn't shaking, wasn't showing physical signs of crying, but the tears had not stopped pouring. She was hurting, but it felt so distant, like it was happening to someone else the next street over. It didn't feel like the wound was to her, and yet, there she stood, bleeding out.

Like a crack of thunder on a still night, Agatha's voice sounded, so close to her ear.

"I'm right here. I've got you."

It was the softest, the smoothest sound. It was like hearing a choir on Christmas morning. It was a salvation, an offering of hope.

"You're okay. I know it doesn't feel that way, but you are. You're right here, with me. You're safe."

Each word, a deliverance.

It was reaching those depths, but the reaction was limited. It wasn't reaching far enough.

"I know it's hard, but we have to go. Someone's probably going to call the police, so we should get home."

Rio's face, which was pressed into Agatha's chest, crumpled at the mere thought of having to move. She didn't know if she could, if there was any way for her to force movement into her own being. She felt stuck, like she had been thrown back to being in college, to looking at that face and knowing she'd never had a choice.

He had taken her autonomy, but she had been so deep in her isolation that she had not been able to recognize it until Agatha had showed her what it meant to have control over those choices. Agatha had taught her that she was the one in control, no matter how much she listened to Agatha when she was making her coy demands.

Agatha had showed Rio what it meant to live for herself, even if she had made the conscious choice to live for Agatha, too.

"Come on, my love," she soothed one more time, hoping that somehow she might be able to convince her to move, to just get to the car.

Rio was stuck, though. The last thing Agatha would do was drag her, but the panic was boiling in her chest, hotter and hotter the longer Rio wouldn't move.

Oh, fuck it.

She didn't put much space between them, but Agatha's movements were quick as she leaned down and did everything she could in her power, heaving the entire weight of Rio's body up onto the front of hers. It was a move she had made before, but in an new, wholly heartbreaking context.

Rio was aware it was happening, she knew what Agatha was doing, but she simply couldn't comply. She couldn't move her feet, couldn't find any way to just fucking move. As her feet lifted off the ground, she slumped forward, folding into Agatha like a piece of paper that had been creased over and over again.

It took her a moment to gain her footing, but Agatha was on the move, heading back to the car where Nicky was waiting outside of it, moving to pull the door to the passenger's side open so that his mother could pour Rio into it. She took the extra moment to fasten her seatbelt, but then bolted to the other side as she climbed into the car. As she slammed the door shut behind her, she looked down, realizing this was not her car.

A hand flew back as Nicky shut the door.

"Keys," she demanded; she wasn't intending on being so sharp to the kids, but she was running on nothing but pure adrenaline and it was clouding her judgement, obviously. Tay was immediate to put them in her hand.

She started the car and was quick in their exit, but as she started driving, she realized that she had no idea where she was going.

She pressed her lips together and inhaled a slow breath.

"Girls, can you help me get back to the apartment?" she requested, her voice dropping into something akin to an ashamed murmur.

Estee was the one to speak up, indicating where she needed to turn next. Even though she was helping to navigate, the fact was that her eyes had hardly left what she could see of Rio in the passenger's seat.

What had happened in that restaurant?

She fought the urge to ask, multiple times, instead keeping her comments strictly to getting them where they needed to go.

Agatha parked the car at the base of the building. She placed her hand on the back of the passenger's seat headrest so that she could turn to look at their children in the backseat.

"I'm sorry for the way I spoke to all of you. It wasn't okay, no matter what happened. But... if you guys could help Estee into the apartment, we'll join you in a moment, okay? And then I promise, we'll talk."

She was met with quiet nods of understanding, taking one more good look at them before she turned back around, her hand reaching across the space between the front seats to pick up Rio's hand. It felt... so limp. So... lifeless.

Agatha could recognize this for what it was; Rio was literally in shock. The lights were on, but no one was home. She was coping, she was tucking back her consciousness while the rest of her dealt with the blow that had been dealt to her psyche.

It only took a moment to process, to run through options. As she watched the children disappear inside of the apartment, Agatha showed a flagrant disregard for her own physical comfort, but was also thankful for the extra bit of space she had to work with because of the size of the vehicle.

With all the grace of a newborn fawn, Agatha managed to somehow climb over the middle console, turning so that she was facing Rio as she sank to her kneed before her. It wasn't the most practical idea, and it was uncomfortable, but she didn't care. She reached forward, pulling Rio's hands into her own, looking down at them.

The hardest part of those moments? How despondent Rio seemed. There was not a single flicker of the Rio that Agatha had come to know like the back of her own hand in those green eyes.

Agatha's actions were both gentle and deliberate as she encased Rio's hands between her own palms, holding them tight, trying to warm them. Her helpless gaze searched across her face, darting over every single feature in some attempt to try and find some sort of jumping-off point that might make this end sooner.

She glanced back down at their hands and moved, gently releasing one to take the other in both of her own. She gripped it, squeezed it, and then she pulled it toward her, guiding it where she knew it needed to be.

She placed Rio's palm in the place on her sternum that was exposed by the way her blouse was buttoned, right above her heart.

"I know you can feel it," Agatha whispered, her eyes looking up at Rio's face, though her eyes were still cast out to the window, hollow and empty. "Rio, baby, please. Come back to me. I'm right here."

She wasn't sure at what point it had started, but it almost startled Agatha the moment she realized she was crying. The tears were hot and terrified, trying to figure out how they were going to get through the next five minutes.

Agatha's hold on Rio's hand on her chest tightened, pressing harder, paying no heed to the fact that if she applied any more pressure, she was going to bruise herself.

The tears were still falling and the panic had fully set in, ripping through Agatha like the angry tide in the middle of a cyclone.

Again, she pressed, fighting the way she wanted to flinch at the contact.

"It's right there, Rio, beating for you. It's yours, so just... just fucking feel it. Let it pull you back."

There was another still moment, the echo of Agatha's increasingly frantic breaths bouncing off of every window.

"Come home to me."

Although Agatha was starting to resign herself to the fact that she was likely going to have to take Rio to the hospital? She wasn't sure she could do it, but she knew that if it needed to be done, she was the only one that was going to be able to.

And then, it was right there, almost missable.

Rio's eyes fluttered, moving just the slightest bit.

While her breathing had been so low and shallow that Agatha had been convinced she'd just been holding it the whole time, her chest inflated slowly, pulling in the first breath of a new consciousness.

Agatha was still sat there in front of her, that pressure so hard that she was certain with one more good push, she could crack open her own chest cavity.

And then, it happened.

Agatha felt in all five spots at once as Rio's fingers flexed, curving into her skin in a weak attempt at a grab.

She sat up a little more, her back colliding with the bottom part of the glove compartment, but she didn't so much as wince. Her hand raised, sliding beneath Rio's cheek that was closest to the window.

In a moment that felt like it lasted an eternity, Agatha watched, the tears still spilling, as Rio found the strength in her to manage the ability to lift her head, even just to let it roll along the headrest.

Another moment, another eternity.

Rio's eyes finally reached Agatha's, and it took literally every single fiber of her being to hold it together. Instead, what came out was soft and warm, meant to be an auditory embrace.

"Hey there, beautiful," she cooed softly, her thumb brushing Rio's cheek tenderly.

All at once, the weight of everything Rio had been shutting out came crashing down around her, her face completely crumpling, a soft sob escaping her.

Agatha moved, gently pressing toward the seat between Rio's knees as she pulled her into her arms, tucking Rio's head into the crook of her neck, holding her there. She could have told her it was okay, she could have repeated literally any other sentiment that she'd said in her frenzied panic, but what was the point?

Rio knew.

She had to know.

They sat there for a solid fifteen minutes even after Agatha had somehow managed to pull her from the state of shock she had so terrifyingly been stuck in. It was just silence as Agatha swayed from side to side, keeping Rio held tightly in her arms.

The longer the hold remained steadfast, the more Rio felt like she was breaking apart. How had this happened? It wasn't like he had followed them -- had he? Did he know where Estee lived? She had started to rip into an entirely new wave of panic, but Agatha's arms tightened around her at the feeling of Rio tensing in her arms.

"I need you to know," Agatha breathed into her hair, "That as long as I live and breathe, I am never going to let anything happen to you. I need you to hear me when I make that promise to you. I need you to understand that I mean it when I sit here telling it to you."

Rio managed to blink, trying to process what she was hearing with what she was feeling. The words landed and struck, but the sound of Agatha's voice? Was that even Agatha speaking? It was a sound that Rio had never once heard in their time together. It pulled her back, brought her closer to touching solid ground again.

"I believe you," she managed, though it sounded like she was forcing words out of a throat that had spent hours swallowing glass.

The softest choked sigh tumbled out of Agatha's lips as the look of relief seemed to wash over her instantly at hearing the sound of Rio's voice.

Rio sniffled, her hands raising to rest on Agatha's back, a simple touch that was nothing more than a need for contact than it was any kind of clawing to keep hold.

"I'm sorry," Rio's shaky voice managed, the shame so thick, dropping the pitch of her tone.

"Shhhhhh," Agatha pressed, holding her tighter, the swaying still consistent. "I never want to hear you apologize for anything that has to do with him ever again. He's not even a memory anymore, Rio. He has no more power over you, not anymore."

Rio felt those words in every last inch of her body. She felt them sink through her skin, winding through every strand of every muscle before they welded straight to her bones.

"I would be nothing without you, Agatha," Rio cried quietly.

This caused Agatha to pull back so that she could look at her, really look at her.

Agatha wasn't just looking at her, or looking through her, or even looking into her.

Agatha was seeing her.

Both of her hands were warm as they landed on Rio's cheeks, so undemanding and affectionate in their contact.

"Oh, Rio," Agatha breathed at her. "You were everything before me, and will be so long as you live. It just happens that I'm the one who gets to see it every day."

Agatha leaned toward her, pressing their lips together in something Rio realized was the most intense outpouring of adoration and love that she had ever thought possible. It was Agatha's turn now, to dump everything she had into Rio in hopes that she might be able to fill her back up, to cure the hollowness that had swallowed her whole.

When their lips parted, Rio's eyes flickered open to consume the sight before her, pulling it over her like a thick quilt, like it could somehow fight the chill that had settled into her soul.

Something struck her -- the sound of Estee's voice clear as day in her head. She blinked it back, somehow finding her voice.

"You're staying?" Rio choked out, and it was right there on full display for Agatha to see: the painful sting of hope that she could not stand to have ripped from her grasp.

Agatha's face melted into nothing but tender care for the other woman as she closed that space again, stealing another gentle kiss.

"I'm not going anywhere."

*****

After another thirty minutes where Agatha gave Rio the time to pull her pieces back together, they had managed to untangle in a way that they were able to get out of the SUV and make their way into the apartment.

The moment the front door shut, the television in the back of the house paused.

This was something they had covered in that thirty minutes; Agatha had offered to remove Nicky and Tay so that Rio could have the private conversation with Estee. At first, Rio had seemed to consider it, but she had given a gentle shake of her head, divulging to Agatha why she wouldn't do that.

If they were going to be building this unit, this... family, then transparency was going to be a necessity. She knew that Estee would not feel embarrassed, or like Rio should have handled it differently. Estee was not ashamed of the courage her mother had showed her entire life, and she never would be.

So, as they paced down the hallway and appeared in the doorway? All three pairs of eyes were on them -- Nicky sat on the corner of the bed, both of the girls in their assumed positions -- and all three postures softened almost at the exact same time. It was Estee's voice that came first, though.

"Mama..." she breathed. She wasn't going to ask her if she was okay, because whatever had happened had clearly injured her and was going to take some form of recovery.

Without a word, she pulled Agatha to the loveseat and nearly folded onto it next to her, trying to dig up every last ounce of courage that she could find to have this conversation.

She lifted her gaze, meeting Estee's across the bed. She knew that she was having this conversation with all of them, but she needed the peace she had always found in her daughter's beautiful face to truly gather that courage.

"Elias was in the restaurant when we went in for more wine." Rio's voice surprised even herself in its strength, although that resolve wavered not a minute later at the way Estee's eyes began to fill and spill with devastated tears.

"Mama, no... I..." she choked out. Rio had almost missed it, the way Tay had picked up Estee's hand in both of her own. Of course she had told her.

"Shh, mija. It's okay. I know that I... I know that was scary. But... Agatha punched him?"

The reaction from four different people happened all at exactly the same time.

Nicky balked, his wild and shocked gaze falling onto his mother. No fucking way. His mom had punched someone in the middle of a restaurant? Part of him hoped that it had happened fast enough that no one could grab any pictures, or else her PR team were going to have a literal nightmare on their hands. Still, that thought was overshadowed by the fact that she had literally punched a man in the face?

Agatha straightened a bit, bringing up a hand to hold forth two fingers, a smirk twisting up her lips. "Twice."

Tay's hand had literally clapped to her mouth. She had watched Rio live in her peace, and had been lucky enough to be on the receiving end of her love, but the way she had seen her in those passing days since she had come back home with Agatha? She saw a woman who spent so much time tending to the needs of everyone else finally coming to understand what it meant when someone did that right back to her.

Estee's reaction was nearly the polar opposite, and it was the one that seemed to suck every bit of air right out of the room.

She sobbed. She didn't tuck into Tay, didn't try to hide her face. She just sobbed.

Rio gave Agatha's hand a soft squeeze as she rose to her feet, sliding onto the bed carefully to pull Estee into her arms, pressing her lips to the top of her daughter's head and let her cry.

"Mija..." Rio breathed, holding her tighter to her chest.

She shook like that for a few more moments before she seemed to find some way to calm herself. Slowly, she lifted her face from Rio's chest and looked up at her mother, their green gazes nearly mirroring one another as they locked.

The younger Vidal's lips twitched up slightly.

"So the takeaway is that your future literally beat the shit out of your past? What a fucking metaphor."

And with the swing of her pointed humor, every bit of the ice that had filled the room around them seemed to crack, and then completely shatter.

There was a collective breath, as if they had all surface at the same time, although Nicky still looked a little lost. From her spot against her daughter, her eyes raised and met Nick's, that previous conversation with him flashing through her mind. He had told her so many things she had needed to know, and if he was going to be a part of this? He had a right to know.

"When I was in uni, I was attacked by the man that is Estrella's biological father. I had not spoken to him since the morning I left his door room, not even when I found out I was pregnant with her. He was inside, when we went for more wine. I... I froze. I had not seen him in over two decades, and there he was, that... predatory look on his face."

Rio lifted her head, glancing over at Agatha, holding her gaze for just a moment before she looked back at Nicky.

"She did what she does. She found an answer to my biggest problem."

This seemed to have an impact as a tidal wave of understanding washed over Nicky's expression and posture.

His own gaze flitted to his mother, the clear emotion welling there. He looked so impossibly proud of her. She couldn't see Agatha with the way she was holding Estee without looking over her shoulder, but she swore she could hear it.

He's never looked at me like that before.

Rio straightened up a bit, her hold on Estee loosening now that she sensed she had reached a point that she wasn't going to completely shatter into pieces at the sudden weight of everything that had unfolded since the moment Rio and Agatha had both walked back into that restaurant.

"So, on that note. When we order dinner later, we are also splurging on a couple of bottles of tequila, because I think we all deserve it."

There was this sudden feeling that ripped into a full bloom at the chorus of laughter that bounced off of every wall of that room.

Rio had been content in her life before Agatha.

But life with Agatha?

Loving Agatha was its own beast, but the tender blossom that sat in the center of Rio's sternum was a love for something else.

In that moment, those sounds filling her ears, she realized that she, Rio Vidal, had finally secured her a life she could fall in love with, too.

Somewhere Only We Know

Oh, simple thing, where have you gone?
I'm getting older and need something to rely on.

*****

The afternoon had worn on, and although the five of them were gathered in that bedroom, watching anything they could land on that they thought might be able to distract them from what had unfolded earlier in the day at Bespoke. It shifted from drama to reality to sitcom and seemed to repeat a cycle that was indicative of just how indecisive they all felt as the turmoil slowly ebbed away.

They had finally settled on a more modern version of a spy film, something that had been light, easy to follow and and had let them get lost for a little while. Estee had, at one point, suggested that it was a good film to turn into a drinking game; one shot for every time the main character, Eggsy, said 'fuck.' Agatha had been pretty quick to point out that they'd all be hospitalized for alcohol poisoning by the end of the film.

That sound; that bright, full, boisterous sound.

It was an absolute symphony of different pitches, of different cadences as their laughter combined and overlapped, somehow managing to swirl in the sweetest sound that Rio knew she'd ever heard in her life.

Before Estee turned on the sequel, Rio had opened the floor to the debate of what they were going to order in for the night.

It had bounced back and forth between Thai, Indian, and pizza, with Tay and Estee both declaring that it had been far too long since they'd had a Fat Badgers pizza. That, then, turned into a bargaining of just how many pizzas they were going to get and what, exactly, the toppings would be.

Despite the fact that it took an entire twenty minutes to settle on a sensible decision, Rio had sat there enjoying every single second. It was this open dialogue, this back and forth of conversation that, in her solitude, she had never given herself the permission to experience. She had let someone she didn't know rule her life, but now? Now, it was going to be hers, again.

She had placed the delivery order, coupling it with an additional order to the liquor store, securing those two bottles of tequila after confirming that Estee had plenty of limes in her refrigerator with a sly Ayy, 'atta girl, mija.

It hadn't taken too long by the time there was a rapping at the front door and Rio was on her feet to collect their meal and the relief they all deserved. She knew it was probably not the smartest choice, and that the last thing they all actually needed was to get completely hammered, but there was something in the power of letting go of control when surrounded by company that would cradle it, embrace it, and never dare dream of taking advantage.

She had momentarily departed from the two bottles of liquor and returned to their little corner of heaven with all three pizza boxes in hand, a stack of plates poised on top. It was just the strangest feeling that settled into the room, that utter enlightenment of what something like this could actually look like.

On the other side of the same coin, though, Rio would still catch herself in the quiet moments. That little sprout of anxiety would poke up, reminding her that even though there was a bit more of a deadline in front of them, they still had it. It was still there, looming, however far out.

They had six months to find something that might work. Truthfully, she'd been struggling to do so for weeks, but perhaps with a couple of more perspectives in the mix in the forms of their children? It was possible that there might just be some way forward. She knew that she would never ask Estee to leave, even if she had implied that she had hope that she'd follow. This was her home, it was all she had ever known, and Rio would never force her hand in making her give it up.

At the same time, though, Rio was grappling with just how hard it might be to put that much space between herself and the best friend she'd had every single day for nearly the last twenty-two years. She knew that, if given the chance, Estee would absolutely push her out the door and toss her packed suitcase out behind her. It had become all too clear in the last week and a half since they had brought her home that she was their biggest fan, and always had been.

There were other times, in the louder moments, when Rio let herself live in it, let herself simply succumb to the sheer joy that came from being in the same immediate space as the four other people in the room. She had tried for so hard and so long to claim that she was happy, that she felt things like joy and elation, but had that ever really been true?

Sure, but only in direct relation to her daughter. Estee had always been the light in Rio's life, hanging up so high, even in the darkest night skies. All Rio had to do was take on look at that beautiful face and for a few seconds, everything was right in the world, even when it wasn't.

She knew that although she'd been saved from seeing it first hand, even the implications of what had happened earlier in the day were weighing on Estee's heart. Rio could see it, in those moments when she would turn her head to catch her daughter's eye, only for her to divert her gaze as if she hadn't meant to get caught watching.

Even without seeing that gaze full on, Rio understood it. She could feel it, the heat of it as it settled over her arms, leaving the hairs standing on end.

Estee was getting sights of sides to her mother that she had maybe known existed, but Rio had spent Estee's entire life trying to keep from her. Yes, they'd had that conversation the moment Rio thought that she could handle it, though she honestly could have caved a year or two sooner and still managed the same result. However, Rio had never once let on to what those first few months had felt like.

She had never dared utter that for the first six months of Estee's life, Rio just cried. The more Rio cried, the more Estee cried, this endless back and forth of frustration and pain that seemed to cycle in its destruction.

And then, one day shy of her six months, it had happened.

Estee had laughed for the very first time.

And Rio hadn't shed another tear for a long, long while.

Sure, life had come and gone and it was unrealistic to think she would never cry again, but the fact still remained:

The first time Estee had laughed was the first time she accepted that the little ball of light in her arms was hers, and only hers.

And there, as she doled out plates and opened up pizza boxes, her eyes raising to those familiar green hues, a striking realization seem to crackle into her, the briefest strike of lightning.

A little piece of Estee belonged to the other three people in that room, even if Rio would always hold the heft of it.

Estee wasn't just hers anymore.

She was theirs.

She was so, so impossibly loved by everyone in that room. She didn't need a verbal acknowledgement of the fact from Nicky; it was in the way he was constantly on his feet to help her when she needed to get to the bathroom. It was in the way he always asked her if she needed anything any time he went to the kitchen, surely not asking anyone else who was able bodied in the room for dramatic flair.

It was even in their soft conversations, Nicky listening with rapt interest as Estee prattled on about how the synaptic firing in a person with ADHD could nearly be triple the speed of someone who was neurotypical, or the exact way certain medications reacted with the brain.

It was much the same way when he would pull out his laptop to run updates for the app, which Estee and Tay had both agreed that they would have used, if they'd ever had any interest in actually dating -- which did not get past Rio by even an inch -- but that the concept was absolutely brilliant. It was when he asked their opinion on the appearance of a certain feature and seeming to truly take what they said into consideration, that Rio's heart seemed to lodge in her throat.

It was so... domestic.

It was so... perfect?

No. That was an understatement.

This was ascension. This was living in the stars.

She sat back, tucked beneath Agatha's arm as the two of them ate their pizza in adoring observation of the interactions between the three other people they loved most in the world. It was scary, really, how fucking fast they'd all just fallen into this...

Ah, there it was.

That word again.

The word that had always meant Estee and Rio.

The word that now meant Estee and Rio and Agatha and Nicky and Taylah.

Family.

"It's pretty crazy, isn't it?" came Agatha's voice, a velvety whisper that sounded so close to Rio's head that it was almost breathed into her hair.

She jumped, pulling back slightly so that she could look up at Agatha, curious green eyes darting back and forth, looking for an answer to an unasked question. The more often that moment seemed to happen between them, the harder it was getting to for Rio to believe that at least some essence of Agatha resided in her mind, listening in on those wordless moments.

But then... Rio could hear Agatha just as loudly, couldn't she? Hadn't she always?

Hadn't that been the biggest mystery since the moment they had placed themselves at that bar in the middle of The Freehand, and with an air of complete certainty, Agatha had correctly ordered Rio's drink without a single question asked?

Agatha knew things about her that she'd never said aloud in the presence of anyone who wasn't Estee. Agatha knew things about her that she sometimes realized she had forgotten about herself. Maybe the question was no longer how or why.

The question had become, at Agatha's own suggestion: When?

The relationship that they had built within a month, it didn't explain it. Hell, nothing even explained that first night. There had been no tension, no awkward air despite the circumstances they had found themselves in. The most miserable part of the entire sixteen hours had been watching Agatha walk out her front door, having no idea who she was, but having complete confidence in the fact that they would never see one another again.

And then, the way Agatha had run up to her in front of that office building, kissing her like she'd been missing it for years?

No other memories needed to remain, from whatever past life it was they had come from. The important ones, the only ones that needed to remain were the resolute echoes of their very souls, bound for the entirety of time. Even past this life? There was something so deeply seated within Rio that just... knew. She knew they would find their way back to one another, back home.

Time could turn, the world could spin on its axis, flowers could bloom and die, trees could grow hundreds of feet from the roots of a sapling, and the world could change as was willed.

One thing that would never change?

Rio and Agatha were meant for one another. They were nothing short of destiny, if it had ever been able to corporealize in two human beings.

Finally, in the midst of every bit of chaos that happened to be those thoughts, Rio found her voice.

"It's everything I never knew I needed."

There was an instant and emotional gleam in Agatha's eyes, her lips pressing to the small space just between Rio's brows.

"Get used to it."

Rio managed the breathiest huff of a laugh, pulling back a little further so that she could bring her hand up to cradle Agatha's cheek. She just watched her, drinking her in, her lips curled in the smallest mile.

"Impossible."

*****

"Here, I'll take them," Nicky offered as he clambered to his feet, swiping everyone's plates as the meal was decidedly over. He turned to take them toward the kitchen, but Rio stopped him.

"The only reason I'm asking is because it's going to be six inches away when you get to the sink, but would you bring the tequila back with you? And, if you feel so inclined, some shot glasses?" Her smile was warm and charming as it filled her face, her eyes sparkling at him in her sweet request.

"Only because I like you," he shot back with a grin and disappeared through the doorway.

"Did you really get two bottles?" Estee asked, quirking a brow.

"Yes. Of the Mijenta."

At this, Estee nearly erupted into laugher, right alongside Tay.

"Holy shit, Mama," Tay managed, holding her side in her laughter. "You were serious."

At this, Agatha looked confused, but Rio picked up on it immediately.

"It's really really good tequila. I mean... Not 'three hundred dollar of brandy that never actually got opened' good, but still pretty good."

A dawning of both realization and humor seemed to curve up Agatha's features, her smile pulling a bit sheepishly at the corners of her mouth.

"You googled it?" Agatha asked, an abashed warmth hugging each word.

Rio grinned.

"You're more concerned with the fact that I googled the price over the fact that I pointed out it never got opened?" Rio posed, her brow quirking question.

"Guess I found better things to get drunk on at the time," Agatha responded simply, though Nicky's reappearance gave her a reason to act like she hadn't just said something with that much gravity.

He was concise in the way he doled out the glasses and filled them carefully, having set the plate of cut limes in the middle of the bed. The three of them that were not on the bed did come to the edges, holding the glasses out.

"What should we toast to?" Estee asked, and there was a brief but silent exchange of glances as if to see who was going to speak up, though no one was surprised when Agatha raised her shot glass a little higher.

"To walking in the bike lane," she announced, and Rio could feel so severely every place inside of her that turned to an absolute puddle. Her head had turned and she was looking at Agatha, seeing her. In that moment, their eyes locked, not even the smitten stares of the other occupants seemed to matter.

I love you so fucking much.

Agatha's smile only seemed to grow, and as their eyes held steady, Rio knew she heard it this time.

I know.

Estee, who was wearing a smirk so amused, gave a gentle clearing of her throat. The two older woman seemed to snap back into the moment, everyone else moving to raise their glasses in unison.

"To walking in the bike lane!"

The glasses clinked above the middle of the bed which they then dropped them to, all grabbing a lime at the same time. After a tap to the bed, they all threw the shots back, completely synced in the way they immediately crammed the limes into their mouths.

It was so silly, so stupid, but so... light. It was so freeing. It was permission.

Rio could walk away from her past, finally. The reason? She simply couldn't let it hold her by the ankles, keeping her away from moving toward her future.

Rio would cross any distance to get closer to that future, and it scared her that she'd contained little to no hesitation at the thought. But then again, her recklessness and blind hope had been ever present since the moment Estee had pointed out the obvious about the earring. It truly seemed to know no bounds.

And so, they had sat and drank and listened to music, taking turns as they passed the remote around, everyone getting a chance to play their own selections. They had talked for hours about anything and everything under the sun, though Rio's favorite topic had been the one where she was pretty sure that she, Estee and Tay had successfully swayed Agatha and Nicky into letting them teach the two of them how to surf.

"I am forty nine years old. What on earth makes you think I am meant to learn to surf this late in life?!" Agatha had managed through her laughter, dissolving into those giggles that had been sparked by the thought.

"Well," Taylah posed, her slightly tipsy smile a little crooked on her lips. "For what it's worth, you're the fittest forty-nine year old I've ever seen."

At this, Estee swung her hand back, lightly hitting Tay in the stomach.

"Just because you've got three shots in you does not mean you can hit on my mom's girlfriend," she offered, though the amusement was written so cleanly across every feature.

"I'm not!" Tay tried to defend, but she saw that mischievous twinkle in her own girlfriend's eye. "I was just clearly stating the obvious."

Another burst of laughter, sounding in every bit of its purity.

Another shot. More laughter.

Another one. Hysterical, belly aching laughter.

Things began to wind down, though, and although Rio would have considered herself reasonably drunk, there was something warm and inviting about making her way down that hallway with Agatha and just falling into her for the night. She'd been of the mind that it was likely she would probably doze off pretty quickly, anyway.

As the two of them decided it was time to turn in, they rose, hands so easily finding one another in the space between them.

"I don't care if you guys keep drinking, because you're adults, but I'm not cleaning up anyone's sick," Rio voiced as she made her way toward the bed, leaning over to kiss both Estee and Taylah on the foreheads, almost at the exact same time Agatha replicated the action to Nicky.

"Goodnight children," they both voiced at the same time as they departed, causing soft giggles to bloom on their lips as they made their way down to their awaiting haven for the night.

Rio pushed the door shut behind her as Agatha went further into the room, over toward the backpack she had been keeping her life in. There was something postured, something that screamed intent as she rummaged through the bag, pulling something out of it that she palmed easily, walking over to the little end table on the side of the bed she had been sleeping -- always Agatha's side, no matter the bed.

She set it down, but from where she stood, Rio still couldn't tell what it was outside of a small bottle; the printing on the label was too small to read. Agatha turned, her eyes falling on Rio, the curling of her lips so warm in their motion.

"Come here, my love," Agatha requested in the softest murmur, her hands held out to accentuate her request.

Rio heeded the call, stepping forward until she was close enough to slide her hands into Agatha's, who pulled her close, steadying her uneven gait. One hand released its hold so that she could wrap her arm into that familiar crux of the small of Rio's back.

Her other hand lifted, gently laying Rio's own hand on her chest. As her gaze lifted and Rio found herself drowning in those beautiful, gorgeous, mesmerizing blue eyes? She found herself swallowing down a sob that had unexpectedly rocketed out of her chest.

"Take off your shirt," Agatha requested, and Rio seemed so stilled, a little shocked by the lack of well... anything leading up to that soft demand. It wasn't that she wouldn't comply, it was just that it had simply caught her off guard.

She moved within the confines of Agatha's light hold on her, reaching down to somehow pull her shirt up over her head, though Agatha's focus never left Rio's face.

She leaned forward, brushing their lips together at first, but then pressing a little more firmly, though it did not escalate past that. Instead, she pulled away, her hand on Rio's right side gave a gentle squeeze before Agatha voiced her next request.

"Turn around."

Again, Rio watched her, trying to read her, but the silence was intentional, but in the air, and in her own head. She watched her just another beat before she obliged, facing away from Agatha.

Agatha's fingertips raking down her back were an instant sensation that whipped heat all throughout her body. They halted, lifting, though the clasp of her bra came free and she let the garment drop silently.

For as drunk as Rio might have been, she was oddly tuned into that moment.

Agatha's hands landed on her bare sides, so tender in their caress as they began to slide down Rio's sides to her hips. As they reached that destination, though, there was something different about the way that Agatha moved. She was being so... gentle. So... careful.

He tips of her fingers tucked into the waist band of Rio's joggers, but only her joggers, and gently pushed them down, letting her lips brush feather-light down the middle of Rio's back as she did so.

She rose to full height and began to strip down herself, pulling her blouse over her head, shucking her jeans. As she tossed her own bra aside, they were both left in only their underwear.

Rio could feel it just before it happened as Agatha's arms secured snugly around her middle, her lips finding a home on Rio's shoulder. She kept that contact for a long few moments, but then straightened up once more, her embrace loosening, though she was still close to Rio's ear.

"Lay down," she breathed into Rio's ear, letting her go.

Without hesitation, Rio simply followed her own intuition and did as she knew she needed to do. She wasn't certain what was happening here, but she knew that it was bringing with it a different weight, a different sense of certainty.

She slid onto the top of the duvet, laying on her stomach, just intoxicated enough that she was not raising much question. That, and she trusted Agatha entirely.

Agatha was almost silent in the way she moved, reaching up to turn off the light on the end table before she picked up the bottle she had set there earlier.

She knelt onto the mattress and quickly found where she needed to be, settling with her legs on either side of Rio's hips as she rested on the curve of her ass.

There was nothing sexual about this. This was something else, Rio knew.

She knew it even before she felt the warm oil on her back. A surprised but warm hum fell from Rio's lips. It was low, it was a sound of surrender as everything seemed to slide into place, becoming crystal clear.

Agatha leaned forward, both of her palms laying across Rio's back flatly before they moved, dedicated to the act of spreading the oil where it needed to be. There was a very clear statement here; Let me soothe what parts of you I can.

Rio had already been well on the way to being a complete puddle, but the moment that Agatha began to actually work?

The way her fingers seemed to knead and roll into every muscle in exactly the right way, it was doing something to Rio. Or... It was undoing her, one gentle press, one soft pull at a time.

The gentlest sounds would escape her lips, a soft grunt when Agatha hit a particularly tender spot, or the lightest sigh as she tended to a tense spot.

Rio had never known what it was like to be touched like this, and she thought there to be something rather comforting in the fact that Agatha had picked this day of all days to pour this type of affection into her.

The longer it drew on, the more she could feel the peace seeping into every bit of who she was as a human being. Her eyes had shut and her breathing had begun to even out, and after another few moments, Agatha realized that Rio was asleep.

She leaned over her, her own front flush against Rio's back as she placed the most tender kiss to the crown of her head.

Carefully, she slid off to the side and pulled the duvet over them to the best of her ability, though Rio's position stalled the effort. As Agatha rolled to her side, she scooted forward, pressing against Rio as her arm fell over her back.

And even in the depths of her dreams, Rio could have sworn she heard it.

I'm going to marry this woman.

Valiant

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Very slowly, as exam week wore on for Estee, everyone else had kept busy -- and as quiet as possible -- as they began to pack up the apartment. Estee had always made it very clear that while this had been her home for four years, her home would always be where her mother was. She knew she could lay roots down in Auckland, opening up an office where she could really get her feet beneath her.

But then again, couldn't she do that anywhere she wanted to go?

While Estee had shelved the thoughts to focus on passing her finals, it had been something that often kicked up a waterspout of indecision in Rio's mind.

What was she going to do?

They were bringing Estee home, soon, but... Where was Rio's home?

That was an easy and automatic answer.

Right beside Agatha.

But what did that mean when it was clearly trying to rip her life in two, trying to pull her in two different directions that were oh so very far away from each other. It had been nearly thirty five years since Rio's father had brought her to New Zealand; it was the place she had made the most memories -- until Agatha.

In ten days, Rio had seen, felt, experienced more than she had been able to comprehend. She got to see the beach at sunset from the back of a horse. She got to see the entirety of Los Angeles from the vantage point of a goddess. She'd known what it felt like to be high up in that ivory tower, where she was meant to be in that office as she looked out on a city that had been so unfamiliar, but had grown to feel like something more akin to comfort.

It was the exact opposite of everything Rio had always been; LA was loud, it was full, it was busy and twisting up with too many people to count. Rio had always been one to keep to herself, to stay out of crowds. But the way, as they walked the streets, window shopping or just people watching, Rio had noticed it -- the world did really move around Agatha.

Couldn't she relate?

Since the moment their hands had touched, Rio's entire life had moved about the presence of that mysterious woman. It had never really gotten past it, instead just circling. Getting on that plane had been a move that had put her directly in Agatha's path, though, and now, this was her life.

Could she really see herself in a city like LA, dating Hollywood Royalty? Well, she was halfway there already, without question. She felt like a scratched record, the needle skipping over every carved indent. She just kept going around in circles knowing that this choice was simply impossible.

There had been moments, as the two of them had laid in bed, that they had tried to talk about it, but it usually ended in one of them getting frustrated and dejected, leading the other to pepper her face with kisses.

Before, Rio would have said that what had happened between them would have always been impossible, but she had somehow made it possible. But this? This was beyond impossible; there was no clear cut decision here that wasn't going to hurt someone. She wanted to find a way that everyone was happy, but it seemed less and less likely the longer their time in Queenstown had drawn to a close.

Something Rio had noticed, over the passing few days, was that Agatha had been spending a lot more time on her phone. It wasn't anything excessive, like she was absorbed in something she couldn't get away from, but she was constantly checking for notifications and immediately responding when she had them. She had even stepped out once or twice to take a call; Rio knew that she had put work on the backburner, so what was it that had Agatha's attention all of a sudden?

The moving company had come the Sunday after Estee had finished her exams, and Rio knew that it was likely she was thankful for the distraction, that she didn't have to fixate on waiting for her results. It was funny, though, because she was mostly just giving direction due to her literal physical inability to help; at least she knew how to coordinate pretty well, Rio would give her that.

The plan of attack was initially that Rio, Agatha and Tay would fly out first with Nicky and Tay behind them to make sure that nothing got left behind. That had shifted, though, and Rio had decided to be the one to stay behind with Nicky. Perhaps it was more for sentimental value than all else, but she had wanted to be the one to see that chapter of her daughter's life close.

They would surely fly back for graduation, but Rio had been all too aware of how much Estee had been missing home, and life on that little house boat.

Oh. Shit.

That was definitely not something Rio had taken into consideration in the throes of them packing and trying to orchestrate the move.

How were five people going to cram onto that house boat?

That was something they could figure out when they got there, she supposed. It did no one any good to be stewing on it until then; it was a little too late in the process to be starting those plans.

Maybe the thought of a full house should have worried her, should have made her fret over whether or not everyone would feel comfortable, but in the same turn, there was something warming, comforting about it. There was something that Rio almost couldn't identify, but then it settled into her chest cavity.

She had always hoped for this.

She'd never allowed herself to admit how much she needed it. Admitting that Rio's life was not the perfectly constructed facade that she had been cultivating for decades? It once would have been like pulling teeth, but now? Now, she knew that although it still felt like she was living a complete dream, she could say it. She could finally bring forth the truth that she had been lying for the entire duration of the time, both to herself and to anyone who would listen.

Another thought had struck her, once she and Nicky had gotten on that plane.

It would be Agatha's first time back on that houseboat since the day they'd met. It made Rio's heart squeeze in her chest with an emotion that mixed somewhere between thrill and affection. In some way, it made her a little sad that Agatha was going to get there before her, but that also meant that she would be the one to welcome Rio home when she arrived.
