So, by the time the car pulled up to drop off Rio and Nicky, she was completely confounded when she crossed the threshold of the post, getting closer to the door.

There was no sound. Rio tried the handle, but it did not give. It was still locked.

Her brow pinched and she immediately pulled out her phone, though Nicky noticed, too.

"They're not here?" he asked, the uncertainty in his own tone.

"Call your mom, I'm calling Estee."

They both punched in the numbers, and she could hear Agatha answer first, but half a second later, Estee's line picked up, too. On both lines?

Rio could hear it from two different sources, the absolutely tickled laughter of the three women in the car. It made her heart soar, launching somewhere up into the atmosphere. Not only were they okay, but they were apparently in good spirits.

Concurrently, Agatha and Estee both revealed to Nicky and Rio that they were simply running an errand, something that Agatha had remembered she'd needed to do. It was vague, and Rio thought they were both full of shit, but she didn't press the issue. Whatever they were up to, Rio figured it probably wasn't the worst thing in the world -- and the thought of all three of her girls spending time together made her melt like an ice sculpture on a hot summer day.

She had let the two of them in and had showed Nicky around, though there was something about the look on his face, a sudden dawning of acceptance and understanding. He could see, in that quaint little home, each piece of it that his mother had loved. He had studied the plants, even asking the occasional question about what type a certain one was when Rio would bustle by him, trying to get everything adjusted to make things a little easier on Estee. She had been doing better, but if Rio could eliminate any inconvenience? Well, she'd do it without question.

Nicky had eventually set about his own work, cleaning out the refrigerator from the remnants of what Rio had left behind a month and a half ago when she had beelined it straight for America. They had chatted, and thrown on music as they moved about, shifting things, finding ways to make it all flow together in a way that would be able to contain the now large size of their family.

By the time, two hours later, they had given the home a once over and decided that they had accomplished all they set out to do. Folding onto the couch, they decided to watch a documentary about the kookaburra, per Nicky's request, though Rio was growing anxious.

What the hell were they doing that they'd been gone this long? She was getting occasional snaps from Estee, so she knew they were fine, but her curiosity was beginning to nibble on the edges of her stomach, almost creeping toward anxiety.

Ten minutes later, she could hear them coming up the walk in all of their chatter and giggles.

Rio was on her feet in an instant, nearly ripping the door off of the hinges in her excitement to see them again, as if they hadn't just parted ways earlier that morning. The grin on her face was wide and bright, noting the couple of bags that dangled from Tay's fingers from Rio's favorite restaurant.

"Why do I feel like the three of you have been up to absolutely no good?" Rio posed as she stood back to let them in, Agatha bringing up the rear.

Before Rio could even move to shut the door, one of Agatha's hands were on her side, and the other was cradling her cheek like it were more valuable than pure gold. "I missed you," she breathed, leaning in to press their lips together in a kiss that never seemed to lose its ability to snatch the breath out of Rio's lungs.

As they parted, Rio's hand that had landed on the side of Agatha's neck during their lip lock seemed to hold her in place, not letting her get too far away. Rio was searching, diving as deep as she could in those beautiful blue eyes, trying to pull it out of her, trying to listen in to what was going on in that head of hers.

"So, are you going to tell me what you lot were doing?" Rio murmured, at her, tilting her head so that the tip of her nose grazed the side of Agatha's, a soft beguiling.

Agatha seemed to think for a moment, her eyes searching around toward the ceiling, as if she might find the answer there. Instead, the smirk that wound its way across her lips did something to Rio's stomach, both making it flip and also feel like it had been loaded with stones.

"Sure am... not going to do that," Agatha answered, her smirk growing. "Instead, we are going to eat our fancy take out from Culprit, which Estee informed me is your favorite, and then we will figure out the rest of the evening. So. Chop chop, vamanos!"

For the briefest moment, Rio was pretty sure that her soul had completely vacated her body with the shock that hit her at hearing Agatha use that word. It was the first time she'd done anything even remotely similar and it was a pit of warmth that nestled right in the center of Rio's middle. Her brows twitched slightly, almost imperceptibly, but then her head tilted at the woman before her.

"You... Jesus Christ, woman. Knock that off, it's not an appropriate time," Rio shot back, leaning in to steal one more quick peck before the separated and she shut the door.

And so, they had all managed to find a space in the main room of the home, huddled around the coffee table that supported the weight of their meal. Although Rio was almost certain that Estee had told Agatha what to get for Rio, those damn steak tartare cones were absolutely to die for, and she was thankful for the thought that had gone into it.

The way they'd exchanged forkfuls across the table, sharing with each other so everyone could get a little taste of everything, it felt to Rio like it had been ripped right out of some heartwarming family film. It felt like this was a dream she might have had in some distant memory, something she had thought that she would never actually be able to see, and as a result?

Rio was not entirely convinced she was not still asleep. Rio had laid her head down that night, after watching Agatha leave, and maybe it was just true that she'd simply never roused. It would have made more sense than what was currently splayed out in front of her, leaving her so full to the brim with love in her chest that she hardly knew what to do with it. It was begging to burst through her ribcage, through her muscles, tearing her skin. That love wanted her to be open, to be vulnerable, and she was finally conceding.

After dinner, Rio had stood to clean up, but Agatha seemed to be of the same mind, raising to her feet behind her. The two of them collected the trash, stowing it in the paper bags that it had come in. Rio had indicated that she was going outside to dispose of them in the bin, but Agatha was quick in declaring she would join her.

Rio opened the lid to the bin at the same time that Agatha shut the door and paced over to her, that look on her face... What the hell was that look? She tried to ignore it as she held her hand out, slipping the handle of the bag out of Agatha's grasp and into her own before tossing it inside, too. She let the lid drop shut and moved forward to where Agatha stood on that walkway.

She had been under the impression that they were going back inside, but realized the moment that Agatha wrapped her up in her arms that maybe they just needed a minute. Just a quiet moment, a moment to realize where, exactly they were standing, and the crushingly affectionate weight of what that meant.

"You know," Agatha breathed from her position with her chin tucked over Rio's head. "I really missed this place."

Rio exhaled the softest giggle, barely a breath out of her nose.

"It's not sentient, but if it were, I'm almost certain it would say it missed you too."

Agatha lifted her head and leaned back slightly, just enough to reach up to tuck a curved finger under Rio's chin so that she could tilt her head back.

Those burning blue eyes, they were... No, it wasn't the normal look that Agatha had in her eyes when she peered into the depths of Rio's soul.

This was something different. There was this silent determination, this steadfast resolve to do... whatever it was she was thinking about doing. She dropped her head just enough to brush their lips together.

"Let's go for a drive," Agatha suggested, that mischief showing itself in a bright gleam in her gaze.

"And let me guess, you're driving?" Rio posed back, that thrilled smirk finding her face. Here she was, Agatha taking charge in every single bit of her glory.

"Of course, as if that was in question. Plus, you don't know where we're going."

At this, Rio's eyebrows shot up in excited curiosity. For as much time as they had spent in Queenstown to be with Estee, it had not really ever crossed Rio's mind until that moment that perhaps Agatha had done a little more sight-seeing than she had ever let on to when she had been there on her initial trip.

"Well then, let me grab my keys for you."

She had disappeared inside, informing the kids that they were going to go... somewhere, for a little bit and that they would be back.

Somehow, beyond Rio's own comprehension, each of them were absolutely fighting for their lives to remain calm and stoic, nodding in understanding and wishing them a good time, as though they were completely clueless.

She told them she loved them and made her way back outside to an Agatha who looked damn good in those orange hues of the setting sun, leaned so casually against that post, the nail still jutting out from the side, this time bare in its adornment, no earring to be seen. Her arms were folded over her chest and one leg was bent at the knee, her foot flat against the post.

For a moment, Rio was just stood there, in complete awe; she was looking at the eighth wonder of the world, and absolutely no one else could have convinced her otherwise.

Agatha seemed to notice the lack of movement and turned only her head, some of her hair dropping over her shoulder to behind her back. She had this smile on her face, and while it felt so familiar, there was something else about it that Rio couldn't quite put her finger on.

"Are you waiting for something?" Agatha posed, one side of her mouth hitching up in a smirk.

"Nope," Rio responded, tilting her head a bit to the side, soaking up every bit of that moment she could. "Just admiring the view."

Agatha rolled her eyes and righted herself, holding her hand out for the keys, which Rio forked over gladly.

As they slid inside, the moment her belt was buckled, Agatha's hand dropped over the center console and found a home on top of Rio's thighs, giving a soft squeeze.

As Rio looked over at her, she was still trying to listen, still trying to hear what always seemed to be so deafeningly loud in so many other instances. She heard nothing. There was no give, no whisper. Just silence.

As Agatha kept checking her smart watch, Rio caught a brief glance and saw why -- she had a map there. And the longer they drove? Rio could understand why.

Agatha seemed to have a complete confidence about her as she made her way out of the city, heading up along the edge of the coast.

"Where are we going, Agatha?" Rio asked, gripping at her hand a little harder. They'd been driving nearly two hours in this strange anxious tension that both of them were hiding beneath the guise of gentle wonder and mystery.

"We're almost there," she responded simply, though the tone of her voice had an odd ring of comfort to it.

"Okay," Rio returned, pressing her lips together for a moment. "But where is there?"

The only answer she got was Agatha's grin seeming to grow as she checked her watch one last time and slowed to make her turn. This only caused Rio's brow to pinch again as they turned into a neighborhood. What the hell was Agatha doing?

After another moment, the car rolled to a stop. Finally, Rio found it in her to rip her interrogative gaze away to turn her head back toward the window to see what was so important that they had to drive two hours to see it.

The house was massive. It was a sharp angled two story building that was actually rather striking. The upper level hung over about two to three feet from the one beneath it, and the paneling looked like hardwood. There was a thin rectangular window on the right side. Below it, there was a wooden doorway with three windows on each side that was blonde in color, surrounded by dark bricking that extended over as far as the far wall of the two car garage, the door of which matched the front door. Going the other way, the bricks stopped about halfway, leaving a white paneled space with a large glass opening in the middle of it. It was the same white paneling, Rio noticed, that was on the room above the garage.

It was... beautiful. Rio had never seen anything quite like it, even having lived in that city her entire life.

She was completely stunned to silence, trying to process what was being implied here. There was no way. There was no way Agatha had gone so far as to buy them a house. Rio was not going to accept that for an answer until she had some kind of explanation. As overjoyed as the thought made her seem, she had been under the impression that this would have been an at-length conversation before any big decisions were made.

"Agatha..." Rio managed, feeling like she could only taste sandpaper. "What are we doing here?"

Agatha unfastened her seatbelt and shifted around so that she could take in the sight of Rio, and what could be a home for them through the window behind her. Her lips wound in thought for a moment as she tried to parse through her own chaos to say what she wanted to say, exactly the way she wanted to say it.

"What if you didn't have to choose?" Agatha finally asked her.

Rio's eyes narrowed slightly as her brow knit tight in clear misunderstanding. What did that mean?

"What if... You could come and go as you please? We could come and go as we please. All of us. There's four bedrooms and four bathrooms in there. It's four thousand square feet of livable space. And," she added, as if this would seal the deal, "You're only a six minute walk to the water." Agatha gave Rio's hand a firm squeeze, her eyes never once leaving Rio's confused expression. "We don't have to stay in one place all of the time. So... this way, we always have somewhere soft to land."

At this, the tears in Rio's eyes were hot and instant, but because there was absolutely nothing else she could have done, no other gesture she could have made that would have accurately displayed what it was she was feeling in that moment.

Rio's lips parted, but only a breath came out. There was no sound, no voice, no words. She was trying, but she was suddenly so confounded that she didn't know how to process what was being handed directly to her.

Agatha dropped her hand and reached up, cupping her cheek gingerly as her thumb brushed away that soft trail of tears on her warm skin.

"I know... I know i should have talked to you about it. But... I've been working on it since the day Estee started taking her exams. And... If it's not something you want yet, that's okay. I didn't really think about how this might feel like an ambush." Her smile softened, almost guilty in its new delivery. "And this is absolutely not to say you have to sell the house boat. In fact... for purely sentimental reasons, I really hope you don't. But... we could all come and go and still call it home. And... on the other end of that, my house is way too big for just me. There's five bedrooms in there, and the pool house."

As Rio watched her, completely floored by just how much thought Agatha seemed to have put into this, she could see that there was more behind those eyes.

Agatha straightened up a little bit, but she did not release her hold on Rio's hand.

"I am also willing to finance any desire to obtain dual citizenship, for all three of you. Visas work, sure, but... that way, you'd still be able to have what you've always known, when you want it, and I... I get to have you."

In a sudden surge of motion, Rio adjusted her own position and leaned over the center console, kissing Agatha as hard as she could muster in her very bones. There wasn't anything to say, really. How the hell did anyone respond to that, anyway? What string of words in any entire linguistic history could ever describe just how fucking much she loved Agatha Harkness?

It was almost forceful in its insistence of her feelings, but Agatha didn't stop her, didn't try to tame her. She instead fed right back into it, kissing Rio like her life damn near depended on it. Well, that was one hell of an answer.

After a few long moments, they parted, their chests rising and falling a bit quicker as a display of their effort. They were just locked, blue and emerald, doing that search, looking for the answer as to how it was all possible that this was where they were.

Swallowing down the emotion sitting in her throat, Rio looked back at the house for a beat, but when she turned back to Agatha, she was holding up a key that Rio immediately realized was to the front door.

"Do you wanna go in?" Agatha posed, that grin spreading over her entire face, wrinkling the corners of her eyes.

"I would love to."

Agatha was out in a flash, coming around as quick as she could manage to open Rio's door for her, holding that steadfast hand out for her to take.

Rio's heart was beating so impossibly hard, so overflowing with the sheer devotion to the woman who unlocked the door to their future for the very first time. This was it. This was really, really it. This was the loudest Agatha had ever been in declaring what lengths she would go to in order to ensure that their relationship was something they never had to go without.

The view from the front? That had been a farce.

The inside of the home, of what she could immediately see, was not only absolutely massive, but there were giant windows on the far wall, looking out just far enough that the water was visible. It might have only felt so large due to the lack of furnishings, but something about it immediately struck Rio as somewhere she could spend her time.

Agatha gave a gentle tug on her hand.

"Tour!" she nearly chirped in a sound that was so light Rio hardly knew how to contain the way her breath caught somewhere near the base of her throat.

"Kitchen, complete with everything state-of-the-art that I could ever hope for."

Agatha was talking, but Rio wasn't listening, not really.

No, Rio was staring at the very black, very small box that was sitting atop the very white marble countertop.

"And --"

"Agatha."

The one word stopped her mid-sentence, and the look that smoothly slid onto her features showed that she had known it was coming.

"Yes, my love?" she asked, as if she had no idea why Rio had interrupted her.

Rio was staring so damn hard at that box that she didn't even know if Agatha was looking at her; she didn't even really care.

There was no way it was what Rio immediately assumed it could be.

Absolutely no way.

"What is that?"

Agatha's hand gripped a little tighter at Rio's, almost rattling her knuckles together, though her words were a stark contrast, a way to keep up the game.

"Oh, this?" she asked, reaching for the velvet box as she held it up. "This is for you," she told her. "If you say yes, of course."

With ease, Agatha used her one hand to flip open the box, revealing what was inside.

There was no question about it: Rio's heart stopped beating. Maybe it was two seconds, maybe it was ten. She'd forgotten every single automatic function that her body was supposed to be responsible for.

There, nestled in black velvet was the most incredibly exquisite ring that Rio had ever laid eyes on in her entire life. The detail, the stippling, the design? They were all incredible, but they seemed to pale in comparison to the large rock of a diamond that was lodged directly in the middle.

All at once, she gasped for a breath as her hand that wasn't in Agatha's flew up to her mouth. The one that was in Agatha's was gripping it for dear life, and for utter fear that she was two seconds away from passing out.

Agatha's own hold loosened, indicating that she needed the use of both of her hands.

It lifted, finding its home along the angle of Rio's jaw, her thumb caressing the skin there.

"So, Rio Vidal, would you make me the luckiest person in the world and be my wife?"

There they were again, those hot, moved tears that seemed to be the only way she could communicate. Her hand raised, landing on Agatha's wrist as she willed herself to nod, struggling to get her vocal chords to vibrate the way they needed so her answer could be heard.

"Y-y-yes, Agatha. Yes, I will be your wife."

Agatha's other hand raised, still clutching the box, so that she could hold Rio's face firmly where she wanted it as their lips pressed together again.

That wasn't just a kiss.

That was an understanding.

Their story had started that very first moment Rio had spotted Agatha on that bridge.

Now, it was time to move on to the next chapter.

*****

What do you say? Would you marry me today?
The moon would gush all inside out and my nightmares would go away.
What do you say? Would you devote yourself today?
Like riding out a sinking ship as it lowers into the bay.
Please stay.

Simple Math

Chapter Notes

dont read this in front of your family (;

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Simple math, it's why our bodies even lay here.
Sinful math, the truth cannot be fractioned.
*****

The moment their lips separated, still remaining a simple breath of way, it was a feat of wonder that neither of their faces cracked with the grins that absolutely split them.

Agatha had taken the time to remove the ring from its cradle, wasting no time in sliding it onto the correct finger on Rio's finger. The way that Agatha just held her left hand in both of her own, just staring down at the ring on her hand? She had dissolved into utter love and affection.

They were engaged.

ENGAGED.

Rio fucking Vidal was engaged to Agatha Harkness.

This was a fairy tale, full stop. This was something that had surpassed even the most intense dreams of longing and want. For every night Rio had fallen asleep alone, trying to shush the small voice that whined for companionship?

Rio never had to want ever again. It had become astoundingly apparent that Agatha would move mountains if she had to in order to provide for Rio, or their children. She would go to any lengths to make sure that they had whatever it was they needed in life, and she had started right there, in the kitchen of their new home.

She had never really considered the idea of being able to float; she had never been much of a traveler, but she was willing to adapt if it meant that she got to keep this, what she had right then. She had Agatha, and the promise of a life that she knew would fill her with endless happiness.

Was she naive enough to think that there would never come a time that she and Agatha would butt heads? Of course not. Despite the incredibly strange symmetry to them, they were still two very different people. They would eventually unlock whatever differing opinions might lie between them, but with everything they had already experienced? After what they had been through?

Rio could live with it if Agatha was ever mad about how loud she brushed her teeth, or how she loaded the dishwasher wrong. She could live with it if Agatha hated something she cooked, or said, even in a moment of frustration, that Rio's endless optimism was excruciating.

She could live with all of those things because it meant getting to live with Agatha, too.

Their edges fit together and when combined, the were able to show a fuller glimpse of what this like could look like for them.

And then, to add the other three pieces? The image was growing, turning into more of a snapshot, a full sight on what lay ahead. It was thrilling.

In the middle of drowning in those gorgeous blue eyes -- that belonged to her gorgeous fiance! -- Rio had come up for air, something dawning on her.

"The kids knew," Rio accused softly, though her smile rang through clear as day in her tone.

"Of course they did. Who do you think helped me pick out the ring?" Agatha breathed back at her, stealing another soft kiss. "And I texted Nicky after you both called to tell him what we were really doing. I met the realtor at the restaurant for the key."

Rio's eyes were full of nothing but stars. She was beyond moved, beyond just touched. This woman was looking her dead in the eye and professing that she could not bare the thought of not being together. There had been times when Rio had chastised herself for feeling that way, telling herself that she didn't need to be so needy, that she didn't need to cling so hard.

Was clinging to Agatha really that much of a bad thing if she could feel Agatha clinging right back?

"I don't even know what the fuck to say," Rio managed, an infectious giggle spilling from her lips, a sound of pure, unadulterated joy.

"Gods, whatever you do, don't say 'thank you.' I won't un-ask, but... a few other things might be off the table..." Agatha glanced to her side, the smirk winding across her lips before her eyes met Rio's again. "Er-- counter."

In the matter of one single second, the temperature in that entire house absolutely skyrocketed.

Gods be damned, how the fuck did Agatha do that?

Because she was so fucking ethereal. And also so goddamned hot.

"Oh," Rio responded, seemingly nonplussed, her eyes hardly following where Agatha's had gone. "I guess I didn't realize that there was anything else that was supposed to be on that counter. Did you bring a fruit basket?"

That devious flash in her eyes was burning hot, and she could see as each one of her words hit Agatha's ears.

"A fucking fruit basket?" Agatha shot back, bordering on falling prey to a fit of laughter, but she somehow stifled it with a deep breath, those beautiful blue eyes darkening with a voracious appetite that Rio had grown accustomed to. "The last thing I want to eat off of this counter is fruit."

There it was, that absolute fireball that landed right in her middle. Sometimes, she swore all Agatha had to do was breathe just the right way and it could turn her on, make her weak in the knees. But right then?

Agatha had dropped a lit match into a full fuel tank.

Rio felt it, from her toes all the way to the top of her head, as she caught fire.

If the blush was even half as powerful as the actual heat? She was sure that she was red on every piece of skin that was visible, and every single one that wasn't, too.

Rio's hand fell flat to Agatha's chest, but then moved, making its way to her neck. Her fingers curled around the back, but her thumb seemed to find that little spot, right next to the hollow of Agatha's throat, where she could feel the gentle drum of her pulse, though she could tell it was a little faster than it probably should have been.

A smirk curled one side of Rio's lips, applying the tiniest amount of pressure, the force of the drumming only seeming to increase. The look on Agatha's face? Helpless in its surrender. Rio's smirk only seemed to grow, satisfied in the reception to what she was trying to do here.

Her green eyes had grown dark, her own insatiable famine seeming to rip through her. Her thumb slid up, along that hollow, until it reached Agatha's jaw. With a little bit of pressure, Rio was giving a silent demand, mostly to see if Agatha might actually comply, and she did, her head tilting back.

Rio was watching her, trying to determine what this feast was going to entail, trying to determine how, exactly, she was going to make Agatha understand just how much fucking emotion was putting her at critical mass.

It wasn't just the physical attraction; it had always been a plus, but none of what they had built was solely physical. It was the camaraderie that had been formed between them, the way that throughout every single minute of their time together, it had always been about mutual respect. From that very first intimate moment in that hotel room, it had always been about consent, about knowing there was still power in that.

Agatha had put those guidelines down right out of the gate, and it was one of the reasons that had presented a bit of a confirmation bias that led Rio to realizing just how fast -- and hard -- she had been falling.

And there they stood, five weeks into their relationship, and they were fucking engaged.

You're My Excuse To Travel

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

If you still want me to be there
Oh, I'd be there in a minute.

*****

There was something so beautiful about the weight of reverence that had settled above the two of them there, completely naked and covered in sweat. It was like a comforting blanket, something meant to keep them secured, so close to one another.

Their phones had been ringing on and off for the last ten minutes, oscillating between Rio's, then Agatha's. It was an invisible game of table tennis, this back and forth until all three children probably realized that they weren't going to get an answer, and that the likelihood of that being for nefarious reasons was slim to none.

The feeling of laying, bare back pressed to that cool marble countertop, with Agatha stuck to her side with her head on Rio's chest? In their home? On the night of their engagement?

There was nothing better.

Rio was completely and entirely convinced that there was no way that their lives could possibly get any better.

Two Months Ago Rio would have keeled over at the mere mention of feeling any type of connection with another human being that would impel her to make the decision to commit, to promise to spend every bit of the rest of their lives together. She would have been struck stupid with such an idea.

But that was because Two Months Ago Rio was the same Rio who had not ever actually been able to process her trauma. She had kept going, yes, but she had done it by telling herself it was the only thing that could be done. She hadn't actually spent any time learning how to cope with what had happened to her, or how her entire world had changed as a result. She had just learned to live with it.

She wouldn't have changed a thing, but there had also been no way in Hell that Two Months Ago Rio could have ever had any vision of what the last month and a half had looked like through her eyes. The bridge. The wine. The dryer. The documentary. The nameless goodbye.

They'd stung, for reasons she never could have started to understand at the time. Maybe, even now, there's weren't answers so much as there were hopeful theories that they gripped tight like the chains of a swing, life blowing by them in their new back and forth. These decisions they were making, they were big ones, but to Rio? It felt as simple as choosing what type of wine to unwind with at the end of the day.

To Rio, even the big choices were easy when the person making them with her was Agatha.

With an ease that came with an act like breathing, Agatha had impressed this ideology, directly into Rio's chest, that the world held for them whatever they were willing to take.

It wasn't about money, it wasn't even about anything material at all. But it was something that rang true to not only who they had become as a couple, but who they had all become as a family.

She could pinpoint more than a few instances in which that faith seemed to bloom, reaching toward the light it was being offered.

One: Nicky. He had been so angry that first night, the way he had shouted at Agatha, leaving Rio in that kitchen torn between knowing her place and wanting to put him in his over his amount of disrespect. It had stirred this sense of protectiveness within her, one that had usually only been reserved for Estee. It had made her want to defend Agatha, her own name be damned. That first night, she really couldn't have cared a bit less what he had thought of her, and while it had taken a couple of days? He had come around, of his own volition. He had been willing to take the risk of showing up and facing whatever that might have held.

Two: Estee. There were so many facets of Rio's relationship with her daughter that she knew some people just could never understand. Estee had always been her biggest fan, even if through her own bias, but she had never lacked in her ability to give Rio a very vivid reminder that life was worth living. Once this whole thing had begun, though? If it weren't for Estee taking the risk of challenging Rio's narrow view of the situation? Well, it was a surefire thing that she would not be reveling in her post-orgasmic haze with the love of her life against her side.

Three: Taylah. Rio had always held a place in her heart for the girl that had become her daughter's best friend the moment they had met. They had been conjoined at the hip most of their lives, and while Rio had tried not to impose her own hopes on any expectation toward their relationship, the way they had loved one another before they had loved one another? It was moving in its own right. She had watched those girls go through so much together, and when it came down to crunch time, and the death bell started to hum? They both hit that realization that they were so used to the idea of one another that they no longer wanted uncertainty between them that it was what they needed, moving forward. Taylah had taken the risk to fall into the only home she'd ever known.

Four: Agatha. While there was an incredibly long list of moments Rio could find when it came to her, there was one that stuck out, that seemed to level out a bit higher than the others. Rio could still hear the crisp smack of plastic on polished wood as Agatha had snapped that pen down onto the bar top. And then, it felt like slow motion. It felt like watching through water as Agatha had straightened up, taking a singular step to the side so that she was able to entirely put herself, as a wall, between Rio and someone who had injured her far beyond the meaning of the word. All of that only after making sure that the kids were as far away from the situation as possible. Rio hadn't even seen it, the way he had reached for her. His hand never made it past the edge of Agatha's arm in her view. Agatha had taken the risk of punching a man in the middle of a busy restaurant to protect the woman she loved.

Five: Rio, herself. Of all the risks she'd taken up to that point, she knew what it was for her. It was that moment, in the hotel room. The one where Agatha had sauntered off into the bathroom to take a shower and Rio had stood there, literally planted in her indecision. She had been so terrified, but of what? At the time, it had literally been decades since she had chosen to be intimate with another person. She had been a teenager. She was a grown woman, months away from her fortieth birthday, and she had been nervous. She'd almost let it win, too. But once she'd stepped into that shower? Never in her wildest dreams could she have ever managed such an overwhelming display of nothing but affection and adoration, a tender care shown to the shell that housed who she truly was.

Rio had taken the risk of leaping.

Agatha had been right there to catch her.

Who needed religion when you had a faith like that?

The first sound in several minutes -- a low grumble from Agatha -- hit the air around them and Rio's lips were instantly curled into a smile, blowing a soft huff of a chuckle through her nose.

"You doin' alright down there, my love?" she murmured as she turned again to nuzzle into Agatha's hairline.

"Oh, me? I'm splendid," she crooned back, that soft edge of warmth coating her words.

Another moment of silence passed, but then Rio was on the move. She shifted a little, much to Agatha's chagrin -- that she made apparent by the low whine she let out -- but then gave a gentle nudge to her shoulder, as if asking her to move. She complied, rolling to her back, though Rio could see the shiver that coursed through her at the feeling of her warm skin on the cold marble.

With no hesitation, Rio was swift in her movements as she swung a leg over and straddled Agatha's hips, to which she whined again.

"Rioooo, I'm tired," she managed, though Rio's smile was instant.

"Relax, my love. I'm just..." That smile, it melted into something a little more tender, a little more loving. It wasn't the first time she'd said it that night, but that didn't meant it was any less genuine. "Admiring the view."

At this, Agatha's eyes opened directly into hers, and the arch of her brow indicated that she was intrigued.

"Yeah? And what's it look like from up there?" she posed back, and Rio heard it, the coyness in her voice, but this one time she couldn't engage. Her honest won out.

"It sort of looks like the rest of my life," Rio told her, and while her voice was soft, there was a clear intention in the words she had chosen. She meant them.

In a movement that, admittedly, caught Rio off guard, Agatha sat up, raising a hand to cradle the side of her face. She wasted not even a breath before their lips were pressed together, a kiss that quickly overfilled Rio's state with every ounce of love that was poured into her. This was really what she got to have, because she'd made that choice. She could leap, time and time again, and if Agatha wasn't there to catch her? It was only because they were holding hands on the way down.

Rio's hands had landed on her chest in the midst of motion, and as her finger twitched just slightly, she felt it -- that raised patch of skin. She could remember explicitly tucking that away for later, and somehow it had escaped her. Maybe it was because she had gotten so used to Agatha's body so quickly that she had not really thought about it again; it was just a part of who she was.

Right then, though, it felt like a better time to ask than the first chance she'd had.

She backed away only far enough that she could look down at it. Her eyes studied the tips of her fingers as they traced over the scar that was about an inch and a half long and barely a pinch wide. If Rio didn't know any better, she would have said --

No, the only way to know was to ask.

"How did you get that?" she posed, pressing her fingertips over the entirety of it.

Rio wasn't looking at her, but it took Agatha everything within her own power to not crumble. An uneven breath released from both nostrils, but she managed to otherwise maintain her composure, for the moment.

"That answer requires a bit of a prelude," Agatha divulged, and though her voice was still soft, Rio could hear the strain in it. Her hand moved, sliding up to cradle Agatha's cheek, her thumb picking up that automatic action of brushing beneath her eye. She gave a gentle nod, a silent encouragement to move at her own pace.

"When my mother was pregnant with me, I had a twin. Her first couple appointments, everything looked good. And then, one time she went in and... it was just me." Agatha's normally well crafted exterior was beginning to crack, right in front of Rio's eyes. "It's called Vanishing Twin Syndrome. I... I basically absorbed him in the womb. It... I..."

Rio was completely still, entirely devoid of movement outside of the light caress of her thumb. She was feeling beneath her touch, the more that exterior cracked, and she could see it in Agatha's eyes, too. She'd seen Agatha upset a handful of times, but this... This was trauma.

This was something Rio could relate to.

And something, Rio realized, that Agatha had always been able to relate to, too.

Seeing that look on her face, almost like she were reliving it all over again? Rio suddenly understood exactly how Agatha had felt when they'd managed to get out of that restaurant. Right then, Rio would have done absolutely anything in the world she could have to make it so that Agatha never had to look like that again for as long as she lived.

Agatha took in a steadying breath, though those cracks were growing, and the dam was well on its way to bursting. She tried, as hard as she could, to smooth it out, to try and push it back into place, but Rio simply leaned forward, placing her lips to the space between her eyebrows, leaving them there for a long few seconds.

That seemed to do it, even though it had not been Rio's intention.

Agatha's body offered the slightest tremble, at first, but Rio didn't move. And then, that sound came.

It was a sound that, honestly? Rio would have been perfectly fine with never hearing again the rest of her life. It was a choked, anguished sob that -- if she had to guess -- Agatha had been holding in for the majority of her life.

Without much thought to it, Rio's hand moved, sliding around to cradle the back of Agatha's head as she pulled her in to an embrace with the other arm. She held her like that, letting her release every bit of what she hadn't been able to let go of for so long. More than that, Rio was pulling it out of her, and pulling it into herself. For every moment that passed that Agatha was in her arms, she could feel it. She could literally feel the tension fading at the realization that she was in a safe place, being held by someone who wouldn't let what she had to say effect anything in regards to her feelings.

After another couple of minutes, she could tell that Agatha had stopped crying, but she didn't move her cheek from the skin of Rio's chest as she started speaking again.

"She held it against me... my whole life. It was always an insult of no matter how well I did, he could have done better. She's... a psychopath, honestly. Very old-world ideology. So, because I murdered her precious son in the womb? Well, she had a very clear desire to keep it tit for tat, but couldn't stand the thought of going to prison."

Rio's hand, as it was wrapped around her, began a gentle motion of rubbing at Agatha's arm, trying to soothe her, but also to show that she was there, right there, to catch her as she was falling through those memories.

Rio wouldn't let her fall, either.

"My seventeenth birthday, one of my friends snuck in my room. She brought some shitty handle of gas station vodka and we drank and made out and talked and laughed. Well, we woke her up and when she barged in and saw us laying together?"

Rio could feel against her chest right where Agatha squeezed her eyes shut. Her own hold tightened around Agatha, her presence saying all that it could, in the loudest possible way.

"Lizzie ran out, but that just left me there alone to deal with her. We had a pretty awful back and forth, but awful in that I finally told her where she could take her moral righteousness and shove it. We had somehow ended up in the kitchen, and I didn't even realize it until after the fact. She'd grabbed a butcher knife and had literally fucking stabbed me. It wasn't deep, and didn't hit anything important... but... What do you do when you're seventeen years old and your mother finally tries to kill you?"

Agatha trembled softly again in Rio's arms, but her hold did not loosen, even a little.

"It's... it's not like I didn't know she wanted to do it. I just... never gave her the credit that she was that insane to actually try. So... I left. I stayed on couches of friends whose parents took pity on me. I graduated, I got accepted to AFI, and I ran as far away from her as I could."

Agatha drew in an even breath, most of the emotion seeming to have washed out from the moment. While she'd known it was a necessary evil, having to hear Agatha talk about her own life like that had really wounded something in Rio, but on Agatha's behalf. How could this woman, this complete enigma of an incredible woman, have ever been treated so poorly by the one person that had brought her into the world?

Nicky had tried to shed light on it, that day in Estee's kitchen, but Rio was realizing that even he probably did not understand the gravity of just how awful it really was.

"But... I still let her voice in the back of my head tell me how to live, for a very long time. I knew before I was out of middle school that boys were of no interest to me. But... after I landed in LA, I still tried to live my life by some well-adjusted version of her code, not realizing that it was the whole problem itself. So, I did what I though was right of me to do. I found a husband, I had a child. And... Colton was never bad to me, but I was never happy. And then Nicky got older, and the older he got, the more it seemed like nothing I did was the right thing to do. So then I chose to do wrong things because I was indignant in the fact that nothing I tried to do right ever actually landed that way."

Agatha sniffed, and as another tear hit Rio's skin, her heart tightened in her chest, but she remained quiet, sensing that Agatha was not quite done.

"I drowned myself in making movies. I poured so much of my time into it that, even though I was dragging him with me, I wasn't considering how it was effecting my son. I poured myself into the only art form I've ever known, but I forgot about filling the other cups around me, too."

Slowly, Agatha began to shift, and immediately Rio recognized that it was because she wanted to look her in the eyes as she continued.

"A month before I started the project that brought me here, I got a phone call that Colton was in a coma after an accident. I... still haven't told Nicky, but I know how he feels about Colton's choice to walk away from him, whether it was because of me or not. And so, I threw myself into it, completely and wholly."

Rio could feel it, the emotion building in her own middle, causing her eyes to glass over with the threat of tears.

"I had been in meetings all morning, and I had called Wanda to see if she would be able to make our nightly FaceTime drinks. Truthfully, I had been a little upset about how the meeting had gone, but mostly because of one of the assholes that was in the room. It had been bothering me, clearly enough that I wasn't aware of my environment."

Agatha's lips turned up in a smile, though it was a sad one.

"Then again, that was the first time I felt like that. But it hasn't been the last. Because... when I'm with you? Hardly ever do I have any environmental awareness. You're the only light on in any given space. And I... I keep trying to figure it out. How... how you've suffered for so long, and yet? You are the sun, every bit of its warmth and light, never hidden behind cloud cover. Ever present, whenever I need you."

The tears had started spilling down Rio's cheeks far beyond her own awareness and a surprising sob choked from between her lips.

She held Agatha's face between both hands, but she did not kiss her. Instead, she leaned forward and pressed their foreheads together, just sitting there as the silent tears streamed down both of their cheeks.

Rio had never even considered the possibility that someone could speak to her like that, that someone in the world would ever find it in them to string those words together when they were speaking about her.

In that exact moment, Rio realized her own power.

Agatha could say those things to her only because Rio had given her a reason. She had showed up for Agatha when it was impractical and insane. She had taken time off work, put herself on a plane and crossed an entire ocean with the smallest hope that they might see one another again.

By choosing Agatha, she had fundamentally reached into every bit of Agatha's internal processing and ripped out every single wire, stating loudly that she was the only person with the knowledge to put the connectors back in the correct places, not the ones they had been in for far too long. Life had wired Agatha to bare teeth, to wield her power. Rio could make it so that she still could, but that she didn't always have to.

Rio wasn't trying to change who Agatha was as a person, but she would see to it that she would change the way Agatha saw herself.

"You are everything to me, Agatha Harkness," Rio breathed at her, though her eyes were still shut and their foreheads were still pressed. "You have changed me, forever, and you have shown me that sometimes, even in the meaningless chaos, there's still light. There's still reason."

Rio's face shifted slightly so that she could press their lips together in the most unassumingly tender kiss.

"You are my reason, Rio."

The words breathed against Rio's lips truly caught her off guard, but she felt them in every single inch of her body.

While the pleasurable come-down had been one thing, this emotional one?

The two of them had sat like that on that countertop for at least twenty more minutes, Rio holding Agatha who had tucked herself back into Rio's chest.

By the time they lowered themselves back to the floor, Rio located her phone, noting that it was a little after two in the morning. As they dressed, she had picked the keys up off the floor and stepped into Agatha, who had just finished pulling her shirt over her head. She'd given her a soft kiss and spent all of ninety seconds convincing her to let Rio to be the one to drive home, which eventually worked.

When they got back to the houseboat, most of the lights were off, but that little television they had moved to the front room was on when they opened the door. The moving images illuminated the form of an asleep Nicky on the couch, his hiked leg hanging off the edge.

Hm, Rio mused internally with the smallest warmth pooling in her chest. Just like his mother.

She had let Agatha go long enough so that she could place a kiss to her son's head and took the time herself to make her way to Estee's door, peering in to see the girls cuddled up, asleep.

As she and Agatha showered quickly and climbed into bed, Rio's legs were instant to tangle in Agatha's, getting as close as she could.

The quiet surrounded them, and even though she wasn't sure if Agatha was asleep or not, Rio still found her voice, her eyes never leaving the shadowy features she had fallen so in love with.

"I'm really glad that today was the first day of the rest of our lives."

Just enough silence had passed that Rio's eyes slid closed, ready for sleep.

But then, as soft as the beat of an owl's wings in the night:

"Me too."

*****

The sun was not even up, and Agatha's phone was ringing. Rio let out an annoyed grunt, though it wasn't directed at Agatha. Whoever was calling her, though? Rio could have given them a hefty slap over the head.

The ringing stopped and Rio pulled herself closer to Agatha's form for the comfort it would offer in allowing her to go back to sleep, but it rang again.

Agatha shifted, a tired arm flailing as she slapped around for her phone. She forced one eye open, seeing who it was. She let out an irritated growl, though she answered the phone.

"What the fuck do you want, Dave? It's not even 6am."

Rio wasn't paying much attention, instead losing herself in Agatha's warm skin.

"What the fuck do you mean I've been served?" she spat back, though there was more volume, and more irritation brimming in her voice. "Open it!"

This alerted Rio, who picked her head up off of Agatha's chest, looking down at her as she listened to the man on the phone.

"I don't give a shit that it's a federal crime, Dave, fucking open it."

Another pause as the man did as he was instructed. Rio could hear the faint murmur of his voice, but she couldn't tell what he was saying. Agatha's eyes flew open and her skin blanched.

"My mother..." Agatha hissed into the phone, her voice thick with venom. "Is suing me for emotional distress?"

And, with all of the force of a ten-ton anvil, every bit of their peaceful morning had just completely shattered. Or... So Rio had thought.

She watched as the notion was being processed behind those blue eyes, as she actually digested what that meant.

And then?

Then Agatha laughed. She really, truly laughed. It was a laugh that Rio was almost certain would wake the rest of the house up if it continued too long in its duration.

"You know what, Dave? Track her down, personally deliver the message that I'd love to see her in court."

And with that, Agatha hung up the phone, tossing it aside as if it were the most unimportant thing in her life at the given moment. The arm that had been secured around Rio's shoulders pulled her closer.

"Mmm, fuck her," Agatha hummed, giving Rio's form a gentle squeeze.

"Yeah, fuck her."

Chapter End Notes

sorry this will be the only one for today, yall. i need a little break for the night. <3 hope you enjoyed!

Separate From You

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

I think of everything that we both went through
I'm tired of feeling separate from you.

*****

In the coming weeks, it felt to Rio as though there was more time that Agatha was on the phone than she was off of it. Rio understood it; what was unfolding in Agatha's life was not only strangely poetic, given the conversation the two of them had shared not hours before she'd gotten that call, but it was also something Rio recognized as what the universe was placing before them to see how they were going to navigate it.

Perhaps this was the first trial.

Rio couldn't have been more certain of that fact the moment Agatha came in from the deck, a somber look on her face like she had news that she wasn't ready to deliver, and it made Rio's stomach sink.

Most of the things that they were going to be moving to the new house had been packed throughout the passing week and boxes sat, stacked in random spots throughout Rio's houseboat. It stirred something in her that she wasn't quite sure how to name; she wasn't selling it. No, that wasn't an option. No matter what happened, it was hers... No, it was theirs. It would always be a place that they could tuck away when the need for the water became a little overwhelming.

The thought struck her; Rio had gone from having that houseboat, her whole world, as her one and only home. And now... now she had three places that she was going to be able to call home. Really, though, home simply was no longer a place.

Agatha was home.

Still, that look on her face right then as she appeared in the living room didn't have anything positive attached to it.

The girls had taken Nicky out to dinner for the evening and truthfully, it had excited both Agatha and Rio that they were all falling into this ease of just wanting to spend time with each other. While she'd not been worried about Estee or Tay, Nicky had been an only child who had rarely gotten the attention from his mother. Rio thought it reasonable to be nervous that he might have some feelings about her now giving some of that attention to three other people.

Pleasantly, she had been surprised, and she was going to be a little thankful that the three of them weren't around for the conversation that it looked like Agatha needed to have with her.

Rio's eyes lifted to her as she placed herself on the couch next to Rio, not hesitating to pick up her hand, though she didn't immediately dive into the conversation. Instead, Rio couldn't wait for her to gather her nerve.

"What's going on, my love?" she posed, giving Agatha's hand a squeeze before she covered it with her other one.

Agatha's lips pressed together, but she still wasn't looking at Rio, even when she found her voice.

"I have to go back to LA."

Even though she had known this was inevitable, something about hearing it out loud caused Rio's heart to bottom out into her stomach, decaying quickly from the acids there. It was this feeling that she had been anticipating, but the punch it packed was a little more debilitating that she had been able to predict.

Rio swallowed down the rock in her throat, squeezing Agatha's hand again.

"Do you have to go alone?"

As Agatha's gaze lifted and their eyes met, that sinking feeling only got worse, as if Rio knew that she was going to say before she said it.

"It's better if I do. I have to be physically present to file a countersuit, and if for whatever god forsaken reason she's anywhere close by, I... I just don't want you near her. I don't care about what she says about me... But if she were to talk to you like that?" Agatha breathed a dry huff, her lips pressing together in a hard line. "Well, I'd lose my career and spend the rest of my life in prison. Which, as much fun as I'm sure conjugal visits could be, I'd prefer to not have scheduled times I get to see you naked."

At this, Rio couldn't fight her own breathy chuckle.

Agatha shifted, scooting down a little so that she could lay her head on Rio's shoulder. Automatically, Rio's head tilted to rest atop it.

"I... I know it's not fair to ask you to stay. But... I really do hope you understand that I'm doing it to protect you. And... I think once she sees the countersuit, she'll quit playing her bullshit games. It's been thirty fucking years. Plus, if she keeps pushing, I can't get her on abuse because of the statutes, but I can clearly prove the claim right back. And I have physical proof." She took in a breath, her thumb brushing over Rio's knuckles. "I'm hoping that it'll only be a few days, but it could realistically, if she does try to see this out, be a couple of weeks."

Although it made her sad, and she didn't want this to be something they had to face yet, Rio still understood it. She got that this was something Agatha had to face on her own, and she appreciated that even in a tough decision, Agatha was still taking Rio's feelings into consideration.

"I'll be okay. I have the girls." She paused, her gaze shifting to the corners of her eyes for just a moment while she considered how she wanted to say what was on the tip of her tongue. "And Nicky is more than welcome to stay, if he wants."

She could almost feel it, although Rio couldn't see it by the way they were situated. Agatha's face softened, and then a moment later, her posture did too. She seemed to just melt right into Rio's side, and it was something that she already knew she was going to miss.

It had been unrealistic to think that this day might never come, but hadn't most of their entire relationship been rather unrealistic, when it came down to it?

"You know you don't have to do that," Agatha murmured softly, her thumb still keeping its gentle pace over Rio's knuckles. "You don't have to feel obligated. I'm sure he'd be fine to go back to Dubai."

"Shh," Rio hushed her, turning her head so that she could place her lips to the crown of Agatha's. "I know I don't have to, but... they're getting on like a house on fire, and if he wants to stay, the option is there. Plus, who else is going to help me move these boxes over to the new house?"

This caused a gentle shake of laughter to take over Agatha.

"You're right, he is pretty useful for manual labor."

Rio pressed another kiss to the top of Agatha's head before she removed the contact, straightening up. She was quiet for a moment, trapped in pensive thought. The silence wasn't unwelcome though, and felt rather warm over them. After another moment of thought, though, Rio spoke.

"What can I do to make this easier for you?"

She turned to look at Agatha, but she had not been expecting the bewildered look she was receiving the moment their eyes met. A slight blush crept onto her cheeks from sheer embarrassment, even though she knew that there was really nothing to be embarrassed about. It was a genuine question, but it just seemed to have caught Agatha completely off guard.

"I'm telling you that you have to stay here when we both know it's the last thing you want... and you're asking how you can make it easier on me?" The question wasn't sharp, but Agatha's disbelief was thick in her tone.

For a brief second, the thought made Rio sad. It wasn't a huge deal, at least not to her. However, Agatha seemed to be completely verklempt by the offer. Was it because no one had ever cared enough to ask her that question before? Was it because she was so used to people only needing her for what they wanted that it was so hard to believe someone would actually want to help in a tough time?

Sure, she was leaving. Rio knew, though, that she was not doing it by choice. More than that, Rio knew she would come back, or that she herself would go to Agatha when the waters were a little calmer. It wasn't an easy path to trek, but they were going to find their way somehow.

"Of course I am," Rio stated simply, as though it were literally the most obvious thing in the world. "Because I love you."

Agatha's nervous expression seemed to dissolve the moment Rio's words touched her ears. It was clear she had been worried, and it was even more clear that this was one of the hardest things she'd had to do in quite sometime.

Rio could have played it off, said that Agatha just wasn't ready to face her mother, but Rio knew the truth, no matter how conceited it sounded:

Rio was Agatha's comfort person, and they'd been together for nearly a solid two months, since the day Rio had turned up at Agatha's office. This was the first time, in two months, that she was going to have to navigate a very difficult situation without Rio by her side, and she was very obviously having a difficult time handling that.

Rio lifted the hand that had been covering Agatha's and reached up, brushing her cheek lovingly with the backs of her knuckles.

"You know you can always call me. Hell, you can put me in an AirPod and do whatever you need to do, and I will sit in that very big office in that very big house while I work and just be there. If you need me to say something, or to talk to you, I will, but... I can still find ways to be with you when I'm not with you."

Agatha's throat tightened visibly toward the front of her neck, and Rio knew that she was just piling on the endless heap of things that Agatha had probably convinced herself she would never hear from the lips of another human being.

"I love you, Agatha, and I know you know this. What I don't think you know is what that means." Rio turned her hand, instead moving it to cradle Agatha's cheek in her palm. "What that means is that I'm going to always want to contribute to your quality of life. What that means is that when you cry, I don't judge you for it. When you're angry, I validate your feelings. When you're confused, we work toward an answer together. That's what I mean when I tell you that I love you. It's just a lot less to say," Rio added, her lips hiking up just enough at the corners to prove a warm smile.

"So, if you have to ride off into battle against your biggest foe, and I can't be there as back-up, then I'll be here as back-up instead. Point being, you still don't have to be alone, even if you're not right here with me."

Rio had been waiting; she'd watched them build, creating a glassy film over those blue eyes. Then, they had started to pool on the edges of her lids. As Rio finished speaking, though, Agatha blinked and the tears rolled down her cheeks, the one on her left side catching a roadblock in the form of Rio's hand.

Instantly, Rio was wiping it away with the pad of her thumb.

"There's that optimism again," Agatha murmured at her, turning her face into Rio's palm to place a light kiss against the flesh there.

"Endlessly annoying, hm?" she shot back, raising a playful eyebrow.

For as resolute as she was being in this, Rio was scared, too. She had never known space like that between them since they'd been reunited, and the idea of being without Agatha, even though she knew she was still going to be loved and taken care of, it was one that brought with it a wave of anxiety.

As if listening in, Agatha spoke.

"You don't have to do that when it's just us," she whispered, and Rio felt the sudden pang of familiarity in her chest. She'd heard those words before, but she had been the one saying them.

She felt like Agatha was looking straight through her, but she tried to fortify that facade as quickly as she could.

"I don't know what you're talking about." Rio's head turned and her eyes dropped to the floor, an immediate tell that she didn't want to have the conversation Agatha was trying to open the door to.

"Rio, baby," Agatha crooned at her, reaching across her own body to gently hook Rio's chin into the crook of a curved finger. There was a brief moment where Rio tried to fight it, but she knew it was no use. Slumping, her head turned and she took in the sight of Agatha who looked like she wanted to burst into tears right along with her.

"I don't want to talk about it. Because I don't want you to feel guilty in any way. You're doing the right thing, and nothing I say will contribute to that way of thinking. Because..." Rio stopped herself, pressing her lips together. "Because selfishly, I hate this. I understand it, and I know you're protecting me, but I still hate it."

Rio choked back her own tears, stuffing them down. She wasn't going to make this any harder on Agatha than she already was, but she knew that trying to hide her feelings would only wind up hurting Agatha more.

"I hate that I have to sit here while you're six thousand miles away, going toe to toe with a woman who literally tried to kill you. I know she wouldn't dare try now, but..." She took a breath, her lips worrying together for a moment before she found her voice again. "This whole thing is a farce. It's a way for her to assert that she still has some form of control over your life, and I hate her for it. You deserve better, and you made better for yourself for thirty years." Her voice had gained a little bit of strength, and it almost felt like she was a teenager again, trying to barter with her papa for something she did not want to give up. "It's not fair that she just gets to march in and try to take it."

She had still somehow managed to get through that entire little speech without shedding a single tear, but judging by the way Agatha was looking at her? Her efforts had to be painfully obvious.

"Listen," Agatha said back a little stronger, though her voice was still so very soft. "I'm not worried about this, or about her. I'll take a member of security with me to my lawyer's office."

Agatha blew a soft breath out, though there was a little force behind it. "She can't get to me at home, so when I'm not cleaning up this absolute shitshow, I'll be there. And I'll be on my laptop with your face across my screen as often as I can."

Rio's lips twitched, the discomfort still heavy in her bones. She knew that Agatha was a grown woman, that she could take care of herself... But Rio liked taking care of Agatha.

With the gentlest show of force, Agatha pulled Rio closer by her chin, placing a soft kiss across her lips. She didn't try to further it, didn't try to push. It was just the most undemanding display of love, of adoration, and it was moving mountains within Rio's chest.

This was hard, and it was something that she was sure to complain about the entire time. She knew, though, that with the help of their children, it could at least be bearable. Rio knew that in her mind, she'd already gauged what Nicky's response was going to be; even if Rio wasn't the reason he chose to stay, she was almost confident he still would.

Estee and Tay? They'd always had each other.

Nicky had always been an only child.

It was his first time getting to spend time with people who treated him like an equal in the situation they'd all found themselves in. He'd already made it clear on quite a few occasions that the time difference made it easier for him to work, and that he quite enjoyed getting out of the Dubai heat. They were just little things, little ways for him to say that he wasn't ready to leave without him actually having to say it.

Rio saw it, even if she didn't acknowledge it. She wouldn't ever box him in, but in the moments when he would say something goofy and Estee would ruffle his hair? It turned every drop of Rio's blood to magma, heating her from her middle out. They acted like siblings. They acted like this had been something they'd known their whole lives, even having grown up on two different ends of the world.

So, no. Rio was not worried that Nicky was going to hightail it the other direction when they had this conversation with the three of them.

As their lips parted, Rio tipped her head, her forehead landing just below Agatha's right eye as she heaved a frustrated sigh, though she tried to temper its severity. This wasn't Agatha's fault, and Rio didn't blame her, but she also would have done anything to see to it that this could happen differently.

She felt like a clingy child, but there was perhaps an underlying fear there that she was having a difficult time letting herself acknowledge.

The last time Rio had been alone, she had not been a fulfilled person. She'd had her purpose, had her reason in those two young woman she loved so dearly, but she had been so... alone. She had been numb to the idea of companionship. She found the idea of commitment laughable.

So, then, how was it going to feel when she was alone and none of that was true anymore?

Would she be able to handle an entirely new heartache of having to kiss Agatha goodbye for a yet undetermined amount of time? What was it going to feel like when, until the furniture arrived for the new house, she had to curl up in that bed on that houseboat alone, the smell of lilac and vanilla still in the pillows?

Rio knew it was useless to get caught up in the what-ifs, but she had never put herself in this position, and it was hard trying to determine how to navigate something that was so utterly unknown. She didn't know where she'd be able to find footing, but she had to stop thinking she couldn't. She wouldn't put that kind of guilt onto Agatha, she couldn't.

"Can I just say..." Rio whined, lifting her head to meet Agatha's gaze with her own panicked but warmed one. "...one last time, that I really, really hate it?"

Agatha raised a hand, two fingers skimming along Rio's temple as she pushed her hair back, tucking a piece of it behind her ear. Those two fingers brushed over Rio's ear and pushed further, tangling into her dark locks. Agatha leaned forward, placing her lips to Rio's hairline just behind her right temple. And then, an inch over along the guideline of that hairline, she would place another, and another.

Much in a back and forth sweep, Agatha was literally kissing every inch of Rio's face she could get to, side to side and over again. By the time Agatha had made it most of the way down her cheeks, the tears had started to slip through closed eyelids. She knew what Agatha was doing: She was making a memory. She was giving Rio something to hold onto in the coming weeks.

She was making a mark.

As she reached the corner of Rio's mouth, she couldn't stay still, or wait another moment. Her head turned, catching Agatha's lips between her own fully.

There had been too many times to count that they had kissed.

None of them felt quite like that one, though.

This one was... desperate, but not in the way that they could hardly contain themselves. No, this desperation felt like a pit, like a very deep and very empty well. It was a dire need to say what no words ever could. It was a pouring of every bit of angst she was feeling over the entire situation. Rio knew that she needed to get a grip, that she needed to conduct herself a little bit better. How could she?

The Rio that sat there kissing Agatha like she needed to steal as much of her as she could to cling to in her absence had learned so much about herself in a mere two months. She had learned that it was okay to be spontaneous, that it was okay to do something uncomfortable because the end result was more than worth it.

Agatha had taught Rio that she'd always been her own goddess, she'd just needed someone to hold up a mirror in front of her so she could see it clearly.

Rio knew that she could not wonder about what it would be like when Agatha wasn't there to hold that reflection up. Instead, she had to take hold of the mirror.

As Agatha pulled their lips apart, there was no doubt in in Rio's mind that she was aware of the tears still spilling down her cheeks, especially gauging by her reaction. Agatha released all holds, but then slid one arm behind Rio's back and the other beneath her knees, using that incredible strength to lift Rio into her lap, tucking her into every bit of overhang she could manage.

It was funny, Rio thought. It almost felt like the compression of an anxiety blanket.

And it was working.

This moment was going to end. They were going to share their last meals together, and she was going to watch as Agatha walked away from her to get on a plane.

These were all facts.

But what she felt right then, with every bit of Agatha applying every bit of pressure she could, as if she would doing everything she could to hold Rio together?

What Rio felt was resolved.

If this was what she got at the end of their time apart?

It would be worth it.

Rio had let herself be held like that for over ten minutes, finally finding it within herself to force movement. Agatha's hold loosened, but she didn't let her go completely. She looked down at those breathtaking blue eyes and raised a hand, tracing the lightest line down the middle of Agatha's nose.

"We're going to be okay," Rio voiced, placing the tip of her index finger to Agatha's lips, which puckered in response.

"I know we are, baby. You just have know it too."

*****

The conversation with the kids had gone over as well as had been expected. None of them were thrilled but they all understood. But when Agatha had offered Nicky the option of joining her, going back to Dubai, or staying with the Vidals?

The ease with which the decision had come almost stole Rio's breath. He had been listening to the first two options with a dissatisfied downturn of his lips, but when presented with the third? His immediate focus shifted to Estee and Tay, as if to ask them if they would be okay if he chose that option. When he was met with shit-eating grins? His head whipped back to Rio, his green eyes wide with his question.

She had nodded her head and he had been so excited that it was almost infectious. He'd spent almost the rest of the night with a huge smile plastered to his face, and it touched something deep inside of Rio. He'd chosen to stay. Sure, he had his own reasons, but for Rio?

For Rio, Nicky was the piece of Agatha she would get to hold onto.

When they woke the next morning, Agatha had an email from Dave that contained her tickets and itinerary for her flight that was due to depart that afternoon, and it had all become even more real.

Rio had clung to that resolve, though. She knew that she could get through this, because she had their kids. She had those three beautiful, bright, incredible kids, and they were going to get her through this. She had not a single doubt about that.

They'd spent most of the day in bed, a little more than thankful that the kids had taken the hint and decided to go out for a bit. With Estee in therapy, her mobility had been improving and so they had declared they were going to spend some time at the beach.

For Rio and Agatha, it was their last chance to feel that physical closeness. That morning had been filled with nothing but love, but passion and affection. It was warm skin, soft laughs all wrapped up in a tangle of sheets.

They had gotten out of bed to shower and Rio had helped Agatha with packing her things, offering things she knew Agatha would otherwise forget.

Walking into that airport, hand in hand, had Rio on the verge of throwing up. She asserted again to herself that this was something she was capable of doing, that it was something she knew she could do but only because she had to. It was currently the absolute bane of her existence, but it was going to be alright, with time.

They reached the partitioned off part of the TSA line and stopped, turning to face one another. Immediately, Agatha let go of her suitcase and pulled Rio into her arms in one of the strongest hugs Rio had ever gotten from her. And then, like a whisper in the night, she could hear it.

We've got this.

It was Agatha's voice in the back of her head, and it rang with certainty.

They clung like that for as long as Agatha's impending flight would allow, finally pulling apart despite the fact that it was the last thing either of them wanted.

With minimal space between them, Agatha's hand raised and cradled Rio's jaw with ease, pulling her in for an urgent but tender kiss.

Their lips parted, foreheads pressed together, and Agatha's whisper landed somewhere in the middle of Rio's chest.

"I love you more than you know. Any time you doubt that, you give me a call, okay?"

Another stolen peck.

A sad, soft chuckle.

"I plan to be in your ear always. I... I love you too, Agatha. And... I'm really going to miss you."

Agatha's smile was gentle, but it was also reassuring.

"I know, because I'm going to miss you, too. But... I can think of at least three people who are going to make it easier on you, if you let them."

"You're stalling, Agatha."

"I am."

Agatha gave one more gentle tug on Rio's jaw, placing their lips together in one kiss that hummed with a sense of finality, no matter how much Rio hated it.

"I love you, Rio. I'll message you as soon as I land."

Rio drew in a slow breath, willing back the sting in her eyes.

"I love you too, Agatha. Be careful. And... call whenever you need."

"You can count on it."

Agatha stole one last peck, and though she turned and began her journey back to America, Rio had not missed the anguish in her eyes for that one brief moment, and she did everything she could not to let it sink her like a stone.

It was going to be okay.

It had to be okay.

Chapter End Notes

with the decision made that this is its own beast entirely and will go where it goes, i'd like to place something here that i had intended to save for the end of the story.

i want to dedicate this work to my best friend, alyssa. this story absolutely never would have been possible without her and her countless hours of helping me world build.
she and i live on opposite sides of the country and have for our entire friendship, but we have never stopped creating in the 18 years we have known each other.
every story you will see me put out, she's helped me cultivate and has opened this avenue for me to explore not only these characters, but myself as well, in a way that i never knew i could.
i wouldnt be where i am without alyssa, and i just needed you all to know that.
<3

Favorite T-Shirt

I've been sitting here trying to figure out:
What did I do right to be with you right now?

*****

Rio knew the path to follow; it was clearly marked and had visible red 'EXIT' signs with indicative arrows dotted every so often along the walls. Rio knew where she was going. She'd done this many times with Estee. So why did it feel like such a hard path to follow? Despite keeping her faculties as she tried to get back to the garage, the acute sense of panic was very quickly welling in her chest.

Somehow, though it took her far longer than it should have, Rio reached the car and poured herself into it. Impressively, she had not let another tear fall until the moment that car door slammed shut.

Half-way into Rio's very first sob, her phone began to ring.

She sniffled, her brow knitting as she struggled a bit to get her phone out of her pocket. That crease in her forehead seemed to only deepen as she produced it to see a photo of herself and Agatha across the screen, Agatha's little profile photo, and her name. They were all three indicators that Agatha was, indeed, calling her.

Snapping out of her trance, she swiped the answer button over and nearly slammed the phone against her ear, unable to hide the anxiety in her voice as she spoke.

"Agatha!? Are you okay?"
