It was almost panicked, as if something could have gone wrong in the twenty minutes it had apparently taken her to get to the car.

"That's subjective but... Are you?"

In that moment, Rio's heart both wanted to beat out of her chest and also completely stop at the same time. Agatha's voice was warm, as always, but her question was worried. She could just hear in Rio's own voice that something was off, and Rio had never felt so seen when no one was looking at her.

"I... I'll be fine. Is everything okay? What happened?" Rio was asking questions, trying to decide what the crisis was that Agatha had called her so soon.

"Rio, Rio," came Agatha's soothing tones, only causing more tears to prick at the backs of Rio's eyes. Why did she sound so understanding?

That answer was obvious.

No one else in the world but Agatha could understand what Rio was feeling right then, because she was sitting half a mile away feeling the exact same way.

"Baby, nothing's wrong. I'm at the gate waiting. I just... couldn't get on that plane without hearing your voice up until the last minute."

Hotter and faster, the tears escalated from a stream to a heavy pour. They dropped off of the line of her jaw, dotting her olive scoop neck and chest. She knew it was stupid, she knew that she shouldn't be crying, but she was at a point where she was looking at fractured glimpses of her life and knowing that she had to put those pieces back into place if she was going to be able to keep going.

"Hey, hey... Rio, it's okay."

Rio tucked her face into her free elbow, trying to remember what it meant to take even breaths.

In for four. Hold for four. Out for four. Hold for four.

Repeat.

Agatha had been quiet, knowing what was happening on the other end of that line, but as Rio's whimpers grew quiet, Agatha's voice came over that line. It was every bit of the deliverance she had intended it to be.

"I love you. I love you. I love you. And I am already on my way to coming back, because every minute I'm gone is a minute I'm closer to seeing you again."

That logic could have been so broken, so picked apart if Rio had wanted to put any kind of effort into the act. She didn't. She wanted to hear what Agatha was telling her over what words she used. Yes, she was leaving, but every step she took toward what awaited her in Los Angeles was a step that was the beginning of the circular path she was about to take, every step a step closer to home.

"I love you too, Agatha. I'm... sorry. I'm not trying to make this harder on you, because I know that's what I'm doing. I just... thought maybe I could have a car breakdown. And bed breakdown. And shower breakdown. You know, all of that, before I got to hear your voice again."

It was soft, but she could hear Agatha's soft chuckle over the line.

"I took an Ativan the second I sat down. I am going to sleep the entire time as to avoid a very public plane breakdown, so I get it."

This made Rio relax. That poor woman was sitting alone in an airport, tossing back anti-anxiety medication to try and sedate herself enough to sleep through the misery of doing something she didn't want to do. Was it gut-wrenching? Of course. But was it also touching? Without question.

Rio was quiet for a few long moments, just listening to the bustle of the airport in the background of the line. Her lips twisted for a moment in pained thought before she found the right words.

"Do you..." she hesitated, biting roughly into her bottom lip. "Do you have anyone else in LA, besides Wanda?"

Agatha was quiet, stunned by Rio's question. It was clearly a ploy to build a support net on Rio's end, but it was a little louder than that, too.

"I mean... I could go spend time with Jack and his girlfriend, if you absolutely insisted on it in opposition to hiding in the house. They're just younger and it makes me feel so old sometimes." Agatha's voice still had this little tinge, the tiniest and sharpest edge of anxiety. Rio could almost hear the panic she had unintentionally incited by forcing Agatha into the realization that she should probably tend to her life outside of all of this in what ways she could.

"And I know if I call Wanda, she'll turn up with a handle of gin and we will drink and I will probably fight myself on not crying because some part of her still thinks I'm a giant hard-ass." Rio could hear that Agatha was using humor to deflect, and so instead of pointing that out, she just let it happen. What harm would it do to let Agatha have that outlet?

A soft sigh over crackled static.

"I just don't have any desire to be in anyone else's company. That might change, but as of right now..."

"Agatha." It was firm, even in its tenderness. "I know how you feel. But in the same way I'm going to need to throw the moments I can't have with you into time spent with our children, you need that, too." Rio took in a slow breath, wondering if she was toeing a line she shouldn't be by saying what she wanted to. "And I know you run a tight ship, and you're not fond of having friends. But... the ones you do have? Let them help."

Rio could almost hear the indignation, the utter dissatisfaction, as it bubbled up in Agatha's chest. They were so close, but so far away, and the distance was only going to grow.

Before Agatha could bring herself to words, it sounded: the boarding call.

Rio felt her throat pitch forward, but she kept herself quiet. This was hard enough as it was, on both of them, and she didn't need to go breaking both of their hearts before Agatha walked onto that plane.

"Mi amor," Rio murmured at her, and the way Agatha's breath caught was audible.

Rio had never called her that before.

"Te amo ms que a nada.

She heard the smallest sniffle over the noise of the other line, and she fought to not let it sink her. She could see the look on Agatha's face without having to look at her.

"I'll see you, my love."

This time, it was Rio's turn to try and stifle the sound that wanted to escape her. It was clear that Agatha had asked Estee what their parting exchange meant, and Estee had probably told her, all too eagerly.

Rio, somehow and somewhere not within her own body, found her resolve.

"I love you, Agatha. I'll talk to you when you land."

"I love you too, Rio."

And with the dull brrm brrm that indicated the call had been terminated, Rio stared down at her phone, which was now her wallpaper.

That wallpaper was chaos contained in a single photo.

It was the one that Nicky had taken the night they'd all gone to the lava caves on Rangitoto. They'd ended up on the beach while waiting for their ferry, and he had insisted on taking it.

He'd had the longest arms, but the way he had contorted himself to make sure everyone was visible was almost obvious in the image. His head was ducked and cocked back to the side, Tay coming around his side with Estee's mega-watt smile in the space between them. And there, behind them, were the matriarchs of their little family. They hadn't even been aware at the time that he had been taking it, and it showed. Agatha was facing the camera, but she was looking up at Rio, who was stood with her front pressed to Agatha's side.

The way they were looking at each other?

That was what artwork could be when the world happened and they weren't paying attention because what was in front of them was, at that second, the most important thing in their purview.

That photo was the essence of their family. Theirs.

Not once since the blending could Rio even recall when the terms 'my son' or 'my girls' were ever used between the two of them. It was always just... the kids.

And now, Rio was the one left to hold down the fort. She knew that out of the four of them, she was undoubtedly going to be the one who fell under the category of being most fragile, but she felt the need to show up for them, too. She felt the need to remain present, even though half of her was going to be on an entirely different continent.

Minutes passed, two turning into five and five turning into ten. By the time even that doubled? Rio knew she had to go back home, back to their children.

Finally, she managed to convince herself to start the car and drive back to the marina. She had taken a few more moments to try and build up that brave facade and, with intent, pulled in a long and slow breath, braving her way back into the house.

As she removed the key from the lock and pushed the door open, there was never any reality where she could have expected what was waiting on the other side.

Everything in the main living area had been pushed to the outskirts of the room and two mattresses were side by side on the floor, covered in a plethora of blankets and quilts that Rio knew came from the linen closet. All three kids were sat near the tops of them, their backs pressed to the front of the couch. There were bags of candy and chips (which most of were notably Rio's favorites, and some of Agatha's) and even a neatly tied bag that bore the logo of their favorite chip shop.

For the umpteenth time that day, Rio's tears were hot and streaming before she could even consider any reaction to keep them checked.

Those three beautiful souls knew what this entire situation meant, and what it was going to feel like for the two women they respectively loved in their lives. They wanted to show up for the parent they had with them.

"Y-you..." Rio forced out, though it was all that came through for a moment. "You guys did this for me?"

She had been expecting Estee to speak first, or maybe even Tay, but Nicky's voice sounded before all else.

"We thought that maybe tonight was a good night for fish n' chips, too much junk food, and... some movies." With this, Nicky's lips turned up in a sheepish manner, but Estee cut in.

"I don't know if you've ever told her, but I know that the only three films you've seen that aren't documentaries are Fried Green Tomatoes, Night Mother and Delores Claiborne." Estee raised a hand, indicating the several DVDs laying on the bed in front of her. "So, we're having a Harkness movie marathon."

Rio's lips twisted in a mixture of anxiety and gratitude, and she was having an incredibly difficult time finding a way to let them blend in peace.

Estee gave Tay's leg a soft tap of request, and Tay was quick on her feet to help her girlfriend up. While she was able to hold weight and walk for short periods, Estee still needed help every now and again. She limped her way over and did not hesitate to take her mother's face in both of her hands, looking her directly in the eye.

"That's what they're for, mama. She wanted to give people the chance to live in her head for a couple of hours at a time. So... that's where we'll stay, for now."

With caution to her still-fragile physical state, Rio instantly reached up, pulling her daughter into her arms in a tight hug, though she somehow managed the feat of not letting another tear spill. These kids that they had raised? They were good fucking kids.

They had untangled and set about their evening, the four of them sat hip to hip across both mattresses, propped up against the couch.

Nicky. Rio. Estee. Tay. In that order.

When Nicky had sat himself next to her, even going as far to lean into her the slightest bit? Again, it was another struggle in fighting tears, but she managed to gain the upper hand that time.

The first film was Estee's pick and honestly? Rio wasn't sure what she had been expecting, but an entire character exploration on one woman's journey from losing her family in a selfish tragedy, into the marines, and back out into civilian life after an honorable discharge? The film was heavier on the latter bit of that, following the woman -- Athena, she had been named -- as she relied on the friends she had left to help her learn what it meant to process grief instead of running from it. It had been beautifully well done; the dialogue was pointed and direct, but there was this sense of care about each line that had been delivered. The acting had been incredible as well, but Rio found herself several times pointing out, in her own mind, the most obvious pieces of Agatha that no one seemed to be aware of.

The second, as the lights were turned off and the snack bags were opened, was about two friends who, through the shots of stolen glances and the superb acting choices, were clearly in love. The friendship moniker was something they'd brandished, though. Leaving a meal that celebrated Vivian's -- an EMT in the story -- first in-ambulance delivery, the two women stumbled on an attack, leaving Vivian to jump into action. Her best friend, Marley, could only watch as one wrong tackle ended the attacker's life, and a whole slew of problems happened for Vivian. There were elements of romance, of heartache, of courtroom showings as Vivian's life was held in the balance. The declaration of love between the two main characters in an empty room between lawyer meetings, it had struck something in Rio.

Agatha didn't just think about the things she put into her films. She felt them.

By the time the second one had finished, both of the girls were fast asleep on their sides, two waves washing into the tides of sleep together.

She had not been expecting Nicky to have stayed away, but as the credits began to roll, he turned his head toward her, that sweet little curl of his lips so present. "Do you want to watch another?"

Rio's face softened and in a move that was a little too out of character, she raised her arm across her own body, reaching up to cup Nicky's cheek in her palm. Her lips turned down at the corners, pressed into the tightest line. She was trying to vault her emotions at what that simple question had meant to her. It wasn't what he said, it was what he meant.

"I think I'm going to go to bed, kid. But..." Affectionately, her thumb brushed his cheek. "Thank you. For staying, for what you have with them..." she voiced, tilting her chin toward the girls for a moment. "But most of all, thank you for giving your mom another chance."

Nicky's own lips pressed, his teeth barely visible as he sunk his them into the bottom one. Rio could have even put her hand on her chest and sworn that she saw his eyes grow glassy.

"Thank you, Rio, for helping her find the woman I always knew she could be."

In tandem, both sets of cheeks were suddenly wet and Rio moved with a hurried necessity as she adjusted so that she could pull Nicky into her arms in a ferociously tight hug, her body rocking them side-to-side gently. After a few minutes, her hold loosened, but she tilted her face toward that mess of wild hair and placed a kiss softly to the top of his head.

She let him go completely and got to her feet, taking one last look down at him.

"Goodnight, sweet boy."

"Goodnight Rio. If it's too hard... there's room for you out here, too."

She gave him a tight smile that was a complete disguise for her absolute need to completely crumble in that moment. On what felt like shaky legs, she carried herself toward the bedroom.

She wasn't sure when it happened, only that it had. It had stopped being Rio's bedroom.

It was their bedroom.

And there were traces of Agatha all through it, like debris left after a whirlwind of a storm. Her bottles of hair product on the vanity, her perfume on her nightstand -- something she had explicitly left for Rio -- and her varying shades of purple blouses hanging in the closet.

Rio drew in a steadying breath and marched ever forward, sliding into bed on the side that was not typically her own.

For a moment -- maybe one full second -- it almost felt like falling into Agatha. The sheets were not quite as soft as her skin, and the scent of her was still on her pillow, but then with a wash of disappointing realization, it hit Rio that it just wasn't the same.

The tears had come, but the shaking had been kept at bay. She could still cry, still feel upset over missing what the universe was telling her she could not have right now. What she could also do, though, was pull herself out of bed the next morning, make their family breakfast, and find ways to fill her time.

That had been one of the last few thoughts she'd had before she'd exhausted herself to slumber, wrapped up in every bit of Agatha that she could manage.

As one eye flew open in the dark, Rio could instantly hear the buzzing of her phone on her nightstand, though she screen was face down. She didn't need to see who it was. A hand leapt from under the covers and she snapped her phone to her ear as she answered it. Before she could even spit her greeting, she heard Agatha's voice.

"Hey, my love."

In an instant, Rio's heart was lodged in her chest, even though she wanted to shout back how happy she was to hear that sound.

"Good morning, baby," Rio crooned groggily at her.

"I know it's early there, but I wanted to tell you that I landed. Dave had the car waiting, so I'm on my way home."

"Not the right one, though," Rio murmured back, though there was a lightness in her tone that indicated it was more playful than it was anything else.

Agatha blew out a huff loud enough that Rio could hear, causing her lips to turn down in guilt.

"I just meant... I'm sorry," she voiced back.

"It's alright, baby. I realize I woke you up, but I told you I'd let you know when I got here and I always keep my word. Why don't you go back to sleep? I'll call you later on."

"Agathaaaaa," Rio whined, her face still half buried in the pillow.

"Yes?"

"I miss you."

The silence wasn't awkward, but it was heavy. Rio didn't think for a second that Agatha was going to leave it unacknowledged. Instead, she was letting it process and trying to determine the respectively correct output.

"My heart doesn't beat the same when you're not around."

Damn her.

"My sad poet, I think you may need a nap." Rio's voice was soft, but it was melodious in its delivery.

"I miss you, too. And I love you. We're pulling up to the house now, but we'll talk more after we've both had a little more rest." Something Rio was noticing that that while there was still a tepid touch to Agatha's tone, it had started to shy away from any actual form of warmth.

"I'm sorry this is something you have to do. But... you have people there. Use them. Or I will make Nicky give me contact information and I'll order them to come steal you away to keep your mind busy."

Agatha's laugh came over the line and Rio's heart soared for the first time since she'd let her go in that airport.

"Plus... You can always be an Athena Saltzman. You know, actually choosing to rely on others in really hard times."

Agatha sucked in a sharp breath and the strangest noise sounded, if Rio had to guess, somewhere near the base of her throat.

"Rio Daniela Vidal," Agatha nearly hissed at her and it had the grin on her face nearly cracking her apart.

"Yes, my love?"

"You didn't..." Rio could hear the flooding as it built, could feel that raw emotion clawing within Agatha's chest. She knew what that meant to Agatha, even without her having to say it.

"It was the kids' idea. I showed up and they had crisps and lollies and they got dinner from the chip shop. When I sat down, they just... swarmed me. We ate, we drank wine and we just... lived in your head for a little while." Her voice was still soft, but there was a little more conviction there, a sense of resolve that Rio had only found in those hours spent with their kids.

"Gods be damned, I fucking hate my mother."

It was a truthful statement, but it was one Rio could not have agreed with anymore. Sure, they would have eventually gone back to LA, but they could have either done it together, or as a family. They could have had a good time, had the chance to show the kids some of the things that Agatha had shown to her on her first trip. They could have had the chance to make memories.

"So scare the God out of her and come back home to us."

Rio wanted so badly to be on the other end of that phone, to be right next to the woman she loved, to know what was going on in those eyes and on that face as she sat in silence. She heard movement, as Agatha climbed out of the car and shut the door behind her.

"I'm going to do my damnedest. I just got to the house, my love. Go back to sleep, I'll FaceTime you later, hm?"

Rio grumbled in response, though the thought of a few more hours of shut eye didn't sound like the worst one. Still, doing that meant hanging up the phone and cutting off any chance she might get to hear Agatha speak again.

"Rio?" she beguiled, unsure if her request had already worked.

"Okay, okay. Fine. I will sleep, and then make breakfast. And then I will sit on our deck trying not to stare at the bridge while I read."

Agatha exhaled a laugh that almost turned into a snort. "You know that the moment -- okay, maybe not the moment -- that I get home, we're planning the wedding, right?"

A rapid fluttering happened in Rio's chest, her stomach squeezing in the utter delight it brought to her at hearing Agatha say something like that. She exhaled her own light giggle, a truly amused sound.

"I would expect no less, my love. Now go!" Rio chided, her tone sweet but sincere. Her next words were softer, but they were still indicative of how she was feeling. "And if you miss me too much, I'm pretty sure that I forgot my All Blacks kit somewhere in the closet the night we left. I bet it would look good on you."

Agatha sucked in a breath, but exhaled it heavily a moment later.

"I'll let you be the judge of that. I love you, beautiful. Quit stalling."

Another light giggle zipped across the line, right into Agatha's ear.

"I love you too, mi amor. And if I don't wake up to a picture of you in that kit, I might be a little disappointed."

"Dually noted, sweetheart. I'll see you later, yeah?"

"Not soon enough."

The Mist in the Clouds

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

You are life itself.
I could swim in your forever, and drink you til I drown.
Your mind's a constellation, your voice the perfect sound.

*****

Rio had decided with absolute certainty that her least favorite thing had now become hanging up a phone when Agatha was the one on the other line. It was painful, though not debilitatingly so. However, it was still a stark reminder that they were half a world apart, that they couldn't just walk into the next room to see the other.

Rio's one true home was across an ocean and the painful reminder hit her every single time that line went dead and she was left alone again.

She missed Agatha. She hadn't even been gone a whole day.

She had tried to heed Agatha's instruction, but sinking back into the bed had not provided any relief. She couldn't stop thinking about her, thinking about how much of life they had experienced since the day they'd met. They had witnessed so much and felt so much, and it had only ever bonded them. Their experiences had bound them together in a way that had been subtle, and now?

Well, now their ties were very visible in that diamond on Rio's left hand. She turned her head on the pillow, her right cheek finding the soft cotton as she raised her hand to take it in.

Every time she looked at it, the breath in her throat often got swallowed down. It was so... perfect. When she'd had more time to look at it, to study it? It was almost like she could pinpoint every single reason that Agatha had picked it. The divots in the metal looked like leaves, the curling of the halo of smaller diamonds that looked like rose petals. Agatha had gone on a hunt until she found the perfect trophy to bring home and Rio could not have been more flattered.

They were going to get married. That was still a thought, however much of an astonished one it was. Sure, there was no date, nothing set in stone. But hearing Agatha say that to her, that the planning began when she came home?

Rio had never so much been in a serious relationship, and there she had been discussing planning a wedding with a woman she had known for just over two months. In the grand scheme of things, it had to seem insane. She knew it did. Nicky's initial reaction had been all too indicative of that. He had been the voice of what was probably the entire world if anyone else had known about the situation.

It should have terrified her, but something she had learned in the last two months?

When it came to Agatha, the only thing she had to worry about was her ability to walk after they'd been fucking like teenagers for hours.

What an incredible form of safety: Rio had shut the world out for her protection, only to fork over every last bit of her reserves to someone who handled them with intent and care. Agatha could have easily wrecked her, even on that first day, by saying that night on the boat hadn't meant anything. Instead, she had embraced Rio with a wild fervor that Rio had never seen present in another human being.

For as often as she had thought in their absence that she had been insane for feeling the way she had, the moment their lips had touched at the foot of those stairs, Agatha holding onto her face like that?

Soulmates, past lives, seeking faith. Everything they were happened in that one moment, they just hadn't realized it.

The longer Rio lay there, the more she realized that she was not going to find a way to go back to sleep. A tongue swiped over dry lips and she let out a soft sigh, not wanting to move to her own side of the bed to retrieve her chapstick. Instead, she opened the drawer of Agatha's nightstand and peeked her head over to peer inside. As she rummaged, a yellow Post-it note was revealed only by the corner and there was a slight line that formed in Rio's brow.

Carefully, she pulled on it, and when she saw what was on it? Her face crumpled and the tears started welling in her eyes.

There, on that little square of paper, was a poorly drawn boat on rocky waves. Next to it was Rio's scrawl; her name and phone number.

Rio hadn't even been aware that the note had ever been passed onto Agatha, especially after they'd had their little reckoning outside of that office. What was more, Agatha had kept it with her in the same way Rio still had that purple Post-it with Agatha's message from their first time together.

There was something to be done with that, Rio supposed, but that would be a project for another day.

She found a tube of chapstick in Agatha's drawer and applied it to her lips before she tossed it back inside and shut the drawer. Rio wanted to throw herself back into the pillows, to just wrap up in the ghost of Agatha a little bit longer, but the sun had been steadily rising and she knew that there was no point.

In contradiction to what her mind wanted, she forced herself up and swung her legs over the edge of the bed. Her palms pressed flat to the mattress on either side of her as she brought the morning into focus, her eyes drifting over to the closet. Agatha's shirts were still hung and it caused Rio's lips to rub together in choice.

After another moment of thought, she pushed herself to her feet and padded over to the closet, thumbing through her fiance's clothes. Through all of the different shades of purple, though, there was something that caught Rio's attention that she had never noticed before.

Almost like it was hidden, there was a t-shirt in the back. Unlike the other hues, this one was a vibrant cardinal color. How had she never noticed it before? She reached forward, pulling the hanger off of the pole, and turned it around to face her.

Emblazoned on the front in big gold letters: "USC Trojans." Between the words, there was a small logo of a Trojan warrior. Rio was completely confounded. She didn't understand what the insignia meant, but she was curious. With the hanger still curled safely in her grip, she crossed back to the bed and pulled up her phone, inputting the words into Google.

When the results came across her screen? Rio simply blinked down at her phone.

Agatha liked college football?

She didn't even go to USC.

Agatha had to like collegiate American football. And for some reason? It felt like to Rio, she had just learned an entirely new side of who Agatha was, fundamentally. It was silly, surely, but the fact that Rio got these chances to learn more and more about this woman she loved each and every day? She was thankful.

Each piece she gathered, helped her build something bigger and better. Each new fasten she could gather secured their bind a little more. There were so many staples to Agatha that Rio knew she'd have some time to find how they all fit, and where they went. This was just another piece of that.

Then again, should Rio be that surprised? After all, she did know how much Agatha loved rugby, and she supposed American football was... diet rugby. Rio didn't exactly understand all of the rules, and it felt like quite a bit to grasp onto, but it was entertaining enough to watch with no context.

That struck a thought in her.

Her All Blacks kit.

Agatha's Trojan's shirt.

The moment the idea formed, Rio's lips curled into a smirk. She laid the shirt down on the bed and pulled off her own before she gave a little stretch to loosen some tension in her back. She made quick work of removing the t-shirt off of the hanger and slid it over her head, her legs still bare from the hem of the shirt down.

Rio had started to move to find a pair of shorts, but then... another thought.

She turned back to the bed and scooped up her phone, making her way over to the full-length mirror that was in the corner. Seeing her reflection made her grin. She was missing Agatha, yes, but she had so many pieces to hold onto.

She brought up the phone, positioning it just right so that her grin was still visible as was the rest of her in her entirety, clad in nothing but that t-shirt and her underwear that weren't even visible beneath the edge of the shirt. Rio snapped the picture, and then another where she was chewing on her thumbnail.

When she was satisfied with the product, she stood there, composing a message to Agatha.

"I know you're probably sleeping, but I couldn't. So... I went through your things. ;)"

Rio included the two photos she had taken in the message and sent it. With the knowledge that a response would likely not come for a while, she decided to start the day. She found a pair of shorts and slid them on, making her way out into the living room. Her eyes fell on the mattress, but as she did a head count, a kid was missing.

Her own.

Rio's head tilted back to look down the hallway behind her, but the bathroom door was open and Estee's mattress was one of the ones on the floor, so she wouldn't be in her room. Rio's brow pulled slightly, but she paced to the door that led to the deck, pulling it open as opposed to trying to look through the blinds.

There, sat in the chair that Rio always tended to occupy, was Estee, her gaze up and to the right of where she sat. There was this look on her face that Rio couldn't quite place; she looked contemplative, yes, but there were these brief licks of pain that seized certain spots in her face every so often. She had been so absorbed in whatever thoughts she was having that she had not heard Rio open the door.

"Mija? Estas bien?" Rio's voice was low and soft, but it was full of her concern.

Estee's eyes snapped over to her mother, the surprise taking over her form. When she processed the question, she gave a gentle nod. "I'm just..." She stopped, those beautiful eyes filling with an emotion Rio had not seen in her before. "Just thinking, that's all."

The dismissal flagged something in Rio's mind. Her lips worried together for a moment, but then her feet were moving as she moved over to the other chair -- Agatha's chair -- and placed herself into it.

"Thinking about what?" Rio posed, looking over at her daughter's profile. That little slope of her nose that ended in the cutest curve, those perfectly placed cheekbones. Even through Rio's own bias, she knew that Estee was a beautiful young woman, no matter who was looking at her.

"It's too early for that conversation," she attempted to dismiss, but she knew before she said it that Rio was not going to let it fly.

"Estrella."

Even though she didn't move to look at her mother, Rio could still see it. Her lips pinched down at the corner and her eyes filled with emotion. She could also see Estee's throat bob as she tried to swallow that emotion down.

"I... It's just that... It's always just been you and me and Tay, and that's been perfect. That is all we have ever needed. I didn't need another parent because I had all I needed in you." Estee's voice was low, but Rio could hear the sincerity, and it touched her. She could feel the emotion beginning to wash into her chest, too. With a fight, she shoved it back down to let Estee say what she had to say.

"But mama?" she voiced, turning her head to take Rio in, one of the tears breaking free to slip down her cheek.

"Yeah, mija?"

"It's hard when Agatha's not here."

The tears in Rio's own eyes that had been sitting, held back by her own will, slipped down her cheeks soundlessly. Gods, if that wasn't the honest fucking truth.

"I know, mija. And here I was thinking I was going to be the only one to struggle," she mused, breathing a sad chuckle through a tight smile.

"Honestly, I thought you were, too. And... yes, I hate seeing you without her because I know you're struggling... But my reasons are a little more selfish." She paused, her eyes landing somewhere in the water in front of them. "When I woke up in the hospital, I thought I was dreaming. I mean, a member of Hollywood royalty was sitting beside my bed, holding my hand. I never could have imagined that you, or her, would ever have been there." Estee reached up, wiping at her wet cheeks. She took in a long, slow breath and then exhaled before she spoke again. "When I looked into her eyes? I felt safe. I felt like even though it wasn't you, she was going to protect me until you got back."

The longer Estee went on, the hotter and faster Rio's tears fell even though she did not make a single sound.

"I've never wanted to admit it to you, but I sometimes had thoughts -- mostly as a kid -- where I wondered what it would be like to have two moms, or a mom and a dad. The older I got the more I realized it didn't matter... but the way Agatha treated me that day? The nine-year-old in me had wanted it to be someone like... Not, not someone like her. It would have killed to have her as that second parent."

This was tearing at Rio, clawing at her in a way that was too scarily reminiscent of what she had felt that day she'd laid eyes on Nicky in that hotel lobby. She took a calming breath, though, and tried to center herself.

"It's just the timing. I wish that you could have had her this whole time. And her not being around... Well, it just sucks."

Rio reached across the table, laying her palm on the top of Estee's forearm, giving a gentle squeeze before she began to brush the skin there with her thumb.

"I know, mija. But we're going to get through it. Not only because we have to, but because we can."

As Estee finally looked over at her, a curious look wove into her expression. "Mama, what are you wearing?"

Rio looked down at the shirt, then back up to Estee. A grin pushed up wet cheeks.

"It's Agatha's. It's an American football team, I guess. We were talking about my All Blacks kit when she called me to tell her that she was safe and back in LA. I had ended up thumbing through her things because I missed her and I found this in the back. Thought it a bit fitting, hm?" Rio posed, tilting her head sweetly in Estee's direction.

"It's almost gross how much you love each other," Estee offered back, her tears seeming to have dried.

Rio offered her a sunny smile and tip of her head, a silent acknowledgment.

They were quiet for a moment, both pairs of eyes cast out into the water. The silence rippled apart at the sound of Estee's voice.

"Nick mentioned wanting to go somewhere he could get some good photos, so Tay and I decided we're going to take him to Cape Reinga. We'll probably end up getting a hotel room up there since it's such a drive." The way Estee delivered this to her with such ease was warming in every way imaginable. "If we leave by 10, we can get there no later than 16:00, which will give him plenty of time to set up for sunset photos."

Rio let out a laugh that caught Estee, and honestly even herself, off guard. The question in those green eyes was apparent, but Rio's smile never wavered.

"It's almost gross how much you guys all love each other," Rio parroted back, her grin splitting her lips smoothly.

Instead of protesting, Estee simply gave her shoulders a shrug, turning her eyes back out before them.

"I've always loved Tay for as long as I can remember. She's never been a sibling figure through my worldview, no matter how many times I said she was my sister. But Nick? He just... feels like a brother. He cares like one, he acts like one. He's so kind and does so much to just make our lives easier. So, I guess I just want to return the favor."

Rio gave Estee's arm another gentle squeeze. "I'm happy that you have that, mija."

"Me too, mama."

"Well, I'll go in and start breakfast. Crumpets and eggs sound alright?"

Estee gave a small nod as she looked back over at her mother.

"Te amo, mama."

"Te amo, mija. Come in when you're ready, and if you need help, just give a shout."

*****

Rio had done as she had said, cooking the four of them breakfast which finished right around the same time that Nicky and Tay greeted the morning. They'd all eaten with a documentary about the dodo that Nicky had randomly selected, more background noise than anything else.

Afterward, Rio cleaned up the dishes while the kids packed their bags for their trip that was likely to roll into the next day. As they departed, she'd kissed both Estee and Tay on the cheek, who each returned the favor when the embraces broke apart. When she hugged Nicky, though, she hadn't been expecting to place the lightest brush of his lips over her cheek.

It caused this pit to form in Rio, one that made her miss Agatha but made her love Nicky at the same time.

"You three behave. Call if you need anything. And please, please, please. Be careful."

They had all announced, almost in perfect unison, that they would, and disappeared toward the parking lot to load up Tay's car, slow going to keep pace with Estee.

Rio turned back to the empty home and she was hit with a realization.

Not only was this her first time here alone since the day Agatha had fallen into her life, but that thought did not make her sad. Did it fill her with longing? Absolutely. But... The houseboat had always been her refuge, and now with a piece of Agatha hanging around her torso, she felt oddly at peace.

She'd showered, watered her plants that the neighbor had taken amazing care of, and finished any remaining cleanup from their marathon the night before. By the time she finished, her eyes fell onto her bookshelf and she stepped toward it, running her fingertips over a couple of the spines.

They landed on one that she'd been meaning to read for a while: The Shimmering State. It was fiction, but a thought piece on valuing the high of happiness more than one's sanity.

Hm. How fitting.

She pulled it off the shelf and located her sunglasses before making her way out to the deck. She had the book in one hand and a glass of wine in the other as she placed herself into her chair, leaning back into it. She took a sip of the wine, not caring that it was two in the afternoon, and set it back down as she cracked open the book.

As it turned out, it was a great deal easier to read when she did not have Agatha feet away from her as a glaring distraction.

She'd gotten through a good forty pages by the time her phone had started to ring. The grin that lit her up was wide and immediate as she reached over to grab her phone, elated at the sight of Agatha's profile indicating she wanted to FaceTime.

Without missing a beat, Rio swiped to answer, the words spilling before the image of Agatha even appeared on her screen.

"Good evening, my love!"

As the camera registered, though, Rio felt like she had been struck with a blast of nothing but ice, chilling her from head to toe. And then, as it processed? The flames swept in, staring at the crown of her head and racing down to the soles of her feet.

There, in the background, were those familiar swirls of marble on the wall. The corner caddy held all of the soaps, shampoos, and skin care products. The showerhead was on full blast.

None of that was as prevalent as Agatha, directly in the center of the frame and visible down to about mid-calf.

She was also completely naked.

Rio's reaction went far beyond her cognition. In an instant, still gripping her phone tightly, she leaped to her feet, her eyes wide. As a result of her action, the book she had set in her lap launched off and over the railing of the deck, landing with a splash in the water.

"Agatha!" Rio fought to gasp.

The vexatious smirk she had been wearing immediately shifted into something softer as she took in the sight of Rio and what she was wearing.

"Is that my USC shirt?" she asked, the desire for being a troublemaker suddenly pushed to the back-burner momentarily.

"I didn't know you cared about American college football. And also, you apparently did not get my message." Rio mused back as smoothly as she could manage despite the sudden hunger blooming in her chest.

Agatha could see it on her face, though, that she was losing the battle. She stepped closer to the other corner caddy where she had set her phone, that warm smile filling her face.

"I did not. But... I missed you. And I needed to shower before Dave and the lawyer come over, so I thought I'd give you a call and kill two birds with one stone." The way she rattled it off, it was like it was such a smart choice, such an obvious one.

"You know, I can't fault the logic, but maybe could you give a girl some warning next time? You made me ruin a really good book," Rio whined back, jutting out her lip in a dramatic pout that only caused Agatha's grin to grow.

"Baby, I'll buy you whatever book you want," Agatha mused, stepping back to pump some shampoo into her hands before working it into a lather atop her head. Her eyes were closed and her head was tilted back and Rio was having the hardest time not completely salivating at the sight. She had taken her seat again, but she was placed on the edge of it.

She wanted to be there, wanted to be the one to wash the six thousand miles off of Agatha's skin, but she just had to watch instead.

"How are the babes?" Agatha posed, though she was still engrossed in her task and Rio was growing more fevered with each passing moment.

"Th-they're good. They headed to the north part of the island so Nicky could take some pictures at sunset. They're going to stay the night and come back tomorrow."

At this, Agatha's eyes opened and the kindling that had previously been obvious in her eyes erupted into a full-fledged bonfire.

"Is that so?" she posed, her lips pursing in thought for a moment as she leaned back to rinse the shampoo. The conditioning process was roughly the same, but when she started to wash her body? "I wish you were here."

"I want to touch you just as much as I ache to be touched by you."

A sharp breath pulled in between Rio's lips right before her teeth sank into the lower one, stifling the whimper that fought to escape.

"Agatha..." Rio whined softly, hating every single inch of distance that separated them.

Her hold released on her chest, but her hand did not lift. Instead, it started a trek. It headed back to the center of her chest and then began to drift downward. Rio was stuck. She knew what this was, what Agatha was doing. She knew what it stirred in her, but the idea of getting to her feet and somehow making it to the bedroom?

Rio stepped toward the bed, leaning into the frame of the phone with a smirk on her lips. "Oh, does that do it for you?"

Agatha let out a laugh that was strange in tone, but Rio realized it was because she had hit the nail on the head.

"The thought of balling the back of it up in my fist while I'm taking you from behind has crossed my mind once or twice since the beginning of this phone call," Agatha replied coolly, even though that sultry tone didn't shake.

How the fuck did Agatha do that?

"Hmm, how so?" Agatha mused as she came closer to the phone again.

"The first time we had sex, I seriously thought you were having a seizure. And in the times since I thought it was just what an orgasm did to you," Rio explained, though her eyes were still stoked with the heat of the embers burning there. "But... that's the one time it wasn't like that."

Agatha's smirk hiked up a corner of her lips, her eyes warm but still wild.

"Rio, my love. No one has ever made me come like that aside from you."

Rio's eyes widened. That couldn't possibly be true. There was no way that was just something she could do... was there?

"Well," Rio posed, the pink still on her cheeks from their efforts. "If you miss it bad enough, you'll find a way to come back as soon as you can."

"Already working on it, baby. Hence the 8 pm lawyer meeting. Which, if I do not get out of here and get dressed for, it not going to happen."

Rio's smile fell slightly, but she did her best to hide her disappointment.

"Call me before you go to sleep tonight," Rio requested softly, her head tilting in question.

"I'll call you as soon as they leave. You have my word."

"I miss you, Agatha."

"I miss you too, Rio."

The look on Agatha's face made Rio want to burst into tears, but she found a way to hide them for the moment. She wouldn't make this any harder than it already was.

"Te amo, mi amor."

Agatha picked up the phone, holding it closer as the warmest smile curled her lips. It was an obvious attempt to mask the greater effect those words seemed to have on her.

"I love you, beautiful."

And then, the call ended.

Rio was alone again.

Somehow, though, this time didn't sting so bad.

That night, Agatha had called Rio again via FaceTime, but this time she had been dressed, and yet it had still managed to knock Rio on her ass.

This opened up a couple of different possibilities. Either she would respond with conditions Agatha might be willing to meet, drop it entirely, and realize that if Agatha won that countersuit she would lose everything she owned, or she would fight. Considering that the woman had tried to kill her only child, Rio wasn't sure she could safely assume which course of action the woman might choose.

What she hoped she would choose? Agatha had told Rio that she would even make some kind of deal if it meant getting to come home to her family. For once in her life, she'd managed to pull it off.

"Yeah, of course! How exciting!"

And so, Rio had spent the rest of the night with the kids, relaying the information she had received. They'd all four been so impossibly overjoyed, and even though Evanora Harkness could go fuck herself, they had all learned a very powerful lesson.

Even if things were hard, they would still manage to find a way through them.

They had indeed managed to get the majority of the things over; the furniture had been delivered on their first trip and Nicky had stayed while it was all assembled.

This was the first time she would pick up Agatha from the airport, but she knew it probably wouldn't be the last. More than that, the duration might be longer in the future.

Before Agatha could make her next move, though, Rio's hands were on her face and she was pulling her in, kissing her as hard as she could. She had missed her so fucking much and she needed to find some way beyond words to make sure Agatha knew it.

They were like two teenage girls, not giving a single care for any local disdain for public affection. It was just them, together, again. It was Agatha and Rio. Rio and Agatha, as they were meant to be.

They kissed for a long moment, but Agatha was the one who pulled away first. As Rio's eyes flickered open into hers, she saw what she had known would be there.

Agatha, once again, was absolutely starved. Rio had missed her, and she had missed the intimacy that came with being physical, but Agatha?

At that moment, it looked like Agatha had thought of little else in her entire time away.

"You brought Tay's car?" Agatha asked lowly, stealing another soft kiss, though as she pulled away her smirk was wide.

"I didn't think it was much of an option, but I would have anyway if it was."

"Well, then we should probably go before I show how classless I can be and drag you into the first bathroom we see on the way out."

Agatha had watched over two days as Rio had built up her fuel, and kept stocking for when they could see one another again. All that fuel?

Once again, Agatha ripped that torch and set her alight.

"You thought about this your entire flight, did you?" Rio purred in question.

"Oh, my love, you have no idea what I thought about on that flight."

The heat had gripped her and she suddenly had no idea how they were going to make it to the car without stripping each other down in the middle of that damn airport.

The giggles, the glances, it truly was like they were young and wild and ever so free. They didn't have a care in the world as Agatha threw her bag into the front seat on the floor. She wanted to keep as much space open in the back as she could manage. She nearly slammed the door shut, though it hadn't been her intention before she turned back to Rio.

Those blues were almost white hot with how much heat was burning there, how much hunger. Her eyes never left Rio's as she reached forward and pulled the back door open. Rio hadn't looked away, though, or made any kind of movement to climb in. Agatha's jaw tensed, her eyes flickering across Rio's features in impatience.

"Rio," she asserted firmly as if this would impel her to move.

"Hm?" Rio posed, that little smirk twisting up her lips as her eyes glimmered with mischief.

"Get in. Now."

"What scares you, Agatha Harkness?"

It could have been two minutes, it could have been twenty and Rio would have had no clue in the world. Time, it didn't really matter anyway. It was a construct, a supposed natural progression to life. When it came to the reality of life, of knowing another human being? Time was an inadequate way of trying to measure what a relationship was worth.

Nearly a month without Agatha before actually knowing her had been shitty, but it had been bearable. Rio had managed to get through it out of nothing but sheer will and determination.

The last three days?

The last three days had been misery in its purest, most raw form. It had been an entirely new pain that Rio had convinced herself was all contrived inside of her own mind. What she had realized the moment Agatha had been able to get her hands on her?

Agatha had felt the exact same way.

That hadn't just been hard, or even only uncomfortable. The distance had hurt. It seemed insane, as most things did when it came to their relationship, to think that she could hardly get over herself long enough to spend a few days away from Agatha without feeling like she wasn't whole anymore. It was codependency at it's finest, and she was well aware, but that could be a therapy session a year down the road.

Right then?

Right then, Rio had her one true love pressed into her side, her breathing falling so even that Rio began to question if she had fallen asleep. She had instantly decided that if she had, she was going to let her sleep for a little bit. She'd just spent over twelve hours on a plane and there was no doubt in Rio's mind that she was completely exhausted.

After however fucking long that whole escapade was? It would have been no wonder if she'd passed out even sooner.

It was like a film in her head, one she would watch through and then immediately hammer down on the rewind button so she could relive it over and over again. "How about we go home? The kids are at the big house for the night, so it's just me and you and our boathouse."

In the same moment, Agatha's hands fell to her hips, her grip solid but not offering any kind of push or pull. She was just holding her. This was on Rio's terms, full stop.

As Rio began to adjust to the fullness, it became a little easier to navigate, though as she began to slide into a gentle rhythm, her hands slowly lifted. She no longer needed the support. Instead, as she felt Agatha's hands slide to her thighs, her own hands lifted to her head, sliding into her hair that she gripped in one at the back of her head. The other hand fell back down, palm flat against her chest as her hips continued that steady movement.

Her eyes had been closed almost the whole time, but as she finally forced them open?

Agatha's expression was entirely ethereal. She looked like she had completely transcended outside of time and space and any physical constraint that her worldly ties might have had to offer her. She was in heaven, if it had ever existed on earth. Her hands would glide over skin, but she did not grip or press or pull. She did not even lift her hips once.

Rio felt her power in those moments, especially as her movements became a little more rushed, a little more filled with need and frenzy. Agatha sensed this and in a sudden surge, she sat up, her arms wrapping around Rio so that her palms landed along her spine. Their fronts brushed with Rio's fervor, but Agatha's lips landed at the base of her throat, kissing every inch she could reach.

The more frequent Rio's little gasps became, the more it pushed Agatha closer to that edge, too.

In some act of what had to be sheer coincidence, Agatha's lips pressed to Rio's chest, directly above where her heart sat in her chest and she could feel in literally every single place between the two of them where muscles tensed for several seconds and then released, their moaned cries tangling together in a soft symphony of pleasure that wrapped around them like a warm blanket.

Rio nearly folded forward into Agatha who immediately fell back into the pillows behind them, both bodies trembling steadily against one another. Agatha was the first to move, surprisingly, and turned her head enough that she could place as many kisses as Rio would allow against the side of her head, her ear, her cheek.

Slowly, it seemed like their limbs began to still and the pleasure stopped rippling as violently through them, enough that Rio could roll to Agatha's side, completely and entirely spent. Like clockwork, Agatha's arm wrapped around her shoulders and pulled her close, while at the same time reaching down to remove the appendage, discarding it somewhere to the side on the mattress.

The laptop had since died and there was no other sound in the room aside from their labored breathing as they chose to live in the quiet bliss for just a few more moments.

As coherency seemed to find them again, Rio managed to pick up her head so that she could rest her chin on Agatha's chest, their eyes locking as a warm smile found Rio's lips.

"And that's what I got the ice cream for," Rio informed her, the most delectable giggle parting her lips.

"Mmm, ice cream. That was a good idea," Agatha hummed back, a blithe smile curling her lips as she picked up her head, indicating she wanted a kiss, which Rio happily provided.

"Want me to go get it?" Rio posed, hiking up a brow in question though that stunning smile had never left her face.

"In a minute," Agatha responded reaching down with her free hand to give Rio's side a light squeeze, an indicator that she wanted more of her attention.

Again, Rio obliged, scooting up a little further so that she could place her lips lovingly against Agatha's in the most tender exchange. It was slow, soft and so completely undemanding for the few moments it went on, reverent in its intent.

Agatha, again surprising Rio, was the one who broke the contact, a light huff of a chuckle blowing through her nose.

"I think I'm ready for ice cream now," she mused, floating the idea as though she had any doubt Rio might object. Rio's sweeping grin was so bright and full as she nearly scrambled out of bed to retrieve their treats and a couple of spoons.

As she returned and handed Agatha's over to her, she placed herself on the bed in a sitting position, her legs crossed in front of her in a way that left her shins pressed to Agatha's hip. They sat like that for the entire duration of time it took them to eat their pints, sharing laughter and conversation and loving brushes of skin throughout.

By the time they had finished and placed their empty containers and dirty spoons on their respective nightstands, Rio glanced at the clock on her dresser to see that it was nearing three in the morning. She slid against Agatha's side once more, finding her home in that vastness of skin.

Rio had just started to doze, but Agatha's breath hitched and a soft Oh! sounded around them, causing Rio to jerk her head up to find out what was happening.

That look on Agatha's face, though?

Rio knew that look.

Agatha was hungry again, sparked by a thought that had suddenly appeared in her head.

Her eyes shifted down, taking in her fiance as her lips curled into a smirk.

"How quiet do you think you can be?" she posed, that huskiness finding her tone again.

Rio's brow pinched, indicating that she didn't understand.

Agatha remained quiet for a moment, her eyes flicking from side to side as she reached Rio's face, that mischief on her own only seeming to get louder.

"It's 3 am and I think the likelihood, if you can be quiet, of me fucking you over the railing of the deck could be pretty high. And also, a great deal of calculated risk's worth of fun."

"Agatha!" Rio shot back, her jaw dropping a little. "You're insane."

"What I am not hearing yet is a no..."

"...And you won't."

Chapter End Notes

im not crying you're crying

In Her Arms You Will Never Starve

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

In her arms you will never starve, you will never freeze
And when the world is hard, you can fall asleep there
In a world of chaos she could be your silence
The oceans of her kindness, they will pull you under
*****

The light of the morning sun was not the first thing Rio noticed as she stirred to consciousness. Her eyes did not open, though it shone orange through her eyelids enough to notify her that the morning had come.

What she noticed first was that the sounds of the waves lapping against the outside of the house were almost in perfect time with the soft sounds of Agatha's breathing.

Each breath Agatha took, a lapping of the waves harmonized perfectly.

Two of Rio's favorite things, ebbing and flowing with the force impelled by the universe.

After just another moment of brief personal introspection, Rio's eyelids fluttered and then lifted. The light wasn't entirely too bright, but indicative of a morning that had already begun. What the light touched, though, was what drew her attention.

Bathed in the golden hues lay Agatha's nude form, chest down with her face pressed to the pillow in a way that Rio could see it, behold it, in all of its beauty. Though she was naked, there was a small corner of the sheet that had twisted in her slumber in a way that left it laying across the small of her back. It left the hills of her backside revealed as they transitioned into those smooth, muscular thighs.

Rio's eyes swept back up, though as they hit the blanket, they slowed again. Instead, she chose to take her time in tracing those little lines, the little divots of muscle on her back, her shoulders. Agatha's arm was pulled up, tucked underneath the pillow that was pressed to her cheek.

She looked so... peaceful.

Surely, she had fallen asleep with that wicked air of smug confidence that she had surely earned herself through their little foray out on the deck the night before. It had almost seemed like doing the impossible for her to stop grinning every time they looked at each other.

Yes, it had been... incredibly hot. But there had been something else, something that Rio had not identified until she had been about to fall asleep.

Making that kind of choice, for Rio, would have seemed out of character in any context. A woman who had not ever let anyone close enough to touch her, let alone bend her over a deck railing in a very, very public place no matter what time it was, made that choice. A woman who, toeing the line of forty years old, had not even so much as kissed another human being in over half of her life.

In those moments, the ones where she tried to choke back her pleasured cries, she had simply been a woman whose heart and body belonged entirely to Agatha Harkness.

Had it been completely insane to even consider it? Of course. There was never much question about that, but what had come from it had been something she never could have conjured in even her wildest dreams. The freedom that she had found in her relationship with Agatha had been something she had never known was possible, and even as they fought to keep their voices subdued acting like a couple of thrill-seeing teenagers she knew that she would have never had that freedom with anyone else.

Agatha's body had folded over her own, arms secured snugly around her middle as the two of them had just stared down into the water while they fought to catch their breaths.

"Hm" Agatha had breathed into Rio's ear, like whatever she was about to say next was going to be something pointed. "I think I can see your old phone."

In that one moment, it took all of five seconds for almost every memory they'd made since that day to flood her mind's eye at a breakneck speed. Rio was certain that she couldn't actually see it, but the fact that it was something she had remembered enough to crack a joke?

It was just yet another reason to fall in love with Agatha, as if she had needed any more.

The look that was on Agatha's face in that moment, though, was a snapshot of true serenity. She was where she was comfortable, she was where she was wanted and loved. Agatha was home.

Rio had carefully slipped out of bed to brush her teeth and run a brush through her hair with the intention of getting back into bed, but something else tugged at her. She paced back to the bedroom and pulled on a t-shirt and a pair of underwear. Before she made a second exit from the bedroom, though, she knelt down on the bed and leaned over her fiance to press the softest kiss to her cheek. Rio was not surprised when she failed to stir; that wasn't the intent behind it anyway.

She righted herself on her feet again and made her way out into the rest of the house, heading straight for the kitchen to survey what might have been left in the refrigerator. She found four eggs and a somehow untouched pack of bangers. That, she decided, was substantial enough for a breakfast that would refuel them in some attempt at correcting the depletion of energy they had caused themselves.

And so, she had set to her work. The aromas began to lift, to carry, but as she was close to finishing the task of making them food, she could hear it -- however faintly -- as Agatha's phone started to ring. Ah, she must have turned it back on before she fell asleep.

What perplexed Rio was that it had sounded twice, but then was silenced. With the work before her, she hadn't been able to hear Agatha's voice as she answered it.

She did hear it, though, when Agatha shouted.

"WHAT?!"

Eyes wide, Rio immediately dropped the spatula in her hand and took off in a mad dash back toward the bedroom. Even though she had clipped the corner as she rounded it, she didn't slow down, even with the knowledge that it was going to be one nasty bruise.

By the time Rio got to the doorway of the bedroom, though, she almost saw it before she heard it.

Flat on her back, hair strewn around here like wildfire and one hand pressed to her forehead, lay Agatha still naked. And she was... laughing?

She was really laughing.

Rio's chest heaved both from the panic and the exertion of ripping across that houseboat to try and find out what the hell was going on. Agatha had not heard Rio's commotion through her own laughter, which still had not subsided.

Rio was frozen in that doorway, absolutely no idea what was happening. That wasn't a 'ha-ha that's funny' laugh. It wasn't even a 'someone told me a good joke' laugh. There was sparks of electricity buzzing around that laugh, like it could be so very dangerous if it got any louder. Rio's eyes had not left Agatha, though. Her hand moved the longer the laugh went on, sliding down her cheek to eventually cover her mouth to try and stifle it.

Just before it got to the point where Rio started to grow concerned, Agatha finally calmed herself, though she held her palm over her mouth for a moment longer before she seemed to find herself again. As she began to speak, she had not realized that Rio had returned.

"I swear on all that is holy, Dave, you better not be fucking with me. I'm looking it up myself, so I'm putting you on speaker." Agatha did as she had said she was going to, lowering the phone as she switched it over to speakerphone and began to Google something.

"It hasn't been reported yet, Agatha. Not that it should be, anyway. Her only tie to any semblance of fame was you and we all know how fantastic that was." Dave's voice was nothing like what Rio had thought it might sound like when Agatha talked about it. "I only found out because the lawyer called me when he got an email that the suit was dropped."

Rio's brow pinched; she was seeing each individual piece, but she was not able to make sense of them. That laugh did not match what Dave was saying.

Agatha's face screwed up in frustration, realizing that Dave had been right and nothing had been reported.

What was it that she was looking for?

"The moment there's anything in print, you need to send it to me. I'm not kidding, Dave. Call Brielle if you have to. I know you hate stooping as low as to poke the bear of TMZ but she never lets us down if we point her in the right direction." Agatha breathed a heavy sigh through her nose, though there was this brief giggle that sounded giddy.

"Okay, so one more time. And I swear Dave..."

"According to the email from the lawyer, the plaintiff was no longer alive to pursue the suit."

At this, Rio completely forgot about any attempt she had been making to be nothing more than an observer.

"What?!"

Agatha sat bolt upright and as she did so, Rio could see her expression full-on, and with crystal clarity.

There were flashes of light dancing in her eyes which were glassy, threatening to spill. Despite the tears, Agatha looked over the fucking moon.

"Is that Rio?" came Dave's voice over the line.

Rio stepped into the room, tucking a leg beneath herself as she slid on the bed, facing Agatha but putting them in a position where her knee was at Agatha's hip, leaving Agatha's knee at her own hip.

"Hi, Dave," Rio greeted sweetly. She had not had the chance to make his acquaintance yet, but Agatha had a very deep well of respect for the man and his ability to keep her focused.

"Hello to you as well." He cleared his throat, as if it were an invisible way to segue the conversation. "So, I reached out to a couple of contacts out that way and her personals were across the street from the scene, including her wallet. Her identification was inside. They have to do an autopsy, but... when a lifted pick-up plows you over at ten at night doing twenty over the speed limit..."

Rio's jaw had nearly come unhinged. The name hadn't been stated, but with the pure glee radiating out of every bit of Agatha's bare skin, Rio didn't really feel like she needed to ask.

"If for whatever reason this ends up not being true, David, I reserve the right to choke you nearly within an inch of your life."

"Agatha," he scolded, clicking his tongue at her. "It's two in the afternoon. I have spent all morning vetting this."

Her eyes lifted to Rio's for the first time since she'd placed herself next to her, that grin nearly splitting her face in two.

"Say it again, Dave. The first thing you said to me when I picked up the phone."

"Rio," he addressed, knowing exactly why Agatha was asking him to repeat it. "Evanora is dead."

There was something about just having an idea and then actually hearing it. Actually hearing it somehow made it feel less real than the idea she had been piecing together in her mind. It was ridiculous, something that seemed like some weird plot twist that no one had been expecting. Rio blinked it into her brain, trying to sink it further and further to somehow make it register.

Agatha's face never shifted, though, that bright and beaming smile lighting up every inch of her expression.

Rio had opened her mouth to say something, but she drew in her breath and an acrid smell filling her nostrils -- fuck!

"I was making breakfast!" she nearly shouted as she flew to her feet and dashed back toward the kitchen. At the sight of the charred sausages and completely inedible eggs, she couldn't even find it in her to be upset about it.

Rio knew what this meant. Rio knew that if anyone else would have witnessed Agatha having this kind of reaction to finding out her mother had been killed after being hit by a car? It seemed ridiculous. She had literally just put this to bed not 48 hours ago. Agatha had taken her power back and she was still donning it like armor.

This, though, was literal insanity.

This was the universe sticking its hand in the matters of humankind.

Evanora had made it her mission to ensure that Agatha's life was nothing short of hell if she had anything to say about it. She had been the sole reason that Agatha had ever gotten on that plane in the first place, the only reason Agatha had left her family behind to put down her past.

This turn of events didn't even feel real, but hearing Dave state it with such conviction made it hard not to believe him.

Rio turned off the burner and pushed the hot pans toward the back of the stovetop; they'd just have to order something instead. Or, maybe this was a call for celebration, depending on how this landed with Agatha over the next twenty minutes.

Once she was sure nothing was going to catch fire, Rio made her way back -- slower this time -- to the bedroom to find Agatha propped up against the headboard, Rio's jersey on her torso, though her legs were still bare. She had been absorbed in her phone screen, but she noticed immediately this time as Rio entered the room again.

As she lifted her head, those beautiful blue eyes were still shining with her emotion, though Rio was waiting with baited breath for the other shoe to drop. The smile she was still wearing did not dim in the least.

"Agatha..." Rio ventured, not wanting to prod too hard but also wanting to make sure that she was alright. This was big. This was something that Rio was sure brought on a flurry of mixed emotions.

She slid onto the bed once more, placing herself next to Agatha, though she refrained from initiating contact simply for the fact that she was trying to gauge what type would be best to field how Agatha was feeling.

Their eyes locked and for a moment, Rio was almost convinced that this was going to devolve into a conversation about every reason Agatha was glad about the situation.

Those eyes started to shine a little more, despite the other woman's best efforts. Agatha's throat bobbed as her lips parted and she tried to find words, words that wouldn't come.

And then, the shine turned to glass. The glass turned into a tidal wave. The tears began to slip down Agatha's face, but she was quick in her movement to make sure that they were the only ones to fall as she wiped them off her own cheeks. It was enough of a show that it helped determine what Rio's next move was.

Lifting her arm, Rio dropped it around Agatha's shoulder and pulled her toward her chest. Agatha nearly folded right into her, placing her head against the front of Rio's shoulder as she let her eyes fall shut. The tears seemed to have been stifled, but she could still feel the tension in Agatha's form.

"It's... It makes me a bad person to be relieved, doesn't it?" Agatha whispered into the fabric of Rio's t-shirt.

"No, baby, it doesn't. The last few days aside, you never deserved what she did to you. A mother is supposed to love unconditionally. You never got to know what that was like, so it's... It only stands to reason that your life now suddenly feels easier at the idea she's no longer around to interfere." One of Rio's hands had moved to smooth over Agatha's hair, trying to help in whatever way she could.

"Plus," Rio added, "the fact that you even question if you're a bad person is enough proof that you aren't."

After only a beat, Agatha began to move, lifting her head so that she could meet Rio's gaze.

"How do you always know the right things to say?" Agatha asked her, the expression on her face reading as something that could have been called mystified.

"Because I know you, my love. I know your heart. I know what you are willing to do to protect the people you love, and you don't even care if that means standing your ground. A bad person would not have had any issue picking up and leaving. A bad person would have done it themselves, taken them out, when in the same country as their aggressor." Rio raised a hand, her fingertips tracing along the curve of Agatha's jaw.

"You're a good person because you handled your shit and the universe decided to hand you what you could never do yourself."

Agatha's head turned and she placed her lips to the center of Rio's palm in a soft kiss of affection. She left them there for a moment before she turned back, her eyes flickering up to find Rio's once again.

"Do you... God, I feel like a fucking asshole." Agatha exhaled a sigh, though she didn't look away. "I'd really like to go to lunch and get a bottle of champagne, if you wouldn't mind."

Rio was not as shocked by this admission as she had briefly considered she might have been. Agatha was really truly free. There were no more surprises, no more wicked turns their paths might take that would have anything to do with Evanora fucking Harkness.

Rio leaned forward, pressing their lips together in a full but warm kiss, pulling away to simply behold Agatha for a moment before she formed her answer.

"I would love to go out to lunch with you and share a bottle of champagne where we can toast to a lifetime of doing whatever the fuck we want without ever worrying about your past coming back to bite us," Rio offered back, as if she were trying to entice Agatha into agreeing to her own idea.

This time, when Agatha's eyes sparkled at her, it was out of nothing but pure affection.

"I love you, Rio," she cooed and Rio's lips simply curled up in response.

"I love you too, Agatha. Let's shower and get dressed. We can go to Soul Bar and maybe indulge in two bottles of champagne if we decide to take an Uber," Rio attempted to goad, as if she really needed to work any harder to convince Agatha.

Something flashed in Agatha's eyes, much like a lightbulb springing to life, an illumination of a forgotten thought.

"Maybe we should go to the dealership first," she offered and for a moment, Rio was confused, but then it hit her too. "I owe Tay a new car."

They had both puddled into laughter and took only a moment to recover so that they could set about their day.

They had done as they had set out to do, settling on something a little similar to what Tay had before, but was definitely a bit of an upgrade with more bells and whistles than she would probably ever need. With it being the main vehicle that could accommodate the five of them, it was as much for everyone else as it was to replace what they'd sort of ruined in the heat of their reunion.

They had turned up at the house to find Estee's car gone and tucked the new SUV into the garage. As they waited out front for the Uber that would take them to the meal that had now evolved for dinner, Rio had decided to text Estee to let her know that they were alive, at the very least.

They had a short back and forth that had closed out with Rio assuring that the two of them would be returning to the house that night so they could all be back together again. She had learned in the conversation that the three of them had been at the market, picking up things to fill the fridge with, which worked out in everyone's favor.

Their celebration dinner had felt just as good to experience as it had to even entertain the idea.

Rio could see it, sitting across that table from her true love, that she was finally liberated. She had finally reached a point of enlightenment in her life where she knew she had to worry about one less person that might ever try to hurt her. Selfishly, Rio was glad. Rio was happy that this was not going to be something that was hanging over their heads for years to come.

Of course she was not so insensitive to announce it aloud; no matter how glib Agatha was acting about this, there were still surely feelings to be had in this regard. This was a lifetime of conflicted emotions, things that she had surely tried to repress in every way she could. Maybe the breakdown would come that night in bed, or maybe it would come a week from that moment, in the middle of the market with a carton of eggs in her hand. Maybe it would be a year down the road, or... It very well could be possible that it just might never come.

Rio did not understand the depths of Agatha's trauma with her mother, and she would never pretend to. What she could do, though, was tread water right beside Agatha, ready at any given moment to jump into action to keep her afloat.

They had not quite finished the second bottle of bubbly by the time they decided to pay the bill and make their way back to the house to meet the kids.

While they were not drunk, Rio and Agatha were just intoxicated enough that sustaining any kind of physical contact had been a necessity. Rio's hand had landed on Agatha's thigh and Agatha had responded by playing with her fingers. Agatha's head had fallen to Rio's shoulder and in turn, Rio had placed her lips to Agatha's hairline. It was this quiet give and take, this balance of just how symbiotic they truly were.

They got out of the back of the car on relatively steady feet as they made their way through the front gate and up the walk, giggling at the idea of what was about to unfold when they walked into that house.

Rio unlocked the door to let them in and they could immediately hear the sounds of...

Those, Rio realized, were the sounds of being home.

The kids were laughing, shouting things that sounded like trivia answers while soft music droned on in the background. As they came around the corner, hand-in-hand, all three of them were absorbed in the trivia game playing on the screen in front of them. Rio and Agatha stood, side by side and just... reveled in it.

Their three children.

Siblings.

Family.

When the round was over, Nicky had announced he was grabbing a drink and asked the girls if they wanted anything but as he got up and turned around, the sight of Rio and his mother startled him.

"Christ! When did you two get in?!" he asked, pressing a hand to his chest as he tried to catch his breath from the way it had left him in his fright.

The girls' heads both whipped around, mirrored grins appearing on beautiful faces.

"Mamas!" the girls chirped in unison and even though it was so casual, Rio caught Estee's eye and shot her a knowing look that practically screamed she was fighting for air at their little trick.
