"Heads up, Tay," Agatha acknowledged, tossing the keys over the space between them, landing snugly in Tay's palms. As she looked down at them, her brow pinched in confusion, her blonde curls falling forward as she studied it.

"Erm..." Tay voiced, almost as if she were afraid to point out the obvious. "These aren't my keys..."

She lifted her head and looked over at the two matriarchs, the confusion completely scribbled across her face.

"Yes they are. The car's in the garage." Agatha's answer was pointed, but it wasn't cold. She was just trying to head off the conversation.

"The one in the garage?" Tay repeated, having already spotted it when they had brought the groceries inside. "That's not my --"

Rio did not miss the way Estee's grip sunk into Tay's arm, as if willing her to absolutely not press this conversation any further. Tay's head snapped toward her girlfriend, but Estee's face was soft in its pleading, but Tay was not getting it.

"Please babe, just take the keys and say thank you," Estee nearly begged her.

All at once, Tay's posture stiffened slightly as the realization hit her. Her lips pressed together and even though she couldn't see Tay's face, she could see enough of Estee's to tell that they were torn on wanting to call them absolute heathens and embracing the perk of a brand new vehicle to drive.

Tay's head turned back, though her smile was not pained or awkward.

"Thank you, Agatha," Tay offered, trying to hide her mixed emotions over the gift, but ultimately she truly was thankful.

"It's good to have you home, Agatha," Estee told her, tilting her head at her sweetly.

"It's good to be home. I missed all of you," Agatha stated, but before she could think to say anything else, Nicky was on his way over, walking right into his mother's arms. Rio felt warm from head to toe as she watched the exchange; it was so vastly different from the first time she had witnessed a sight so similar.

As Agatha let him go, though, both of her hands landed on his cheeks, her eyes searching his face as she debated how best to deliver the news she had to serve.

Rio watched with vested interest as Agatha looked from Nicky to the girls, her gaze finally casting next to her, landing on Rio. The way Agatha was looking at her, she was looking for that little push, that touch of encouragement that said this was the right thing to do.

Rio gave the gentlest nod, tipping forward in a silent push.

Agatha's eyes landed back on her son as her lips pressed together.

"Evanora was hit by a car last night," Agatha admitted out loud, and Nicky's eyes widened immediately, huge at the realization. "She's dead."

The silence in that room was the loudest thing Rio had ever heard, and it lay there for a long several moments before Estee was the one who decided to break it.

"What... What does that mean?" she posed, her voice unusually small, though her eyes hadn't left Agatha's face.

Meeting her gaze, Agatha's lips curled in the softest smile.

"It means that if I ever have to leave again, the option for one or all of you to follow me doesn't have to be tabled for your safety."

It happened so fast: Estee's jaw bulged and her throat quivered as she fought back the urge to cry. She succeeded pretty quickly, but Rio knew.

"It means that my lifetime nightmare will never inflict pain on this family ever again. That's my promise to all four of you," Agatha voiced as she stepped back, looping an arm over Rio's shoulders.

"And..." Agatha added, a bright twinkle in her eyes. "That means we have a wedding to start planning!"

Chapter End Notes

well tbh this is 100% an instance of this story just telling itself. but ding dong the witch is dead??

Glory/Us

All tied in one
Honesty waits here forever
I've been undone
Glory and us come together
*****

There was something about the way the evening settled around them as the children tucked into their own spots on that massive sectional that filled the majority of the living room that solidified of piece of Rio's heart in her chest, an acceptance of the fact that this was actually a life she had attained.

Nicky had fetched everyone snacks and beverages and the girls had situated themselves on either wise of the women, Tay sidled up next to Agatha and Estee curled right into her mother's side. Nicky, once he had finished the task her set out to accomplish had placed himself on the ottoman in front of the four women, leaning forward on his thighs as he cracked open his soda.

Agatha had pulled out her phone and was flipping through pictures, settling on one that she had previously mentioned in conversation with Rio. She held it up, showing the photo that was on display; It was Agatha who was holding the phone, but her arm was around a younger man who was quite handsome with that rugged jaw that was covered in stubble and piercing blue eyes that were several shades closer to white than Agatha's. His arm was around a smaller woman that fit perfectly into his side.

"That is Jack," Agatha indicated, mostly to Rio so that she was able to put a face to the name she had heard many times. "And that --" She had started to indicate the woman under his arm, but Estee was quick to cut her off.

"Is that Thea Landon? From the show Eleven Hours?!" At this, Tay seemed to crane in to get a better view of the photo.

"It is," Agatha confirmed, and without even looking over at her, Rio knew that she was grinning ear to her.

"How?!" Estee asked, her bright eyes sweeping up to Agatha in amazement.

Instead of answering her, Agatha reached up with a finger and swiped to the next picture. In a word? That photo was pure chaos. There were a good almost twenty other people in it. At the back stood Agatha under the arm of a taller, older man. He had grey hair and the same colored stubble, but he looked like an absolute rockstar. On her other side, a slightly smaller woman was hugging Agatha's side beneath her arm.

Around them were about eight faces that shared similarities to the adults on either side of Agatha to confirm that they were likely their children. Rio recognized them only through the story Agatha had told her about going over there, about spending time with them.

The girls had no such knowledge, and this was evident by the way they both devolved into bewildered shrieks of surprise.

"You know the Landons?!" Estee squealed, nearly leaning completely over Rio to try and get a better view.

"No way, how?!" Tay voiced, repeating Estee's earlier question.

"Jack and I have been friends for a couple of years, now, simply by brushing elbows. But Walker and I? We go way back. He's been a song writer on a great deal of my original soundtracks. He's... an amazing musician. And he's a pretty great dad, too."

"Yeah, doesn't he have like ten kids or something wild like that?" Estee posed, her eyes transfixed on Agatha's face as she asked, as if she already couldn't wait to have the answer.

"Nine, but he also adopted and raised his younger brother," she informed them, exhaling a gentle laugh. "The youngest five are all quintuplets. Thea, Jack's girlfriend, is the youngest of the lot."

"Yeah, but she's also definitely the meanest," Nicky shot with a laugh.

"No, she's just mean to you because you're more annoying than her own brothers," Agatha shot back pointedly, though the immediate grin she was wearing was a clear indicator of her teasing.

"Aren't all of their kids stupid famous?" Tay asked, her eyes ust as fixed on Agatha, enchanted by this side of her life that they had not been privy to up until that point.

Rio had been of the understanding that Agatha had likely rubbed shoulders with powerful people and important names, but to Rio? Estee did not try to mince words when calling her out for the amount of media she had consumed in her life that was not filmed out in the wild. It could have been said that perhaps she was a little uncultured, which would explain why she was not completely losing her mind with them.

"The oldest is a musician," Nicky had started, but Agatha was quick with a follow up.

"Who I also love to tap into when it comes to creative artistry. When I need something heavier, Walker's always my first call, but Liz is... She's incredible at what she does," she explained.

"Right, we've been listening to her since we were in high school," Estee gushed.

At this, realization snapped itself quickly over Rio's face.

"Wait, is that the one that I had to buy you the same CD three different times because you guys kept taking it back and forth between houses and scratching the mickey out of it?" Rio posed, and the girls burst into laughter at the memory.

"Yep," Tay confirmed, "That's the one."

"Oh, well shit."

Agatha's own mega-watt grin softened only out of tenderness as she turned her head to place a soft kiss to the side of Rio's head before she turned her attention back to her phone.

"That's one of the older twin boys. His name is Rhys and he is a photographer for Vogue. He used to work for Alternative Press, but he climbed the ladder," her fingertip landed just below his chin to indicate who she was speaking about. "He has an identical twin that plays for the Indianapolis Colts."

"This is... unreal," Estee managed, something just louder than a breath. "Like, we obviously knew that you were famous... but holy shit."

"The next oldest is Dalia," she indicated, zooming in on two women; the one with the lighter hair looked incredibly similar to the matriarch of the clan and the other, taller girl was nearly holding onto her for dear life. "That's her wife, Cole, with her. Dalia does a lot of charity work with a lot of the local LGBT shelters and Cole is one of the most esteemed trauma therapists in the state."

There was an affection on Agatha's face as she looked down at the two women and Rio gave her a gentle nudge in the ribs, as if to ask: penny for your thoughts?

Agatha glanced at her, then back to the photo.

"Their story, when they told it at their wedding... God, it was so beautiful. Literally something I would salivate at the idea of adapting, but also something I would never touch out of respect for who they are and what they came from." Agatha stilled for a moment, her eyes casting down to Rio for just a moment; this was going to hurt to hear as much as it was going to hurt to recount it, if for no other reason than the fact that they were mothers and they understood.

"Cole came from a very broken foster system, and she was a fighter. The day they met, it was because Cole chased some boys off of harassing Dalia. One night, the Landons were coming home from a birthday dinner and Dalia spotted her outside of a club." Agatha took a breath, that warm smile still on her face. "She talked Walker into picking her up and he ended up letting her stay the night. They... they went through a lot of really heavy shit for teenagers, but Cole will look you in the face and not blink when she tells you that becoming a Landon is one of the biggest accomplishments of her life."

"That's actually fucking adorable?" came Tay's voice, a little laden with emotion.

"What makes it hilarious," Nicky chimed in, "is that when you meet them separately, you would never guess that they're together, let alone married. Cole tries to make herself seem so tough and hard toward anyone she doesn't know that isn't a patient, and then D is literally sunshine in human form. It's pretty hilarious."

"So, wait," Estee interjected, finally catching on. "You hang out with them?" Her eyes widened slightly, but then narrowed. "And you never thought to tell us?! Nick! You suck!"

The moment she hurled the last playful jab, she also pulled the pillow from behind her and threw that at him, too.

"I mean, when I'm in town, I like hanging out with Wyatt and Dustin! But ever since Dustin started dating the girl that is Cinderella at Disneyland..."

"Wait..." Rio cut in this time, her brow pinching slightly. "I thought I was doing a pretty good job of keeping up, but what?"

Agatha locked her phone and leaned back, wrapping an arm around Rio's shoulders to pull her in a little closer.

"When you have nine kids dating and or married to nine different people, stories get pretty wild," Agatha offered, her light laugh so sweet and affectionate as it hit the air around them. "Trust me, Walker and I have a standing deal that should they ever decide to go the biography route, I'm the first call he will make."

"Hm," Rio mused, sneaking a glance up at Agatha from beneath her lashes, a small smirk curling her lips. "Sound like a standing deal that you might have with someone else attached to the Landons," she prodded, digging a gentle but teasing finger into Agatha's ribs.

"Wait!" Estee cried out, a hand flying out to land on her mother's forearm. Her head whipped around, eyes darting from Agatha to Rio and then back to Agatha again. "Does that mean... that you'd invite them to the wedding?!" Her eyes shifted down, looking across at Tay as if they were going to be floored if Agatha said yes.

Agatha, however, took a beat of measured silence as she best figured out how to answer that.

It was not something the two of them, as a couple, had actually discussed yet. They had known there would be time to have those conversations, but Agatha had not been expecting it to come up so soon, she wasn't quite sure how to field the answer.

"That's something we're going to talk about..." Agatha had started, but Rio was quick to pick up where she had left it.

"Tonight," she added, her eyes finding Estee's with a soft smile on her face.

Estee's head dropped onto Rio's shoulder and she squeezed Rio's hand between both of her own, holding it tightly, a silent line of communication that she was happy, that she felt safe, and that things in their lives had finally turned out alright. It had been a long time coming for the two of them, and it had been one hell of a road to get there, but they had finally reached the precipice and all that laid before them was majestic and regal in sight.

With Agatha in their lives, everything had fallen into place.

With Agatha around, life just seemed to make sense.

The five of them had sat, milling about in idle conversation as the night seemed to wind down around them. The sun had disappeared from the sky and there was nothing but milky twilight visible out the floor-to-ceiling windows. It was the closing of another day in which they were all going to fall asleep under the same room.

"Wait!" Rio pressed suddenly, her eyes a little wide. "You know what I just realized?!"

Three pairs of eyes fell on her in question, but Agatha's grip around her shoulders tightened as Rio felt her lips press to the side of her head. It was almost as if she knew what Rio was going to say.

"It's our first night here... all together..." Rio remarked, the amazement of the realization so warm over her words.

"While we did leave a couple of boxes that not a one of us had any desire to open," Estee divulged, "we did get most of the clothes put away, as well as the bed made so that you wouldn't have to worry about it when you got back."

Rio's middle warmed and she leaned just barely out of Agatha's weight so that she could kiss her daughter on the forehead.

"You three..." Rio began, wonder in her voice. "You are all just something else."

Nicky's eyes found Rio's across the space between them and those lips hitched up in an earnest smile.

"We just know that when we're all together, it's the best it can be. We know that... it's been a lot and so if we could see to it that, after making everything happen for each of us like this, you could come home and just... be? Well, we didn't mind."

Rio had watched him, rapt for a moment as she listened to him speak, really heard what he was saying.

That was the thing with Nicky; the words he chose were important yes, but the conversation he had with his eyes? The way he said so much while still physically saying comparatively much less? His words themselves were heavy with his intent, but that look in his eyes as he didn't budge from Rio's gaze moved something in her.

What Rio had not clocked was how Estee was watching the man across from them, nearly holding her breath. It was like there was something unspoken between them, like she was waiting for what might come next.

"I know this might seem out of place, or like maybe it isn't the right time..." he began, and while his lids fluttered and Rio thought he might look away, he did not. Instead, he kept going. "But... this... this is what I dreamed of as a kid. This was what I wanted. And I got it because my mom fell in love with you. I..." his lips twisted a moment, but his face smoothed, even softening before he found his voice again. "I would be remiss if I didn't take a moment to tell you that I love you too, mama."

If there had been absolutely any hope of Rio holding back her tears? It had completely sailed out the window with his delivered sentiment and that soft inflection over the term she was so used to hearing from her own girls. The tears welled, hot and emotional, before they slipped down Rio's cheeks. While she was stunned to stillness for a moment, she finally found her cognizance and lunged forward, getting to her feet.

Nicky read the reaction in the blink of an eye and got to his feet, too, already braced for the way Rio nearly launched herself into an embrace around his middle, her cheek pressed to his chest as the tears still streamed down it.

Behind her on the couch, Agatha was struggling to choke down her own tears that were threatening to devastate her in the sweetest way.

They had come a long way from him looking her in the eye and telling her he would never respect Rio as any kind of a parent, and he had just addressed her as such of his own voalition.

Before Agatha could win that battle, though, the grip on her left tightened and just as quickly, Estee filled the space where Rio had been, immediately dropping her head to land on Agatha's shoulder. "And we love you too, mum," Estee murmured at her, eliciting another tightening of Tay's old on Agatha's arm.

In the same breath, the same exact moment, two voices sounded from feet apart with different intended targets.

"Te amo, mijo," Rio murmured softly.

And at the exact same moment:

"I love you, girls."

It was the softest symphony of a promise, a guarantee that what they had was unbreakable. While Tay was the exception, both of their biological children had spent half or all of their lives with one parent, one support system to keep them propped up and on the right path in the world.

In what had apparently been a conversation between them, they had come to the conclusion that with things headed where they were, and a wedding on the horizon, it was okay to accept the inevitable.

Did Rio think he might use that term every time he addressed her from there on out? Of course not, but the fact that he had taken it upon himself to show the initiative truly touched her.

It had been a smooth transition as they all untangled and Rio and Agatha announced that they were going to turn in for the night. The embraces had been exchanged, heads had been kissed once a piece and the children had declared they were going to watch a movie before they themselves decided to turn in.

They bid the three of them a good night and headed up the stairs, still a little buzzed, hand in hand to head to their new safe haven.

As Agatha flipped on the light, Rio's eyes swept around the room, taking in the sight of it. The bed was put together and made, the dressers adorned with photographs that the kids had placed in frames. There were three in total; one was of the five of them, and the other two were photos of Rio and Agatha that Rio immediately realized neither of them had been aware of.

In each of them, though, despite the setting around them?

The only sun they cared to stare into was the soul of the other.

As Rio scooped one up to look down at it, she felt Agatha's arms around her middle as she tucked her chin over Rio's shoulder to peer down at what was in her hands.

"That's definitely a Nicky shot. Must have been when we went to the island," she commented in a gentle murmur, though she only punctuated her statement by tucking her face into Rio's neck, placing a soft kiss there. Rio slowly set the frame back down and reached up behind her to cradle the back of Agatha's head in her palm.

Slowly, Rio shifted, turning around in her grasp. She raised a finger, tracing it down the slope of Agatha's nose, just a gentle show of affection and appreciation.

In classic Agatha fashion, as Rio's touch dropped to pass Agatha's lips, she moved quickly enough to catch Rio's finger between the teeth, though the hold was only momentary. She released, a grin pulling at her lips as she tilted her head at Rio.

"You're positively rotten, sometimes," Rio cooed at her, though she leaned toward her to give a soft kiss.

"But you love me," Agatha posed back, the playful challenge audible in her tone.

"Without question."

They shared in another kiss and then took a moment to just... take in their room. There were pieces of art propped up against the walls that Rio was sure Agatha had ordered and other little knick-knacks were placed in the exact spots Rio would have wanted them in. It was clear that the kids had taken their time, had wanted to make sure that they could help in whatever way the could.

The care that they had taken to make this into another home for their mothers was moving in a way Rio almost felt undeserving of.

They'd ended up in the closet, which was almost large enough to be another bedroom entirely, and Rio truly was struck with just how amazed she was by how absolutely perfect this place was for them. Agatha had clearly put a lot of time and attention into making this happen, and she had done an amazing job.

After changing into sleepwear -- t-shirts and panties -- they had slid into their respective spots that they filled whenever they got in any bed together. It was routine, it was habit. It was their normal.

While Rio was normally the one who seemed so easily to fall into Agatha, it was Agatha's turn this time to melt into her fiance, causing Rio's arm to move only to secure Agatha against her side. As her head tilted back against the headboard, her eyes slid shut and she just let it all fall around them.

She was stuck again, in that frame of mind where she was still finding it so hard to believe that this was what her life had become. There had been so many nights when she would stir from a dream in a cold sweat, confused as to why there wasn't someone next to her. They had been more frequent when she had been younger, but they had never truly stopped the older she got.

Now, the only days since they'd been reunited that they'd been apart had been the three days it had taken Agatha to go to LA and come back. Now, when she woke up from those dreams? The dreams had become about Agatha, and Agatha was there when she opened her eyes. Even more than that, she was steadily against Rio's side, or only inches away.

Gone were the days when Rio had to find comfort and solace in being alone.

Now, as she lowered her chin, she had the woman she loved asking her a very loaded, but very sentimental question.

"Where do you want to get married?" Agatha posed, her soft tones barely above a whisper.

Rio's fingers absentmindedly began to trace light shapes on Agatha's upper arm as she began to think. That was... a pretty big question. If asked, Rio would have said they could have gotten married on that bridge for all she cared, just the five of them and someone to officiate, and she would have been fine with that. She sensed that Agatha was asking for a reason, though.

"It's really... Saying it doesn't matter doesn't feel right," Rio explained, turning to nuzzle into Agatha's hair as she continued. "But... if you're asking me if I'd rather here or LA... I don't think that I would have a preference. Yes, this has been home, but that will be home, too, you know?"

She could feel Agatha's cheek pull up in a smile against her chest.

"There's a place... it's in the mountains. A couple of years ago the fires did a lot of damage, but the blooms came back for the first time this year." There was this cute little hike in her voice, like there was more to it than she was able to explain in this conversation. "So, depending on how long we wanted to wait... they'll be at peak in April."

Rio's smile was instant and she breathed the softest chuckle into Agatha's hair.

"You want to get married in six months?" Rio cooed at her, the whispered words still holding a sing-song cadence to them.

"I'd marry you tomorrow if I thought it practical," Agatha murmured back at her, exhaling a soft sigh.

"And would this be a very large and very grand wedding per the nature of your status?" Rio teased, her lips brushing barely against Agatha's scalp as she spoke, though it seemed to elicit a shiver.

At this, Agatha pulled back to look at her, studying her for a long moment before she formed her answer.

"At max, I'd like fifty people. I don't know if we'd hit that number, but if we invite every Landon and their partners, we'd already be pushing over twenty. And of course Tay's parents are more than welcome and..."

"We don't," Rio answered before Agatha could ask if they had anyone else they would want to be included.

While Agatha's lips turned down at the corners for a brief moment, she understood it. She always had.

"But it's okay, because we have the only people we have ever needed right here with us," Rio informed her, raising a hand to curl her finger beneath the corner of Agatha's jaw. She held her there for just a moment before she leaned toward her, placing their lips together lightly in a neat kiss.

Agatha peered into her, trying to read her, just trying to listen. Judging by the look on her face, she wasn't fairing well and so she decided to speak the question aloud.

"What do you want in all of this?" she posed, and while Rio understood the context in which she was asking, that was not the vein in which she chose to answer.

"I want to walk down an aisle where you're at the end waiting for me. I want to hold your hands as I look you in the eye and promise to tie my life to yours for as long as I continue to breathe. I want to put a gorgeous ring on your finger, kiss you, and call you my wife." Rio paused, taking in the look on Agatha's face which registered somewhere between rapt and taken. "Everything else? Those are just semantics."

Agatha's expression was so soft, so vulnerable, and it almost seemed like she might have hit an emotional epiphany, but she took a slow breath and closed the gap between them again, their lips crushing with a tender gentleness that was only slightly familiar to them. The longer they kissed the more Rio began to taste salt on her lips.

Another moment passed before she pulled back, her eyes opening to take in the sight of Agatha who had glistening streams down her cheeks.

"Hey, hey," Rio soothed, affectionately brushing her thumb over Agatha's lips. "It's okay, what's wrong?"

Agatha's eyes opened into her own, but they were not upset or worried. Those eyes were not panicked or scared. Those eyes were full of deep emotion and a lack of a way to try and communicate it.

"I'm just so lucky," Agatha murmured at her, so close that Rio could taste the remnants of the champagne on her breath.

"Yeah?" Rio whispered back."Why's that?" She tipped her head just enough to steal another soft kiss before she allowed Agatha to continue.

"Because of all the people in this entire world, you chose me."

Rio's own eyes threatened to spill, but she somehow managed to blink the flood back, settling herself.

"Oh, Agatha. I'd choose you every single time. Every. Time."

All to Myself

On top of the mountain screamin', sky-high with an ocean view
I hope somebody sees me, I hope it's you
Like hanging clothes out to dry, I put it all on the line
Your hand fit perfect in mine, all this must be by design
*****

As the weeks started to come and go in a faster fashion than they ever had, the more their little family began to fall into a routine. Rio was able to devote more time to her drone project, which left a slightly directionless Agatha to try to busy herself. But, more often than not, she ended up in Rio's office on the couch with a book or a magazine, or sometimes she pretended to scroll through her phone, but Rio always caught her staring.

"What is it this time?" she would ask every time.

Every single time, Agatha had a different answer.

"I was just looking at the poster on the wall."

"I can see the little wrinkles in your brow that look like the number eleven. I think you're working too hard."

"Oh, nothing, just that if you bite your lip any harder, you're going to make it bleed."

"I was just thinking about cheese rolls. Should I go get some?"

Usually, by the fourth or fifth question, Rio would cave and place herself in Agatha's lap to pay her a few minutes of the attention her restless brain seemed to be craving. They would kiss and giggle, they would whisper silly promises as they brushed the tips of their noses together.

Most mornings, Rio still had a thirty second adjustment period where she would open her eyes and struggle to place where she was, or what kind of life she was living. All it took was rolling over to see Agatha -- either on her side facing away or on her stomach with fingertips less than an inch from Rio's form -- and everything came falling back into place.

She was in bed next to her fiance, in their massive house while their children slept in the other rooms. She was in a healthy and loving relationship with a woman who had been ripped straight out of a dream. They had three children that loved them both in equal measure. What more could Rio have possibly asked for when her life felt so perfect?

Estee and Tay's graduation had rapidly approached, and the five of them had boarded a flight to attend. Rio was certain that the image of their little troupe hustling through the airport had been one for the ages, but she couldn't have tamed just how happy that kind of chaos made her. It was brief flashes of her hand in Agatha's as she led the pack, chin high and hair blowing behind her from the force of her gait. Rio scrambling behind her trying to keep up. Nicky and Tay practically carrying Estee who was still a little slow-going despite the progress she had been making in regard to her leg. The group of them getting into their seats, only minorly bickering about who got aisle and who got window.

Watching Estee and Tay walk across that stage, accomplishing something they had worked years for? Rio had been convinced that she was going to be the only one looking like an emotional fool, the moment Agatha wrapped an arm around her and laid her head against Rio's, Rio had been able to feel the shake of her crying, too. When they looked at each other, Rio was moved by the sheer emotion in those beautiful blue eyes.

"I'm so proud of her." Agatha's sincerity coated her words like thick honey, clingy and sweet.

"Me too."

Instead of flying back that night, they'd decided on a couple of hotel rooms at the Crowne Plaza -- three, actually, at Nicky's behest despite the fact that the girls said they could behave themselves -- and had swiped several bottles of champagne to celebrate. Rio and Agatha had offered to take them out, but instead they requested to order take-out from Flame. They had all convened in Rio and Agatha's room to share their meal and their champagne, and Agatha had pointed out that the food was very reminiscent of American BBQ, and even though she hadn't mocked Rio like she could have, it still earned her a bemused glare from bright green eyes.

There had been something so serene about that evening, even as everyone tucked away to their own rooms, Rio and Agatha both pulling each of the girls into tight hugs to tell them how impossibly proud of them they were, and how their lives were just beginning.

Unsurprisingly, Nicky had taken the opportunity to be his usual smartass self.

"Yeah, you guys did okay I guess," before that face-splitting grin cracked his face nearly in half and the girls each reached with one hand to give him a playful push.

It was moments like that, moments where the pieces of their lives had fallen into place and the whole masterpiece was visible, where Rio was left breathless. Sometimes, she often wondered if even the children had been siblings in a past life, because the bond they had managed to build with complete and utter ease? It was incredible. It was astounding.

As it turned out, the longer time wore on, the more of those she got. And Rio ate up every last one.

It had been six weeks since Agatha had returned home and their lives felt settled and yet, still somehow chaotic.

That morning in particular, Rio had woken up to an empty bed -- something that made her frown and grumble concurrently -- but it had only taken a moment for her senses to kick in. Judging by the smell wafting throughout the house, Agatha was cooking breakfast.

After her typical morning routine of stretching, brushing her hair and teeth and making sure she was appropriately dressed, Rio made her way downstairs to see Agatha in the kitchen, where she knew she would be. Although it had been a couple of weeks since she'd last seen the sight, Rio couldn't fight her grin at the sight of Agatha with her All Blacks kit on, her hair twisted up into a disastrous bun toward the top of her head. It was a casualty of war when one had that much hair.

Silently on soft footsteps, Rio carried herself toward the counter, noiselessly slipping onto the stool as she propped her chin on the palm of her hand, just... watching.

As she knew would come, Agatha started humming a tune -- one that Rio recognized as a love song she'd given Agatha shit for knowing -- as she tended to the work in front of her. Leaning just slightly to the side, Rio could see that she was making pancakes. As Agatha shifted to the right, Rio's eyes landed on the large pile of them that had accumulated up to that point in her progress.

It was funny, really. For years, breakfast was cereal or granola and a cup of coffee. Not since Agatha had been around. Even that first morning, Rio wouldn't have typically cooked a breakfast, but she'd wanted desperately to find a way to keep her around, even if it had failed.

Now, Agatha made her pancake batter from scratch, she picked up eggs from the farmer that lived ten minutes down the road, always trying to barter with him to get an extra bottle of milk by promising him she'd bake him whatever cake he wanted. It always worked.

The humming continued and Rio's smile only seemed to grow. This was what she had been missing out on her whole life. If twenty of years of isolation meant that she got it now, and every day for the rest of her life? She was more than okay with that. Ideally, they had the next five to six decades to sit beside one another and watch as the world moved around them.

Agatha moved the pan to the back burner almost at the same time her left hand flipped the last pancake onto the stack. She turned to head for the refrigerator, but out of the corner of her eye, she caught sight of Rio and nearly jumped out of her skin.

"Jesus fucking Christ, Rio!" she managed, her hand flying to her chest in some attempt to still her now wildly beating heart.

Rio's giggles were instant, a feigned look of guilt writing itself across her face. "I'm sorry!" she pushed, though she didn't mean it even one bit.

"How long have you been sitting there?!" Agatha nearly shrieked, her eyes still wide though Rio could see in her face that she was simply more startled than she was upset.

"Maybe five minutes. Or however long it took you to cook the last two pancakes."

Agatha rolled her eyes, her jaw set as if she were trying to keep up that air of irritation, but Rio knew her better than that. Before they could engage in any further back and forth, a duo of sing-song greetings met them.

"Good morning!" came the sweet sounds of Tay and Estee's voices.

In the same vein, they were met with a harmony of "Good morning, girls," from both Rio and Agatha.

"Mmmm, smells good. Pancakes?" Estee asked as she and Tay both moved to take seats on the stools on either side of Rio.

"Of course. I also managed a small jar of Khia syrup from the farmer yesterday. He said it's really sweet, though, so to use it sparingly," Agatha advised as she began to move about, grabbing plates and silverware before she set them on the counter top. A moment later, the stack of pancakes was next to them and the syrup and butter sat next to them.

"Help yourselves," she offered. She turned toward the coffee pot and began fixing herself and Rio each a cup of coffee.

Black for Rio, as always, and cream for herself. Always.

As Agatha finished making her own plate, her eyes fell to the remaining plate, a wrinkle forming in her brow. Rio knew what she was going to ask before it left her lips.

"Is Nicky still sleeping?" she asked, her brow pinching a bit more.

This, to Rio, was a perfectly normal question that should have had a perfectly normal answer. But as the girls failed to respond and Rio turned to look from one of them toward the other, the sheepish smiles that were almost echoes of each other formed on their faces.

"Erm, that's not an answer?" Agatha responded, her brow quirking in silent demand for compliance.

"You lot went out last night?" Rio posed, tearing off a piece of her pancake before popping it into her mouth, her eyes landing on Estee, head tipping in interrogation.

"We did."

"And... you two came home... and Nicky went where?" Rio pushed a little harder.

Tay cleared her throat, almost like she was trying to not let their grilling shake Estee's loyalty. The hotter Rio's gaze grew, though, the quicker she started to melt beneath it.

"Okay! We've been going to The Mothership for the last few weeks... And two weeks ago, he met someone."

The moment Rio's jaw dropped, Agatha's eyebrows shot up, creasing her forehead in multiple spots. The shock between the both of them was completely palpable in the air around them. Rio sensed there was more, though, so she eased back on her stool, but her unwavering gaze encouraged her daughter to keep going.

"His name is Hmi. He's Mori and he is very handsome," Estee admitted, and although Tay almost immediately started speaking, Rio's gaze had already cut back to Agatha who was wearing an expression that was a perfect mixture of shocked and proud.

"And he's really funny," Tay added. "Nicky said he thought he could be home in time for breakfast, but clearly he did not manage to make that happen."

Agatha's eyes dropped to her plate as she tore a piece of pancake off and tossed it into her mouth, chewing thoughtfully for a moment.

Rio was watching her like a hawk, studying her every movement, trying to discern what was going on up there in that head of hers. She didn't look angry, or upset. In fact... she looked... happy. Her gaze shifted to Agatha's hand as she grabbed her mug and took a long pull of her coffee, despite how hot it was.

"You know what?" she said as she lowered the mug to the counter. "Good for him."

In the exact same second, four grins spread across the room like a brush fire.

"He was going to tell you," Estee told Agatha, the honesty clearly written on her face. "He just wanted to make sure it was something worth telling first."

At this, Agatha softened and Rio understood it immediately. He had spent a large part of his youth watching her parade women in and out of their home, never making an appearance twice. To him, it had seemed like she was shoving it in his face, but she'd been so deep in her own need to fix herself that she hadn't taken him into consideration. For him to state so plainly that he didn't want to do that to her, or even the two of them, it was a shining example of how his character had evolved through dealing with his trauma.

Agatha took another sip of her coffee, something Rio realized immediately was both a stalling tactic and a way for her to literally swallow down her emotions. She knew that Agatha was undoubtedly happy for him, but that little piece of information had settled a little uncomfortably within her. Still, as she lowered the mug, that stunning smile returned to her face.

"I'm really happy for him. And I hope he brings Hmi over some time. We would love to meet him." Her answers were a little political, but Rio knew that she was still processing. Agatha's eyes flickered with a little bit of light as she looked between the two girls a couple of moments before she posed her next question. "Is he very handsome, or is he very handsome?"

The girls burst into laughter, Estee even dropping her fork.

"I love that the gauge of how attractive a man is ranges from very handsome to very handsome," Estee managed through her laughter.

At this, even Rio joined in to the foray of laughs.

"We are lesbians," Agatha asserted over the rim of her mug and the laughter only doubled, a bellowing and brightly beautiful sound.

The rest of the meal had been pretty tame in opposition to the way it had started, but Rio eventually moved to clean up, rinsing the plates off before she put them in the dishwasher. Agatha had busied herself with refilling their coffees and Estee and Tay had declared that they were going to go to the beach and that anyone was welcome to join them, Nicky included if he ever returned home.

This had gotten a laugh out of the older women, but they had wished the two of them a good day as they departed with their beach bags slung over their shoulders.

The moment that door shut, Rio had reached up to turn off the tap, but she did little else before she felt Agatha's arms as they wrapped around her middle. She felt every single place that the front of Agatha's body pressed to her back, including the cheek that was pressed to her shoulder. Although it did feel nice, Rio understood it for what it actually was.

Agatha was processing. She had done an incredible job of keeping the mask up in front of the girls, but now that they were alone, she knew she had permission to crumble a little.

Rio's right hand raised and landed on Agatha's arm, brushing softly at the skin there. "Do you want to talk about it?" she asked her softly, turning her head just enough so that her lips could brush the part of Agatha's forehead she could reach.

There was no verbal answer. Instead, she received a tightening of the grip around her waist and her eyes fell shut, a slow breath drawing into her lungs.

Slowly, she shifted, though she found a way to do so without making Agatha break her grip completely. She leaned back against the counter and reached up to cradle Agatha's jaw in both of her palms, looking her in the eyes.

"I know that was a bittersweet thing to hear, and I know it hurt you. But... As hard as it might be to see it this way, he's learning from your mistakes. I'm not saying that you're not allowed to have very valid emotions about it, but he's acknowledging that he doesn't want you to feel the way he felt," Rio tried to explain. She had no idea if she was right, but it seemed like the most logical explanation.

"I know," Agatha muttered softly, her lips turning down at the corners. "It's just not something he should have had to learn at all. And as much as I can claim to be over it, I am sure there will always be interspersed moments like this where I realize that the things that make him a great human are the things I was never capable of."

At this, Rio's eyes began to sting.

"Agatha," she admonished softly, her thumb moving to brush at her cheek tenderly. "You cannot do that to yourself. And never is a very strong word. Maybe it was something you couldn't have done before, but you do it every day that you wake up and choose me, and our family."

Rio almost felt it before she saw it, the single tear that dropped out of Agatha's eye and hit the topmost part of her thumb which stopped it before it could go any further.

"I really do work on forgiving myself for what I put him through, but I can't stop feeling like he will never not hold it over me. And I know that this isn't that, exactly, but... What I chose to do, selfishly, has clearly impacted how he operates in his day to day life. That's just.. a little hard to swallow sometimes, I guess is all."

Rio gave a gentle tug on Agatha's face, pulling her close enough that they could press their lips together in a gentle kiss, one she let communicate the forgiveness Agatha needed to be giving herself. After a moment, she pulled away, those beautiful blue eyes opening into her own.

"Be kinder to yourself. You've made incredible strides with him the last several months. He doesn't mean harm, he's just... careful. And if that's the worst trait he picked up along the way? He's not doing half bad," she tried, and this seemed to settle into Agatha with a little more weight. It registered on her face as she looked at it through the perspective that Rio was offering.

"I.. It's just..." Even as she tried, Rio could see that Agatha was having a hard time fighting the logic. She knew Rio was right, and she admitted as much. "You're right. I just think that I project my own ability to not forgive myself onto him and assume that he would stoop to my level because I raised him."

"But," Rio countered, "It's because you raised him that he chose a different path. He loves us, and he just wants to make sure it's worth bringing home to the parents."

Agatha's lips twitched up slightly and Rio could see in her eyes as what she'd had to say began to sink in.

"How do you do that?" Agatha asked and Rio's grin was instant.

"I put myself in your shoes and I tell you all the things I would need to hear, hard or not, to know that I'm still a good mom." Rio leaned toward her again, stealing the softest kiss before she pulled back to gaze across at her.

Before she spoke again, Agatha leaned in and kissed her again. This one was a little harder, a little warmer, a little more full with the intent of making sure Rio knew exactly how she felt about her.

"I love you more than anything," Agatha breathed against her lips and Rio's own curled up into a small smile.

"Not more than I love you."

Such Great Heights

I am thinking it's a sign
That the freckles in our eyes
Are mirror images and when we kiss
They're perfectly aligned
*****

"I've booked the tickets! The flight leaves Friday morning at six, which would put us in LA roughly around ten at night." Rio could almost hear the excitement in Agatha's voice as she shut her laptop and swiveled in her chair to face Rio where she was laid across the couch in the office, knees pulled up and a book resting on them.

Oh, and she was wearing her glasses. She'd only put them on after Agatha had turned around and set to her task of creating them an itinerary for their trip to America.

"You little devil," Agatha nearly hissed, but she somehow managed to keep some integrity to her tone.

Rio simply lifted her eyes from her book and glanced toward her fiance, the corners of her lips pushing up in the smallest smile, a very coy one for how innocent she tried to play it off.

"So," Rio began, moving to close the book in her lap and straightening out her legs, leaning back to stretch against the arm of the couch. "I expect you are going to run me ragged in our five days there?" Though her words were taunting, her tone was still sweet. It was only accentuated by the slight tip of her head to the side in an inquisitorial manner.

"Well..." Agatha offered back as she got to her feet and padded over to the couch. She reached down and hooked a hand under Rio's far leg, lifting with ease. She was clearly delighted as Rio lifted the other of her own accord so that Agatha could place herself beneath them, letting those toned calves fall across the tops of her thighs. "We have two venue viewings on Saturday, but I made them both in the afternoon so that we could sleep in a little if we're too jetlagged." Agatha's hand raised, but only to drop two fingers so that she could trace light lines up and down the surface of Rio's shin.

"So thoughtful," Rio teased softly, though a giggle tumbled from her not a moment later. The arm that was closest to the back of the couch raised so that Rio could slide her fingers through the hair on the back of Agatha's head, nails lightly dragging over her scalp. It caused Agatha to tip her head back into the touch, her eyes fluttering shut as the softest little hum rumbled her pressed lips.

"And what else?" Rio tugged, trying a little harder to unravel the plans Agatha was knitting together for them.

"Sunday is another one. And -- mmmmm."

Rio stifled her giggle at the way Agatha seemed to be enjoying that contact on her scalp, so she simply kept going, the smirk starting to curl up her lips.

"And?" Rio cooed at her, though her tone was thick with her feigned innocence.

"And if you don't stop that, we're not going to end up making it to the market," Agatha warned, her tone low.

Accepting that as a challenge, Rio pulled her hand away and let it fall to Agatha's shoulder, eliciting a grumble of disapproval.

"What?" Rio posed, tilting her head as Agatha's gaze snapped over to her. "I just needed you to focus so that we can both get through what you've been plotting for our trip, and also we need groceries. Those children of ours are eating us out of house and home."

The laugh that fell from Agatha's lips did something to Rio's chest in the way that it filled it with a swarm of butterfly wings, the lightest pink dusting her cheeks.

"Okay, okay," Agatha conceded, though she had never stopped her motion of dragging her fingertips up and down Rio's shin; it was just a way to sustain contact, especially with her disappointment at Rio's insistence she focus. "Sunday morning we have a venue in Oak Glen, which is a little more inland, but that's the one I told you about with the blooms. Obviously we won't be able to see them yet, but they'll have photos we can go over. Sunday night..."

Agatha trailed off, her eyes dropping to her hand as it made work of keeping the touch against Rio's soft skin.

"What do you have planned for Sunday night, my love?" Rio questioned sweetly, raising her hand so that she was mimicking Agatha's feather light touch, only along the side of her neck, down into the crook, and over what portion of her shoulder was exposed by the tank top she had on.

Agatha cleared her throat in an attempt to distract herself from Rio's touch, and it seemed to be half-working. "I would really like to introduce you to Jack," she disclosed, her chin turning to hover over her shoulder as her eyes met Rio's across the length of her torso. "When I told him that we were flying in, he extended a dinner invitation. A double date, if you will," Agatha added, unable to temper the way that smile filled her face, bright and hopeful.

Rio could have feigned indifference, but there was no reason to. The fact that someone Agatha cared about wanted to meet her? Rio? Living-on-a-houseboat Rio? Nobody Rio?

That wasn't fair. Perhaps for twenty years, she had only ever been Estee's somebody, but now things were different. Now, she was Agatha's somebody, too. She was the person that Agatha wanted to wear on her arm, the person who's hand she wanted to hold as they walked down the street no matter what city they were in or who was watching. She was the one Agatha ached to come home to when she was away.

It made Rio wonder what it would have been like to be a fly on the wall of the Landon home that night. The pictures themselves had been chaotic, and hearing Agatha speak about them had moved Rio in a way she hadn't been expecting. While they were clearly a tribe in their own right, Rio had not missed the way they had rallied around Agatha to become her tribe, too, when Rio and the kids could not be around.

What had Agatha told them? Of course it wouldn't have been anything negative; that wasn't even a thought in Rio's mind. Some locked away part of her was still curious, though, about what her presence was when it left Agatha's lips and fell into the ears of the people she cared about and trusted. It was very possible that it could have been the same things that Agatha told her day in and day out, but she couldn't help wondering sometimes what she looked like through those familiar blue eyes.

In the same vein, she realized that Agatha might never see herself the way Rio saw her.

When Rio looked at Agatha, she saw a woman who had dealt with a lot of hardships that could have turned her into a different person entirely. She saw a woman who knew what her passion was from a young age and had done whatever she could in her power to see to it that it became her livelihood. Rio looked at that beautiful face like it was a work of art, and saw all the years of heartache and struggle and pain and success and love for her son and dedication to her craft. She saw the laugh lines, she saw the worry lines. Rio could see every spot of Agatha's face that had been touched by a momentous occasion in her life.

Agatha wasn't just a masterpiece.

She was a diamond.

She had started from darkness, nothing more than coal. As her life had worn on, pressure and heat and time all combined to turn her into the glimmering majesty she now was.

Sure, Rio might have been able to look at her hand to see one, but what was the need when the biggest, most beautiful, steadfast rock she'd ever wanted was right there?

Rio's lips curled up slightly as she tilted her head against the cushion of the couch, her eyes locking into Agatha's. Her fingertips remained in its motion of caressing her neck and shoulder, but she finally found her voice.

"You're sure?" she asked, that small shred of doubt seeming to win out for just a moment.

Agatha's brow pinched but then almost immediately smoothed out. In the next second, her expression melted completely.

"Of course I'm sure. We didn't have a whole lot of time for introductions when we were sealing ourselves in the little bubble of those first couple of weeks. But... Jack says he's incredibly eager in getting to know 'the woman he got woken up at 3am to call a jet for.'" As she finished with the little waving of her fingers to indicate a direct quote, Rio couldn't stop the laughter that overtook her and Agatha's own was almost right in tune.

"It was all his idea. We didn't decide on where to go, mostly because I wanted to make sure that it was okay with you," Agatha explained, though that soft gaze had never wavered from Rio's face and after her little air quotes, those fingers had resumed their work of gracing Rio's shin like they had never stopped. "But... he and Thea both asked me to relay that they would be honored to take the two of us out."

Rio's expression had practically melted the longer Agatha spoke. She could hear the tenderness there, the affection. She could hear that this meant something to Agatha.

Rio had gathered that Jack was someone who might have started as a colleague, a co-creator, but he had evolved into a higher tier position in Agatha's life. He had become her friend. Rio had gathered that garnering such a title in Agatha's world was an accomplishment, something not many people earned the opportunity to do. Jack had done it though, and even in the small amount of time that Rio had been in Agatha's life -- objectively, at least -- she had watched him come through for her on more than one occasion.

"I think that would be really nice. I'd like to thank him personally, anyway." Rio's voice was gentle, but it was genuine. She had benefited from his string pulling, and in a way she felt like she owed him for the couple of hours he had helped keep Agatha's head above water when she'd been so far away from the people she called home.

As nervous as the idea of beginning to integrate into Agatha's very real, very public life could sometimes make her, this seemed like the safest place to start. Jack was Agatha's safe place, and that was something Rio could find comfort in.

"Well, then Sunday night it'll be a double date with Jack and Thea," Agatha announced, her palm dropping to canvas Rio's shin wholly, giving a delighted squeeze. The way she lit up like that struck something in Rio.

Rio had been stewing over the idea that she might not fit as seamlessly into Agatha's life as Agatha had fit into hers.

Agatha had simply been waiting for the right time to make it happen, having zero doubt that it could go any other way than well.

Using the strength of her abdomen, Rio pulled herself out of the arm of the couch so that she could reach up, tucking two fingers along the far side of Agatha's jaw so that she could turn her head back the way it had been just a few seconds before. Once they were face to face, Rio closed the remaining space between them with a kiss that she hoped could say what she couldn't find the words to.

That kiss told every whisper of how thankful she was. It was every murmur that could have said how much Rio loved Agatha. It was every shout to the world that this woman was the rest of her life.

That kiss was the most convincing thing Rio could manage when trying to make Agatha understand all the things she just couldn't find the right way to say.

As she pulled away, she was not surprised when Agatha sealed the space quickly again to steal the briefest peck.

Rio's hand shifted so that the tips of her fingernails could graze along the nape of Agatha's neck. She had not missed the way Agatha shivered for just a moment, the goosebumps flaring and fading over her skin in rapid succession.

Agatha took a steadying breath, her face turning toward Rio's again the slightest bit.

"There's a lot about my life that you have not experienced yet," Agatha told her in a gentle murmur, and Rio sensed by the way she said it that this was both a good and a bad thing. "Most of it, and most of the people, I cannot wait for you to see and meet. There are... other aspects that might be... a little more difficult to deal with."

Rio had considered this. Although she did not truly understand the depth of it, she did understand that Agatha was famous. She understood that people knew who she was, that there were people who would go to see her films because she was the one who had directed them.

What Rio did not understand was the sheer fanatics and disregard for the human condition that could come with such fame.

"So... even though I am aware that we are long past the point where it could fracture our relationship, I just want to make sure you understand that it might not always be easy, to be with me."

The way Agatha said that, it pulled on the strings that were tied to the deepest cockles of Rio's heart. It stirred an emotion in her that, at first, felt hard to place. The longer she took the time to identify it, though, the more she understood that it was an incredibly raw and real form of compassion.

Rio's fingertips pulled from Agatha's neck and her hand easily moved to find her cheek, cupping it lovingly.

"Agatha," Rio breathed at her, a quiet request for her to lift her eyes. When she complied, Rio's thumb brushed along the arch of her cheekbone. "You know that despite just how easy it has been, that's never what it's been about for me. I know who you are, I know what you do. I know the company you keep. I know, even if I am sure I do not understand, the kind of attention that a powerful and successful woman like you draws."

The longer Rio spoke, the more Agatha seemed to lose the resolve she had been clinging to. Rio wasn't quite finished.

"But what I also know is that I love you with or without all of that. Your career had nothing to do with why I fell in love with you and it will not be the reason that I would ever stop, ever. Maybe it'll shock the hell out of me, maybe it won't. What it won't do is cause a rift between us." Rio's words were quiet over murmured tones, but she meant every single one that left her lips.

Agatha's chin tipped and she straightened up just enough so that she could place her lips to Rio's forehead in a light but loving kiss.

"Do you think this will ever make sense?"Agatha muttered, her breath warm against Rio's skin.

"Does it matter if it does?" Rio whispered back, a light giggle passing the inches between them, landing like music to Agatha's ears.

"No, I suppose it doesn't."

*****

Come Friday morning, despite their insistence that they could get an Uber, all three children had woken up at four in the morning with their sleepy eyes and tousled hair to get Rio and Agatha to the airport. It had been the sweetest thing and it honestly had made it a little harder to leave them to fly six thousand miles away.

The girls had asked if the older women were absolutely sure they could not come, and even though they had been teasing, Agatha had simply promised them that the next trip made, they would surely be in tow.

Rio didn't need to question it; Agatha was being cautious. She was wanting to see how this unfolded first, and even though they'd had that talk earlier in the week, some part of Rio couldn't help but feel like Agatha needed to prove to Rio that it might not be as simple as she had possibly convinced herself it might be. At the same time, if that were going to be true, Agatha did not want the children involved.

They had all loaded into Tay's Highlander and Nicky had used the GPS to assist him in their voyage to the airport. The ride had been quiet; everyone had been exhausted and the general mood of their departure didn't fall into somber, but it wasn't exactly elation, either.

Hugging their children goodbye had been bittersweet. Rio knew that she and Agatha were going to do, she knew what it would mean. She knew that they were beginning to build a true future for all give of them. That didn't make it any easier to turn around and walk away from those three beautiful faces, even if it was only for a few days.

The flight had been easier than the first one Rio had taken to America and she was fully aware it was down to the way that Agatha had booked them to fly first class. The way she had selected their seats meant that they could drop the center divider and be face to face, which Rio found great comfort in.

Even though they'd put on the same film to watch together, Rio had fallen asleep almost twenty minutes in. Agatha had found more interest in watching Rio than watching the movie. And then, she fell asleep too.

Rio had woken up to check the display and see that they still had about four hours left in the flight. Agatha had still been asleep so she'd simply busied herself by playing solitaire on her phone despite having access to the wi-fi. Agatha had come-to a short while later and they'd munched on the snacks that had been provided enough to tide them over until they were back on American soil.

Agatha had declared with about twenty minutes to go that she did not care how late it was, the first place they were going to was In-N-Out.

And so, Gio had been waiting for them as they spilled out into the cool night air at the pick-up of LAX. Agatha had immediately notified him that his first stop was the first In-N-Out he passed, and with a chuckle, he had delivered an 'Of course, ma'am,' as he rolled up the partition.

They had sat in the back of that town car with their cheeseburgers and their milkshakes like they were teenagers after a night of drinking, giggling and gushing about just how good it was. It was a dose of the young love Rio had never gotten the chance to experience.

Falling into bed that night, a thought had passed through Rio's mind.

The last time Rio had been in that bed, it had been Agatha's bed. It had been a rest stop on Rio's journey across the world, a place she had never meant to stay.

The last time she had gotten out of Agatha's bed, she had been filled with fear and terror in a way that she had never known possible.

Pouring back into it, it was their bed, in their third home.

It didn't matter that there weren't any touches of Rio gracing the walls yet. It didn't matter that they'd not had the time to set up rooms for the kids, though Nicky already had his own. It had nothing to do with the practicalities; by principle, it was a third place they could call a safe haven.

As Agatha had correctly predicted, they had slept in the following day. Even when Rio had woken up a little too early and started to get out of bed, Agatha had simply hooked an arm around her and pulled her closer. It was those softer, more tender moments when Rio knew that Agatha was not actually fully conscious but still chose to hold on, that made her question how she'd gotten it so damn good.

With the feel of Agatha's breath on the back of her neck, it had been a task of ease for Rio to close her eyes and find sleep for just a few more hours.

They'd slept long enough that they'd woken up to the sound of Agatha's alarm that she had been smart enough to set to ensure that they would have time to get ready before they set out for the day.

There had been something about the way that Agatha had rolled over atop Rio's back as she laid on her stomach and Agatha peppered the side of her face with kisses that had pulled several seconds' worth of sweet giggles into the air of the bedroom that settled into the deepest recesses of Rio's soul.

She got to have moments like this for the rest of her life.

They were going to get out of that bed, walk into that big master bathroom, climb into that massive shower for an exchange of affection and appreciation, and then they were going to start making decisions on where they were going to get married.

And that was exactly what had happened.

They had grabbed a late breakfast at a bagel shop on their way inland and had continued about their day with their iced coffees in hand and sunglasses shading them from the midday sun.

As the car rolled to a stop, Rio realized that it was the first time she'd pulled her attention from Agatha and the little silly and stupid conversations they were having to look out of the window.

It was almost scary how easy it was to get lost in any moment with Agatha.

What met her gaze on the other side of that window was a large brick structure that had white trimming and pillars in all the right places. It was two story, but seemed almost bigger than it should have been even with the additional floor. It was beautiful, really, in a way had a difficult time explaining. It was clearly old but as Agatha leaned over, voice low, Rio hadn't expected her to say what she did.

"This is the second oldest brick structure in the San Bernardino Valley. It's called The Barton House. It was finished in 1904."

Rio's smile had been hard to tame; the way Agatha floated it to her, like it was a secret even though Rio was sure it was common knowledge, spoke louder than the airy deliverance that had met her.

Agatha had considered this place because of its history.

For Agatha, history was integral to character.

They'd made their way out of the car and met the guide who had been a shorter woman with dark hair and a pep in her step that Rio couldn't help but respect. The woman knew how to hustle, she'd give her that.

She was animated as she showed them around, indicating all of the different features and included deals. It was a gorgeous property, but something about it just didn't feel... right. It didn't feel like them.

Agatha had been cordial in that businesswoman kind of way, assuring the other woman that they would be in touch, but Rio knew that she was just being polite. Rio had caught Agatha's eye on more than one instance and the conversation had been silent, but it had been heard. It was nice, sure, but the history wasn't enough to make it feel like it was the right choice.

They'd walked hand in hand back to the awaiting car and were on their way to the next destination.

The next venue, Agatha informed her as they arrived, was called Los Willows. There was a large lake on the back side of the property and one of the options for a ceremony was on the lake, which they had been shown almost immediately. It was damn near breathtaking, and Rio had not hesitated to voice as much, which had earned her a squeeze of Agatha's hand around her own. It was clear that Rio was a little captivated, but it went a bit deeper than that.

Rio could see in every inch of the places they were being shown that day why Agatha had made these decisions. She could see the intention and the attention she was pouring into these choices and it left Rio with the motivation to be a little more proactive in the decision process.

The rest of the property had been just as gorgeous and while Rio had found a fondness for it, there was still the thought in the back of her mind that the one Agatha had been most excited about was still on the horizon. So, for as much as the entire feel of it was resonating with Rio, she would simply tuck those reasons into her pocket for the time being. Of course she had shared with Agatha on the car ride home all of the things she had liked and the very few that could have been better. They'd agreed on most of it in a way that Rio had been certain they would.

They had arrived home and Agatha had announced that they could order in for the night and she'd worry about getting a couple of day's worth of groceries for them the following day. Before she could submit their order though, there was a rapping at the front door and while Agatha's eyes flew to the door, Rio's had landed on Agatha.

Rio knew there was a gate. Rio knew there was a guard. So who could be knocking on the door without Agatha having been notified?

Slowly, Agatha got to her feet and made her way over to the door. While she might not have known exactly who it was, the way Agatha moved assured Rio that there was no reason to be alarmed. She sank back into the couch, though her eyes never left Agatha as she pulled the door open. Rio's eyes flicked up to Agatha's face in time to catch the smile as it lit up her face.

"Good evening, Dave," she greeted warmly, stepping back to allow the man inside. Rio noticed before anything else that he had a couple of bags in his hands that were emblazoned with a chic logo that read 'Tramonto Bistro.'

As Rio's eyes swept up, it was almost jarring to put a face to the man she had heard Agatha speak of so many times. She'd even heard Agatha rip into him a time or two, too. What Agatha had never put into words that Rio had always heard anyway was that Agatha loved Dave in a way that had been borne from years of loyalty and dedication. Dave was good to Agatha, so Agatha was good to Dave.

His jaw was strong but not quite chiseled, covered in something that was too thick to be scruff and too thin to be a beard, but it suited him well in that speckled white and grey color. The hair atop his head was trimmed on the sides but wound in short and unruly curls atop his head. His eyes were an absolutely stunning hazel color and that smile that found his face as he looked over and saw Rio was a little startling.

His eyes lifted to Agatha and that handsome smile only seemed to grow.

"I knew if I asked to meet her, you'd tell me no. So I went to Tramonto and I got you the Quattro Formaggi gnocchi that I know you absolutely will not turn down. I then took a risk and got both the Casarecci and the Del Tramonto and figured Rio and I could fight over them."

Rio could both feel it in her own posture and see it in Agatha's as they both softened. This man clearly cared for Agatha in a very unique way and Rio could sense that it was not very often he got the chance to show it without any kind of push back from Agatha.

He lifted the bags up and held them out to Agatha expectantly who blinked at him for a moment in confusion. His eyes dipped to his hand, though, indicating that he wanted her to take the bags. Slowly and in a stunned manner, Agatha lifted the handles of the bags off of his fingers and the moment she did so, he was moving, crossing the room to where Rio had been occupying space on the couch. The moment Rio realized, she got to her feet to meet him.

With his pace, she'd almost thought he might hug her, but he stopped about a foot and a half in front of her and held his hand out.

"Ms. Vidal, it's a pleasure to finally meet you. I am David Crain, Agatha's -- "

"Right hand man," Agatha supplemented before he could offer his own opinion on his title. At this, Rio could feel even in the handshake as any tension in his muscles released.

"Yes, right. Well. I've heard quite a bit about you and suppose I couldn't wait to see what the buzz was all about. So please forgive me for crashing your evening."

"No forgiveness needed, Dave. It's a pleasure to meet you, too." Rio's voice was rich and smooth, trying to convey just how touched she was by his gesture. He released her hand and and turned back to Agatha who had moved closer, still holding the bags.

"You going to take these back and feed us so I can grab us a bottle of red?" she shot at him, though her tone was light and playful in a way Rio had never heard her speak to him before. He chuckled as he took the bags from her and she excused herself to grab the wine, though she did not hesitate to place a soft kiss to the apple of Rio's cheek as she passed by her to head for the cellar.

Rio placed herself back on the couch as Dave sat in the chair at the end of the coffee table and began to pull the food out of the bags.

"Thank you, Dave. This was kind of you."

He didn't acknowledge her at first and continued about his work until everything was on top of the coffee table. He lifted his head, those hazel eyes meeting her own.

"Thank you, Rio. You have no idea how much you've changed her life. And I realize I only have these ninety seconds to tell you, so feel what you need and then get it together so she doesn't know I'm loose-lipped with the things she won't even admit herself."

Rio felt emotional even as the smile formed on her face, but she drew in a slow breath and offered him a slight tip of her head accompanied by a light shrug of her shoulders.

"If it's even half as much as she's changed mine, I think I might have an idea."

Just Talk

I guess my love has found you either way
And I can't let you go.
*****

Having dinner with Dave had been a delight that Rio had not known she needed the pleasure of experiencing. There had been something about the tiniest little inflection in the way he spoke that had tugged at something deep in the core of who Rio had become as a person since the age of six, but she had tried to bite it back.

That was, until it became too hard to ignore.

Rio had finished the bite of the spinach and ricotta ravioli that she had won in their debate and set her fork down, leaning forward on her knees as she watched Dave with vested interest.

"Where are you from?" she asked him curiously. His skin was darker, a smooth tan color that had not come from years in the sun. His eyes were dark but had an ability to reflect any light they pulled in. Something about him when she looked closer at him, studying him was... comfortable.

"I was born in Tahoe, up north from here," he responded, though by the smile that immediately found his face Rio knew he had something else he wanted to share. "But three years before I was born, my Irish mother and Mori father moved from Tolaga Bay."

Rio's eyes widened and her jaw dropped in shock. Had Agatha known this? Had Dave ever even told her? Based on Agatha's next question, though, Rio could safely assume he hadn't.

"Is that...?"

"Seven and a half hours from Auckland," Rio answered before Agatha could finish the question. Her eyes hesitated on Dave for just a moment longer before she turned to face Agatha who looked just as surprised as Rio did.

Agatha's nose scrunched as she tried to best phrase what she felt in that moment.

"If you wanted to award me with the World's Worst Boss placard for not knowing that, I wouldn't totally blame you," she offered him, but his deep and bass filled laugh sounded almost instantly.

"Agatha, we have never needed to have a conversation about where our parents came from. I do not fault you for not knowing," he told her, though he was still laughing over the idea that she seemed to think of this as some kind of egregious error.

There was something Rio saw in Agatha's eyes, though. It was guilt. She'd spent nearly two decades with this man by her side and she didn't even know his roots. As quickly as it had appeared, though, it seemed to flicker away.

That had been the first instance of their dynamic but the longer the night wore on and the more wine they drank, the more Rio simply sat back and enjoyed the show. She would chime in when it was warranted, but watching them in a back and forth meant that she could observe and learn, that she could see the history that was so rich and thick between them.

They verbally sparred, challenging each other on whatever topic they had landed on, not to force perspective but to change the lens instead. They could debate different points of view without growing frustrated or upset. The way they held conversation was completely fascinating. They were two equal individuals who did not place themselves higher than the other when it came to an intellectual understanding.

Rio could tell why Agatha respected Dave.

With some of the points Dave made, Rio could also see why Agatha was cursing at him a great deal of the time, even if those points were valid.

By the time the three of them had drained that bottle of wine and their meals were completed, Dave did not waste time in getting to his feet in a way that signified he was not going to overstay his welcome.

"I best be off," he offered with a kind smile. Agatha stood first, but Rio was quick on her feet a moment later.

She let Agatha pass in front of her to give him a warm hug.

"Thank you, David. It was an unexpected surprise, but a pleasant one nonetheless. And you got what you wanted out of it, I assume?" she posed, cocking her head as she stood back with her hands on her hips, as if she were being a petulant teenager.

The way all three of them burst into tipsy laughter melted that stance right out of Agatha.

As she stepped back, Rio took her previously occupied spot and wrapped her arms firmly around Dave, giving him a firm squeeze, though there was little more that needed to be said between the two of them. He'd gotten his point across in the moment alone and Rio hoped that she had, too.

As she sidled up against Agatha, looping an arm around her waist, Dave hesitated at the door and lifted his head to look back at them. His grin registered a bit mischievous before he spoke.

"Please, for the love of god, behave." He paused for a moment, his gaze lifting to Agatha. "I don't want to have to pay out thousands of your dollars to purchase photo rights to you punching someone in a restaurant mid-day."

What he had said could have been a lead anvil being dropped right on top of them. They both knew what he was referring to, and from the way Agatha had never brought it up, Rio was not sure even she had known that it may have been something that had happened. It was heavy enough, and rooted in enough of Rio's past trauma that it very well could have done a little unintentional damage. What he added only seemed to soften it, though.

"I don't need to know, mostly because it was probably deserved. But... You don't need a reminder from me that there's someone paying attention at all times."

"Thank you, David," Agatha returned, her voice conveying her gratitude more than the words could.
