"Yes, thank you Dave. We appreciate it more than you know," Rio felt compelled to add, even though she was sure he had a pretty good idea.

"Goodnight ladies. Have fun in Oak Glen tomorrow. It's truly a beautiful spot."

With that, he let himself out and pulled the door shut quietly behind him.

Rio loosened her hold on Agatha, but only so she could look over at her better.

"I see why you love him," Rio cooed at her, though Agatha was quick to feign disregard as if she didn't know what Rio meant by that as she blew a huff of air through her nose.

"You don't have to say it out loud for it to be true," Rio prodded a little further, though Agatha's head turned and met Rio's gaze. She looked a little sheepish, as if admitting that she knew exactly what Rio was insinuating.

"He's okay, I guess," Agatha offered, though her smile grew.

They both knew that Dave had taken up the role of being Agatha's rock for the last eighteen years. Maybe he wouldn't have said it in so many words, but he was relieved to see Agatha find that comfort and solace in someone else once she had met Rio.

"He seems to keep you in line," Rio teased, digging a light finger into her side with a soft chuckle.

"He is pretty good at that," Agatha agreed, craning across the space between them to give Rio a soft kiss. "Let's clean up and head to bed."

"Wait," Rio pushed, placing a hand in the center of Agatha's chest. Agatha's gaze dropped back over to her, a little stunned, but Rio didn't leave her waiting long. "It makes me happy to know you have him. He would very clearly step into the line of fire for you. That's a very rare kind of loyalty to have."

Agatha's expression softened and the look in her eyes was both one of understanding, but also one of appreciation.

"Little does he know I'd do the same for him."

Agatha had pressed her lips one last time to Rio's forehead before they separated to gather the empty containers left over from their -- incredibly delicious if you asked Rio -- meal. The clean up was quick and Agatha, as always, had led her upstairs to their little haven of a bedroom by the hand.

The moment they crossed the threshold, Rio could almost feel as the exhaustion from their day and the remaining jetlag seemed to dump right on top of her. They'd undressed, but before Agatha could pull on a shirt, Rio had stopped her.

"I just want to feel your skin tonight," she requested softly, and this seemed to be perfectly fine with Agatha who unceremoniously dropped the shirt right back into its drawer.

The moment they slid into that bed and Rio turned on her side, Agatha did not skip a beat in sliding right up behind her. The moment Rio felt every single place where the skin on the front of Agatha's body touched the back of her own, it had been a struggle to keep conscious. She had managed to succeed just about as long as it took her to whisper to her finace.

"Sweet dreams, my love. I love you."

It could have been possible that Agatha returned the sentiment as she gave Rio's middle a light squeeze, but Rio had dozed before she'd heard it. Agatha had even realized it as she placed a kiss to Rio's shoulder and let herself fall asleep, too.

The next morning, Rio had woken up briefly when Agatha had removed her hold from around her. She had let out a soft grumble of disapproval but it smoothed into a soft hum as she felt Agatha's lips press to her cheek right before she whispered that she was going to go make them breakfast.

This had satisfied Rio enough that she was able to fall back asleep for a little while longer in that big bed of theirs.

When she woke up almost thirty minutes later, she could smell in the air a mixture of a fresh pot of coffee coupled with whatever it was Agatha was making. Rio reached up and swiped her phone off of the nightstand to see that she had a couple of messages from Estee who informed her that they were doing fine and had not caught the house on fire yet.

With a breathed chuckle, Rio had shot back a message indicating how much the three of them were missed by herself and Agatha and included in it that they were thankful for the lack of pyro work. When it sent, she closed her phone and removed herself from bed. She busied herself with brushing her teeth and pulling on a tank top and pair of shorts to move about the house in, growing more and more enticed by the smell that was wafting from downstairs.

After pulling her hair up into a disastrous bun atop her head and not really caring, she finally made the descent to a sight she knew she would never get sick of.

Agatha was at the stove, moving about with the precision she always maintained when in the kitchen, once again so absorbed in her work that she had not heard the soft creak of the stairs when Rio had come down them. Her hair was in a long braid that hung down the middle of her back -- impressive work for having not asked for help -- and although it was not Rio's jersey she was donning, it was still one of Rio's t-shirts that clung to her torso.

While Rio did take a silent moment to appreciate her life and the woman she loved for all that they were, she did not let it linger for too long. Her approach was still quiet, but her hands fell immediately to Agatha's sides before they moved around to her front, wrapping firmly around her middle. She placed a soft kiss to the back of Agatha's head before she tucked her chin over the other woman's shoulder to take in her work.

"What're you making, my love?" Rio murmured softly in her ear, the grogginess still a little heavy over her words.

"It dawned on me this morning that you have not yet been introduced to the American staple of sausage gravy and biscuits," Agatha informed her, turning her head enough that Rio understood she was asking for a kiss, which she happily provided the moment before she laughed.

"It sounds absolutely repulsive," Rio informed her, but what she saw on that stove? It didn't make sense with the description provided, but it smelled incredible.

"Hey don't knock it until you try it," Agatha returned haughtily, though the laughter that spilled from her lips indicated that she was having her fun.

As it turned out, Agatha hadn't been wrong. There had definitely been a bit of trepidation on Rio's end, but as she finally allowed herself to overcome the mental block, it was actually pretty delicious. The 'biscuits' as Agatha had called them looked more like a scone, but the texture and taste were both different and not in a bad way. The salty and buttery biscuit itself paired with what Agatha called a gravy -- but Rio still could not reconcile as one -- was a unique taste, but after the second bite, Rio had decided she actually liked it.

"I wouldn't call myself a convert, as it still makes little sense, but I will say that it tastes incredible. But... very little do I doubt you once you step foot into that kitchen," Rio offered in low praise, though the look on her face was more tender than it was povocatory.

Agatha leaned toward her, over the corner of that very long and very regal table that Agatha headed up every single time she sat at it. That was one thing that Rio hoped never changed. Agatha was the captain of their family, the one who made the tough calls because she knew she had to, even if it upset everyone in the process. She was the one doing the legwork in finding ways to cement their future. She was the one who would take charge of whatever situation she needed to in order to do what was best for those she loved.

"Be real," she prodded, a playful smile on her lips. "Very little do you doubt me, ever."

Rio's brows raised in faux surprise, but her smile was almost instant.

"You know me so well, my love," she returned, her tone light as a air. Her grin tempered only in the way that it was absolutely necessary so that they could share a sweet kiss.

Finishing breakfast, Rio had been insistent on clearing the table and getting the dishes loaded, but she'd had an ulterior motive in asking Agatha to get the shower running so they could get ready for the day.

The look she'd received in response wasn't the one she'd thought she'd get and in turn, it left her feeling a little touched. There was this warm softness to Agatha's entire demeanor the moment she registered the question, like she recognized that Rio was true to form in her mischievous ways but also craving something that had become routine for them.

They had habits. They had routines. They had patterns and processes.

As a unit, they'd built this life, and Rio couldn't have been more in love with it if she tried.

*****

The drive into the valley had been a sight that while almost felt familiar to Rio, had its own distinctive qualities as well. Despite the lack of flowers, it was an incredible sight. The mountains stood resolute and tall, majestic in their stature that reached toward the sky. The greenery that lined the sides -- only having returned in recent years due to the fires in 2019, Agatha informed her -- offered a serenity that seemed almost out of place for the rocky peaks that protruded from it.

As the car rolled slowly into the lot, Rio could already see the vision and they hadn't even gotten out of the vehicle. She didn't need to see the blooms to understand why this had been the one place Agatha had mentioned first.

As they toured the property, each step they took was a step closer to Rio understanding that this was the place they were going to tie their lives together. There was a small pond bordering this one, but there was also the most adorable little wooden bridge that arched over a part of it that Rio could already see being used for photos. The shrubbery that lined the water was still dotted with flowers, though they weren't as majestic as they ones the guide had shown them on her tablet.

There were several other places, including a absolutely breathtaking greenhouse that almost moved Rio to tears, that were surely intended for photo opportunities. That was the one, the one that made her grip Agatha's hand tightly in her own as if somehow managing to say that they needed to look no further.

They had still continued, though, through the rest of the property. When the woman had led them to where the ceremony would be held, Rio's eyes prickled with the threat of tears but she swallowed them down, damn near fighting for her life to not completely break down at how beautiful that view was. The platform itself had a circular metal frame atop it that the woman explained was wrapped in flowers and vines for the ceremony. Rio could already envision it and it made her heart pound a little harder in her chest. The view beyond it, though, was what really took her breath away.

The edges of mountain ranges were woven into each other, though the small buildings in the valleys were visible even from where they were, though they looked no bigger than the size of ants from that perspective. It was perfect.

The last place to see had been the reception area, which yet again was impossibly beautiful. Rio could almost picture it in her mind's eye, the way Agatha's friends and loved ones would fill the space to eat and drink and celebrate the fact that they were choosing to spend the rest of their lives together. She could see their children dressed to the nines, laughing together. The mere thought of the introductions Nicky would be making between the girls and friends he had known for years was enough to almost choke Rio up.

Agatha had not missed a single thing.

The piece de la resistance had been the moment the woman had pulled up something on her tablet, indicating that they were running a special on one of the packages that was inclusive of a special detail.

When she lowered the tablet, both sets of eyes fell to take in the image of the white carriage that was led by two white horses.

No fucking way.

Rio looked up at the woman in disbelief, simply blinking at her. Was this real life? This woman was standing there telling them that a perk of booking an already otherwise perfect venue, was that it came with a fucking horse-drawn carriage.

Agatha had seemed to take charge of the moment where Rio was so clearly having a moment of reconciliation, yet again, that this was what her life had become.

Politely, Agatha had indicated to the woman that the two of them needed a moment to discuss and the woman gave a nod and stepped away. At the same time, one of Agatha's hands hooked around her arm and pulled her a little closer.

"What do you think?" Agatha questioned softly. Judging by that knowing look on her face, she was aware she had not really needed to ask.

Rio was staring ahead at her, completely verklempt. Agatha had known. Even though she had provided options, and they'd been suitable, she had always known that this one would be the one. And so, all Rio could do in the moment was state as much.

"You knew," she managed and in a way, it was half an accusation and half a realization at the same time. "You knew this would be the one I'd want, even before the utter insanity of you being delivered to me by a horse-drawn carriage?!" The giddiness was apparent not only in her tone, but it was painted over every last inch of her face.

"Hey! Who said it was going to be me?!" Agatha managed back as she moved forward to wrap her arms around her wife-to-be.

"I did. This is one executive decision I get to make."

"Ooh, okay bridezilla," Agatha murmured at her. Her grin was wide, though, and Rio couldn't help but roll her eyes.

"Hush up, you," she growled playfully before leaning in to steal a brief kiss.

Agatha had handled the rest of the transaction, though Rio had been right by her side watching everything, reading what they were given, and signing the contract for the reservation. Despite the fact that the total the woman announced right before Agatha slid over her card was completely insane, Rio had long since learned to stop assigning value to a dollar amount when it came to Agatha.

Whatever Rio wanted them to have, they would have. Agatha could provide and so she always would.

Once finished, they each shook the woman's hand and bit her a good rest of her evening. Agatha had checked the time, hissing a soft shit under her breath.

"We're going to be late for dinner reservations. I should text Jack."

As they slid into the back of the car, she had done just that and informed him that they were on the way but the tour had run over a little longer than expected. As Rio did not doubt, he had assured Agatha that it was fine and they would see them when they got there.

Agatha stowed her phone and lifted her arm so that Rio could fit herself beneath it, snug against Agatha's side. The ride was quiet for a few moments, but Agatha finally found her voice.

"Is there anything you want to know before we get there?"

This perplexed Rio who lifted her head so she could meet Agatha's gaze.

"Is there anything I should know before we get there?"

Agatha's response was instant, a gentle shake of her head with a slightly pinched brow that smoothed not a second later.

"No, no. Of course not. I mean, other than reformed Hollywood playboy with a heart of gold. I..." Agatha paused, a warm smile curling her lips. "I suppose that I see a lot of myself in him. He's got vision and drive and he has never taken no for an answer. More than that, he's aware of his place in the industry in the kind of way that enables him to support others in the community instead of trying to contend with them." She paused, pursing her lips slightly in thought. "So, he might be a little better than me. At least, when it comes to anyone who isn't him."

Her soft chuckle was met halfway by a giggle from Rio who sensed that even between them, it was a bit of a humbling thought for Agatha to have.

"Well, I'm very excited. And Estee has messaged me twice to ask if we've met up with them yet. I think she might be a little more excited than me," Rio returned in a soft murmur, tightening the arm around Agatha's middle that had been holding her close. "I'm just happy to get to meet the people who care about you. It's nice to see the way they look at you."

"What do you mean?" Agatha returned, tones inquisitorial.

"I mean... I know how I look at you, and I know how the kids look at you, because you are our world. But, take Dave for example," Rio offered. "When Dave looks at you, I think he sees someone above his station that he respects. At the same time, he looks at you as someone who, even outside of your working relationship, is still worth putting on a pedestal."

The slightest shift in Agatha's posture signified to Rio that perhaps that was not something Agatha had ever stopped to give much thought to.

"So," Rio concluded, "I'm excited for two more perspectives on the woman I love most in the world from the people who care about her."

Agatha was clearly in a battle to not roll her eyes, but she seemed to win for the moment, though the look she offered Rio tried its hardest to be admonishing.

"That optimism is..." Agatha had started, but Rio was quick to interject.

"Your favorite thing about me."

"Always."

Just Know That I'm Rare

I'm so glad our stars aligned
I like who I can be with you
I'm uptight most of the time
This reckless mess feels so brand new
*****

Rio's hand felt warm in Agatha's grip as they bumped along in the back of the town car on the way to their dinner date. She was so unassuming, as she always was, that when the car began to slow and pull toward the curb, her gaze flickered to the window for a brief second and cut away again. As what she saw began to process, her brow knit together.

They were sitting outside the Freehand.

They were right outside the first place Rio had tucked into the moment she had landed in America.

That hotel room had been her safe haven in those first few days of trying to get her feet under herself with Agatha's help. That had been the place the seed of their love had first been planted. It had since been repotted several times. In that hotel, in room 2315, they'd decided to sink it into the ground to be nurtured.

That was the place where their love had started to bloom.

"Agatha..." Rio voiced, her tone hushed and filled with the sweetest mix of shock and curiosity. "What are we doing here?"

"We're meeting Jack and Thea for dinner," Agatha informed her. There was something about the way her voice rang, still so soft, with the slightest tinge of sheer giddiness.

"But this is the Freehand," Rio pointed out, as though it weren't completely obvious.

"It is. And... I don't know how much research you did before stalking me..." Agatha teased, the smile audible in her voice before Rio saw it spread to her lips. "You would know that The Broken Shaker sits on the roof."

Rio's expression pinched for a beat, but then smoothed, her cheeks a little pink with her embarrassment at not, actually, having known that.

"I did not do enough, apparently," Rio returned as Agatha pushed the door open and climbed out, pulling her behind by the hand.

"It was Jack's suggestion. He didn't know and I didn't tell him. Or you. For this very reason," Agatha informed her as Gio pulled away from the curb and left them standing at the foot of that hotel, a sense of nostalgia washing over Rio like the tide on a hot summer day, warm and all-encompassing.

"You're..." Rio started, though her lips twisted as she turned to look at Agatha.

"The sweetest, most sentimental fiance you could ever ask for?" Agatha returned airily, but that wicked grin across her lips sang another tune, one that told Rio she was up to something.

"Yes, my love. That's exactly what I was going to say," Rio responded, making a quick move to snatch the breath of a kiss off of Agatha's lips before she could form any rebuttal.

"We're already late, but I don't think we should keep them waiting while we get all sentimental," Agatha prodded, giving Rio's hand a gentle squeeze to indicate they should get moving.

They wound their way through the familiar hotel lobby and Rio had been unable to keep herself from glancing across at the bar and to two seats they had occupied the first night Rio had spent in America. She hadn't expected to ever be back there and to see it all again after everything that had changed in the last several months. It was emotional in its own way, even if it was touching at the same time.

What she Rio not actively anticipate was what it would be like to step foot in that elevator again. The elevator where she had made out with Agatha for the first time. The elevator where they had been so engrossed in the task of learning what the other tasted like for the first time that they'd stood there long after they had reached their floor. The elevator where Rio had come to the realization that she was in it deep, and Agatha was in the trenches right next to her.

The moment the doors slid shut, Agatha leaned back against the wall of the elevator and gave a tug on Rio's hand, pulling her to her in a way that left their front's pressed together. Agatha dropped her hand to wrap her arms around Rio's waist, leaning in just enough to bump the tips of their noses together in a way that pulled the lightest giggle from between Rio's lips.

"We are not making out in this elevator before you introduce me to your friends," Rio murmured at her, though she did not hesitate to punctuate such a statement with a quick peck.

Agatha raised an eyebrow in silent challenge, clearly mulling through words to find what she wanted to say.

"So after, then?" she shot back, stealing a brief kiss of her own.

This earned her a light jab with a lone finger to the ribs and cause that bright and beautiful sound that Rio was so fond of to bounce off of the walls around them.

"Can you blame me? I'm feeling... sentimental." Agatha's voice was just as gentle as the intention behind her words, even if that mischief still lurked in the lowest registers.

Rio had started to speak, but the elevator signified they had arrived at the roof level and the doors pulled open. Rio turned, still clutching Agatha's hand and let her lead the way. They had gotten about halfway through the dining area when a man in the corner got to his feet, the woman next to him doing the same. He moved around the end of the table as the two of them approached, a wide smile on his handsome face.

The first thing Rio noticed was his eyes. They were strikingly blue against the contrast of his tan skin and dark eyebrows. His hair was a dark brunette color flecked with almost imperceptible blonde patches, and a short beard of the same color hugged his chiseled jaw. He simply looked charming.

As Agatha stopped short of him, Rio did the same next to her side. He grinned at Agatha, but his attention turned to Rio as he held a hand out. She took hold of it, giving a gentle shake.

"You must be Jetplane Jack," Rio teased softly and she could see immediately the delight that washed over his expression.

"And you must be Boat Woman," he returned, a boyish gleam in his eyes.

"That I am," she offered back. "It's a pleasure to meet you. I've heard a lot about you."

He dropped her hand and took half a step back so that he could usher his partner forward who did not hesitate to introduce herself as well, offering her hand.

"I'm Thea and I have been on the end of the line in the game of telephone enough to assure you that we have heard a lot about you, too."

There was something about Thea that struck Rio somewhere in her chest.

It could have been the long dark hair, the softened features, or even those beautiful dark eyes, but whatever it was, she reminded Rio of Estee. Estee, who was probably sitting at home eagerly awaiting a text on what it was like to meet a member of the Landon family.

As Rio's hand dropped again, she could see as Agatha and Jack parted from a hug and Agatha moved to do the same to the younger woman, telling her how good it was to see her again.

They'd taken their seats and Jack was almost instant in his move to pull the bottle of wine over and fill the two empty glasses that had been waiting for their arrival.

That first sip of wine was exquisite, Rio thought. It was rich and deep with notes she could not quite place, but cherry had been the most obvious. The way it lingered on her tongue was satisfying in a way few things often were.

Once they were all relaxed and comfortable, Jack placed an order for the ceviche so that they would have something to pick at while they talked. Rio had come into this with the suspicion that this was not going to be a quick share-a-meal type of gathering, and while it had slightly contributed to her nerves, she could already understand why this was the company Agatha willingly chose.

"So, any chance you've given it more thought? I'm just as hungry now as ever," Jack opened as he leaned back in his chair, his hand clearly reaching for his girlfriend's beneath the table in the same moment.

Agatha rolled her eyes, her own hand finding the top of Rio's thigh at the same time.

"You're like a dog with a bone," Agatha chastised, tipping her chin at him.

It took Rio only a moment to catch up to content of the conversation, having used enough of the context to get her there.

He was talking about making their life into a movie.

Something about it thudded into Rio like she were a gong and that deft strike sent a deep wave of vibration into the air around them. This was soundless, though, in the way that only Rio felt it as it shook her very bones.

Rio had many a conversations with her daughter about the fact that what had happened to her wasn't practical. She'd met a woman and they'd spent an amazing night together in a way that had somehow been romantic, but also kept the air of staying platonic. That air had never lost its charge, even as Agatha had fallen asleep with her head in Rio's lap.

The romance had won out, though, the moment Agatha had taken those few steps and kissed her. Then, she was gone and Rio could still taste that kiss on her lips hours later.

In the quiet hours of the early morning when Rio found sleep difficult, she would often replay those parts and pieces she had clung to in the wake of Agatha's absence. Rio had never known what it was like to miss a stranger and it had been enough to spark the kindling within her.

Kindling that Estee had tended to with a careful hand and measured caution. She had known just where to push to get Rio to buckle and had easily applied just the right amount of pressure to make it happen.

In the throes of understanding, something struck Rio that -- stupidly -- she had not once stopped to consider.

For everything she had told Estee, there were surely things that Agatha had turned to Jack to vent about.

The two of them had managed surface level conversations about their time apart, but the depth there was something Agatha had left unexplored when it came to discussing it with Rio. Clearly at their reunion outside of her office, she'd been given some idea that Agatha had discussed her with people she cared about, but Rio hadn't thought that it could go that deep.

Maybe, Rio was starting to realize, she had not been the only one devolving into insanity at having met someone she felt drawn to and had no way to ever reach out or see them again.

It was very possible that Agatha had sat up in that office, staring out of those windows, wondering what it could have been like if things had been different. Rio knew it was possible because she'd sat on her deck, staring at that bridge as she did the exact same thing.

Having been privy to everything since, Jack still had that hunger to show what they had to the world. It could have been intimidating, but Rio felt... astounded.

She had been a lonely woman who spent too much time hunched over her laptop pouring countless hours of her life into something she knew would make a difference in the world. She might have garnered an award here or there in her field, but not much else would come of it in terms of notoriety. That wasn't something that bothered her.

Rio had been content -- no, she could no longer say that and believe it. What Rio had been before Agatha toppled into her life had been complacent, not content. She had fallen into the steady thrum of routine in a life that was solely her own. She'd had acquaintances, made nice with her neighbors, but Rio's distrust of humans at large had kept her shrouded in her loneliness.

And then, she'd met a complete stranger who felt the same way. Even not knowing who she was or what she did, it had been apparent through their conversations, through the way they had chosen to speak to one another throughout the night. Those low tones had been ones of betrayal in even the most miniscule ways. They were just ways neither of them had understood at the time.

Rio had realized perhaps a beat too late that the conversation had carried on as she had been grasping the idea that her life was literally something that an incredibly successful Hollywood director wanted their permission to share with the world. Of course she had heard Agatha the few times she had mentioned it, but maybe she hadn't actually heard her.

Sort of in the same way she hadn't really heard what the other people at the table were talking about.

There had been a soft pressure on her thigh, one that seemed to reel her back into the moment. Agatha was still holding conversation with Jack and as Rio began to understand what she was hearing, it was clear that he and Thea were gushing about the puppy they had just gotten. The conversation had evolved beyond Rio's cognition, but Agatha seemed to be aware that those cogs were moving, gears clicking into and rolling out of place and Rio had just needed time to process.

It wasn't being star-struck. She genuinely had no idea who these people were outside of their importance to Agatha, but it was the power that came with a position like his that seemed to floor her. She appreciated the dedication, but what she appreciated more was just how genuine he seemed to be, even on several different avenues of conversation.

They had discussed a variety of things over their shared ceviche, from Thea's family to Jack's latest project. Agatha had detailed to the two of them a little more about her sabbatical and how it was likely she would hit the ground running once things settled down after the wedding. That was a talking point that had garnered silent action from Rio, who had wrapped her hand around Agatha's where it had stayed perched on her thigh.

They had placed their dinner orders, but no sooner had the waiter walked away than Jack's attention was on Rio.

"So, I have heard bits and pieces from this one," he began, flicking a hand to indicate Agatha, but his piercing blue eyes had never left Rio, "but I hear that you have two fans at home. And I hear they are very intelligent and accomplished fans, at that."

Rio's smile was instant, but it was a little bashful. Those girls' accomplishments had little to do with her, but she understood the sentiment.

"We do. And they have probably checked their phones at least fifty times by now for any sign of an update," Rio offered with a smile that grew a bit, the fondness for her daughters so clear in her voice. She did not miss, though, how Jack's eyes dropped to where her phone sat toward the edge of the table.

"May I?" he asked with a boyish grin that caused a ripple of realization to quake through Rio.

And then, it smacked into her even harder as it settled.

When Agatha looked at Jack, she saw parts and pieces of her son, ones that seemed to fit into parts and pieces of herself and combined into this charming young man.

Rio nodded and picked up her phone, unlocking it with ease and opening the camera app before she handed it over to him. He did not waste any time in swiveling around in his seat so that he could extend a long arm, holding the phone sideways so that, as Thea leaned in, the four of them were in frame.

Agatha did not waste the opportunity and scooted her chair closer to her fiance, leaning against Rio as they all looked toward the camera and beamed, the four smiles in that photo bright enough to light up the night sky. He snapped a couple more, encouraging a variety of expressions.

On the last one, Agatha was lightning quick as she reached for Rio's chin, turning it with the gentlest curl of her fingers so that she could kiss her the moment Jack snapped the picture.

"Oooh, that one's my favorite!" Thea declared as Jack lowered the phone to survey his own handiwork for a moment. The way Thea craned in to look, too, made something melt even further in Rio's chest.

The other couple was clearly at least ten to fifteen years their junior and yet, it felt like being in the presence of equals. It was funny how life worked like that, wasn't it? There were people Rio's age that could still behave like children, and then there were people like the two on the other side of that table who were clearly still young, but had lived so much life in that time.

After another moment of inspection, Jack proudly forked the phone back over to Rio, that grin still plastered across his face.

"Please do not wait to send those," Thea pressed, her grin almost as bright as her boyfriend's.

"Yes, please. I think it's some of my best work."

Those grins were very obviously infectious as one found Rio's face, too. She set about the quick work of sending the photos of the four of them to her daughter. Once finished, she set the phone to the side and had every intention of letting that be it.

She turned her attention back to them as she reached for her wine glass with the hand that had not landed on Agatha's thigh after their mini-photoshoot.

"So Agatha said they graduated not too long ago? What were their majors?" Jack posed, the genuine interest so clear in the way he had asked the question.

"Well," Rio began, "Estee, who is actually mine, graduated with a BCs Honors, which is a bachelor's of science with a minor in psychology."

At this, Thea lit up in a way Rio had actually known to see coming.

"Oh, she absolutely has to meet Cole. She's my sister-in-law but she's a psychologist, too. She does a lot of amazing work with LGBT youth and kids who have trauma from bad foster situations," the younger woman nearly gushed.

"Oh, those two together would be an absolute sight," Agatha chime in just before she took a sip of her own wine. "A meeting of the minds that could stop the world."

Rio softened in the way she did every time Agatha praised who Estee was as a human being.

"And Tay, her girlfriend, graduated with a BACom, which is a bachelor's of arts and commerce. Her plan is to find an architecture firm one a home base is officially settled upon."

Across the table, Rio found the expressions of two people who were thoroughly enjoying these little bits and pieces of her and Agatha's life together that Rio was willing to share. Surely, they'd heard enough from Agatha to understand, but she could see what it meant to them to hear it from her lips.

"Do they want to come here?" Jack inquired, though his interest was not pointed, just curious.

"They definitely would love to visit, probably before the wedding, but we shall see how that plays out."

It was Agatha who spoke next, her hand landing atop the back of Rio's as she leaned forward slightly, but only to smooth the stem of her wine glass between the fingers of her other hand.

"When they do, Nicky will likely be with them. I tell you, it's like three peas in a pod. It's... adorably insane how quickly they've fallen into... siblingship?" Even as the word left her lips, Rio could see the disbelief for the brief second it passed over Agatha's expression.

"How is he doing?" Jack posed, but as Agatha went to answer, their meals arrived.

Rio was already almost full up with the things she had been feasting on during their time together. Once everything was placed and the waiter departed after making sure they didn't need anything else, Agatha seemed to not miss a beat.

"He's... got a boyfriend, apparently?" she offered, though her laugh that immediately followed showed how tickled she actually was by it.

"No shit?" Thea managed, her eyes shimmering with the amusement this brought.

"He's Mori, and according to the girls, 'very handsome,'" Rio divulged, though she threw up her free hand to provide air quotes over her last words, eliciting laughter from the three other people at the table.

"Good for him," Jack mused before he washed down a bite of his food with a good pull of wine.

"It does something to my mom heart," Agatha admitted. This caused Rio to steal a glance at her, trying to read her profile for the briefest moment that her eyes lingered. "I'm sure he's dated since he left, but... This one hit a little different. In a good way."

The conversation had stayed like a steady stream between the four of them for the duration of their meal, and Jack and Thea had even kept it up when Agatha excused herself to use the washroom.

The only time it seemed to stall was when Rio suddenly realized that Agatha had been gone for a suspiciously long time. She reached for her phone to see that Estee had sent her nine messages since she had received those photos, but Rio wasn't concerned with opening them at the moment. Instead, she pulled up Agatha's contact and started to type a message asking if she was okay, but only having hit two keys, the chair next to her slid out and Agatha placed herself directly in it.

"I was getting worried. Are you alright?" Rio asked as she looked over to Agatha. It could have been overbearing, but she knew Agatha knew her well enough to know that she was simply concerned.

"I'm fine, my love." To prove her point, Agatha leaned into her and pressed a soft kiss to her cheek.

As Rio's eyes swept back across the table, Thea's cheek was in her own palm and her elbow was on the table as she looked at the two of them adoringly.

"You both are sickeningly sweet," Thea voiced, her grin growing.

"I second that," Jack tacked on, a bassy and deep laugh following his statement.

They'd talked a little longer before they had all mutually agreed to pack it in for the evening. Jack had made them promise -- more Rio than Agatha -- that this was something they could do with some sense of frequency, even offering to find their way to Rio's neck of the woods at some point. Jack had even made a very casual mention of how he would love to see the houseboat. It had forced Rio into a genuine grin as she released him from their hug and stepped back to do the same to Thea, assuring her that the girls would be more than pleased to make her acquaintance in the future.

As Jack and Thea departed, Agatha had taken hold of Rio's hand and tugged her toward the railing that ran around the rooftop, looking out at the city shrouded in night before them.

"That was impressive," Agatha blurted, looking over at Rio with a grin on her face. The question on Rio's face was almost instant and Agatha picked up on it. "You just... sat a table with one of the most revered young couples in Hollywood and you absolutely held your own. Maybe you haven't wanted to talk about it, but I am almost certain you have worried about what it would take to fit in to this side of things. And you just... do it. With Dave, with Jack and Thea." There was this hint of wonder in Agatha's voice but it was only that much more moving when Agatha raised Rio's hand to press her lips to the back of it.

"I am constantly in this suspended state of being completely certain that there is nothing you could do that could possibly make me love you more. And then... you go and do it without even trying."

Rio looked over at her, the gentle affection for the woman she loved completely taking her under.

"I'm just..." Rio hesitated, lips worrying for a moment. "I'm just being myself." She gave a gentle shrug, though after a moment she leaned in to steal a soft kiss. "I guess you're not the only one that finds that to be fascinating."

The way Agatha's expression smoothed and that tender light flickered in her eyes caused that familiar squeeze to happen in Rio's chest.

"Let's go, my love," Agatha offered, not hesitating to steal one last kiss before they peeled away from the edge and headed back to the elevator. Agatha seemed to be on her best behavior during their ride down, which Rio suddenly found quite suspicious, but she did not press.

As they unloaded into the lobby, Rio had been under the assumption that Gio was outside waiting to take them home where they would pour into bed and she was almost certain that Agatha was going to find a way to make her feel every bit the queen Agatha saw when she looked at her.

She was surprised and quite caught off guard, then, when Agatha gave her hand a firm tug, leading her to the front desk. She was completely stunned, left blinking as the man at the desk seemed to recognize Agatha, a warm smile filling his face.

"Is it ready?" she asked him, though her tone was level and even, not overly frantic or hurried.

"Maid service should be done within the next few minutes, but I'm able to give you the key now if you would like," he responded.

"Would you comp their meals for the rest of their stay to my card as well?" she added on, to which the gentleman nodded and set about his task. As he grabbed the correct key, he slid it across the marble edge of the desk.

"Room 2315, Ms. Harkness. They should be done within the next five minutes."

Rio felt like she'd turned to stone, like the entire weight of her form was so heavy that she could have sunk right into the ground.

"Thank you. Have a good evening."

"You as well, ma'am."

With that, Agatha began to pull Rio away but after only a couple of steps, Rio planted her feet, the disbelief still coursing through her.

"Agatha," she asserted, warm green eyes questioning as they fell into those electric blues the moment Agatha whipped around to realize Rio wasn't moving.

"Yes, my love?" she posed innocently, feigning indifference.

"Are you about to take me up to the room we stayed in when I first got here?"

Agatha's grin seemed to be the only answer she was willing to provide for the longest moment, her eyes wrinkled at the corners with how wide it was.

"Of course, my love."

Pull Me In

We traded everything and left the country side
Metal towers, skylines over lucid starlight nights
Found a northside neighborhood that we could call our own
I'm just fine, I'm alive, I am home
*****

Rio hardly felt like she was moving, like she was the one actually in control over her feet carrying her forward. Even as Agatha stopped at the bar and leaned over it just slightly to request that a bottle of the finest wine they had available and two glasses be sent to room 2315, Rio did not think she would be moving without Agatha's assistance.

Room 2315.

Agatha had really done that. She had said the dinner location was unintentional, but something about this felt very intentional. It felt very... Agatha.

The moment the elevator door shut, Rio was actually surprised to realize they would not be doing a play-by-play of their first time in that elevator. Considering Agatha's goading earlier in the day, she'd expected something other than the way Agatha mimicked her actions from that evening on their way up and pulled her close as she leaned against the wall.

Rio leaned in, stealing the briefest and softest kiss before she pulled to look back into those homey blue eyes.

"And why was maid service cleaning out that room at nine-thirty at night?" she posed, a hand landing flat on Agatha's chest, though her thumb and forefinger moved to pinch some of the fabric, rubbing it between her fingertips.

Agatha's eyes dropped to where Rio's hand laid and her lips turned down at the corners in ignorance, as if she had no idea. "I guess they must have moved to a different room."

Rio's eyes narrowed playfully and she raised her hand to place a finger beneath Agatha's chin, forcing her gaze to lift so that their eyes could meet once again.

"Is that so?" Rio pressed, both of her eyebrows arching as if to turn up the volume on her interrogation. "Then why on earth would you comp their meals for the rest of their stay?"

At this, the placidity Agatha had been fighting to maintain slipped and her lips split wide in such a beautiful smile that for just one moment, Rio forgot to breathe.

"Well..." she began, though her cheeks only seemed to push up higher with that grin. "They might have moved because I covered half of their stay and wired them five hundred dollars."

Rio's eyes were wide in an instant and her hand dropped from Agatha's chin to swat lightly at her chest.

"Agatha!" she nearly squealed, both from the shock and from the way Agatha's strong arms secured around her middle in a tight embrace. "I want to say I cannot believe you, but... this checks out."

Rio had hardly finished speaking before she had started to laugh, but Agatha's lips were on hers after another blink, stifling any sound she might have made pretty quickly. The hand that had been hovering between them, just above Agatha's chest, settled again in almost the exact same spot it had been moments ago.

It wasn't a desperate kiss, wasn't one that was begging for immediate attention in other places. It wasn't a grab for clothing or heavy pressure on body to wall.

It was a kiss that Rio understood to be a desire for nostalgia and familiarity, just remixed in a more tender way. It was a kiss that somehow made her heart skip a beat, but then soften in its thuds against her ribcage. It was a kiss that wordlessly informed her of just how much Agatha loved her, and the lengths she would go to in order to show that love.

The sound of the elevator dinging caused Rio to pull away from the exchange, but she didn't go far. Instead, she stayed close enough that she could smell that cherry wine on Agatha's breath.

"Sometimes I don't know what to do with you," Rio mused in a soft whisper, though it was not meant to be alluring. I was instead a statement of her wonder.

Agatha could not be contained. She would never be boxed in or caged. It wasn't for a lack of trying on the world's part, certainly. No, Agatha was something beyond capture, something that would break through any constraints she was placed in.

Agatha was the sun. She was so hot and full of fire in regards to how intensely she lived life, but there were other facets of that to be explored, too. She was light, she was vision. She was illumination of some of the darkest parts Rio had ever known existed in herself.

What it meant to finally lean out of Agatha's grap and take her hand to walk that familiar hall to that familiar room was surreal in its own right. They had walked out of the door they now stood in front of with the intention of moving forward. Now, for a night, they got to go back.

Rio could still recall the way they had been laying in bed and she had nearly shot up to announce that she was ready to go. She could still remember what it felt like as that certainty hit her that she would have been happy anywhere as long as Agatha was right there with her. She could almost feel the weight of what it had felt like when the realization that something cosmically was binding them together had managed to slide under her skin.

As Agatha slipped the key into the lock and pressed the door open, actually seeing the room again made Rio want to cry. Not because she had any doubts or questions about a single decision she had ever made in that room, but because she remembered so suddenly every choice she made in that room that had led her closer and closer to Agatha.

Agatha seemed to pick up on the hesitation and gave Rio's hand a light squeeze, leaning into her so that she could place a kiss to the side of Rio's head.

"Come on, my love," Agatha requested in a light tone as she moved forward to tug Rio inside. Just before the door closed and clicked shut, there was a call from down the hall.

Agatha dropped her hand and moved to catch the door before it closed. With how wide she had pulled it back open, Rio had been able to see the man in his hotel uniform as he brandished the bottle of wine and glasses Agatha had requested on a tray. They made the exchange and Rio could have sworn she heard Agatha apologize for not having cash and that his tip would be added to the room.

A moment later, the door shut and Agatha turned on her heel with the tray in her hands. She was grinning again.

Rio made her way to the familiar side of any bed they slept in and slid atop that impossibly soft duvet. Her eyes cast toward Agatha who was making quick work of pouring them each a healthy glass of the red wine and while there was not an active smile on her face, it was instead threaded through her entire posture.

There was nothing pressing about it, like Agatha's plan was to get her drunk and strip her down. Instead, the fluidity of her movements was unhurried and calm. For as ornery as Agatha could be, and for as much as Rio had assumed she was being inceredibly sly in orchestrating all of this, Rio realized that for the first major time in their relationship, she had misread the room. She had misread Agatha. Not entirely, of course. She knew that want in Agatha's eyes all too well, but for the time being, it was tempered by the reminiscence that was being offered to them, held within those walls.

Rio extended a hand to cradle the glass Agatha offered her before she joined her on the bed, in her spot right against Rio's side.

Rio's head turned and she was ready to ask Agatha what it was they were toasting to, but the contemplative look that was visible on Agatha's profile as she stared into her wine gave Rio pause. It lent to a moment of silence where she let Agatha just... process.

Rio had been right, that very first night on the houseboat when they had sat on her deck and drank their wine.

Agatha looked beautiful when she thought.

The idea had been absurd on that first night, but now, Rio could justify it a little more. Agatha took the time to sort through the own mess in her head to find the perfect way to convey what she was feeling, what she was thinking. She compartmentalized the unimportant so that he focus was on what mattered, and how conveying that could be tricky but so necessary.

Finally, after just a little while longer, Agatha raised her glass. She still did not look at Rio for a second, but then she turned, bringing her glass a little closer to Rio's.

"To room 2315," she offered and while it was a toast, something to celebrate, the undeniable tenderness was there so plainly. Agatha was not loud, she was not exuberant. She was reverent. She was nostalgic. She was appreciative.

Of everything she could have said, it was the most appropriate and emotional thing she could have picked.

The curling of Rio's lips that happened was one that bled with admiration, with affection, and she couldn't keep herself from leaning those few inches toward Agatha to place their lips together in a kiss that only lasted a few seconds.

"To room 2315," Rio agreed, moving her own glass so that the rims clinked softly together.

At the same exact moment, they both leaned back against the headboard. It was a motion that drew a quiet laugh of acknowledgement from both of them.

"Do you know how much I love you?" Rio posed as she brought the wine glass to her lips, though her brows arched pointedly as she glanced over at the woman beside her.

Agatha's own head turned so that they were a little more eye-to-eye, but that smile seemed to be stuck to her face in a way that it could not even be pried off with a crowbar.

"I think I have some idea," she managed back. She took a quick pull from her own glass, but she apparently had a follow-up. "I mean, you love me enough to forgive me when I leave the milk out. And... You love me enough that you will sometimes organize the papers on my desk because you can't stand to see them cluttered and you know I don't have the wherewithal to do it myself, no matter how much it irritates you."

There was a pause and Agatha took another sip of her wine. "You love me enough that even when you're mad about me leaving my clothes everywhere, you still pick them up to wash them. You love me enough that when that happens and you're frustrated, you still kiss me before bed, even if you lay with your back to me but still lay close enough that your little butt is touching me."

"My butt is not little!" Rio clipped back as her brow pinched and she used her free hand to gently hit Agatha's stomach.

"And you love me enough that you don't actually get mad when I call your butt little," Agatha added, the wattage on that smile only seeming to increase. In turn, it only made Rio smile, too.

"Yeah, I guess I kinda do love you that much. But don't sell yourself short, either." Rio's voice was low, quiet, but only in a way that was facilitated by the warmth she was feeling both from the alcohol and also from Agatha's overt display of her love by landing them there.

"Oh?" Agatha posed back, her expression communicating that she was intrigued to hear Rio elaborate.

"Yeah, I mean... You love me enough that when you trip on the hose because I left it out when watering the garden, you still tell me you love me even though you're angry and in pain. You love me enough that when you wake up in the middle of the night and I'm not in bed, you come find me in my spot in the back yard and sit in my lap until my desire to get you back in bed and comfortable again compels me to go back inside with you."

Rio shifted the glass to her inner hand so that she could reach up with the far one to tuck some of Agatha's hair behind her ear. "You love me enough that you forgave me ten seconds after I offended you when I told you that cinematography was more important than dialogue in a film." Rio's lips curled a bit more, though the stretch of her lips conveyed far more than just her joy.

Above all else, Rio knew that she was thankful for Agatha.

For her, that went beyond just loving her. It was a recognition of everything that had been accomplished since they had met, how things had truly changed who Rio was as a person beyond just who she was when she was head over heels in love with Agatha.

"You're right, I do. And I'll love you enough to forgive you no matter how many times I skin my knees. And I'll love you enough that when I can't find you, I'll follow the trails of you to bring you back to me." Agatha closed the space between them with a brief peck before she pulled back, those blues so soft in the way they were filled with the light of her honesty. "And I will always love you enough to make sure you understand that you are my everything, even if we disagree."

Rio closed the gap again, this time with a kiss that had more intent, a kiss that said what she felt too breathless to say in those moments.

What did one even say when the woman of their dreams was looking them in the eye and telling them things like that? Would there ever be any string of words, any verbal articulation that would somehow be able to make Agatha understand that when Rio was with her, she didn't feel completed, but she felt complimented, like two bigger parts had come together to make something that expanded beyond the original size? Would there every truly be any way, within either of the languages she spoke, to get Agatha to understand what every second of time they spent together meant to Rio?

Rio didn't think so, so she let her kiss speak for her.

There was no rush as their lips smacked softly, Rio's palm having found its way home as it curled against the curve of Agatha's jaw, holding her firm but also having enough leverage to bring her closer when Rio wanted. Even after a few moments, the heat did not elevate and the frenzy seemed to be staved off between the both of them for the time being. Agatha was actually the one to pull back, her eyes fluttering open only a single blink after Rio's.

Once again, teeth were showing in a wide and genuine smile and Rio could feel her heart fluttering in her chest at the sight.

"It's... weird, isn't it?" Agatha mused, seeming to fight herself for a moment before she tore her eyes from Rio's to sweep around the room.

RIo's own gaze followed, simply taking in a sight that she could have still so accurately described from the images in her mind. It was peace, in its own way.

"When Jack told you that we were meeting here, did you know you were going to do this?" Rio posed, her head turning back to take Agatha in, though Agatha kept her gaze on the walls, just scanning them.

"No," she answered almost so automatically that Rio was tempted to call her out. Then, her lips twisted and left the corners turned down the tiniest bit. "In fact, I had been actively fighting myself on doing so for the majority of the night. Until about two minutes before I excused myself."

This perplexed Rio and it showed on her face as Agatha's gaze swept toward her.

"What changed your mind?"

Agatha's features pulled the slightest bit, but it was the way her eyes were darting around over the terrain of Rio's face, that same twisting of her lips happening as she searched for words.

"I am just so completely floored by your ability to adapt to any situation you're put in." It was a statement, one that held weight and and an earnest sense of sincerity. "You don't have to put in any effort, it seems like. You just..." A soft puff of air blew through Agatha's nose. It struck Rio that she was struggling, that the words weren't as easy to find as they had been so many times before.

"I guess it's just that I've spent so long drowning myself in work and bad choices that I didn't even realize that I was doing it because I was trying to fill this gaping hole I've carried around in my chest for so long. I... I thought, due to my mother's conditioning, that it was because I needed a relationship and a child. So I got blackout drunk with a sound tech on one of my first films." Agatha stopped, understandably compelled to put her glass on the stand by her side of the bed. Rio mimicked the action and the moment her hand was free, Agatha made a grab for it, holding it in both of her own.

This was a moment Rio had known would come. It was never one she would have asked for, but with it so close she could almost feel it, she simply placed her other hand over Agatha's.

Agatha took a breath and then continued.

"The next morning I hated myself. I had known my entire life it wasn't what I wanted, but I had forced it. It wasn't anything he had done, it was just... It was wrong for me. And I had every intention of not making the same mistake twice and moving in my own way and doing what it was I wanted. And while I didn't ever cross that line again... And I had walked away confident in that decision... And then..."

Rio knew. She knew before Agatha said it.

"And then Nicky happened," Rio concluded, giving Agatha's hands a firm squeeze to communicate that she understood, even if Agatha was already aware. Sure, their situations were vastly different but there were enough similarities that Rio finally understood why Agatha had always been so empathetic.

Rio had never asked for what happened to her.

Agatha had completely incapacitated herself to make a decision she had been conditioned to believe was the right one, only to find self-loathing and a lifelong responsibility of raising a child.

Rio sensed that there was a lot more to uncover there, but it seemed as though Agatha was satisfied with where it had ended up.

"All of that was a roundabout way of saying that even with doing what I thought I could, even having my amazing son, even chasing every dream I've ever had... That hole never went away." Agatha paused and drew in a slow breath. "Then, I spent six hours with you on the deck of your home and it was the most whole I could ever remember feeling in... Damn near my entire life."

The longer Agatha went on, the more Rio could feel -- very acutely -- as the backs of her eyes began to sting and burn. Agatha had said a lot of flattering things to her over the course of their relationship, but there was a depth here that they had not quite reached before.

"I know that each and every single person that you have met in my life had undeniably questioned my sanity when I explained to them what happened and how I felt about it. And every single interaction I have watched between you and those people... I've gotten to watch it creep in, the light of dawning as they begin to understand. In the way you told me that you liked being able to see me through the lens of the people that care for me... There has been something so... utopian about watching the people I care for as they see for themselves every reason I am so hopelessly devoted to you."

That had done it. The hot emotional tears finally found their escape, spilling over Rio's lids to roll down her cheeks. Agatha was quick in releasing her hand to reach up and brush them away. She cradled Rio's cheek in her palm, that loving look in her eyes so goddamn honest.

"I could almost guarantee that I could throw you into a room with the entire Landon family and you'd come out with twenty new friends. Because... they love me. And who you are is a part of me, now."

The emotion that had completely taken over Rio left her stunned for just a moment, enough to blink through a long strand of thoughts, but she knew it was pointless to try and use words, yet again.

So then, to be laying there nearly an hour later staring at the ceiling with a snoring Agatha on her chest, their skin pressed together everywhere on her side all the way down to where Agatha had her leg hooked over Rio's own, Rio was annoyed.

She had not been entirely wrong, but something was keeping her up. For the first half an hour, she didn't even know what it was.

It had been in the way Agatha's arms had pulled taut in her attempt to unlock from Rio's grasp, her fingers releasing their hold in an effort to regain her faculties, but Rio had held on for that second too long.

It shouldn't have been bothering her. It clearly had not affected Agatha enough for it to show past that one spike of a moment that was now living rent free in Rio's mind. So then what about it was literally keeping her awake?

The longer she laid there, green eyes locked onto one specific spot on the ceiling, she began to question herself. She was making a big deal in her own mind over nothing... right? It had been literally miniscule in the grand scheme of their night together. It had been a glitch, just a hiccup in time that displaced rationale.
