Rio was able to put her phone away after that, turning to the rest of their evening with Agatha. They'd put on a movie, made out for a little bit, and after they'd all but abandoned the film, Agatha wickedly informed her that clothes were not the only thing she grabbed when she'd gone home.

That had turned Rio about six shades of red, but more out of excitement than anything else.

And so, they had spent their last night in that hotel room absolutely fucking like feral teenagers. It had been hot, it had been raw and primal in a way that gave Rio such a rush, a coursing of excitement that lasted for the hours they tangled and kissed and licked and sucked. It was hips slamming into hips, hands grabbing every single spot they could hold onto.

What it had really been was yet another display of how much they loved each other. It was a showing of their ability to completely ravish one another, to get so entirely lost in the physical closeness that came with being so intimate.

They had fallen asleep much earlier that night, but only after Agatha had booked them a flight out the next evening that left at five. They had both decided to not disclose their early arrival to the children, as Rio had hoped they might, wanting to surprise them with an early return.

The next morning, they'd gotten up early enough to check out and had grabbed breakfast at an adorable little diner. Mid-meal, Agatha had stated that she needed to stop by her office before they left to grab a few things she wanted to take back with her.

Rio knew the moment she said it that it was a ploy, but she went along with it.

She also went along with the office sex that Agatha had not hesitated to initiate with a request that they be much quieter since the office was full that time. At one point, as Rio was bent over Agatha's desk and Agatha was completely taking her from behind while also pinning Rio to the cool wood with her hand on her back, someone had knocked.

The sound of Agatha's voice as she had screeched a NOT NOW had almost ripped Rio from the moment and sent her into a fit of laughter, but Agatha cut that off immediately by sinking a third finger inside of her. That had Rio biting her own arm to stifle the sound that was begging to escape her.

For them, the office had been a quickie, but it had thoroughly exhausted Rio by the time they poured into their seats on that plane. It had taken each of them less than an hour to fall asleep. Neither of them stayed that way the whole flight, but they'd cut off a large chunk of the wait in their slumber.

As they walked up their drive, hand in hand, they were each donning grins that were obvious displays of how excited they were to be home, to be back with their children. Although it wasn't intentional, little noise was made as Agatha unlocked the door and pushed it open.

From where they stood in the doorway as they pushed their small suitcases to the side, Rio could tell that the television was on in the living room but there were no other noises to indicate who might have been occupying the space.

They stepped further into the home on quiet feet after having removed their shoes and were met with the backs of two heads over the top of the couch.

It was not Estee and Tay.

Agatha's grin filled her face in an instant and it was positively devious. She let go of Rio's hand and strode over, scaring the life out of the two men as she came around the side of the couch and placed herself directly next to Nicky, her palms slapping to the tops of her thighs in excitement and also perhaps a dash of mischief.

"Good evening, boys!" she chirped at them.

In moments like that, Rio could only beam with how in love she was with that woman.

This Time Around

Fell, ten thousand feet In a sea
To be a somebody
All I ever needed was you to believe in me
*****

For just a moment, Rio simply stood back to behold the scene before her.

She didn't need to see Nicky's face to realize that the second his mother placed herself on the couch next to him, he had turned at least twelve different shades of red. While Rio and Agatha had wanted it to be a surprise that they got to come home sooner, they definitely had not expected to stumble upon a pot of gold upon their return.

Rio could almost see the way Agatha was buzzing. It wasn't even that she'd out-maneuvered Nicky. In fact, Rio was pretty sure the last thing Agatha was thinking about was the conversation they'd had with the girls that had left her confidence a little dinged. What Agatha was seeing in that moment was that her son had found someone he liked spending time with, maybe even someone he had started to care for. What Agatha was seeing was that there was a young man sitting right there who looked at her son and could see any flicker of a future with him.

Surely, that future had included meeting Agatha a lot further down the line, but that didn't match the brand of chaos that went on in the Harkness-Vidal household, now did it?

Rio watched as the man on the other side of Nicky sat up a little bit and turned toward Agatha. She could see other movement, but could not see the way Hmi extended his hand to Agatha who took it and gave it a light shake, even though she knew it was happening.

"It's a pleasure to meet you, Ms. Harkness. I'm Hmi. I've heard so much about you."

Agatha was fucking beaming. Rio had seen her be giddy over things before, but this was on another level entirely. There were enough lights in her eyes that LA at night would have been put to shame. That smile could have given the sun a run for its money.

Agatha was just... happy.

That wasn't to say that she wasn't happy around Rio, because everyone was well aware that she was, but this was a different strain of happiness. This was a different expression of joy that could only have ever surfaced in regards to her son.

Agatha still thought in the darker moments that she had damaged Nicky in ways that not only would he never forgive her for, but that he might never recover from. She still worried that even though she had tried her hardest to repair what she had broken between them, it might taint whatever they could build.

Right then, none of that touched Agatha's expression. There was just thrill and excitement in every single muscle. There was just utter anticipation as to how this might unfold.

"Please, you can call me Agatha."

Nicky had realized, despite his embarrassment, that something was slightly off. As he went to question it, Hmi was actually the one who turned to look behind him.

He was speaking, but the moment Rio saw his face, she wasn't really listening.

"And it's nice to meet you as well, Ms. Vidal. Nicky has a lot of good things to say about you too."

It was a sweet introduction, sure, but it was not what was keeping Rio quiet.

Rio's complete control over her own cognition had slipped. She was starstruck.

That was quite a hilarious thought given who she was engaged to, but there had always been something a little off-kilter about the things Rio valued in her life.

The fact that she was staring at the face of a Prop on the All Blacks had her feeling like she was about to faint.

At the prolonged silence, Agatha too turned to look at her, followed a moment later by Nicky. All three of them, heads over the back of the couch, were just staring at her. Rio knew she needed to talk, needed to say something -- anything -- but the words simply would not produce themselves.

Surely this was something the two men had discussed between themselves, and Nicky knew how Rio felt about the All Blacks.

This was evident the moment she found herself able to shift her gaze and it landed on him. The grin he was wearing was ridiculous. He knew exactly what was happening and he knew that Rio was probably a good five seconds from having a coronary.

"Rio... Are you okay?" Agatha's voice was concerned but there was still a lightness to it, like she realized that nothing was wrong but something had stopped her in her tracks.

"I... But I..." Rio fumbled, her eyes cutting back to Hmi who had also started to grin.

Agatha glanced to her side at the two grinning idiots next to her and felt completely out of the loop, and it showed on her face.

"Is someone going to explain since my fiance is too incapacitated to speak?" Agatha bit, though it was more out of confusion than anything else.

"Hmi plays Prop #3 for the All Blacks. We did not know you guys were coming home, obviously, or I would have at least tried to prep her!" By the time he finished speaking, Nicky was damn near giggling and the dawning realization washed over Agatha's expression.

She whipped her head to the side, pinning Rio with a narrowed gaze.

"Really!? You had dinner with two of Hollywood's biggest names right now and this is what stuns you?!" It was a little shrill, and the disbelief was there, but Rio could so clearly hear the goading and playfulness in Agatha's tone.

Finally, Rio found her sense -- or, at least some of it -- but she was still transfixed on Hmi.

"You're Hmi Manaaki. You... You played in the Bunnings for Auckland before joining the All Blacks two years ago." It was said like a statement, but the truth was that Rio just needed to hear it out loud, even if it came from her own lips.

"I am. And I am also incredibly flattered that you know that." His voice was so warm and he looked like he genuinely was taken aback by not only the awe, but by the knowledge Rio possessed about his career.

Agatha was watching, completely and entirely tickled, as she was bearing witness to a new side of the woman she loved.

The woman who had never had any idea who Agatha was until she saw her on the Oscars.

The woman who had dinner with Hollywood stars and did not bat an eye.

The woman who was currently shell-shocked in her own home because she was meeting a rugby player from her favorite team.

There truly was no end to the wonder Rio could bring to Agatha's life, and it showed on Agatha's face.

"And..." Rio managed, raising a feeble finger to wave it back and forth in indication. "You... this... you guys? Together?"

The delighted humor on Agatha's expression only seemed to grow. She had literally never had any chance to see Rio like this before, bumbling and trying to feel her way through a conversation without completely wrecking herself in the process.

"Yes, ma'am," Hmi responded, though Rio did not miss the way he glanced toward Nicky as he answered, or the way his smile seemed to grow as he did it.

"This was most assuredly not on her bingo card this year, so please forgive her for being entirely incoherent," Agatha supplemented in Rio's silence as she looked toward Hmi, her smile pushing up her cheeks so high that it almost looked it her eyes were closed.

"I am just..." Rio managed, her heart still racing in her chest at the feeling of not knowing how to behave in front of someone she held a great deal of admiration and appreciation for in such a regard.

Rio had always loved rugby, ever since she was eight and her papa had taken her to her first match. She had even played a bit of it in secondary school, but she realized pretty quickly that she did not possess the brute force or dexterity needed for it. Still, it had never quelled her appreciation for it, though.

Maybe it had rooted with her father and those games when she was a kid, but the older Rio got, the more it became an escape. It was a chance every week to get away, to watch the thrilling game of catch and chase as it unfolded before her eyes. There was something exhilarating about the way impacts could sometimes be heard from the stands. There was also something about the unity that being a team provided in that specific way that was moving to Rio.

Watching fifteen players get into a scrum formation could get her blood pumping every time. It was about the fight, the battle to prove who wanted it more. It was a ferocity that Rio as a human had never had much of in her life, and so she chose to live vicariously through a sports team that she'd loved for most of her life.

"I am in awe, I guess," Rio finally managed. "I've always just sat in the stands, never one to push the pitch in celebration. So... I suppose I am just appreciative of your hard work and dedication."

Two heads down, the look on Agatha's face had softened exponentially. It was almost like she was understanding it through seeing it. There was respect written all over Rio's face, and while she was quick to show respect to her family, this was a little different.

This was a physical presence of something important to Rio, something that had been a part of her for almost as long as she could actually remember.

Although it took another moment, Rio found it in her to move in a way that allowed her to come around the side of the couch, stopping behind Agatha as her hand landed between Agatha's shoulders.

"What I have been meaning to say this entire time is that it's a pleasure to meet you too, Hmi."

She leaned forward and extended a hand that he met easily, giving a light shake.

"So..." Agatha drawled as she absentmindedly reached up for Rio's hand as she retracted it and used it so that she could drape it over her shoulder. Rio let her palm fall to Agatha's chest as the hand that had been on her back slid to rest on the opposite shoulder. "Surprise! We are home early! Where are the girls?"

Rio was grinning there behind her, not only because of the way Agatha was speaking, but because Rio could literally feel her vibrating with the joy this had bestowed upon her. It had been a pleasant surprise, but she could tell that for Agatha, it was a little more.

It was an opportunity to do right. She could play the annoying mom card, sure, and she absolutely would. However, this was... different. This was Agatha realizing that she had stumbled into a moment that would be a hallmark for Nicky if this relationship went somewhere. It was surely not how he had intended things to go, but if Rio knew anything, she knew that Agatha was not going to fuck this up for him, even if she did have her fun in the process.

"They went for a surf but said they'd be back after they got dinner. Knowing them, they're probably tipsy, holding hands and walking through the street downtown talking about all the different uses for seaweed."

As obscure as that would have sounded, he'd pretty much hit the nail on the head.

In turn, it made Rio burst into laughter, leaning over Agatha slightly in her humor. It was a very vivid reminder of how wild their children could be, and how silly.

For a moment, Rio was reminded of that text message with its little emoji. The tender smile that formed as she straightened back up was something Rio was glad Agatha could not see, even if it might not have seemed so out of place with where they currently were.

They really did have some amazing kids.

The four of them had sat like that, Rio shifting only slightly so that she could rub Agatha's shoulders in a unconscious show of affection every so often. They talked about the basics, about where Hmi grew up, some of his favorite things to do.

When he brought up his love for photography, Rio could feel in Agatha's shoulders where the pieces fell into place in her mind. That was the tie, for those two men. Looking at the world through a lens and capturing its beauty was where the pull to one another had probably started. It was clear, even in the little glances they stole at one another, that something more was growing, though.

Listening to him talk about his family, the little spots he tucked away in as he grew older, Rio was thankful for it, but not for the reasons anyone else might have thought.

Rio was getting to literally feel beneath her fingertips as Agatha ingested a new point of view on a place Rio loved so dearly. She was getting snippets from someone else, from an outside perspective that had an entirely different appreciation for where they now lived as a family. For Hmi, his entire life was grounded in family and it showed in the way he spoke and held himself.

There was a deeply rooted sense of pride in being Mori and Hmi was a perfect display of that.

As the conversation wound down, Hmi had announced that it was probably best he head home and get some rest before he had to be up early enough to make it to training on time. The three occupants on the couch joined Rio in her position on her feet.

Rio watched as, with a wide and sweeping smile that was -- as Estee had put it -- so very handsome, Hmi turned to Agatha and lifted his arms for an embrace. Agatha stepped in and gave him a very gentle and very motherly hug, patting his back as she let go.

"It has been a treat getting to know you. I hope that you would like to make this a habit in the future, because I think I speak for the both of us," Agatha said, indicating with a sweet flourish of her hand toward where Rio stood just behind her, "when I say we would be delighted to have you."

Agatha released her hold on his biceps and stepped back, an automatic hand sliding to the small of Rio's back to guide her forward.

"Ms. Vidal," he acknowledge with that same smile and a gentle tip of his head to ask if she would like a hug too.

He didn't know it, but that unasked question was a stupid one.

While she was able to find restraint over the course of their evening, there was something about hugging him, knowing that this was the man someone she loved was growing to care for that made the moment just a little bit more special for her.

Rio let him go and Nicky was swift in picking up his hand and offering to walk him out, despite that jocular look that was written all over Agatha's expression. He didn't appear to be antsy or uncomfortable; it was more something along the lines of 'Holy shit, you just survived meeting the parents.'

As the door pulled shut behind them, Agatha immediately sank into Rio side, her arm hooking around Rio's back as she let her head fall to rest atop Rio's shoulder.

"I didn't fuck that up, right?" Agatha asked softly and even though her voice was low, Rio could still hear the edge of trepidation as it snuck in.

"You did not fuck that up, my love," Rio soothed, turning her head just enough to place a kiss to the top of Agatha's head, centered in the middle part of her hair. "In fact, I truly do think we will be seeing more of him. Did you catch the way he looked at Nicky when he was talking?"

For as wide as Rio's grin was, she could feel against where Agatha had her face pressed to Rio's form where hers may have been bigger.

"Nicky looked pretty smitten, too, don't you think?" Agatha asked back, the softest laughter spilling from her.

Rio shifted slightly in a way that prompted Agatha to lift her head so that they were eye-to-eye again. There was no hesitation from Rio as she leaned toward her and stole a sweet kiss, a hand raising to lay flat against her chest. They stood like that for a long moment, just watching, just listening for the things that might not get said. Finally, Rio spoke.

"Before... all of this," Rio voiced, her free hand waving around them to indicate the state of their entire life, "Nicky's answer was to run. It was to protect himself, and to do what he needed to in order to get by. But the young man that just sat there for an hour, holding the hand of his boyfriend, while they got the third-degree... He's not the same Nicky that went to Dubai. Hell, I don't even think he's the same Nicky we came home that night from the hotel."

Rio could see the emotion winning out, first in Agatha's eyes and then in each muscle of her face. This was what happened when Rio knew exactly how to point out the things Agatha needed to hear.

"And... I think that we should be sinking stock into the fact that he is invested in trying to find relationships here. Even if doing so means giving me a heart attack."

At this, Agatha breathed a soft laugh and Rio's hand raised to cup her cheek.

"Just remember that we're all learning new things about each other every single day. There's never going to be a wrong way to do that, so long as we let it inform how we move forward. So... as we always do, we just take it a day at a time."

With this piece of sage wisdom, Rio leaned forward and pressed her lips to Agatha's in a tender but chaste kiss before she pulled away, but was still close enough that their fronts brushed with any movement or shift.

Rio had started to suggest that they get down a bottle of wine and fold into bed for the rest of the evening, but before she could, she heard the sound of giggles and laughter from outside the front door.

A moment later, the door opened and their three children came shuffling in.

Their little triad of diamonds.

"Oh! Good! You're on you're feet!" Estee chirped as Rio turned around to face the door, though her hand stayed stationed on Agatha's chest as she did so.

"No thanks to literally any of you?!" Rio managed back, pitch a little higher than normal.

"Okay, in my defense... I just knew he played. I did not know until literally two minutes ago as he was leaving who he played for! So, that one can be all Nick's fault," Estee stated with another burst of giggles as she leaned into Tay who caught her with ease and kept her on her feet.

Rio's eyes narrowed but the grin she wore was instant and absolutely amused.

"Hm," Rio blew out in a puff of air. "Meeting Nicky's boyfriend and seeing my daughter drunk? This really was the best night to come home."

*****

The five of them had gathered in the living room for a little while to catch up and Estee and Tay had not hesitated to ask for every detail there was to be had about Rio's experience meeting Jack and Thea. It had been so cute to see how excited they were, as well as the looks on their tipsy faces when Rio assured them that Jack and Thea both expressed their excitement in getting the chance to meet them, whether it was at the wedding or before.

It had been this strange feeling of peace and serenity, of sheer rapture that had warmed them like a thick blanket as they just... did what families did.

After only a little while, though, the exhaustion had started to creep in. Sure, it was a given for Agatha and Rio who had spent almost the last three quarters of their day on a plane, but Rio could see it in the way Nicky sagged into the couch and the way Estee's eyes had fallen closed as her head rested against Tay's shoulder.

She had been the first to get to her feet, but she was quick in pulling Agatha up behind her. They each showered all three of the kids with cheek kisses and soft 'goodnights' before they turned to depart. As Agatha headed for the stairs, though, Rio let go of her hand in a way that allowed her to run her fingertips along Agatha's palm and the entire length of her fingers until they separated. Agatha had started to offer protest but Rio held up a finger in a request for just a moment as she floated her way to the kitchen only to return a moment later with a bottle of red and two wine glasses.

"A goodnight snack," she had indicated, holding her full hands up with a grin.

They had made their way up to their little corner of heaven and the moment Rio set down the bottle and glasses on her nightstand, she felt as Agatha's hands landed on her sides and she stepped into Rio's back. Her lips pressed to the back right of Rio's hair, stilled there for just a moment as Agatha breathed in the scent of her shampoo.

"Do you know..." Agatha murmured against her scalp, "That there is not a single day since I have met you where I have not questioned the fabric of reality itself?"

Rio giggled softly, leaning her head back into the contact the slightest bit. "Please do elaborate, I feel like this is good," she beseeched, that giggle still sparking through her words.

Agatha's hands began to shift, winding their way around Rio's front to wrap around her, holding her close. Agatha's face moved but only to tuck inward in the way that allowed her to place a kiss to the side of Rio's head.

"There are these... moments. They don't last long, but there's one or two a day... They just feel like they exist outside of time. There are certain points when I look at you, or Estee, or Nicky, or Tay and I am struck with such a profound sense of..." Agatha hesitated, her lips twisting in thought, but she seemed dissatisfied with what she was managing to grab hold of. "Ack, 'love' just doesn't feel strong enough. I guess it just feels like, when that happens, that this will be a life I have no matter how many times I revisit this earth. This is what is meant for me."

The longer Agatha had talked, the more Rio could feel herself melting. She knew that while Agatha was aware of the power of her words, she also sometimes doubted herself in trying to convey what she needed to clearly.

Rio leaned back into her, humming softly at the security and warmth she felt there every single time it was where she wound up.

"Do you know that when you say things like that, it makes me feel like 'love' doesn't cut it, either?" Rio breathed at her in something that hardly reached the registers of a whisper.

Agatha's head ducked a little bit lower as she pressed her lips to the crook of Rio's neck, her hands sliding up to cross over Rio's chest, squeezing her tightly.

"I am yours forever, Rio," Agatha murmured against her skin, "And I'll remind you every single day."

Rio's head turned, causing her lips to brush Agatha's forehead immediately, her own soft words spilling over skin.

"And I am yours, my hopeless romantic," Rio returned, though she had not been able to keep the soft prodding out of her words.

The tightening of Agatha's grip just seemed to prove her point.

Blow Your Mind

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

I know it's hot, I know we've got
Something that money can't buy
Fighting to fifths, biting your lip
Loving too late in the night.
*****

In the Harkness-Vidal household, time had a strange way of working.

On one side of the coin, it was as if it was slow, it was careful, it was patient. There, in the softest moments, it could have stilled and not one of the five of them would have been the wiser. It was intentional in the way that every memory made in every second was there for an impression, branded into who they were as individuals and who they were as a family.

On the other side of that coin, it felt to Rio like she had blinked a couple of times and suddenly, they were only weeks from their trip to Los Angeles for their wedding.

It still didn't feel real. They'd picked a venue, they'd picked a cake, and in a move that was so them, they had also decided on the attire. There was something different about it, though, something that was unique to them and also very indicative of who they were as a couple that was about to tie their lives together.

They had chosen one another's outfits.

They had each laid out specifications: Rio wanted a suit. She didn't care what color it was, but she was absolutely not going to be climbing into a dress if it could be avoided for this experience. It wasn't to say she would never wear one, but for this, it simply wasn't what she wanted.

Agatha, however, certainly wanted a dress. It couldn't be too frilly, couldn't be too flashy. The color was up for choice, as well, but it had to be anything other than white.

That had made Rio grin. Of course Agatha would toss even that tradition out the window.

What it came down to was that they, as a couple, had been and likely always would be a little more on the unconventional side. Nothing about them had ever made sense and yet, they just worked. They were complimentary to one another in that they did not need to complete each other because as individuals, they were already whole.

Finding Agatha had been like finding an addition Rio had never known needed to be built onto her life to provide more room for the love she was capable of feeling.

Part of the exchange was that neither of them would see their clothing until the day of the wedding. Agatha's dress had arrived already and was stored safely in the closet of Estee and Tay's room in the big house. What Rio did not know was that her suit was sitting in Nicky's closet for the same very reason.

With the trip and the idea of the honeymoon after -- which was going to be in Iceland, per Agatha's insistence that Rio experience snow for the first time in her life -- Rio had decided to make it her mission to dedicate what time she could to work before then.

It was her intention to finish it, to get that damn drone off of that desk. She knew that it meant spending her additional time hunched over her laptop, glasses at the end of her nose as she wrote and edited code for hours on end. Rio knew she was close. She knew that if she could just keep pushing, she would be able to complete it before they left.

With just under two weeks until that happened, she was beginning to panic over the fact that she might not actually meet such an accomplishment. She did what she could to keep a lid on that worry but it still sat there and she knew that if it got much worse, Agatha was going to pick up on it and Rio feared that if she was confronted about it, she was going to fall apart.

The work Rio was doing was important to her. It was a dedication of years of her life and she could feel that she was so close to the top, so close to victory but there were certain lines that had been giving her hell for days and she was bordering on driving herself up a wall to figure it out.

So, it was a Sunday afternoon and they had thirteen days left until they got on a plane -- The Hoatzin, as it turned out -- to head for America. That was thirteen days for Rio to figure this the fuck out.

Rio was hunched at her desk in the office, leaning forward to get close enough to the screen to see if she might somehow be able to locate her error by magnifying her ability to see it. As if it was going to work on the eight-hundredth try as opposed to the other seven-hundred-ninety-nine times before it.

On the couch in the office sat her fiance, knees pulled up with an iPad propped against them. Agatha had stated that Jack had sent her some footage from what he was working on and asked her to review it. There were times when Rio would glance over and Agatha's nose was scrunched, or she pulled down the large glasses that Rio had been offended to know she needed sometimes to pinch the bridge of her nose. Rio's offense wasn't to her having them, it was to the fact that for as big of a deal as Agatha had made about Rio wearing glasses, she had never supplemented the information on her own.

This, she told Rio, was because she had hated them; she insisted they made her look like her mother. Rio had quickly asserted that she didn't know what Agatha's mother had looked like, but if it was anywhere close to the demonic vision she had in her head, she was far prettier.

It was this tiny showing, one of a few since Evanora had died, that Agatha was taking back the control in her life. There were other ways she had been doing that, ways that were far more intimate.

It was how, one night after they'd gone to the beach so Rio could surf for a little while Agatha sat on the sand watching her, they had come home and fell into one another as they usually did but Agatha made a decision that Rio had never been anticipating.

Agatha had taken hold of Rio's hand and moved it to where her wrist had been laying above her head. Agatha had been very deliberate in the way she had locked Rio's fingers around it and the way she had met Rio's gaze with her own before whispering the softest Don't let go. It had done something to Rio that first time that she hardly knew how to place, let alone explain.

Agatha had trauma, that was something Rio was aware of. The fact that Agatha, in that beautiful head of hers, was actively taking steps to cope with that trauma? It was so fucking emotional that Rio simply needed time to process it, though in the moment she had complied. Even when Agatha had started to jerk away, despite the soft but pleasured 'Don't' that slipped through her lips, Rio had still listened.

There had been no tears, even if there had been a strong showing of emotion as Rio tended to the after-care part of what Agatha needed most. Agatha had taken the leap, and Rio had been right there to catch her. The pride it had caused her was so insane that Rio had been convinced she could not keep it contained.

Agatha loved her more than she knew how to say, so she chose ways to show Rio instead.

It had started happening with a little more frequency, Agatha sacrificing those modicums of control and giving herself over a bit more each time to someone she knew was never going to hurt her when in that position of power.

Similarly, Rio loved Agatha more than she knew how to say, so she chose to listen instead.

Rio was always listening, even then as she sat at her desk and heard every sigh and giggle that would flitter out of Agatha at whatever was holding her attention.

Rio would sit back, lean forward, type furiously and then repeat the process. Somewhere in her fourth bout, she'd caught something out of the corner of her eye. Agatha had started doing something that was probably a tick, something she likely didn't even realize she was doing. Her hand would move as she flicked her wrist, her fingers flexing in the air. It was such an absent-minded gesture that Rio was sure Agatha had no clue just how much it was catching her attention from across the room.

For the first few minutes, Rio tried to ignore it. Every time Agatha did it, though, Rio couldn't help but to steal a glance at her.

Agatha's hair was pulled back and tied into a ponytail at the base of her skull and those clear-framed glasses looked somehow cuter when she frowned and those little lines between her eyebrows appeared over the frame. Her lips would twitch into a smile, or sometimes a frown, but each time Rio looked at her, she appeared entirely focused and concentrated.

She looked so effortlessly good in those shorts that were too short for public purview but perfect for Rio's. With the way she was sitting, Rio could see the tiniest sliver of her ass cheek which would cause her lips to curl involuntarily every single time she managed to sneak a glance.

She was thrumming with the power of what it was to revolutionize a side of technology that had only been slowly progressing in recent times. This was huge and Rio knew it.

Agatha did too.

Rio licked her lips, eyes filling with wildfire. Agatha didn't want to ask her that.

"I'm not sure you want to hear that answer," Rio finally forced out, her dry throat warping the sound of the words as they left her lips.

"Tell me."

*****

The next morning, after a much needed shower together, Agatha had decided to take her weekly trip to see the farmer she'd made friends with and Rio had let her go with a soft kiss and an insistence that she had a book she could surely tend to. Agatha had made a comment about her wearing her glasses, to which Rio had simply stated only if she could borrow Agatha's. It had earned her a pointed glare right before Agatha had told her she loved her and walked out the door.

An hour later, Rio sat on the couch in the living area, legs crossed beneath her as she hunched over the book in her lap. She was truly immersed in the story before her when she heard the soft clinking of metal pots and pans behind her and lifted her head to see Nicky in the kitchen rummaging through cabinets.

"Mijo?" she called to him. "What are you looking for?"

"Has visto la licuadora? Quiero un licuado."

"Yeah, it's --" Rio caught herself mid-response as the auditory echo of the moment replayed in her head. Her brow pinched tight and she was staring a hole directly into him.

"Nicky... Qu dices?"

Rio could see it on his face as he was actively fighting to keep the smile from gracing his expression.

"Pregunt... Donde est la licuadora?"

Rio blinked at him.

"Nicholas... How..."

At this point, there was no use trying to hide his giddy grin.

"How else, mama?"

"Oh, that daughter of mine is in big trouble."

Nicky's grin grew wild and wicked, the lights dancing in his eyes.

"I don't think that she's going to be in as much trouble as you are when mom comes home and you realize that I'm not the only one who's been taking lessons."

At this, Rio's jaw dropped and her eyes went wide.

He was right. Rio was in big trouble.

Chapter End Notes

Tell The World That We Finally Got It All Right

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Let the sun fade out to a dark sky.
I can't say I'd even notice if it was absent
Cause I could live by the light in your eyes.
Unfold before you
Would have strung together
The very first words of a lifelong love letter
*****

The day had finally arrived.

The five -- technically six because Hmi had joined as well -- members of the Harkness-Vidal family had touched down in Los Angeles earlier in the week, met with a warm and vibrant LA spring.

In a move that Rio learned Agatha had not known about, Jack, Thea, as well as the man Agatha introduced as Walker, had met them at the private airstrip where The Hoatzin had landed a little ways outside of Malibu.

Walker stepped forward toward Rio, holding his arms out in an unasked question. She grinned and walked toward him, taking the embrace.

"You are very quickly becoming a fan favorite in our home," he told her with a gentle chuckle as they separated. "Jack and Thea have had nothing but the highest praises to sing. I know that there are a couple of heads in my household that have been excited about this since your dinner together."

Rio could feel the blush on her cheeks; realizing that she was the topic of discussion in a home filled with powerful and talented people did something to her in a way that could prove in no other showing than that pink dust on her skin.

Rio might have doubted her own ability to be completely enchanting, but Agatha did not.

Agatha knew what and who Rio was in this world and never doubted it. Getting to see her integrate further into Agatha's life was a joy that perhaps Rio may never understand the gravity of.

Upon seeing their welcoming committee, the girls had both completely lost their minds while Nicky had simply met Jack with some concocted secret handshake that had made Rio chuckle from the distance between them.

Watching as Thea pulled Estee into a hug was quite a sight, given the way Estee looked like she was so excited she was going to either cry or vibrate out of her skin. It was both sweet and beautiful in the fact that it was like watching more pieces of the puzzle of their lives as they fell into exactly the right places.

Departing the runway had meant taking the girls to a new home that belonged to them, too. When they arrived, Rio had been completely floored as Agatha showed the girls their room, that she'd apparently put Dave to work. The room had been painted a pastel teal color -- Estee's favorite -- and there were several sweet touches across it. On one of the white nightstands, there was a succulent plant and two picture frames.

In one, it was a photo Nicky had taken of Estee and Tay on the beach. They were wrapped around each other, clearly in a state of laughter as the sun sank over the vast ocean behind them. It was so, so sweet.

In the other, it was a photo Rio had never seen before. It was herself and Estee; Estee's head was tilted up and she was looking at something out of frame. Next to her, Rio was looking at her daughter with the love and pride only a mother could have for her child. It had almost made Rio cry, but she had stuffed it down.

Tay's nightstand looked similar with a little philodendron that sat between two photos, as well. The one of the two girls there had been one that Rio knew to have been taken by Agatha. They had been out at dinner one night and Tay had leaned in to whisper in Estee's ear with a smile on her face so big it nearly let off a glare in the camera lens. The other, it was all five of them, but it was a photo Nicky had used his tripod for. Tay had run to make sure it was working correctly and as she tried to sprint back, the photo had snapped. As a result, Rio, Agatha, Nicky, and Estee were all mid-laughter and Tay's back was visible, some of the sand she was kicking up catching in the light.

It was their brand of chaos.

As the weight of it all truly landed, the girls both turned and nearly threw themselves at Agatha, who only staggered slightly as she caught them.

"It's perfect, Agatha," Estee had nearly squealed into her neck, hugging her tightly.

"It really is. Thank you," Tay added. The emotion in both of their voices had been strong, enough to give Rio a good thump in the middle of her chest.

"I owe most of the credit to Dave. He did all of the leg work." Agatha's voice was warm, but the appreciation was there. "Obviously, you don't have to live here forever and we are of the understanding that you will eventually want your own home, but you'll always have somewhere to fall back to if you ever need it. It's yours forever."

Another thump, square in the center, nearly cracking Rio's sternum in a way that made her eyes sting with tears. Those tears only fell as she looked up at Agatha who's expression resembled melted ice on a summer's day as she clung to the girls.

Rio's girls.

Now they were Agatha's girls, too.

Every single time that realization struck Rio with force, it was almost disorienting.

While the days following had been filled with last minute trips and errands, they'd made time to go over to the Landon mansion in order to properly make introductions to the entire outfit. It had been intense in the best way. Learning everyone's names was going to take Rio a couple of days but she knew that with the more time they all spent together, it was going to get easier.

As a family, the Landons were absolutely formidable. As individuals, each and every single one of them was a work of art. They had their own niches, fell into their own careers, and they had become spectacular humans in the process.

Rio's favorite part about that night in particular had been watching as Estee engaged in conversation with Cole, a meeting of minds that had been called by Thea that night at dinner those weeks ago. They were both lit up and holding a very clear dialogue that was bouncing back and forth, and judging by the hand motions and moments of pause for thought, Rio could tell they were talking shop in regards to psychology.

There were other moments that Rio locked in her mind, too.

There was the way Agatha had stood with her arm slung around Nicky's shoulder and Hmi held his opposite hand as they shared wine on the back deck in conversation and Rio had returned from the washroom to behold the sight.

It was the way Rio had sidled up to Nicky and tilted her head to lay against the side of his shoulder as they bathed in the light of the setting sun.

There was the way that Tay and Rianne talked about wanting to travel and see more of the world, which had included an off-handed invitation from Rianne that they come see Paris, where her boyfriend was from, some time.

It was also in the way that, as Rio had stood back to consume the sheer chaos, the Landon matriarch, Adam, sidled up to her.

"I know it's a lot," she'd said, tilting her head up toward Rio a bit. "But... After the twelve texts I got the night you an Agatha met Thea and Jack for dinner, this moment in the making has been a very justifiable cause for buzz in this home."

That made Rio smile so hard her face ached.

When they had departed that evening, their goodbyes had taken almost twenty-five minutes. It was almost comical, really, the way everyone made sure to get a hug from every occupant in the room they did not already live with. It was beautifully chaotic in the most pure way that Rio realized she had ever experienced.

Time pressed on, and finalizing everything that last day before the actual wedding had been almost nerve-wracking. By the time Agatha and Rio were being pulled to different hotel rooms in the middle of the hallway in the Morongo Casino, Rio was more than a little pained at the idea of not getting to sleep in a bed next to Agatha, even if she was just in the next room over.

Luckily, they had adjoining balconies, too, with a divider between them that Rio had pointed out to Estee could allow her to at least talk to Agatha if they really did want to stay separated.

Rio knew that they had done away with the majority of typical traditions when it came to this wedding. However, they had both made the decision that this tradition, the one that would build up the anticipation right until that moment when they got to see each other for the first time in that venue, would be well worth it.

They had ordered room service from the restaurant on the 27th floor, and while the food looked amazing and it did taste pretty good, there was this small irritation that Rio could not shake as she pushed it around. She knew it was unfounded, and that it was only because it was the first time since Agatha had come home from LA after dealing with her mother that they'd been separated.

It wasn't that Rio was actually upset, it was just... hard to be so close and yet, feel so far away.

This had been remedied by 8:30pm. Rio had gone outside to catch some fresh air and just gaze out into the valley, but Estee had been quick in action as she texted her brother that Rio had gone outside.

"My love, is that you?"

Rio swore she could hear the way Agatha smile.

"It's me, baby," Agatha returned and Rio was very aware of the sudden uptick in her heartbeat.

She leaned forward, her forearms bracing on the railing of the balcony as her hands dangled, desperate for purchase on any bit of the woman she loved that she could have gotten to.

Immediately, without verbalizing the thought, she got it.

Agatha leaned forward, too, on the other side of that divider and the moment she'd seen Rio's hand, empty and hanging, she'd wrapped her fingers around it and gave it a firm squeeze. The act alone made Rio wanted to burst into tears but she managed to quell the urge, forcing it down with a slow and deep breath.

"I miss you," Rio admitted, her lips turning down at the corners as she anxiously toyed with Agatha's fingers, feeling like she could have simply hoisted herself over that railing and made a daring leap to the other side to just put an end to it, but it truly wasn't so unbearable. Rio knew, deep down, that it was irrational to feel that way and that she should probably seek help when dealing with it in the long term, but it was the circumstances that had her antsy.

Yes, it was one night apart and she would survive it. It was also the third biggest night of her life to date and the first that was exclusively in relation to how much she loved Agatha. Rio knew the next night would take its place, but right then as they stood on that balcony holding hands around the divider between them, it felt like scaling a mountain.

Tomorrow was going to be an impossibly big day, not in terms of size or grandeur, but because it was their chance to show the people they cared about how much Rio and Agatha also cared for one another. It was an opportunity to stand in front of people that loved them and openly devote the rest of their lives to each other.

Even more than that, though, it was a chance for them to prove it to one another. They'd made all of these choices together, had come this far, and now it was nothing more than a waiting game for them to get to the finish line. It was a waiting game that involved separation, though, and while it wasn't unmanageable, there was still the tiniest ache in Rio's chest that compelled her to throw it all out the window and fit herself into Agatha's arms.

Right then, their fingers wound together like that, Rio knew that waiting would be worth it, no matter how much she detested it in the meantime.

Rio was a rational human being the majority of the time and rationally, she got it. She completely understood the concept and respected what it meant and what it instilled.

The fact that the next time she got to see Agatha, she would be wearing the gown that Rio had picked out for her, it was enough to make her forget how to breathe for the briefest moment.

The next time she saw Agatha, Rio would be in whatever suit Agatha had procured for her. She would also be standing on that platform as Agatha was brought to her in the back of a fucking horse drawn carriage. That was a bit of minutia that Rio was still a little hung up on. How insane was that? It was like it had been ripped straight out of some children's nighttime story.

Rio was going to get her queen, and she was going to have her for good.

To do that, she had to get herself through the night before them, first.

"I miss you too, Rio," Agatha returned a couple of moments later, though their hands had not stopped fidgeting with one another since Rio had spoken.

Rio breathed a gentle sigh through her nose, letting her eyes fall shut as her head hung slightly.

"I know this is like... part of the thrill and all, but I can't stop thinking about how stupid it is that you're literally right next door and I have to fall asleep without you." Rio's voice wasn't sad, but it was low and had the smallest little edge to it that she could not hide.

She could hear Agatha breath a soft laugh, the pad of Agatha's thumb running over the backs of Rio's knuckles.

"That might be so, but... You have two very affectionate and very sweet girls who would love to surround you in my place." Agatha always knew, always had faith, that Rio's biggest support in her life would always be Estee, no matter what happened. Everything else could come and go, but Agatha had always recognized and respected that Estrella Vidal would always be Rio's reason for all that she did. Agatha also knew that it was a mutual feeling and that Estee loved her mother more than she knew how to tell her.

"Yes, admittedly I think I got the better end of the deal," Rio admitted with a soft giggle, glancing down at their hands. "You got stuck with the stinky boys."

In only a breath, Agatha began to laugh too.

"I told them they were absolutely showering before bed -- separately," Agatha poked back, her voice light with amusement. "And again when they wake up."

The softest giggle passed through Rio's lips as she gave Agatha's hand a gentle squeeze.

"We really are pretty lucky, aren't we?" Rio posed softly. "We have amazing kids, your friends are so supportive and kind, Dave is literally the man, and I... All of that is even before I take into consideration what it means to us to have each other."

"You're right, we are. And this life we have managed to build together still stuns me every morning when I open my eyes. Sometimes, you're there and sometimes I can smell that you're working in the kitchen even though that's my domain," Agatha murmured at her, a gentle cajoling.

Rio's eyes were locked on their hands, the only part of Agatha she could see, even if the sound of her voice felt like a warm blanket on a cool night as it carried over the space forced between them.

"And sometimes, I'm laying in the yard looking at the stars because I wonder how in a world so big, I managed to find the perfect person for me." Rio's lips twitched upward, wanting nothing more than to throw herself in the arms of the woman who's hand she was holding in that moment.

"You know, I can still get you that telescope..." Agatha mused and this actually did get Rio to grin.

"Agatha," Rio chastised. "You are not buying me a four thousand dollar telescope to put in our backyard."

"But your birthday is next month..."

"And I don't need a stupid expensive telescope as a monument of getting another year older." Rio's voice was soft, but it still held an admonishing edge to it.

"But what if I wanted to get it so it would be easier for when you teach me about constellations? I mean, the quality would be so much help." That little twinge in Agatha's tone, it told Rio that she did mean it, but she meant it for other reasons, too.

Whatever it was in the world that Rio could ever want or need, Agatha had always made it apparent that she would provide.

"If I tell you no, you're probably going to do it anyway," Rio pointed out, her smile audible in her voice.

"You're... probably not wrong?" Agatha returned, though by the end of it, she was laughing.

"Rarely, but it happens. You know, like the time you told me that you were too tired for morning sex. Turns out, you were super wrong about that."

Instantly, they were both laughing. Agatha had a fair point there, Rio would admit.

Another moment and Rio parted her lips to speak.

She hadn't been expecting to harmonize with Agatha.

"I love you, Agatha."
"I love you, Rio."

It shouldn't have, but it caused tears to spring and spill down Rio's cheeks as her head tipped forward and a ghost of a chuckle hit the air around her. She had been convinced it had been quiet enough that Agatha couldn't hear it, but she questioned that the moment Agatha spoke.

"You're crying, aren't you?" she posed softly, squeezing Rio's hand firmly.

"Of course. How did you know?"

"Because that got a couple of tears out of me, too."

So they had sat, for hours as the night fell darkly around them, just talking about their lives, about their dreams, about their hopes for their futures. They talked about nights on the beach with a fire, they talked about the possibility of getting to be grandmothers some day. They talked about their children, their children's partners, the love they all shared. Even Hmi seemed to fit so perfectly into their little puzzle, and they talked about how much they loved him, too.

And then, they talked about their past. That was a little bit more of an emotional conversation than anything else up to that point had been. They'd already covered almost all there was to know about those beginnings, but just taking that trip down memory lane had been something Rio had not known she'd needed until she had it. And they kept going like that, just a soft back and forth in the middle of the Morongo valley that only they could hear.

At some point, Rio had been the first to doze. She'd fallen asleep with her fingers still hooked into Agatha's as their hands had fallen to a resting position against the concrete of the balcony beneath them. Agatha had submitted to slumber not moments later.

Rio was immediately aware that Agatha's hand was no longer in her own. It took a second of panic for Estee to reach out and touch her shoulder from the position she held as she was squatted down in front of Rio.

"Nicky woke her up and she wouldn't move. He got Hmi to put her in bed. He said it was very fireman-carry-esque and that she also whined the whole time, asking for you."

They enveloped her almost immediately, arms wrapping in calculated ways to smother Rio in what love they had to offer, knowing it was all they could do.

It had taken her little time to fall asleep to the sounds of their breathing and the smell of their perfumes.

Rio loved Agatha, that was an immovable fact.

Rio also loved her children more than she knew how to express, especially as she had drifted off to time travel to the next morning.

The sun came up and six pairs of eyes opened at intervals in different rooms to greet the day.

The coordination that the children had displayed in getting the two women to the venue that morning, separately, had been quite a feat but it had left Rio entirely impressed.

As she tried to help the girls load everything she would need that day inside, they had simply waved her off and insisted they could take care of it.

It was only minutes later as the girls carried in the three garment bags and hung them in the hutch along the far wall of the room they would be spending the morning in.
