This had only been kept from Rio due to the fact that they were going to be matching her suit that she had been told she was not allowed to open until stated.

In turn, while Rio had opted to keep the boys' suits black, she had not been able to keep from inserting her input on the lavender ties they would be wearing.

The dresses were a gorgeous pastel green color and the shape of them was nearly to die for. Rio knew they would look even better once the girls got them on, but just the sight of them had Rio ready to start shedding tears left and right.

Once they were done showcasing their own attire, Estee hooked a finger beneath the curve of Rio's hanger and lifted the bag out, moving to stand in front of Rio so that she could hold the bag in a way that allowed Rio to unzip it.

The moment she did and pushed the sides of the bag away enough to reveal what was inside, Rio could feel tears spring instantly to her eyes.

Within that bag was an absolutely stunning velvet suit, hunter green in color. The sleeves were cuffed and cinched near the elbows, as well as the waist. The lapel ran high but curved in sharply in a very striking way. There were even a couple of flat pockets toward the bottom of the jacket. The pants were long and flowing, a bit of a contrast to the jacket.

What Rio realized next made her smirk and curse Agatha in the same moment.

There was nothing else there, nothing that was going to go beneath that jacket in any kind of a blouse or camisole. With the cut of the neckline that was going to be created by the buttoning of the jacket, Rio calculated that it would conclude in a sharp point somewhere just below her sternum.

"It's incredible," Rio managed, fingertips trembling as they touched at her lips, the overwhelming urge to run down that hall and kiss the woman she loved starting to swallow her whole.

"We thought so, too. But this made every moment of keeping it from you so worth it." Estee's voice was so warm, so rich in its honesty that Rio could have cried even more.

She took another moment to collect herself, finding a composition she was unaware she had and took a deep breath.

That was until Tay turned around with a white box in her hand, roughly about 1x1 foot in size.

"We did a trade off with Nicky when we took him the pendant. She got this to complete your ensemble." Tay's voice was so sweet and Rio could hear how clearly she adored this exchange and everything it symbolized.

"Open it, mama," Estee pressed and Rio stepped forward to do just that, both hands raising to open the lid of the box.

There, nestled in black velvet was a thin crown of silver vines, one that bore leaves of diamonds along its entirety. The suit was incredible; there was no denying that. But that piece of adornment that Agatha had very clearly sunk all of her intention into choosing?

Rio's face crumpled and she clasped a hand over her mouth to stifle the sound of the sob that leapt out of her, though she wasn't incredibly successful. Every inch of her wanted to take off, to scour every room in that building until she could find Agatha and give her a kiss that could somehow tell her just how much Rio loved her in those moments.

Apparently, she was not the only one who had such an idea.

Estee's phone dinged and she looked at it the next second, though her eyes grew wide and she reached out to grab hold of Tay's hand, pulling her over to the door as they pressed their backs to it in the form of a brace.

The text from Nicky simply read: "INCOMING!"

It took only another beat before Rio could hear the commotion out in the hallway, though it wasn't incredibly close.

Hmi's voice carried right down the hall with how deep it was.

"I'm sorry, Ms. Harkness." A second later, Agatha exhaled a grunt and then a very loud growl.

"Hmi! Hmi put me down right this instant!" Agatha's voice was little more than a screech and Rio knew she was angry, but it was the sweetest thing.

"No can do, Ms. Harkness. You know the rules," he informed her. The fact that the three of them were stood there just listening felt like an added layer to the comedic weight of the moment.

"I do not give a single solitary fuck about rules! I want to see her!" Agatha was shouting and while not one of the three women in that room could see what was going on, it was pretty easy to paint a visual.

"For everyone's benefit, you cannot see her until the ceremony."

This caused the three women locked into the room to fall prey to a fit of giggles, though the moment was not quite over yet.

"What the hell does that even mean?!" Agatha cried, the struggle in Hmi's grasp so laden in her tone.

This time, it was Nicky's voice that carried down the hall, though the volume was decreasing as they got further away.

"Because you know that you'll kick everyone else out and we won't make it to the ceremony."

Rio was grinning so hard that she thought her face might crack. Even further at what she swore she heard Hmi say.

"Thanks, babe, I didn't wanna say it."

She fucking loved that woman.

And she was going to tell her as much in a few hours.

Estee's phone dinged again and she brought it up, grinning the moment she read Nicky's message. She read it again, this time out loud.

"Nick said, 'I gave her the pendant. She moved faster than I could catch her.'" By the time she finished reading, Estee was in giggles, her eyes sweeping up to her mother's with a broad smile on her face.

It really was a beautiful piece of jewelry, and with the dress Rio had selected, that giant purple tear drop gem matched the cut of the diamond on the ring Rio had chosen to slide on Agatha's finger later on that day. Everything Rio had done in regards to this day had been so thoroughly calculated, so planned in a way only she would ever be able to manage.

Agatha was already beautiful, that was a known fact. The idea of Agatha dressed in what Rio had picked out for her as they announced their devotion to one another in front of a small crowd of people that loved them, that was beautiful, too.

However, there was something so much more beautiful about the way Rio could still hear Agatha's hollering as Hmi hauled her back down the hallway to her appropriate room.

A moment later, there was a soft tap on the door. The girls, who were still pressed against it, glanced at one another but did not move.

"That has to be Nicky. You're Nicky right?!" Estee called through the door over her shoulder.

"Yes, Estee, it's me. Lemme in."

The girls released their brace on the door and Estee reached down to pull it open, revealing a grinning Nicky on the other side of it. He stepped inside, his eyes lifting to Rio. His smile only seemed to grow.

"You really got her with the necklace," he told her, tilting his head sweetly.

"Yes, well, turns out bringing Hmi has many uses. And also, something about the way he just manhandled your mother makes me adore him even more. So, no pressure, but try to keep him around," Rio informed him with a gentle giggle.

"Dually noted," Nicky returned with a chuckle. "Well, I thought I would come down and explain that when she opened the box, she attempted to bully me for her phone. When she remembered that I'm too tall for her to reach an entire upright extension of my arm, she just looked me dead in the eyes for a solid three seconds and then bolted."

"Sounds on brand for mum, honestly," Estee voiced with a shrug as she paced back over to her bag to rummage through it, producing the chapstick she had been looking for.

"I also think it pertinent to mention that she's already asked four times how much longer and obviously the stylists have not even shown up yet," he tacked on, rolling his eyes in jest at his mother's antics.

"Well," Rio posed back, her cheeks pushing up in a broad smile. "Sounds to me like you boys are doing a terrible job of distracting her. The girls have been keeping my mind o--"

"Oh, PLEASE!" Tay squealed, giving an eyeroll even more dramatically than Nicky had a moment ago. "You opened that crown and you were so ready to bolt."

Rio's cheeks quickly flamed red at being called out so directly. She had thought that maybe she'd been able to keep it under wraps enough that neither of them had noticed, but Rio knew them both better than that.

"You know... you could at least give me some credit for not doing it?" Rio shot back, but the question was still heavy at the end of her words, as if she did not fully believe it herself.

"Mama," Estee admonished, "That is literally only because she did it first and we had you trapped in here. The likelihood that you were getting through both of us before Hmi had time to pull her away was slim and we all know it."

Rio's brow pinched in a mock frown; she wasn't actually angry, but Estee was making a fair point.

This was something Rio and Agatha had decided on together. It was important, in its own silly way. It was a way to turn up the tension and anticipation, to make the wait of the day worth it when that moment finally happened and they got to see one another for the first time. This was also something they had clearly stated to all four of the younger adults that they really did want.

In that moment, they had all garnered quite a bit of respect from Rio.

They had all listened and they had all played their part in making sure that the two of them, who only lacked reasonable self-restraint when it came to their relationship, got the request they had submitted.

Would it feel good in the moment to just get tangled in kisses and arms and sighs and whimpers? Of course, but the reality of it was that they had a very big, very important day ahead of them. They had photographers and videographers showing up in an hour, and the stylists were surely on their way as well. There were so many moving parts and pieces to this that it was imperative that they be kept on track.

Rio simply told herself that she could get through the next few hours, that she could sit there while her makeup was done and her hair was styled. She told herself that she was going to walk down that aisle and wait for the approach of the woman she could not have loved any more, in any way. They were going to exchange their vows and trade rings, then they were going to eat and drink with their loved ones. Once they wrapped that up, they got one more night in the hotel -- which, smartly, Agatha had gotten them a different room on a higher floor so the children could have the adjoining ones and also save their mental wellbeing -- and then they were rolling out of bed in the morning to climb back onto The Hoatzin once more to head to Iceland.

She could get through it, but it didn't make the entire situation any more believable even as she ran through it in her mind.

As she rooted herself in it and realized it for all that it was, Rio felt confident for the first time in saying that if Jack felt so inclined to ask once more about showing the world their lives, it didn't scare her like it once did.

What Rio and Agatha had was magic.

It was human connection and the insatiable need to not let it get away.

It was just... love, in it's purest form.

That was what made it so beautiful.

Rio's gaze lifted to Nicky and a thought struck her. She paced over to her own bag and rummaged around, finding a half-crumpled list of everything they'd needed for the day. It was no longer needed, so she grabbed it and located a pen in one of the drawers of a desk in the room they were in. Flipping the paper over, Rio bit the cap of the pen and pulled it off, hunching over the desk.

Rio scribbled something down and then tore the corner of the page off, turning to face her son. She held it out, though to made no move to fold it in an attempt to hide the message.

Keep falling a little longer, my love. I'll be waiting to catch you.

Rio didn't conceal it because only Agatha would understand the words that weren't written on that paper.

Rio would forever be her soft place to land. This time, the fall wasn't immediate into ocean water, it was a slow careening that would land her right in the arms of her wife.

Nicky glanced down at it and while he might not have understood the sentiment, he got it enough that the look he gave Rio when he looked back up at her was tender and soft. Rio raised a hand, giving his cheek a light brush with thumb.

"Keep her in line for a bit more, if you would. I know it's a task, but... She'll be thankful for it later." Rio adjusted her hold so that she could tip his head forward that enabled her to place a soft kiss to his forehead as she stood on the tips of her toes. Once she was level again, she let him go and gave him a gentle nod. "I am impossibly thankful for you, Nicholas. And Hmi, too, if you could pass it along."

"Of course, mama," he told her softly. Before he made his exit, though, he leaned toward her and wrapped her up in his arms, giving her a tight squeeze. When he pulled away and let her go, he was grinning again. "I'm just... happy to be here."

It was a light statement, but it dropped like a lead weight with the tone he used. It said all the things his words couldn't, the primary one being that this was a moment he had never thought he would experience in his life, given who his mother had tried for so long to be. All it took was a loud whistle and an aggressive and irritated cyclist and there they stood, months later and only hours away from making a move that would solidify their own little dynasty.

"Te amo, mijo. Now go! If you wait any longer you might come back to a battered boyfriend."

This got a laugh out of him, as well as the girls who had been quiet up until that point just observing the moment of respect and care between Rio and Nicky.

"Okay, okay! I will see you guys soon," he offered, lifting to give a gentle wave as he departed.

The moment the door shut, Rio's eyes shimmered with unfallen tears. This was all actually happening. They were stood there, waiting for the inevitable. The love of her life was apparently fighting for her life to keep the distance in place.

Their lives had started over that day, the moment they had opened their eyes into the light of the day.

It had only been a little while longer until the photographer and videographer had shown up, their little team setting about making a plan in the corner of Rio's room before a couple of them dispersed, surely to relocate with their things to the room Agatha was getting ready in. Shortly after, the stylist had arrived and everything seemed to take off.

It was hours of makeup and hair and Estee dumping a handful of cashews into Rio's palm so that she could keep enough on her stomach to quell any nerves that might have tried to surface.

This didn't make Rio nervous. None of it made Rio nervous, but Estee had pointed out that if she didn't maintain some semblance of normalcy, it might create room for those nerves to break through.

Things were coming together, robes were put on and photos were taken. Rio and their girls, and surely Agatha and their boys. It could be a little wild when there were so many people moving about Rio's given space, but she was doing everything she could to keep a level head and remind herself that the time was passing and they were getting closer to the day's final destination.

The stylist that had been tending to Rio gave one last gentle flick of a brush over her cheeks and stepped back to survey her work. Rio's eyes lifted to the woman to see that she looked completely thrilled with what she had managed to accomplish.

"When you're ready, there's a mirror behind you," she told Rio, pointing a finger in indication over Rio's shoulder.

While she still intended to look, Rio's gaze lifted to the two girls on the couch who looked up at roughly the same time. In almost perfect sync, their expressions both softened and immediately, Rio was convinced they were going to cry.

"If you shed tears, now's the time to do it before you get your makeup on," Rio informed them.

It was Estee that moved, pushing herself up to her feet so that she could cross the room to her mother. She was careful in her placement, but she pulled Rio into her arms and gave her a firm hug, sniffling softly over her shoulder. When she pulled away, the look on her face was practically bleeding with honesty before she found her ability to speak.

"Mama, you know I will always think that you are the most beautiful woman to exist, but... Right now, I think you're finally gonna understand why."

The smallest curling of her lips happened and she gave a gentle nod toward Rio, indicating that she really should take a look for herself.

As Rio spun in place in her chair, the moment that her eyes found that mirror, she almost cried, too. She wondered in that moment if the stylist had meant it when she asserted that the makeup she was using was as waterproof as it could get. Surely, they were going to find out by the end of the day.

The choice of eye shadow, the application of just enough blush in just the right way, the color her lips now were, they were all just so... perfect. Her hair was pinned slightly on one side, but otherwise the curls that hung in ringlets over her shoulders fell just right. Rio had never been lacking in confidence when it came to what she looked like, but she truly heard Estee's words, and she understood them.

As Estee stepped up on one side of her, hand sliding onto Rio's shoulder, Tay copied the movement on the opposite side.

While the thought crossed Rio's mind that she wished she could have a photo of their reflection in the mirror, she did not realize that one was being taken from behind her, even if the reflection wasn't going to be visible in the shot. In consolation, it was the back view of a mother and her daughters in what was nothing more than a show of love and admiration on the happiest day of her life.

A few minutes later, Rio finished fastening the button on her suit jacket and glanced down at herself, the widest smile filling her face with ease. The suit fit perfectly in every right way, cinched exactly where it needed to be. It wasn't form-fitting or too tight in the way it hung from her frame. Despite the velvety material, it didn't feel thick or heavy. It was instead light in a way that Rio had not been expecting, a way that made her feel like she could float away before she stepped foot from behind that little screen.

The moment she did, there were two gasps that sounded at the exact same time. The way Estee and Tay were sat, hands clasped to their mouths and their eyes growing glassy again, Rio could have been knocked over with a feather. They looked truly taken by what they were seeing and it caused Rio to feel a warmth from her scalp to the tips of her toes. Her gaze shifted to the full mirror toward the corner and took a couple of steps into the frame of it.

What she saw just about took her own breath away. Agatha knew exactly what she was doing with every single choice she had made within the confines of that outfit. It was almost as if she had been able to see Rio in it before Rio could.

Her jaw tensed but only in an effort to not shed any tears. She wasn't going to cry before they got to the actual ceremony. She was not going to put her makeup at risk and chance looking like a fool before she could even get herself where she needed to be.

Rio turned to face the girls as they got to their feet, and there the three of them stood in their attire for the evening.

"One more thing," Estee reminded her, stepping forward to gingerly lift the vined crown from its box so that she could place it perfectly atop Rio's head. The action of doing so clearly made her emotional, but she seemed to choke it down for Rio's sake.

A moment later, an alarm sounded on Estee's phone. She quickly silenced it and cast her gaze back up toward her mother, a proud light dancing in her eyes.

"It's time, mama."

With that, the night before them became etched in stone.

As the sun started the very beginning stages of its descent in the afternoon sky, Rio, Estee, and Tay emerged from the backside of the chateau they had spent their day in, arms linked with each woman on either side of Rio. What greeted them was a sea of roughly fifty heads that turned, filled mostly with faces Rio recognized, but there were a couple here and there that she did not know. Surely, there would be time to remedy that throughout the night.

The walk toward that platform with the structure wrapped in flowers and vines and where Jack stood waiting, it felt almost infinite. It felt like Rio might never get there, but her Oxfords finally scuffed against the wood beneath the flowing legs of her pants. Her head lifted to Jack, mouthing a silent 'thank you' to him for having agreed to officiate.

Rio could hear it like a drum between her ears, the way her heart was absolutely pounding. She knew this was it, this was the dream being realized. It was months of planning, it was the way those blooms on the mountainside were bright and vibrant in the way Agatha had promised they would be. It was the rows of nicely dressed attendants who all bore wide smiles, thrilled to simply be a part of something so special.

She took her spot and turned to take in the view of the expanse she had just crossed, finally letting herself understand the weight of what was about to happen. Her smile was instant as she saw Nicky and Hmi walk into view, completely dashing in their suits with those perfectly offsetting ties. They looked so damn handsome that it made Rio swell with just as much pride as she had for the two women who were now standing behind her.

Hmi stepped forward, the small pillow bearing the rings in his hands as he made his way toward Rio and then stepped off to the opposing side, his grin never once dimming.

The moment the first notes of the song "I Choose You" by Sara Bareilles began to play, Rio almost felt like she wasn't even in her own body. She knew what was coming and yet, as the clopping of horse hooves sounded over the music, she felt like she very well might choke on her own anticipation.

She caught a glimpse, just briefly, as the carriage made its way down the hill, though it was mostly shrouded by greenery. And then, it pulled into view and Rio was instantly in an active battle to keep a lid on her desire to just melt into the ground at what she saw.

The driver of the carriage got out and opened the door just as Nicky approached, lifting a hand for his mother to take so he could help her out.

The moment Agatha's heels hit the pavement and Rio finally saw with her own eyes the vision she had tried to create in her mind? She forgot what it was to breathe.

There stood Agatha, her arm in their son's, in that lavender dress that was embroidered in a way that almost made the bodice of it look like lace, though as it wound down into the skirt, it flowered out a bit more. The neckline had been exactly the right choice, even more so with the way that breathtaking jewel sat in the middle of her chest.

Right then, Rio Vidal was looking at the rest of her life.

She had never been more certain of anything else in her entire existence.

There was music. There was soft awe and reverence from those around them. There was the clicking of camera shutters happening. All of that noise and yet, the only thing Rio was convinced she could hear was the beating of Agatha's heart in time with her own.

The moment their eyes met, it was a distanced reflection of painfully wide grins and expressions that were fighting to keep the heavier emotions at bay for the time being. For as taken as Rio was right then by the sight of Agatha, she could clearly see that the same emotion was taking over Agatha, too.

Each step she took in stride with Nicky, Agatha's smile somehow grew, even a hair at a time. By the time Nicky helped her up those couple of steps onto the platform, Rio was worried that between the two of them, Agatha's face was going to crack first.

Nicky stepped off to place himself next to Hmi at the same time that Agatha slid her hands into Rio's, the shine of a thousand stars happening in those unending blue eyes. Rio could feel every emotion as it sat in her throat to be standing there like that, looking into the eyes of the woman she loved most in the world. She could feel how it wanted to choke her, but she wouldn't let it.

Before she could lend too much thought to it, Jack was speaking, his voice carrying due to the microphone on his lapel.

"Good evening everyone! Thank you for joining us today. Please be seated and silence your phones if you haven't already."

Although it felt impossible, Rio tore her gaze from Agatha to look over at him for just a moment, already thankful for the presence he was able to pull. After a second, though, she was back to staring at the rest of her life.

"I am convinced that the foundations to a solid marriage are often formed way before marriage is ever even a thought." His voice was so strong, carried so well even outside of the assistance that microphone offered.

"Nothing solidified that belief more than the first text message I received from Agatha the moment she returned from her trip to New Zealand for the first time. I will respect the bit of decorum she probably wishes to keep and not read those messages word for word," he offered and while everyone laughed, Rio's laughter hardly made its way around the emotion that was still sitting in her throat as she fought for her life to hold onto her composure for the next fifteen minutes.

"In those messages, she told me the most wild story. She said that she fell off of a bridge into a marina, and that the most beautiful Kiwi woman who lived on a houseboat pulled her out of the water." His gaze dropped from the crowd to take each of them in, in equal measure.

Rio's cheeks were hot; hearing someone talk about her like that and knowing that he was only quoting the woman before her nearly made her swoon, but she continued to keep it together.

"She detailed to me how they sat on the deck of that houseboat and drank wine while the woman cooked her dinner and dried her clothes. She talked about the depth they'd managed in their conversations together. She spoke about her decision to throw a glass of water on dry clothes so she could stay there longer." At this, not only did Jack chuckle, but everyone else did, too. That was inclusive of the two brides as they both actively relived the memory.

"Agatha talked about how she'd fallen asleep with her head on the woman's lap and woke up to her clothes folded and waiting for her. She talked about coming out to see the woman making them breakfast and how much it had killed her to insist that she had to leave." He paused again, his eyes falling to Agatha who caught it and gave a gentle nod of encouragement. "When I asked her what the woman's name was, she told me she did not know. And in that moment, my heart broke for her. Because... When you see someone talk about another person like that? It's pretty clear how they feel about them, even after only a night."

In Rio's view, Agatha's lips twisted and it became clear to Rio that she was not the only one managing not to choke on the emotion of the moment.

"She spent the next weeks fighting through the awards season, but every single time we met up or she shot me a message, the conversation always turned back to Auckland. Most of the time, she would catch herself and apologize before turning the conversation in another direction, but it was something she had clearly been stuck thinking about."

At this, Rio gave Agatha's hands a firm squeeze. This was a little tidbit of information that Rio had not been privy to before and it was only piling onto the amount of love she was feeling in that moment.

"About a week and a half after her most recent win, I received a text message from her. I will read that one in it's entirety. It said: 'JACKSON FREDERICK! YOU ARE NOT GOING TO BELIEVE THIS. BOAT WOMAN SHOWED UP AT MY OFFICE THIS AFTERNOON!' And yes, it was all capitalized."

Again, another bout of laughter filled the space around them and Rio was damn near white knuckle gripping Agatha's hands in her own.

"It had been my hope, at that time, to meet 'Boat Woman,' who I then learned was actually named Rio, before she returned home. That hope was dashed when I received a call at three in the morning from Agatha asking for a favor so that she could get Rio back to New Zealand to be with her injured daughter."

Jack cleared his throat a little as he glanced toward Estee to give a small smile. He lifted his head again to look out at those gathered before them.

"Over the next months, I was on the receiving end of updates and photos that were very clear showings of just how much love exists between these two women. I got to watch through Agatha's lens as they quickly began to construct a life together in a way that seemed nothing short of magical. I was blessed to be privy to such a story, and I retain that sentiment to this day."

At the same time, both women turned their head to take Jack in for the briefest moment, their appreciation so glaringly obvious as it was written on their faces.

He offered them a smile and continued.

"Agatha sent me a photo of the engagement ring the moment she bought it after only a month. She included with it a brief but appropriate message, one that simply stated: 'Don't ask me if I'm sure, because I 100% am.' In that moment, I understood it without her having to explain it to me. There are moments in life, people that cross our paths, where we as humans just... know that they're supposed to be there. Agatha has always known that Rio was meant to be in her life. No amount of time would have ever changed that fact, or compelled her to make a different choice."

He offered a soft chuckle, looking up from the notes on his phone.

"As anyone here knows, Agatha is the most hardheaded person around. What I got the chance to learn not that long ago was that she had fittingly fallen in love with the most softhearted person I've ever had the pleasure of meeting. Rio is many things. She is a mother, she is an engineer. She's a reader and she knows how to surf very well, apparently. Rio has also become Agatha's best friend, her compatriot in the battle of life."

Jack took a brief pause, his adoring gaze falling to the two of them.

"I have no doubt that these two women are going to spend the rest of their lives in a marriage that brings with it not only happiness and joy, but also discovery and knowledge."

He took a step toward them.

"So, if you are both ready, I'd like to ask a couple of questions that will attest to your commitment to one another."

As their gazes broke to take him in, they each gave a gentle nod.

"Do you both choose each other to be partners for life?"

In unison:

"We do."

He continued.

"Do you choose to trust and respect each other, and to support one another in both good times and bad times?"

"We do."

"Do you love what you know about each other in this moment, and trust what you do not yet know?"

One more.

"We do."

"Perfect," he crooned softly. "Now is the part where I let them tell each other exactly why they're making this choice right here, right now, with their personal vows. Rio, if you would."

There it was. It was right there. She was in it. She was so wholly in the moment that she needed to take more than one deep breath to steady her wildly hammering heart long enough that she could form words.

"Agatha, my love," she began, shocking herself with the strength she had somehow found in her tone. "Since the day you fell into my life, you have given me a vantage point of the world that I never would have had in any other life. You have blessed me with an ability to see the truly remarkable things in the world, and how they often lay in the quieter moments." Rio took a breath, pressing her lips together to steady herself for a moment.

"So, I stand here today with every intent of saying 'I do,' but what I am really saying is 'I will.' I will wake up every morning with the intent to love you the same, if not better, by the time I fall asleep that night. I will shower you in my affection for as long as you'll let me until you get annoyed and make a little quip about how much my optimism can be grating. I will catch the spiders that scare you in the shower and put them outside. I will fight myself every day on remembering to put back the hose after watering the garden. I will find peace in both the moments of us together as a family but also in those moments when it is just you and I alone. I will love our children, all of them, with the same ferocity that I love you. I will promise to go to any lengths I can manage to see you happy, to ensure you know how loved you are by me."

Rio drew in one more slow and deliberate breath before she finished speaking, though the expression Agatha was wearing almost made her choke on it. She looked so fucking enamored. Rio persisted.

"I stand here now, looking you in the eyes, telling you with the most sincerity I am capable of holding in my body that I will love you every, single, day, for the rest of my life without a single question to be raised."

Agatha released one of Rio's hands to quickly swipe at the lone tear that had dropped over her eyelid, stopping it before it got too far down her cheek.

She took a breath and Rio simply gave her an understanding and encouraging nod.

"Rio, my entire heart," Agatha managed, clearing her throat in a search for strength when what Rio had to say had clearly moved her so deeply and so irrevocably. "This is a place I never thought I would be again in my life. The idea that I could look into the eyes of another human and promise them, the way I am about to promise you, that I could love them unconditionally for as long as I am able to breathe was one that had seemed outlandish. In the context of it being anyone else, it still is." Agatha's hands squeezed tightly as she pressed her lips in a tight but emotional smile as she found it in itself to keep going.

"You, Rio, are the only person on this earth that I will ever love forever. You, Rio, are the woman I will wake up in the middle of the night to watch stars and contemplate existentialism with. You, Rio, are the woman I will follow no matter where you go. You, Rio, are the woman I will think about no matter the day or time, or even if you're right next to me. You, Rio, are an incredible mother to our children. You, Rio Daniela, are all I will ever want or need in another human being, the only one who will know the love I have in this way. You are the one I will spend every single day proving that to."

There was only the quickest moment of complete awe and reverence that fell over every person in attendance, but Jack was quick to progress the ceremony.

"Now, Hmi, the rings, if you would."

Hmi stepped forward, presenting the rings. Rio reached over first, gently pulling that masterpiece of a wedding ring into her slightly trembling fingers. She pulled Agatha's hand into her own and very carefully but full of intent, she slid the ring onto Agatha's finger.

"These rings are a symbol of your lifelong commitment to one another. They are a seal to the vows that you have both made here before us. They are a physical presence of your unending promise to love one another for as long as you so shall live."

As Rio's eyes dropped to Agatha repeating the motions Rio herself had just done, and she saw the ring Agatha had selected? Her right hand flew to her mouth, fingertips gracing her lips as she sucked in a shocked breath.

The ring Agatha slid onto her finger was... It was so Rio. The main focus was not actually a diamond, it was a clear agate with green vines inside, winding through it. The band itself was a double set and the top band split into silver vines that cradled the top and the bottom of the agate. Beneath it, linked through the the bottom band, were five diamonds, the middle being the biggest as the pointed end of its teardrop shape faced Rio's knuckle. It was beautiful, and the fact that Agatha had picked such a piece had clearly landed with her in the way Agatha had been intending.

"By the power vested in me, and through the sheer power of your own love, I now pronounce you married!

Please, do us all the favor and finally kiss each other."

Despite the grin that had formed at hearing those words, and the soft laugh that produced itself beneath the sound of her heartbeat in her ears, Rio did not hesitate to do as she had been instructed.

Both of her hands raised, cupping Agatha's jaw in a way that was both familiar and so brand new and met her halfway in the first kiss of the rest of their lives.

Her wife, Agatha Harkness.

Chapter End Notes

I would like to shout out to my name twin for helping me make this all that it is. i couldn't have done this without you, bestie.

You Make Me Complete

You make it hard to breathe with every step you take closer to me. I'm cold with every touch, and I can't fall asleep. I can't stand to be without you, now that you've figured out just who I am, And I can't stand to look into your eyes, now that I've realized That you make me weak, you make me love, you make me wanna scream your name at the top of my lungs. You make me shake, you rescue me, but most of all, you make me complete. I'm drawing pictures in your hand. Being away from you is something I can't stand. I feel your breath upon my cheek, and you're my everything, my heart is yours to keep. Well I don't have the strength to stay away, because I'm falling more in love with you, each and every day. I can't stand to not be by your side, now that I realize that you make me weak, you make me love. You make me wanna scream your name at the top of my lungs. You make me shake, you rescue me.
But most of all, you make me complete.
*****

There could have been a roar of applause, could have been a chorus of cheers the moment Rio was afforded the opportunity to kiss her wife, but it fell upon Rio's deaf ears. She couldn't hear a thing over the sound of her own heart as it pounded as loud as thunder in the center of her brain. All she cared about in that moment, everything else completely drowned out, was that she was kissing her wife.

Her wife!

This was a moment that, at a very early point in their relationship, Rio had realized was inevitable. Every theory, every question, every hypothesis that Rio and Agatha had shared with one another had led them to that moment, their friends and family roaring in approval as they solidified their love for one another in a promise of forever. Rio had invested herself wholly in every word she had said while looking Agatha in the eye, and she knew the same could be said for Agatha.

What they had done was momentous. What they had done was beautiful.

As they turned and held hands, facing the crowd that had gathered for them, Rio couldn't find it in her to dim her grin in the slightest. How could she? She was married. She had officially committed her life to someone else. No, not just someone.

She bound herself to Agatha.

Agatha would never be just someone.

Agatha was everything.

Seeing those smiles as they walked back up that aisle to the awaiting photographers and photo opportunities, it was the lightest feeling, and still somehow there was weight to it. It was the happiest Rio had ever been, but there was an understanding also found in those vows. They'd had it pretty easy in terms of how well they had integrated into one another's lives, but Rio was not foolish enough to ever consider that marriage would not take work. Forever was a long time, but Rio was of the mindset that any hiccup, any spat, any argument would be worth figuring out if it meant that she got to keep Agatha.

They had spent the following hour -- while all their guests enjoyed beverages and hors d'oeuvres -- migrating from one location to another while the photographers bustled about, catching them in various poses; a side view from afar of Rio's lips pressed to Agatha's temple as Agatha grinned beneath the trellis lined with white roses in the greenhouse, one of them holding each other on that little bridge over the pond, grinning like complete idiots at each other.

There had been one that the photographer had immediately paced over to show them with a grin that Rio had immediately fallen in love with. There were on a ridge that dropped off into the valley and there was a jagged line of mountain base in the background as the sun set behind it. It was the purest illumination of the two women in love as Rio's hands were stationed on Agatha's sides and Agatha's hands had found Rio's biceps. That slight inch Rio had Agatha had dissipated with the height afforded by Agatha's heels and they were looking straight ahead, right into the eyes of the other. The wonder was clear on Rio's face and the absolute adoration was written all over Agatha's in ways that were glaringly obvious even from a profile view.

There were plenty of others, but by the time they were wrapping up, she could hear a faint call for order up the hill in the reception area. Everyone was finding their places and their children were likely putting on a show as they danced their way into the space.

For the briefest moment, Rio had that startling realization that she'd been struck with several times throughout her relationship with Agatha.

This was their life.

Rio did not think, in the least, that it would be the last time she had that thought in her lifetime, but in that moment, it felt like the most profound instance of it to date. The two of them had made their way up the stairs that led to the top of the hill. There was a stone path that wound forward in the direction of the reception area. As they got close to the mouth of it, Rio could hear Jack's voice booming as he introduced them.

The first notes of an acoustic guitar began to play to the tune of 'Complete' by Austin Gibbs as Rio glanced over at Agatha, that familiarly bright grin stuck on her face. Rio gave a light squeeze to Agatha's fingers before they turned to face forward, taking their first step toward greeting everyone they loved and cared for as a unit. They had been two separate pieces, but right then, they finally formed the bigger picture.

Seeing everyone on their feet, clapping and cheering was the most surreal feeling. It was a celebration for them, a showing of love and support for this incredible life change they'd chosen for themselves.

The truest joy, though, was on the faces of their kids. They all looked close to tears, their vibrant grins never once faltering.

Agatha and Rio had made the joint decision to save the first dance until after dinner; their guests had been out for hours in the hot California sun and it was probably best to feed them as soon as possible. So, as the newlyweds made their way behind the table and took their seats between their children, their eyes cast out on their support system, watching the chaos as meals were served and drinks were fetched.

While prayers were not exactly their style, they had asked Jack to offer a blessing, which as usual, he handled with absolute finesse.

Jack was good with his words. Jack loved Agatha. Jack had grown to love Rio, too. Every time he opened his mouth to speak that day, all of those facts had been painfully obvious.

There had been little haste as the area filled with overlapping chatter and the clanking and clanging of silverware on glass as everyone began to eat. This, they had all known, was going to be the most opportune time to hold attention, and there was a lot to be said, at least by the two children that sat to the side of their mothers.

Estee had gotten to her feet first, tapping her champagne flute softly with the end of her knife.

"Hi, everyone," Estee greeted as the attention turned to her. Rio glanced up to take in her daughter's profile and the way her throat quivered just slightly from nerves. Estee was no stranger to public speaking, but this was a little different. This was her reaching back as far as she could to try to explain to those before them what this meant to her, to be standing there making that toast. "My name is Estee and obviously, Rio is my mama. You are going to have to bear with me, as this might be a bit long." She was palming her glass as her eyes fell to her mother, her grin growing. They lifted again, sweeping over everyone in attendance.

"She has been my one and only parent for my entire life and no matter how many hours she spent giving herself a hard time over the fact, I had never wished for it to be any other way. In fact, I got into scraps with kids who told me that I had to have a dad because that was how the world worked." Estee paused, giving a little chuckle. "Once, I got into a fight with a bigger boy in primary school. I really gave it to him, but he busted my lip. Mama was this insane mixture of pissed off, proud, and worried when I came home that day. She asked me why I got into the fight and I wouldn't tell her."

Rio sat, leaning into Agatha who had her arm draped over Rio's shoulders. The expressions on their faces were almost carbon copies, transfixed and rapt by the way Estee was commanding the space.

Rio's eyes had started to water but she was once more actively reminding herself not to cry.

"It took me a couple of weeks, but I finally did. I told her what the kids said and she just... hugged me. She told me that she appreciated my desire to defend her honor, but she also looked me in the eyes and told me that when you have the people you love in your life already, you don't need anyone else." Estee took a breath, her lips twisting as she glanced over at her mama and her mum. She offered them a wide and bright smile before continuing.

"I think for a very long time, she believed that. In fact, for most of my life, she believed it. It was just us, and that was more than good enough. And then, one morning I got a phone call, one that completely changed my life way before I would ever be aware of it. During that call, she told me about how she'd had a dinner guest and did not immediately follow it up with any indication that it was a neighbor or colleague. This, I knew, was different." The glass shifted from one hand to another as Estee continued. "Listening to her talk about about this woman who had fallen off the bridge... It was insane because I heard tones of voice I had never heard from my mother. I heard her use words that told me how much she'd thought about it. I could hear the grin she was wearing the longer she went on."

The air around them was still and silent, but Estee understood it for what it was; this was the only first-hand view anyone would ever get of what it was like to watch as Rio, actually, was the one who had fallen the furthest despite Agatha's plunge.

"When she told me that she didn't know the woman's name, I was... pretty crushed. I'd literally never, in twenty-one years of life, heard her talk about anyone or anything the way she talked about that woman and that night. And... when she picked me up from the airport for break, it was clear that something had really taken root in her, something that was pulling her down. So, I kept her busy, made sure she had something good to think about. The Monday after I got in, the Oscars were on." Estee paused to breathe a laugh. "We watch it every year even though she doesn't care, or have any idea what's actually going on. She does it because she knows I like it, even if it has never had much significance to her outside of an opportunity to bond and make me happy."

At this, Estee drew in a long and slow breath, moving to cradle her glass in both hands.

"As was normal, she was distracted by something on her phone during the category I had been excited to see. And then, they announced the winner. And then... Then, mama looked up and I have never seen the color drain out of her entire being the way I did in that moment. It didn't make any sense. It made even less sense when she called me by my actual name and said 'That's her.' I tried to reiterate that it was the director I had referenced earlier in the night, but she shook her head. She looked me in the eye as she told me that the woman on the television was the same woman that had fallen into the marina. I literally didn't believe her at first."

At this, there was a collectively gentle laughter that bubbled over the crowd and Estee smiled, knowing that from that point forward, she was not going to be able to wrangle her true feelings and the severity of them much longer.

"After that, the rooting was pulling her deeper. Something about the entire thing had started to sink her and it... It was hard to watch. So, when she took me back to the airport to return to uni, I had something to say. I knew it was something she wasn't going to like, but I needed to say it nonetheless. I told her that I thought she should go to America and... Then I admitted I had already found the address to Agatha's office. She... wasn't thrilled with me, or the idea." She braved a glance at the two older women for just a moment before she looked away and cleared her throat, her own emotion starting to well.

"I don't think that she meant to let slip about the earring. The earring she had found on the docking post at the end of the walk. She said it was Agatha's earring, but then tried to explain it away by insisting she lost it. So... I asked her a very simple question. I asked her if the back was on it. And... it was."

Estee's lips curled into a warm smile as she glanced down into her champagne, a soft chuckle passing through her lips.

"So I let her sit with that as I boarded a plane to head home. She called me at two in the morning that night and told me she was going. Even though I was exhausted, I was so happy for her. She was terrified, but she was doing it anyway, and that made me so damn proud. What followed was... Gods, it was amazing. She was so... happy. Even when things back at home had their hiccups and she was ready to immediately take off from that happiness, I was able to convince her to stay, and I am so glad I did. Every FaceTime, every phone call... I was bearing witness to my mother falling for someone for the first time in my life. I would have told her to stay forever, if the universe had allowed it. But... As we all are aware, that is not how the world works."

It was at this point that Estee knew she had to keep her focus ahead of her. If she didn't, she was not going to make it through the rest of her speech.

"One night after spending time at the beach looking for crabs, Tay and I were headed home. I... Admittedly, I don't remember much of it. I was told we were in a pretty serious accident, and it left me to spend the next months learning how to walk again. But... before any of that, I woke up first." There was the slightest tremble in Estee's strong tone, breaking slightly. "I opened my eyes to a white ceiling and I felt two hands wrapped around my own. My first and only thought was that my mama was there, that somehow, she was there. It didn't make sense in my disoriented brain, but... it was my first thought. When I turned my head, though, it wasn't mama that was sitting there with wide eyes that brimmed with tears of relief. No, it was Agatha instead."

Estee cleared her throat, trying to find her resolve again.

"Agatha and I met for the first time in that hospital room when I was at my most vulnerable and Agatha was brandishing her cape, proving that she was an actual superhero. She played with my fingers as we talked about mama, about what had landed them there. That look on her face any time mama's name came out of her mouth? I didn't need either of them to put a name to it for me to see what it was, even right then and there."

Behind her, Estee could hear the sniffles as they first started and then grew in frequency.

"In the weeks that followed, with accompaniment from some annoying kid with wild hair and a bad attitude..." Estee voiced, grinning as she tossed a comically pointed glare at her brother, "We spent more and more time together. In that time... this strange thing started to happen. It was almost as if life had started to build around us, instead of us building a life. Things just fell into place in a way I thought only existed in fairytales. That couldn't have been more true our first day back in Auckland after Tay and I were done with uni. Before we even got back home, Agatha stole Tay and I away so she could purchase an engagement ring with our help. Being asked to assist with such a task... It told me that Agatha didn't just love my mom, she loved me too, and it meant something to her that I be a part of that decision."

Out of the corner of her eye, Estee could see the movement of both of her parents dabbing at their faces to try and keep from ruining their makeup. It caused her to huff a gentle chuckle.

"When life happened and Agatha had to come back here alone... It really hit me. I didn't have to fight public opinion anymore, even if it had never really been all that important in the first place. The fact still stood... It no longer felt like I only had one parent. Mama has always had my back, but without Agatha around... Without her haughty sarcasm, her profound musings and her constant ability to keep a smile on mama's face... It felt like a piece of who I have grown into was temporarily displaced."

What Estee had not realized was that in the crowd before her, there was hardly a dry eye there. She was a little too deep in it at that point to notice.

"So... Maybe mama had been convinced once upon a time that she would never need this, that she would be okay to keep our little village to her, myself and Tay... But if I look at her right now, not only will it cause me to bawl like a tiny tyke, I will also see that having this village of six instead means the absolute world to her."

Estee took one final breath and held up her glass.

"So, all of this to say... Here's to finding the things you never even knew you were looking for in ways you never knew you needed. Cheers, everyone."

As Estee turned, Rio was already on her feet in an impulsive show of affection that solidified itself in the way she wrapped her arms around her daughter tightly. The clinking of glasses and soft cheers sounded like nothing but murmurs of congratulations as Rio squeezed her daughter as tight as she could manage.

"Te amo, mija," Rio breathed at her, kissing the side of her head. As she released her and they both started to separate, they were unaware that Nicky had gotten to his feet, holding his own glass up slightly.

"So I'd like to first start by saying that Estee is absolutely being modest in that entire retelling and will never take the credit over being the entire reason we're all sitting here," he began, glancing over at Estee with his classic Nicky grin. "But... she is. She doesn't know we all talk about it as much as we have... But if she never would have asked about the backing on the earring... If her genius brain had never caught onto that one small detail... Well, I think you can all imagine," he tacked on, grinning wide even as he glanced to his mother for just a moment, a soft look of reverence crossing his features.

"As the majority of you know, my mom and I... Well, we've had several personal growth moments over the years. We've had our ups and we've had our downs. And... the night I first met Rio was most certainly not an up." Nicky's chin tucked slightly and while Rio could see that it was important to him to frame things this way, she couldn't help but think back to that night and how angry he had been. He was right there with her.

"I had come home to surprise mom. And... there was a new face to add to the long list of ones I'd spent plenty of time trying to forget. I was... not exactly nice when she tried to explain herself to me. I called her names I shouldn't have, made a lot of snap judgements that even now, I wish I could take back."

He paused and gave a gentle clearing of his throat as he glanced over at Rio, offering her a tight smile before his eyes lifted again.

"I remember looking mom in the eye and damn near promising her that I would never look at anyone, Rio included, as any kind of a parental figure. In that moment, my anger had been speaking. In that moment, I never could have realized just how wrong I was. I never could have imagined what it would feel like to stand in the pool house by the window and listen as Rio talked about my mom to Estee and Tay for the first time. I never could have imagined what it would feel like to get that text from mom that she'd left the country because Estee had been hurt. I spent hours debating on what the right thing to do was, having just gotten back in Dubai. Before I even realized what I'd done, I was printing a boarding pass for Auckland."

His eyes dropped to his drink in an attempt to figure out what words were going to work best right then.

"And then... A life I hadn't known I wanted to be living started to open up before me. I made two amazing friends who I now look at as sisters. More importantly, though, I finally let myself accept the idea that maybe I could see Rio as someone who cared not only for my mom, but for me, too. It was in the small things, like the recipe trading and the tips and tricks when it came to cooking. Mom had taught me to cook pretty young in life, but Rio taught me how to fold passion into every bite. The two women I love most in the world always do that, they find ways to impart their perspective wisdom in regard to the same topic and yet, it's two completely different pieces to a whole picture, no matter what that topic actually is."

Nicky tried to clear his throat again, but it was clear to the women looking up at him that he was struggling a little more with the weight of his words more than he thought he might have.

"For me, what it all boils down to is that the moment I stopped being angry about the things in my past, it was the same exact moment I understood what it was to be loved, by many people, unconditionally. I understood that this amazing woman my mother fell in love with was forever going to be a fixture in our lives, as long as I chose to stick around."

He shifted a bit, his eyes falling on his mother and his mama, a sweet smile curling his lips as the rest of his expression softened. He was focused on Rio as he spoke again.

"So for as much as this toast is to your union and future together, it is also to you, mama. Te amo ms que a nada."

It didn't need a translation, not with the way Rio's face crumpled and she sniffed softly in an attempt to not immediately start sobbing. Before Rio could get to her feet, Nicky had already moved to place himself behind her, leaning over to wrap an arm around her, squeezing her tight.

"I love you too, Nicholas," she breathed at him, just loud enough so he could hear. "More than anything."

Although Agatha and Rio had faired pretty well, there was still this bold statement of pure and raw feeling that was sitting over that table, heading up the space they all occupied.

Their children were... Incredible? Brilliant? Compassionate? Articulate?

Their children were masterpieces in their own rights.

They all sat, laughing and talking and bantering across the table as they finished their meals. As everything had been cleared away, Jack had once more stepped up to announce that the time had come for the brides to share in their first dance.

With ease and a strange -- and almost foreign -- sense of confidence, Rio got to her feet and held her hand out to Agatha who grinned the moment she took it and stood as well. Together, they walked out into the open space of the dancefloor as the lights hung all around them illuminated it in a sparkling haze.

Rio's hands fell into place on Agatha's side at the same exact moment Agatha's hands landed on Rio's chest, fingertips finding her shoulders.

The faintest guitar plucks sounded over the speakers as the song 'Boats and Birds' by Gregory and the Hawk began to play. It was one that Estee had brought to them in an earnest showing of how deeply the lyrics had resonated with her.

If you'll be my star, I'll be your sky. You can hide underneath me and come out at night. When I turn jet black and you show off your light, I live to let you shine. You can skyrocket away from me, and never come back if you find another galaxy far from here with more room to fly. Just leave me your stardust to remember you by.

The movements were easy only because they were automatic as the two of them began to dance, slowly swaying and shifting as they locked eyes across the space between them. What had started as grins had softened into something more tender, something more reserved for that moment right then.

If you'll be my boat, I'll be your sea. A depth of pure blue just to probe curiosity. Ebbing and flowing and pushed by a breeze, I live to make you free. And you can set sail to the west if you want to, and pass the horizon 'til I can't even see you. Far from here, where the beaches are wide, just leave me your wake to remember you by.

It could have been a moment for soft conversation, for stating the disbelief at the moment they were locked into right then, but they didn't need it. They had what they needed, all that they needed, in the way they were holding onto one another, sharing their very first dance as a married couple. They held everything in that gaze that was entirely unwavering until the song began to draw to a close. Agatha was the one to break it, glancing down at Rio's lips in a way that made Rio feel so impossibly warm.

As the last notes played, she was not at all surprised as Agatha's hands lifted from her chest and cupped her jaw so that she could give her a sweet and gentle kiss that drew cheers and applause. It made Rio's cheeks flush, but she was reminded once more that this was their life now.

Jack's voice sounded as he indicated that the next dance belonged to the mothers and their children. Nicky and Estee both raised from their seats and made their way around opposing ends of the table to both Rio and Agatha awaiting them with outstretched arms. The embraces happened in time with one another and then, the music began to play.

It was a song both of the children had decided on and after Nicky had played it for them the first time, Rio had spent the next three days listening to it on repeat whenever she had a free moment. It was called 'Different' by Acceptance and each new time Rio had listened to it, she found something else that hit her square in the chest.

Her arms were nearly wrapped around her daughter as they began to move in time with the music.

Tell myself on the ride home, getting tired and hating all I've known. Holding on like it's all I have. Count me out when it's clear that I find it hard to say. I wanted to see something that's different, something you said would change in me. I wanted to be anything different, everything you knew would change in me.

Rio was still surfing the wave of speechlessness, but she should have known that they were not getting out of this dance without Estee having something to say with a gentle whisper that could be heard only by Rio over the music.

"This is where we really begin, isn't it mama?"

A lone tear dropped despite Rio's heartwarming smile, but she didn't address it and instead reached up to cradle the back of Estee's head so she could pull it toward her to place a kiss to the soft skin of her forehead.

"I think it is, mija."

The grin Estee wore as she lifted her head was bright, but there was also a sense of mischief, one that Rio did not understand until the end of the next verse.

Got this way, up front but never true. God, I'm wrong and it's just the way I am. Crashing down, any chance you hear. Caving in, any chance that you could see inside of me and I don't know what to say. It's fine; This isn't Hollywood. So fine, getting in your way.

I wanted to see something that's different.

At that moment, they were all four close enough that Nicky and Estee caught each other's gazes and grinned, giving a nod. In an instant, Estee let go of her hold on Rio and Nicky's grip on Agatha released, too. With the most fluid movement, they danced around one another and swapped spots. Nicky's arm was around Rio's waist in an instant, his hand holding hers up and poised. Estee landed in Agatha's arms with a beaming and bright smile lighting up her face.

"Oh, you two," Rio chastised the young man in front of her, but he hadn't stopped smiling.

"We didn't feel right not sharing," he disclosed in a soft murmur and Rio repeated the same action she had managed with her daughter, though it took a little more effort to kiss Nicky's forehead with how tall he was.

I'm taking a chance, this could be different. This could be all I'm waiting for. Something that's different. Something that's different.

As the song drew to a close, there were still tears sitting in Rio's eyes, ones that fell as Agatha and Estee approached. Not a moment later, all four of them locked in an embrace that sparked sniffles and tears from several members of the crowd.

When they broke apart, it was time for the party to really begin.

Greeting everyone, trying to hold even small conversations, it was a lot, but Rio felt like it was also easy at the same time. She was comfortable there as she mingled and made any introductions that might have been missed previously. It was endless conversation from person to person and instead of depleting Rio's social battery like she had been worried it might, she was absolutely thriving.

She had been close enough to hear an exchange between a couple of the Landon siblings -- Thea and Wyatt -- and Nicky, who was fastened snugly against Hmi's side.

"You... You look really happy, Nicky. It suits you," Thea had told him, her voice soft with her honesty. Nicky's reaction immediately displayed that such behavior was not commonplace for their relationship.

"Thea, how much have you had to drink? You're being nice to me?! Something's wrong..." he managed back, that wild and teasing grin bright across his face.

"Oh, my mistake. I'll remember to never be sweet with you again, lest you worry and send for an ambulance."

The laughter that bubbled out of the group and for a moment, Rio glanced back to her partner in conversation, Adam, who was smiling nearly as wide as Rio was. The brightness on those smiles seemed to amp up even further at Wyatt's words.

"Okay, but really... I'm still single and living at home. What's the chance I can get some of what y'all have if I hop a plane to New Zealand?"

More laughter, more clinking of glasses, more drinking.

Rio and Agatha had migrated back toward one another after Agatha tied up whatever conversation she had been having with Jack and she had spotted Rio in conversation with Walker and Dave. She had joined them, diving right in with ease as the four of them simply talked and discussed plans for the future, what their travel schedule would look like and when they could come to the Landon Mansion and spend time with them. Rio had been transfixed on Dave, who was talking about wanting to visit where his father had grown up, to a point where she had not noticed anything else happening.

However, Agatha was locked in. She'd watched as a man -- entirely underdressed and very out of place -- stepped into the space by the bar. The fact that this floored her did not touch her posture.

Instead, Agatha was processing.

What the fuck was Colton Scratch doing standing in her goddamn wedding reception? Not in a coma, at that!

Apparently, the source that had delivered the news had not thought this to be pertinent enough to inform her, or Dave, of this time around.

As Agatha was working through a plan in her head, her eyes lifted and caught sight of Nicky, whose gaze had lifted at the wrong time, catching sight of his father. Coolly and calmly, Nicky placed his hand to Hmi's chest and placed a soft kiss to his cheek as he excused himself for just a moment.

Nicky was immediately on the move. For a moment, Agatha let him go. She was still muttering soft mmhmm's and yeah, sure's to try and appear invested in the conversation, but she was nowhere near being present in that moment.

The closer Nicky got, she knew she needed to be there to intervene if it got bad. Agatha placed her hand on the small of Rio's back and kissed her on the cheek.

"I'll be right back. Found someone else I haven't spoken to tonight." It was a simple enough explanation that drew no question from Rio. However, Agatha's gaze lifted to Dave before it flickered toward the direction of her son and ex-husband, and he only needed a second to understand. It was now his task to keep Rio busy for the next five minutes or so. He gave an almost imperceptible nod and Agatha departed.

Nicky came to a stop directly in front of his father and even though Agatha could not see his face, she knew how angry he was before he had even started to speak.

"How dare you," Nicky growled, poking a firm finger right in the middle of Colton's chest. "You literally fuck off for a decade and then you think your balls are big enough to show up here? Tonight of all nights? You could have fucking picked up a phone, but you're trying to ruin a moment for her because... What?! You're jealous?! You're angry?! Guess what, Colton! It doesn't matter!"

His voice was firm, but he was not being loud. In fact, Agatha was almost certain that anyone who was any further away than she was likely wouldn't have even heard.

"You were a shit dad when you were around and now you're just a shit person for coming here to try and fuck up the one good thing my mom has in her life. I really, really do not want to cause any type of scene here, out of respect for my parents, but I swear to gods if you don't leave..."

Before her son could make a threat that might get him into any kind of trouble, Agatha stepped up behind him and slid her hand onto his shoulder from behind. She leaned up enough to press a soft kiss to the side of his head.

"Go back to Hmi and your sisters, baby boy. I can handle this."

As he looked down at her, she could see just how upset he was. His cheeks were red and his eyes were a little wild, that bright green flashing with licks of flames. He huffed a disgruntled sigh out of his nose and let his shoulders slump before he complied.

The moment he was on his way, her attention sliced right back to the man before her.

"You didn't even tell him?"

"What?" Agatha snipped back, her eyes narrowing. "That a man who hasn't spoken to him in ten years was in a coma? Honestly, I thought you still were right up until the moment that I looked up to wonder what the fuck nerve you think you have to be standing anywhere near my very private wedding reception. Which, please do let me know who gave you the information. I've got plans for them."

"Agatha --"

"No, Colton. You don't get to show up here and say anything. I don't want to know the reasoning behind such a show of disrespect. How fucking dare you show up here, in front of my wife. How fucking dare you show your face around a child you haven't cared for in ten years. So I will say this only once, Colton Scratch. Your existence is not a necessity in the lives of anyone currently here, not our guests, not the children I share with her, and certainly not my wife or myself. This is not a time where you get to talk, where you get to say absolutely anything at all. This is the time where I look you, right in your eyes, and tell you that I never want to see you again for as long as I live, and I feel safe in the assumption that Nicky feels the same. If that changes for him, I'll help him find you to reach out, but that is a mighty large 'if.'"

Her lips pressed together hard, her hot gaze doing everything it could to burn holes into the man in front of her.

"You made your decision to abandon him because of your feelings toward me. I'm sorry that you got stuck with me for ten years, truly, because it wasn't a walk in the park for me, either. I'm sorry that your feelings were hurt the moment you knew we only got married because of my public appearance. But... you knew. You knew before I got blackout drunk that night that I didn't want to sleep with you, or any man. And once I did, I knew I'd never do it again and I walked away from you in any facet that wasn't a public one. But Nicky... He was worth the shot at a normal childhood. With the two of us, he of course had no hope, but I'd still wanted it for him."

There was a brief pause in her tirade as she took in a deep breath and re-centered herself.

"He's never had to tell me for me to see how hard it was to spend time with you when I was away. He's never had to put into words that it wasn't just me who was neglecting him, but you were the one present. You looked at him and all you saw was everything you hated about me. He deserved more. He deserves more, and my wife gives that to him. She tells him she loves him every chance she gets. She lays her head on his shoulder when we're all watching movies together. She cooks with him. She drives him to places she knows he would love to take pictures of. She has zero biological relation to him, but he is her son just as much as he is mine."

One more breath, one final blow to be dealt.

"So I will give you the next fifteen seconds to make your exit without protest or I know an incredibly fit rugby player that would be more than happy to help you find it. And I'm sure if I ask him nicely, he'll make it hurt when he tosses you to the curb."

The venom was thick over each and every single one of Agatha's words and the way her eyes had narrowed left little room for any kind of miscommunication.

Without another word, he turned on his heel and walked away with his tail tucked between his legs, making Agatha feel far more powerful than she had thought the interaction might. He'd not gotten a word in edgewise and he had accepted her scathing degradation of his character for what it was. It also helped that he knew Agatha was not one to make empty threats.

"Are you alright, my love?" Rio asked, none the wiser to anything that had just transpired.

"Of course, baby," Agatha assured her, leaning in to steal a soft kiss.

"Did you know Dave was planning on buying a house in Wine Country?" Rio posed, the softest giggle that indicated her raised level of intoxication slipping through her lips at the thought.

"He's been saying that for almost ten years," Agatha returned, an easy grin finding her face despite the gravity of what had just unfolded.

The rest of the night had worn on with countless cheers and dancing. It was a flurry of joy and happiness and unity that Rio had never before gotten to experience. It was a thing of beauty, something that she would be happy to hold onto forever.

Things had started to wind down after cake and last round of drinks, but the children were not quite finished with the emotionally touching gestures for the day. Hmi and Tay had placed themselves to the side as Nicky and Estee pulled their mothers back to their seats at the head of that big table and sat them down.

"What's this about?" Agatha had questioned, but before anyone could offer a verbal answer, Estee reached over Rio's shoulder and laid down a large leather-bound book that was very clearly a photo album.

"This is our gift to you. And we wanted to give it to you now so that you could take it with you to Iceland if you needed it." She gave her mother's shoulder a soft squeeze, looking over top her head to beam down at Agatha who looked like she was suddenly on the verge of tears.

Together, both Rio and Agatha reached forward and opened the cover to reveal the first page.

In the very middle was a large, page-wide photo. It had been taken weeks before by Nicky at the scrimmage Hmi had invited them to; it was after it was over and Nicky, who had been on a higher level, snapped a picture that had all six of them in frame. Hmi was leaning over the barrier with an arm slung over Rio's shoulder who looked like she was going to combust from happiness. Agatha was right on the other side of her, laughter all over her expression. Estee's grin was only visible just barely as she peered out from behind her brother, and Tay rounded out the photo with her head just above Estee's.

Just below it, in gold print read the words:

The Harkness-Vidal Family and Their Memories.

The next fifteen minutes was spent reliving so many moments in the last months that had been captured by their kids beyond their knowledge. There were photos of Rio as she danced around the yard and watered the plants. There were photos of Agatha with her hair up and a pen in her mouth as she tried to put together a piece of furniture. There were ones of the two of them together sitting in various places as the light of a setting sun filled the space before them. There were pictures of Agatha chasing Estee around the yard with the hose, and ones of Rio and Nicky playing Go in the living room. There were over a hundred photos that had been slotted into place in that book and there were spaces for many more.

The tears had started falling somewhere in there, tears that wet the cheeks of both women as well as Estee, who pointed out that not crying didn't make Nicky tough.

Rio stood and pulled her daughter into a hug for the millionth time, squeezing her tight though this time she did not feel the need to assert yet again just how much she loved her little girl. In tandem, Agatha was on her feet and squeezing her son firmly in her arms. As they all parted, they were informed that their ride was there and it was time for the final send-off.

Every person in attendance had lined up, two parallel throngs of people facing each other, and the moment Agatha and Rio appeared before them, they lit up the extra long sparklers they had been handed and extended arms, creating an arch of sparks that illuminated the dark mountain night. With a grin on each of their faces and their hands fastened tightly together, Rio and Agatha began their journey toward their life as a married couple, walking through every bit of love their friends and family had to offer on their way.

They placed kisses to the cheeks of their children before sharing in one last embrace with each of them. The goodbyes weren't hard this time. The kids knew where they were going, knew they were free to spend time wherever they chose over the course of time Rio and Agatha were going to be in Iceland. The kids knew that this instance of separation was much needed and they made it known in the way they delivered their 'I love yous' and 'See you laters.'

Rio pulled the back door to their limo open and stood back, offering the space to Agatha so she could slide inside. The moment Rio copied the action and shut the door behind her, she felt Agatha's presence immediately against her, a cause for an instant and tender smile.

"Hello, my wife," Rio cooed at her, placing a soft kiss between Agatha's eyebrows.

"Hi, my wife," Agatha murmured back, nuzzling her face into Rio's neck.

"Today has been perfect."

Agatha breathed the gentlest laugh into Rio's skin.

"Life with you has always been perfect, Rio, and I'm glad I know I get it every single day moving forward."

That, Rio thought, was a forever that she could hold onto with pride, with happiness, and with commitment.

That was a forever that Rio Vidal would never shy away from.

This Love Isn't Good Unless It's Me and You
