She would make it known until she was blue in the face if that was what Agatha needed to find a way through it.

Some time after two, Agatha had finally fallen asleep. Rio only knew this because she stopped moving every fifteen to twenty minutes.

For the first hour, Rio didn't deviate from her place behind Agatha, arm secured firmly around her middle. After the second, she started to get hot and wiggled around enough to kick the covers off of her legs and bare feet, though she resumed her position pressed to Agatha's back a moment later.

By the third hour, Rio knew she wasn't going to sleep. How could she when all she could do was think about the fact that for even a few days, their family felt fractured? She did not blame Agatha, did not think there was any need for guilt or remorse. What was done was done and it was better that Nicky knew now and not even longer down the road.

Rio also empathized, in a way, with where Agatha was coming from. She had very understandable and valid reasons for not being so forthcoming with him, especially given the state their relationship had been in before Rio had entered their lives, as indicated by both of them. It had been taut and fragile in the way that one catalyst could have snapped it clean in half and as a result, it had never felt safe to Agatha to dump that kind of weight on him.

Having met him in that stage of his life, Rio could agree that it had been a wise decision.

Seeing this as it played out before her? It was glaringly obvious that both Agatha and Nicky had grown in those months, exponentially more than Rio knew herself capable of verbalizing. Agatha had grown enough to understand that the time had come for her to atone. On the other hand, Nicky had grown enough to know his own boundaries and take things like time and space so that he could properly digest his emotions without saying things in the heat of the moment that he would later regret.

He had once looked Agatha in the eyes beneath an inky sky on an otherwise normal night and told her that he would never respect Rio as any kind of parent.

That night, he had sat under a sky of the same color and called Rio 'mama' and told her how lucky they were to have her.

That alone was enough proof to Rio that somehow, things were going to be alright. Maybe Agatha didn't believe it in the meantime, but Rio had yet to lose the faith, even as the room around her started to lighten with the way the sun was clawing its way up the horizon.

She had tried to stay, tried to keep herself in bed until Agatha roused so that she would be available for whatever it was her wife might need, but the restlessness had started to border on unbearable. It was early enough she could make coffee and perhaps sit outside for a bit of self-reflection. The girls tended to sleep in more often than not and with the way Agatha had tossed and turned until the early hours of the morning, Rio had a sneaking suspicion that she was likely going to find consciousness a bit later than usual as well.

The orange hues of the rising sun streamed through the front windows, illuminating parts and pieces of the house, broken up here and there by the shadows of the walls between windows. The smell of coffee began to fill the space of the kitchen and something about it felt like a comfort to Rio, a gentle hug to remind her that there were still things that were normal in life.

After the pot finished and she poured herself a mug, Rio picked up her coffee and made her way outside around the back of the house. She could sit in the lounger, or she could perhaps go down to the water; it was only a minute long walk and surely looked beautiful in the light of the rising sun. Instead, she chose to pad over to the edge of the pool, roll up the legs of her pajama pants, and plant herself on the concrete, legs sliding easily into cool water.

There was such a duality to the entire set of circumstances that had befallen their family and Rio was struggling to find the balance in it. Everyone was making the correct choices, handling things in all of the right ways, but it didn't keep any of them from hurting.

This, Rio knew, was a prime example of how the right choice sometimes wasn't going to be the easy choice.

None of this was easy. It was difficult for both Agatha and Nicky to be experiencing, she was sure, but it was difficult for her to sit by and watch, knowing nothing she could do would make it any better. Even worse was knowing that really, there wasn't even much that could be done to begin with.

Rio had played her role. She had held both mother and son in their tears and did her best to soothe them, to ease their worries. She did not know if she had actually succeeded in such a goal, but she had tried and that felt like the most important part.

Something in her had thought that once Agatha had fallen asleep, she might break, might shed tears over the heartache she was feeling at bearing witness to everything happening. Surprisingly, even as she sat at the edge of the pool and sipped at her piping hot coffee with too many thoughts to count rolling through her head, Rio did not cry.

Instead, she released a sigh full of as much tension as she could muster, dispelling it from her form in a move that felt very reminiscent of what Agatha had taught her in the bathroom of that Queenstown hotel room the night Nicky had turned up unexpectedly.

It was a bullet point on a long list of things Rio had learned simply by being with and around Agatha. The beauty of what they had was that anything could be a teachable moment through the right lens, they just had to be willing to adjust the scope.

Not certain how long she'd been sitting there with her mind circling laps over the same thoughts and emotions, Rio nearly jumped out of her skin as she caught movement out of the corner of her eye dangerously close to where she was sitting. The moment her head snapped to the right to see what it was, she was met with the sight of her daughter settling on the concrete next to her, legs making the softest splash as they dropped into the water.

"Good morning, mija," Rio voiced, swapping her coffee to her left hand so that she could reach up to hold the far side of Estee's head, pulling her closer to press a kiss to her hair. "Did you sleep alright?"

"Morning, mama. I slept... okay, I guess," Estee answered, scooting a little closer to Rio. "I would ask you the same, but I think it would be a safe assumption to deduce that you probably didn't sleep much, if at all."

"Have I told you that you're a smart kid?" Rio's question was soft, but it was also light in its taunting as she leaned toward Estee, playfully bumping their shoulders together.

"Sometimes, but could do with more," Estee teased with a returned nudge of her own.

Rio lifted her head and looked out across the expanse of the pool, the water calm once the ripples from their legs ebbed into smoothness. She wanted to broach the topic of what had happened the night before, but she wasn't quite sure where the best place to start might be. She didn't know what Nicky had told Estee and as such, she was not sure of what questions she might want or need to ask.

Before she had succeeded in finding the best path forward, Estee found her voice first.

"So... About last night..." she started, though her voice was soft. That choice of tone was not one of shame or secrecy but was rather one that knew the conversation ahead of them was one that called for a little tenderness. "I... Am not entirely sure what all he told you, and I don't want to breech his trust by saying something I shouldn't, so maybe we should start with what he told you," Estee suggested, turning her head for those beautiful green eyes to take Rio in.

Rio knew how intelligent her daughter was, and had always known, but when she phrased things so delicately and was still somehow clear in her demands, it stunned Rio almost every time. Estee had this way with words, this intention that was so threaded into who she had grown into as a young woman, and Rio was blown away when it presented itself in such a wholesome manner.

By making such an ask, Estee was not only proving that she had grown to love Nicky, but she was also proving that she was loyal to him, too. This could have been tricky to navigate and also could have devolved quickly into a spiral of misconceptions, but Estee was heading that off before it could even begin. She had spent years of her life understanding how to navigate things like this and it was showing, something that made Rio so impossibly proud.

Dark eyes fell to black coffee, the tiniest reflection of a whisp of white from a cloud overhead visible for the quickest moment before Rio looked over toward her daughter, a sad frown forming.

"He told me that he's not angry about much other than not knowing," she decided to start, her voice soft, her demeanor a little morose from her lack of sleep. A soft sigh passed through her lips, eyes falling into Estee's as she continued. "He's hurt because he felt like she didn't see him as worthy of being told the truth. But... I know that's not true. And I think deep down, he does too."

"He does," Estee cut in gently, reaching down to where Rio's hand had landed on her own thigh so that she could thread their fingers together. "We had a long talk in the car. We'll get to that. Is there anything else?"

Rio gave Estee's hand a gentle squeeze, her head turning toward the pool again. "He... asked me some unfair questions that I wouldn't give him answers to, but only in the sense that he was trying to compare two very different situations that had minutely similar attributes. And... I shut it down." Rio paused, her lips twisting in thought for a moment before she let go of another quiet sigh.

"He said he thought she never wanted him." The admission was heavy, it was depressing, but it was also not something anyone could have told him he was wrong for feeling, and both Rio and Estee knew it.

"He told us that one. And he also told us what you said. You..." Estee stopped herself to clear her throat, clearly having had a much larger view of what had been inside Nicky's head. "You have no idea what it meant to him to hear you say those things. There were... A lot of tears in the car on the way to the airport, from all of us."

Hearing this, Rio couldn't help but wince. Pain was inevitable in life, Rio was aware, but knowing that the people she loved most were all struggling in their own ways cracked something in her. She wanted to fix it, to make it better, but that was a naive world view. Pain had to happen for change to be brought about, that was a known fact.

Rio didn't like it, though. She probably never would.

There had been the thinnest silver lining, though. Rio had been in the trenches of everyone else's emotions to the point where she didn't have to feel or process her own. She loved her family so much that in her own mind, she'd been able to sort everything into boxes, kicking her own into a dark corner.

She should have known that if anyone was going to find and consequently rifle through such a box, it was going to be her daughter.

"How areyoudoing in all of this?" Estee questioned softly, her thumb lightly caressing Rio's knuckles.

No!Rio wanted to shout.Put the box back! Do not open that box!

"I'm fine," Rio stated, choosing in that moment to lie despite knowing it was useless.

"Okay, so," Estee began, pulling Rio's hand into her lap so that she could cover it with her free one as well. "I'm gonna ask again and we'll pretend like it's the first time and you didn't try to lie. How does that sound?" Her tones were gentle, just as her words were, but she was being very firm in her instruction. "So, mama... How are you doing?"

Rio's shoulders slumped, her thumb moving to hook over a couple of Estee's fingers with the way their hands were woven together.

"It's a lot, but I'm dealing with it by not dealing with it right now," she attempted to explain, though she felt as though it fell a little flat, especially to her daughter who had a degree in psychology. "I think... If I let myself hurtwiththem, I won't be in an objective enough place to be able to help them. Because I see it from both sides, and that's... A tough place to be in."

The hand of Estee's that did not have fingers that were interwoven with Rio's moved to gently rub at Rio's arm, trying to soothe her.

"You're right, it is," she confirmed, leaning into Rio a little. "But while you are absolutely doing the right thing in providing all of the support you can, I think you need a little reminder to not empty yourself out in your attempt to fill everyone else up."

Somehow, Rio should have known the moment that Estee sat down next to her that she was in for an impromptu therapy session. It was her sage wisdom combined with her unique life experience that always seemed to guide Rio in the right direction, even if Estee was half Rio's age.

"I know, mija. It's just hard to do things like sleep when all I can think about is how much pain Agatha is in. I know there's nothing I can do to actively repair or heal anything, but my mind simply won't shut off long enough to let me do anything but just... Think."

"What about a sleep aid?" Estee posed, knowing that it was at least worth a suggestion.

"It's morning now, Estee," came a gentle chastising in response. "Plus, we are having dinner with Dave tonight to discuss the interview with Vogue that Agatha and I have scheduled for Friday."

This news delivered so casually still caused both of Estee's hands to clench, gripping Rio's hand and arm.

"What?! Are you serious?! When were you going to drop that morsel of information?!" she nearly squealed, though she was still considerably quiet enough to not cause any disturbance.

For the first time that morning, Rio's lips pulled apart in a genuine smile, though perhaps not as bright as it might have been had the surrounding circumstances been different. It was still a smile, one she meant.

"When I found the right time and... well, guess it's now. The day we shot you guys messages to say that we loved you, we... also found out about Wyatt's little mishap. So Agatha spoke with Dave, she and I sat down and selected an outlet. That just happened to be the one."

"Vogue?! Of all things, Vogue?! My parents are going to be inVogue?!What the fuck is my life?" she trilled, a round of giggles tumbling from her lips.

In spite of the weight of what was happening with Agatha and Nicky, Rio could almost feel the shackles of her worry break for the time being at the sound of her daughter laughing. It was such a light sound, a pure one that Rio could feel within the hollow of her bones. It filled her with a warmth that had previously been chased away by anxiety and heartache.

Even more than the warmth of her laughter was the heat her words brought forth.

It was the very first time Estee had referred to both Rio and Agatha collectively as her parents.

For every bit of emotional fortitude that Rio had been clinging to, it all seemed to completely melt away the moment that word settled in her mind. Sure, the wedding had been the grandest gesture of them coming together as a family, but there had been a couple of weeks put between them that had stalled moments like this from happening sooner.

It could have been a good thing.

It could have been a bad thing.

Right then, it was theonething that finally moved Rio to tears.

She had been trying so hard to keep up that stone facade, to keep her loved ones from having to worry about her when there was already so much going on, but it had been pointless to keep trying to do so in front of Estee.

Estee was talented at many things, but her greatest talent to day perhaps was that she knew exactly the right strings to pull to compel Rio into shedding her armor long enough to be seen by someone who could handle it. Maybe that could be Agatha in all other aspects, just not this one, and Estee was fully aware of that fact.

Quickly, Estee released her hold on Rio's hand and lifted her arm, pulling her mother to her chest in an action that Rio had executed not once, but twice the night before. Rio did not make a sound outside of the way her breath would catch in her attempt to stifle her own sobs as Estee clung to her, a gentle hand rubbing up and down Rio's back in comfort.

"You need to try and get some sleep, mama,"Estee whispered into Rio's hair, giving her mother a light squeeze."Even a couple of hours would do you good, I think. You need to give yourself a break."

Rio knew she was right. She knew that Estee, in all of her twenty-two years, had developed this second sight when it came to those closest to her and in those moments, she was choosing to utilize it so that she could convince her mother to give into the natural call of rest that she had been fighting in her discomfort and anxiety. Rio didn't want to admit that she was right simply for the sake of saving face, but it was pointless to resist.

"But what if Agatha wakes up before I do?"she asked back, sniffling softly. She knew it was stupid and nonsensical in the larger picture; it was a needless worry in the sense that if Agatha woke up first, there was little chance of her doing anything other than curling up into Rio and ruminating in her feelings until they were both awake enough to greet the day.

"If she happens to get out of bed before you do, I am sure Tay and I can keep her occupied, but I don't really see that happening,"Estee mused in a murmur, gently beginning to sway side to side with Rio still in her arms."I am almost certain that you have used the phrase 'it's going to be okay,' a time or two in the last twenty four hours, but I don't think you've really heard it as it's come from your own lips. So... Mama, it's going to be okay."

It would not have been difficult for an outsider to glean where Estee got her emotional maturity from, and while she still was so very young, she had grown up with her feet planted in nothing but reality, both the good an the bad. It had given her a perspective to know that of anything that could happen in the world, healing could still come after. It had to, to restore the balance in the world.

"I know,"Rio admitted, lifting herself from Estee's hold so that she could return the embrace."And you're right, I needed to hear it from you."She kissed Estee's head again and let her go, but not before giving her back a gentle rub of appreciation.

"Now will you please go lay down and try to get some sleep?" Estee coaxed, lightly and playfully poking a finger into Rio's ribs.

"Yes, mija, I will go lay down and try to sleep," Rio chided back, this time leaning over to kiss Estee's cheek. "I won't get sappy and cry more, but I will say that I am so lucky every single day that you are mine."

"Not as lucky as I am that you're my mama," Estee responded, turning her head to show Rio just how much she meant it by the look in her eyes.

"Te amo, mija,"Rio murmured, lifting a hand to cup her daughter's cheek lovingly.

"Te amo, mama. Now go!"she reiterated with another bright giggle.

This time, Rio listened. She dumped out the unfinished portion of her coffee once back inside and climbed the stairs, not entirely shocked to find Agatha still asleep and twisted in the sheets. It was an indicator that she had not slept well, that she was tossing and turning, likely even more in Rio's absence.

Carefully, she fit herself between the little portion of sheet left on her side of the bed and shifted over as close to Agatha -- who was on her side and facing Rio -- as she could get without waking her, their faces close despite the room Rio had between them to pull her knees up a little toward her chest.

Her arms were bent at the elbows and hands had come to rest tucked near her chest and the moment her head settled into the pillow, her eyes slid shut. They had been closed for less than even a minute when something startled her.

It was the feeling of Agatha's hand wrapping around hers.

Her eyes opened to see that Agatha's own blue ones were still closed, but there was a ghost of a smile on her lips.

"Go back to sleep, my love,"Rio whispered, tipping her chin enough that she could raise their hands to kiss Agatha's knuckles.

"Are you okay?"Agatha murmured sleepily, proving this with a yawn that followed a moment later.

"I am fine, I promise. Let's sleep a little longer, though, hm?"

"I'd be okay with that. But come here first,"Agatha supplied in answer, letting go of her grip around Rio's fingers so that she could lift her arm, an open invitation for Rio to come closer.

It took no thought for Rio to oblige, scooting forward so that she could press to her wife, their legs tangling together with ease.

It didn't matter that the world was falling apart around them, not right then. In those few isolated seconds of quiet, all that really mattered was that they had one another, as they always would, as they had promised when they had exchanged their vows just a couple of weeks prior. This could be the first trial, one they would overcome, but they were both of the understanding that it would be nowhere near the last, and that was okay.

Because once those trials were gone and the tribulations had been had, it was the two of them, wrapped in one another in that big bed.

Held firmly in the protective cover Agatha's arms had to offer, it took Rio a lot less time to fall asleep.

When she awoke, it was to the feeling of soft kisses being peppered on her face and a light tickling happening on the skin of her chest not covered by her tank top. As she opened her eyes, she understood that it was because Agatha was leaned over Rio's side of the bed and was kissing her to pull her from sleep.

"M'up, m'up,"Rio grumbled, her face scrunching in disapproval that she was conscious again.

"Dave just texted me, he's on his way,"Agatha informed her softly, placing one more kiss to the tip of Rio's nose.

A low grumble rattled from Rio's slightly parted lips as she forced her eyes to actually open, beholding Agatha's tired eyes but relentlessly warm smile. Rio could see the emotion there, could see the lack of sleep, but Agatha knew, as Rio did, that life had to go on. They also both knew that the best way to get Agatha through this was to keep her busy and her mind occupied. They had plenty on the horizon to deal with and this meeting with Dave was going to be the first on a decently sized list.

"Did he bring his husband this time?"Rio questioned, a sleepy laugh spilling from her as Agatha lowered herself to sit on the edge of the bed. She picked up Rio's hand and idly began playing with her fingers, staring down at them.

"No. This time the lie was that Ozzy was bathing the dogs. I think he's just scared of me after the one time we met when I flung and entire script across a boardroom table. He has not come around since then." While Agatha was laughing about it, Rio could see that something in her might have acquired some guilt over the years as it pertained to such an issue.

Perhaps one day, Rio could be the buffer to spawn a second meeting, one that might be a little less tense and a little more relaxed.

"We'll work on that," Rio countered with a soft smile, looking up at Agatha from her spot there on her back, nestled so comfortably in bed. Her next words came through teeth that were bared in something that had escalated to a grin. "Did Dave say what he would be feeding us this evening?"

Agatha lifted her hand to cover a yawn that overtook her, causing her eyes to squeeze shut for just a moment. It was obvious that she was still tired, but they still had to move about their lives in normal fashion. "Sparrow," she answered, stretching for a moment before she settled again, her arm over Rio's body as her palm landed on the other side of her hip. "Ciabatta for me and I figured Thai turkey burger for you. He got the girls food as well, but if you'd rather the black bean one, I can still text him."

For just a moment, Agatha's lips tucked down and there was a ripple of anxiety in her eyes, like she might have fucked up the one thing she thought she could do right. Instead of letting her stew, Rio raised her hand to land on Agatha's thigh, giving a gentle squeeze.

"Agatha, that is perfectly fine with me. Do I have enough time to hop in the shower before he gets here?" Rio posed, though she took no immediate action to sit up, still comfortable and warm cradled by the mattress.

Agatha picked up Rio's hand again, bringing the back of it to her lips. "Only if I can join you."

Such a request might have seemed mischievous to anyone else, but Rio knew better, and it was why she agreed.

They had been relatively quick, knowing they had a miniscule amount of time before Dave's impending arrival, but it still held that touch of warmth and affection and tenderness no matter what shower they were sharing.

By the time they descended the stairs, hair still wet and in fresh lounging clothes, they could already hear the girls chattering happily with Dave in the living room, though he tried to keep his tones lowered, as if he were telling them a secret.

"He was literally six and a half feet tall, could probably lift me with one hand, and she had him intears," he told them, eyes lifting as the two women came into view on the stairs, a sheepish grin finding his face.

"Ah, telling the kids horror stories again, David?" Agatha asked, tutting her tongue at him with a cheeky grin.

"Of course. They think it's hilarious when you made grown men cry, don't you, girls?" he offered through a shit-eating grin of his own as he got to his feet to offer both Agatha and Rio a warm hug. "It's good to see you both in one piece and also not as giant ice chunks."

Rio opened her mouth to make a completely inappropriate comment, but Dave held a hand up before she could get a word in edgewise.

"Don't do that to these poor babies," he warned, though he was already falling prey to laughter before he finished.

Rio's lips, while curled, still pressed together as she tilted her head at him in her silent chastising before she rolled her eyes. Despite the fact that it had been nearly six months since the first time Rio had actually become acquainted with Dave, he seemed to have gotten to a point where he understood Rio very quickly. He saw her motivations, understood her choices, and sometimes Rio was left wondering just what Agatha might have divulged to him about her in their conversations.

"Yeah, mama, don't traumatize us like that," Estee added, though Tay was already giggling beside her.

"Well!" Agatha announced, clapping her hands together. "If we are all going to share a meal, shall we relocate to the dining room?" She flourished a hand in the general direction of the kitchen and while there were still dark circles beneath her eyes, the blue in her irises had found a renewed brightness. "Are we feeling wine or whiskey with dinner?"

All at once, Rio and Dave chose to call for wine while the girls, the devious little creatures they were, called for whiskey. Agatha had announced she would grab both, but that she was siding with the girls that night.

Estee shuffled over to help her collect glasses and delivered them to the table so that Agatha was able to pour everyone a glass of their choice. As she sat at the head of the table with Rio and Dave on either side of her and the girls lining the table next to Rio, Agatha's eyes fell to her whiskey. There was the smallest, almost imperceptible, twitch of Agatha's lips before she took hold of the glass and raised it.

"To Vogue," she offered, her gaze casting to her wife in a show of silent appreciation.

"To Vogue!" everyone else returned, the soft 'clinks' of glasses sounding at the toast before everyone began to feast on the meal that Dave had provided for them.

The conversation had initially begun as small talk and then had moved onto the honeymoon, which the girls had been eager to hear about as well. However, it took that long-awaited turn toward what awaited the two of them that Friday afternoon.

Dave wiped at his mouth and set his napkin on the table, dark eyes landing on Rio, though the expression he chose was somehow... calming. It was because he knew what he was doing in how he was choosing to navigate this new facet of Rio's life.

"I know this is new for you, but I also know that she is going to hold your hand through it. You both need to be there by 9:30 that morning for hair and makeup and the interview will begin at 11:30." He sat back in his chair, lips twisting in consideration for a moment before he continued. "I have selected three outfits for each of you that will be sent over for the photoshoot that will follow the interview. And do not fret, I had some help."

The moment he glanced at the girls, they were giggling again though they tried to stifle the sounds before they could draw any heat from Agatha or Rio.

"But, all-in-all, you should be headed out no later than 3. So... Please make sure to eat something before you head over. I imagine," he voiced, looking back to Rio, that same kindness filling his expression, "the nerves might be next level, but trust that she will guide you through it. She might have already done it a time or twenty."

Agatha's hand found Rio's on the corner of the table and gave it a comforting squeeze.

"He's right. It'll seem like a lot, but... Depending on who we get, it might just feel like talking to an old friend," she explained. Rio knew she wasn't minimizing anything but was rather trying to offer a frame of mind that this could be comforting as opposed to terrifying.

"Per the last email I got, it's between Alana Sharpe or Caprice Bourdain. I have heard nothing but delightful things about both of them from other contacts, so it should be an easy day," Dave informed them, his eyes landing on Agatha, a twitch happening just above his eyebrow that indicated he might have known something no one else did.

"Can you push for Caprice?" Agatha asked him, her head tipping back as if she were trying to establish some authority. The requestion piqued Rio's interest and she eyed Dave instantly for an answer, already knowing Agatha would try to be dismissive.

Dave's lips split, a soft chuckle escaping through his grin. "Alana... Maybe has a thing for Agatha. And has for a... very long time," he offered, but as he was explaining, Agatha's grip tightened around Rio's hand subtly.

"She's nice," Agatha attempted, but she didn't sell it well enough to convince Rio to buy.

"But?" Rio pressed, thumb absentmindedly brushing over Agatha's hand in her grasp.

"She's... a lot. And... Caprice is a lot funnier anyway. So," she stated decidedly, looking back up at Dave. "If there's absolutely any way you can make that happen, it would be greatly appreciated."

"You got it, boss," he returned, raising a hand to deliver a mock salute that only caused Agatha to roll her eyes while the girls, making sound for the first time since the heavier part of the conversation had begun, dissolved into more laughter.

"Don't you have a husband and clean dogs to get home to?" Agatha grumbled at him, reaching for her whiskey to toss back the remainder of it.

"I suppose I do. I guess I was just... shockingly... enjoying my time with you. But silly me, it was probably just the wife and daughters that had me lulled into contentment," he teased her, pushing himself off the table to rise to his feet.

"Thanks for tea, Dave!" Estee gushed with a grin.

"Anytime, ladies. All of you have a good night, yeah? If you need anything in the meantime, you know how to reach me." He offered a light wave and started to make his way to the door, but he stopped about halfway and turned, his eyes dropping to where Rio sat toward the end of the table. "And Rio... It's going to be okay. Trust us and it'll get you through it, yeah?"

"Thank you, Dave," she replied, her voice sweet and smile kind.

He waved his hand in one last gesture of his parting and let himself out the front door, leaving the four woman sat at that grand dining room table, the remnants of their meals all shoved into the sack they had arrived in.

There was a heavy and still silence that started to settle, but it was something that Estee was not going to let happen.

"So I downloaded JackBox party packs to my Xbox and I think that we should each have another glass and play for a couple of hours. Just something silly and fun, you know?" she posed, grabbing her glass so that she could drain the last of it.

"You know what," Agatha voiced, catching Rio a little off guard. "I think that sounds like an amazing idea, actually. If you want, you can hook it up down here and we can play on the big TV."

Both Estee and Tay's expressions brightened in an instant.

"Really?!" Estee questioned back, voice hiked in her surprise. It was clear that she had not actually thought the suggestion would lead anywhere, but as Agatha nodded her confirmation, Estee was on her feet and pulling Tay up so they could collect the console from their bedroom.

Once they had disappeared up the stairs, Rio let her gaze fall to her wife, but once more, Agatha was heading her off before she found the right thing to say.

"A puzzle is still a full picture even when a piece is lost. The piece will get found. Shouldn't make the entire view any less grand."

It was moments like that when Agatha said the most profound things that Rio was left wondering just how it was her sitting there, absorbing that kind of wisdom from a woman who had likely only found such a thing since they had met.

"You're right," Rio agreed, leaning forward over the corner so that she could place a delicate kiss to her wife's lips. "We can still enjoy the sights we have and know they'll get even better soon enough."

"Small blessings," Agatha offered, the corners of her lips tugging up slightly.

"Small blessings, my love."

This Time I'm Feeling A Change

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Stop
You're thinking too much about it
Love's gonna heal us
Again and again
******

While life had yet to return to normal and a piece was still missing from the Harkness-Vidal household, ithadstarted to garner a little more regularity with each day that passed.

It came from the couple of trips Rio and Agatha had both taken to Agatha's office while she slipped back into the throes of her career.

It came from the few nights that Rio and Agatha sat out back with the string lights on and the girls across the patio table from them, chatting and laughing until they all tucked in to sleep.

It came from the mornings Rio would bring Agatha her coffee in bed while she was still fighting to greet the day.

Maybe Nicky was still thousands of miles away sorting through his own pain and emotion, but Agatha still thought of him, even going through the motions. Rio could see it in the way she would sometimes catch Agatha looking at photos of him when he was younger. It was in the way Agatha would casually inquire with Estee on if she had heard from him. Agatha did not grovel, did not ask Estee to pass on any message to Nicky. She just wanted to know he was okay.

Agatha was letting him have his time.

She was growing, too.

Rio knew it was hard, knew that Agatha was struggling, and they often unpacked at night as they snuggled in to prepare for slumber. They talked about the way Agatha was feeling, what she was going to do moving forward and how she had every intention of being as honest with Nicky as was possible moving forward. There were still things he should not know, sure, but those items ran on the same list as 'Things Absolutely No One Other Than Rio Should Know About Agatha Ever.'

Still, every night, Rio would trace her fingertips up Agatha's back and whisper into her hair that they were a little closer to things being okay again, even if it didn't feel like it yet.

Thursday night, it was Rio's turn to develop those live-wired nerves that caused her to feel as though nothing but electricity was running through her veins. It was stupid; she had been offered comfort in regards to their venture the next day, from Agatha and Dave both. They were both well aware that this was an entirely new world for Rio, something she was just being thrust into.

Dave had stated a couple of times that they should consider the tiniest bit of media training for her, but Agatha had been dismissive of the idea each instance.

"She'll be fine. I'm going to be right next to her," she told him again and again. He seemed dissatisfied with such an answer, but it was as though it stemmed more from concern than anything else.

Rio hoped Agatha was right. Mostly because she didn't exactly understand what the fuck 'media training' even was, exactly. Surely, that was a problem, but Agatha was not treating it as one so Rio had decided to show it the same respect.

She had almost asked Agatha, a couple of times, to explain it to her and break it down like she was a five-year-old, but it felt a little too embarrassing. Something in Rio simply wanted to rise to the challenge, to prove to Agatha that she could fit into her life as well as Agatha had so seamlessly fit into Rio's.

In spite of her nerves, Rio had managed to catch a few hours of sleep, though she woke before the sun started to rise. For those first drowsy morning minutes, she laid on her back and stared at the ceiling, listening to the soft sounds of her wife's intermittent snoring.

The day was upon them. They had put their story on display for the fifty or so people that had attended their wedding. Now, it was time to show it to the world.

Never before in her life would Rio had ever envisioned living through any series of experiences that would have put her where she was. Only a year ago, her life had been coasting, just sailing along a predetermined path that held complacency and routine. It had been a comfort to know that the life she had been living was the life she would continue to lead. But... That wasn't how life itself worked, was it?

All it had taken was a little incompetence on Agatha's part and a mild hero complex on Rio's for things to change forever.

And now, they were about to try and explain that to the masses.

The restlessness began to creep in and Rio carefully peeled herself from bed to go about her morning routine before heading to the kitchen to put on a pot of coffee. As she stood with her back to the counter, arms wrapped loosely around her middle, Rio's eyes fell to the front windows and the soft orange hues that were beginning to spill in.

It was a beginning, one to a day she had never, in her wildest dreams, been able to see coming.

It was her chance to step up, to prove that she was worthy of being the woman on the arm of the Wild Witch of Hollywood. In her bones, she knew it was stupid. She didn't have to prove anything to anyone, least of all the court of public opinion, but something in her couldn't help but want to make Agatha proud. Time and time again, Agatha had made concessions and done things to benefit Rio's life and sense of well being. All Rio wanted to do now was return the favor.

The discomfort had been rising, but it seemed with each sip of coffee she took from her spot perched on her chair at the dining room table, it started to wane. It steadied the trembling of her hands, brought Rio back into a reality where this was absolutely something she was capable of doing.

If all else failed, she knew she could simply keep quiet and let Agatha do the majority of the talking. This, after all, was Agatha's realm to rule over, and Rio now understood a bit better that she could do so with an iron fist.

In something close to a trance-like state, Rio had been staring out those front windows at the acres of yard when a voice snapped her back to reality.

"Mmm, I smell coffee," came Agatha's melodic but still sleepy tones.

As she looked over, Rio nearly melted at the softness of the sight before her. Agatha was wrapped in one of her favorite robes, hair a mess and was using a hand to dig the sleep out of an eye with her knuckle. She was bathed in those orange tones that streamed through the windows, looking every bit the angel Rio knew her capable of being.

The rest of the world might always call her a witch, but Rio knew the truth.

Agatha Harkness-Vidal would be salvation for those who loved her.

That was the most important part.

"It's still hot," Rio offered, watching Agatha with a soft smile as she made her approach.

"Just like my wife," Agatha teased, leaning down to steal a good morning kiss.

"Oh, so the plan's to butter me up to shake the nerves?" Rio jabbed back with a chuckle that she drowned in a sip of coffee a moment later as Agatha departed to fix a cup of her own.

"You're still nervous? Like... On a scale of manageable to vibrating out of your skin... Where are we falling currently?" Agatha inquired, though her back was to Rio who had turned around in her chair to watch the small act of domesticity that could be found in a morning routine.

Rio chuckled, downing another pull of the coffee before she answered. "The vibrating has quelled a bit with the help of coffee. I just... Don't want to fuck up, I guess. So... Probably closer to a mild annoyance than all else."

In her gliding, Agatha was near silent to a point where Rio did not even realize she had made her approach until she was sliding into her chair at the head of the table, spoon still in her mug.

"That's understandable," Agatha offered, tilting her head in assessment. "But... I know you, and I know how this experience is going go, barring any insane twists or turns, and I know that you are more than capable of reading social cues and understanding appropriate content to discuss." She raised her mug, taking a measured sip as she secured a finger around the handle of the spoon to keep it still.

"Oh," Rio voiced, her lips curling in the smallest smirk. "So mentioning that time you fucked me senseless over the railing of the houseboat deck is a no-no then?" Even though she hadn't started laughing, it was painfully obvious that Rio was on the verge of breaking, even before Agatha's eyes flashed for the briefest second.

"I don't know if I'm amazed at the brazen suggestion or pissed at you for making me think about that before I've finished my first coffee," Agatha commented, and while she might have been trying to be menacing, Rio still felt Agatha's foot beneath the table as it graced up the back of her calf.

"You're only pissed because there's no houseboat here for a repeat," Rio teased back, leaning forward to steal a kiss that tasted of sugar and cream more than it did coffee.

"And not enough time in today, unfortunately," Agatha mused sadly before she relaxed back into her chair, still cradling her mug in her palms. Her eyes lifted from the liquid inside and found her wife's gaze, the most tender smile pushing her cheeks up. "You're going to be amazing. You know how I know?"

At this, Rio's head was the one to tilt, green eyes searching Agatha's face for any clue despite already knowing what she was going to say. So, she stayed silent and tipped her head in encouragement.

"Because all you have to do is be you. It gets the job done every time." Agatha raised her coffee, taking a sip, though her eyes flickered back to Rio before she lowered it again. "Just try not to over think. We're just having a conversation with someone who's friendly. Dave texted me at 5am to tell me that we did, in fact, get Caprice. So... I think you will like her. Very... Professional but with a sense of humor."

"Does that man ever sleep?" Rio questioned with a laugh.

"I've never asked because I am not sure I want to know the answer."

"Fair enough," Rio mused. She finished the rest of her coffee and gave Agatha's leg a gentle nudge so that she could stand to rinse the mug. Before she departed, though, she leaned over and stole a light kiss. As she stood up and shuffled to the kitchen, her chin tucked over her shoulder as she called to her wife. "You know what I think might help soothe the nerves?"

"What might that be, my love?" Agatha questioned from her place still at the head of the table.

"If you come shower with me before we go."

Like clockwork, Agatha was slamming back her coffee and scrambling to her feet before Rio even reached the base of the stairs.

Some things should never change. That was one of them.

*****

By 9:30, Rio lifted her chin as high as she could manage while still looking natural as she strode into the towering building that housed the Vogue offices inside, her fingers hooked tightly around Agatha's.

By 9:45, they were sipping at the coffees they had gotten with their breakfast sandwiches on the way to the office while different woman busied themselves by treating and styling their hair.

By 10:50, they were still chattering back and forth happily between themselves as well as the stylists, but the focus had shifted to makeup instead. The two women tasked with getting them camera ready were a delight to converse with and the room had been filled with little more than giggles throughout their time spent within it.

By 11:20, Rio and Agatha were alone again, waiting to be fetched to join Caprice for their interview. Rio swiveled in her place as the door shut behind the two other women, taking in the sight of Agatha in the chair mere feet away.

They had chosen their own interview outfits after minor protest from Dave. Agatha informed him that he had deciding choice in every photoshoot look and so, the choice for the interview was theirs. Even despite their newly founded tradition of choosing something for one another, this time they chose for themselves and it was clearly a bright idea.

In that chair, hair cascading down her back in messy loose waves, Agatha looked like royalty. She looked like nothing short of agoddamn queenand Rio absolutely would have groveled at her feet. The way she exuded beauty and confidence in that baby blue and white pinstripe button down with the navy blazer over it and the slacks to match? Rio's knees felt weak and she hadn't even given thought to the act of standing up.

Rio was a sight in her own right. The emerald blazer on Rio's frame over the black camisole she had on was a stunning pop of color that threw a very stark but cool contrast against Agatha's blues. Her own legs were clad in chic black trousers and pointed toed heels that were a similar color to her blazer poked from beneath the hem.

Although they landed on one another at the same time, Rio's declaration came first.

"My love," she gushed, her grin sweeping cleanly across her features. "I've seen you in that before, but right now..." There was a mysticism to her tone, a wonder that often befell her in the quieter moments. "You look incredible."

Agatha's smile was so impossibly wide that it wrinkled the corners of her eyes deeply, clearly finding appreciation in her own view.

"And you? A vision," Agatha declared, reaching forward to hold her hand out, a seemingly common request.

When Rio slipped her fingers into Agatha's palm, though, she realized it was much more than that by the way Agatha's fingertips brushed over the still-healing script imbued upon her wrist.

"Are you the nervous one now?" Rio inquired softly, giving Agatha's hand a light squeeze. Maybe she could have left it alone, but Rio could see that tiny shimmering of uncertainty in those breathtakingly blue eyes.

"Not... nervous, per say," Agatha responded, her lips pressing for a moment. "I just... There will likely be questions about my... rather sordid past. And while I know Caprice will absolutely be tasteful, I just..."

"Agatha, my love," Rio soothed, encasing Agatha's hand in both of her own. "I meant what I have said in the past. If everything you have told me is everything I need to know, no question that gets asked is going to unsettle me."

"It is," Agatha tried to rush, but Rio tightened her grip to calm her first.

"I know. I do. So... what I said still stands to reason. You have entrusted me with the most vulnerable parts of you, and I handle them with respect. Nothing that woman says or doesn't say will change that." Rio lifted Agatha's hand to her lips, kissing at her knuckles lovingly. She lowered it down into her lap and looked Agatha dead-on in the eyes. "I love you, Agatha. And... Well... Sorry about your luck, but I'm pretty sure it's never going to change."

Even though she knew she shouldn't have, with their fresh layer of makeup on, Agatha leaned forward and pressed her lips to Rio's in a chaste but sweet kiss.

Agatha's lips parted to form a response but her eyes cast over Rio's shoulder as someone opened the door behind her, a dapper looking gentleman with his light hair slicked back in a way that did not look entirely pretentious.

"Ladies, we're ready for you. If you'd please follow me," he requested, standing back so he could hold the door open for them. Once in the hall, he led them down a few doorways to turn down another hallway, pacing another thirty or so feet until he opened the door he had been in search of. He held it again, gesturing for them to enter.

As they stepped inside, the room was positively filled with light from the large arched windows on the far brick wall, ones that were nearly as call as the vaulted ceilings. It felt like stepping into a completely different world, one that did not exist inside that plain looking office building. It was furnished with a couch, a couple of plush chairs and a few end tables that all sat atop a tufted white rug.

Rio couldn't help but admire the smaller touches, like the tiny pot of chicks and hens on one of the end tables, or the monstera in the corner. On another end table, there were a few cans of San Pellegrino -- something Rio would not be touching with a ten foot pole -- anda pitcher of water with glasses; it was likely a sign they would be there for a bit. Overall, it was a space meant to offer a comfortability that was conducive to opening up, to being willing to talk. Rio had never been the most forthcoming person in the world, but in that space with Agatha right next to her? It might be a bit easier to speak than she had been telling herself it would be.

There had been a woman already in the room, one that got to her feet the moment she heard them enter. When the turned to face them, a bright smile parted her full lips, red in color. Her eyes were a dark almond color but they were kind, friendly and a compliment to the almost-but-not-quite copper hair that fell down just past her shoulders. She looked both professional and comfortable in her white blouse that was spotted in tiny blue polka dots and her dark gray trousers.

Her hand reached forward as she approached them, her demeanor rather... disarming, if Rio had to give a name to it. "Good morning, ladies!" she greeted.

"Good morning, Caprice," Agatha returned, meeting the outstretched offering with a firm handshake. The woman then turned her attention to Rio before diving into any further pleasantries.

"Good morning," Rio chimed, giving her hand a light shake as well. As the contact separated, Caprice took a step back and gestured to indicate the white sofa that had been awaiting their arrival.

"Please, make yourselves comfortable," Caprice informed them as she returned to the space she had been occupying before they had entered.

Rio dropped into a passenger mindset pretty quickly, letting Agatha be the one to lead her forward across the room. Their arrangement on the couch wasn't overt, but in the spaces theycouldbe touching -- knees, thighs, hips -- they were. The moment they were both comfortable, Agatha did not hesitate to pick up Rio's hand, weaving their fingers together out of habit.

"So," Caprice began as she lifted her phone from the end table beside her. She looked up to Rio and offered a kind smile, one that would hopefully ward her from any nerves that might be remaining.

Honestly? It kind of worked.

"I'm sure Agatha has probably explained how this is going to go, but I'll do a light reiteration. I'm going to record," she indicated by giving a light wave of her phone, "but I will also be taking notes. Mister Rhys over there," this time, she gestured over her shoulder to a man in the back of the room at a table, fiddling with the camera in his hands, "will just be taking candid shots for about the first fifteen minutes. Otherwise, no more photos until afterward."

Rio gave a nod of understanding. However, before Caprice could continue on, Agatha leaned over, calling to the photographer.

"Oh, Rhys! My right side is my better one!"

When the man lifted his head, Rio's face filled with an immediate grin.

It was Rhys Landon, someone who had been present at the very wedding that had sparked this entire instance in the first place. She knew that he was a publication photographer, and maybe even something at the very root of Rio's brain hadknownit was Vogue, but it had simply slipped her mind.

"You got it!" he called with an amused grin before he returned back to the work in his hands.

"In that conversation, I told her about the earring. I was insistent it was just something that was lost, that it meant nothing. Then..." "So you hopped on a plane just like that? And... How exactly did that go?" she probed, her pen hesitating above her notebook.

"I am pretty sure her security guy was ready to call the police on me," Rio divulged. "So... I gave up. I wrote her a note with a name she didn't know, an out-of-country phone number and, in some form of blind hope, I drew theworstlittle boat as if it might have been an obvious showing that some insane woman had flown thousands of miles for one more second of her time."

"Before that day... What did life look like for you?"

This, for some reason, made Rio shift around uncomfortably, suddenly realizing that the main focus was onherand whoshewas before Agatha had tumbled into her life.

"Mostly tame, quiet life. I didn't keep many friends and my daughter, Estrella, was away at school. I worked a lot, on a project I have since finished. Agatha's grip was still strong in both places she was holding onto Rio as she finished speaking.

In a way, it almost gave Rio permission to be a little more emotional. Her eyes did glass, but tears did not spill. Hearing Agatha phrase it like that had impacted her in a way previous iterations of the same sentiment had not ever done before. The topic turned to the engagement, then the wedding, which had taken up another good chunk of their time. After a few more questions about home life and the consistent travel schedule, Caprice thanked them both on the record and reached over to stop the recording. "Off the record," she offered, a warm and genuine smile filling her lips, "that was probably one of the best interviews I have done. I know that for you, Agatha, it... probably wasn't easy."

"Well, thank you again. Our portion has come to a close, but I can escort you to the studio where Rhys will be awaiting your arrival."

The three of them got to their feet and Rio and Agatha both met Caprice with one more firm and appreciative handshake of parting before she took them to their next destination.

In the hours that followed, Rio was almost certain she had never had so much fun in her life.

Dave had sent over three outfits for the two of them, set in pairs. The flowing black dress of Rio's that matched a white one Agatha slipped into was a perfect contrast, a showing of the duality between the two of them. The poses were elegant and poised, but there had been laughter and giggles between shots, moments that Rhys had quietly captured, as well.

The second pair of outfits were equally as stunning in their dichotomy. Rio's suit was red with a black printed pattern that was reminiscent of feathers that wound around it. In turn, Agatha's suit was glaringly white with a black blouse underneath. It almost felt silly to Rio, like they were playing dress up as though they were children, but she was loving every pose, every glance, every smile, and she never wanted it to end.

That was photographic evidence that Agatha Harkness-Vidal was never going to love anyone the way she loved Rio Harkness-Vidal.

After a series of thank-you's that ended with embraces, the two of them were free to go about their day. Gio was already at the curb, waiting to open the door for them with a bright smile upon his lips.

While the mood had assuredly been jovial, there had been an internal monologue that had been quaking around inside of Agatha's head that Rio had not been privy to. It was a monologue built on watching Rio tackle a new aspect of her life head-on and with very little fear. For every bit of doubt that Rio might have been carrying with her about how she could fit into Agatha's life, Agatha had found reasons why she fit perfectly.

Let It Be, Baby Breathe

Chapter Notes

you were warned.
the 2 people who knew about this idea beforehand had intense reactions.
ENJOY!

Take it off, you want it off
'Cause I know what you're feeling
It's okay, girl, I feel it too.
*****

The day of the interview had been a gift in many ways.

The night of the interview had been an even bigger one, in themostmeaningful way that neither Rio nor Agatha could have seen coming.

Sounds of chatter as they approached the front door of the home they shared with their children were never that rare of an occurrence each time they came muffled and slightly muted by the thick wood. From a short distance, and even upon unlocking the door, it could have been assumed that the girls were inside, enjoying a Friday evening with take-out, or maybe alcohol.

Agatha pushed the door open and a deeper, bassier laugh bounced off the walls of the house. The very moment the sound touched Agatha's ears, Rio watched as she froze in place. It was a laughter that Agatha had heard evolve for two decades. It was a bright sound that had embedded its way into her brain and it was, in those ticking moments, a sound she had not been prepared to hear so soon.

Right behind her, Rio reached up and placed a hand to the middle of Agatha's back, right between her shoulder blades. It was probably a good thing that Agatha couldn't see her face; she was just as shocked. Rio had not been informed that Nicky had established any plans to come home, let alone that he would be there when they returned that evening.

"Keep going, babe,"Rio pushed in a whisper, not wanting the moment to break before it could truly begin.

With a sobering breath that seemed to quell that tiny tremble in her form, Agatha pressed the door open further and stepped inside, drawing an end to the clucking inside as the children realized their mothers had arrived home. The pair of them shuffled inside and before Rio could properly get a good look at the occupants of the room -- which she did gauge as being Nicky, Estee, and Tay -- Nicky was sailing across the room, careening straight toward Agatha.

Agatha was a bit more with it than her surprised wife, arms wide to receive her son as he walked straight into the awaiting embrace, his own securing tightly around his mother's shoulders. His head dipped, face landing in her still loosely styled hair as he hugged her as though he were afraid she might get even an inch away.

"Hi, son,"Agatha murmured, clinging right back to him and obviously not willing to let the contact end quite so soon.

"I missed you, mom,"he returned quietly. After another moment, his hold loosened and he pulled back, his hands landing on Agatha's biceps.
