The more I hear, the more they decide to tell me, the more I begin to wonder if Agatha is the director of this movie, after all.'"

Rio paused her reading again to glance beside her, a light curl of her lips happening as Agatha caught the movement and met her gaze.

"She very clearly respects you. And from what you've told me, that's hard to come by with relationships like these, so it makes me happy that the world gets to see it, too," Rio informed her, leaning in to steal the quickest kiss before resuming the work before her.

"'It is what Rio tells me next that almost surprises me the most.

"It took me a little bit of time, but with some convincing from who Agatha likes to call 'the greatest wing-woman in the world,' I booked a flight for LA with nothing more than an office address in my pocket." Now, it's her turn to wear an expression that communicates that she is entirely aware of how illogical it sounds when she says it out loud.

When I ask her how it turned out, she starts to laugh. It's sudden and a little loud, but it is so very bright. I understand why immediately.

"I am pretty sure her security guy was ready to call the police on me," she remembers, leaning a little closer to me as if she is telling me a secret. "So... I gave up. I wrote her a note with a name she didn't know, an out-of-country phone number and, in some form of blind hope, I drew theworstlittle boat as if it might have been an obvious showing that some insane woman had flown thousands of miles for one more second of her time."

It is in that very moment that I decide this is what blind faith mixed with gut instinct looks like.

When I look to Agatha and question if it had worked the way Rio intended it to, she is grinning once more when she responds.

"It didn't have to," she returns without hesitation. "When she was leaving, I was coming back. And I... saw her at the top of the stairs. And it was the strangest mix of feelings. It felt like I was being electrocuted, sedated, and had been on a four day bender all at the same time. And the only thing I was physically capable of in those moments was just... Going to her."

There is this gleam in Agatha's eyes which are looking somewhere just over my shoulder. I can see as she pictures the images in her mind, as she stows away to those moments for just a few seconds before her attention comes back to our task.'"

Rio was smiling, and Agatha could hear it, but she did not stop reading to indulge in the laughter she was trying to hold in.

"'A soft laugh escapes Rio before she offers her perspective."It was magnetic. I was moving at the same time she was and we met at the bottom of the stairs. She had kissed me before she left my home that day... But that kiss, at the bottom of the stairs to her office... That one was the first one of the rest of our lives."

This is romance.

This is meeting someone and simply knowing they are meant to be a part of your life and showing the initiative to make it happen.

It has very clearly worked out for them.'"

While it was nowhere near the end of the article, Rio took a moment to stop and turn to her wife that she loved so wholly and so dearly. Her hand raised, fingertips gracing Agatha's cheek so softly, beckoning her to look at her. Once obliged, Rio took a soft but prolonged kiss, one where she tried to tell Agatha what it meant to be reading those statements without using any words of her own.

"I love you more than anything,"Rio whispered softly against her lips.

"Almost anything. You can never love me as much as I love you,"Agatha teased back, taking one more kiss before Rio resumed.

It took about ten minutes to finish the rest of the article and while overall it was a beautiful piece, Caprice had undeniably garnered not only respect, but appreciation as well from Rio. Even before she asked Agatha her opinion, Rio was of the opinion that what had been written had been a true and honest telling of who they were as a couple.

She did not lock the iPad screen, but did lean into Agatha once they had finished, her head landing in the cradle of the crook of Agatha's neck.

"How are you feeling about that?" Rio asked her softly.

"The photo placements were brilliant for the sections they were put in. And --"

"Agatha," Rio cut, gently grabbing Agatha's side between them. "You know what I mean."

A soft sigh fell from her lips and Rio could feel it as her chest deflated, sinking her posture slightly as Agatha held her close.

"I appreciate that she doesn't miss a chance to assert that this is only a direct relation to you. And I... like the little lie she added at the end about me yelling at one of the interns on the way out. It helped me save a little face, I think," Agatha informed with a light chuckle.

"Ah, yes. Maintaining the Ice Cold Bitch thing is super important," Rio mused with a soft laugh, though she could practicallyfeel Agatha roll her eyes.

Agatha started to say something, but the iPad dinged with a new sound Rio did not recognize. Her gaze dropped to the screen where there was a notification at the top of the page. She swiped down to view it, her brow winkling at what she saw. Rio didn't understand it.

"head4harknesstagged you in a post.
|"wifey is that you?" "

She clicked on it to see what else there was. Attached to the post was a screenshot of another notification, one that head4harkness probably had about 100 of, at the very least.

"rioharkness-vidalliked your post."

Immediately Rio's head dropped between her shoulders.

Busted.

"Your URL is yourfull name?" Agatha questioned, the disbelief thick in her words. She looked so beautiful when she balked at the sometimes very idiotic things Rio could do in relation to the current state of the world. It was still cute, and Rio was almost certain it made Agatha love her even more.

"No," Rio answered in a pout. "I left out my middle name."

"You're ridiculous," Agatha chided, leaning to press a kiss to the side of Rio's head. "And also totally caught."

For a moment, they both sat in silence as they stared at the screen and the very obvious waving of hello from someone who had appreciated Agatha for a very, very long time.

Rio had been running through various ways to respond in her head when Agatha's voice sliced right through the frenzied chaos that was filling Rio's mind.

"I think you should message them," she voiced, though it sounded like she really meant it.

Rio's brow wrinkled slightly and she turned her head, meeting Agatha evenly as the question had clearly written itself on her face.

"You've clearly been caught. You could either ignore it, or we can just say hello. I've looked at it. It's clean, tasteful, respectful. It seems... Appreciative more than obsessive," Agatha pointed out. Rio knew it was actually a fair assessment; there was nothing that had ever been posted that had been unbecoming or had shed any kind of a negative light on Agatha.

Rio debated for just a moment before she began to navigate the app, pulling up the page and then the message option. As the keyboard appeared at the bottom of the screen, her lips pressed and her finger hovered aimlessly in the air for the longest moment of hesitation.

"What do I even say?" Rio asked, looking over at Agatha again.

"Maybe start with... 'hi?' Anything after an initial greeting is fair game," Agatha teased, causing Rio to roll her eyes in response.

Rio typed those two letters, then hit the paper plane.

rioharkness-vidal: Hi.

Her follow-up was quick.

rioharkness-vidal: You caught me.

"Now we wait," she announced, reaching up to lock the screen. Staring at it wasn't going to make head4harkness respond any faster.

When she felt Agatha's fingertip on the far side of her jaw, she turned toward her in compliance but they both froze at the sound of a tumblr notification from the iPad. Immediately, both pairs of lips were twisting into wicked grins.

Agatha's hand dropped and they both returned their attention to the iPad as Rio reopened the message.

head4harkness:'you're lying.'

rioharkness-vidal:Afraid not. Someone has already
criticized my innocently poor choice
to use my name as my URL

head4harkness:theres no way. prove it.

Rio glanced up at Agatha to question how they hell they might manage such an ask, but Agatha was already grinning.

"Hang on," she voiced, scrambling over to her nightstand to retrieve a small notebook and a pen. Once she had gotten what she needed, Agatha placed herself right back against Rio's side, opening the notebook in front of them. "This might be stupid because people on the internet are actually insane sometimes, but... I don't know. What could it hurt?" she mused, scrawling something on the paper. When she sat back, Rio grinned down at the message Agatha had left.

'Hi, head4harkness! Have a good day! :)'

A delighted giggle escaped Rio as she reached over to steal the pen from Agatha's grasp. She pulled the notebook over and wrote her own, smirking almost the entire time.

'Hi head4harkness, your URL is something i strive for every day :D'

The moment Agatha saw it, she actually gasped.

"Rio!" she practically shouted. "Absolutely not!"

Rio was laughing so hard it was verging on the point of not being able to breathe. It took her just a moment longer to regain her composure, soothing her amusement with measured breaths.

"Okay okay, fine," she playfully grumbled, flipping the page to write something else. "Better?" she asked, pushing the notebook back toward Agatha.

'Hi head4harkness. Please keep posting young Agatha pics. My messages are always open to you too. :D'

"Rio, you're exhausting," Agatha sighed, though she clearly sounded tickled in the way that she was trying not to laugh and offer encouragement.

"Hey, marriage is a bartering system, right?" she teased back, pecking Agatha on the cheek so fast Agatha almost missed it.

Rio ripped the page out, bringing open the camera app on the iPad to see Agatha already grinning like a fool next to her. It was nice to know that she found amusement in her wife's naivety and innocence instead of frustration or anger.

They each held up their respective papers, smiling like the lovesick fools they were as Rio snapped the picture. They were both laughing and repeating how silly it was as Rio pulled the message back up and sent over the photographic proof that a) she had, indeed, been busted and b) she was not, in fact, lying.

And then they waited.

And waited.

After 20 minutes of no response, they had decided to close the iPad and discuss what Agatha would do for the rest of the day.

Ultimately, she had cancelled the majority of what had been on her list for the day, though she did say she was going to attend two video conferences with Jack for something he was working on later on in the day.

They'd lazed around, celebrating the success of the interview in terms of how it had been handled and the light it had shed on their lives.

The world now knew who Rio Harkness-Vidal was.

In that public eye, they also knew that Agatha Harkness loved her endlessly.

After a short nap, they had taken the time to wake up by indulging in cuddles and closeness, soft hums and murmurs of needing to do things exchanged between them. Rio had just about convinced herself to get out of bed when that notification sounded again, several hours after the first time they'd heard it.

"Mmmm, check it!"Agatha urged, releasing her hold on Rio so that she could grab the iPad from her nightstand. She scooted away from Agatha enough that she could place it on the bed between them, opening the message.

Instantly, they both began to laugh.

head4harkness: hey so. sorry for the late response. i think i passed out. but so anyway, holy shit it's nice to meet you both.

A moment later, another message appeared.

head4harkness: jsyk, i am entirely unworthy but your privacy is safe with me. i can guarantee that.

It was a sweet sentiment and they both appreciated it, but they hadn't realized that she was prefacing something else.

Not until the video came through.

Upon seeing the still, they were both confused, but Rio quickly pressed the play button.

It was a very, very old video that had clearly been imported to digital. Immediately, Agatha's voice sounded from the speaker, though it was a little higher pitched. Still, it was apparent in her shouting that it was her, even before she walked into frame.

"Oh my fuckingGOD,"Agatha breathed next to her, her eyes wide. "This is fromcollege.How in the fucking world does she have this?!"

Rio was sort-of listening, but she was mostly paying attention to college Agatha as she walked around, pointing at different spots on the floor as she yelled at different students, instructing them what to do and how to do it right. It might have been some collegiate production, but in that footage it was clear Agatha took it seriously.

"Rio, ask her where she got this right now," Agatha prompted and while Rio was still grinning, she did as she was told.

rioharkness-vidal: Sooo... Agatha would like to know
where you got this from. If you don't
mind sharing your source.

There was only about a minute before head4harkness responded.

head4harkness: 'Thalia Jones.'

Agatha nearly froze next to Rio, this time the one to take the iPad.

rioharkness-vidal: How do you know Thalia?
This is Agatha btw.

And answer came that both seemed to bring Agatha a sense of recognition, but also a sense of pain.

head4harkness: 'she was my mom.'

"Agatha?" Rio asked softly, brow pinching slightly above her nose.

"I... I went to college with her mom," Agatha responded, her gaze tearing away from the iPad screen to meet Rio's.

"Like...went to collegeor just went to college?" Rio questioned, though her smirk had started to form.

"I did not have a crush on her. We were just friends. But... judging by the past tense usage, I assume she's since passed." There was something in Agatha's voice that sounded sad, like it was something that hadn't directly impacted her life for a long while and yet, learning about it still crushed something in her.

rioharkness-vidal: I am truly sorry for your loss. But
we are very happy to make your acquaintance.
And thank you for not sharing that video publicly.
Much appreciated.

Rio huffed a gentle laugh through her nose, unable to keep from rolling her eyes again at Agatha's antics.

head4harkness: 'thank you. it's been a few
years, but i still miss her. we can talk
about that at another time (hopefully?)
but thank you both for responding. you
seriously might have made my entire year.
i hope you have a great rest of your night (:'

This time, Rio took the iPad back and typed her response.

rioharkness-vidal: No, thank YOU. (I meant what
I said about those pics, please don't stop
posting them) Hope you have the best night!

With it sent, Rio locked the iPad and stowed it on the nightstand. When she turned back to Agatha in front of her on the bed, she had a happy but slightly emotional look written on her face.

"You alright, my love?"Rio asked her quietly as Agatha's eyes flickered back to life, locating Rio's face.

"Yeah, yeah. I just... Mortality creeps up on you at the strangest times. We were the same age. Just... something to think about, that's all."

It was an observation of the facts, but Rio could see that there was something a little more there. Right then did not feel like the time to push.

"Let's save the mortality and existentialism crises for stargazing later, hm?"Rio mused softly, leaning forward to kiss her wife."For now, you're going to attend your meetings and I'm going to make us some gnocchi for dinner. And then we are going to drink wine and watch a movie. How does that sound?"

Their lips were still close as Agatha breathed her earnest response.

"It sounds like another day in heaven with you."

Do It, Try It

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Listen to the sound
Of a new tomorrow
Take over my dreams
Walk into the feeling
*****

There was a fascination that Rio had developed with the operation of their lives and how it was not unlike clockwork. It was a clock that could still work when a smaller cog was temporarily displaced, or even two. Did it work better when all parts were present and accounted for? Of course, as all things did, but their family had come to be a machine that could never and would never stop.

The night before, withHmi's arrival, their clock was whole and in perfect working order.

Any other week, a Wednesday would not have seemed like a significant day of the week. That Wednesday was a special one; it was the day that the Harkness-Vidals were going to attend their very first film premiere as a family.

Over the weekend, Agatha had sent the children out with her black AmEx card and instructed them to acquire outfits for the event with the advice that Nicky would be able to assist the girls on securing something that would be appropriate.

With an arm finding its way around Agatha's back as the two of them watched the kids collect their things and stagger out of the house, Rio found a rather unfamiliar tide of anticipation rolling in her stomach. This was something new for them, something that out of the six of them, only Agatha and Nicky had experienced before.

It was a conversation that had popped up quite frequently since it had first been penned into the calendar.

Agatha had explained the first few that there was no real way to truly lay out and define what events like these could entail. There were the typical motions of the red carpet, photos, socializing. There were typically media interviews, but as her involvement in the project had been rather low-key, she had informed Rio that Dave had managed to circumvent press for her for the time being.

This was a way to dip their toes into the vast pool of Agatha's fame without plunging right in. It was a way for them to explore this new facet of their lives as a complete unit with a lowered sense of pressure. It was not one of Agatha's projects, it was not something that was high-stakes for her in the sense that she had her reputation riding on it, and as such it afforded them more of an opportunity to feel it out at their own pace.

In her many pep-talks throughout the week, Agatha had also informed Rio that there would be an after party once she screening was over and that they were more than welcome to attend if they so chose. Surely the kids would want to go and the more Rio considered it, the more she realized it might be a good idea for herself and Agatha to attend, too.

"Most of the time, after parties are rather tame. It's the after-after parties that venture into morally questionable," Agatha assured her.

They were back to back in their closet the Sunday before the premiere, standing on one another's side as they thumbed through dress after dress and suit after suit in an attempt to find attire that would speak to who they were as a married couple when the world was so very used to who Agatha Harkness had always been.

"And are you wanting to attend the after-after party?" Rio inquired playfully as she glanced over at Agatha's back for the briefest second before returning her attention to her leisurely perusing of Agatha's clothing.

"You already know the answer to that," Agatha responded flatly, though by the lack of fluctuation in her tone, Rio could tell than she had not looked behind her.

"I do. Which is why I had to ask. I can't be nice to you always," Rio returned lightly.

"You're telling me you know how to be mean?" Agatha shot, voice sounding a little closer as she did turn her head that time. When Rio looked back, she realized Agatha had actually turned her entire body all the way around and was wearing a viciously tickled grin.

Rio's brow pinched as she dropped her arms and turned around, putting her hands on her hips defiantly. "I absolutely know how to be mean," she stated, weight shifting as If it might make her appear bigger, more imposing than she actually was.

If the sound that came out of Agatha in response to such a statement would have sounded any more like a scoff, she would have found out that Rio was a little more than capable of being mean, but it mixed heavily with a laugh. It was enough to disguise Agatha's total disbelief and enough to keep Rio from growing irritated in some form of indignance.

"You should prove it," Agatha challenged, that grin only seeming to grow.

Rio blinked at her.

"And how should I prove that I know how to be mean, Agatha?" came Rio's request for clarification.

"Be mean to me," Agatha stated plainly.

"Agatha, don't even," Rio groaned, rolling her head with vigor as she spun around into her previous position so she could continue her search for the outfit she wanted Agatha to wear Wednesday night.

"Oh, come on," Agatha pressed. "You know, I've seen you grouchy. And even a little cranky. But..."

Her voice sounded like it was getting closer, but Rio remained focused on the clothing in front of her right up until the point that she felt Agatha's hands land on her sides and slide around her middle, wrapping around her firmly. In the same rush of movement, Agatha's face landed in Rio's hair, a devious hum slipping from between her lips.

"I have not ever seen you angry."

She wasn't wrong; it wasn't so much that Rio didn't get angry as it was the fact that it took a lot to get her there. She could be disgruntled, she could be annoyed or upset, but for her to find true anger, it had to be over something that was genuinely worth it. If Rio was going to expend the energy it took to show pure anger, she was absolutely going to need a damn good reason.

"Mmm, perhaps you should be thankful for that," Rio mused, paying no further attention to the way Agatha had come to cage her body within her hold.

"Tell me about one time you got angry," Agatha beguiled, her nose pressing to the side of Rio's neck.

"Why are you so interested in me being pissed off?" she returned. She had been trying to main an air of indifference, but the softest giggle left her without permission.

"'Cause I bet it's hot," Agatha ventured, digging lightly into the left side of Rio's ribcage with playfully antagonistic fingers.

"If I ever encounter a situation that genuinely angers me, it's not going to be sexy," Rio informed her, pushing a couple of Agatha's suits aside to continue her search. "Plus, the last time I got angry, the only one who got hurt was me." Her hand retracted from the clothing to indicate the small scar above her eyebrow. "I ran into a doorframe because I was mad and wasn't paying attention. And that's why it's stupid to get mad. Because it makes you do really idiotic shit that you would not otherwise do."

Rio could feel Agatha's laughter against her neck by means of her breath, but also in the way Agatha's body trembled with it ever so slightly.

Agatha released a warm, sweet sounding hum as she pressed her face firmly into the crook of Rio's neck, seemingly not bothered by the barrier of hair that lay between.

"Do you ever rationalize so hard you break your brain in the process?" Her question was muffled with the way she was situated with her face in Rio's hair, but it came out intelligible enough. Finally, she had poked a hole in Rio's steel resolve and it showed in her tamed laughter.

"No, I just prioritize how and where I deposit my emotions."

And that, Rio knew, was exactly why Agatha had fallen in love with her. It wasn't just the anger. It was the attraction, the love, the lust, the care, the compassion. Rio's currency was her emotions, each and every one of them, and she had spent the last eleven months making countless deposits into the Bank of Agatha, knowing that her treasures would be stored safely there.

An exhaled grunt slipped between Agatha's lips as she lifted her head and let her chin rest on Rio's shoulder, watching as she continued to sort through clothes even if she had stopped paying attention to what she was doing.

"You are so frustrating in that you're so painfully mature in ways I do not understand and yet it just makes me love you more," Agatha offered, her head tipping to the side to bump gently into Rio's.

Rio considered this for a moment. She knew she didn'thaveto provide any kind of qualifier, but she wanted to.

"I had a very long time to myself where I took the time to appropriately assess what was important to me and the best ways to protect my peace. Anyone encroaching on my daughter, and now my family? Those are anger-worthy offenses." Rio had desisted her task momentarily as her hand dropped to land on Agatha's arm, thumb brushing tenderly over her skin. "Maybe a couple of things about work. But... Most everything else can be rationalized and processed."

Agatha's chin lifted and she turned her head, pressing her lips to Rio's cheek. It wasn't a quick kiss and she left them there for several seconds. The only reason the contact was broken was because Agatha had chosen to speak.

"You fascinate me more and more each day."

This brought a smile to Rio's lips, Agatha's appreciation warming her like a comforting fire on a cold night.

"Have ta' keep ya' on your toes somehow. Now go on, make your selection and leave me be!"she urged in jest, giving Agatha's arm a light squeeze. Any attempt at seriousness was washed away with her phrasing, leaving them to dissolve together into amused snickering.

Agatha adhered and released her to return to her own search, but not before offering a hefty smack to Rio's right asscheek.

It had only taken them twenty more minutes, but they had each settled on a selection for the other.

"Okay. We turn around at the same time," Agatha announced, her giddiness bleeding in her tone in regards to the selection she had made.

"Alright, fine," Rio answered, her own grin audible in her tone. She was pleased with her decision and knew Agatha would be, too. "I'll count us down. Three... Two... One!"

The moment she hit the beat, they both spun and Rio's gaze landed on her proud and maybe also slightly arrogant wife, clutching that stunning red dress Rio had never seen before in her life. It was an off the shoulder piece, one that appeared to have an additional side piece for the other half of her chest, but would also leave her entire right side bare and exposed. There was also a very, very obvious slit up the left side that would end right below her hip.

Rio was grinning before it made sense to have such a reaction.

"And what the hell is that?" Rio teased through laughter that was both flattered and positively delighted.

"Oh? This? I found it in the back of your closet," Agatha answered, doing a terrible job of being convincing.

"It's a good thing you never tried to pursue acting," Rio informed her with a knowing tip of her head. "You're really bad at it. You bought that for this event, didn't you?"

Agatha glanced down at the back of the dress, her lips forming a downward arch in her mockingly thorough inspection. "Maybe. But. Either way, will you tell me no?"

Rio's lips rubbed briefly in consideration before she formed her answer. "Of course not. Plus, Idolook good in red."

"I know you do," Agatha agreed, a smirk creeping up her lips. Her head tipped back at Rio's own selection in question, her gaze following down her nose to inspect. "And what have you there?"

Proudly, Rio held up the black blazer, the matching pants hung haphazardly over her arm. Dangling from her left hand was a black leather bralette that would sit nicely beneath the blazer while still showcasing only appropriate bits of Agatha's abdomen and sternum.

Agatha's own grin was instant and full of emotion, her eyes alight with the thrill she felt at understanding how Rio wanted to see her when they were side by side on display for the whole world to bear witness.

Surprisingly, they had remained relatively tasteful despite how feral they could sometimes be. Unsurprisingly, they had completelynailedthe assignment. It was yet another example on the endless list of how they just simply got one another. They took in the context of the outing, the purpose of their mission, and what it was they wanted or needed the rest of the world to see, too.

It was a sentiment that had been founded for their wedding and now, it would continue forth and become something more, a way for them to have silent conversations with themselves but also with the world. Maybe no one would ever know their little tradition, but it didn't matter. The image that would be beheld by spectators was one specifically curated by them and while it wasforthem first and foremost, those choices had voices in their own rights.

Anticipation seemed to grow every day within Rio's being, her mind often wandering over what it might all possibly look like and feel like to actually experience. This was something she had never even dreamed of. Industry and fame had not ever been something she willingly sought out, but now there were photos of her on websites and her words had been printed by a major publication. Now, she was going to mingle with a great deal of people whose names and careers she did not know in support of her wife and their friends because she could, and because she wanted to.

Estee had already asked her a couple of times if she wanted to do a crash course in celebrity faces and names, but Rio had dismissed her easily, stating with certainty that she was going to be just fine.

By the time they were loading into the back of the limo that Gio had shown up in late Wednesday afternoon, Rio was not entirely sure she still held such a conviction.

The only thing that seemed to be circling her mind was simply not doing anything to embarrass her wife. Agatha had already assured her at least eleven times since noon that she was fine and that this would be an easy and fun night out, one where they would get to enjoy a little attention, a decent (but she really meant great, she just like giving Jack shit) film and an after party where they could spend time with friends and drink pricey alcohol. It was a night to step out of the reality of what life had once been and embrace what it would grow to be.

"Alright!" Agatha declared, slapping her palms to her knees in a shot of sound that was intended to draw attention. "Who here needs a pep talk?"

Rio's gaze swept around both sides of the car, over the pair of young women and then the pair of young men who were sitting opposite each other. Not a single one of them looked like they had been touched with nerves within the last forty-eight hours. Instead, they looked like works of art in their gowns and formal wear.

The black dress that Estee had chosen was positively stunning while maintaining an expected level of class at such an outing. It was collared, the fabric laying in a manner that formed an oval of bare skin over her sternum. Those pieces rejoined, the sides cut out to reveal the curve of her sides before covering her hips down in a loose, flowing skirt portion. Her hair was loosely curled and her makeup was tame for the most part, but it allowed her true beauty to really shine.

Next to her, Tay was just as much of a sight in her gold and sheer dress that Agatha had insisted on her having tailored to fit her exactly right. It had been the right call because she looked phenomenal. The thin straps over her shoulders dropped into a bosom piece that was crusted with jewels before a cheer midsection revealed more of the intricate pattern on the dress, gold and black lines woven intentionally for visual purposes. There was a slit over the left leg, showcasing those gold heels that shone even in the back of that limo.

Of the six of them, Nicky was probably the most underdressed, but that was par for the course for him, Agatha had informed Rio. He was still wearing a button down that was patterned with odd splotches of color over a black main space. Over that, he was wearing a dark navy blazer that matched his slacks. On his feet were probably the nicest pair of tennis shoes Rio had ever seen. He looked so casual, so cool and like this was something he had done time and time again.

There next to him, almost comically,Hmi was alight with a grin and clearly thrilled to be there despite the fact that the tuxedo he was in was miles more formal than what his boyfriend chosen. The look on his face said that he did not care one bit and he was just thankful to have been asked to accompany them. It struck Rio just how lucky they were to have him and the time he wanted to share with them. He was a great man, he made Nicky happy, and nothing felt quite as perfect as it did when he was with them.

"No one?" Agatha pressed a little harder, eyeing them each individually as they shook their heads, one-by-one, in response. Finally, her deep blue gaze landed on her wife. Rio was suspiciously not looking at her.

"Absolutely no one?" she offered like they were at an auction and she were calling for a last bid.

All four pairs of other eyes had landed directly on Rio. Consequently, her skin began to flush with the sudden heat as if they were all pinning her with lasers.

"I'm fine!" she insisted, managing to gather enough nerve to look over at Agatha in that undeniably delicious suit. Rio said that, but then looking at Agatha in exactly what Rio had wanted her in, she knew it was going to be the purest form of self-torture to keep her hands to herself throughout the night. "I know the spiel. Don't say anything embarrassing. Make Dave's life easy. No overt PDA. No --"

"That one. That one hard," Nicky chimed in. The grin he was wearing was telling that he was being humorous, but they all knew how squirmy he got in relation to the topic anyway.

"Not too much alcohol and Nicky has your shoes and Estee has mine," Rio finished, wiggling up a little in pride that she had managed to keep track of her little list of rules for the evening.

"Trust me on the shoe thing. You'd be crying for flats an hour in."

"It's almost like you've done this before," Rio returned, quirking a brow playfully with a toothy grin of awe.

"Okay, so. On that note. The main goal is to have fun tonight."

That was actually a lie. It was just that Rio was the only one in the car who didn't know it.

Her family had been moving parts and pieces around to solidify them as the unit they were. Yes, they had hyphenated their last names and slapped it over the six of them combined with 'family' following right after. Rio had already mailed in the paperwork for her official name change, but she was still waiting for everything to be processed.

She had assumed that, for everyone else, they would figure it all out later.

What Rio was not aware of was that Estee had sent hers in the day after the wedding, and that both Nicky and Agatha had gone through the throes of filing for theirs as well.

Agatha was about to let her know in a very big way, as well as the rest of the world, but they had to go through the motions to get there.

"If anyone pukes, please make it to a toilet first. Preferably, don't get that drunk, but for four of you I understand this is both thrilling and nerve-wracking as fuck. So. Drink until you stop panicking then drink some water."

It was almost comical the way Agatha was delivering such instructions as though she were a drill sergeant leading her troops into battle. Rio understood why she took it seriously. More than that, she understood that this was very close to the core of what Agatha's life had always been and likely would be for the foreseeable future.

"So... Last call... Any questions?" she offered one last time. She didn't look at Rio again, but she did pick up her hand and secure it in both of her own.

"I have one," Estee offered, raising a hand like she were a child in school. "Did you run those outfits by Dave? If the answer is no, are you two capable of behaving?"

Both older women turned to one another out of sheepish guilt, but they were grinning by the time they settled on their daughter again.

"We are responsible adults, mija," Rio reminded her, finding it easy to not take offense to the giggle that came from Estee so freely.

"We'll see," Estee returned with one last soft laugh.

The conversation shifted to more idle chatter in the last minutes of the car ride, something that kept Rio idling without completely stalling. It was going to be fine. Everything was going to be great, and they were going to have a good time. If she kept repeating it, she just might be able to will it into reality.

When Gio rolled the car to a stop, Agatha's head had turned completely so she could survey the scene on the other side of the window. Her grip tightened around Rio's hand, but when she turned back the smile she was wearing was calm, but there was a flicker of excitement in her eyes. It had been almost a year since Agatha had found herself in such a circuit and it was clear that she was eager to jump right back in.

Something about that very fact was enough to instill a bit of bravery within Rio; this was what Agatha loved, and Rio was almost certain that she could learn to love it too.

There was a strange sense of euphoria that settled over her as she slid across the seat and slipped her hand into Agatha's, right where it was meant to be. For the first fifteen seconds of the contact, Rio felt Agatha's fingertips brushing softly over her wrist. Maybe Agatha was doing it for herself, but the act of her soothing that tattoo fortified something inside of Rio, too.

She could do this.

Shewoulddo this.

The moment they set forth into the fray, she absolutelydiddo it.

With Agatha to guide her and issue softly muttered instructions, it was simple enough to hold her hand, grin and pose with her for photos. It felt so easy to listen toherinstead of all of the people shouting their names.

So many people knew their names.

For almost a month after meeting, they had not known one another's. Now, the whole world knew who they were, together. They knew who Rio was. There was this soft and poetic sense of romanticism that momentarily filled Rio at such a realization thatalmosttook her away, but she stowed it to reflect on at a later time. A later time when she did not have to be so present for her wife.

After their trek down the red carpet, they were met by a very sharply dressed Dave in a deep burgundy suit with black lapels who was wearing a very stern look of disapproval across his handsome features.

"Good evening, ladies. Am I going to have to start requiring that you run event outfits by me beforehand?" he questioned, those dark eyes darting back and forth between the two of them, causing their mischievous grins to grow.

"Whatever do you mean, David?" Agatha questioned, that air of disgustingly fake innocence giving her away on the spot.

"You need to beresponsiblethis evening," he informed them, but while his gaze had started on Rio, it had landed on Agatha quickly and lingered. While Rio was fully aware that this was a newer facet of his job in that Agatha had never brought a date to a premiere before, let alone a spouse she was attracted to, she also knew that if anyone in the world knew Agatha best -- even above herself, honestly -- it was Dave.

"Oh, quit that," Agatha admonished, giving Rio's hand a sneaky squeeze as she continued. "I would never cause a ruckus and ruin something like this for Jack. We are here to support him."

Maybe she thought she sounded convincing, but Rio could already sense that Agatha had already made a mental map of where the restrooms were located from her previous experience. There was a chance it wouldn't be utilized tonight, but the more Agatha looked at her, the more Rio could see her realizing that she had shot herself in the foot with that dress choice.

Dave pressed on, offering another warning to Agatha, but Rio wasn't listening. Her head had turned and she was watching as Nicky led the gaggle of them down the carpet, instructing them what to do and how to stand for the people that were snapping photos.

It was a sweet moment on its own, but seeing the looks on the faces of Estee, Tay, andHmi caused a detonation of affection to occur in the center of Rio's chest. They looked so fucking happy, so thrilled to be given the chance to experience something so dreamlike that it had just never once seemed possible for who they were. They'd been there five minutes and those kids were already having the time of their lives.

"Hey, you as well, focus!" Dave voiced, trying to draw Rio's attention. When he realized what it was that had distracted her, he apologized. "Sorry. Just. Can you two please behave tonight?"

When Rio's gaze landed back on him, she offered an agreeable curl of her lips that she chose to couple with a nod of understanding so he was well-informed that his point had been received. She would heed it, as well, for so long as she remembered it at least.

"Alright. Now that I'm out of parent mode... Have fun tonight," Dave offered, his warm gaze settling on Rio. "It's an excuse to celebrate a new project, talent, and to just have a good time. I think you're really going to enjoy yourself."

"Thank you, Dave," Rio offered sincerely. "I think I am too."

He embraced both of them and offered light pecks to their cheeks before he departed, declaring that he would be keeping an eye on them like some well-paid babysitter. Which... That was pretty much exactly what he was.

He had been right, they had spent a bit of time socializing and while most of it had been with Jack and Thea or other familiar Landon related faces, Agatha had introduced Rio to a few new ones as well. She was trying to remember the different names and keep them matched up to the right faces, but it was turning out to be quite the task.

Before too long, they had been ushered into the theatre to find their seats. As it happened, they formed a straight line that turned out to be nothing more than pure convenience for Agatha.

-Agatha. -Rio. -Dave. -Tay. -Estee. -Hmi. -Nicky.

All in a line, perfectly splayed to enjoy the show.

And a few other things.

Rio would give it to Agatha: She lasted almost an entire hour. They had been behaving, simply holding hands with the armrest pushed up between them. And then Agatha let go of Rio's hand. Then, she placed it on her thigh in a manner that left only half of her palm resting on red fabric, the other warm on smooth skin.

Rio did everything she could to not react. It was impossibly foolish for her to have thought that even with Dave's warning, Agatha would not try to pepper in some mischief throughout the course of their night.

It was a valiant effort, but Rio controlled her breathing, even as she felt Agatha's fingers slide inward, tucking between her thighs even in spite of the fact that they were pressed together. The moment she felt them curl around the thin strip of her G-string, she knew she was in trouble. She had been focusing all of her energy on remaining as still as a statue, but it slipped the moment Agatha's touch sank lower and caused her to sharply inhale a breath.

Like lightning, Dave whipped forward and snapped his head to the side, pinning Agatha with a stare that could have sliced her clean in half, even in the darkness of the theatre.

"I will fucking kill you,"he hissed at her, leaving Rio torn between wanting to laugh or moan. Beside her, Agatha slouched in her silent tantrum, withdrawing her hand to leave it to rest on Rio's thigh, wet fingertips be damned.

Seeming to understand that he might actually be serious and not wanting to cause a scene by making Dave and Rio trade places, Agatha behaved herself the rest of the film. Well, mostly. That touch would occasionally inch closer and closer to the junction where Rio's thighs were pressed together from how her legs had crossed but never dared venture toward her body.

From the parts Rio had paid attention to, the film had actually been an enjoyable watch, though she knew she wouldn't be singing any reviews given that she didn't have enough context to be making any. Who could blame her, anyway? It was her first outing, her first chance to see what it was really like to exist among stars. It wasn't her fault that she hadn't completely absorbed and dissected the entire thing, but she would give it the attention it deserved, just at a later time.

As the credits began to roll, other occupants inside the room were getting to their feet, but by and large most people stayed planted. It was a show of respect, but for Agatha in that moment, it was so much more.

"Just wait," Agatha urged, giving Rio's hand a tight squeeze.

Rio's gaze stayed trained on the screen, watching as the different names began to appear across the screen over a colorful and textured backdrop.

And then, there it was.

ASSOCIATE PRODUCER
AGATHA HARKNESS-VIDAL

In the time it appeared across the center of the large screen, Rio read it over at least eleven times. In those eleven times, she could feel Agatha's grip growing tighter and tighter around her fingers.

She'd done it.

Agatha had shouted it to that room full of people, and to anyone else who was going to view that film, who she now was. The interview had been one thing, but this? This was Agatha's way of showing Rio who she had always been as she transformed into who she would be for the rest of her life.

"That was why he kept sending me things to look over and edit. It was a small contribution, but enough to garner a mention," Agatha informed her softly but still loud enough to be heard over the buzz of the conversations beginning to happen around them.

The image on the screen was gone physically, but Rio could still see it in her mind. She could still see that declaration to the world that things were different, that even in small ways, Agatha was different. Try as Rio might, keeping the tears out of her eyes was nearly impossible. Keeping them from falling was a little easier, at least until she turned her head to look at her wife.

"You did this for me?" Rio questioned, though it was clear she already understood the answer.

"I did it for us. All of us. We're better together, and I like that everyone can know it now too."

Rio raised a hand to palm Agatha's cheek affectionately, content that it also offered a hold so she could pull Agatha to her, kissing her softly. "I love you more than anything."

Agatha's smile wrinkled the corners of her eyes.

"I love you more thaneverything.Now, you ready for the fun part?"

Agatha had not been lying. They had relocated for the after party and for the first little portion of it, Rio had spent a fair amount of time praising Jack while withholding the information that she had not been paying attention the entire time. It was still a feat and as a friend, she was still proud of him.

After a little while, she had departed for the washroom and as Agatha started to join her, Dave's hand hooked firmly around her bicep. Rio glanced at him just in time to see his deathly serious stare lock into Agatha's as he shook his head in warning.

With a soft giggle, Rio ventured out and tended to her business before deciding to make her way back to her awaiting wife.

Only part of the way across the room, Rio heard something to her left that originated from a small gaggle of people all standing in a circle.

"What do you mean she's married?" one woman asked.

"No, but really though. Who the fuck in their right mind would marry a stone cold bitch like Agatha Harkness?" Another man's voice sounded and the arrogance there almost made Rio gag.

She should have kept walking.

She was already two drinks in, though, and was feeling a bit brave.

Rio diverted hard to her left and nearly shoved her way in between two bodies, holding a hand out to the man who had just been speaking.

"Hi! I'm Rio!" she introduced, though her facetious demeanor did not slip by anyone in the small crowd.

"Um, hi?" he returned, the confusion clear on his stupidly chiseled features. "Do I know you?"

"No! But I heard you summon me, so I thought I should introduce myself!"

Oh god. The whiskey was a little louder than it should have been.

"Err... Summon you?" another woman asked, clearly as puzzled as the man.

Rio's bright and devilish green gaze snapped to her, a wide grin showing all possible teeth.

"Yeah, you asked who would marry Agatha. And... I happened to be close enough to answer the question." She was still grinning, but it somehow grew as the color drained from several faces before her. "It's me," she added, as though she needed to clear any misconceptions. "I married her."

"Oh -- I -- It's -- We just..." the cliff faced man stammered, but Rio simply giggled.

"Do you think that maybe she's so cold because people like you do stuff like this so she just wants to batten down more?" She paused, tapping a finger to her lips in thought before continuing. "Being emotionally intelligent is such a rare commodity these days..." As she trailed, Rio stepped away and simply walked off to locate her wife once more.

Rio had barely gotten out a greeting as she slid up to Agatha's side by the time Estee was bounding up, her eyes wide and her smile shoving her cheeks up.

"Mama!" she gushed, latching onto Rio's arm. With one good look at her, it was clear to see that she was more than a little tipsy. "What did you say to them?! They looked like they'd seen a ghost when you walked away!"

Agatha's attention had been pulled by Estee's arrival, but it was most certainly at an all time high when she realized what Estee had said.

"Say to who?" Agatha questioned, seeking clarification as she looked over Rio's shoulder.

"There was some people over there," Estee divulged, waving her hand loosely behind her to indicated who she might be speaking about. "They were just talking and mama barged right into their convo and they all looked like they'd just been told the exact day and time they were gonna die." Estee's drunken giggles could only be stifled for so long, finally ripping loose the very moment she stopped speaking.

Agatha's head turned very, very slowly as she practically bored a hold in Rio's profile, wanting elaboration. Rio simply shrugged her shoulders, looking down into her drink.

"They asked who would marry you. And... as the person who did, I thought I needed to answer."

Finally, Rio dared to meet Agatha's gaze, that bright smile finding her lips once more, as if to insist it had been purely innocent.

"You're something else, my wife," was all Agatha voiced, although the look in her eyes stated that she understood and appreciated it as so much more.

After finishing another few drinks, Agatha had departed to speak with another producer and Rio had stated that she would find the kids to check on them. She had been well on her way to complete her tipsy task when a voice caught her attention.

It was a woman's voice, but it held an accent that was quite similar to her own. She recognized it as more southern, though, likely from around the New Plymouth area. Her feet halted their motions and Rio debated for just a moment on what she was going to do. She could have kept going, but there was an instant camaraderie at knowing someone else there grew from the same soil she had.

Her head turned to locate the source, finding a shorter woman that was likely around the same age Rio was. Her brown hair was notably darker than Agatha's and there was a lot less of it. She was taller than Rio by maybe an inch and those freckles told tales of long afternoons in the hot New Zealand sun.

Something about her almost felt familiar in other ways, too, but Rio wasn't able to put her finger on it.

With a deep breath, she pushed forward as the other person the woman had been talking to walked away. The woman herself had lifted her head to search for her companions, but she found Rio first, who held out a nervous hand.

"Hi, sorry," Rio offered as the woman shook her hand. With just those two words, the woman's expression lit up. "I just heard you talking and you're the first other Kiwi I've come across tonight, so I wanted to say hi. South, right? Based on the accent, I mean?"

There was a dazzling grin on the other woman's face as she emphatically nodded her head. "I was born and raised in New Plymouth. My family moved us to England for a year, but we went right back. Attended uni in Wellington, but dropped out."

"Ah, I have a daughter who just graduated. She's thinking about opening a practice here in the city as opposed to back home. I think she really likes it here."

They went on like that for several minutes, a gentle banter about home life, with Rio making sure to indicate that there was an All Blacks player wandering about the floor. That seemed to excite the other woman as much as it had excited Rio when she had first met Hmi . After a little longer, the woman's husband made an approach and apologized that he needed to steal her away.

With a small wave, Rio assured her it had been a delight speaking with her and turned to locate her own tribe, but once more Estee had been watching her like a hawk, waiting to swoop in.

"Mama! What are you doing?!" she squealed drunkenly as she slid up to Rio's side.

"I was just chatting. That woman's from New Plymouth. She was very sweet."

Estee blinked at her.

"You know who that is."

That time, it was Rio's turn to blink. Why would she know who that woman was?

"I do?" Rio asked back, befuddled when she could find no such information within the depths of her mind.

Estee cleared her throat, trying her hand at a British accent that faired pretty terrible. "'Oh, motha. I'm only here for the food!'"

Rio simply stared at her, playing it over and over again in her head, but still coming up dry.

"The nice sister from Ever After! Iknowyou've seen that one! We watched it when I was a kid!"

Oh.

Oh.

Well, this was life now, wasn't it?

Maybe Rio had only seen a handful of films in her life, but shenevercould have expected that she'd be having conversations with the people in them. And yet, there she stood, having talked to someone who's work she had known for quite some time but was a little too out of touch to have ever made the connection.

Agatha had inevitably returned moments later and for the rest of the evening, they simply enjoyed in the socializing, the laughter, and the drinks. Midnight had approached and while it had been quite the evening, Rio knew that Agatha could tell her battery was depleting and their large bed sounded like a phenomenal idea.

She had led Rio around by the hand as they said their goodbyes and approached the children who were lounging easily with several other people their age, drinking and laughing.

"We are off. Should we tell Gio you bunch are going to stay for a while?" Agatha questioned, eyes dancing over the group to see who was going to answer first.

"Yeah, maybe have him back at 2?" Nicky spoke up, a drunken grin stuck to his lips.

"Perfect. We will see you in the morning.Pleasedo not puke in the house. And if you do, clean it up."

"We will!" It sounded four times at once in various voices that were all undeniably intoxicated.

Bidding them all their love, Rio and Agatha made their way to the awaiting car and an amused Gio who seemed tickled by their stumbling.

"Do we need food before I deliver you home?" he offered as he held the door open for them.

"I really want chips and guacamole from Del Taco," Rio informed both of them in a giggle.

Agatha's eyes cast up and met Gio's as she offered a nod to indicate that was where she would like him to go. He shut the door behind her and made his way to the driver's seat, setting off on their journey.

"That was fun," Rio announced decisively. She was quiet for a moment before her eyes lifted to Agatha's profile in the shadows of the car. "I did okay, right?" she asked, though her voice had dropped considerably.

Agatha turned to face her, cradling her jaw in an instant. "You did more than okay, my love. You were incredible."

To Rio's drunken brain, such a statement was high praise considering who it was coming from. She still felt the need to tack something on.

"I just wanted to make you proud," she told Agatha in earnest, her eyes soft.

"Rio," Agatha whispered in admonishment. She leaned forward, placing their lips together in a tender kiss before she pulled back, beholding the woman she loved. "I will always be proud of you."

Agatha paused, her lips twisting up into a small smirk.

"Plus, I'mrealproud of you when you look like that."

"Oh, is that so?"Rio mused back, her own mouth hitching up at the corners.

"It is. Maybe you'll let me show you just how proud when we get home."

A flicker of a flame whipped across Rio's gaze, her grin turning from delighted to daring.

"I'd be disappointed if you didn't."

Chapter End Notes

Can We Stay a While?

All seems too clear
Let it wash over me
Don't disappear
Visions are hyperreal
*****

The night before, mid-July, when Rio had fallen asleep, she had not given much thought to the following day. She should have. It was a big day, an important day. Well, it was to anyone who wasn't Rio.

For Rio, it was just another day.

To everyone else, it was the day, forty years earlier, she happened into existence and began a journey that landed her in the big house in Malibu that she shared with her wife, curled up and warm in their massive bed. It was the day that a light sparked into the universe and illuminated their lives the very moment they came into contact with it.

It was Rio's 40th birthday.

With how she had been choosing to not acknowledging it, everyone had been following suit. For some strange reason, it did not strike Rio as suspicious, though it should have. She knew her daughter and she knew that birthdays were important to her. More than that, it was Rio's first birthday with Agatha and as such, it was also her first with an actual family.

It had probably been a little too foolish to think she would get by with treating it as any other day, wanting to sleep in a little after Agatha went to work. She figured she would drag herself out of bed, making some coffee, and wind up with her legs in the pool on a tame and cool morning while she waited for everyone else to rouse.

If all else failed, Rio was almost certain that another first, their initial trip to Disneyland as a family -- and consequently, Estee proposing to Tay (and Tay returning the favor, but Rio was theonlyone who knew about that) -- the following day would be enough of a distraction to keep the focus off of her.

It wasn't that Rio didn't want to be celebrated, it was simply that she thought it was shown enough every other day of the year that she didn't need extra helpings to feel any more valued or treasured.

Rio knew what she was to her family. She had every single day since she'd had them as a whole.

Being woken up to being completely dogpiled by four other people was a nice reminder, though.

"HAPPY BIRTHDAY!!!!"

It was first a harmony and then a chorus as the sentiment got repeated again and again. Despite the crushing weight, Rio was instantaneously aware of every single spot that Agatha's lips pressed to her face, kissing her with delighted fervor on a day of celebration.

"You... guys... crushing... me... can't... breathe,"Rio choked out, trying to wriggle beneath them to no avail.

The giggles and laughter that filled her ears the moment Agatha's lips pressed to hers made Rio wonder for just a moment if she were still actually alive. There was only one reason she even thought to question it.

This feels like heaven.

A year ago, Rio had woken up on her houseboat to the smell of fresh bread and homemade jam prepared by her daughter. They had cuddled on the couch and spent the day watching documentaries before going out for a nice meal.

This year, Rio's day had not even started and she was already being smothered with quadruple the love and affection than her life had ever been capable of providing before.

While Rio had been under the innocently quaint misconception that no plans needed to be made and nothing truly needed to be celebrated, her entire family had been of the complete opposite opinion.

"Happy birthday, my beautiful wife,"Agatha gushed, this time placing a kiss to Rio's lips as everyone else began to ease their weight from her form.

"Mmmm. Thank you. I am not sure what would have been a better gift, this or sleeping in,"Rio murmured playfully. Her head picked up so that she could take her own kiss from Agatha, her second in a long line of birthday kisses she would surely garner.

"Getting up after being loved on, of course!" Estee informed her from her spot near the foot of the bed.

"And why would I want to do that when I could forget that I'm forty by laying in bed and eating pickles and cheese like a true grown adult?" Rio returned, sinking down a little further into the mattress as her eyes slid shut again.

"Because I got us all tickets to Knott's to celebrate. Then we've already placed the order for Nobu to bring home when we're done!" Nicky announced proudly. The one thing he left out was that Hemi would be meeting them at the amusement park, and he had come bearing gifts.

"Don't you all have jobs to tend to or like, plans for them or something?" Rio questioned with a giggle as her arms finally raised to wrap snugly around her wife. Agatha had made the choice to not move from her place half atop Rio's body and for that, Rio was thankful.

"Not today!" Estee and Tay chirped in unison. "Besides, Cole's just waiting for the other therapist's contract to be up and she said the office is as good as mine."

"And I pretty much make my own schedule," Nicky voiced, as though he needed to remind them.

Agatha's head dropped, resting against the front of Rio's shoulder so that she could press her face into her warm neck. "AndImade sure months ago to tell Dave that nothing got put on the schedule today for this reason."

Rio was laughing before Agatha even stopped speaking, shaking her head against the pillow with her tickled giggles.

"You are all literally insane," Rio informed them, though she was still holding onto Agatha like she was the best birthday gift Rio could have ever gotten. "It's just another day! It's not a big deal!" She was clearly floundering under all of the focused attention, but the smile on her face clearly communicated that it truly felt wonderful to be woken up by the majority of her loved ones as they ached to celebrate her spending another year upon the earth.

"Itisa big deal," Agatha informed her, like arguing such a point was idiotic. "Out of the four people in this room, four of us have one favorite person who was born on this day forty years ago. Majority rules. We win." Agatha picked her head up and sank heavier against Rio's form as she peppered kisses to Rio's face in a sprightly manner.

"You lot are excessive," Rio managed through the laughter that did not desist because Agatha had not stopped kissing at her face.

"Of course we are. Look at the two of you," Estee shot before she clapped her hands together in front of her. "Up! Out of bed! There's donuts and coffee downstairs and roller coasters are calling our names!"

For the few seconds it took for the three children to disperse and for Agatha to slump off of Rio's torso to her side, Rio could feel a smooth and calming wave of love and appreciation wash over her.

For forty years, even in spite of Estee's rambunctious desire to celebrate, her birthday had just been another day for Rio.

This year, it felt like a little more.

It felt like the first birthday of an entirely new life.

That, she thought, was a little more worthy of celebration.

With as much gusto as she could muster, and with the help of her too-sweet wife and the fuel of her encouraging kisses, Rio peeled herself out of bed and prepared for the day. They took a quick shower, giggled their way through brushing their teeth, and held soft and praising conversation -- coming from Agatha's end, obviously -- while they put on light makeup and dressed for their day of fun.

Rio was coming to realize something very dangerous; the way Agatha kept talking to her, her voice such a smooth hum of adoration, and telling her that she was the most beautiful, that she was a blessing they got for another year, that age only looked better on her, she was going to need a change of underwear by noon.

No, she argued back against that pathetic little voice, she was a grown woman and could handle herself for a morning and afternoon out with her family.

Maybe.

Probably.

Hopefully.

Putting it to the test was the only way to find out and so, once dressed, the five of them convened by the front door before departing. Gio greeted them in the early morning sun with a bright grin on his handsome face as he gifted Rio aHappy Birthday, ma'amwhen he held the door for her.

In their totality, they were buzzing. It was a weekday late morning and they were going to spend their entire day just havingfun.It was a time to be together, to laugh and make more memories to add to the infinite list. When they pulled into the lot and climbed out, Rio's eye caught a dark haired man leaning against a very shiny Escalade. The daring grin he wore was a direct contrast to the dark shades on his face as he pushed off the car.

"Hemi!" Rio greeted, nearly stumbling over herself to get to him. "I didn't know you were here! No one tells me anything!" Her embrace was strong as she held him close, thanking him softly before she released him with a bright smile on her lips.

She just felt so loved.

And that was before Hemi opened the back hatch of the vehicle and reached inside, pulling out something black and covered in several spots with illegible white markings. He picked the top item off and handed it to Rio with his eyes wrinkled at the corners from his grin.

"Happy birthday, mama," he told her softly.

She took the item from him, opening it up more to truly get a good look at it. She was staring at the front side of an All Blacks kit; she was torn between giggling and crying.

"Turn it around," he urged.

Rio's shimmering gaze flickered to him in question for a fleeting moment, her brow pinching slightly at the beaming he was still doing. She did as she was told, though, turning the kit around in her hands.

There, above her lucky number 23, were bright white letters stitched into the black fabric.

HARKNESS-VIDAL

Rio didn't want to cry. She didn't want to spend her entire day as a sap who couldn't wrangle the emotions caused by being loved so wholly and treasured so infinitely. "You had this made for me?" she questioned, looking over the shoulder hem to meet his gaze.

As it turned out, forty wasn't so terrible.

Granted, Rio was only two days into it, but something about it felt like an entirely newfound freedom that she had not ever really thought she'd needed.

There were things about it that were different for the first time in forty years. There was the fact that it was her first birthday since she was six that she had not spent in New Zealand. It was the first year it had not just been Rio and Estee and a small little cake split between them. It was the first time Rio had someone to spend itwith.In fact, she had five other someones to spend it with.

Amassing all of those things, walking into another year of life felt more like swinging into it while sitting in a tire that dangled from the tallest Redwood. It was youthful freedom in a way that had been so unexpected. Forty didn't feel like forty.

Forty felt like the first year of Rio's new life.

Forty felt like a rebirth.

There was a newfound sense of lightness that had blossomed within her and it had not gone unnoticed. She had started singing again, something that had slipped from her subconscious for too many months to count. That morning, Rio was in the kitchen making them breakfast before Agatha left for work when she felt strong arms snake and fasten around her middle. Her rendition of The Ocean by Tegan and Sara was stopped short by her startled squeal, though it took her little time to melt right into Agatha's hold.

Occasional distance was healthy, and while it was going to be difficult to be away from her family, Rio was aware that there was justifiable reasoning to it.

The water had been cool, the birds had been vocal, and there was a sense of serenity that had fallen over the back area of the house that Rio reveled in. With everyone constantly coming and going, Rio almost always assumed the house was empty unless obvious, so when she surfaced at the edge of the pool and saw twenty pedicured toes, she gasped, her eyes lifting to see her daughters grinning down at her, still in their pajamas.

"Lazy day today, then?" Rio posed, slicking her wet hair back and wiping the excess water from her face.

"Yes," Estee answered simply with a shrug, her hand picking up Tay's out of nothing more than habit. "But Gio's going to take us to In-N-Out and we wanted to see if you'd like to join us."
