Dinner, as Rio had been so certain it would be, had been phenomenal. Geoffrey's was never a disappointment, and watching the waves roll in as they ate, crashing softly in the distance, only added to the ambiance. They talked, they laughed, they clinked their glasses more than a few times as they indulged in the fine wines.

In the times those lower conversations befell them, the top of Rio's foot would find the side of Agatha's calf, caressing it in the smallest strokes while she attentively held active conversation. Agatha seemed to be the one faltering there more often than not.

Despite just how close to the beach their home was, the waited had divulged something toward the end of their meal. His eyes had cast toward the water, shimmering in the moonlight.

"You can't see it that well from up here," he indicated, "but another customer said that there's a bioluminescent bloom tonight. They're hard to predict, so if you've never seen one, you should."

Rio knew exactly what that was, and what it meant when he said they were difficult to track and understand. Her wide eyes turned to Agatha, giddy with excitement. She'd seen many before, but never in California. It felt special and perhaps even a little poetic that on an occasion they'd indulged in a pricey plate for absolutely no reason, it was also providing a special experience that Rio could only have for the first time once.

When she had started to ask as he had walked away, Agatha hadn't let her get out a word edgewise before offering her answer.

"Of course we can."

In the darkness of a night, their feet in the water, Rio had been filled with a sense of sheer elation to be watching the blues and greens as they lit up the waters that lapped at their calves. It might have seemed childish, but Rio had spent so, so many years on Auckland beaches doing this exact thing. Sometimes she was alone, something Estee was there to indulge in the glee as well.

Now, Rio stood on the west coast of America with her hand snugly grasped in her wife's as they experienced it together.

That, Rio thought, was what life looked like. Progress. Experience. Jubilation.

By the time they had arrived home, the wine had induced an unparalleled tiredness that felt hard to fight. After a brief internal debate, Rio had put on a pot of coffee and returned for a cup after she had changed. Per Agatha's request, she'd fixed her one too and arrived back in the bedroom to settle in.

In an attempt to keep herself awake, Rio had cracked open a book -- another Jodi Picoult piece, Vanishing Acts -- and put on her glasses to read.

Some part of her had fully intended on reading.

The other part of her knew what was going to happen the moment she slid those frames onto her face.

Agatha had tried to act like she didn't notice, but Rio saw her look over a couple of times in an almost imperceptible manner before she would turn her attention back to the cooking show she had put on. And then, about five minutes later, her hand landed on Rio's thigh.

That was all it had taken before hands were flying and mouths were meshing, tongues pressing and tasting and devouring.

As she often did, Agatha made Rio keep her glasses on. It was amusing and yet, still somehow sweet despite the tinge of absurdity it seemed to hold. Rio met the request every single time, knowing that if it gave Agatha that extra little push to be that much more obsessed? Who was Rio to stop her?

At one point, they had actually fallen off. Rio wasn't quite sure when, but by the time they were sprawled out on the bed, thoroughly spent and pleasured, her face was bare and smushed against the front of Agatha's shoulder. The panting had lasted several minutes, but recovery crept into their forms eventually.

"Mm, what time is it?"Rio murmured, her speech morphed only slightly by the placement of her face.

Agatha's arm flopped out, fingers gracing the edge of the nightstand, but not reaching quite far enough to grab her phone. When she shifted, it drew a rather pathetic sounding whine from Rio who clung a little tighter to prevent any occurrence of distance.

"One-twelve,"Agatha whispered back. She dropped the phone onto the bed beside her and settled back into place, pulling Rio a little closer to her form."Fuck, we have to be up at seven."

For what felt like the millionth time since she had woken up that morning, the gift of laughter settled in Rio once again. It was a quiet sound, hushed as it rolled from her lips and over the skin of Agatha's chest.

"We're going to need something stronger than coffee. If I miss the shock on Tay's face, I'm going to be so mad,"came Agatha's tired insistence.

Rio adjusted slightly, hooking her leg over Agatha's so that her body could overlap a little more, reveling in the warmth and safety she found there.

"You focus on Tay for me, hm?"Rio posed, though she hadn't stopped to think about what she was implying. When Agatha shifted slightly and then asked her question, Rio knew that she had completely fucked up. Well, with less than twelve hours to go, was telling her wife of all people the worst thing?

But she'dpromisedTay she wouldn't say anything.

Maybe Agatha wouldn't press. Maybe she wasn't paying enough attention to understand the implications there.

That was foolish; even completely worn out from their physical activity, Agatha wasalwayspaying attention.

"And where will you be paying your attention?"she asked lowly, pressing a couple of fingers tauntingly between Rio's ribs.

"Oh, I just meant --"Rio tried to recover, but she knew it was unlikely Agatha would buy any excuse she had to offer.

"What did you just mean, my love?"

Tucking her lower lip between her teeth, Rio quickly came to the conclusion that there was no point in trying to keep the secret any longer, at least not from Agatha of all people. She had done a remarkable job to that point, keeping it as far away from her consciousness as possible, but the jig was up and there was no reason to hold out anymore.

A resigned sigh passed through Rio's lips, a hand raising to trace light circles on Agatha's chest."I just meant that Tay is proposing, too. So someone's gotta watch Estee."

The news landed and the roots planted in Agatha's mind, sinking deeper and deeper until they struck her comprehension.

"No fucking way,"she breathed back in her disbelief. Her hand slid up Rio's back, touching her neck with a soft gracing of fingertips that requested attention. It took Rio a few long seconds to make the decision to meet it. When she did, the disbelief written on Agatha's features, even in the dark, something softened in Rio."Double proposal?"

Rio nodded her head, though it was still like a dead weight as it rested just inches away from Agatha's heart."Double proposal. But youhaveto act normal!"Rio's insistence was accompanied by a light tap of two fingers to Agatha's chest in the most gently threatening gesture.

"I always act normal,"Agatha offered back, feigning offense as she lifted a hand to poke Rio's cheek in jest.

"Yeah, oh-kay,"Rio shot, rolling her eyes. She scooted herself up enough to grace Agatha's lips with her own."We should sleep, my love."

"Double fucking proposal. Goddamn,"Agatha breathed with a grin before puckering her lips one more time in demand. When Rio kissed her again, her eyes closed and when Rio settled back into her side, they did not open again.

"Love is quite wonderful, hm?"Rio whispered into the night. Her hand had landed in the center of Agatha's chest, right above her heart.

She could hear the soft huff of agreement above her as it slipped from Agatha's nose. Before she returned her hushed answer, her fingers began to trace the gentlest lines up and down Rio's bare back.

"It is. It's why we're here, isn't it?"

For every negative opinion that existed in the world about Agatha, Rio knew the truth.

Agatha was an incredible person, not just for her talents and her abilities. No, Agatha's heart was unlike any other Rio had ever come across, even outside of a romantic context. Agathadidcare, she just didn't always show it the way people thought she should.

When had Agatha done anything other people thought she should in the last decade?

"And always will be,"Rio murmured softly, words slurring minutely as the exhaustion began to win its battle to take her offer."Sleep now. I love you."

"I love you too, baby."

*****

The first time Agatha started to grumble about being tired, Rio had immediately pressed her finger to Agatha's lips and urged her to finish her coffee by the time they got to the park. Agatha had tried to look annoyed, but she knew that Rio was right.

She also knew that the reason for such tiredness had been entirely worth it. Rio didn't need to point that out vocally, though. Especially not in front of the kids who had all met them in the kitchen to prepare for the day ahead of them. For Rio, cradling her black coffee in her hands, it was a compelling feeling to see the excitement and invigoration running through the kids.

Nicky had been to Disneyland before, of course, but the other three had not and so, it had been an ongoing promise from Nicky that it was going to be magical.

Every time he did it, Rio's attention would snap to the girls, seeing if either of them might offer any give, but neither did. They stayed composed, masked, ready to take on a day that was sure to change their lives moving forward.

Rio had her own ideas; she knew that they both wanted that commitment, but there was something else that had struck Rio: Maybe they wanted a family a little sooner than Rio had anticipated. It wasn't an overt display, but the smallest comments that got dropped that piqued her interest and helped her to form such an opinion.

Her girls just wanted to truly start living life.

She was well aware that when the time came for the important conversations to be had, Estee would sit her down and have them. Until then, Rio had to sometimes remind herself that her little girl wasn't quite so little anymore and she was making very adult choices that she thought were going to better her life. Rio would always respect that.

Loading into the massive SUV was always comical, but that morning it had garnered an extra laugh when Gio shook his head with a soft chuckle.

"Respectfully, ma'ams, you can't pick up any strays or we're going to have to upgrade to a limo."

Rio's grin had been so instant and so wide that she considered for a moment that her face held the capability of cracking from it.

"Might have to do that, anyway! Thanks for the idea, Gio. You're always a genius," Agatha offered as she climbed into the back of the vehicle.

For as excited as the kids were, when they had arrived at the park, Rio had immediately felt an easily established sense of wonder. While Estee never passed up an opportunity to make a dig about how little media Rio had consumed before meeting Agatha, Disney films had been universal, including in their world.

Seeing the different attractions, watching as the kids indulged in the rides, eating lunch as a family through laughter and shenanigans were some of the things that had filled the first part of their day, and the fun felt endless.

Everyone, surprisingly, had been keeping their cool. There were two people --Hmi and Nicky -- who were eager and ready for Estee to propose. Then, there were the other two -- Agatha and Rio herself -- that knew the intensity of what was going to occur. And then, there were the girls who had no idea that they were of the same mind and were likely only going to find another way to fall further into love with one another.

After lunch, they'd continued about the park until they had reached Snow White's Grotto.

And then, the wishing well.

Estee was ready; she'd tucked two quarters in the same pocket that held the little red velvet box. Rio pulled Agatha to the side by the hand, shuffling close enough to be within earshot.

"We should make a wish," Estee told Tay, handing the coin over with a bright smile. Rio could see from their vantage point as the flicker of recognition danced across Tay's gaze. To her, this was innocent and without intention and it was an opening she could use to further her agenda. And that agenda was to ask Estee to be her wife.

"We should," Tay agreed, thanking her softly as she took the coin. "Same time?" she asked, holding the coin up. It was locked and loaded, ready to be flipped into the well.

"Same time," Estee agreed with a nod. "One... Two... Three!"

Concurrently, both girls flipped the coins into the well with the softest clinks of keratin fingernails striking silver. They both watched for a moment before they leaned back and looked at one another.

Rio's hand found Agatha's and locked it into a vice grip, not certain who was going to break first.

It was Tay.

"I know you're not supposed to tell what you wished for..." she said, turning to face Estee as she picked up her hand. On her opposite side, she was reaching into her pocket. "But I think if I do, it's not going to ruin my chances of it coming true."

Rio had caught the way Estee's free hand had come to rest in her pocket, not leaving even as she turned to face her girlfriend a little more. Agatha bumped into her, scooting her over so they wouldn't miss anything.

When Tay pulled the box from her pocket, she dropped to one knee and held it up, the hinged lid open and revealing the three pronged solitaire diamond ring inside. The band was thin and it was a lone stone, but it was a decent size. It wasn't flashy or bougie. It was... so very Estee.

"I wished that you'd love me just enough to agree to be my wife," Tay informed her. "So do you think you might help it come true?"

Rio was locked on Estee, watching her realize that her perfectly crafted plan had completely fallen to shambles in the most beautiful way. Her hand did not fly to her mouth, she did not gasp or squeal or cry. Hell, she didn't even vocalize an answer. All Estee did was remove her hand from her pocket, holding the ring box out for Taylah to see.

"Only if you'd return the favor," Estee told her softly.

It was in that moment that four pairs of eyes glassed over and the true elation of what was unfolding started to sink in. Even the boys looked a little verklempt at the turn of events they hadnotbeen expecting. They'd anticipated Estee knocking this out of the park, not a clue to be had that Tay had secretly been making her own moves.

"The only thing I'd love more than that is you," Tay answered, getting to her feet. The moment she was planted, she pulled Estee to her, offering a kiss that Estee returned with ease. It was a beautiful gesture, a showing of how much they loved one another. It was a decades long love, and it was one that would continue to span throughout time.

The whoops and hollers were intended to be embarrassing as they left the four others, but Rio realized that neither of the girls heard them. Neither of the girls heard anything other than the silent conversation they were having with their foreheads pressed together and their lips a breath apart.

With another gentle brushing of lips, they separated from one another but only to tend to the important part. They both grinned instantly as Estee was the first one to pluck the ring -- which Rio had known was a platinum round cut with a jewel encrusted band -- so that she could slide it onto Tay's finger.

Only a moment passed before Tay returned the favor, sliding that gorgeous tear drop diamond onto Estee's ring finger.

The way they each clutched empty boxes in one hand and raised the other to palm the opposing cheek before their lips met in a kiss filled with nothing but love and adoration caused Rio to melt.

This was all she had ever wanted for Estee.

Rio had spent eighteen years of Estee's life doing anything and everything she could to provide for her, to take care of her and remind her every second of every day that she was loved so wholly and so relentlessly. Estee had been Rio's entire world, and she still was, but she had become Tay's world, too.

Their love had always been obvious, even if it had shifted in context and now, they were looking at building a life together. Their careers were being planted to grow and thrive with time and so now was their future as a couple, too.

The moment seemed to stretch on, even though their kisses tapered off and they were simply left basking in the reality of what had happened, and the new weight of the rocks on their fingers. When their heads finally lifted to take in the sight of Rio and Agatha, only one of them was crying and it was very obviously Rio. With the eye contact, she got her permission and let go of Agatha's hand to surge forward and wrap them both in her arms.

"I knew this day was inevitable,"Rio murmured at them both, holding them close,"but it was far more magical than I'd ever thought it could be."

*****

The six of them had reveled in the joy and excitement the double engagement had brought with a crowd around them offering their soft congratulations as they passed by. It was sweet, really, and heartwarming in a way that Rio hardly knew how to explain. It was watching the inevitable finally fall into place, propelling their lives forward in new ways.

While Rio was not of forward enough mind to be thinking about wedding planning and things of that nature, Agatha was already buzzing, waiting for the first chance she got to give the girls anything they wanted and more. She felt them to be deserving of all the best in the world, and she started proving it the moment they left the park, each and every one of them donning an almost painful grin.

Gio, per Agatha's quiet instruction, had taken them to Fleming's Steakhouse for a celebratory dinner. The alcohol was pouring and the children were happily indulging, but Rio's only drink for the evening was her solitary celebratory glass of champagne that Agatha had used to toast.

She stood beside Rio and held her own glass up, her eyes falling to Estee and Tay who were so close they were practically on top of each other, grinning like the sweet and in-love drunkenly adorable idiots they were.

"I knew this day was coming, I just wasn't sure when," Agatha announced, watching them tenderly. Rio was right beside her, that softness filling her features as she beheld two of the five people she loved most in the world. "But that day, the first day, that I met you both... I knew. And watching the both of you, from an outsider's perspective, has been the most thrilling delight. You both grow and learn and build every single day so that you may have a life you both want and crave. You have a tenacity woven into the fabric of your relationship that is truly remarkable and inspiring."

Agatha glanced down to Rio who looked back up at her, the emotionally moved tears brimming her lids as she smiled through the squeezing in her chest. Her head lifted again, finding herself basking in the love that radiated from the younger couple.

"So here is to you, Estrella and Taylah, and the many years of love and marriage ahead of you."

There was something in Rio that was thankful that Agatha was the one to take the helm on such a toast; Rio was not as certain in her ability to be so articulate in the face of such emotion. More than that, it was a pure and honest showing that for Agatha, they were her girls, too, and seeing this happen for them was just as special for her as it was for Rio.

Seeing that in her wife formed a new sense of reverence that Rio felt was a little to complex to fit into any vernacular.

"I'll cheers to that!" Rio offered, standing to offer her glass as well. Everyone was up and on their feet around the circular table between them, holding their glasses up, grins matching and light laughter swirling and mixing around them before the crisp clinks of glasses folded right in.

They had all settled and continued on with the evening, but Rio had not missed the way Agatha had spent a considerable amount of time on her phone, even if she had not been able to catch sight of what was on the screen. It didn't matter, Agatha told them anyway when she was finished and set her phone back on the table.

"You two have a suite at the Grand Californian Hotel and Spa, which happens to have park access. So... Stay there the next two nights and go to the park again tomorrow just the two of you, my congratulatory gift." Even though the gesture was soft, Agatha was trying to speak of it like a business transaction despite there clearly being so much more weight there.

Rio knew the truth. Agatha was trying not to cry.

That became a little easier when Nicky spoke.

"So we get a room at the Ritz?" he questioned, dissolving everyone into tipsy laughter.

"You have an entirely separate house to yourselves," Agatha returned, as if he needed a reminder. "You want a night at the Ritz, you've got a credit card."

It was a similar conversation to one they'd had earlier that week, but the playfulness glimmered in Agatha's eyes. Nicky took it for what it was.

"Yeah, but I'd be too cheap and get a room at a Motel 6, so pool house it is."

More laughter, more eye rolling, more gentle nudges and playful pushes.

With their dinner coming to a close, there was something that struck Rio as they climbed into the back of the car to drop the girls off at the resort before heading home.

She needed to stop having limits; too many times had she marked a moment in her life as being the best it was ever going to get.

That was never going to stop happening.

Life was only ever going to get better, no matter the dips that might come.

Together, the family they had become, life would never stop in its ability to be more astounding the next day than the one before it.

It was a life Rio could never show enough gratitude for and she knew it.

Infinity Pools

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

I'm swimming in your eyes, floating out of time
And I can't get out
You're like a sunbeam that lights my fever dream
*****

The time had come.

Rio had known it was coming. Agatha had known it was coming. Hell, even the kids had all known it was coming and yet, no one had truly been ready.

In the grand scheme of things, spending a week away from home should not have been a big deal. Taking into account that it was the longest amount of time Rio and Agatha had spent time apart since Rio had landed in LA after their first meeting, it sort of made it a big deal. Rio could try to tell herself it wasn't all she wanted, but it was.

Everyone else knew it, especially Nicky.

It had been the night before when he had pulled her aside to the large lounger on the back patio, holding her by the hand before he tucked something inside of her palm.

"What is this?" Rio asked him softly, looking over to him with a confused expression before she even dared to look at what he was giving her. It was small and it was cold, flagging a couple of possibilities in her mind.

"I think you should cancel your hotel reservation in Dubai," he said softly, looking at her directly without any hesitation. She started to ask, lips parting to pose the question 'Why?' but he was speaking before she could get it out. "Because I still have six months left on the lease of the apartment I have there. And... I know it's going to be hard to not be here. So, don't make it worse by being somewhere strange."

The gentlest smile curled Rio's lips as she tilted her head at him, finally dropping her gaze to glance at the key in her palm. He was so sweet, and she wassotouched that she fought to cover it up with sarcasm.

"Youare strange, so I assume your apartment would be, too," Rio teased him, bumping him lightly with the broad part of her shoulder. "I'm kidding. But, Nicholas..." she trailed, looking back up to him with glassy eyes, still battling just how moved she was. "You don't have to do this. I don't want to encroach on your space. It's still yours, after all."

"Mama, stop," he chastised softly, moving to close her fingers over the key. "I know what you're doing, but it won't work. Just... do it, okay? I know it's not much, but it's a little piece of me that you can hold onto. It might make it a little easier to hold onto everyone else while you're away, too."

Damn it if he didn't have some sage wisdom for being only twenty.

Almost twenty-one, he would remind her if she mentioned it out loud.

"It makes me glad I kept it, honestly. It was my home away from home. For these few days, it can be yours, too."

Rio reached around, snagging him gently by the back of his head as she placed her lips to his hair. There had been times when Rio had really questioned her role in his life and what it would actually mean to fill another parental figure for him, but she could see so very clearly that she had done it without even trying. She had done it by welcoming him into the lives of her and her daughter, by wanting to do right by him, and even going so far as to lethimoccupyherspace when she was not there.

The houseboat had been a lifeline for him when he had been trying to work out the tough truths of his reality. Now, he was offering Rio the same in return when she needed to tend to business.

Four days wasn't a long time, but that was only four days in Dubai. She had two more following in New York. At least those two days Agatha voiced the possibility that she might be able to join. It had been briefly discussed the evening before Rio's departure, but they had capped the conversation with Agatha promising to have Dave look into her schedule and book flights and a hotel if she could make it.

And then, she had followed it up with another declaration.

"Okay, that's a lie. I don't care what my schedule looks like. He will book them. And then, I will message you with the hotel information and we can go from there." Ah, that authoritative side of her that seemed to shine when Agatha knew what she wanted. How beautiful it was.

Agatha was acting tough, she was playing it off like this was not at all going to bother her, but Rio caught her glancing at the suitcases by the wall, or the outfit Rio had already picked out to dress herself in at 4am before Gio shuttled her to the airport. She would hesitate on them, like she was considering the idea of just asking to tag along, but she never did.

Not once did Agatha insist she needed to be there.

Rio knew she wanted to, and desperately, but she never let the request meet the air.

For as much as neither of them wanted to have an ocean between them again, especially after the way the last ten months had gone, they both knew it was something that had to happen. They were not exactly harmful in their codependency, but they both understood it was not the healthiest. Rio was convinced that she had it worse, and Agatha let her believe that; it was easier for both of them when Rio was the one to cave first.

Agatha was still the fiercely independent woman she had always been, but not having the physical show of Rio's comfort wasn't the easiest thing in the world. She would puff her chest, hold her head high and soldier on, but that didn't mean it wouldn't grace her at all.

Luckily, Agatha had something on her side that Rio knew for certain to be entirely foolproof when it came to holding it all together: Agatha had the kids.

With Nicky's blessing, Rio had a little bit of them, too.

As it turned out, that was actually a lot more helpful that Rio had considered it might be.

After eighteen hours of planes and airports, Rio provided the address to Nicky's apartment to the rideshare driver and poured into the back seat, completely spent and exhausted. Thankfully, by the time she got up to his floor and let herself into the apartment, she had a few minutes to decompress before she was certainsomeoneif not a few someones were going to give her a call.

That was the only logical response to the text she had sent Agatha to let her know she had landed, realizing it was just before noon on a Sunday in Los Angeles despite being pitch black at ten at night on the other side of the world.

As she predicted, Rio's phone began to ring not two minutes after she plopped down and sprawled out across the plus sofa in Nicky's living room, her bags left forgotten by the door.

"Hello there, beautiful," Rio greeted with a grin as Agatha's face filled the screen.

"Conversation over! Your mama is on the phone!" Agatha called over her shoulder before glancing back to her phone, a bright grin on her face. "Hi, my traveler," she offered in return, her head tipping to the side. "You look tired."

"Because I definitely am," Rio responded through a yawn, her body wanting to make a point despite her best efforts. "But there was no way I was going to be able to sleep without saying good night -- Er, good afternoon -- first."

"Well, I knowIappreciate it, and I'm sure --"

Rio had been able to hear the rumblings of an argument happening behind Agatha -- one that sounded like it was being had between Nicky and Estee -- but finally, Estee's voice reached a volume that drowned Agatha out.

"Stop harassing her about her grey hairs, Nicholas! She is a refined older woman!"

Rio didn't even ask. She didn't have time. Instead, all she could do was burst into laughter.

"Another relaxing day by the pool then, hm?" Rio asked through her laughter, bringing a hand up to try and stifle some of it. It made her miss the lot of them, but seeing that their silly children were keeping Agatha busy (if not on her toes) was a small consolation that came in the form of comfort. For as much as she was already missing them, just hearing their voices and seeing Agatha herself made it sting a little less.

They were back home, just waiting for her to return. On the other side of business meetings and discussing contracts and bids, she would head back to America. At least there, she would have Agatha in her general vicinity, even if it was two more days of bartering and laying down boundaries of what her drones could and could not be used for.

"I try to get them outside to expend some energy and they do it in the form of bickering," Agatha pretended to grumble, shooting them a glance. Rio definitely caught the soft snickers in the background in response, their children full of mischief.

"Yes, well," Rio supplied, cocking a brow. "If I may submit the wife's two cents... I like the gray. More of the gray. But... Again, just the opinion of the woman you married." Her grin was instant at the delight in Agatha's infinitely blue eyes, shimmering and soft.

"I like it when you remind me of how smart I am," came a soft admittance, though it ran impossible deep for how quiet it was.

Agathameantthat. Rio could see it, she could hear it.

If you asked Agatha what the smartest thing she'd ever done in her life to that point was?

Rio didn'thaveto ask to know she would say it was getting married, the two of them.

Some could have called it cocky, but looking at the life they had since built in ten months -- their homes, their marriage, their children -- Rio knew it was true. She was only certain because she felt the same way.

Rio had assuredly made a lot of stupid decisions in her life, as well as some really intelligent ones, but the act of committing herself to a life of love with Agatha and their family had easily been the most no-brainer choice Rio had ever made. For someone that had previously been convinced that love was a farce, she knew the life she had was only possible because of it.

The moment she'd laid eyes on Agatha up close for the first time, Rio had been resigned to the idea of love at first sight, even if she had hated herself for it at the time.

Now, thousands of hours since and thousands of miles away, she could not have been more thankful.

"Yes, well, you make it easy. And," she added, her eyes narrowing with the width of her smile, "you'resosmart you know when it's best to listen to me."

Agatha's smile was warm, it was captivating, and it made Rio wish for nothing more than to be right next to her, to be in on the conversation where Nicky was apparently giving his mother a hard time over growing old.

For Rio, it wasn't a punchline or the response to a joke. For Rio, the idea of Agatha growing old thrilled her, because Rio would do the same right beside her until one of them landed on death's doorstep first. For Rio, it was watching Agatha grow and change and evolve and it was a pleasure to bear witness to.

"Dully noted," Agatha offered with a light chuckle, rolling her eyes.

Rio hadn't wanted to bring down the mood at all, but her statement found the airwaves before she could consider choking it back.

"I miss you guys already," she said and while her sadness was apparent, she tried not to sound so completely destitute over such a truth.

"We miss you too, mama!" Estee called from behind Agatha, making sure that her own feelings on the sentiment were known.

"We do," Agatha added, as if she'd needed to in order to be convincing. "But it's late there and you should try to get some sleep. You have a big few days ahead of you."

Agatha was right. Riodidneed to sleep if she had any hope of holding her own in the meetings she had set. The first one with her lawyer would help with that, but the two that followed were sure to be long and grueling. While she was skating about Dubai and bartering her way to a deal on the technology she developed, her family would be tucked in their beds and sound asleep, dreaming of her return.

Well, at least Agatha would be.

Estee and Tay were probably glad for the breathing room, even if it seemed like they had hardly let Agatha out of their sights since the day before when Rio had departed. Nicky, the little rascal he could be, was probably filling his time with Hemi, no matter which continent he was on and that was perfectly fine. The busier he kept himself, the better, of that Rio was certain. It also appeared as though Estee was more than happy to lend a nagging word to distract him, which would likely prove to be a saving grace for Agatha.

"Hey, wait!" came Nicky's call. Agatha's head turned to catch an understanding, but Nicky was already up and on his feet, swiping Agatha's phone right out of her hand as he paced across the room, his voice dropping as he made eye contact with Rio on the screen.

"There's..." he glanced over her shoulder, most likely at the three women who were looking at him as if he had lost his mind, but then turned his focus back to Rio, whispering. "There's a little sloth heating pad thing in the hallway closet. If you put it in the microwave for like twenty seconds, it really smells like lavender. It always made me think of mom. Maybe it'll do the same for you."

Rio wanted to melt.

She wanted to positively turn into a giant puddle on Nicky's couch at the helpful tip.

It was so earnest, so wholesome, so sweet.

What it said to Rio that she was sure he did not want his mother to hear was that even though he had put distance between them for years, there had still been the smallest ways for him to hold onto pieces and parts of her.

In that moment, Rio was especially thankful that Nicky had offered her his apartment, his home, the deepest parts of himself. No hotel in Dubai was going to have a warm bean-bag that smelled like Agatha. No, the only place in Dubai that would was already surrounding her with its orange walls, muted by the outside darkness, and its halfway homely decor. While it was clear that Nicky had been raised in part by Agatha -- in that he had her eye for design and aesthetics -- it was also painfully apparent that he was still a twenty year old man in his tastes.

Rio wouldn't hold it against him in the same way she had never held Estee's own interests against her, no matter how weird they could sometimes be (like the time she spent two months in grade seven dissecting dead bugs she found; she'd never kill them, but she had always been curious what was inside).

How could she ever holdanythingagainst him when he had that adorable look on his face like he had just told her the most important secret in the world?

"Thank you, Nicky. I think I'll have to go grab it before I lay down." Rio's voice was just as soft, clearly wanted to keep to the low-key vibe he tried to set. He didn't want to expose himself as being so attached, but at the same time, his desire to make things easier on Rio seemed to matter to him a little more.

"Goodnight, mama," he told her with a smile before handing the phone over to Agatha.

"And what was that all about?" Agatha posed, glancing from the phone to her son and back, an eyebrow raised in curiosity.

"Nothing!" Nicky attempted before Rio could get a word out edgewise.

"Just some helpful tips and tricks about existing in Dubai, that's all." Rio couldn't see him, but she was quite sure that if Nicky heard her, he relaxed. She loved him and because he had made a show of trying to be discreet, she would honor his wishes to keep some things a little more under wraps.

"Anything that will help you sleep?" Agatha teased, wrinkling her nose in jest.

"Yeah, actually. Gonna work on that after I move my things into the guest room. Also, tell Nicky I love the lights around the television. "I reallyshouldgo to bed. But... What I wouldn't give to be sharing in a lazy Sunday with you lot." Rio's voice was warm, but the soft expression that found her was very plainly indicative of just how much she was already missing her wife and their children.

"Four days, my love," Agatha soothed, reaching up to slide her glasses atop her head so she could bring the phone closer. "Four days and I will see you in New York. And then, two more and you get to come home for real."

Agatha said it was like a promise and while Rio knew it was, it still felt like an eternity existed in the distance between them. Agatha said four days and then two factually in the sense that it was really less than a week, but it felt so much longer. It felt like endless meetings and flights and texting her son for all of the go-to places to grab a bit or keep herself busy.

Maybe that was what it would end up being, but it would also be worth it.

They didn't need the money that would come from the transaction of finding a suitable corporation to mass produce and deploy Rio's pollinator drones, but they all knew without a shadow of a doubt that it was about the accomplishment more than it was the money.

Even so, there were still considerations to be made; someone could offer Rio ten million over asking and it wouldn't have mattered if they didn't agree to the clause about not utilizing her utility or coding for anything other than its given purpose. They were meant to foster life in lieu of a substantial bee population, not destroy it by being turned into a weapon. Rioknewhow the world worked and it was why, come hell or high water, she would find a home for her labor of love that would use it properly.

Rio might not change the world with her 'robot bees,' but she just might change apartof it yet.

"Okay, okay," she finally conceded with a sigh, slouching into the couch. "I will sleep. But have a margarita or something for me."

"Will do, my love," Agatha consoled. She knew that it wasn't enough, but the promise was yet another thing to hold onto, a guarantee that even while she could not physically be there, her presence was still felt amongst her loved ones.

"Goodnight, my wife. I love you," Rio murmured, puckering her lips in a kiss she could not deliver, no matter how badly she wanted to.

"Sleep well, baby. I love you too."

Rio didn't want to hang up.

Neither did Agatha.

It did not go unnoticed.

"Get some sleep, mama!" came a rigid demand from her daughter, faceless in the background behind Agatha.

"Alright, fine," Rio conceded for a final time. "Goodnight to all of my loves. I will speak with you soon."

That time, Riodidhang up. It was the last thing in the world she wanted to do.

The first thing was to get right back on a plane and fly home to revel in the snuggles and laughter and jokes of her family.

But first, there was business to attend to.

Only after she warmed up NIcky's little sloth and clutched it to her chest until she fell asleep, the scent of Agatha filling her nose.

Monday was as long as Rio had predicted it might be, both meetings taking up a cumulative five and a half hours of her time. The second one, she'd left mad as fuck with her lawyer -- a sweet woman named Kendra -- hot on her heels.

"No!" she shouted, spinning on the woman who had been chasing after her. "An extra eighty million doesn't fucking matter if the plan is to bomb cities, schools, hospitals. I told you coming into this that I would absolutelynotbend to the will of the war machine! I won't do it, Kendra!"

Poor Kendra.

She was one hell of a lawyer and despite her profession, she was rather kind. However, right then, she was seeing a fury that few people had ever had the misfortune of witnessing before. While perhaps unwarranted, as Rio was practically seething in her anger, the woman was coming to understand a very important part of who Rio was.

She was a healer, a compassionate soul, someone who wanted to try so fucking hard to make the world a better place. Maybe the drones did not work the way she had hoped, maybe her whole mission ended up failing. That could happen because such was life, but at least they would fail at the purpose they were intended for and not turned into weapons of unnecessary distruction.

"I understand your frustrations, Mrs. Harkness-Vidal, but..." Kendra kept talking, but Rio stopped listening.

She couldn't hear her because she just heard those three words over and over again in a way that slowed her wildly beating heart and dulled the sound of her pulse in her ears:Mrs. Harkness-Vidal. Mrs. Harkness-Vidal. Mrs. Harkness-Vidal.

That was who she was. She was Rio Harkness-Vidal and in no world was she ever going to let any man try to run her over in a boardroom. She was the wife of Professional Hardass Agatha Harkness-Vidal and as such, she had a reputation to uphold, one where she took no shit and left absolutely nothing left unsaid.

Granted, calling the CEO of a weapons company a 'grubby-pawed dropnuts' who was 'only concerned with lining his own pockets' was probably not the best idea Rio had ever had, it felt fitting in the moment. But, she hadn't left it unsaid. There was that, at least.

"I'm not saying you have to apologize, but moving forward, probably best to not insult them. Although, I admit, 'dropnuts' is a new one for me. Is that from where you lived?" Rio finally tuned in long enough to register the tail end of Kendra's speech, a small smile tugging on her lips as she posed her question.

"It used to be my daughter's favorite insult when she was younger. Guess it stuck with me."

"Tell her thanks on my behalf. That'll have me chuckling for days." The woman reached up, pulling her bright red and so-curly-it-was-almost frizzy hair over her shoulders, dark blue eyes sparkling in the evening sun. They were a pretty shade, but Agatha's were far prettier.

Oh, she missed those deep blues so very much.

"Get some rest tonight. We only have an afternoon interview tomorrow, so try to sleep in if you can. Maybe get in some family time. Agatha would have me fired in a heartbeat if I did not harp on family at least once this trip," she half-joked with a bright laugh.

Rio offered her hand, giving a firm shake of the other woman's when she met the wordless request. "Thank you, Kendra. And I will try my hardest not to lose my temper. But maybe we preface any talks with what I am not willing to waffle on. That way we can prevent any sneaky tactics and surprise guests."

Kendra gave a nod of understanding; the company had not been on the roster for the meeting and still somehow had managed to sneak in. Hopefully, Rio's little tirade might have gained her a bit more credibility than she'd already had.

She was a woman who knew what she wanted and was unwilling to settle for less.

She reallyhadbecome a Harkness-Vidal, hadn't she?

That night after a meal alone and a glass of wine, Rio made her way back to Nicky's to tuck herself into that big bed in his guest room, settling for text message windows for her loved ones who were occupied by the business of their days. Agatha was at work, Nicky had left for Auckland and the girls had decided to hit the city to window shop for potential wedding dresses.

They were all living life to its fullest extent and there Rio was, in bed alone on the other side of the world.

She missed her family.

Of course she had known what it was to miss Estee when she was away at school, or even when Rio had flown to America, but this was a new kind of longing that made her chest feel hollow.

She missed her wife and the early morning giggles they so often shared in.

She missed her girls and their raucous laughter at the stupidest things.

She missed her son and his awful jokes, as well as his boyfriend and the serenity he brought to their little troupe.

Rio just missed her life. Their life.

When she woke the next morning, it was to discover that she had slept in past ten in the morning and the bright light of the late morning sun poured in from the windows across the room.

That meant it was still the day before in LA. Maybe everyone was still awake. If not everyone, maybeAgathawas still awake.

Quickly, Rio cycled through the routine of peeing, brushing her teeth, and brushing her hair before she climbed back into bed and grabbed for her phone. She punched in Agatha's contact, still grinning from the sight of her phone wallpaper when the call connected.

At first, it was a black screen.

And then, all she saw were big green eyes, that cute little button nose, and a massive grin.

"Hi mama," Estee greeted, angling the camera to face up her nostril. It had Rio laughing instantly.

"Hola, mija. And what might you be doing with Agatha's phone?" Rio managed, finally surpressing some of the laughter that had taken over her.

In response, Estee extended her arms, giving a fuller view of the room she was occupying -- Agatha and Rio's bedroom. There, on the bed with her, were Agatha and Tay.

"We are watching a movie!" came a bright call from the left of Estee, Tay laughing as only half of her face occupied the frame.

"Oh, is that so?" Rio questioned, her gaze sweeping to the other side to behold her wife, leaning into frame with a massive and thrilled smile on her face.

It was clear that although Rio could not be there, Agatha was still finding a way to keep her around. It was also clear that the girls had absolutely zero qualms about keeping their mum company.

"The girls told me I had to watch 'Death Proof.' By rule of thumb I don't like to watch Q's films, but they were pretty insistent. Have to say, I get it now." Rio could tell that Agatha was being honest, but if she were telling the truth, Rio did not have a single clue what it was they were talking about.

"And are you all having a good night?" Rio questioned softly, trying to hide the emotion that wanted to write itself so blatantly over her face.

The truth was, seeing the three women she loved most in her life all sharing close space while they enjoyed in something as simple as a film together truly touched Rio everywhere that it mattered. It softened her, made her feel as though the people she cared about most in the world were truly invested in taking care of one another.

The phone shifted, the lens shaking a bit as Estee handed the phone to Agatha and snuggled into her side, leaving her forehead and eyebrows in frame.

"We are. But we definitely wish you were here. The movie, while not your typical bag, is actually really good and Estee got really excited over someone named --"

"Zo Bell! She's in it, mama!" Estee chimed in, leaving Agatha grinning at having her sentence finished by someone that was not Rio.

"Ah, yes," Rio agreed with a nod. "Might not watch a lot of films, but everyone back home knows of the fearlessZo Bell."

Agatha chuckled, giving a nod of her own. "I was informed she did all of the stunts herself. Which... Given what I know for my career is actually crazy work, but... We all make a buck somehow." As if she had suddenly realized the time, Agatha's brow pulled together in confusion, her head tipping in question. "Don't you have a meeting today?"

Rio stretched, yawning at the same time before she offered an easy answer. "Yes." A warm smile tugged on her lips. "But not until later. Kendra told me to use the extra time for family. So please don't get her fired."

A hearty laugh left Agatha as she tipped her head against the headboard in her humor. When she lowered it and their gazes locked, they were mirror images of silly grins.

"As long as she's being good to you and for you right now, she can keep her job."

For as light-hearted as it was, Rio knew Agatha was serious. As long as Rio was taken care of when Agatha couldn't be around to do it herself, that was all she cared about.

Rio fell quiet for a moment, just watching as Agatha watched her. She wanted to kiss her, to hug her, to fall asleep against her chest. She was only two days away from that happening in some ritzy hotel room in NYC, but right then, she ached for it.

"I should let you lot finish your film," Rio offered softly; sure, she'd gotten up with enough time to catch them before they ended their day, but she also did not want to intrude on what was clearly a bonding moment.

"You sure?" Agatha asked, her lips turning down slightly at the corners. She didn't look disappointed, exactly, but she also didn't seem all that eager to hop off the phone, movie or no movie.

"Yes, baby. I don't have to leave for another couple of hours. If you're still up after or can't sleep, you can call." It was soft, but it was sincere. While Riodidwant her loved ones to revel in their time with one another, she was never going to turn down more time to speak with Agatha, so long as Agatha had the time to give.

Agatha's lips twisted in her uncertainty, but the way Rio's features softened seemed to win her over a little more. "Okay, okay. You're sure I can call when we're done?"

"Positive, my love."

"Alright, then I'll talk to you soon, hm?" The way Agatha's eyes shone in the light of the television struck Rio directly in her chest, causing a yearning that felt almost painful to overtake her.

"Soon. I love you, Agatha."

"I love you too, Rio."

"FOUR MORE DAYS, MAMA!"

At that, Rio found laughter again. Goddamnit if she hadn't raised one funny fucking kid. Leave it to Estee to diffuse the somber mood by being loud and helpful in her reminder.

"Four days, mija. Four more days. Goodnight my loves, get some sleep."

"Goodnight mama!"
"Goodnight mama!"
"Talk soon, baby."

It was a clashing of pitches and sounds, but it made Rio grin all the same. It was a grin she still wore even as the call disconnected and she sank back into the mattress below her, staring up at the ceiling.

Life might never be perfect, and being away from home certainly was not, but no matter how far away she was, as long as Rio Harkness-Vidal had her family, it was all she would ever need.

Chapter End Notes

hi! it's been a while!
thanks for the patience.
hopefully this was worth the wait.
and also hopefully i don't take nearly as long with the next one lmao

Wildfire

Rio had known she missed her wife.

Rio had known she missed her kids.

What Rio had not known was how much more she was going to miss them after that phone call. She hadn't been expecting the girls to be present when she had called, but seeing the three of them together all bunched up in that big bed had dealt Rio a case of homesickness that she never had experienced before.

Maybe that was only because Rio had never had a home that felt like the one she shared with her family. It wasn't the house, it wasn't LA itself. It was the space that her loved ones occupied at any given moment. That was her home, where she belonged.

In Dubai, she was still wrapped in the warmth and comfort of familiarity in every bit of Nicky around her, but it wasn't the same as physically being wrapped in it when the five people she cared about most surrounded her and wrapped their arms around her, much like they had on her birthday.

The hour of the morning was suddenly no longer on Rio's mind; all she wanted to do was climb on a plane and jet back to where she was wanted most.

But no. She couldn't. She had business to attend to.

...in a couple of hours.

The idea of finding something to do with that amount of time left her feeling restless; Agatha had said she might call, but it was exceptionally late on the west coast of America and if she would have preferred to sleep and ready for the next day, Rio would wholeheartedly support that decision.

Agatha was a busy woman, a powerful woman, and while they were still in the beginning stages of planning her next project, she still had things to do and places to be.

She didn't need to stay up until one in the morning just to make Rio feel a little less lonely.

She didn'tneedto, but about twenty minutes after Rio hung up the phone, it rang again and a photo of the two of them kissing filled the screen. The text overlay of 'My Wife' appeared at the top and Rio grinned.

For as much as she told herself that it would be fine if Agatha chose to go to bed, the way her heart picked up in her chest indicated just how much she'd been lying to herself.

With a snappy swipe of her thumb, Rio answered the call, practically beaming in the morning light that shone in through the windows of Nicky's guestroom.

"Hi," she greeted brightly, even if the volume of her voice was still low for no other reason than the tenderness she felt warming the center of her chest. "I thought you might go to sleep."

As Agatha adjusted the phone, the image of her soaked in the dim light of the table lamp finally coming into clear focus, Rio noticed something.

Agatha was no longer wearing the shirt she had on when she'd been watching movies with the girls. They frequently slept naked, even when sex wasn't involved, but the sudden idea that Agatha was laying in their bed -- and from the reversed frame and angle of the light, it was apparent she was onRio'sside -- naked sparked something low in Rio's belly.

It was a conflicting feeling; she was turned on by the mere thought, but frustration immediately followed over the fact she couldn't be there. Shewantedto be there. She wanted to completely dissipate into atoms and rematerialize in that big fucking bed right next to her wife.

This was what co-dependency felt like, wasn't it?

Rio was only human and while she knew that she would be perfectly fine for just the couple more days until she got to see Agatha again, she hated waiting. She hated screens and microphones and everything else between her skin pressed to Agatha's.

She just wanted to go home.

"Hi, my love," Agatha returned through a yawn, clearly showing she was, indeed, tired.

"Why are you calling me instead of sleeping?" Rio asked softly, feeling the need to dial back on the excitement she felt at getting to have just a couple more minutes of Agatha's time.

It wouldn't be her arms wound around Rio's body, or her hands on Rio's skin, but seeing those pink cheeks and that sleepy smile and those bleary but tired eyes... It was enough for the time being.

Agatha could have givenanyanswer in the world, but she went with the one that intensified Rio's homesickness even more.

"Because I miss you."

Rio wanted to melt. She also wanted to cry. She knew that occasional distance and independence were important parts of any relationship, but she had not expected just how much of a shock to the system it was going to be to find herself alone on the other side of the world from her wife.

"I know the feeling," she murmured, drawing in a slow breath to try and find some sense.

Was it difficult? Yes, way more than she thought it would be. But. She knew it wasn't forever. There was a finish line, one to cross that would leave her clinging to Agatha for days to come. Any meetings she had in New York? She'd be wrapped around that woman like a damn sloth, answering questions from her shoulder and squeezing her when she needed someone to yell a bit louder and be a little more intimidating than she felt herself capable of being.

She had learned the day before that she had to tap into Agatha's fire to get men to take her seriously. It had worked, but having Agatha nearby would make it a lot easier.

"I wish I was there."

It was an honest statement, but Rio couldhearjust how much Agatha meant it.

"I wish you were here too. I hate not falling asleep next to you." It was probably a pathetic admission and Rioknewthat they needed their independence, but missing Agatha was for the birds, she had since decided.

"Probably almost as much as I hate not being able to touch you." It was truthful, but there was the tiniest smile on Agatha's lips that insinuated it was a double entendre.

"You mean that in more ways than one, don't you?" Rio questioned, the softest laugh hitching to the end of her words.

"Of course I do," Agatha returned, that smile on her face growing even wider.

"Why don't you elaborate on that... You know, for the fans... Er, fan of the idea."

Rio knew what she was doing. She knew she had less than an hour and a half before she had to be dressed and out the door to meet Kendra, but... If she got to spend a little time on the phone with her wife before then while they talked about all of the ways they would be touching each other if sharing space? Was it really the worst thing in the world?

No, it was not, and she was going to indulge simply because she could.

After all, hadn't Kendall encouraged her to have some family time?

Getting sensual with her wife while over video chat was probably not the thing she had in mind, but Rio didn't care. Being away from Agatha was hard. In fact, it waswayharder than the first time, when Agatha needed to leave to deal with her mother (God unrest her soul) and Rio felt it more and more as her time away wore on.

"Well..." Agatha hummed in response, the most charming smile sweeping across her lips. "If you were here, you'd be laying on your side probably. And I, of course, would be behind you. But..." Agatha's eyes flickered with the softest light as she considered where to truly begin. "I'd have my hand on your hip, doing that thing where I lightly rub it when you know I want to just touch your skin."

Rio's eyes slipped shut for just a moment, allowing her to visualize and try to feel in her imagination what Agatha was describing. She could almost swear she did, the way Agatha's prodding yet tender fingers would knead her flesh and the way her palm would smooth over it, just feeling her out.

"Youdodo that a lot," Rio giggled, opening her eyes. Her wife was looking at her like she were a bright light and she was doing nothing other than basking in it.

"It's because it's really soft," Agatha informed her knowingly, that smile hitching up just a little more. "And the skin on your thighs, which I always touch next, is just as soft if not softer. And while I trace lines there, I'd press my lips to the back of your neck."

Rio almost felt like she was there, like hearing Agatha say those words was enough to make them true. It wasalmostenough to make her forget that they were laying in beds on opposite sides of the world, if only for a few minutes.

"I like it when you do that," Rio told her softy. Beyond the scope of the camera, her hand had started to move, lazy fingers tracing light paths over a thigh that was raised, bent at the knee. Maybe Agatha was only talking her through a reality they could not have, but Rio was in possession of a hand, one that could touch in place of her wife's.

"Tell me more."

The softest sigh passed through Agatha's lips, leaving them to twitch slightly in thought. That glimmer was in her eyes again and it was clear the more doors Rio opened, the quicker she ran through them.

"I would be leaving kisses on the back of your neck as my hand moves up to trace over your stomach. Ireallylike feeling out your abs." There was a lightness to her words, one that caused Rio's eyes to slide shut as her own fingers mimicked the action, the tips tracing through the gentle valleys of skin and muscle.

"Mmm, yeah?" Rio cooed, forcing her eyes open once more to look directly into Agatha's on that screen.

"Yeah," Agatha replied, her breath catching in the middle of the word. "And then, I'd scoot back so you could lay on your back and I could kiss your neck,justthe way I know you like it."

Her voice was so calm, like they weren't having that conversation of all conversations to be had, but her eyes were wildly dancing with both amusement and arousal.

"I'd lay up against you, my palm on your stomach until it slides up," she ventured, leading Rio to follow suit as her hand skimmed up her chest. "And then I'd take your chest in my hand, squeezing in the way that makes your back arch."

Although Agatha had not been able to see exactly what Rio was doing, the moment Rio's hand found her own breast and gave a weighted squeeze, her back arched and she camera jostled enough to finally give her away.

"Oh."

It was so impossibly soft, but it slipped out as Agatha's jaw faltered and dropped the tiniest bit.

"Oh, my innocent wife," Rio breathed, a light smirk filling her face as she settled against the bed once more. "Did you think I was only going to settle for hearing you talk about it?"

"Well, no," Agatha countered immediately, though the way she licked her lips signified that her mouth had dried out with a quickness. "Butfuckif I don't wish it were my hands instead of yours."

She had a point. It was a point Rio could empathize with.

There was not a thing in the world -- aside from their children -- that Rio would not have given up if it meant that she could be back in bed, naked, with her wife as another day drew to a close.

But Rio's day was just beginning.

And what a beginning it was proving to be.

"You and me both, my love," Rio assured her softly, voice just loud enough to carry to the mic. Licking her own lips -- and again wishing they were Agatha's -- Rio snuggled a little deeper into the bed. "So please, keep going so we can pretend."

Imagination could be a beautiful thing, and right then, it was tying the two of them together, keeping them as close as they could be with an insurmountable amount of distance still between them. An ocean could separate them physically, but they were always with one another, carried in the smallest ways.

For both of them, it was the little origami flowers that were inked onto their skin. In addition, for Agatha, it was that tiny little boat behind her ear. For Rio, it was a written reminder from her wife of who she could be and who they were as a married couple.

They had once separately imagined a life where Agatha hadn't left before telling Rio her name, and vice versa but now, they were imaging what it was like to never have distance between them again. It was a fantasy, yes, but it was what was going to get them through the hours and days of being alone. Because they weren't ever actuallyalone, not really.

Agatha was grinning again, eyes full of joy and mischief at Rio's encouragement.

"I'd drag my nails down your side --"

"I'm not doing that!" Rio responded immediately, fighting her laughter. "You know it tickles!"

"Aw, you're ruining my fun," Agatha returned in a pout, her bottom lip sticking out in a way that showcased her flair for the dramatic. "Just once?! I wanna hear you laugh like that."

Rio fought not to roll her eyes; she could tell what Agatha was doing, but there was something she seemed to be forgetting.

"My love, I can not genuinely tickle myself."

Oh, wait.

Rio's lips pressed and she heaved a defeated sigh at the exact same time a giant grin plastered itself to Agatha's face.

That was exactly what Agatha had hoped she might say.

"Exactly, so you should be able to comply with no issue." She sounded so impossibly arrogant, but the way those lights were shimmering in her eyes, Rio knew she was just excited and in that excitement, she wanted to have all the fun she could, given where they found themselves.

The world would be damned if Rio didn't love her even more for it.

"Okay, okay. You win." This time, the fight was to notcloseher eyes as she adjusted to run the tips of her nails up her own side. An odd feeling filled her; Agatha had committed to such an action too many times to count and every single time, Rio had never been able to refrain from laughing. Yet, under Agatha's instruction, looking directly into her eyes on that phone screen, two parts of Rio's brain tried to reconcile themselves, melting into one another.

This time, the immediate reaction was goosebumps and the softest moan that Rio did not try to withhold, knowing Agatha would have only encouraged her to not hold back if she did.

This was what itcouldfeel like to have Agatha touch her there, if only her brain could mimic the response she was experiencing right then. It was Agatha, but it wasn't. Agatha wasn't there, Rio was carrying out her desires, but in some tiny little corner of Rio's mind, Agathawasthere.

It was a ridiculous line of logic and yet, Rio felt it in her chest.

She tried, really tried, to keep her eyes open, but it felt so damn good that the ability escaped her, lids sliding down as her breath caught in her chest.

"Then," Agatha voiced, tight and the slightest bit worked up, "I would drag my middle two fingers over the haunch of your hip, making sure to trace the outline of your tattoo before making my way to the inside of your thigh."

Rio didn't need to be looking at the damn phone right then tohearjust how fucking badly Agatha wanted to be there. She wanted to be the one following this little to-do list, but Rio continued to find both joy and relief in the act of providing it herself.

Her two middle fingers did as instructed, tracing over her tattoo and the curve of her hip, reaching the crease of her thigh -- barely grazing a few strands of coarse hair on the way -- and sliding down further to meet the inside of her leg, a soft sigh passing through barely parted lips. For as much as she couldn't have what it was she wanted, this was appearing to be a somewhat suitable substitute.

Okay, it was more than 'somewhat suitable.'

But it still wasn't the real thing.

When Agatha spoke, Rio wasn't sure it actually mattered quite as much as she thought it did.

"I would run --fuck-- my fingers --"

Rio's eyes flew open as something struck her; her lips pursed and a knowing look filled her face, a brow cocking in interrogation. Truthfully, she was trying to distract herself from the way her fingers were stalled only an inch away from the absolutely throbbing warmth between her legs. She knew without even touching herself that she waswetat listening to Agatha talk her through it.

"Did you start before me?!" Rio posed before Agatha could hide the guilty look in her eyes.

The sheepish smile she bore in the next sake reminded Rio very quickly that she did not actually care.

In fact, that was really fucking hot.

Her wife, in their bed, so fucking turned on by Rio's display of needy compliance that she simply couldn't keep herself from indulging at the mere idea.

Because she couldn't actuallyseewhat Rio was doing. She stillknew.

With an agreeable smirk, Rio requested a little more than that. "And how should I do that?" she asked lowly, bright green eyes flashing with the whitest spark of lightning. When It's Just Us

*****

By the time Thursday afternoon rolled around and Rio set foot on a plane destined for JFK, progress had been made.

As a result of the six meetings she'd had over the course of the week, the pool for potential buyers sat at three. It was half of who she had sat down with, but she still had her reserves in who she was considering selling to. It was such a comprehensive decision to be made and even after meeting with company after company, there were still two to be heard out.

Those would happen in New York, late on a Friday afternoon.

More importantly, those meetings would only happen once Rio saw her wife first.

Staying in Dubai had been a complex experience; being so close to Nicky's presence had definitely helped and Rioknewit was good to have a little time to herself, but missing her family had been an entirely new ache that Rio never could have prepared herself for. She had known it would be tough, but not having an arm around her after a long and frustrating day offered a new perspective she had not known was possible.

For as much as Rio ached to not be in the presence of her loved ones physically, she was warmed every single time she realized they were with her anyway. They were with her in text messages and phone calls. They were with her on FaceTime and voice notes.

Getting a text from Estee Wednesday had really driven the point home.

"She doesn't even leave until tomorrow and she's already climbing the walls. She can't wait to see you."

It wasn't lengthy or wordy, but it was the loudest display of who they were as a family and what they meant to one another. There she was, an ocean away on a weeknight while her wife was climbing the walls in the morning hours of the same day at the mere thought of their reunion.

And there their daughters sat, soothing her, calming her, promising it would all be worth it.

Rio had seen it with her own eyes the several times they'd been on video call; even if the kids weren't with her at first, the moment any of them heard her talking, they popped in to say their hellos and remind Rio they could not wait for her homecoming. None of them more than Agatha, maybe, but the sentimentality of it all meant the world to her.

It had almost been a year since the day Agatha had fallen into her life and the lives of the girls. Only a year.

As Rio climbed onto the plane that would carry her a little closer to home, the idea that such an occasion was worth celebrating struck her. As such, the moment they were in the air, she was doing her research.

Shehadseen Agatha again, but only because she had given chase.

Now, almost an entire year later, they were married and as in live as they had ever been. Rio felt that was something that deserved to be honored with celebration.

Family would always mean everything to Rio but for a week, she just wanted the time and space to worship the woman she loved most in the world.

She was fully aware that it was only reminiscent of the day they met, but wasn't it the most important day for them? Sure, meeting in LA and even confessing feelings mere days later were monumental, but none ofthosedays would have ever happened if Agatha had never fallen off that bridge.

Agatha had fallen into her lap and her lifenevercould have been the same.

Estee had parents, ones that were thrilled for the lifeshewanted to build with the woman she loved. She had two figures in her life that would have done anything for her happiness, something she had never really had before. Yes, Rio had loved her more than enough for two people, but actually having Agatha fill that role for her clearly meant the world to everyone involved.

Rio had courage. It wasn't that she had been weak or a coward before, but Rio had learned even more how to hold her own with Agatha's staunch and fierce presence to draw from. That much had become prevalent over those few days in Dubai; Rio had never once accepted an answer she didn't like and she didn't hesitate to state why. She didn't care who might not like or thoughts or feelings, not when this project had taken up so much of her life.

More than anything else, though, she felt... stable. Agatha's chaos had come into their lives and yet, all that was left in the wake was nothing but calmness and peace.

Sometimes, it didn't make sense. Others, it made every bit of sense there was to be made.

That was the beauty of their love and their lives; one thing was neverjustone thing. What was scary could be beautiful. What was maddening could be a lesson. What was heartbreaking could be enabling toward any form of growth.

The six of them, at the end of the day, were still human and life would always happen without permission, but having one another to lean on would surely get them through it.
