"Mmmm, good morning beautiful," Rio cooed softly as she rolled over in place so she could take in every bit of radiance that was the woman she loved. "I missed waking up to your kisses."

It was soft, but it was genuine in its sweetness. Rio had missed her family dearly, but she had gone months without Estee before; that was light work at that point. Spending so long away from Agatha for the first time had beentorture.She knew it was inevitable, knew it was something that would happen again and again in their futures, but Rio had already made the decision that she hated it.

She was happiest when Agatha was right next to her, or right in front of her. Or beneath her. But that was reserved for a Friday morning when theyweren'tin New York and she did not have an 11 am meeting ahead of her.

It was a meeting where her wife would get to sit in to watch and listen as Rio handled her business with a cunning outlook and a vast bravery that came from knowing just what she had come to create. Her technology was revolutionary, that was nothing more than fact. What it meant for her, however, was that a variety of organizations were going to be chomping at the bit to get their hands on it, as she learned over the course of the last business week.

It was up to her to determine who was worthy, who would utilize it appropriately, and who wouldnotturn them into weapons of war.

Rio's bees were her pride and joy, second only to her family. What happened to them mattered to her; letting them go was only worth it if they were used to reignite a spark of life in the world, one that could severely slow the decline they were seeing. It was why she'd committed herself to the several days away from her wife and the entire week away from her children.

Those bees meant the world to her and she needed to ensure they were treated properly.

It might have seemed silly to anyone else, anyone who didn't know Rio, but her family got it, Estee especially.

She'd been there for the late nights and early mornings of Rio clacking away at her keyboard. She'd been there for the highs of coding going right and the lows of it going very, very wrong. She was the one on the other end of the line at 3 am when Rio was up on too many espresso shots and made a breakthrough.

Estee had witnessed it all... Almost.

What Estee had not been there to behold, Agatha had.

It was Agatha who encouraged her and pushed her and motivated her in the very last stretch. It was Agatha that was the one asleep on the couch when Rio burst into tears over finally havingeverythingright. It was Agatha that was the one to hold her and kiss her and tell her how proud she was.

Her daughter and her wife, the witnesses to her biggest accomplishments.

While she could not have Estee there in New York, she had Agatha and that wasalmostthe same thing, at least when it came to feeling supported.

"Do you want breakfast before your meeting or can we lay like this a little longer instead?" Agatha asked her, leaning in for the lightest of kisses.

"If I eat, I fear I might throw up. For that to happen in my absolute last meeting of the week would be... unfortunate."

Agatha's laughter sounded immediately, but she stole another kiss anyway. "My love, you could have just said 'let's stay in bed.' But thanks for the mental image and the laugh."

"Well!" Rio cried softly, pressing her face into Agatha's neck. "No one wants to throw up in front of their crush."

"Rio," Agatha shot back, falling prey to giggles again. "I'm your wife. I've seen you get sick before. Doing so on a bunch of snobby old white men would not deter me from loving you." Despite the insane nature of the conversation being had, it was actually kind of sweet.

Although, this meeting wasnotwith a bunch of snobby old white men andthatwas why Rio didnotwant to fuck it up.

In fact, it was with a Swedish techno-development team that was composed of some of the greatest scientific minds of their time. If her life's work was going to go somewhere,thatwas where Rio wanted it to go. She spent hours on end the week before vetting their company thoroughly -- although she was alreadyveryaware of their prestigious reputation -- and knew of every meeting she had booked,thatwas theonlyone sheneededto go smoothly.

"This is a big one," Rio whined lightly into her skin. "I don't want to muck it up."

Agatha's arm wrapped around her and pulled her close, holding her tightly. Her head turned and her lips landed somewhere in Rio's hair, pressing a loving kiss there.

"You're going to walk in there and you're going to sell this to them like their lives depend on taking it up. And you're going to absolutely crush it."

With those words ringing in her ears all morning, that wasexactlywhat Rio did.

Kendra collected both of them -- Agatha in a loose lavender blouse and form-fitting jeans and Rio in a business casual charcoal grey suit -- and prepped Rio on the way, but she hadn't really needed it.

All Rio needed was what Agatha said to her in their big bed in that big suite in that extravagant hotel.

It was more than enough fuel to rocket her forward, she thought.

She had been right.

Rio pitched her plan to a room full of brilliant and talented minds with an air of undeniable confidence, pacing the width of the table as she indicated slides and projections. It was a floorplan she'd gone over in her head a million times because of nerves and yet, delivering it to that table filled with men and women alike was the easiest thing in the world. She was proud, she was confident, and she was convinced that of all the moves to be made, this was the best one.

Agatha sat quietly behind her, just watching as she moved with grace and talked with her hands, her tone animated and bright. She was like a machine, hitting every single point she needed to and doing so with a lively flair that held everyone's interest.

"This isn't me standing here before you telling you that it's necessary you invest in some godawful and easily sellable QVC item, and we all know that. This is important, itmatters."

She took a breath, her eyes scanning from one face to the next while she debated her phrasing.

"This is life that cannot die. They're non-organic, they're always replaceable. No matter what happens to the units once they're out, more can be made. These drones aren't meant toreplacewhat bees we have, but to work alongside them to foster a new generation of growth."

After another fifteen minutes, Rio straightened up and waved an intentional hand toward the desk, pressing a key on her laptop.

The example drone lifted from its perch and hovered for a long few seconds before it simply... began to move. It wasn't heading anywhere in particular but was clearly searching for something it would not find in that office at a leisurely pace.

"The sensors within the drone are seeking minutely elevated pollen levels. It does not fly with intent other than to locate what it needs. There's no directive, no general push to do anything outside of... Well, pollinate."

It was truly a spectacle in the most endearing way, the way the passion simply poured out of Rio as she explained to a room full of people why those little robot bees meantso fucking muchto her and all the good they could do.

After a good ninety minutes of Rio's presentation and her answering any questions asked of her, the seven men and women rose and each offered her a firm shake of their hands and declared they would be in touch. Nothing was set in stone as the lot of them emptied out of the room, but Rio had a good feeling.

Areallygood feeling.

When she turned to her wife with an ecstatic grin on her face, she could tell Agatha had that good feeling too. She pushed to her feet and surged forward, wrapping Rio in a strong but warm embrace.

"I'm so fucking proud of you," she admitted, pulling back just enough for a kiss. "That was... Incredible to watch."

Rio could hear how much Agatha meant it and perhaps, if she was not completely wired on adrenaline, it would have made her cry. In the moment, she just breathed the softest laugh of disbelief against Agatha's lips.

"I've been doing it all week, but that felt... Different. It didn't feel like a fight. It felt..." Rio paused, her lips pressing for the briefest moment. "It felt right."

"Alright, lovebirds, sorry to break this up," Kendra cut in from the side, though it was clear by her tone that she was nervous about intruding on the moment. "But their lawyer informed me they'll be in contact no later than Tuesday with a decision. So... I just wanted to offer my farewells and..."

The woman paused for a moment, glancing at Agatha before she met Rio evenly with a sweet smile on her lips.

"It's been an honor to work with you on this. When Agatha told me you didn't have much experience in boardrooms, I was ready to help as needed but... It seems you've always had it all figured out. Pretty impressive, if I can say as much."

Truth be told, Kendra had been Rio's biggest support in all of it. She was always there to offer encouragement, to push Rio to keep going even when she was nervous. Of course the woman had been terrified of losing her job the entire time, but she never once slipped up or let Rio feel as though she was lacking a faithful believer who knew what she was capable of.

Untangling from her wife to turn to the other woman, Rio offered her arms for a warm hug. "We'll stay in touch, obviously. But thank you, Kendra. You've been vital to this all going as well as it has. Truly."

When they separated, Kendra was donning a bright grin with an appreciative gleam in her eyes. "It's been my pleasure. Now, you two go and enjoy a New York afternoon!" She turned to gather her things, but her calls were bright over her shoulder as she set off. "It's a beautiful day! I hear Central Park is a delight!"

The two of them were left laughing softly in her wake, watching as she disappeared from view, though her whistling could still be heard for a few seconds longer.

When their focus turned back to one another, there was a shine in Agatha's eyes that Rio could not quite name. Maybe it was love, maybe it was admiration or respect, but it almost felt a little more playful than that.

"What do you say we just... go for a walk? See where it takes us?" She made the offer sound so casual, but Rio thought there was more to it than that.

"Just a walk, hm? No destination in mind?"

"No," Agatha answered honestly, her eyes casting toward the window in thought. "Just... Haven't spent much time here without an agenda. Could be nice to take a look around."

Agatha was a mischievous person by nature, but something about what she was proposing seemed truly innocent.

So Rio agreed.

"You're really hard to say no to, you know that?" she posed with a quirked brow. Before Agatha gave some witty retort, Rio silenced her with a light peck and a humored smile. "Let's go."

They wandered the streets for a short while, stumbling upon a homey little cafe where they procured coffees and returned to the bustling and lively afternoon. Even in spite of all the normal-for-New-York chaos, the air that surrounded them as they walked was rather low-key and the sunglasses they both wore obscured enough of their features to not make them immediately identifiable.

However, about an hour in, Agatha saw them first.

"Paparazzi to the left," she voiced lowly, more as a warning than anything else. Rio's eyes scanned behind darkened lenses until she found the culprit in an ugly cream colored button down with a baseball cap on and a camera in his hands.

Rio knew she shouldn't.

Sheknewshould just keep walking with her hand in Agatha's and act like she hadn't spotted him.

But she had a free hand.

One that was fartooavailable to not use to flip a middle finger in the man's direction, a thousand-watt smile filling her face.

Beside her, Agatha hit the 'ah, fuck it' button at the exact same time. Hers was a little funnier given she was still clutching her coffee cup and only her middle finger lifted from it, but it was actually one paparazzi photo Rio couldn'twaitto see.

Surely, Estee would send it less than two minutes after it was posted online.

She would never admit to it, but she had a ping on the two of them, notifying her the second anything about them hit the online surface. Rio noticed it shortly after their return from Iceland, something Estee had likely done in the wake of Wyatt's little slip-up so that she would never be left uninformed again.

Giggling like teenage girls as they continued on their way, Rio couldn't have been happier.

It was so strange to compare her life to merely a year ago, but nothing about it was wrong.

In fact,everythingwas right.

She had just made the pitch of a lifetime in an attempt to distribute an ecologically revolutionary technology to one of the most powerful firms in the world. That alone was a triumph in and of itself. Then wandering around the streets of New York City hand-in-hand with her incredibly famous film director wife, flipping off paparazzi and drinking their coffee?

Rio Harkness-Vidal stayed winning, if you asked her.

It was far better than any dream her subconscious could have conjured, or any fantasy she could have wished for.

It still didn't feel real. Nor did it feel real when they ended their walk at some ridiculously pricey steakhouse where Agatha treated her to an early dinner, declaring her faith as they toasted with their full wine glasses and a soft kiss.

"To the inevitable sale of your hard work and dedication to truly making the world a better place," she declared with a smile, tipping her glass forward.

"I couldn't --"

"No, no!" Agatha argued before Rio could even finish. "You don't get the whole 'I couldn't have done it without you' bit this time. Because you could have, and you absolutelywouldhave. I'm just lucky to have been privy to the last leg of the race."

Rio was good at the whole 'not taking credit where it was due' thing, and often liked to distribute it evenly, but Agatha was making it clear that was the one time she didn't get to do it.

That project was half her life in working hours and now, it was time to finally have something to show for it. It wasn't about money -- though that was an enormous perk of the circumstance -- but was about making a difference for the planet they occupied.

Rio hadhope.

Thatwas what it was truly about.

"Alright. Well," Rio amended, green gaze dropping to her wine glass for just a moment. She was quiet in her contemplation, but those soft eyes flickered up and were caught easily in Agatha's blue ones in the very next second. "I have appreciated your endless support. And motivational speeches. And... other forms of motivation." The last admission came with a sly smirk as Rio sipped at her wine in an attempt to hide it.

"Yes, well," Agatha replied as she cleared her throat. "What can I say? I really have you figured out."

"That, my love, you do."

They spent a little longer wandering around the city after their meal, watching as it was bathed in orange and pink hues with the sun sinking in the evening sky. It was truly a remarkable sight, though nothing really compared to the view from Agatha's office building in the dead of night.

This one, for all its efforts,didcome in at a close second.

For every bit of the high she'd been riding on throughout the day, there was nothing quite so sweet as what it was like to finally return to the hotel, leaving the night air outside behind them. It was a familiar elevator ride of Agatha lightly sandwiched between Rio and the wall, their lips smacking softly with their flurry of kisses.

It was almost amusing, really, how the pair of them devolved into little more than horny teenagers the moment a set of elevator doors closed behind them. It was at least good to know some things would never change.

In that same vein, after a shower and dressing herself in a plush robe, Rio swiped her phone up off the nightstand to find seven text messages awaiting her.

All from Estee.

Mija (8:19pm):MAMA! MAMAAAAAAA! WHAT THE FUCK
Mija (8:19pm):WHY DO I HAVE THE COOLEST PARENTS EVER?
Mija (8:20pm):YOU BOTH LOOK GOOD AS HELLANDYOU'RE FLIPPING OFF THE PAPS?
Mija (8:20pm):JESUS CHRIST
Mija (8:20pm):oh my god we are FREAKING OUT
Mija (8:21pm):who looks like fucking royalty on a MID AFTERNOON WALK THROUGH NYC?
Mija (8:21pm):okay. im done now. but. this is some cool shit.

Plopping onto the bed, Rio burst into laughter, rolling her eyes at the same time she rolled into Agatha.

"What's so funny?" Agatha teased, leaning over to place a light kiss to Rio's forehead.

"Our daughter is a complete spaz," Rio informed her in a light giggle. She flipped the phone out, allowing Agatha to read through the series of texts.

Unsurprisingly, they made her laugh too.

"Do you think the day will ever come when she realizes she's now technically a member of a famous family?" she asked, nestling against Rio's side to lay her head on her shoulder.

Easily hooking an arm around Agatha, she pressed a quick kiss to the top of her head. "Probably not. But that's half the fun, isn't it? I mean, hell.Ibarely remember until you whisper in my ear that there's paparazzi across the street and we show our asses for fun."

"Davedidsend me his favorite," Agatha informed her as she turned away only enough to grab her phone for the proof. A moment later, she held it up and the mere sight caused Rio's heart to melt instantaneously.

It was one of the set from earlier that day, but instead of both of them in their crisp outfits and shades while flying the bird at full mast, they were both turned a little inward. It was obvious from their expressions that they were laughing, reveling in their brief moment of immaturity as it delighted them so thoroughly.

Alright, fine.

Dave had taste.

That was probably going to be Rio's favorite, too, no matter what the other ones looked like.

That unasked question was answered when Rio dropped her arm off to the side and logged in to tumblr, a message awaiting her from head4harkness.

head4harkness:hello! happy friday! i don't post paps pictures to the blog out of respect, but i did want to send these ones to you in case you haven't gotten them already. given you knew they were taken, clearly, it just made sense. if not, ignore this message and we will collectively pretend like i didn't embarrass myself! enjoy nyc!

Below were ten different photos, all from the same set. The one Dave liked was in there, as well as several of them in the phases of their half-assed pose. Personally, the one where Rio's tongue was out in defiance and Agatha was laughing beside her washerfavorite of the bunch despite her internal assertion only moments ago that she would likely agree with Dave.

As Rio started to bring her phone up again in order to show them to Agatha -- who was absorbed in her own phone -- she realized something rather ridiculous.

They could not keep calling this poor girl 'head4harkness.'

As funny as it was, shehadto have a real name.

rioharkness-vidal:Thank you so much for these! We had a laugh about it earlier, but they actually turned out rather cute. I am about to show them to Agatha, but... I realized I don't know your name. You don't have to tell me, obviously, but... It might be a little better than referring to you by your URL. Thank you again! Seriously!

It took one a moment for a response to appear.

head4harkness:my name is joelle, but you can call me joey. i'm off to an event for the evening, but i hope you two truly do enjoy what time you have left in the big apple! goodnight!

With a soft smile, Rio opened up the photos again and lifted her phone, giving Agatha a light squeeze to get her attention.

"Our tumblr friend sent us the whole set," Rio informed her with a quiet laugh. "Which, her name is Joey, by the way. I figured it was time to get that out of the way."

"Oh, I see. You can jerk off to her content but not know her name?" Agatha goaded, prodding a bony finger between a set of ribs.

"Hey! Her content is you! My wife!" Rio cried, feigning defense.

"Maybe you'll rub one out to these," Agatha suggested, unable to combat the laughter that attempted to break up her words. "Which, at least you know her name now. So Iguessit's okay."

Oh, how Rio loved Agatha and her stupid humor so.

As the two of them flipped through the photos together, it was little more than a surreal moment of appreciating their new life and everything it entailed. It was a life where they could gallivant around in whatever city they were in, a life where they could laugh and be their goofy and ridiculous selves, a life where they were bound to get photographed on the streets and would be splashed across the internet mere hours later.

Of course, Rio was aware of such a fact and had been since their very first lunch outing as a full family, but now it meant something else.

It meant the world got to see her with her wife.

It meant the world got to see their love, their happiness.

It meant, somewhere halfway across the planet, the man Agatha had decked in the middle of a restaurant full of people could bear witness to a woman who had survived him and come out stronger because of it. A woman who had a true family for herself and her daughter to belong in., a family that loved them, accepted them, and embraced them for all they were.

For Estee's entire life, Rio never once considered a future for them where she got the one thing she'd always deserved; another parent. It was never Rio's goal to date or try to fill in something she did not believe was vacant or empty solely for the sake of fitting into societal norms and yet, Agatha happened anyway.

Because that was what Agatha did.

She did not just come and go.

No, Agathahappened.

She was a force, a presence, and she had blown into Rio's life in a way that never could have left her the same woman after they parted. Maybe for those first couple of weeks, Rio had successfully convinced herself that she would never need to know the woman from the bridge's name, but she'd learned pretty quickly just how wrong she'd been about it.

Agathahappenedto her and she never could have been who she was before that night.

Never.

And that was exactly how she wanted it.

"I like this one the most," Agatha voiced as Rio landed on the last of the bunch.

In it, Rio was maybe two steps ahead of Agatha, their linked hands visible in the small gap. Of course with her sunglasses on, it was impossible to see what Agatha was looking at, but it was so,soeasy to just tell by the look on her face.

She was looking at her wife, the woman she loved most in all of creation, and Rio was walking in front of her, completely clueless in the moment.

"And why might that be?" Rio posed, shifting her head enough to gaze at the top of her wife's head where it rested on her chest.

"Because even though my eyes aren't visible, anyone who looks at this is going to know you're mine, and know exactly how I feel about it."

Rio didn't tear up, didn't let her eyes glass over, but hearing Agatha be so damn sentimental out loud did something to her, made her feel warm from head to toe. Sheknewhow Agatha felt about her. Hearing her be so fucking proud of it was still new, still something was taking time to get used to, but Rio never wanted her to stop.

Before she could give it much thought, Rio quickly adjusted position and flipped Agatha to her back, rolling atop her as her robe jostled loose the slightest bit. There was a playful grin twisting her lips and a tender light danced in her eyes.

"And how do you feel about it, my love?" Rio questioned gently as her head dropped for a soft kiss.

It was a kiss that had barely started by the time Agatha's arms flew up and locked around her, rolling them over on the bed. As Agatha's head lifted and she peered down at Rio, Rio was almost certain she could bask in the light of her wife's smile for so long as she lived.

"I'm not always great with words," Agatha lied, though Rio let her have it simply because she knew what was coming next. "So how about I show you?"

Beaming up at the woman she loved, Rio could have had no other answer.

"Please do."

Chapter End Notes

hello your humble writer here to thank you once more for your patience.
life is a crazy and fickle thing. be kind, pay it forward, but still be a menace to society.
thanks for coming back time and time again. these idiots shall live on forever.

edited 9/24
i don't have social media, so i figured the best place to leave this would be here. my personal life is really amping up and i've got a lot coming up the next few months so i will likely not be updating very often, if at all. i have loved writing these stories and never expected anyone to give a shit about them. it means so much to me that people have found things in them that have helped or soothed them or given them hope. this was just supposed to be a way to escape a bad living situation, but it turned into so much more. updates will come here and there, but over all, i think the hyperfixation has finally faded and there's not as much joy as there was before. i love all of you and thank you so much for your support. it means the world.

Afterword

Please drop by the Archive and comment to let the creator know if you enjoyed their work!
